Finally hit 100% on this and have seen all 20 endings. Fantastically clever and deep little game which rewards patience and planning while punishing recklessness and short-term thinking. Love it.

This is a very interesting game. The depressive world and story mixed with that intense music, a game i've never played before. It's very difficult and challenging, it requires all your concentration to not miss a tiny detail on any of the given papers; this game is for open-minded people who like very challenging, brain straining games. I really enjoyed the flow of the game, and loved the story changing characters, which appear ever so often, as well as all the other little details put in it. While intensly working on checking data from the papers, you always have to be ready for a terrorist attack or some other event which may come unexpected. I also especially like the moral choices (which do not have influence on the story), for example, will you accept the wife to get to her husband even though she doesnt't have correct data? Will you accept bribes for people with not enough money to get the needed papers? Then there are bigger decisions that may change the complete story of the game, which I will not give an example for, because they might contain big spoilers.   This game is definitely worth checking out, if you don't want to buy it, you might as well check out some videos on the web.

Papers, Please is a very strange and difficult to rate game. You are an immigration officer, charged with determining who to let into the fictional Eastern European communist country of Arstotzka. Even the genre of the game is rather hard to pin down; ultimately, the game boils down to trying to find inconsistencies in the papers, making it a puzzle game of sorts, but it somehow lends checking people’s paperwork an air of great gravity and tension, even if the actual activity itself is rather boring.  I don’t know if you can really say that Papers, Please is a fun game; there is a great feeling of tension throughout, and yet also of monotony. Somehow, you feel obligated to keep your faceless family members alive; somehow, you feel like the question of a bribe is a real one that has real weight; somehow, you feel like what you’re doing is important. And yet, ultimately, you’re just checking paperwork and determining whether or not to let people through based on the paperwork and your own feelings about the situation.  It is definitely an engaging experience, but I'm not sure if I can really say that I had fun playing it, apart from the interactions with Jorji and the tasks I did for EZIC. But I still played all the way through without putting it down.
Awesome game depicting the job of a border patrol officer while managing income.

This is the best marriage of gameplay and story. Incredibly smart concept and flawless execution. The retro-gfx serve a purpose and are not only used for style and the music sets mood perfectly. No wonder it on so many GOTY lists in 2013. Go buy it!

Once again, another staggeringly unique title is pulled out of the seemingly endless hat of indie game concepts. This time in the form of a disturbingly farmiliar dystopian society known as Arstotzka. While it may seem like the monotonous, dull drone of endlessly stamping passports; Papers, Please is a game of moral conflict. In the world of Papers, Please, you play as an unnamed protagonist, a mid level beaurocrat, working in a border checkpoint that seems like a parallel to East and West Berlin in the 80s. We can only assume these countries are roughly based on the Soviet Union or other Soviet influenced republics. The graphic style has an appropriately grey and muddled appearance that fits the situation very well. The gameplay is deliberately dull, which may be difficult for some to appreciate. As you go down the line, you begin to work in a rhythm. As you gain this rhythm you have satisfaction for catching frauds and it becomes fun in a droning, dull way. Later into the game you may look up, horrified, and realized that you have become a cog in the machine. You have begun processing people and are shocked with how you can dehumanize them in such a way. Sometimes you want to help others, but your family is still barely hovering above the poverty line. How can you keep them alive without accepting bribes or perhaps sending a poor traveller back to their home country where they will die because they do not have the correct papers? That is the beauty of Papers, Please or better yet, that is what is ugly and disgusting about Papers, Please; but we love it so.
An interesting little game that requires a keen eye. It's an old school game, so don't expect amazing graphics, but the core game play is a lot of fun.
Amazing game. Just drop everything and play it now, it's that good.

Papers, Please is definitely an addicting game. It has 20 different endings, so there is replay value. Your first playthrough will really be entirely getting used to the system and to be as quick and efficient as possible, in order to maximize how much money you make everyday. Additionally, as a Passport Control Officer, you have to make decisions which will affect your character's, and your family's lives. Whether helping take down the government by letting terrorists through, letting people take vigiliante justice, denying people entry even though they may be executed if they return to their home country, or personally killing people to provide for your family. This is not 'Passport Control Simulator.' In this game, you really have to pay attention, and it is good for your brain, because you have to juggle multiple documents at the same time and remember dates and so forth off the top of your head on the fly. Not only that, it realy makes you question what you would do in these circumstances; help others at your family's expense, or only look out for yourself. Though it will get dull rather quickly, it is definitely worth the few bucks it costs.

When I first heard about this game late last year, I thought 'how on Earth can such a game be fun?' Now that I've finally played for some hours, I have to admit my first reaction to the game idea couldn't have been much farther from the mark. The background story is quite grim, having been influenced by the not so distant history, and this brings unforeseen depth to the game. However, humor is present as well, in the myriad funny details, cultural references, and indeed, the somewhat sparse unique characters. Even the cumbersome old smuggler who kept wasting my valuable inspector-time made me smile every time he trotted in front of the desk and started rambling cheerfully. The mechanic is quite ingenious in that it forces the player to make difficult choices: for instance, is it better to buy the essential supplies that are needed for the family to survive, or upgrades to the inspector's gear that, in the long run, enable the player to gain more money with which to secure their family's well-being? Choices that at first seem good investments in the future may turn out to be little more than shortcuts to an early grave, since a certain amount of randomness in the game's events ensures that each decision the player makes is laden with uncertainty. The carefully balanced mix of random and scripted events effectively create an addictive feeling that the player's actions have real consequences for the player's character and other characters as well. Well done.
Comrade, you need to buy this game and participate to gloriousness of Arstotzka  you willl not regret.

When I first turned on Papers, Please...I wasn't sure what to expect, I hadn't watched any videos about the game or even read very much about it. It was a Humble Bundle pack-in and I thought it might be interesting.  I was absolutely right. Papers, Please is easily one of my top games of ALL TIME. The gameplay begins as simple, but gradually becomes more and more challenging as the game carries forward. Small subplots twist and turn the otherwise very straightforward storyline...  There is a good chunk of comedy relief as well (Lolibutts loves you Jorgi), and a little heartstring pulling here and there.   There are also 20 different endings. Which is pretty damn cool if you ask me. Overall, I'd say give this game a try if you're in the mood to try something 'Different'. It can get frustrating at times when the slightest detail was overlooked and costs you credits or just ups your citation count...but luckily you can always replay the day later.   Addicting, fun, and just plain original. Glory to Astolska.   9/10

There's just a rare issue with certain lines of text having a whole row of pixels chopped off, but it doesn't affect readability (if it happens on Windows too, then it's all ok). Innovative and with political jokes, this game pass the sensation that how would be like ' or was ' to work on the customs house of a country inside the 'iron curtain'. The have a well developed gameplay unlike the graphs that for being unnecessarily reduced often causes confusion. At the beginning of the game you have a low speed and limited options, however these options can be improved over the course of your career, the game also has multiple endings which makes it really challenging . The main idea of this game is simple, ' how fast is your ability to handle a huge amount of information and answer yes or no ' this idea (I believe) is innovative and beautifully crafted in this game personally believe that this game had been created during an older generation it would be considered a classic for its difficulty.  Pros : - Smart. - Creative. - Funny. - Different finals. - Challenger  Cons : - Graphics unnecessarily limited. - The library ( Book / Manual ) is unnecessarily slow. - The oscillation of your disambiguation options is irritant .  My Grade: 89/100  Inovador e com piadas de gênero político, esse jogo consegue passar a sensação de como seria 'ou era' trabalhar na alfandega de um país da 'cortina de ferro'. O jogo possui uma jogabilidade muito bem trabalhada diferentemente dos gráficos que por serem desnecessariamente reduzidos muitas vezes causa confusão. No inicio do jogo você possui uma agilidade reduzida e opções limitadas, porem estes quesitos são aprimorados ao decorrer da sua carreira, o jogo também possui diversos finais o que o torna desafiador. A principal ideia desse jogo é simples, 'o quão rápido é a sua capacidade de processar uma quantidade enorme de informações e responder sim ou não' essa ideia é (acredito ser) inovadora e muito bem trabalhada neste jogo, pessoalmente acredito que se esse jogo tivesse sido criado durante a geração mais antiga ele seria considerado um clássico pela sua dificuldade.   Pros: -Inteligente. -Criativo. -Engraçado. -Diferentes finais. -Desafiador  Contras: -Gráficos desnecessariamente limitados. -A biblioteca(Manual/ Manual) é desnecessariamente lenta. -A oscilação das sua opções de desambiguidade é irritante.  Minha nota: 89/100

In Papers, Please, you play as the newly-installed border agent for the fictional dystopian country of Arstotzka. Reviewing passports, forms, tickets, permits, scans, fingerprints, ID cards, and vaccination records against an increasingly complex and daily-changing set of rules, you are the judge of whether each newcomer is granted entry, turned away, detained, or even shot.  Sandwiched among the ordinary visitors, travelers, immigrants, asylum seekers, and diplomats, you encounter characters whose future rely on your discretion. These encounters range from the humorous to the heartwrenching, and you have to decide whether to adhere to your guidelines or your sense of right and wrong, whether you're better off taking a bribe or accepting your piecework pay. Some of these decisions have gameplay consequences, while others are merely matters of conscience. Meanwhile, your ability to pay for your family's basic needs rests upon your ability to quickly and accurately process the line of faces waiting in front of you each day. To me, these encounters and decisions were the most compelling part of the game. The player is able to make interesting and consequential choices and either advance or hinder an underground rebellion movement, as well as the lives of individual people.  Most of the time, though, you're just processing paperwork, and that's about as interesting as you would expect. The game does a good job of simulating the inanity and tedium of comparing item after item against rule after rule, checking for discrepancies; of pulling out the 'DENIED' stamp, aligning the passport under it, pressing down upon the stamp, putting the stamp away again, and handing each piece of paper back to its owner. If you like details a lot, are a bit OCD, or enjoy spot-the-difference games, this might become curiously addictive for you, but even as I compulsively continued to stamp paperwork, I experienced a nagging sense that what I was doing felt more like work than fun. I played through the story mode twice for the achievements, and although I was much better at processing the paperwork the second time around, I also found myself thinking about how many game days were still coming with an odd sense of dread. The first time around, there was at least the tension of whether I'd be able to make it through the full month and get to the end of the story (on my very first try, I reached the ending where you run out of money very early on), but on my repeat playthrough, I felt like I had to go through a great deal of tedium to reach the few meaningful encounters that I was interested in experiencing again, differently.  The game does feature several different 'endless' modes, complete with leaderboards, but I see very little incentive to play them, since for me they remove the best parts of the game and keep the most dull. But if processing an infinite line of passports holds appeal for you, that option is available.  One final note: the save system in Papers, Please is excellent. It uses a branching system that allows you to start from the beginning of any game day in any of your previous playthroughs and continue from there, making going back for achievements or to see alternate endings much easier than it might otherwise have been.  Overall, I'd recommend this game for its unique concept, quirky humor, evocative decision-making, and immersive ambience. The story is worth seeing through to a few of its 20 possible endings -- but probably not all of them. Keep in mind, however compelling this game is, it's still a simulation about paperwork.

It is a dark age of communism. Your country has just ended hostilities with its neighbor and are now allowing travel into the country. You are in control at the Berl...I mean Grestin Wall. Not by choice, but by threat of death if you are not able to provide for your family or if you even inadvertantly perform the tiniest act that may be traitorous. Slight missteps result in citations that take away what little money you are paid to support your family. Enjoy the great communist pasttime of: Food or Heat? Will your family starve or freeze? All up to you in this dystopian masterpiece that is a lot better than I have described. Yet it is exactly as I described it, but for some reason it is one of the most addictive games I've played in awhile; fair warning, it can be repetive and menial and I have some minor OCD which could be why I enjoyed it.

Allow me to explain why this is one of better games I've played in a while.  Granted the graphics don't look like much but what it lacks in Hi-res PhysX it makes up for in atmosphere, tension, gameplay and consequence, in abundance. (I rather think the graphics and audio are matched perfectly and harmonise each other well) It took me a two or three levels to fully understand how this game plays. (Essentially a spot the difference) But it is so much more than that. It places you in a dead end job with ever changing rule & regulations thrown upon you. But it thrusts completely grey area moral choices at you, interesting people and events.  It has a large amount of replayability. Truly earned it's place as one of my most favourite games.

Papers, Please is a very strange and difficult to rate game. You are an immigration officer, charged with determining who to let into the fictional Eastern European communist country of Arstotzka. Even the genre of the game is rather hard to pin down; ultimately, the game boils down to trying to find inconsistencies in the papers, making it a puzzle game of sorts, but it somehow lends checking people’s paperwork an air of great gravity and tension, even if the actual activity itself is rather boring.  I don’t know if you can really say that Papers, Please is a fun game; there is a great feeling of tension throughout, and yet also of monotony. Somehow, you feel obligated to keep your faceless family members alive; somehow, you feel like the question of a bribe is a real one that has real weight; somehow, you feel like what you’re doing is important. And yet, ultimately, you’re just checking paperwork and determining whether or not to let people through based on the paperwork and your own feelings about the situation.  It is definitely an engaging experience, but I'm not sure if I can really say that I had fun playing it, apart from the interactions with Jorji and the tasks I did for EZIC. But I still played all the way through without putting it down.

This game is fantastic.  It can be a little tedious, since you're... checking paperwork at a border checkpoint, but there's a certain something about it that makes you call 'Next!' with anticipation. You never know what the next person in line is going to do, say, want, or be.

'Papers, Please' is not easy to describe. It isn't what most people would consider a traditional game. There are no points, and winning or losing isn't as black-and-white as you may be used to. You could categorize it as a bureaucracy simulator or an everyday survival game, and that wouldn't necessarily be wrong, but it would definitely miss the point. 'Papers, Please' is — at its heart — an adventure game.  Though everything takes place from within a tiny border checkpoint, the game's drama and tension all comes from the decisions you're forced to make. You'll never feel more anxious stamping a piece of virtual paper than you will when playing this game. You will legitimately hate your supervisor, and you might even care about the people who pass through your little booth.  TL;DR: Get this game if you're looking for insightful, clever political commentary.

This is a very interesting game. The depressive world and story mixed with that intense music, a game i've never played before. It's very difficult and challenging, it requires all your concentration to not miss a tiny detail on any of the given papers; this game is for open-minded people who like very challenging, brain straining games. I really enjoyed the flow of the game, and loved the story changing characters, which appear ever so often, as well as all the other little details put in it. While intensly working on checking data from the papers, you always have to be ready for a terrorist attack or some other event which may come unexpected. I also especially like the moral choices (which do not have influence on the story), for example, will you accept the wife to get to her husband even though she doesnt't have correct data? Will you accept bribes for people with not enough money to get the needed papers? Then there are bigger decisions that may change the complete story of the game, which I will not give an example for, because they might contain big spoilers.   This game is definitely worth checking out, if you don't want to buy it, you might as well check out some videos on the web.
Finally hit 100% on this and have seen all 20 endings. Fantastically clever and deep little game which rewards patience and planning while punishing recklessness and short-term thinking. Love it.

For one month in late 1982, you are an immigration officer who must allow those with valid passports to enter, and turn away anyone with conflicting, outdated, or falsified credentials. Easy at first, but something new gets added to the mix each day during the intensifying conflict, paranoia, and border tension between two countries. Do well enough, and you might just make enough money for you and your ailing family to survive the winter...but time is short, mistakes are costly, and increasingly harrowing dilemmas will present themselves. You will likely learn something new about yourself if you make it all the way through, and it won't be a pleasant revelation.  You should play it, it's awesome.  GLORY TO ARSTOTSKA

On paper, (no pun intended), this game has a pretty boring premise. See how much mind-numbing paperwork you can process in a day to make ends meet. It sounds like a level of enjoyment that can be achieved through the use of Microsft Excel. However, clever storytelling, surprising character development and a difficulty curve that increases as the layers of beaurocracy stack up, make this game intriguing and surprisingly addictive.  It is 1982 in a fictional slice of Eastern Europe. The player becomes a border control inspector in the nightmare totalitarian state of Arstotzka, turning away impoverish families into the cold because their visas are a few weeks out of date. Or maybe you want to play the good guy and let a few desperate people slip through the net? But you also have a family to feed, and in this communist society, your salary is paid based on how many people you process correctly in a day. Too many citations and you’ll be the one left out in the cold.  The simplistic graphics of this game are more than just nostalgia. They add to the impact when something shocking and unexpected happens. Like that guy with shifty-looking eyes strutting out of the ticket booth and shouting ‘GLORY TO KOLECHIA’, shortly before blowing himself up and redecorating the wall with the innards of your security guards.  Your moral choices can alter the stormy political atmosphere, re-unite friends and lovers and deliver justice in any way you see fit. For people don't just live in the country. They ARE the country. I think my only complaint about the game is that it feels dry, sinister and clinical. I know that it was designed to be this way, but it means I can't play for any more than a few minutes before I just feel ... dirty inside ... and want to play something brighter, more colourful and happy.  Nevertheless, Papers Please gets 9/10 from me. Glory to Arstotzka, komrade.

This game is a true gem. Even though it is based off repititon, the rules and game changes every in-game day. The decision making is better than a lot of big budget games nowadays. It's so anxiety-filled and rather terrifying that it somehow wears the guise of 'fun'. But really. It's $10. It's amazing. Play it.

Lucas Pope's Paper's Please is an oddity, in that it's a 'Dystopian Document Thriller'. Reminiscent of Orwell's 1984, Papers Please takes place in Arstotzka, a fictional country that resembles an Eastern European country during the Cold War. Here in Arstotzka, you are a border checkpoint officer, looking over the passports and documents of all citizens attempting to cross into glorious Arstotzka, making sure they have all proper paperwork, whilst also making sure you family doesnt starve to death or get sick.  Whilst this seems like it would make for a boring game, Papers Please is probably one of the tensest games i've played. It riddles you with moral choices, decisions that affect your future (and that of your family), and the stress of taking care of 5/6 individuals, being paid based on your performance. You have to decide if you are going to let you're family go hungry so that you can help you co-workers, or maybe not have any heating, in exchange for letting in one too many people whose stories touched you. Maybe you'll find yourself aiding a terrorist organisation, or even a vengeful father. Or perhaps you will stay a hardworking, productive member of Arstotzka, with all which that entails.  Papers Please is an excellent game, with unique gameplay, hard moral decisions, a large amount of replayability and a fantastic audiovisual aesthetic. It is truly unique, and definitely a game that everyone needs to play.   Glory to Arstotzka!
Awesome game. I highly recomend this game to anyone who is just looking for something fun to do to pass some time.

Papers, Please is the game that made me think I'm a terrible person. This game simulates a life in a totalitarian regime where you work on the border, deciding people's lives. If you do good and let people who don't have a passport but want to go over the border continue, your pay will be deducted. If you don't have money, your family will starve, and if you don't have money to pay the bills you will be arrested. On the other hand, if you don't help the people you will feel like you are a terrible person. I made this mistake once in the game, and never again. I destroyed their regime, saved my family, but alas my son has died. I would recommend this game to everyone to check their moral codex, and especially to people in rich countries, so they can know what is like living in poverty.

Papers, Please is a punishing puzzle with an inventive story, told in a unique manner.  Hopefully that didn't scare you off. It's clear that this is an indie game; most big publishers  would  be scared off by the game's punishing yet fundamentally repetitive gameplay. However, anyone who enjoys brainteasers and an excellent story will be impressed with Papers, Please.  The game, which takes place in an Arstotzkan border checkpoint at East Grestin, is based on sorting through papers. Does this person have all required papers? Are the papers valid? Does anything about the documents conflict with something else? These, and other new complexities, are difficult to understand at a glance, so game difficulty is no problem (though I haven't tried the Easy Mode yet). New twists, often caused by events at your own checkpoint (Kolechians are temporarily forbidden from entering Arstotzka following a Kolechian terrorist attack), are introduced, and often moral dilemmas arise, as bribes, anti-government rebel agents, and star-crossed lovers (Ooh-la-la) are frequent occurences on this border. Money troubles also appear, as you must maintain your family of four (fun things like 'Your wife, uncle, and son died' are treated with little fanfare).  The depth of the story (which has 20 endings) is (quite) deep. The unique method of storytelling, where you see just a snapshot of the lives of travelers, is enough to recommend the game on. The gameplay is interesting, but loses much of its appeal early on. For one to look at this as an incredibly difficult and intense virtual novel would be a good summary, and if you enjoy those types of things, then this could be one of your favorite new indie titles. For gameplay first, story second players, the game is likely to bore you, as the story is the real selling point here.

I'm so conflicted... I love this game, even though it makes me feel very depressed/apprehensive about things. The reason why I like it so is beause of the masterful way the story is told. Games are a unique storytelling medium because of the level of interactivity. Really, no other media has that level of interaction (movies, books, comics, theater, music). What makes this game special is that through its mechanics and gameplay, the story unfolds. Line, hook and sinker the mechanics get you before you realize you're in too deep.   Overall, if you play games for them to invoke some sort of emotion... This is it. Highly recomended.

A very simplistic game with an interesting mechanic surrounding everything. With 20 endings to unlock, this game quickly makes you like stamping documents and worrying more about threats on borders. A great little game, but probably worth buying when on sale.

Papers, Please has to rank up there as one of my favorite gaming experiences of the year. You take on the role of border passport inspector for an impoverished East German-esque dystopia. Your job is to check each applicant's paperwork, verify their authenticity, and either approve or deny them entry. The graphics and gameplay are incredibly drab and monotonous, yet there are many well developed underlying story arcs, truly difficult moral choices, and an ever present sense of oppression that gives this game a unique and amazing feel all its own, and makes it hard to walk away from until you see it through to one of its many (usually grim, or at best, bittersweet) endings.  This is a tough game to describe and sell to friends, because at its core, it's a paper-pushing bureaucracy simulator with pixelated graphics and a depressing mood, but it is so, so much more than that (trust me!). If you like games, or you even like a really interesting (and not too time consuming) experience, you owe it to pick up this jem for its bargain bin price.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Absolutely an amazing title, very original as far as I am concerned.  You play a person that decides who and who can not get into your country. Rules changes every day as to who can get in, making it easier and easier everyday to miss stuff, so you better pay attention, the game requires your attention if you don't want to go in debt.  You're faced with many moral decisions.  For example one time a woman will be the next in line and she has valid papers but begs you to approve her husband, who is after her, who does not have valid papers. Do you want to ignore the rules and accept him into the country and risk going in debt or do you want to follow the rules of Arstotzka and deny him?  Glory to Arstotzka.  9/10, must buy.

Frankly, this game is masterfully done. The idea is original, the graphics fit the claustrophobic and choking atmosphere, the music enhances the idea of a smothering government regime in which the player finds himself as both citizen and employee, and the stories told through the window of your booth are engaging and develop themselves with intrigue and secrecy. It's hard to find where this game could be improved. It's something that works so well as a game, and as an educational experience that it could almost be used in a teaching environment. The idea that a citizen of this government would be placed into the position they are, allowing or denying various people access to their country, seeing the amount of paperwork involved, watching the rules and regulations pile up and change over the course of time leading to frustration, being faced with the moral dilemmas asked of them, and deciding how to handle their allegiance to country versus their conscious and compassion for other human beings is something that truly isn't captured as well as it is here with Papers, Please.   I will say that the game is so well done, that it actually feels like work after awhile, which cuts into the fun factor, though it enchances the simulation aspect. It's almost hard to qualify it into a genre. The mechanics are crisp and clean, they build on themselves day after day, slowly increasing the difficulty by usually adding one or two additional rules, and eventually the player will find that they are totally immersed in the experience. It does feel like work after awhile though, so some players may actually be glad to 'punch out' after an hour or two of game play.  This is a game that has left me thinking about it long after I exit the program. It's something that reaches a state where it's actually more than a game, it's a slice of actual human life.   This falls into the same category as This War of Mine in that it's an important game, and one that people should play with more in mind that just entertainment. Excellent, excellent purchase.

This game accurately recreates what it would be like to be a bureaucrat working the border outpost of a communist dictatorship - your dayjob is mind-numbingly dull, the pay sucks balls (to the extent that you take bribes whenever you can or your family starves to death), and eventually the secret police will think you're a traitor and try and execute you. I picked up this game a year ago, needing a small game to tide me over since I couldn't really get involved in big immersive RPGs. I was extremely surprized with that I got.  I had heard Papers Please is a good game but I didn't expect the kind of addiciton that makes you play it for 7 hours straight. It's hard to pin point what really achieves this level of addiction. But it's probably a combination of genuine challenge, an interesting story line and essentially thousands of moral choice elements for 20 possible endings.  Don't snub it, it's a fantastic game.

The best game.  You need to play this. It is a work of art. The atmosphere and plot alone are better than some AAA titles. The 'morality' choices you will make are deeper, and more fulfilling than any sort of binary 'good/evil' choice you make in games that try to simulate it. (Like bioware or bethesda games.) You will find yourself roleplaying, perhaps against your will.  Do an internet search for the free beta and play it for a taste. The finished product is even richer.  I guess the gameplay may not be for everyone. But, I love it. It has a unique tension all its own as you wait to find if the person you admitted was legitimate or not.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Stangely addictive... You fall into a 'Just one more day' mentatlity then oops, it's 4am!

Well then. I feel like this will forever occupy the spot of 'A game that no sane person could comprehend without playing' and anyone who tries to describe it will sound like either a madman, or the most boring man in existence. Yes, it's a 'Paperwork Simulator.' Or as Yahtzee put it best, a 'Beurocracy 'em up.' And yet it genuinely is something worth trying. I doubt it will enrapture everyone, it's definitely for the 'Art Game' demographic - but it gets its point off well, and is a surprisingly engrossing thriller of sorts and there's a weird charm and atmosphere that takes you in, and while its still best played in short bursts - it doesn't get as repetitive as it might seem either. It's not going to appeal to everyone, but if you want to try something that just might surprise you - this is a good offering at a nice price.

Many games and companies claim to be inovated or trying to push the norm and being progressive. In the past Nintendo were the biggest innovators pushing the gaming industry with new ideas on how to play video games. The past few years the gaming industry has seen little to almost no new ideas since the wii came to store shelves. All of this is important because you won't see innovation from some big company; you will find it from some indie developer called Lucas Pope. A man who used to work for Naughty Dog Studios working on the beaten to death series Uncharted broke free and decided to do his own thing.   This game just surprised me from every aspect and I just wanted more and more. The gameplay consist of reading things carefully and making sure everything matches to what it is supposed to be. If things don't match or seem fishy you will deny or detain a person. Sounds easy at first but you must do all this under a strict clock. You get money for every person you deny or pass, but you do thing wrong and you get fined for it. And you need this money to pay rent, feed your family, keep them warm, and healthy. You can barely get enough money to do all of these things for your family. You need to manage your money very carefully.    This game is maybe one of the best games I played in my life. It is so different and original and it does it all in such a fantastic way. I highly reccomend everyone to play this game if you ever get the chance. I only wish more games to take such new approaches to gameplay can come out sooner.

This game idea is simple, yet really unique. It's a really fun game to play, the story is surprisingly good too. There are many moral choices to make, you can be like a robot and do everything as you're told too or you can sometimes slip in people that really need it in order to save themselves and if you feel greedy you can aid terrorist groups. At the end the decision you make will affect your final outcome, how much money you earn and if you're capable of paying all the expenses in order for your family to survive. This game Includes 20 endings, and the people presenting their Papers are randomized when not exactly Important, so it dosen't gets to repetitive.

One of the most oryginal games I have ever played. Never could have expected that game about beign boarder control officer who is checking (well gues) papers can be s o intersting and often funny.  This title is agreat example of an Indie Gaming. Hope to see more games of such type in the future.  Glory to Arstrotzka

HIGHLY recommend this game. Essentially, in this game you play as a border agent who has to examine passports and other official documentation to determine whether a person is allowed entry into your country or not. The game starts off relatively easy and slowly progresses into a more complicated game as you progress. If you mess up, you'll be deducted pay at the end of the work day and your family will undoubtedly suffer as a result. While it sounds rather tedious and repetitive, it does suck you in. Before you know, you've wasted 6 hours trying to provide for your family while watching out for illegals.

I am not a meticulous person so this is the antithesis of what I consider a fun video game. Despite this, all the aspects of a good game are there and nothing was overlooked. The game is very burreacratic with a lot of tongue in cheek moments. If you enjoy this form of humor and dont mind going through endless amounts of paperwork, this game if for you. Glory to Arstotzka!
hey niko want to get a passport?            no.      0/10

Pixel Indie Games are terrible most of the time but however I quite enjoyed this game! - It's graphics are not good - It doesn't have that much movement and action    but  - The game has lots of endings depending on your choices which is epic If you don't fail. ( I'd suggest you to try and get the endings on day 32)  -Some weird ♥♥♥♥ happens everyday!  -There are small humorous charachters such as Jorji Costava who makes you laugh every single time.  -The game is quite hard and innovative if you don't play it on the easy mode.  -There are so many things going on other than checking documents! I----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I Plus other than that YOU HAVE AN EPIC SON   Plus Plus I really enjoyed the game and unlocked all the achievements and got almost all of the ending, I suggest It so badly  Plus plus plus  - Help ''The Ezic'' all of the time or never help them  -------GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!--------

Allow me to explain why this is one of better games I've played in a while.  Granted the graphics don't look like much but what it lacks in Hi-res PhysX it makes up for in atmosphere, tension, gameplay and consequence, in abundance. (I rather think the graphics and audio are matched perfectly and harmonise each other well) It took me a two or three levels to fully understand how this game plays. (Essentially a spot the difference) But it is so much more than that. It places you in a dead end job with ever changing rule & regulations thrown upon you. But it thrusts completely grey area moral choices at you, interesting people and events.  It has a large amount of replayability. Truly earned it's place as one of my most favourite games.

Papers please is a funny great game which can make you lose hundreds of hours in. Definetly recommend this to anyone who loves strategy and humor. It is up to you to dermine who can get by the border into the country. Tons of different options to chose from and the game evolves with the story. Will you feel sorry for those you have fallen or hard times? Or is your families well being more important. Papers, Please tests your human morals to new levels.  Amazing game. Great story highly recommend.

An absolutely amazing game about normal life in a communistic society that shows how different the ideals between people and this so called perfect government really are. One of, if not my favorite, games that I own, it also has many hours of gameplay to be had that is constantly changing enough to stay fresh as you go through piles and piles of paperwork accompanied by crisp, clean, and satisfying sounds for everything that you can click on. 9/10
Best detaining simulator I've ever played.  glorytoarstotzka/10

Frankly, this game is masterfully done. The idea is original, the graphics fit the claustrophobic and choking atmosphere, the music enhances the idea of a smothering government regime in which the player finds himself as both citizen and employee, and the stories told through the window of your booth are engaging and develop themselves with intrigue and secrecy. It's hard to find where this game could be improved. It's something that works so well as a game, and as an educational experience that it could almost be used in a teaching environment. The idea that a citizen of this government would be placed into the position they are, allowing or denying various people access to their country, seeing the amount of paperwork involved, watching the rules and regulations pile up and change over the course of time leading to frustration, being faced with the moral dilemmas asked of them, and deciding how to handle their allegiance to country versus their conscious and compassion for other human beings is something that truly isn't captured as well as it is here with Papers, Please.   I will say that the game is so well done, that it actually feels like work after awhile, which cuts into the fun factor, though it enchances the simulation aspect. It's almost hard to qualify it into a genre. The mechanics are crisp and clean, they build on themselves day after day, slowly increasing the difficulty by usually adding one or two additional rules, and eventually the player will find that they are totally immersed in the experience. It does feel like work after awhile though, so some players may actually be glad to 'punch out' after an hour or two of game play.  This is a game that has left me thinking about it long after I exit the program. It's something that reaches a state where it's actually more than a game, it's a slice of actual human life.   This falls into the same category as This War of Mine in that it's an important game, and one that people should play with more in mind that just entertainment. Excellent, excellent purchase.

An excellent dystopian thriller that will have your head in your hands as you weigh protocol against morality. With a unique pixilated art style and a lengthy story mode accompanied by an endless mode, you'll find yourself coming back to Grestin Border Checkpoint time and time again, and with 20 unique endings depending on your choices in-game you'll never get bored.  Get this game now, inspector, and report to Grestin Border Checkpoint. Glory to Arstotzka!

Quick Breakdown:  A stellar game where you play as an inspector working at a border checkpoint between your communist country of Arstotzka, and the neighboring country Kolechia, which your country has just recently ended a 6 year war with.  Length:  2-4 hours (Main game), 8-10 (Completionists)  Score:  8.5/10   Full Review:  Papers Please is a truly unique game. Admittedly, it’s a pretty tough sell. On paper, the game sounds like it’d be awful. Even when I purchased the game, I wasn’t really sold on it, but I took a chance on it based on the ravings from my friends, and the low sale price of $2.50. After playing the game, I’m glad I did. It’s worth getting at full price even, but this is Steam, we all wait for the sales, don’t we?  So why’s it a tough sell? Well, you play as an inspector at a border checkpoint. People give you their papers needed to enter, and you look over them and either let them enter your country, deny them entry if their papers are not all in order, or even detain them if need be. Sound like fun? To me it didn’t, but maybe you can see the appeal there.  So why is it worth playing? Odd as it may be, that very task I talked about in the last paragraph actually is a lot of fun. But there’s further reason that is even more compelling. You work for the glorious country or Arstotzka, at the checkpoint the border town of Grestin. The half of Grestin belongs to the neighboring country of Kolechia, which Arstotzka has just ended a 6 year war with. Your border checkpoint has just opened because of this, and people are once again allowed to enter Arstotzka for the first time in 6 years. This setting, and the people it brings through your checkpoint, and the events it leads to, are the game’s biggest strengths. You’ll encounter natives trying to re-enter the country, foreigners who can finally come to Arstotzka to work or visit, or even just pass through. There will also be terrorists, who aim to harm your glorious country, and it is your duty to deny and even detain them.  The game’s story and dialogue are both well written. Your actions during the day (the gameplay portion, which we’ll get to in a moment) affect the story between days, and down the road. Both the one time characters passing through, and those who are recurring are interesting, and some even quite memorable. (I think everyone who’s played this game loves Jorji). The dialogue is quite good, and has plenty of memorable lines.  So what of the gameplay? It’s done in a single screen, divided into 3 portions. Roughly the top third of the screen is a top down view of the border checkpoint, the line, and the guards. This part isn’t used too often for gameplay. The bottom two thirds of the screen are divided as well, the left third presents a first person point of view from your place inside your border checkpoint. This is where applicants seeking entry to Arstotzka come in and give you your papers. The rest of the bottom portion of your screen is where you can look at said papers up close.  Now this is the part of the game that I think is the hardest part to sell someone on, but I’m going to try anyway. When the game starts, applicants give you a passport, and so long as they are a resident of Arstotzka with a valid passport, they may enter the country. You simply stamp all passports with either “approved” or “denied.” At the end of the day you will be paid 5 credits for every person you correctly processed. The first two incorrectly processed applicants will earn you a citation with a warning and no payment, each error after that will also incur a penalty docking some of your pay. Citations are reset at the beginning of each day.  During this end of day phase you will also need to balance your finances, and decide if you have money to pay for heat in your apartment, or to purchase food for your family. If you’re not able to take care of them properly they can die. If they’re all dead, or if you run out of money entirely you’ll get a gamer over (there are other ways to get a game over, in total the game has 20 different endings). So it’s important to do your job well.  On day 2 things become more complicated, and foreigners may enter as well so long as their passport is valid. On each passport you have various things to check for, a valid issuing city, that their photo matches their physical appearance, and that it hasn’t yet expired.  As the days go on more documents and rules will be introduced. I won’t go over all of them, but you will also have documents for entry permits, work permits, and you’ll need to crosscheck the name and passport number -as well as other information- on these documents with what’s printed on their passport. Sometimes you’ll also need to fingerprint an applicant, or search them for weapons or contraband (can’t let the drug smugglers and terrorists in). You’ll need to go over the documents carefully, pointing out discrepancies, and even giving a proper reason for denial. On occasion you’ll need to detain some of the applicants instead of simply denying them entry.  That about covers the basics of the game, so let’s move on to the graphics. They’re done in a simple pixel style, they’re not anything fancy, but they are pleasant to look at, and they help set the dreary mood of the game.  And it is quite dreary working this sort of job in an oppressive country, barely making enough to care for your family and survive. The music is good, and helps compliments this mood, and so do the sound effects.  My main criticism of the game is levelled at trying to point out discrepancies. Now, it’s not that I have issue doing this, I enjoy it. No no, my issue is that while you know which rule is broken, it’s not always clear how to properly point this out. Once you do figure it out, it’s a non-issue the next time you must deny someone entry for the same reason, and it’s not an issue most of the time, but it happens occasionally, and there’s not really a good reason for it. In the end though, Papers Please is a fantastic game. If you’ve not played it yet, hopefully I’ve been able to convince you to give it a go, if you’re on the fence though, I urge you to gamble on it anyway, wait for a sale even if you wish. Just make sure that you do play this game.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Good, fun little game - gets increasingly challenging as you go along, gameplay can get a little repetitive if you play it too much. Fun puzzle game, with an original theme that certainly adds to its attractiveness. Recommended!

Absolutely an amazing title, very original as far as I am concerned.  You play a person that decides who and who can not get into your country. Rules changes every day as to who can get in, making it easier and easier everyday to miss stuff, so you better pay attention, the game requires your attention if you don't want to go in debt.  You're faced with many moral decisions.  For example one time a woman will be the next in line and she has valid papers but begs you to approve her husband, who is after her, who does not have valid papers. Do you want to ignore the rules and accept him into the country and risk going in debt or do you want to follow the rules of Arstotzka and deny him?  Glory to Arstotzka.  9/10, must buy.

Papers, Please   Is a very unique, fun, and challenging. It is not too simple, but not to complex, either. It has just the right balance that any game sould have, and I have loved every hour I have played.     Glory to Arstotzka
A great game, But near the end, Get's a bit overwhelming...

As soon as I saw the video for this game, I was already fascinated. I consider $5 a STEAL for a game of this caliber. Totally underrated, I wish it had a little more fame as a game. You will be faced with a wide variety of moral dilemmas, as well as appropriately-placed comic relief. I received this game as a gift, and after playing it for nearly two days straight, I promptly bought that person their own copy of the game. They love it too!

I absolutely loved this game. It was fun and in every way lovable. It is also very addictive, it is that addictive that you are filled with sadness when the game ends. You get roughly around 10 hours of playtime in Paper Please. This game is by far one of my favourite games. It is different and unique and that is what I love about it. The music is wonderful and is perfect for this type of game. This game is great and fun.

Very polite title, which I appreciate. Most other games are so aggressively named, but Papers Please has the decency to ask nicely. Especially good given the nature of the game and its depiction of a totalitarian police state with strict and unwavering border control regulations. Juxtaposition is a great word to play in Scrabble if you can get your hands on an X or a Blank. Just wait until somebody writes 'position' and then add the 'juxta' with the biggest look of smugness you can muster. That's my favourite part of Scrabble. My favourite part of this game though is the achievement you can get for being arrested for being too honest. That made me happy.
Strangely addictive and enjoyably stressful.
This game is so much more fun to play than it is to describe to people.

High intense spot the difference  Keep your family alive  Become an agent for an secret society  Stop terrorists  20 different endings  You start out as a lowly humble border paper inspector, you turn into a terrorist shooting, criminal detaining, paper inspector  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

This game is amazing. It is such a unique idea and concept which was executed perfectly. I remember playing the beta a few years ago and wondering how something which seemed so boring and mundane could be interesting, and it was nothing short of interesting. The best passport and documentation simulator I have ever played. I highly recommend Papers, Please to anyone, no matter what specific genre of games you are into.  Nice try Jorji, MR_PERSISTENT. Papers, Please is an incredible game. It happens to be one of my favourites on Steam. The gameplay is always fun and engaging and is also rather addictive. The great thing about this game is that there is lots of replayability. The scenarios are always different, meaning that you will always be challenged, which is a great thing. Who knew stamping passports could be so much fun? So, for the love of God, please buy this excellent game.  Glory to Arstotzka.

One of the best Games on 2013. Very popular since the beta. It combines a pixelart style with a post era of dictatorial history in a fiction game world. You play the role of an Immigration and passport border checker. Even if the every day's tasks looks simple, the overflow of the small details added encourage you to go on and on to see what trickery situation you will get into, the next day. Every time a person comes to you, after you check his/her papers and find its not worthy to let him/her pass, youl'l need to take decisions which involves: your money situation, your devotion to your job or your apartenence to an rebel group. And with each choses you make, the end of the game will be different. So what are you waiting? get it and try it!

The best passport stamping drama video game ever!  'Papers, Please' puts you in the role of a citizen of Arstotzka who has just been selected, through labor lottery, to man the Grestin border checkpoint. It is your job to approve or deny entry to the country.  From the music to the atmosphere, the game is wonderful. It features an unique and refreshing art style, and the gameplay itself is rather challenging. I highly encourage everyone to try this game! Well worth every penny!  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

This game is near to perfect. I would recommend *everyone* to buy it, even if you're not planning to ever play it. So go ahead, do a good deed and reward the developer for his brilliant ideas. Never thought 8-bit graphics, repetitive music and monotonous gameplay could make up to such a gripping and stirring (and also fun) experience.   Glory to Arstotzka!
This is a super interesting game The trailers and pictures should give you a decent idea what it is about Don't buy this if you just want to relax and have a good time.
This is not puzzle-type fun game, comrade.  This is very serious business. Let good guys in, Keep bad guys out. Do a good job, Get paid, Keep family alive. Do not let us down.  Glory to Arstotzka!

This is the mosty addictively boring game in the world. It's billed as a 'dystopian document thriller', and I can say it certainly lives up the title. You're a border inspector for the Great Nation of Arstotzka, and all you will do all day is check the papers of travelers who are seeking entry into the country. In the beginning, all you have to do is check for one or two things. By the end, there's a massive list of potential things that could be wrong with some of the paperwork.   I didn't believe the person who told me this game would be super fun. I picked it up for 75% off during a Steam sale anyway, because they raved about how good of a game it was. When I tried it, I understood. It's extraordinarily fun. I can't recommend it enough. It's definitely worth the $10, but if you want to wait until it goes on sale, then it's even more definitely worth it.   Glory to Arstotzka!
This game is so fun with the story encorperated into checking passports!

Papers, Please is a game where you cannot judge the game based on gameplay alone, because let's face it - when has checking papers at a checkpoint ever been any fun? That's the point of the game; you do it because it is telling you a story - the story of a man who despite juggling responsabilities provided by a corrupt government and a terrorist organization; has to do his job to help his family survive. The story can and will go in any direction depending on what you do as the inspector, and even tests your own morality and ability to bend the rules for others in desperation.  It is a gritty, unshaven and spirit-crushing masterpeace.
fun and addicting, love this game

At first sifting through papers seems a bit daunting, but after a while the game becomes a sort of psychological study-- 'That man is offering to give me money when I detain people? I WILL DETAIN EVERYONE!!'  I just hope I'm not trying to get into Arstotzka any time soon... I'd be detained.
Good for training attentiveness. Great game. Interesting world. Want some action or RPG in this setting.

Innovative and with political jokes, this game pass the sensation that how would be like ' or was ' to work on the customs house of a country inside the 'iron curtain'. The have a well developed gameplay unlike the graphs that for being unnecessarily reduced often causes confusion. At the beginning of the game you have a low speed and limited options, however these options can be improved over the course of your career, the game also has multiple endings which makes it really challenging . The main idea of this game is simple, ' how fast is your ability to handle a huge amount of information and answer yes or no ' this idea (I believe) is innovative and beautifully crafted in this game personally believe that this game had been created during an older generation it would be considered a classic for its difficulty.  Pros : - Smart. - Creative. - Funny. - Different finals. - Challenger  Cons : - Graphics unnecessarily limited. - The library ( Book / Manual ) is unnecessarily slow. - The oscillation of your disambiguation options is irritant .  My Grade: 89/100  Inovador e com piadas de gênero político, esse jogo consegue passar a sensação de como seria 'ou era' trabalhar na alfandega de um país da 'cortina de ferro'. O jogo possui uma jogabilidade muito bem trabalhada diferentemente dos gráficos que por serem desnecessariamente reduzidos muitas vezes causa confusão. No inicio do jogo você possui uma agilidade reduzida e opções limitadas, porem estes quesitos são aprimorados ao decorrer da sua carreira, o jogo também possui diversos finais o que o torna desafiador. A principal ideia desse jogo é simples, 'o quão rápido é a sua capacidade de processar uma quantidade enorme de informações e responder sim ou não' essa ideia é (acredito ser) inovadora e muito bem trabalhada neste jogo, pessoalmente acredito que se esse jogo tivesse sido criado durante a geração mais antiga ele seria considerado um clássico pela sua dificuldade.   Pros: -Inteligente. -Criativo. -Engraçado. -Diferentes finais. -Desafiador  Contras: -Gráficos desnecessariamente limitados. -A biblioteca(Manual/ Manual) é desnecessariamente lenta. -A oscilação das sua opções de desambiguidade é irritante.  Minha nota: 89/100

In Papers, Please, you play as the newly-installed border agent for the fictional dystopian country of Arstotzka. Reviewing passports, forms, tickets, permits, scans, fingerprints, ID cards, and vaccination records against an increasingly complex and daily-changing set of rules, you are the judge of whether each newcomer is granted entry, turned away, detained, or even shot.  Sandwiched among the ordinary visitors, travelers, immigrants, asylum seekers, and diplomats, you encounter characters whose future rely on your discretion. These encounters range from the humorous to the heartwrenching, and you have to decide whether to adhere to your guidelines or your sense of right and wrong, whether you're better off taking a bribe or accepting your piecework pay. Some of these decisions have gameplay consequences, while others are merely matters of conscience. Meanwhile, your ability to pay for your family's basic needs rests upon your ability to quickly and accurately process the line of faces waiting in front of you each day. To me, these encounters and decisions were the most compelling part of the game. The player is able to make interesting and consequential choices and either advance or hinder an underground rebellion movement, as well as the lives of individual people.  Most of the time, though, you're just processing paperwork, and that's about as interesting as you would expect. The game does a good job of simulating the inanity and tedium of comparing item after item against rule after rule, checking for discrepancies; of pulling out the 'DENIED' stamp, aligning the passport under it, pressing down upon the stamp, putting the stamp away again, and handing each piece of paper back to its owner. If you like details a lot, are a bit OCD, or enjoy spot-the-difference games, this might become curiously addictive for you, but even as I compulsively continued to stamp paperwork, I experienced a nagging sense that what I was doing felt more like work than fun. I played through the story mode twice for the achievements, and although I was much better at processing the paperwork the second time around, I also found myself thinking about how many game days were still coming with an odd sense of dread. The first time around, there was at least the tension of whether I'd be able to make it through the full month and get to the end of the story (on my very first try, I reached the ending where you run out of money very early on), but on my repeat playthrough, I felt like I had to go through a great deal of tedium to reach the few meaningful encounters that I was interested in experiencing again, differently.  The game does feature several different 'endless' modes, complete with leaderboards, but I see very little incentive to play them, since for me they remove the best parts of the game and keep the most dull. But if processing an infinite line of passports holds appeal for you, that option is available.  One final note: the save system in Papers, Please is excellent. It uses a branching system that allows you to start from the beginning of any game day in any of your previous playthroughs and continue from there, making going back for achievements or to see alternate endings much easier than it might otherwise have been.  Overall, I'd recommend this game for its unique concept, quirky humor, evocative decision-making, and immersive ambience. The story is worth seeing through to a few of its 20 possible endings -- but probably not all of them. Keep in mind, however compelling this game is, it's still a simulation about paperwork.

This is certainly not a review about the game itself. We ALL know how great it is.  I'm here to talk about the quality of its Linux port. I'm not surprised that an indie title has flawless support so far, compared to certain AAA titles I will not mention right now.  Everything works as you'd expect, display, input, audio... no major problems. There's just a rare issue with certain lines of text having a whole row of pixels chopped off, but it doesn't affect readability (if it happens on Windows too, then it's all ok).  PS: I like the fact on fullscreen it uses nearest neighbor interpolation and keeps pixels square. I'm kind of a sucker for that.
Best detaining simulator I've ever played.  glorytoarstotzka/10

Papers, Please is a perfect example of storytelling. With little narration you quickly pick up on gameplay and story and the constantly escalating difficulty will keep you enthralled for hours. So much fun to play!

An absolutely amazing game about normal life in a communistic society that shows how different the ideals between people and this so called perfect government really are. One of, if not my favorite, games that I own, it also has many hours of gameplay to be had that is constantly changing enough to stay fresh as you go through piles and piles of paperwork accompanied by crisp, clean, and satisfying sounds for everything that you can click on. 9/10
One of my all time favorite games.

'Papers, Please' is simply the best game of this year. I bought it on a recommendation from my favorite youtuber, and it was... stunning. The games graphics are simple and perfect for what it needs to do. The story is basic in the same way that life is. This game contains care in each pixel and each word; if any of the world's greatest authors made a video game, this would be it. Don't take that as meaning this game is only based around the story, there is an endless supply of fun in the actual gameplay. Buy it right now.

Strangely addicting, sly, and clever. Papers, Please has become popular lately with all due respects.   The concept of the game seems boring. Who would want to stamp passports for fun? While holding a careful eye and detailed memory, Papers, Please tells the story of a corrupt civilization waiting to be discovered and uncovered all through the eyes of a gatemaster. All while doing this, you must balance your salary to keep your family healthy, full, and happy.  I obviously have not beat the game yet, and am curious to see what happens. Its like that new book you just can't put down.   9/10
Glory to Arstotzka! Who would have thought a game about checking passports would be so good?
Dark, atmospheric and deceivingly simple. Download the demo and give it a try!

If you've ever dreamed about checking paperwork at the border control of a dystopian communist country, this game is for you. As you play, you have to learn the job, gradually assume more responsibility while keeping pace, feed your family and deal with ethical dilemmas daily. If you like unique/creative games, this is a masterpiece and well worth the money.
Have you ever dreamed of having a dreary, boring job full of paperwork where you decide who gets to live and who dies?  This might just be the thing for you.

Nice indie game s little short hopeing former Naughtydog employee Lucas Pope makes more games like this.
Simplistic and wonderfully executed. It may seem like a boring idea, but Paper, Please is actually very fun with an increasing sense of urgency as you move on in the game.
