I didn't buy this last time I'd seen it on sale, but it had certainly peaked my interest. I bought it this time and I'm glad I did!  I wasn't really expecting much of this game, but it ended up being splendid - simple yet wonderful. You have a choice no matter the situation and you have up to twenty endings you could end up with (reminds me of those stories when I was a child with the multiple endings, can't remember what they're called). Most of the endings seem to require different sacrifices you have to make along the way and give a realistic insight to the life of a border officer. It explores not only moral issues but corruption, blackmail, terrorism, bribery, etc. which is honestly a good portrayal of today's society. Following the rules to a T or being honest will not give you a good ending.   As each day moves forward, you are introduced to new daily tasks, many of which might be unfair to the person crossing the border. You get plenty of different people - some who are obviously crooks and some who just want to be free of their old country or visit a family member. There's a secret organization trying to infiltrate your country as well and whether you decide to help them or not, the consequences might never be the same.   I don't know. It's entertaining and makes you ask questions. I think that makes this game a very good one, despite how repetitive it is. You're at least engaged with the central story and your life, your family's lives, and countless other families' lives depend on your decision, whereas other games like this might not make you have such conscious choices where so much relies on said choices, which really makes Papers, Please stand out.  Definitely recommended. (:

Papers, Please is a thoughtful, oddly enjoyable, and surprisingly funny game. It's brisk without feeling superficial, so you can get as much out of it as you like without devoting a month of your life just to get through the story. Highly recommended if your looking for a game that's totally different from the mainstream.
I still cannot believe, how they could fit such a perfect story into this game, along the perfect mechanics. This game unique and is a masterpiece. 10/10

If you told me that an Eastern-European bureaucratic paperwork simulator would be this captivating and addictive, I probably would have said 'That's not a game genre, no one would play that'.  But it somehow both exists, and is amazing.
The only game that's ever compelled me to consider filing paperwork as a hobby.

A friend of mine once remarked that there's no way to describe this game that still makes it sound fun once you've explained it. By all reason, Papers Please shouldn't be as much of a good time as it is. You serve as an unnamed male citizen of the Arstozkan Empire, employed by lottery to rigorously scan and verify documents at the newest border crossing station in your dystopian, communist nation circa the 1980s. The names are all changed, but you essentially control Checkpoint Charlie at the Berlin Wall, and it's your job to make sure illegal immigration in your sector grinds to a halt. If you fail, your impoverished family will starve and freeze even worse than they already do.  But in spite of all its Cold War doom and gloom, Papers Please is a wonderfully intricate and engaging experience. The charm and humor of its characters, such as the permanently cheerful Jorgi Costava or the irascible Dimitri (Your supervisor, who stops by to inform you how bad you're doing each week) draws you in with each passport you process. Soon, you're reading your employee handbook to pass the time, determined to serve your country well and provide for your family. Or maybe you begin working undercover with the resistance, smuggling revolutionaries into the country with falsified papers. Or maybe you set up a smuggling business with a few regular border-crossers, and plan to flee the country yourself.   With 20 different endings to unlock and hundreds of stories to hear, Papers Please is unique kind of game; one that defies the genres of the medium and forces us to think differently about our entertainment. I highly recommend you pick it up. And remember! Always read the daily bulletin!  Glory to Arstotzka!
Short Review

Papers Please is one of the most unique and interesting games you can find on steam, not only is the gameplay addicting and interesting but the overall storyline, endings and possible outcomes make this game a must have. This game also has incredible replayablilty making you just want to keep playing it over and over again to either get better, waste time or find all the secrets. Another outstanding fact about this game is how much it makes you question what sort of person you are, will you do your duty to your country and do as they request? Or will you let in people who want to get in to escape their horrible past? Overall this game is definetly a 9.5/10 from me.
OMG THIS GAME HAS ENDLESS HOURS TO COME <3 would buy this over again

You have to buy this game, there's no option about it, if you have the money just buy it right now!  This game forces you into a situation where you have to do your job near-perfectly to get enough money for your family to survive and be happy, but that involves screwing over a lot of helpless people in situations similar to yours! Will you work hard, not questioning the authorities and provide for your family; or do you make a sacrifice to help the common folk? That's up to you! A lot of other things go on, but I'll leave you to discover that because it's pretty mind blowing on your first play through! (As the game says, it's a Thriller)  The gameplay is also surprisingly fun for a game about checking over paperwork, it involves a lot of thought and skill! It is extremely unique and it constantly throws new rules onto your job based on the events that happen in the game world, changing up the gameplay and making it more interesting day by day!   The game also has a lot of replay value, with many different endings you can achieve and lots of different ways the story can drive forward based on your choices each day. You can replay any day or start a completely new game at any time without losing the progress of later days, so they give you full freedom to experiment and retry when things don't go how you wanted them to!   You see all these people saying that video games can't be an art form, and this game can't be further from the truth. After playing this, no one could deny that video games are an art form. Just buy it now because you'll love it and you need to support true innovative and artistic games. BUY IT! I'm waiting...  Bought it yet? No? Why the f*** not!?
Instigating and story-focused, Papers Please makes you wonder about bureaucracy, international affairs, and dictatorial governments all at the same time. Excellent!

This is a great game, and it's also amazing how you can make a game based ona boring job really fun. The story is great, the gameplay is fun, the characters are cool (especially Jorji) and the graphics are really nice too. If you want a great challenge, then this game is for you.
The game might not be for everyone, but if you enjoy micro management/simulations then you should definitely buy it.

One of the best Games on 2013. Very popular since the beta. It combines a pixelart style with a post era of dictatorial history in a fiction game world. You play the role of an Immigration and passport border checker. Even if the every day's tasks looks simple, the overflow of the small details added encourage you to go on and on to see what trickery situation you will get into, the next day. Every time a person comes to you, after you check his/her papers and find its not worthy to let him/her pass, youl'l need to take decisions which involves: your money situation, your devotion to your job or your apartenence to an rebel group. And with each choses you make, the end of the game will be different. So what are you waiting? get it and try it!

This game is amazing! Entertaining. Challenging. Unusual.  For a week or two, my evenings were spent WORKING as a customs officer.  Even has a branching story line depending on the decisions the autonomy of your job allows.  I will never look at customs at the airport the same way again.  10/10 would recommend to anyone with an interest in games outside of popcorn-COD clones and a brain!

Papers, Please is an incredible game. It happens to be one of my favourites on Steam. The gameplay is always fun and engaging and is also rather addictive. The great thing about this game is that there is lots of replayability. The scenarios are always different, meaning that you will always be challenged, which is a great thing. Who knew stamping passports could be so much fun? So, for the love of God, please buy this excellent game.  Glory to Arstotzka.

This game accurately recreates what it would be like to be a bureaucrat working the border outpost of a communist dictatorship - your dayjob is mind-numbingly dull, the pay sucks balls (to the extent that you take bribes whenever you can or your family starves to death), and eventually the secret police will think you're a traitor and try and execute you.  Yeah, this game is bleak, boring, and depressing. And yet I'm still stamping passports. What the hell?

While the first glimpse says to a store-wanderer ''boring, boring, boring'', this idea is completely false. Papers, Please is the complete opposite of boring.  Taking place in a fictional   semi-corrupt semi-just-want-MIA-members-kept-in-place   country named Arstotzka, you play as a border control agent, accepting or denying job-seekers, immigrants and criminals. While this game's first few hours/minutes (depending on how quick your fingers are and how long it takes to strain them dragging documents around your messy desk) are quite dull, the people I saw in just that little amount of gameplay made me rage, laugh and stare. This is a brilliant attribute as it jolts the brain and your emotions to a flying start. Time to time the game gets harder and more time-consuming, but still follows the same laugh-rage experience. It also displays attributes of a shooter - you will sometimes see a terrorist attack and have the power to stop one at your protagonist's twiddling fingers.   It also gives you opinions and puzzles   (including the bomb some idiot thought would kill off an inspector and all the guards surrounding him)  , like managing your expenses and doing whatever it takes to not be arrested for giving a single document to the police. While this isn't too frequent it still makes you happy there's a change in the game and you have some freedom.   Graphics-wise the game is pixellated, but looks lovely at the same time. This style fits the time the game was set, as I just thought, considering it is set in the 80s, a time when 8-bits were first introduced. It also displays musical talent, and the theme makes me want to go on a march in synchronization with it.   So, overall, I'd say Papers, Please, from such a simple idea, turns out to be one of my favourite games of all time, and I congratulate Dukope for making such a brilliant game.  10/10. Glory to Arstotzka.
This is a super interesting game The trailers and pictures should give you a decent idea what it is about Don't buy this if you just want to relax and have a good time.
This is not puzzle-type fun game, comrade.  This is very serious business. Let good guys in, Keep bad guys out. Do a good job, Get paid, Keep family alive. Do not let us down.  Glory to Arstotzka!

This is the mosty addictively boring game in the world. It's billed as a 'dystopian document thriller', and I can say it certainly lives up the title. You're a border inspector for the Great Nation of Arstotzka, and all you will do all day is check the papers of travelers who are seeking entry into the country. In the beginning, all you have to do is check for one or two things. By the end, there's a massive list of potential things that could be wrong with some of the paperwork.   I didn't believe the person who told me this game would be super fun. I picked it up for 75% off during a Steam sale anyway, because they raved about how good of a game it was. When I tried it, I understood. It's extraordinarily fun. I can't recommend it enough. It's definitely worth the $10, but if you want to wait until it goes on sale, then it's even more definitely worth it.   Glory to Arstotzka!
This game is so fun with the story encorperated into checking passports!

Papers, Please is a game where you cannot judge the game based on gameplay alone, because let's face it - when has checking papers at a checkpoint ever been any fun? That's the point of the game; you do it because it is telling you a story - the story of a man who despite juggling responsabilities provided by a corrupt government and a terrorist organization; has to do his job to help his family survive. The story can and will go in any direction depending on what you do as the inspector, and even tests your own morality and ability to bend the rules for others in desperation.  It is a gritty, unshaven and spirit-crushing masterpeace.

This game is absolutely astonishing in it's dull, gloomy charm and simply overwhelming emotional power. It's a game about spotting discrepancies and stamping passports, and yet it's one of the most powerful games i've ever laid my eyes upon. I can count several times in this game where it flat out almost brought me to tears. Such a great game. A pleasure to play and even moreso to experience. Hands-down amazing.

Papers, Please is a repetitive but challenging indie game where you act as a border control passport inspector. The goal of the game is to let the qualified people pass and reject the inqualified people. Every day there is a new set of rules or addition to the rules making each day still challenging and fun. The game is challenging at first to learn of the different conditions and what each is (such as the passport nations). However later on it becomes more of a 'spot the error' kind of game. If you get 2 wrong, you will not be penalized, but if you get 3 wrong, you will start to lose money. At the end of every day you can devote your money to different things such as heat and food. However, if you chose not to devote money to those for long enough, bad things will happen to your family which is dependent on the money. If you go into the negatives after a day, you get arrested and it is game over.  Overall pretty fun game and has a fitting soundtrack that plays when the game gets to certain points.  Rating: 8.6/10
Papers, Please offers a unique gameplay experience soaked in humour. It's much more than a customs officer simulator. It brings a new perspective to game design. A must play.

I have never really played (or even known the existence of) a game similar to this one. You play the role of a passport station security officer, and your main objective is to check documents of various people passing through the border. While this may not sound exciting at first, as you progress in the game you need to monitor larger amounts of information in a limited amount of time, making the game feel rather fast paced.  Aside from the document checking, there are certain decisions you can make throughout the game, leading to 20 different possible endings. So there is quite a bit of playback value.  8/10 Although this is not for everyone, I would highly recommend it for its unique experience.
10/10 would reject again

Papers, please is a unique and interesting game, you're basically a one man border control and trust me, it gets more interesting... Just looking at someone's face and seeing if it matches the passport photo isn't all of it, a lot of minor detail is included so that you have to pay attention carefully such as expiry date on the passport and region they are from etc. Don't worry, you get a warnings if you get it wrong but any more than 2 mistakes and you get fined. As you progress through the story, it's gets more challenging and there is more specific requirements thrown at you such as workers have to present a valid work permit and certain documents are needed. When you finish work, you get your pay and you have to feed your family, pay for heating and if your family is ill; medicine. The worst part is to make wise decisions, such as sacrificing heating for your sons medicine, if you don't pay for the medicine, your family member might die and thats pretty depressing since your salary is quite low. Although it might sound boring, there is an actual storyline to it, some events happen and your choice of actions might change the story a bit. You'll be glad that everyone you meet are different. Also, you can get some grumpy people who can ♥♥♥♥ you off or you can get people who are desperate to migrate because of war and they beg you to let them in even though they don't have a passport. Decision making is pretty heavy in this game. Overall, its interesting and fun game. I recommend it to those who have some time to kill and those who want pursue a border control career ;)

Very polite title, which I appreciate. Most other games are so aggressively named, but Papers Please has the decency to ask nicely. Especially good given the nature of the game and its depiction of a totalitarian police state with strict and unwavering border control regulations. Juxtaposition is a great word to play in Scrabble if you can get your hands on an X or a Blank. Just wait until somebody writes 'position' and then add the 'juxta' with the biggest look of smugness you can muster. That's my favourite part of Scrabble. My favourite part of this game though is the achievement you can get for being arrested for being too honest. That made me happy.
iz rly gud
Incredible piece of work. Great style ... innovative story (premise) ... and a very compelling experience. I feel so sad for my family ... but, Glory to Arstotzka !  Indie GoTY
A great game, But near the end, Get's a bit overwhelming...

Start playing this game and think it's easy. Spend 5 minutes in it and realise you're not paying attention, so you get a notice from the government. Begin to spend more time on details. The day is over. Notice how you earn less money because you took too much to inspect so few people. Basic needs like food and rent need to be paid. Get to work again and rush more people. Make mistakes; The government is all over you.  This game is amazingly fun and a real exercise to your brain.Try to memorise all the provinces of the different countries (good luck) and the game will tip you off your chair with more government rules. Though some things are easy to check once you get the hang of it, when pressure starts to build up the game will break your concentration with some hilarious comments, love stories or pure eyebrow rising momments from the immigrants.  All in all, this game has simple repeat step X and Y to achieve goal, but all of those steps may or may not come for each of the immingrants you need to inspect, and even if they appear, they will be in a random order. This is what really makes you think.   The game has Story Mode and Endless Mode. You will also have an option to enable 'easy mode'.

Arstotzka - greatest country in the world. You want in? You got Passport? You got Entry Permit? You got ID?  You want to work in Arstotzka? You got Work Permit? No? Entry Denied. And, your face, does not match picture. Surgery you say? Fingerprints please. No, not you. GUARDS!  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!  One of the easiest, hardest, time killers out there. You will miss out, if you don't buy it.

One of the most monotonous and dull dreary games I have ever played- yet one of the most addicting, and although dreary, is still a heck of an awesome game. I recommend this fully, although buying it on sale to be safe is good as it isn't to everyone's tastes :)

The best game.  You need to play this. It is a work of art. The atmosphere and plot alone are better than some AAA titles. The 'morality' choices you will make are deeper, and more fulfilling than any sort of binary 'good/evil' choice you make in games that try to simulate it. (Like bioware or bethesda games.) You will find yourself roleplaying, perhaps against your will.  Do an internet search for the free beta and play it for a taste. The finished product is even richer.  I guess the gameplay may not be for everyone. But, I love it. It has a unique tension all its own as you wait to find if the person you admitted was legitimate or not.  Glory to Arstotzka.

One of the most inventive games I've ever come across, a true masterpiece, telling the story of a border agent in a fictional Communist nation Arstotzka, which has recently emerged from a 6-year-long war with neighbour Kolechia. Traveling to the border after being selected in the October Labour Lottery, you bring along your wife, son, mother-in-law and uncle, you must determine who is allowed to enter the nation, with the criteria for entry becoming increasingly long, to the point where entrants almost need a permit to open doors. The story is amazingly immersing, and I just can't stop listening to the endlessly looping menu music. A true masterpiece that demonstrates why indie games are the gateway into the games industry, with ideas like this Lucas Pope and 3909 are definitely going places.  A truly 10/10 experience, and easily one of the best, if not the best, game of 2013.

A Paladin’s Steam Review: Papers, Please. Glory To Arstotzka's Boring Yet Compelling Job

Papers, Please is the game that made me think I'm a terrible person. This game simulates a life in a totalitarian regime where you work on the border, deciding people's lives. If you do good and let people who don't have a passport but want to go over the border continue, your pay will be deducted. If you don't have money, your family will starve, and if you don't have money to pay the bills you will be arrested. On the other hand, if you don't help the people you will feel like you are a terrible person. I made this mistake once in the game, and never again. I destroyed their regime, saved my family, but alas my son has died. I would recommend this game to everyone to check their moral codex, and especially to people in rich countries, so they can know what is like living in poverty.

Context is everything in this game. You need to get money to look after yourself and your family in a country with a ♥♥♥♥ed economy. That's it. This is one of the most unique games to come around in many years. A cold war based theme set in 1982 where you decide on the entrance of people into your country, the 'Glorious' Arstotzka. The game difficulty starts slowly as you check the validity of people's documents at the border. This continues to build as more complex events occur adding more and more information to verify and new methods to test the stories of the masses. At the end of the work day, you are paid by how many people you processed and penalized for mistakes made. Your money is used to support your family, providing as good a living as you can for the necessities of life: Rent, food, heat, medicine. It is a serious challege to process as many as you can while not letting criminals, terrorists, and other 'undesirables' into your country.  A word about the graphics: they are intentionally low end to give the feel for what games were back in the 80's. Nevertheless, what gamers often times fail to remember, it is the imagination that is the most important piece of play. Many of you will recall how the BEST and most fun you had as a kid was when you had a tree branch sword, a pine cone grenade, or a fort made of boxes. This frame of mind is nearly lost on the current generation as graphics have all but stunted their ability to dream and pretend. This game deserves a look for the price, currently $5. Those of you who remember the cold war era will laugh at the feel of the game, while those who do not may find that they actually have a great time with it as they strengthen 'the muscle of their imagination' that has been dormant for perhaps their whole lives. Glory to Arstotzka!
This game just has so much to say and it says it in a wonderfully tedious way, making yet another point. Points were made, passports refused. 11/10

Papers, please! is a...i would say 'check for diference'/'spot the hidden thing' type of game. i believe it's based on the ussr comunism period so expect a lot of comunistic moments, jokes, stuff like that. it's quite fun and addicting and quite challenging as well.  Cons: - for those who care graphic wise it's not something most people would like, even for pixel fans, but i liked it, it had a unique style/feeling to it; - can be easy since losing doesn't have any penalties; - the amount of transexuals in this game is too damn high! :)) ;  Pros: - simple concept but really fun and challenging; - great music, even thought not alot of tracks; - has replayability; - variety in rules; - story mode and diferent types of endless modes; - funny moments, jokes, lines, characters, viva la jorji! :)) - 20 endings making story mode not always the same; - not the easiest but not the hardest game to 100%; - i would say it trains you brain, reaction sense, observational skills, even moral skills; - randomly generated stuff; - not many penalties on loosing since you can just replay the day again;  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!!!

At a glance Papers, Please is a distopian document checking simulator, and it is, but it is also so much more. Not only is the stress of having to go through passports, entry visas, diplomatic documents, requests for asylum and trying to shoot down any people jumping the border fun, it's also extremely immersive.  This game gets you lost in the fictional country of Arstotzka and makes come to love and hate it. But gameplay aside this game shown me something no game as shown me as of yet. It showed me that I am a corrupt, easily persuaded and cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Well I guess I already knew I am a cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but none the less this game showed it to me again. 'How did it do that?' you may ask, and let me tell you. This game gives you a family that you grow to love. I took bribes, shot people, poisoned people and let people in illeagally if I thought it would let my family have ten extra dollars. If someone told me a sob story about why they couldn't get in I did not care. If they had the wrong papers they do not go in. I arrested people that didn't need to be arrested because there was a chance I'd earn an extra five dollars. It made me hate those dirty Kolechian scumbag terrorists. Every time I let a Kolechian through I hold the key to the tranqualiser just in case he decides to pull something stupid. This game tells a story very few other games do. You're choices have consequences that can be seen. You helped the order? You'll see it in the news paper the next day. The satisfaction of knowing that you are helping your country is great.  This game also has one of the most nerve wracking moments ever. If you mark someone's passport with an entry granted stamp, give it to them but then realise you forgot to check something, the next three seconds of them walking in will be the scariest of your life, hoping that you he had everything right, and if you hear that awful fax machine noice telling you that you stuffed up, you want to cry.  This game has multiple endings, which in my opinion is one of the best things a game could have. Will you help the order? Will you maintain your poor work standards and loose your job? Or will you find a way to claw yourself out from the bottom to the top?  Papers, Please is a game about success, failure and trials. This game teaches us who we are. Are we in it for ourselves or will we take a more utilitarianism approach? In the end it's a game about survival. Papers, Please is more than a document simulator.  Glory to Arstotzka!
Paperwork Simulator 2014. Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please  manages to make what would seem like a midless task mean lots to the player, all while presenting new challenges and thrills throughout the game and managing to be terrifyingly immersive. This is the only game where poor controls can be described as intentional, and they are, to make the grinding task of passport-stamping intentionally tedious and frustrating. Even as a humble worker, you feel powerful as you stamp the papers of endless npcs, some of which contribute to the story. While it won't appeal to those gamers who want nothing but the finest gameplay, the aesthetic, story, message and overall tone of  Papers, Please  draws many to enjoy it. In fact, the strenuous task of paperwork shuffling can actually become fun and addicting to perfectionists like myself.  While short, there are 20 endings in the game, 3 of which are considered 'good'. Obtaining my desired good ending is one of the most rewarding thigs I've experienced from a game.  10 dollars is a bit of a stretch for those who don't know what they're getting from this game, but I would reccomend it to absolutely anyone on sale.

As days go by, terrorists attacks occur and it is clear that a more strict border regulation is needed. So, mostly each day, a new rule is implemented that you must adhere to. But then, then there are the people. Jorji... Ah, I'll let you experience this gem for yourselves. There are choices you have to make though. You must make these more decisions based on what YOU think... Will you let the wife pass with her husband even though she doesn't have proper papers? Over all, this is definitely worth the price and I would pay for it if it were more.

Don't come into this game expecting the graphics to get any better than they do in the Store page's screenshots.  Still, this is a one-of-a-kind game that is definitely worth giving a try.

Alternative names:  - 'Racial Profiling Galore'  - 'Navigate A Cluttered Desk Simulator 2013'  - 'Your Family is Going to Starve And It's All Your Fault.'  - 'This Job Requires Practically No Skill And You Still Can't Do It Properly'  - 'Harass And Strip Search Gender Non-Conforming Immigrants'  - 'Detain That Guy For Having A Minor Discrepency On His Passport'  - 'Accidently Let Terrorists Through The Checkpoint Who Proceed To Blow The ♥♥♥♥ Out Of Everyone'  - 'Why Do These Sex Workers Keep Giving Me Business Cards?'  A Dystopian Document Thriller

You are customs and immigration all in one. You must only allow people with the proper documents and no contraband items through into your country. However, many events will occur which may make you want to bend the rules. There will be many funny moments, as well as sad or scary ones. Will you remain loyal to your country, even though it barely pays you, or help incite a rebellion in the hope of a better future?

Immigration inspector simulator  'Papers, Please' is a point and click, puzzle game developed by 3909.  There isn't much story in the game. You basically play as a immigration inspector who manages who get into the country of Azoska (as well as look after your family). Certain events are detailed via text boxes or in the newspaper. There a over ten endings in the game, which occur based on player action.  Gameplay is exceptional. You need to check the credentials of people who are entering the country and only let in people who meet the laws. This includes checking height, photo, passports, work visa etc. to find any discrepencies. If there are no problems you let them through, else you have to deny access into the country. At each level, you only have a limited amount of time to work and earn money. Therefore you have to arrange where each piece of document you are given goes (either on the desk or counter) so you can efficiently check and hand those papers back as quickly as possible in order get the next visitor and hence more money. Each person you let in earns you ten dollars, while at the same time any mistakes you make (after the first one) will deduct money from you. Money is used at the end of the level to pay for your family's needs e.g. food and rent. Failure to earn enough money will mean that your family members start dieing off. Your moraility will also be tested in the game with various decisions such as whether to accept bribes, detain people to get more money, whether to let a grieving mother through etc. Basically you have to manage your job, family and morales during the game.  There is minimal audio in the game. Alarms and paper sound as they should. People speak via text boxes and some of their dialogue are quite humorous.  Graphics aren't that detaile, but they do a good job at setting a surpressive atmosphere.  If you want to have unique, somewhat-funny point and click game, this game won't dissapoint.

This is a game that stuck with me and told a grim yet realistic story. While the graphics aren't spectacular and it's not the high intense gameplay you can get from other games, this is a game that took a mundane job and made it into a political commentary. I was skeptical initially thinking that a paper pushing game would be easy and I'd get bored of it. In reality, it was the opposite. The game's difficulty progressed with the story line, or in other words, the levels of bureaucracy and trying not to get too many citations. It gets harder when you have to deal with terrorists and providing for your family. The historical backdrop of East and West Germany (ofc in fictional terms) made it even more realistic and moving. This game impacted me and it is a true masterpiece.  Of course, it is not flawless, at times it can feel a bit repetitive and while you can have many endings (20 in fact), it's hard to replay it immediately (better wait a few months to try it again).   In short, if you'd like a break from an FPS and try to be an immigration inspector then this game is for you.  Glory to Arstotzka.
It's a great game. It gets a bit stressful towards the end, but all in all, it's pretty good.

The concept of this game could be deemed to be somewhat repetitive, however the main point of the game is to make the player think. Finding the discrepancies between the documents can be quite engaging at times, as you have to make sure that they follow the rules that are set out. Following these rules such as remembering what is and what is not allowed, stamping documents can be challenging and for the first time possibly overwhelming, however the more you play the easier it gets and you will have a better experience. The pixel art style works well for this game as it gets you to focus more about the task at hand rather than the graphics shown. This game is definitely one to play if you have an hour or so to pass.

Papers, Please is one of those very pleasant, tiny surprises that comes along every now and again. And I do mean tiny: 30 megs tiny. That's four times the price of an iTunes HD episode for less than one-fifteenth the size, but believe me when I say that you'll spend more time on this game than you ever would watching any episode of any TV show.  The power of the game lies in its simple and complex art style and moral elements, respectively. Your position sees very little of any colour other than greys and blacks, probably reflecting that the morality that the game pushes you towards. Almost your money goes to rent, food and heat for your family at the end of each workday, and you get paid by how many people you process correctly. This would normally just serve to give the players incentive to pay attention and not ♥♥♥♥ up, but the game has the simple trick of any citizen just claiming what any citizen would. Maybe they want to get into the country to see their family or reunite with their significant other, and turning them away means breaking that. Of course, letting them through means you might not be able to afford heat this evening.  The game has problems, sure. If you're not the type for it, the morality system falls completely flat and you just don't care, because there's no real penalty for simply doing your job aside from citizens calling you an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in 16-bit text before disappearing forever. The booth upgrades aren't very helpful, and I can't say that this is the most thrilling game to play if you're playing on a stationary rig that can run many more exciting, if not as compelling, games. That being said, it is still surprisingly engaging for its size; I found myself able to play it (before I bought the Steam version) in class for sometimes hours at a time, just processing and processing over and over. And its size and almost non-existant graphical tax means that no matter your specs, you could run it.  In conclusion, it's more than worth recommending. The phrase 'Simple, yet elegant' is thrown around a lot but it really does find a place here, amongst the endless passports and tickets that will inevitably clutter your desk. If you're the type for it, pick it up anyway, but if you're on the move a lot and switching computers, frequently finding yourself with nothing to do, I couldn't recommend Papers, Please higher. It takes some real talent to make a job that should be boring fun and captivating, and that's just what Mr. Pope has done.  Final Score: 8.5/10

Papers, Please is one of the most innovating and impressive games from this year. Being a sort of point-and-click game, Papers, Please excels in the way it uses it.  You take the role of an Arstotzkan border controller who regulates the border checkpoint in Grestin, Arstotzka. You must earn money by doing your job accordingly and with as few errors as possible in order to feed and protect your family, as well as keeping them healthy and living under a roof.  The game focuses on the basic mechanics of point-and-click, but uses this mechanic in a very different way by allowing the player to check entrees' passports as they attempt to enter the country of Arstotzka. Your duty, as border controll, is to make sure that only people with valid documents enter the country. If you make any errors, small amounts of your salary will be held back, and you may even allow in a terrorist if the person that you allowed entrance carried a bomb and you forgot to x-ray them because they had expired documents, for example.  The game has a very simple art direction, as well as a very simple sound design. Lucas Pope, the creator of the game, really nailed it with Papers, Please, as he created something inspiring, entertaining, and very different.  Papers, Please is one of its kind, and is one of those rare indie games that you should defnitely try out.  The only complaint I have is that the main story is too short, but even so, the game has a freemode and so you can continue to play on without focusing on the main story, even though the main story is crafted in a specific way and has its own events, the freemode is very fun too.  No more needs to be said. Glory to Arstotzka.

At first glance it looks like a boring game... but it is one of the most interesting games I have played so far. It makes you think quite a lot and you end up double checking everyone to make sure that you do not get penalized.
if you have a touchscreen this game is a must in my opinion

With over 20 hi-standard awards achieved already, Papers, Please is seriously ONE OF THE GREATEST GAMES published in 2013.  It's old-school, it's innovative, also imo beautiful in a classic way in its brutally simple appeareance and it made me laugh out loud few times (can't remember when single-player made me actually laugh :D). The concept itself is let alone just brilliant but when laced with a great storytelling in which player can impact and with a gameplay that enhances the back-to-the-childhood feeling you get, Papers, Please is one to remeber. Just the ancient-sounding theme music brings an amused grin to your face - a reminder of the good old times. This is not easy game by any means, requires some brains and sharp eye but not in an annoying way. I found the difficulty very fitting and enjoyable.   Papers, Please may not offer something to play for a very long time right away (depends on person), that said it will surely exceed its value by far anyway in the hands of an average gamer. On the other hand I can see myself returning to this game in future, similarly as with e.g. Max Payne, DOOM, etc. I do not want to give spoilers - one's has to experience this game like it happens in it's story - out of the blue. As I fancy 2013 not a great year regarding to game releases I am glad I have now something to remember and to recommend to fellow gamers.   Glory to Arstotzka!

Played this at my friends with him and had a blast, got hte game myself to and I must say it is one of my top 5 games of 2013. What is with all these indie or early access games that are turning out better than 90% of the AAA games this year?  Anyways, to the game, the atmosphere is well done, the gameplay is fun as hell and it is original. I think the only people who won't like this game are graphics who**** who only like games with beautiful graphics. This game is MUCH more than what you see, check it out! You have to investigate and check peoples passports at a check point. There can be terrorists,etc.. and as you get further into the game you have more things you can use to try and find the people who should not be in entering the country. I actually have felt bad a few times when I had to turn some people down. Very well made game and I hope the devs are working on another game in this series or another new game.

For an Indie game, it's impressive. Get the feel of a communist border guard inspector, and find out what it really means to live under harsh conditions. I have to admit the gameplay can be stressful, but that's one thing that makes this game challenging. I would however reccomend to wait until daily sale, I don't think the price is completely worth it, In my opinion.
It is actually intense, belivie it or not. This games gives you a grey, soviet and a special survival feeling. Play it. Glory to Arstotzka

You have been chosen for glorious position at East Grestin Checkpoint! Enjoy Arstotzkan beauty as you walk to your magnificent office! Smell the Arstotzkan stamps! Get pleasure from many happy and foreign faces! Enjoy the tales of your comrades! The war is over, make new and wonderful friends! The Ministry of Admission is counting on your judgement and your loyalty to Arstotzka! Happy people come from swift processing! Inspect all discrepencies, or else we will have criminals and malcontents in our glorious country! Suspect everyone, glorious comrade Inspector, and bring Glory To Arstotzka! [DO NOT READ FIRST LETTER OF SENTENCES!]

You check papers at border control. All is dull until the first terrorist attack happens, cuts your day short and you realise you are falling short in providing for your family. Then the bribes start. The rebels approach you. Your country oppresses you. A handful of dilemmas and 20 different endings make this game worthwhile. Even if what you mainly do is check papers. Do try it.

There will be several instances where, throughout gameplay, you will yell out, 'I do not have enough room to do all of this.' -- and this is exactly the game's purpose. Working for a totalitarian government is not supposed to be easy, nor is it supposed to be accomodating -- in fact, it is simply exhausting. It feels like work, it is work, and by the end of your day, you feel more and more broken down. The first rejection was hard, then the 500 more just become a statistic; their faces become blurs; their stories become muddled; your morals become bland. Their pleading for your mercy only becomes time wasted to accumulate enough money to feed your family for the day, if they are still alive that is. Friends are murdered, families grow sickly, and the innocent with nothing more than a typo on their passport are hauled away to a place only God knows of. 'Papers, Please' is nothing short of brilliant, where you will be stunned as to how a pixeleated game could conjure such visceral emotions out of you -- thereby also realizing that effective storytelling is never a matter of graphics.  5/5

This game is pretty much in a class of it's own. I'm surprised original ideas are still coming out of the woodworks these days, and boy am I greatful for a gem like this.   If you're a closet xenophobe, who enjoys dark humor, this game might be for you.   Seriously, who knew a stamp simulator could be so much fun.
This game so good, no review required!

This game should not be fun. You scan through paperwork and split families because of bureaucratic nonsense. But for some reason, it IS fun. It's addictive, it's clever, and it's a great laugh.  Buy this game. Seriously.

I was definitely hesitant about this game at first, I watched a couple videos online and it seemed so repetitive and boring. But boy am I happy to say I was wrong. I love how there's different story lines where you can follow the rules or trust in some dodgy people and see what happens. This was my 2nd steam game completing all the achievements and now I plan on playing the endless mode! Definitely try it out, it's fun and frustrating at the same time as you facepalm yourself over silly mistakes over and over.

Amazing game, like no others. This game is revolutionary. The atmosphere of this game brilliantly portraited the life of a border inspector whose living in a harsh and difficult life. Papers, Please is a strange game. The gameplay is entirely monotonous: someone hands you documents, you cross check these documents against a set of ever changing rules, point out any discrepencies, repeat for several hours. Despite the seeming simplicity, PP is incredibly addicting and I ended up completing it in a single sitting, something I haven't done with a video game (even short ones) since high school.   Maybe it's the moody atmosphere that's as disturbing as it is darkly humorous. Maybe it's the idea of having absolute authority over the lives of these virtual citizens. Whatever the case, PP is worth every cent.
GLORY TO ARZTOTZKA

I’m not going to sit here and say Papers, Please is an artistic masterpiece, as those terms get thrown around far too often in this industry. The game isn’t perfect, but is more than interesting enough to overcome its downsides. If you’re looking for something truly unique in the modern swamp of AAA titles, Papers, Please will definitely fill that role. At $9.99, it’s a low-entry oddity that tells a compelling story about failure. And who knows? You might just experience a newfound perspective during your stay in Arstotzka.

Papers, Please is an indie game developed by Lucas Pope, in which you play an immigration inspector whom is working at a border checkpoint in a country named Arstotzka . The goal of the player is to inspect documents using a set of tools and in some occasions to inspect the individual per se, in order to keep criminals out of the country . Everything is a bit unknown, until it will be disclosed , the more you play .   Every work day, you receive a document with informations about particular things you have to notice about, the arrival of important people and/or if you have to take some measures if a specific occasion happens, like having to do body scanning to all civilians who belong to the country of Kolechia . We also have a rule book all the time, so we can know what is allowed in the documents we inspect and if there are any discrepancys, you have to reject the entry to the person and later on, if you want, arrest them . A situation with a spy, terrorists and smugglers with not be uncommon, and you will decide if you will let them pass by, because you can bribed and even threaten .  After a day of work, you receive a wage, which depends on how well you did your job, and you will have to decide where your wage will go, some option include 'food', 'medicine' and 'heat', also as you progress in the story you will be able to choose to move to a better house, but it will also have bigger expenses . You also have freedom of will in basically everything since the game changes with your decisions .  Be careful too, this game will play your emotion and will play mind games with you, sometimes you must choose between doing your job or doing the right thing sometimes, there will be families slip apart because of you, but if you decide to let someone passe the border without the correct documents so he or she can be with her/his family, you will face the consequences . Your gaming experience with this game could end in 20 different ways, each occur depending on what decisions did you take in a certain way because you actually have a lot of choices throughout the story, some of them may include, being part of a conspiration group named EZIC against the government of Arstotzka, accepting bribes and even saving money on medicine or food, which will let to the starvation of members of your family .   This game is worth all your attention, since its incredibly addicting, has a great plot and the gameplay its really original, you will not regret it .    Glory To Arstotzka!    ~ 10/10

I genuinely love the atmosphere of this game, it was masterfully crafted, on every level, the graphics are simple yet oddly charming, the gameplay is solid, and actually requires your full attention, the spirit and story of the game is VERY gripping, and the fact that its a constant battle with your better judgement and your emotions really all just blends in to a perfectly crafted game. easily a 9/10

OK, so I'm sure that when you are reading this review, that you are probably sceptical about getting this game. I think, though, that this game is worth buying for a multitude of reasons. This game requires the player to be very observant. I find it interesting that everything you do in this game affects the story line. I do recommend this game for people who like the Stanely Parable and other strategy games.  Brief Overview (Don't worry, no spoilers...): You have just won the labor lottery, giving you a job working for border patrol. While working for the patrol you have to accept or deny people into the country based on their criminal record, ID, and etc. Some people try to forge documents and illegaly get into the country. You can choose to help the country with its corrupt government, or you can gain the trust of the country and try to destroy it from the inside. Even though all you do is click your mouse and choose wether people are entering or not, I find this game very fun and neat. 8.5/10

Say hello to Jorji! Fun Unique game all around. Has nice replayability with multiple endings, for it being a fairly linear game. Enjoyed trying to unlock all of them and the amount of documents always gives you plenty to do.  Worth full price, should be owned by everyone after sales.

This is exactly what indie gaming is all about. From time to time, while shoveling through all the garbage, you stumble upon this kind of gem that makes it all worth it. That being said this beauty is not without its fauls. It can get a little tedious and frustrating fast (easy crutch mode will alleviate some of that), and once you let it go it takes a little bit of... self convincing to come back to it. Being from or conected to the eastern bloc from where this story draws its roots will help a lot for the general feeling. It will hit home in a special way, but I don’t think it’s mandatory. It’s just a bonus for some of us :)

First of all, this game is depressing.  It puts you in the boots of a poor paper pusher at a border-checkpoint of a dictatorship(ed?) country .   While you are struggeling to keep your family fed and warm, you are deciding over human lives in a always shorter timeframe. Why this? The faster you check the immigration papers of people seeking refuge, the more money you earn each day. But if you make mistakes you can loose money as well. This gets harder every day as the administration releases more and more rules and admittances for you to check. At the same time the game throws you into some moral decisions, where there is no right or wrong. Do I turn down the human-trafficer, although his papers are ok? This could lead to a fine and I could not afford the medicine for my son. Do I take the bribe from the nice man claiming to smuggle medicin for his sick wife?  As I said... this game is depressing. Would I recommend you to buy and play it?  Yes!   Because this game manages something only few games manage to do. To get you involved and question your own morality.  And even if you do not get involved in this depressing atmosphere. The game is still a very good reaction-puzzle-like game that needs you to figure out where the small mistake in the forged immigration documents in front of you is.

To be brief, Papers, Please is a game that is unlike any other in terms of gameplay. The best way to describe it is working in Stalin's DMV, sifting through enough papers throughout a day to make a redwood tree flinch in horror. Unique gameplay itself is more than enough to give Papers, Please a look, but what really makes the game pop is its story. Everyone has problems, and you are no exception. The game puts you in a mentality that lets the little details get to you, taking perfect advantage of its setting to make you worried about even getting to work another day. This game is an interactive experience like no other, and I recommend it to any gamer look for something different.
Incredible gameplay, this is really something new and tasty!

Apparently you don't need graphics or any form of conventional gameplay to create a compelling game. Somehow it's more fun to cross reference documents than it is to shoot any number of anonymous soldiers in most games. Who knew?

To be honest, when I first looked at this game I thought it was garbage, boring, and a joke, so I bought it feeling that it would be comidicly bad (It's my weird sense of humor), but once I started playing it a while, I actualy started to get into the game a bit. It's a lot more interesting and creative than I originaly thought and over all, I feel like I got my money's worth. Glory to Arstotzka!

This game delivers dismal and oppressive atmosphere layered on top of a repetitive mundane task that increases in needlessly bureaucratic complexity, all the while you sit in cramped quarters just trying to do your job well enough to provide your family with ample food, medicine, and housing.  Brilliant! This game entertained me, and engrossed me, far more than I thought such a simple concept could have achieved. It can be very frustrating, due to the layers of detail and bureaucracy, but the more you play this game the better you get at it as those aspects become more and more familiar.  Even at full price it was worth the cost.

Deceptively simple, and engrossing. At first the game feels like a sort of work simulator, but after a while the world slowly becomes more real and engrossing. Also, a good choice for gamers with limited resource computers.

It is a very intense game. There is not like there is TNT everywhere blowing up at the same time, it's very stressful about getting one thing wrong, BOOM got a warning slip. You can get only two warnings then you start paying the cash. Cash in this game is pretty hard to get. One passport accepted will get you only five credits, got a warning where you got to pay is five credits. Denying a passport will get you no credits, and you need the credits at the end of the day. At the end of the day is when your cash will go to use, first is warnings that you got to pay, no matter what you need to pay, next is the rent, it's like real life you need to pay for your house/apartments/box, no matter what you need to pay. Finally is the heat and food, this is the only items that you can check off of not paying, your family of five - Wife, Kid, Uncle, and Mother-In-Law - can go hungry, cold, or both. This game is very intense, soon in the game your going to look at ten different files or more just for one person. Remember: Papers, Please.

First things first: Don't be fooled by the ancient graphics circa 1990. This game is an exciting title in all the sense of the world. Your skills will be tested, your loyalty will be tested, and even your principles will.  You play as a boder employee, in charge of entry to Arstotzka. Your duties are to check if applicants meet the current requirements to enter, but it doesn't end there. You'll face terrorist attacks, criminals and people that rely on you to break the rules (or not) to help them. In a nutshell, your decisions have some actual weight in this title. High replay value, entertaining and absolutely recommended. 10/10

An intelligently disigned indie puzzle game, 'Papers, Please' takes you to experience something new and fun. The decissions you take actually affect the outcome, which was (at least for me) unexpected from a simple indie game. Papers, Please is definetly a one-of-a-kind game and a great addition to any library.

This game is like playing the game of life... make sure your family doesn't starve or get sick and die, scrap by on slave wages, detain people 'for the man' and take nude xray photos... yet it still is addicting as all get up!

Papers, Please puts in the exciting world of border control in a communist territory. You play as Jean Van Clyde Smith, a simple man that was selected through the monthly job lottery to serve as the inspector to the brand new open border between Arstotzka and the countries around it.  However this job isn't all fun and games for there are people out there who don't want to see the border open. Meet new and fun people everyday. Engage in a mysterious alliance with a mysterious of people.  The possibilities are indeed infinite.  10/10 Great Gameplay, Very Nice Score and an Amazing Engaging Story.
like skyrim with immigrants
GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

This is by far one of the best indie games I have ever played! Papers Please was created from scratch by one man. Papers Please reflects on the checkpoints situated in Berlin during the Cold War. You might think that looking at dates, numerical values and pictures is boring, but the way PP does it is really great. It's a fun puzzle game that keeps you thinking.  Everything from the music to the pixelated graphics is topnotch quality. Everyone has different passports and there are different ways of dealing with situations. You have to watch out for workers, diplomats, terrorists, spies and people of the secretive Order group.   Of course, this game is not for everybody. If you enjoy playing generic COD shooters and that's all you play, this is not for you. You are working under time to deny and accept as many people into your country as possible without being fined. You have a family to look after and they all depend on you to pay for food, heat, medicine and rent in your class 8 dwelling.   However, I really wish for new content to be added, like a war breaks out between Arstotzka and another nation and new enemies are added, or you are relocated to a whole new checkpoint or something. I just wish something new would be added.   Apart from the noticable lack of updates and new content, this game is worth it.  Glory to Arztotzka!

Do you like paper? Hate people? This is the game for you! This thrilling, hyper-realistic paper pushing game includes miles and miles of paper-handling. From manuals, to passports, to municipally-issued identification slips, to photo-ids, to so much more! Not just paper, though; stamps. That's right, you get to STAMP your papers. Red and green colors! But mostly the red. Well, if you like the color red, it's a plus! Not only that, you get the hate of an entire population (or so it feels) directed at you for denying them passage into the glorious Arstotzka. And you get to hate them back by denying them even more, those filthy heathens!  Well, to wrap this up in a way those who don't like reading will understand, (TL;DR:) 'Papers, Please' is a great game. Especially if you like paper.

I've only played one round of Papers, Please and I've already witnessed a terrorist attack and detained an Olympic athlete who murdered his wife. I'm pretty sure he was executed by the additional guards that were put in place after the attack. The gameplay is a little tedious, but the gameplay isn't the attractive bit about this game. Its the atmosphere. I've never played a game this atmospheric. Its bleak, depressing, and you feel it. It is a truly terrific game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys an atmospheric, story-driven game.   Glory to Arstotzka!
Needs a soundtrack available

Papers, Please is a dystopian game about border security, although this may seem rather tedious initially, the small, simplistic graphics and constant worry of your family and other challenges presented to the player cause a near total immersion experience, so much so that I forgot to eat for the first time I played it. (*sigh*)  This game is very much worth the asking price, and once you become accustomed to the simple but odd gameplay, it is as addictive as any other RPG or story-based game.

How a game in which you check papers at an immigration station could be so much fun, I don't know - but it is. I loaded this up to 'see what it looked like' and four hours later I was still playing. Very addictive and alot of fun.

Way more fun than you'd expect. My favourite indie game of 2013 by far. Also presents some interesting ideas and viewpoints on the subject of immigration law and bureaucracy that one may not have otherwise thought of. Very light on computer resources. I usually play it on my 4 year old Macbook.

Glory to Arstotzka!  The game is quite different. You're the border entry point official dude who gets to decide if people can come in or not. At first it plays like a game where you spot the error and decline entry... but then your son gets sick...  Then it becomes a game of how much you can bend the rules to not be fined or punished too much for trying to make a few illegal bucks to pay for rent and heat  It's deep.
Was not expecting this to be so good. 10/10

I have to say upfront that i have never really loved or even liked this game, that being said buy this game, its just amazing, personally its not my cup of tea but i still recomend this because its a perfect mix of mechanics and story in a way that everything you need to know is told directly through gameplay, never taking you out of the game for a text dump or a cutscene, man its just a good game.

I would say the subtitle of 'dystopian document thriller' is partly correct. The setting and mechanics in this game are fairly unique I think, where you play a border agent in a country with an oppressive government.  The gameplay itself is actually fairly routine, and can be summarized as rule memorization and observation skills. This is fine, as it works and makes sense within the story. The sound design and aesthetic lend to this very well. There were no performance issues.  I don't think there is that much replayability to the story despite the variety of endings. There is an unlockable endless mode, which could make this fun as a pastime too Still, I'd reccomend this game for its unique experience. Its really not something you see every day.

This game's premise sounds simple - people present you with their travel documents, you check if everything is alright and accept/deny their entry across the border. However, there is an incredible depth to the system as it incorporates moral elements - e.g. some people have invalid passports but their family is awaiting them across the border - will you let them through or send them back?  'Papers, please' rewards you with a salary based on your speed and accuracy. The money you earn are necessary to support your family, so you'd better work hard.   The game has a story mode with multiple endings and an 'endless mode' so there is plenty of replayability as well.  Heaps of fun packed into 50 megabytes of data. Would recommend on any day.

Allow in citizens of glorious Arstotzka!  Check paperwork for discrepancies!  Detain filthy Kolechians and drugs smugglers!  Subsist on meagre salary and try to keep your family warm and fed!  As time goes on, paperwork changes!  Review immigrants and asylum seekers!  Break up families and ruin lives!  Take bribes from desperate men and women!  Detain them anyway!  Survive suicide bombings and terrorist attacks!  Decide whether to follow orders from traitorous secret societies!  Hide evidence of treason from your supervisor!  Gun down people trying to jump the border and bomb your checkpoint!  And don't forget to double-check those expiration dates, or you will spend the rest of your days in a glorious Arstotzkian prison while your family are shipped back to their village!  Violate immigrants' most basic human rights!  Check whether they're carrying weapons, contraband, or incorrect genitals by scanning them with machine that lets you see them naked  Even though you really, really don't want to!
Very good game. Interactive, funny, and compelling. Lets you make choices without going out of its way.

Simple, yet challenging game... Seems more like an actual job than a game infact, though it can be a challenge to be 100% about details... unless you hack of course...  The Game mechanic is basically looking at documents and picking out infomation, about a person, that is right or incorrect, and judging whether they have the right enter or be sent away. Fo instance, you will often have to check dates, passport numbers and even have people strip searched! The quicker you do it, the more people you 'process' and therefore the more money you get and the better chance your family dont die' (If your family die : the state sacks you as it seeks to help people with larger families... How considerate of them...)  The game is not linear in any sense either with added plots that crop up, like a woman who is being transported in as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to then work as a slave, asks for you help her by not admitting a man in.. Besides you are doing the same thing, it seems to develop somewhat with added techniques...   I have bearly gotten to grips with this game, but feels like it has plenty of life in it... Perhaps I will take away the 'non-linear' statement when I play more or play 'endless' mode, but for now there appears to be plenty of detail and interesting aspects to consider it to not be linear.  If you have an attention span of a fish, then you will not enjoy this game... If you enjoy problem solving and a good challenge, then working as an inspector for The Glorious Arstotzka and keeping a family fed, warm and healthy will be right up your street!  Once again an Indie game which presents more than what most A++ industry games do and for a fraction of the price! Get it !

I'm not sure how much this normally costs, but i got it for 2.99. I think its worth it for that price, but only for certain people. This game is not a game about 'Points' or 'How fast can i do this'. this game is where you have to take care of your family on a salary barely enough for your rent, but its a lot more than that. You have to make choices that affect not only you, but the world around you as well. There are choices you make that match risk with reward, and there are choices where you must decided in between this person and your family. Every error you make gets a citation, and after two citations, you get docked payment. People ask you to smuggle them out of the city, but doing so can get your payment docked. This can be very bad for your family. They might beg you or tell you that they will die if they don't get out of the city. You can't do anything unless your willing to sacrifice your family. As for morals, you can accept bribes that can help you, but at a cost. I apologize if this reveiw is all-over-the-place, but this game really is a good game.

It's a very well thought game with a very compelling gameplay. It's also pretty interesting in terms of what it says about human nature and the banality of evil.  It doesn't sacrifice gameplay for it's message though, actually using the game to enchance the message.  tl;dr: It's a good game and it's worth getting, if only for it's low low price.
Most fun I've ever had checking documents.

I just love this game!  So many things to do, so many documents to check late-game that they will **** your eyes, and you can end the game in 20 POSSIBLE ENDINGS!! SOME OF THEM REQUIRE YOU TO NOT DO THE OTHERS' REQUIREMENTS FORCING YOU TO START OVER, AND ONLY 3 ENDINGS ARE HAPPY!!!  So many hard decisions, just SO MANY! For example: on a day, a mother that hasn't seen her son for 6 years will come with an expired document, and this is her only chance to enter, you must choose between denying her, or approving her.  on another day, a husband and wife from a country that they describe as 'tyrannic' are escaping to Arstotzka, the husband has valid documents, but the wife is missing a document, you must choose (again) between denying or approving!  on another day, your sister will be arrested for an unknown reason, your niece now needs a home! your payment is low (5 credits/entrant), and you must choose between adopting her for 40 credits, or keep the money and leave her!  and the hardest of all, a strange group (called *SPOILERS! you must find out yourself!*) will come asking for your help to 'free Arstotzka from its shackles' and tell you that the country's leaders are corrupt and greedy. you can choose to help them and *SPOILERS!*, or you can choose to work for your country regardless and *SPOILERS!*  also, the border gets occasionally attacked by terrorists, at first you can't do anything and they cut the day short but later on, the government gives you a single tranquilizer gun with 3 darts, and now, defending the border is your responsibility (and they still cut the day short!)  the game is very stressing, at first, it will seem like an easy job, but it keeps getting harder and more stressing as you advance in the story, but once you find the key (Gotta go fast!) the game becomes easier, yet still stressful.  despite the stress, the game is great! I can recommend it to anyone with pleasure!  10/10 would get executed again
too much action, it gets tiring by time. 10/10

This game is certainly very different, but it is a masterpiece. You play as a man working at the border checkpoint of a fictional country called Arstortzka. You check passports, documents, permits, etc. of anyone trying to enter Arstortzka. This might sound boring, but it's actually very fun. Once you get into the game, it offers a lot of variety. You don't just check paperwork in this game. You can also test fingerprints, search for concealed weapons, detain suspicious individuals, or even shoot terrorists with a tranquilizer. The game also gives you several moral decisions that will be very hard to decide. It's very hard to explain how this game offers you plenty of variety. It's better to play it yourself. Even after you finish the story, there's still another ending to unlock, and there's an 'endless' mode (which I haven't unlocked yet). This game also has awesome music and sound effects. A masterpiece of indie work.  Score: 92/100

Highly addictive game that is well worth the money. This is one of the few games that I enjoyed completing multiple times to get all of the different endings.

Wow.  The human element.. the struggle.. the oppression..  it's so  real !  After playing this game for only an hour, I have never felt so invested in such an elaborate game that feels so.. real. (and you're just sitting in a border patrol booth the whole time!) Not only must you take careful precision in deciding the fate of desperate immigrants, careless citizens and cunning terrorists, but you must also do this as quickly as possible to earn the proper cash to pay rent and feed and hospitalize your own weak, precious family. You are literally playing with people's lives here! With this combination of panic-driven motivation and life-like themes of nationality and humanity (and even a set of memorable characters!), this masterpiece is certainly one to purchase if you want to try something that feels a little more human and igniting than your average title.  Will you seperate families for faulty documentation to feed the starving family of your own?

While the indie gaming revolution has brought a lot of side-scrolling retro-platformer clones, it also has allowed games like Papers, Please to be released to the public and thrive. The premise of being an immigration officer seems like an absurd concept for a game, but Papers, Please boils down to a familiar puzzle format, tasking you with finding differences between multiple sets of information. The game becomes intense as more and more rules pile on and you attempt to get through them as fast as possible to meet your quota. earning the necessary funds to provide for your family. Tough choices become more and more common as you risk your family's well-being to help a stranger into the country. Overall, the game is solid and supports it unique premise with plenty of moral and mental challenges.
I went into this game not expecting much, but it really is a marvelous game. I highly recommend it.
One of my games of 2013. Much more fun than it looks!

This game can make you care about people whos face never shows emoniton, but their words and you experiences with them make you love them. Buy it, its my game of the year. Do not judge this book by the cover. Whatever bias you may have against crude graphics and a basic layout should be put aside. This game is a simple yet very fun and addictive desing, with a ticking clock that actualy makes you want to perform. I can't recommend this game enough. Great detective thinking on the fly.

The banality of evil shown beautifully. And nothing is more banal than powerless beaurcratic simulation. I guess, it's technically a puzzle game. Yet somehow, despite its subject matter, it's compelling and pleasing to play. Papers, Please is one of the best pieces of sociopolitical commentary in games. It is /the best/ example of mechanics-as-message I can think of.   I don't know if you'll like it, but you should play it: it's astonishing. And if you're games designer, it should be mandatory. There's no quick time events here, chief.

An absolutely unique and fantastic game. It creates an aura of tedium and monotony that is extremely engaging, and creates a unique and powerful experience. You have to deal with constantly changing regulations, need to maintain some level of accuracy to not get fined, yet you have pressure to pass as many people as possible through in order to feed your family. The game also makes you face countless moral dilemmas (accepting bribes, not allowing a husband to follow his wife due to missing a document, strip searching someone due to questionable gender), and really gives you a great amount of choice, with over 20 possible endings. I think starting the game is probably the hardest part, in that you are thinking 'am I really spending my free time validating hypothetical paperwork'? But I think once you get past those thoughts, you can immerse yourself into a very powerful and profound experience that is hard to find in gaming.
Much funner to play than it is to watch, and quite difficult too Glory to Arstotzka

So far, pretty interesting. Some of the characters make me laugh.
Great game; feels really authentic. I love it when the user has to decide between their own moarlity and their job.

Buy it now. This game may not look like much, but it is the most unique expierience I ever had in a game. You are selected by a lottery to work in a border checkpoint in the glorious country of Arstotzka and you spend 10 minute 'days' checking peoples documents and either accepting them or denying them. Each day the difficulty raises, whether it is having to watch out for criminals or stop terrorists who are attacking the checkpoint. At the end of the day you have a home screen. If you didn't process enough people, you may not have enough money to buy heat or food for your family.  This game shines with the people you process. In between the hundreds of people you process in your checkpoint there are little stories that are told. A basic one that you get very early on is that a husband has the required papers but his wife doesn't. The wife pleads to let her in and it is up to you. Do you go against your new rules and risk getting fined, or do you deny her and leave the family seperated (I denied her, Glory to Arstotzka!). Later in the game deeper stories uncover, including a plot to overthrow the government. Everything can change for these digital people because you decided one of two choices. It is amazing.  There are 20 different endings and an endless mode after you beat the story once. Overall this is one of the best indie games I played and I recommend it to everyone.  Glory to Arstotzka!
One of the most stressful games I think I have ever played. My son is sick, my wife is sick, my mother-in-law is sick.  My uncle is not sick though, this is suspicious. Interrogate!

He walks out. ... click click click click ... MOA CITATION: INVALID GENDER -5 Credits ... Great. I can't afford medicine for my son now.   10/10

Normally, a video game is made for entertainment. In 'Papers, Please', the entertainment is a side effect that comes from the engagement you have with the storyline.  'Papers, Please' challenges the very definition of a video game. Excluding open-ended games, most storyline-driven video games can be expressed in another media such as a written novel or a movie; even the most non-linear game with branching storylines and choices, which this game falls into that category. However, 'Papers, Please' can NOT be expressed in another media. It is a personal experience. Your emotion, your personality and your very own engagement with the story defines what the narrative is.  Don't let the graphics tip you off; if anything, if it does tip you off, then it's working on you, because the story is as cold as the visual suggests.  Gameplay-wise, it's a concept that would strangely be classified as 'novelty' despite the very administrative nature of the gameplay. It takes a boring and tiring process that is, reading and checking documents, and turns it into a formidably executed source of entertainment. The green stamp and the red stamp, they don't look terrifying but you'll quickly realize the amount of power they hold, because 'you' are the one stamping the documents.   Replayability will depend on your ability to ignore your emotions, if you do feel any. There are some branching paths in the story that I did not dare to explore because choosing the 'other' option feels too wrong.

'Papers, Please' is a cold-war era alternate earth game where you inspect people's papers at a border crossing and either deny or pass them based on if their papers are correct, or depending on the situation, based on your morality.  It's a very 'serious' game, but has the potential to be extremely funny as well, usually with dark humor. Take for example the man named 'Jorji Costava' (A pun on George Costanza) a man who repeatedly tries to get through the border crossing with papers so effortless ('Arstotzka so great, you don't need a passport!') that it just makes you laugh as you repeatedly call authorities to haul his ♥♥♥ to prison. I have no idea why, but Papers, Please is a fun game. It is simple, tedious, but I will be damned if it isn't fun to kill a couple of hours. If you have a few extra bucks I would take a chance on this game.
