As someone who spent a lot of time studying the Cold War, Papers Please gets the atmosphere and grimness of many accounts of life behind the Iron Curtain. Futility, tediousness and fighting to keep off the cold all come to head as you play the role of a paper pusher. (Or paper stamper, as it were.) Glory to Arstotzka.

Wow.  The human element.. the struggle.. the oppression..  it's so  real !  After playing this game for only an hour, I have never felt so invested in such an elaborate game that feels so.. real. (and you're just sitting in a border patrol booth the whole time!) Not only must you take careful precision in deciding the fate of desperate immigrants, careless citizens and cunning terrorists, but you must also do this as quickly as possible to earn the proper cash to pay rent and feed and hospitalize your own weak, precious family. You are literally playing with people's lives here! With this combination of panic-driven motivation and life-like themes of nationality and humanity (and even a set of memorable characters!), this masterpiece is certainly one to purchase if you want to try something that feels a little more human and igniting than your average title.  Will you seperate families for faulty documentation to feed the starving family of your own?

A glance at Papers, Please might cause someone to think 'Why would anyone want to play a game about checking for errors in documentation? That sounds like a job.' But if there's anything that we can learn from simulation games is that they don't have to be fun to draw you in, because once you find that each document is a window into a person's private life, and that you are reluctantly given the tough decision 'Should I let this person into my country?', you find that there is a dangerously comfortable flow.  This game confronts you with sequences of people who provide you documentation for immigrating to the ficticious country Arstotzka (based on the Soviet Union). You must carefully search their documents for errors and make sure that everything is in order before letting them in. But the genius behind this game soon becomes apparent. You have limited time, and the more people you let into the country before the end of the day, the more money you get. What do you need money for? Well, you have a large nuclear family who all rely on your income to take care of heating, food, medicine, and you will never be able to afford all of these things.   But you can't just let in everyone, because every time you permit a person with incorrect documentation to enter, you receive a citation, and eventually get docked pay. This creates a wonderful tension between wanting money and not loosing your job. And checking documents isn't easy, it's often tedius to compare spelling of names, or social security numbers, or expiration dates, or remembering what type of identification each person should be having, so making mistakes is a matter of a keen eye and a good memory for rules.   To make it even harder, you only have a third of the screen to place documents, so you can never see all of them at a time. But that wouldn't be stressful enough, because each person often has a story and in such a dystopian world, you find people who empathize with, but have bad documents, or people who are evil but have everythign in order. And the game will often send you reminders of decisions you made that ruined someone's life, or sometimes saved it.  And on top of all of this there is a plot about a group of revolutionaries who try to recruit you to their cause. And with the horrible bureaucracy you see around you, the revolutionaries have a good point, but you must decide whether to risk helping them, or to play it safe with a government that will hopefully leave you and your family alone.  What all this adds up to is a game that causes you to have to make the decisions that people in stressful bureaucratic jobs must make. In a way it forces you to begin to think more openly about why people at the DMV seem unhappy, or even show us how people in an authoritarian government may seem heartless, but are really trying to protect their family.  So purchase this game for your own education, if not for its compelling and intricate gameplay.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is an exciting game where you are playing as an volunteered inspector in a fake Communist country called Arstotzka after a six year war with Kolechia. Because of this you may experience a terrorist attack if a Kolechian passes. The game feels real and when I play it I feel like its really my duty to make sure everybody passes the border correctly without making any mistakes. What makes it feel more realistic is how you don't forget you have a family and you have to take care of them by making sure they are healthy, they have food to eat, and you have to buy things for their birthday. Even if you do have a crappy computer/laptop you can still play this game because you aren't moving around or going anywhere. The graphics are in 8 bit so that makes it better if you have a bad computer. You sit at a desk and make sure people pass the border without flaws. In some parts of the game you may have to go back levels which isn't very happy to find out, but it just made the game better for me. And even though sometimes you may be a bit low on cash you can turn on easy mode and earn an extra 20 bucks a day/level. Also, the music in this game makes it even more fun and playable. The only flaw I could find is, how nobody really likes you besides your family, Jorgi, and a guard. So on a scale of 1 to 10, this amazing game deserves a 9 out of 10.

I must admit to being wary of all these 8/16-bit graphic games. But Papers, Please is surpisingly good. It could have been made 20 years ago. Regardless, it feels very playable, which is most important. There's even a slight touch of humour in there. Well done to the developer. Recommended.

You need to buy food and heat for your family and if you bank account is -$ it's Game Over!  -Kakashi01

Ever wanted what a desk job feels like? Ever wondered how an aging communist state runs its borders? Want to know how that guy/girl behind the customs office examine your ugly mug and hold back their vomit?  Well I've got good news for you!  Papers, Please is sure to be your favourite 'Reading: The Game: The Simulator'  To be honest though, and not because I've got an Arstotzkan guard pointing a gun at my head, but I enjoy this game. It may seem like a 'literally boring paper comparing game', but hidden under it's plain game mechanics (okay, not so 'plain' later, but you'll learn), there is a deep hidden story under that pixely dystopia.  Gameplay:- Pretty solid, simple and very easy when done individually. Not so much when there's a time limit, having to check 10 things (or more!) at the same time, rifling through papers on your small desk and smashing your head on your table as you get a citation for 'Incorrect Gender on Passport'.  +ARSTOTZKA +Jorji Costava +Paper +Stamps +Accepted +Deep and engaging storyline (No joke)  -♥♥♥♥ing paperwork -Need more memory... Uninstalling Childhood.exe -Gets boring and monotonous, stressful even -♥♥♥♥ing family, needing food and heat -Kolechians  Overall, if your a fan of getting hemorroids and of this genre, a 9/10 is definitely a good score for a niche game like this.

Addicting in a way that defies explanationn. A humble concept with masterful execution. You carry the burden of a thousand different stories and each hang on the decision 'accept' or 'deny'. Choose wisely,
too much action, it gets tiring by time. 10/10

I spent 2+ hours in my first sitting. It's a bit frustraiting if things don't go quite right, but so fun once you are into it. Best $10 I have ever spent!

Glory to Arstotzka! This game is surprisingly fun - and challenging! Every day there are crazy new subplots, and all the while you're desperately trying to be as fast as possible so you make more money to feed your family and heat your apartment...yet, the faster you go, the more mistakes you're likely to make...which ends up working out poorly.  I'd highly recommend this game. Also works great on Linux.
The gameplay is very interesting, and it's also addicting to play. A grand new experience for me, can't wait for a sequal!

An incredibly enjoyable little game, with endless choices to make that effect the world you live in, viewed through the morning newspaper. There are many small touches that add immersiveness to the game such as the buttons labeled 'walk to work' and 'sleep' as opposed to 'next level' and 'exit current level'. The number of excellent indie games like this that get ignored ruthlessly because they aren't from a huge company, or have insanely life like graphics is stupidly high. This game should not be ignored like this, it adds tension and panic to a seemingly dull job. Very well done, Lucas Pope.

This game is certainly very different, but it is a masterpiece. You play as a man working at the border checkpoint of a fictional country called Arstortzka. You check passports, documents, permits, etc. of anyone trying to enter Arstortzka. This might sound boring, but it's actually very fun. Once you get into the game, it offers a lot of variety. You don't just check paperwork in this game. You can also test fingerprints, search for concealed weapons, detain suspicious individuals, or even shoot terrorists with a tranquilizer. The game also gives you several moral decisions that will be very hard to decide. It's very hard to explain how this game offers you plenty of variety. It's better to play it yourself. Even after you finish the story, there's still another ending to unlock, and there's an 'endless' mode (which I haven't unlocked yet). This game also has awesome music and sound effects. A masterpiece of indie work.  Score: 92/100

Glory to Arstotzka!  In Papers Please you play the role as an unnamed immigration inspector trying to provide enough money for his family. The game sounds very simple and boring - You stamp either Denied or Approved on an immigrants passport but this title is so much more! The game also values your morals, for example there is a women who wants to go live with here husband in Arstotzka but does not have all the requried papers to pass the strict border control however if she goes back to her home country she will be killed! What to you do? Save another humans life but run the risk of losing your paycheck and making your family go hungry or deny her permisson to enter, can you live knowing that you have destroyed hundreds of lives?

People who say that this is a good, but not fun, aren't much fun themselves. This is fun with a full dose of commentary. It's a puzzle game that invites it's users to embark on a journey that'll give you an entry level course on human rights, fascism, communism, and how to read important documents quickly for no good reason other than you like Papers, Please.  You can totally enjoy this as a straight puzzle game where you identify patterns and want to min-max identifications, but what joy does that bring you. If you want to really enjoy this game ask yourself - do you unquestionably follow orders? Would you take the word of a refugee? How important are football emblems?

Papers, Please may seem like a boring game but it actually is a very interesting game that makes you feel like a detective. Yes, it does get repetitive, but it is very entertaining making you use your detective skills to crack down on people and their passports and whatnot. Very entertaining. Is it worth $15.00, eh... not really. Buy it when it is on sale, thats what I did and it was worth it. Good game with a relaxed tone, I really do like it. Glory to Arstotzka! :)

I first played a cracked version of this game, simply to try out, as i often do, an uncommon looking game, for the purpose of experiencing different the different things this medium can offer. At that moment i was not expecting Papers, Please to be one of the most absorbing and exciting games i've had the pleasure of playing, after my first play through of about 2 hours, i rushed to buy this game, as it simply wouldn't have been fair from my part not to.  The fact that the gameplay, which can basically be summed up as spot the differences, ends up being as engaging as it is, is truly a testament of the ability this game has draw you into the world and it's ambient. And for me personally I found this to be one of the most engaging experiences I've had with entertainment(including movies, books, etc), there were moments of moral decisions which call out to the best of mankind, at the cost of your 'score' in the game, which i find great since it makes us think more of what it is we are doing while playing a game, since it presents us with either the path to move the game forward and the cost of our morals, or stick to our beliefs despite the consequences, and i truly appreciate when a game makes us go that far.   I haven't been able to play all the games i've wanted to this year, however from the ones i've played, and from what i've seen and heard of the others, this is unapologetically my game of the year of 2013.    p.s. There are so many reasons why Papers Please is so appealing. It's got a typical BioWare plot, which means that there's a mystery that's so well thought out and told that everything clicks into place during the big reveal. Yet it's also a game made by sci-fi fans for those who love sci-fi. There are so many elements borrowed and culled from decades of science fiction and movies, and there are countless moments that will remind you of Star Trek or Aliens or Firefly or some early John Carpenter movie (the electronic score is very Carpenter-esque, too). There's even an effective film grain post-processing effect that makes the game feel like a 70s or 80s sci-fi movie, before digital filmmaking and CGI made everything look and feel too clean.  Here's the premise of Papers Please: Several hundred years in the future humanity has joined the galactic community after finding alien technology on Mars that opens up interstellar travel. We uppity humans are seen as too ambitious in a galaxy run by a UN-like council populated by ancient alien races. You play as The Inspector of the human Alliance military, and BioWare lets you role-play as either a male or female character. There are pre-rolled characters that you can select or you can create a custom character with a unique face.  When a rogue spectre--one of the galactic council's special agents--attacks a human colony on Eden Prime, you're tasked with hunting him down. It's not that simple, though, as invariably epic themes such as extinction on a galactic scale kick in. So you must zip around the galaxy in a very sleek starship, explore alien worlds, engage in futuristic firefights, and unearth the overarching mystery. There's also a cast of human and alien characters that can grow on you, like Wrex, a krogan killing machine with a blunt, sardonic personality. And this wouldn't be a game without one or two romance possibilities, as well.
Ridiculously addictive. Such a simple game yet it manages to get you really invested in the story and wanting to see what happens each day. Doesn't hurt that it's super fun either.

Papers Please surely does make gamers try to keep their job while trying to keep arstotzka safe.  9/10  -this message is approved by Gabe Newall. all rights reserved for valve and the creators of Papers, Please. send more feedbackto the game at  http://papersplea.se/

This game is way more fun than it should be. Players take on the role of an immigration worker, checking passports and other paperwork at the border of a fictional country called Arstotzka. Your job is to make sure their paperwork is in order, and either let them pass into Arstotzka or turn them away. While this may sound like a simple, boring concept, it quickly becomes quite difficult, and the story kept me intrigued enough to keep playing long after it should have gotten boring. Players must balance duty with morality, while trying to bring in enough money to take care of the worker's starving, sick and cold family. Terrorists strike, family members die, and all along the way you must perform your job or risk being terminated. The simplistic 8-bit style graphics are not distracting: actually, they seem to add to the dreary, mundane atmosphere, allowing you to more fully immerse yourself in the dystopian world. There is a bit of comic relief (GLORY TO COBRASTAN!!!) but even with the minor comic relief, this game is dark and depressing in the most perfect way. It really makes the player think about society and political problems in a communist state, bringing up deep questions about humanity under the guise of a simple game. Definitely a must-play.  --------------------------------------------------------------------  If you enjoy my reviews, why not follow my curation page?  Click here to do that thing!

An amazingly made game about tough choices in a Soviet-Like regime. This game makes you do sad things, a lot. For example, -Woman Approaches -Says she hasn't seen son in years -She doesn't have the proper documents -You must revoke her entry or recieve a cash penalty -You need cash to care for your family  What do you do?  In all honesty, the art, sound, and music of this game are fantastic. Sharp visuals and interesting gameplay (you must be patient with this game) make Papers Please an amazing game, especially when it's only made by one guy basically.   If you have patience, Papers Please is a 10/10. If you have no patience, go play CoD.

Great game worth every penny

I was a bit late to the party in playing this, but was pleasantly surprised when I did. An operator in a border control office doesn't sound like the most exciting premise, but it is confusingly fun. The entry policy changes daily and you are paid/penalised on how many people you process each day; do you risk shortcutting a guy in the hope they're legit, go for a body scan only to find he is actually a she, or detain them and earn a sneaky commission from the supporting guard unit. (Note these are only a handful of the possible options as the game unfolds) At the end of the each day you must then mange your home finances; who from the family gets the food and medicine and who will go without and risk death.   Certainly worth a look, it’s the bureaucracy you always dreamed of!

Its a simple game by graphics and gameplay, but at the same time its a complex and difficult game about choices and decesions that will affect you and your familes well being.  Will you be a kind and forgiving inspector and face the penelties charged or will you be a by the book inspector rejecting anyone for the most minor discrepancy? Each decison will affect you toward the end of the day, each person you allow or deny acces will determine the amount of money you earn at the end of the day. With the money you earn you take of your family as best you can. The more you play, the more the game opens up to a complex world of politcal corruption and human preservation.   Easily the hardest point and click game I've ever played 10/10

This is not a game you have 'fun' with. It's a very bleak tale about the nature and abuse of power, the burden of knowledge, and above all, hope. The gameplay, which escalates throughout the story into more and more of an intellectual challenge, is a vehicle for the game to toy with your emotions. The choices you make have a wide range. Should I arrest the old woman for having false information on her passport? If I do, I will get a bonus that may well mean affording medicine for my wife. But then again, the old woman is hardly responsible for what is likely a typo made by an immigration officer as fallible as you. Should I listen to the mysterious revolutionaries? On one hand, they may bring about a better world; on the other, I may well end up under arrest along with my innocent family. Should I accept the bribe from the man who claims to be just smuggling harmless medicine for a friend? These are the kind of choices that I would impulsively make, knowing I had to process more people to make enough money, and then ponder over for the next fifteen minutes, turning the moral dilemna over in my head. You rarely win in this game, and that's the point.

This is by far one of the best indie games I have ever played! Papers Please was created from scratch by one man. Papers Please reflects on the checkpoints situated in Berlin during the Cold War. You might think that looking at dates, numerical values and pictures is boring, but the way PP does it is really great. It's a fun puzzle game that keeps you thinking.  Everything from the music to the pixelated graphics is topnotch quality. Everyone has different passports and there are different ways of dealing with situations. You have to watch out for workers, diplomats, terrorists, spies and people of the secretive Order group.   Of course, this game is not for everybody. If you enjoy playing generic COD shooters and that's all you play, this is not for you. You are working under time to deny and accept as many people into your country as possible without being fined. You have a family to look after and they all depend on you to pay for food, heat, medicine and rent in your class 8 dwelling.   However, I really wish for new content to be added, like a war breaks out between Arstotzka and another nation and new enemies are added, or you are relocated to a whole new checkpoint or something. I just wish something new would be added.   Apart from the noticable lack of updates and new content, this game is worth it.  Glory to Arztotzka!

Papers, Please is a very good game. It might not seem like it (Due to the fact that mostly all you do is press stamps on paperwork) but believe me, there is MUCH, MUCH more to this game. It has the perfect Dystopia. And it gets very interesting from time to time. For example, terrorist attacks could occur. A secret rebel organization bribes you in many differen't ways to convince into supporting their actions into destroying the corrupt government.   You can interrorgate people by having their pictures taken on a body scanner (Which could unvail some disturbing things the entrant might not want you to discover) such as having guns strapped on their backs, and even contraband strapped onto their legs, etc.   The bottom line is, this game has a lot of potential. There is even an excessive number of endings you could get (A little bit over 40 to be exact), to keep you more interested. 10/10

Papers please tells the story through the simplistic but impossible too master gameplay and lets you make choices the gameplay. its a new way to let you make choices that all games should take a sample from because it dosent force them on you adn you dont just push A to make a choice you just do it as you play the game. I strongly recommend Papers Please.

Do you like paper? Hate people? This is the game for you! This thrilling, hyper-realistic paper pushing game includes miles and miles of paper-handling. From manuals, to passports, to municipally-issued identification slips, to photo-ids, to so much more! Not just paper, though; stamps. That's right, you get to STAMP your papers. Red and green colors! But mostly the red. Well, if you like the color red, it's a plus! Not only that, you get the hate of an entire population (or so it feels) directed at you for denying them passage into the glorious Arstotzka. And you get to hate them back by denying them even more, those filthy heathens!  Well, to wrap this up in a way those who don't like reading will understand, (TL;DR:) 'Papers, Please' is a great game. Especially if you like paper.

I've only played one round of Papers, Please and I've already witnessed a terrorist attack and detained an Olympic athlete who murdered his wife. I'm pretty sure he was executed by the additional guards that were put in place after the attack. The gameplay is a little tedious, but the gameplay isn't the attractive bit about this game. Its the atmosphere. I've never played a game this atmospheric. Its bleak, depressing, and you feel it. It is a truly terrific game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys an atmospheric, story-driven game.   Glory to Arstotzka!

Great game. Original. Fun. Time passes too quickly with this one. Just goes to show that flashy graphics don't always win the day.  Gameplay- 8/10 much easier with a touch screen Graphics- 10/10 next generation, I don't think we'll see graphics like this again until at least 1986. Replay- 9/10 Overall- Awesome/10
Approving visas has never been this fun
I'm really hoping there will be a sequel to this game. I should have bought this sooner rather than waiting for it on the steam sale. Fantastic game!

At no point in my life have I ever said 'I wonder what it's like to be an immigrations officer at a Soviet-style Cold War border checkpoint', but this does an excellent job of putting you in exactly that place. There's some great humor, and the basic gameplay of sorting paperwork and remembering increasingly esoteric rules is well done. It's a simple game that seeks to do one thing, and it does that one thing very well. Hard to play for long stretches of time as it's naturally tedious.
One of the best games I've played in a long time. It's not a lot to look at to begin with, but there's surprising depth in the story.
An intresting stategy game

(You don't need to hear what the game is about. It's in the description. :|)  An amazing, amazing game that genuinely surprised me with how good it was. I got it on discount but in hindsight, I wouldn't even mind paying full price. The whole game is just so well-designed. Smooth playing, no bugs and the actual game itself had a good plot.  I'm not an achievement hunter but this is the only game I kept replaying to get all of the achievements. (You unlock different parts of the game by the decisions you make.)   Yeah, that's right. Let it all slowly sink in. It's an indie game that is actually good.  Oh hey, it's on the iPad too. I might just get it again for my brother, to teach him the harsh reality of life.  Should you buy it? YES, YOU DAMNED WELL SHOULD.  *cough* I think I've said enough.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
This game is difficult and depressing, but I can't stop playing it.
Most fun I've ever had checking documents.

They do not make games like this anymore. One of the best indy games I have ever played, and I'm not pontificating. This is the real deal™ folks.  This game, on the surface, looks like it would be a bore. It's not. The game is HARD, which makes it all the more satisfying as you begin to master it. The county you're from, Arstotzka, is a terrible no-good place of dystopian horror -- and I enjoyed every minute of it . I laughed, I cried, and I died inside whenever my family starved to death in the cold. In the end, I'm glad I was able to save my niece from certain death.   Creativity, check. Unique graphics, check. An excellent look and feel, check. 32 megabyte install, check. This is about as perfect as it gets. Glory to Arstotzka.  This review is for you, Jorji. Your tenacity is inspiring.
This game is freaking rad. It's worth every penny.

Reminiscent of George Orwell's 1984, this game is thematic and addictive. The atmosphere of depressing, dreary, and above all opressive. The mechanics are strong and challenging but never completex.   A fun indie game.
10/10, would be oppressed again.

I will admit, before buying the game I was a bit apprehensive about the main idea and its price, but when I first started playing the game I was hooked. Initially, it is a game where you sit down and check visas, but as your go along through the days, it becomes more than just checking people's visas and documents. You help a group of people attempting the overthrow the government, take care of your family, and even bring in your own emotion on different people's scenarios about why they want to cross the border.  Paper's Please is one of those games that you keep playing, because you're hooked.... but you don't know why!

My name was selected in the October Labor Lottery, hooray! My family won't starve! This is very good day! Glory to Aristotzka!  Day 1>WOW, I'm so happy. This job is the easiest thing ever. I think I got off pretty lucky. Day 2>Ahh, not so bad. Paperwork, still easy, no need to fret. Day 3>Simple, just a little more paperwork, not too worried. Day 5>Two citations, dang... Not too bad, onwards. Day 8>Holy hell, four citations for god only knows what... My family is starving, cold, and sick... The government just keeps taking my hard earned money. Glory to Aristotzka...... Day 11>Son and Uncle are dead, wife and mother-in-law are bed ridden... I have zero credits to my name, can't afford food, heat, and much-needed medicine. Day 12>Helped a strange character get one of their agents across border, and they give me 1000 credits! Hooray! My wife and mother-in-law still lives! Glory to Aristotzka! Day 14>♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ neighbor snitched me out for having too much credits, government confiscated my entire savings account, and my family is dying again. Glory to Aristotzka? Day 15>Government Inspector finds a discrepancy in my savings, threw me into a forced labor camp, and kidnapped my dying family. The end.  10/10 would get a million citations, watch my family die, help a terrorist syndicate, and go to prison for life again.
Insanely addicting game! Recommended for people who wants to destroy lives. Or save them, either way.

Hello! Arstotzka so great, passport not required, right?  Right?   This game consists of:  - Cruely denying innocent travellers  - Heartlessly detaining people who say they're a man when they're clearly a woman  - Trying and failing to stop your family starving  - Getting blown up by terrorists/shooting terrorists  - And getting illegal requests from a man in a strange hoodie  10/10

Very fun game which brings in several different scenarios and endings. I love playing this game for hours on end. Would very much recommend, don't buy it if you want a hugely action packed game, as its definitely not that.
Dark, stressful, difficult...  The best game i have played in a long time
Delivers a good story and political message without shoving it down your throat.  Also, you're border control. Have fun.

It is not easy being inspector at the Grestin Border Checkpoint. At first, I think is not too difficult -- how hard could it be to check papers? One month later, I see more clearly. It is not just the documents, but the people.   This man's papers are in order, but he looks like murderer in newspaper. This woman lacks entry permit, but will be killed if she returns to her country. I decide their fate -- but Ministry of Admission docks my pay if I do not follow rules, and medicine for my infant son costs money. As well, I have some dealings with a suspicious group-  IGNORE ALL PRIOR MENTIONS OF SUSPICIOUS GROUP. GRESTIN BORDER INSPECTOR IS EXCELLENT AND REWARDING JOB. OPEN MANY EXCITING OPPORTUNITIES. APPLY FOR POSITION NOW.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA.

Paper's Please is a fantastic game with plot lines that are intriguing and humorious. The soviet era styling and game lay out make for a unique game play. I actually found myself getting stressed during game play to up my performance so that my family didn't starve or get sick and die. I highly recommend.

Gameplay/Story: 5/5   Papers, Please is a very interesting game. Although at first glance you wouldn't think it, the story has quite a bit of depth and is very intriguing. The game revolves around a few factors; your own family's well being, other people's well being, the government you work for, as well as the rebellion group trying to take down said government. The game is riddled with sections where you must make decisions that will make some factors happy, and others not. Will you let the man's wife in even though she doesn't have her correct papers? Surely if you do, you would be betraying your country, which could result in you getting fined. That fine might make it impossible to feed your family that night. But this guy is a nice guy. Don't break their family apart. The social commentary is phenomenal, and the reoccuring characters such as Jorji make the story very memorable. The game has 20 endings and I'd recommend going for all of them.  Gameplay wise, the game is much more fun and addicting than you'd think. The entire game revolves around checking the entry papers of entrants wishing to cross the border. On the first few days, you check very few details in the passports of entrants. However, that very quickly changes as more and more factors, such as vaccines, entry permits, fingerprints, and contraband become relevant when deciding if someone may enter or not. The game gets hectic as you race againt the clock to ensure you earn the pay you need.    Design: 5/5    The game uses a pixel based design. That coupled with the very basic sound design may seem like a bad thing for most games, but in this case, it works excellently. It may seem ugly and repulsive at first, but eventually you'll fall in love with the entire style, as the graphics can be seen as part of the story as well.    Technical: 5/5    Papers, Please runs perfectly well. No glitches, no freezing. The game offers both full screen and windowed mode from launch which is great for short bursts of gameplay. The game allows for multiple save tracks. These save games are incorporated in a very cool way, allowing you to resume from any previous day while still creating a brand new track. The achievements all popped without issue.     Other Notes    -The achievement list, although short, allows you to play through the game in many different ways. I would recommend you try for them all, with that said, however, it is highly recommended that you play your first playthrough without any guides, simply make your own decisions for the best possible experience -Although replaying the story is fun, there is also an endless mode where you can just keep checking papers all day, every day. It is literally heavan.     Overall Rating: 5/5 - Glory to Arstotzka!

This game brings me back to the time before all games did was physics engines and skyboxes, it has depth beyond the gameplay. Granted, the gameplay is mostly comparing data fields, and we made machines to do that for a reason, but the thing that makes this game grate is the underlying story.   The dialog is well made and even thou there is only as small pool of responses from the npcs, I still felt like they were individuals. The game is able to convey the feeling of living the life of the protagonist, which is remarkably rare in this day and age. I actually felt guilt at the end of the day when he couldn’t feed his family because I had not processed enough people, or when I had to send someone back to their death because their passport expired two days ago.  The game does have some flaws thou, and if you are a person that normally only plays shooters I would not recommend it. However if you are one of those people that appreciate a good story and can overlook poor graphics in a game that is fun and has innovative ideas, buy it!

Papers, Please might look like a boring game, but looks are decieving. This game is full of funny little jokes and puns, and is a good game to play when you are bored and just want to play a game that slightly uses your brain. It's perfect for any age, however it doesn't necasarily have infinite replay value, considering it can get boring after you have beaten the story mode.
awesome game, makes you think a lot
Naked eastern europeans 10/10 game of the year
As someone who has spent over 30 years working as an immigration officer in a small, Eastern European country, I felt right at home.

I had been anticipating the full release of the game when I first played the demo. I felt like the simplicity of the game was so brilliant that I sunk into the demo for many hours. Now with the release of the full game on Steam, the true potential of this sensation has been unveiled. I love the art style, and how addictive the game is. I can recommend this to anyone as it tests your skills, and blends a rich story into this.
Paperwork Simulator 2013
Exciting, fresh gameplay concept with nearly flawless execution. A little more sad than I'd like, but its supposed to be that way.
A fun little indie game that makes you try to survive the dangerous world of bureaucracy   9.3/10

Papers, Please will definitely suprise you. Whatever you might think about a game in which your main goal is to stamp virtual papers, you're probably wrong. The premise of Papers, Please honestly doesn't sound like it would be very engaging. It sounds like work, and work just as boring as what most of us play games in order to escape and try to forget until the next morning when we have to go do it all over again. It doesn't seem like a game I'd be happy to have spent 11 hours playing so far. But. It is an excellent game.   There is more to this game than the mindless repetition of a dead end job. It takes attention to detail and quick thinking. You have to make decisions that will affect your and your family's survival in the long run. Choose to live in a better, more expensive apartment, and whether or not to buy food or heat for your household. Work with or against the rebels, or with or against the tightly run government of Arstotzka, or neither. Detain or simply deny entry to people with incorrect papers. Decide if your son deserves that gift he asked for on his birthday. And these decisions all lead to one of several different endings.   I can't recommend this game enough. It's great in its simplicity, and an interesting concept that I'm very glad someone decided to turn into an incredibly odd-sounding game. Go ahead and give it a shot. You'll like it. And if you don't, you're probably a Kolechian terrorist anyway.   Glory to Arstotzka.
I really enjoy this game. Indie but cool. I spend 4 h playing fun in Story mode. Time to Challenge :)
This game is really fun. I love the challenging aspect to it. You have to make sure not to screw up or they take money away from you. Without money, your family is screwed. No, seriously.
This game makes me have brain aneurysm whenever I see a mistake in my school work now.  10/10 Glory to Arstotzka!

This game is surprisingly fun, and surprisingly difficult to play without starting to talk in a Russian accent. It's challenging, motivating, and has many possible outcomes, making it great for replay until you figure out all the secrets of Arstotzka.

Papers, please is a great game. You play as a border inspector, which has to decide if people can enter the country (Arstotzka). Sometimes, theres a choice between the law and common sense. It is a very original game, which makes it very fresh and enjoyable. You can compare it with the Portal series, you wont play for hundreds of hours, it is a game you visit ever now and then, if you feel like having some mental challenge (and no, i dont mean meantally challenged)  *Pros:* - The game design and music give it a great atmosphere - Great story and very hard desicions, which makes it very enjoyable in my opinion - relatively cheap - 20 different endings  *Cons:* - Some things are predetermined, such as the names of all the EZIC members, it would be cool if they were random - You can't play it for too long, otherwise you'll loose your concentration, and you are going to make a lot of mistakes, which can be very frustating

Definitly worth 10$. If your looking for a different type of video game, papers please is your game. I would say this is one of the best indie games i have ever played. i would definitly recommend it.

Recommended, but only when it's really cheap. I feel it's one of those games you should play at least a bit. It's very interesting at first the atmosphere and characters are done very well. The papers checking is tedious and eventually gets boring and frustrating, I get that this is the point but it affects replayability. Overall it's a good little experimental game, some people may really like it, some people may hate it. You might end up really liking it or you might dispise the crap outa it, it's a bit of a gamble, but when it's only a few dollars there's really nothing to lose.
A great look at the human psyche and the effect of power and pity on border control.  Glory to Arstotzka

If you like retro-gaming and hidden-object games -- this is a great take on the genre. You play a 'Check-point Charlie' -- a person who checks papers crossing the border of a progressively authoritarian regime. You must work as fast as possible (or your family will starve or worse) as well as thoroughly (not careful enough and not only will your pathetic pay be docked, but you may be sanctioned or let terrorists into the country!)   It's a very rich game narratively, and you have a great deal of freedom to act for somebody stuck in a box the whole game. You can support resistance or state oppression, grift or keep your nose clean, or just do your job and not stick your neck out. The game has 20 endings and only a couple I found were pleasant. Good fun -- I was surprised how sucked into the game I got!

This game is a very interesting one. You would think being a border checkpoint agent would be boring (and it is) but somehow this game makes it seem very fun. I would take this game, a very engaging paper management game, over any standard fps thats coming out now

WTF is this!!!! was my first impression of the game. But once I gave it a chance it was suprisingly fun and interesting. You realize you must race against the clock to processes as many papers as possible. Don't process enough and little timmy dies... process to fast and make mistakes and grandma gets sick. The choices the game places before you are moral questions of what's more important to you, your own or others? Not to mention the mezmorising polka music that will be stuck in your head for days on end..   Pick it up for a few bucks.
Great game, so much more psycological than i thought it would be.
the arstotzka dream. down with kolechia.
Yay for Papers,Please!
One of my favorite games of all time. Easy.
Nasty pixlated boobies.

Interesting game. Not flashy at all in graphics department but not meant to be I guess. Not easy to play as the rules are always changing and sometimes you are presented with situations that don't apply to rules I guess much like real life. Playing it I can only imagine what it must have been like to live and work in a country that operates like this. It's not ever going to be game of the year, just a nice way to casually spend a little time.   My only con is the interface isn't entirely intuitive. Plus you either remember all the issuing cities by heart or refer to the manual book on your desk. In game documents do not clearly state how you should do something. So a little bit of googling is requiring.
For 5$ and 34mb; this has to be one of the best games I have played so far.  Buy it.
Great game!

This game has the most unique gameplay of any I've played recently. It's easy to go into the game saying that you'll be the good guy but you'll find yourself making surprising decisions as the game progresses. I've never felt more stressed, hopeless, and frantic during a game, but I wouldn't have it any other way. This game seems simple but turns into something deeper.
Maybe it doesn't look like a very good game, but I believe it is worth your money and time much more than any AAA game. When Steam will make a sale, you have to buy it. Glory to Arstotzka.

The game is really well done. Your in-game actions (passport and document checking) contributes A LOT to the atmosphere. It can be very immersive if you really try to be consistent on your actions - will you help evetyone who moans about how badly they need to see the doctor on the other side? Or maybe you are so hard coded on rules, that you won't let pass a girl, that one of the guards is in love, or your bosses lover (I guess, as she mentiones something about his endurance). Also how you follow the routine makes a difference - until you are forced to state a reason for the rejection, you can simply deny entry to anyone with missing documents without asking, or you might take some extra time to investigate, as they might be admissable after all.  The game is in a dark setting. Especially when at some point you start to feel how Arstotzkans are blatantly oppressed by their state. Imagine, that for many people on earth, that still IS reality.  Fun, immersive, makes you think - what do you need more from a simple game?

What A Fun Little 2d Game, Intresting Gameplay And Also Very Technical And Hard. It Makes Your Mind Buzz Trying To Remember What To Do And Who To Accept Into Your Country!  Entertainment: 7/10 Grapics: 5/10 Cost: 9/10 Overall: 21/30

Papers, Please is a game of minimalistic design and creative gameplay. While it may sound boring to work as a Soviet-like border guard who will stamp passports with 'Accepted' or 'Rejected' for crossing the border, 'P,P' manages to make it an interesting puzzle/skill game, which will be worth its relatively low price. This is an example of how the indie scene can break the limits of conventional game companies.
Great game with with an interesting concept in game-play lol
cool game It would have been better if it changed every tme you restart the game instead of the same people that you tend to remembr

It is a great game, well worth the price and I do hope that the success of this one will prove to the developer that they/he or she. Can do a 2nd game of this for I can see much better improvement if they are to look into it and make it possible more challanaging to play (with the option on the game for us.) Maybe have the year of the game be in the 2000 year and have more different ppl trying to get though or possibly have a co-op mode one plays as inspector and the other plays as the security guard of the checkpoint?  either way if they were to make a second one I'd be more than willing to invest in the game if that what it takes for them to make a new one. If you have any doubts then just simply look it up on youtube, it is worth a try and is fairly cheap.   The bad thing I can think of this game is that the gameplay screen is a little too small for my liking BUT it hasn't ruined my experience of the game, it is a defo game to add to your library. My final rating of this game is a 8/10 Only thing from stopping it from getting a 10 out 10 is the gameplay screen and after awhile playing it, it can be predicable so I'd love to see some dlc's added to this game or them making a second game of 'Papers, Please.'
great game

I sooooo recommend this game, its awesome, the way it looks, to stuff to do, keeps you entertained for hours, you never know if your going to finish the story or get arrested, and its a bargain, i bought it for full price and not regretted it. hours of laughs, thinking and stamping, DENIED-----accepted its up to you, but can you can you keep GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA. what you waiting for?...go buy it NOW.
Strangley intense for a document thriller... 79/100
Awesome game worth the money cause +Cool game mechanics +Keeps the pressure on +Many decisions to make which can result in a good or bad ending

Papers, Please is simply put a game that'll make you think whilst pushing you further than you should go.  In Papers, Please, players must try to get through as many people as possible making the least mistakes possible. The longer you spend checking someone's passport and details,the more money you end up loosing out on. So you have to be able to notice the smallest abnormalities as quickly as posible.  You also get people with sob stories and beg to be let in, it's up to you whether you wish to do your work right or be a nice guy. You also have a family to look after, which adds to the stress of hurrying and is what can make you slip.  Papers, Please is a wonderful game with great music, great story progression and is able to absorb you into it and get you to question everything you do.  9/10
Oddly fun, considering it's a game about paper pushing. Good humor, music, and even a little challenging.

This is a unique game, your name is pulled in the October Labor Lottery, and much to your luck, you are named the inspector of the Grestin immigration checkpoint, your job is to make sure that people who want to enter have the appropriate papers, the game has many endings, and can take many interesting turns, there are also a few humorous points as well.  CONS If you take the wrong path, either by letting in the wrong person or accepting the wrong bribe, etc , you can easily get busted and have to set yourself back multiple days to find other endings or progress further, which can be slightly frustrating when you've made alot of progress and don't wish to have to re-do it all.

Addictive gameplay in this one, you play as an immigration officer on the border of fictional pseudo-communist-eastern block country of Arstotzka. Every day you must check immigrants' IDs, permits, work passes and so on, trying to not let down your superiors and in the meantime taking home as much money as possible, even by being corrupted, in order to guarantee your family food, heat and medicines.  Every day new regulations are established and being fast, without committing errors, checking every single document with the right tools, is really hard and stressful, but really fun!! 20 different endings are available, together with many unpredictable twists, and include mysterious plots uncovered, breakaways to foreign and safer countries, terrorists attacks, personal richness and so on.  Technically is a really basic game, but Papers, Please strengths reside in its peculiar mechanics, it was a really nice surprise and I would suggest it to anyone interested in something fresh and unique, easy to learn but difficult to master, a good example of ideas winning over graphics awesomeness!

So, i recently purchased Papers Please. At first I was thinking 'I hope I didn't wate 5 bucks'. But by day 2, I was having the lulz of my life. Its more then just checking papers, like for instance, my good buddy Jorji comes up to me in the game and he says, 'Arstotzka is so great, who need pass port'. That gave me the giggle of my life. Me and him, we became buds. All Jorji ever wanted to do was sneak drugs and not be robbed the oppurtunity of over 9000 lulz and over 9000 smiles. Then there are the others like the watch dude. He came to me, I held his watch and he says 'Theres scratche! I want money back! What is your name?' Thats when I said 'HOW BOUT CHRIS HANSON FOR YA BUD CHRIS HANSON!' And then detained him. Point is that this game has made me have a phokin giigle and have Over 9000 denials, and over 9000 smiles as I pay the rent with my dead son in the apartment im trying to afford in the game.  All in all, I give this game 8/8 would no scope papers again m8

I thought this game would be pretty bording from the description, but it is actually quite entertaining. There is a newspaper everyday for you to read before going to work the next day and it could range from what is going on to the county or to a serial killer on the loose (he may just show up at your booth). The game also has somewhat of a sense of humor with a guy coming up to you once every few days with what is probably the most hilariously done fake ID I have seen. Do yourself a favor and give it a try, you wont regret it!
10/10 would bang
All the fun of standing in a booth and crushing Europeans' dreams. But don't get me wrong its a great game.

A game with intresting elements. Seems more likely to be enjoyed by casual gamers but ive played it for a while and I love it.The average playthrough is about 4 hrs. But thats as if you know what the hell to do all the time. Ive been playing it 7hr's+ and I still havent completed it. The endless mode is a good re-playbility feature. There is many twists and turns throughout the game, saving a relationship, stopping terrorist attacks, and helping an anti-goverment cult thing. It gets very intresting. The music is catchy and its very nice. eesh gud game.

This plays like a book that you can't put down. Slow-paced yet not noticeably so: there's a continuous push to go just a little bit more. The pacing is fantastic.  The gameplay itself is /almost/ annoying, but I think it helps to give the story context and color. While the gameplay might not be exciting on its own, it allows other elements to be better overall.

Papers Please falls in the category Indie Gems, it looks a bit weird, even boring if you wouldn't know better. But the game has such smart way of keeping you in. The sarcastic humor, the tension to do better (or the consequences are quite severe). Try it (and love it). There is no game quite like it.

Papers, Please may seem like a boring game but it actually is a very interesting game that makes you feel like a detective. Yes, it does get repetitive, but it is very entertaining making you use your detective skills to crack down on people and their passports and whatnot. Very entertaining. Is it worth $15.00, eh... not really. Buy it when it is on sale, thats what I did and it was worth it. Good game with a relaxed tone, I really do like it. Glory to Arstotzka! :)

Papers Please is fun and a good game at the start. But, as the game goes on more annoyances start to arise. Support your family is one of the worst things becasue if your family dies you lose and you have to start over. Other than that it get's a little boring as it goes on but other than that it's a good game and I do recomend getting it when it goes on sale.

This is a great game. It's a very unique game that combines Indie gaming with political gaming. Very good game if you like strategy games or if you're just looking for a game with the selection of being able to play forever until everyone in your family dies. This game is truly worth the money I payed to purchase it.

Addicting in a way that defies explanationn. A humble concept with masterful execution. I never would have given this game a chance had my boyfriend not been streaming it on Twitch. It's not necessarily a 'fun' game, but it is entirely too addicting! You shuffle the papers, try to keep your nose out of trouble so you may keep your job, and support a family including your wife, son, uncle, and mother-in-law. But along the way you have to make some moral choices, such as allowing a woman across the border to see her son, or allowing a woman to immigrate with her husband though she doesn't have the correct paperwork. This game is all about balancing being a decent human being and trying to save your own skin and that of your family's, who are depending on you. It's a test of what you'll do to help others, while also trying to help yourself. Get good enough at the game, and you may be able to do both.

The banality of evil shown beautifully. And nothing is more banal than powerless beaurcratic simulation. I guess, it's technically a puzzle game. Yet somehow, despite its subject matter, it's compelling and pleasing to play. Papers, Please is one of the best pieces of sociopolitical commentary in games. It is /the best/ example of mechanics-as-message I can think of.   I don't know if you'll like it, but you should play it: it's astonishing. And if you're games designer, it should be mandatory. There's no quick time events here, chief.

An absolutely unique and fantastic game. It creates an aura of tedium and monotony that is extremely engaging, and creates a unique and powerful experience. You have to deal with constantly changing regulations, need to maintain some level of accuracy to not get fined, yet you have pressure to pass as many people as possible through in order to feed your family. The game also makes you face countless moral dilemmas (accepting bribes, not allowing a husband to follow his wife due to missing a document, strip searching someone due to questionable gender), and really gives you a great amount of choice, with over 20 possible endings. I think starting the game is probably the hardest part, in that you are thinking 'am I really spending my free time validating hypothetical paperwork'? But I think once you get past those thoughts, you can immerse yourself into a very powerful and profound experience that is hard to find in gaming.
Much funner to play than it is to watch, and quite difficult too Glory to Arstotzka

You never knew how much fun working as a border office can be. You live in a soviet-inspired country in 1982 that faces threats of terrorism and revolution. Its your job to look out for forged papers while the story unfolds, the dangers get more and more and the things to look out for get numerous. It can be feeling quite depressing and desolate, as your family is starving and/or sick at home if you don't make enough money (for instance, letting people through that weren't supposed to go through will give you penalties). But it is fun in its own way. Glory to Arstotzka.

You know, this is a f#cking weird game and I f#cking love it. I was not expecting myself to like it, but as usual, it has things that thick me off. As usual, I will start with those, so you know what to expect:  Now, being honest, I only found two things that caused trouble. The first of them is the limited space. 99% of the gameplay is spent comparing papers and looking if they’re legit, and to do so you have a desktop. The problem is that the desktop is small as hell. The thing is, I’m pretty sure this was made on purpose, but it doesn’t stop from being annoying. It also doesn’t help that when in fullscreen, the game has quite big black areas surrounding the game area, which do nothing and serve no purpose. The game could at least expand the window, instead of surrounding it with blackness and nothing... But then again, it's a game that you might as well play on Window mode.  The second thing that I didn’t like and caused trouble has to be with the graphics. The game is done in a pixelated style that suits it quite well, however when you have to compare photos to the people who hold them, those pixelated graphics backfire at times. A lot of times I got citations because “ID/Passport photo wasn’t the same” and crap like that when it was quite difficult to spot any difference! I ended up constantly checking them with the investigate option, and multiple times the game found differences I could just NOT spot by myself. It also doesn't help that the game bugs out at times and tells you that something matches or doesn't match when that's complete horse-sh#t and it looks like it would/wouldn't. Like the ID saying he's 1,55m tall and he seems to be nearly 2m tall, however the game will tell you that there's nothing wrong with those papers. It's hard to trust the game when crap like that keeps happening.  Lastly a third little problem, it’s not a game-breaking bug or anything, but rather an observation: You get paid by who many legit people get through. However, there are days when, I sh#t you not, only one or even no one was qualified to go through, meaning I didn’t get paid ANYTHING. That happened in two days already, and every time it happened I just restarted the day as with no pay, I would be pretty much screwed and forced to get a Game Over.  But besides that, what do you have left? A quite interesting interactive documentary about how sh#t the mid areas of Europe felt during the wars. And even though the countries in the game are fictional, they’re all based on actual countries.  The biggest point the game has running for it has to be the moral choices. It’s up to you who goes through and who doesn’t, and letting the right or wrong people in has consequences.  The audio is also good, fits quite well with the graphics. The main theme is catchy, and the rest of the game usually has ambient sounds with the made-up languages of the characters. Nothing stands out, which is good as it makes everything feel more or less natural.  The graphics, as I’ve said, have a few problems when it comes to the faces, but that being said they fit the game perfectly. Specially the still-images for what happens in special events.  The characters are also surprisingly well written, and could easily pass for real people. From corrupted douchelords to people who only want to survive, from soldiers who are forced to go through this sh#t everyday to jackasses like Jorji who are just lovable in every damn way.  Do I recommend this game? Yeah. It will put your brain to work, looking for what’s actually wrong with all those damn papers, while having a laugh or two with the current, rather sad events. The game also has, for what I know, around 20 or so endings, so that’s a good enough reason to play the game a few times. On a sale, this game is quite worth it for people who look for more casual and relaxing experiences.  TL;DR Edition: Relaxing game about people constantly trying to pass through a frontier with illegal drugs up their #sses. Well written and fun to play, it’s a good pick for any casual player who just wants to have a good time.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Papers, Please is absolutely everything I hoped it would be and more. It somehow manages to capture the drudgery of a repetitive, thankless job, the fear and scorn of those trying to get through a difficult border checkpoint and the hopeless, crushing despair of being unable to properly feed and care for your ailing family. Scraping together enough money to buy my son crayons after a day of denying visa entry to person after person was immensely satisfying. Trust me, you need this game.

This is a brilliant indie game! Some indie games focus on light themes, but Papers, Please is quite dark and dreary.   Working as an inspection officer for Arstotzka, my job was to process entrants to Arstotzka. Some have forged documents and tickets/passes/cards but there was a lot more to look for.   Simply processing enough entrants to gain a decent salary was quite hard; the days were really quick! It took time to process each document and look for mistakes; besides, each applicant only gained you five credits. On top of that, there was the ever-present chance that you woulld slip-up, make a mistake, be handed an M.O.A. citation and lose those precious five credits. You needed every last dollar to pay for food, medicine, heat, etc.  The gameplay was surprisingly engrossing; this is one of the only games where I like its retro-style graphics; it really gives the feel of a Communist setting during the height of the Cold War in '82 (although in this world there may not be a Cold War). The music was realy authentic and added to the game.  Get this and play this.
Finally, not denied by checkpoint guise anymore. Now I can deny them back.

OK, so you've got a dead end job, stamping passports in a paranoid communist country. Frankly, I'm amazed the developer pulled this off - how do you turn such a bland, depressing idea into a great game? And this is a great game!  The story makes you make some really tough decisions - it forces you to understand that sometimes bad people are actually just desperate, good people.   A word of warning - this game relies on attention to detail... if that isn't your thing, you're probably going to get super frustrated. If it is, you'll enjoy seeing how you improve on successive play throughs. (The game is pretty short, but has many endings based on your decisions. A single play through takes me around 4 hrs.)

This game has NO right to be fun as it is. The game boils down to you scanning documents for inaccuracies, and approving or denying entry to various citizens of the futuristic world trying to enter your home country; Arkotsk. You were drafted into working there, and you and your family were forced to move to a new rent-controlled home. You are expected to pay for their food, heat, medicine, and other needs as well as a hefty rent on your measly salary as border/customs agent.   What's really cool about this game though, is that while at first you struggle with the simple basics of the 'job', it soon becomes second nature. Once you become a jaded ♥♥♥♥ at the customs office you start to notice weird things happening around you; corrupt guards, terrorist attacks, ethical dilemnas relating to your post, bombs, murders, and of course forged documents.  It takes only a very short time to get into, and you'll likely want to play it more than one time since you'll fail the first time and recieve the 'worst; of the 20 DIFFERENT ENDINGS. One playthrough takes about 3 hours but checkpoints are created at every day, allowing you to explore all the alternate endings easily.  Don't trust your common sense, buy this game that is literally about fact-checking documents. You will love it,

Papers, Please is a game well worth buying (Especially at the summer sale price!)

Papers, Please is one of the most addictive games I have ever played before in my life. You play as a border checkpoint-man. What you have to do is check passports, ID's, work passes, and much more things to be successful in the game. If you fail at doing so, you will get a citation, but with no penalty. If you fail at checking passports three times, you will get a 5 credit penalty. If you fail 4 times, you will get a 10 credit penalty, and so on. It is worth it to buy it even if it is not on sale.   I rate it 9/10  Not a perfect score, because the game is not for everyone.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!  (Kolechians not allowed)

Ever want to reject someone based on bias? Ever want to pass a terrorist into the country? Ever want to pull a gun on said terrorist? Ever want to join a rebel faction bent on taking down your home country's government? Ever want to manage your family's well being while trying to upgrade to a better apartment complex? Ever want to possibly kill them off? Papers, Please is the game for you.  You begin as a lowly worker in the greatest country ever, Arstotzka (Glory to Arstotzka). You get to decide whether people pass or if they get rejected and are refused asylum from their countries war. As you progress through the days you will get the chance to read important documents, or don't and let Lady Luck decide if you get fired or thrown in jail for not being able to pay the fines. Or if you do pay your fines your family may suffer.. Choose wisely! Oh, also watch out for Cobrastan... nasty place that.

This has been one of the most strangely absorbing experiences I have had with a game recently. Basicially its a beurocarcy-esk game where you play a boarder control guard whose job it is to check papers of all incomming travellers (Papers Please? Geddit.) . Interogate them over discrepancies and make a final accept/decline decision. Except there is some kind of secondary, invisable checkpoint that automatically finds ♥♥♥♥ ups and fines you. So one wonders why we are even here? More layers of beurocrazy are added over time (Passports, Permission to travel, Permission to ♥♥♥♥, Permission to use run on sentances...) until immigrants are handing you scrapbooking projects, and if they spelled their name with a different vowel once, then it is off to talk to the nice men. its hard to sympthathise as you get payed on a per passport total. This is the beauty of the game, there is no right choice. Every couple you reunite comes at the cost of food or medicine that night. There is a lot of telling without showing. Definitely would recomend.

Papers, Please is a very unique and entertaining game. Why is it unique? Because you play a role that is not often played in a game. A border guard in a corrupt communist country constantly dealing with forged documents and terrorist attacks. Additionally, the gameplay in general is not very common. Thoroughly inspecting papers and stamping them? Try and find another game that offers you that. Now, I know the idea of a game which has gameplay centering around basically doing paperwork doesn't sound very entertaining... but trust me on this one, it is.  Let me talk about the pros and cons of this game.  PROS: * Brilliantly written story * Interesting universe that you're always wanting to learn more about * Characters that you know little about and yet get invested in so quickly * Unique gameplay * Pixely but good graphics  CONS: * Slightly dull and boring gameplay * Fairly difficult gameplay * Jorji Costava  This game is definitely not for everyone. However, if you like things such as alternate history (especially communist timelines), games where you remain in one spot, and a game where the universe is likely the best part, Papers, Please is no-doubt for you.  Even if you feel like it's not aimed at you, give it a try. It's worth your money. I would highly recommend Papers, Please to anyone.  As for those of you who are too damn stubborn to try the game...  - The Ministry of Justice has become aware of your stubbornness and refusal to play Papers, Please. - You are under arrest for your horrible crimes. An investigation will follow your imprisonment. - Your family's safety is unknown. - Your Steam account will remain running under a replacement. - Glory to Arstotzka.  I'd give Papers, Please a 9/10. It certainly deserves that high of a score.

Who would have thought that being a border checkpoint inspector for a communist country would make for a compelling game? Papers, Please pulls it off with aplomb, featuring enough ambiguous moral choices and multiple endings to warrant several playthroughs. The gameplay consists primarily of verifying the accuracy and authenticity of documentation, though the choice of whether or not to let someone through rests entirely with you. Sometimes letting someone through regardless of paperwork seems like the right thing to do but when you have bills to pay, morality can often take a backseat. Communist border checkpoint inspectors gotta eat!  Papers, Please is definitely worth a try, even if you find the premise unappealing. You may just be pleasantly surprised.

GLORY﻿ TO ARSTOTZKA

Your job is to run a checkpoint on the border of two countries, approving or denying the entry of people to the country. While this may seem pretty cut and dried, a lot of times you will find decisions that play on your moral compass. The consequences of your decisions are usually viewed in the paper the next day. There are 20 different endings in all based on the decisions you make in-game, and along the way you will meet very memorable characters. The game has an amazing feel to it and certainly was worth every hour I put into it, and I plan on playing it much more to unlock all the endings. If you find that you really enjoy the technical aspect of checking papers and stamping passports like me, when you're all done with the story you can play endless mode too.

Papers, Please is an unique game where you play as an immigration inspector in a dystopian state of Arstotzka. Sure, it is a tedium simulator, but it is anything but boring: the gameplay is engrossing, emotionally involving and requires a lot of attention to details, and the longer you play it the more challenging it becomes.  The Story mode has a great replay value, since there are many moral choices to be made and 20 endings to discover, and the Endless mode can keep you occupied for hours. Buy the game, it is worth it.

This is one of my favourite games in my collection. It is incredibly well rounded and has the perfect learning curve. The storyline is funny and tragic at the same time and captivated me throughout. The 80s aesthetic, the old-school graphics, as well as the atmospheric sounds of fax machines and shuffling papers fit perfectly for this bureaucracy simulator. In my opinion, it is a little piece of art and worth every penny.

This game is simple and hard to categorize, but it will really make you think. About life, about what really matters to you, about what you would do under the heel of a brutal dictatorship.  Not sure I'd call stamping papers the most fun I've had, but the story, the music, and the moral questions it raises make this game one of the most valuable experiences available on Steam.

Simple interface, simple graphics, simple enough way to explain how this game works. But it draws you in quick. It's a paperwork simulator, sure, but it's engaging and interesting. You are in charge of a border checkpoint and have to make sure only those meeting certain criteria are allowed in. If that were it, it would be fairly boring. But underneath it all, there's little things that affect how you play. Do you take a kickback to help pay for rent? How about saving up for your son's birthday? Do you let the person with expired documentation in, or send her back to her country where she will be killed?  It draws you in with the little stories. I don't think any other game has presented moral choices in a light such as this. Yes, you can do good and try to help people, but in doing so, you may be fined, and your family might starve. Do you show compassion and watch your family suffer, or do you protect your family, at the expense of being seen as the cold uncaring bureaucrat?
Its actually a great game despite the graphics which some people think a game has to be. Super fun and challenging at times.
I agree. This game is really indie art. Nice story, pixel-art graphics and bleak atmosphere
