NA

Papers, Please asks you a few interesting questions: after being assigned to man the border checkpoint what'll you do? Follow your corrupt and oppressive government laws by the letter or try and sneak a few poor souls in? Will you accept bribes? Will you try and help the rebels or just see how things pan out? How far will you go to make ends meet and ensure the safety of yourself and those you love?   PROS:   -despite sporting a minimalist art style the game graphics are convincingly bleak and oppressive   -simple yet catchy and appropriate music  -the game throws you several moral dilemmas, some decisions will give positive results, others won't change much while a few might be the end of you  -an engaging and branching storyline with a 20 different endings  -save system saves each day separately, you can also go back to a certain day and make different decisions thus generating a new save branch: this lets you experiment freely with the various outcomes  -smooth difficulty curve, new documents and rules are slowly introduced  -you'll get to meet interesting characters  -some examples of dry humor help balance the overall grim story  -having to correctly process enough entrants to ensure you have money to pay for rent, food, heating and surprise expenses really makes for a tense experience   CONS:   -since you're stamping documents and looking for discrepancies the gameplay is, by itself, pretty repetitive in nature  -some levels really throw alot of different documents and permits your way, making screening for discrepancies quite stressful (ofc this is a design choice)  -the simple graphics sometimes make spotting differences in facial features harder than it'd be   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=457423093   Papers, Please ends up being a quite engaging experience: you'd easily be fooled by its straightforward gameplay but the truth is there's way more to it. Its depth comes from how you can shape the story, the moral choices you'll make and their results on you and the characters you'll be meeting. All things considered the best question the game asks is 'What kind of person are you?'. Your decisions and their outcomes will be the answer.

This is a game that warrants a double take. When you first hear the concept it seems strange. A dystopian border patrol simulator. While at first the premiss of this game may disinterest many people browsing the large selection of games on steam. Trust me this game deserves your inspection. While its not your typical simulator it does a great job of putting you in the game's world. You are a citizen of a communist country called Arstotzka. Your name was pulled in a lottery for the job of the passport checker in the newly opened border of this imaginary country. The whole game is checking and double checking. The object is to either admit or dismiss as many people correctly in a limited amount of time. While this may seem repetitive at first its addictive. Whenever you start to feel bored of the gameplay they add a new twist or challenge to keep you busy. I have put a few hours and have only found one of the supposed twenty endings of this game. If you just want to play for the gameplay there is an endless mode for you to challenge yourself. For as simple as the story may seem it keeps you intrigued. The choices are everywhere. You are faced obvious options on such things as betraying the government, accepting bribes, or just helping people out. The atmosphere is immersive. After playing for a while you start to feel like a horrible dictator. The dark atmosphere and the things you have no control over provide surprising amounts of emotion. This is one of my favorite indie games of this year and am looking forward to more thing from the developer. I highly recommend buying it now or if you are a cheapskate nabbing it during a steam sale. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

This game is just brilliant. Not only is it more than worth the cost, but they have a free beta version (first some-odd levels) for download to see if you'd like it. It has an excellent narrative, tricky gameplay, 20 different endings, and you really get wrapped up in the character and the moral choices you have to make. Easily 10/10 in my opinion.

Papers Please is a masterpiece in recreating the modern mundaity of work and its dehumanising effects on us in a modern era of targeted workflows and admin jobs. It managed to make me think about what a game can be , what my attitude towards my working life is and the hierarchies of families. The truly incredible thing is it achieved all this while still somehow managing to deliver a game experience that was still a game and most importantly, fun to play.  As a brief setup you play as a border agent processing applications for entry into your fictional eastern European country. You earn money for every applicant you process and you loose money for errors you make in processing.  You are made to care about you finances through a pretty simple set of systems. You have a family and you must feed them, heat them, keep them healthy and put a roof over their heads. It’s chest beating “MAN MUST PROVIDE FOR FAMILY” stuff at its most primal but it works pretty well. So well infact that pretty early on in my playthrough I realised that I had subconsciously cut my mother in law and uncle out of my family. After every days work the money was so tight I would rather save the $5 I had left incase of any issues down the line than to maintain my extended family in the form of the mother in law or uncle.  That is a pretty starling revelation to realise that a game has, without you even realising, made you think about your family hierarchy and who matters most in times of need. It’s a decision I don’t think many of us in the developed world have to make very often but it made me think of those who must have to face similar decisions on a more regular basis.  I have seen it argued that the family aspects of Papers Please don’t work that well as you are given no reason to care for them as they are just a line of text in a menu and you don’t have any real connection to them. I personally found this made the decisions I made in regards to family carry more impact. Family members were being presented as purely positions within a tree rather than characters with personalities that may have given me the basis to change my decisions. Whether that was a genuine design decision or just a function of a small team, it doesn’t really matter. The end result was powerful to me.  Fending for your family is the crux of the overall meta game and it provides plenty of purpose to the nitty gritty of processing applicants through your border but its in this processing that Papers Please really starts to shine.  Papers Please is an absolute masterclass in UI design. Some people will read that statement and think I have gone crazy. In an age of sleek flat UI an initial glance at Papers Please would lead you to think it’s a complete mess. But that’s the point.  I work in a office that focuses solely on the processing of applications. My work day used to comprise of a pile of applications with attached supporting documents that I would then workthrough to deem eligibility for the product we sold.   It was always a complete mess and there was never enough room to see everything you needed to make a decision at once. We then moved to a document scanning system and went paper free. This made desks empty but increased the workflow clutter tenfold. A screen can only show so much info at a time and our system only let you view one page at a time. It was slow, frustrating and you always felt like something was in the way of you seeing the whole picture as just that, a whole.  Papers please simulates this whole feeling perfectly with its UI. Nothing is automated. For you to receive documents you have to manually pick them up from your counter and arrange them on your workspace which is just a small window in your real life monitor. There is never enough room and documents overlap constantly meaning you always struggle to feel truly efficient.   As the days progress and more rules are added to qualify for entry the space just gets less and less and every single additional pressure requires you to manually perform a new action. Not sure on a persons ID? Finger print them, manually hand them the slip, manually check it, manually stamp the passport manually pass them each of their 5 documents one at a time. It sounds like a nightmare but it isn’t and it makes me realise something about our real life working day.  People love a rhythm, we like to see repetition because it confirms we know what is happening. Papers Please shows that even when a task is relatively mundane, as long as it has a certain rhythm and you can feel yourself getting better at it over time, there is enjoyment to be had.  I genuinely started off slightly stressed playing Papers Please. I was constantly worried about cash and if I was processing enough applicants. Given time though I improved and realised I could afford to support my family (minus those tag alongs). Its right about that time when Papers Please starts to show its narrative head and you realise there is slightly more going on here than at first glance.  I won’t ruin specifics as they are some of my favourite moments in the game but you start to see some people at your border control more often than others and each of these people have their own set of requirements from you. It starts off with simple things such as a request to let a wife through (she doesn’t have the right docs) but over time more nefarious requests start to be made that have story consequences for the whole of your nation.  These serve to break up the processing of applications very well and they give the whole game a narrative thread from day one through to the end. They also serve as branching points to give the game around 20 different endings. Ive currently seen about six and there is some good variety in there.  It’s in these character interactions that I started to think about how much a job can dehumanise us. There are people trying to get through my border that will have zero nefarious intent. They simply have a document that is one day out of date. It doesn’t matter though because they never get put through by me. In a real world situation I would probably ruin lives by taking such a hard line approach but the paycheck justifies some pretty inhumane actions in Papers Please. Papers Please made me think about how many people in real jobs will take the same justification home with them every night.  Stylistically Papers Please is also a success. It plays on our preconceptions of eastern Europe in some pretty nice ways. The colour pallet is muted. The music is stereotypical of what we would expect and there is plenty of nationalist imagery. The game over screen even proclaims GLORY TO ARSTOZKA! I’ve never been to eastern Europe so I’ve no idea if any of this hits the nail on the head but it certainly matches our preconceptions of 1980s eastern Europe.  Papers Please is a rare game and a game that could only exist in this modern self publishing world we seem to be in now. It’s a measure of how far gaming has come as a medium that a game that simulates a mundane job can be so high on so many people game of the year lists.  In previous years a risk such as Papers Please would never have been taken. A singular creators vision had nothing but barriers to overcome if they wanted to get to market. This is no longer the case and I hope Papers Please is the first of many games in the coming years that subvert our expectations as to what a game is.  Ultimately, and this is going to sound pretentious, I think Papers Please could prove to be one of the first stepping stones that lets us make strides towards games loosing the tag “game”. The medium can be so much more than the play thing the title “games” suggest and Papers Please proves that.

The simplicity of this game means that you write your own story within it, and you become your own character. You are not playing as a defined character - this game has even more freedom in your actions than The Walking Dead.   You meet 10+ people every day and each one of them has a different reason for wanting to get into Arstotzka, and each decision you make (including the time you take to make it) affects how the game continues and eventually ends.   I will definitely be playing the game again and taking a different approach to see how the story changes. What an amazing and original idea.

There are so many reasons why Papers Please is so appealing. It's got a typical BioWare plot, which means that there's a mystery that's so well thought out and told that everything clicks into place during the big reveal. Yet it's also a game made by sci-fi fans for those who love sci-fi. There are so many elements borrowed and culled from decades of science fiction and movies, and there are countless moments that will remind you of Star Trek or Aliens or Firefly or some early John Carpenter movie (the electronic score is very Carpenter-esque, too). There's even an effective film grain post-processing effect that makes the game feel like a 70s or 80s sci-fi movie, before digital filmmaking and CGI made everything look and feel too clean.  Here's the premise of Papers Please: Several hundred years in the future humanity has joined the galactic community after finding alien technology on Mars that opens up interstellar travel. We uppity humans are seen as too ambitious in a galaxy run by a UN-like council populated by ancient alien races. You play as The Inspector of the human Alliance military, and BioWare lets you role-play as either a male or female character. There are pre-rolled characters that you can select or you can create a custom character with a unique face.  When a rogue spectre--one of the galactic council's special agents--attacks a human colony on Eden Prime, you're tasked with hunting him down. It's not that simple, though, as invariably epic themes such as extinction on a galactic scale kick in. So you must zip around the galaxy in a very sleek starship, explore alien worlds, engage in futuristic firefights, and unearth the overarching mystery. There's also a cast of human and alien characters that can grow on you, like Wrex, a krogan killing machine with a blunt, sardonic personality. And this wouldn't be a game without one or two romance possibilities, as well.

Very fun little game. You play as a border inspector. After completing, I recommend replaying it with a different attitude - you can help mysterious underground or try to bend the rules for your fellow men or be the ruling party's lap dog - 'You haven't seen your son for 6 years? Well tough luck grandma, that entry permit expired yesterday. ENTRY - DENIED! NEXT!'. Different actions have different results. ~20 endings.  Try to get it at a sale, since after you finish the game 3 times (~15hours total) it has no more replay value - all the major events are scripted. So at normal price as of this day (~10€) compared to ~20€ for Starcraft 2 or Bioshock:infinite it feels like a rip off. There is some sort of endless/challenge mode after you complete the game, but it seems like working a second job with nothing to show for it...
Amazing Game very deep story and relies on your moral choices for the one of 20 endings
All Glory to Artotzka
Strangly addictive and intense with really hard choices. A new kind of experience. I really like it.

Step into the boots of a underpaid and overworked border inspector! You are tasked with processing immigrants on the border between dirty Kolechia and Glorious Arstotzka! Check papers for disrepancies and make sure that they are not falsified. Inspect the foreigners and make sure that they do not carry contraband and illegal substances. Stamp Passports to approve or reject immigrants! Decide if you are to listen and believe to the 101 sob-story about a family forced apart, or coldly give them a firm 'NO' and send them back into their ♥♥♥♥-countries.  Take care of a large family, give them food and heat and pay the rent on time. If your meagre paycheck is not enough, take bribes and let possible terrorists over the border! Detain innocents and have them sent off to an uncertain fate and get a few dollars in return. Practice your aim on armed men trying to tear your checkpoint down and kill the guards! Manevour yourself between the watchfull eyes of your totalitarian government that will put you in jail for the slightest mistake, and a shady terrorist organization claiming to be fighting for Arstotzkas feedom.   Who will you belive? How will you feed your family? Who will you let through the border? Will your survive the winter? And maybe the most important thing of all: Are you going to stamp that Passport?  I give it 10/10 Glorious Arstotzkas!

It's hard not to recommend this. A very unique game that plays with your humanity. Do you jeopardize your family's well-being? Or send the wife of the man you just let through to her doom because of a number mismatch?  It acts as a great example of a nation led by machine-men, setting rules to (attempt to) keep numbers in check, leaving it to others to face the people it affects.  Gameplay is basically going through papers, checking for discrepancies. New rules are piled on you as previous rules failed to completely prevent incidents of letting the wrong people in. Pressure is on you as you're paid by the stamps, not by the hour. And the rent's just gone up, the heat had to be cut, your son is sick, GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

I took a leap of faith when I decided to purchase Papers, Please. It's a game I heard great things from but never really appealed to me when I saw some footage of the game. When the game won the Community Voter's Choice during the Steam Holiday Sale I decided to see if my $5 would be a good investment for something new. I'm happy to report that Papers, Please not only impressed me, but turned out to be one of the most addictive and intelligent games I've ever played. Papers, Please is a game that puts you in the role of a border patrol agent. Your task is to take passports from many incoming immigrants and citizens and either allow or deny them access to the dictatorship that is Arstotzka. The people you meet all have varied personalities and some are more patient than others. The game challenges you as you constantly have to review information for any discrepancies that you may find. This may result in invalid gender, issuing city, or an false identity. Even more so is many of your clients will come to you and beg for entry or bribe you so they can access the country and not delay their plans. Your role is to ofcourse, make money. You have to survive but also take care of your family which consists of your son, mother-in-law, uncle, and wife. These people can get sick, hungry or cold. You'll have to balance your money and choose whether to feed your family, turn on the heat, or give your sick family member medicine before they die. There is also a conspiracy theory going on deep within the city. Some people you meet will be secret agents, government officials, or members from a dark old organization. This game will challenge your moral standpoint as you'll have to decide whether you can trust someone or whether the person who's supposed to be someone, really is that person. The game will take up more time than you'd expect but will constantly challenge you and pull you into it's well crafted gameplay. Papers, Please is truly a game that you'll get value out of. It will make you question your morals and make you feel the emotional weight of your every decision.

I have just discovered that game and I'm not quite sure what makes it great. Is it the fact that you deny entrance to your country to poor people who have nowhere else to go? Is it the fact you strive to earn enough money to feed your family and always seem to fail? Perhaps. Or not. If I had been told that checking passports, I.D cards and work permits was so much fun, I would have studied to become a border guard.  The game depicts in an extreme but humorous way, a communist country which has recently re-opened its borders. You have just won the work lottery. Congratulations, you are one of the only ones to have an actual job now. You still won't be able to pay the rent or feed your family, but at least, you have work!  The game in itself is very smart, the difficulty increases slowly but surely. You must verify the expiry dates, check all documents, the gender, weight, height, passport number, diplomatic seals, issuing cities, etc. Once in a while, events occur and the policies change. You dismantle bombs, get extra earnings by shooting at people or detaining them. Sometimes, you even get 'special' visits. With about 20 different endings, this game is as deep as it can be while remaining 100% entertaining.
Glory to Astrotsca.
Best game ever definetly worth 10$

This is an amazing game and demonstrates how independent developers excel in creativity. The world they have created is immersive and the characters throughout have compelling reasons (both good and bad) why they should be let through the checkpoints. Small stories carry throughout the game, and may end differently depending on how you decide their fate. The decisions you make may impact how far you make it in the game, as deviating from your job description can land you in jail (and end this game short). These endings are great and allows you to reflect on your decisions. You can restart on certain days in the story to before you made the mistakes and see how the world may unfold differently.
I'm not a violent person but swear I am willing to punch anyone who gives this game a negative review

Papers, Please is a terrific puzzler developed by Lucas Pope. You work as an inspector for an Arstotzkan border and have to check all of their papers to be sure they are valid for entry.  The graphics of the game are extremely simplistic, lovable and eye catching. After every day, you get to see how your family is doing and have to buy food and/or heat for them. There are many interactions you can have with your family, such as your son having a birthday and you buying a gift for them. Leaving them without food or heat for too long will eventually kill them, but hey, less mouths to feed and warm.  Sometimes, there are terrorist attacks and you must stop them with your tranquilizer. You get a bonus for this. Also, while we're on the topic of terrorists, an infamous group called EZIC will contact you during the game. You will get bonuses from them, and a few of the endings revolve around EZIC. You do not have to do all of what EZIC tells you to do, but it's more enjoyable (in my opinion) following them.  You can upgrade your booth for easier inspecting. Some of the upgrades include pressing tab to open your stamps, space to check their papers for discrepencies, etc.  While there is fun moments, the discrepency detector can be a bit buggy, which could kill the fun. I think overall, Papers, Please is a terrific game and if you have the money lying around do get it.   9.5/10   (Jorji lives!)
Learn how it feels to work as Immigration worker in best korea

Papers, Please is one of the most Indie game ever you see (and funny).   In the year of October 1982, you have won the October labor lottery and your name was pulled. For immediate placement, report to The Ministry of Admission at Grestin Border Checkpoint. An apartment will be provided for you and your family in East Grestin. Expect a Class-8 dwelling.  You play as the Inspector, which of course you are working as a border inspector. Your job is to check their passport to make sure no expiration date, issuing city, name, picture, passport number and gender. By the time the day keeps going, there will be more papers which makes it harder to organize and match.  For stamping, 'Approved' if all of the passport and papers are organized and good to go, 'Denied' if some of the passport and papers are not match, forgery or false information. If you make 'Approved' stamp, but saw something that is wrong, you can do second stamp for 'Denied' or go for 'Discrepancy Detected' to 'Detain' them that it does count for that.  The citation warning will bring up what you did wrong. The first two you won't get penalty, but third and more will receive 5 credits penalty each.  There are multiple endings to choose from. Working with EZIC, brainwashed from Arstotzka, freedom, sacrifice, etc.  For me, it kinda feels relaxing and pretend to be working as an inspector which makes a whole lot of sense when I go to the airport or crossing border. Even though, I would get bribed by someone, but I wouldn't do that because the ministry won't like it (as in the game). =P  Overall, I give it 8.5/10 for this game.  You can try out the demo (Beta) before you decided that you want to play it full version.   Papers Please Beta   [dukope.com]   Three words:   Glory to Arstotzka!
A ton of depth and a lot of replayability. The execution is brilliant

It's hard to describe what's so fun about Papers, Please. To put it simply, the game is about checking the documents of people trying to cross a fictional Eastern Bloc nation's border with ever-changing rules and procedures. It's an oppressive environment as you're constantly choosing between strictly enforcing the rules of your superiors, or bending them at your own expense to do what seems right. You can have people detained for cash. You can take bribes. Everyone seemingly has a story or excuse for their discrepancies. And all the while, the rest of your family is starving and cold because you can't afford food and heat.  But it is fun! It's so fun. It's almost entirely mouse-driven, but everything feels perfect. You move the documents onto your desk for closer inspection. Stamping papers makes a satisfying 'kachunk' sound. Upgrades to your interface bring shortcuts. There's a time limit to each day, and you get paid by the person processed, with fines for screwing up (either intentionally or unintentionally) more than twice. It moves pretty briskly but once I got a rhythm down, I never really felt oppressed by the clock. Everything just works great. I got about five of the 20 endings, and I will probably go back to see if I can find the rest.   Glory to Arstotzka.
GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA
Really a lot of fun. Very tactile gameplay, and narrative is engaging.
One of the most harrowing but definitely brilliant games I've played in a while. Felt the need to put that out there.

Old school gaming with 80's graphics are a plus in this case, but the subtleties of its political and strategical references are so genius that I just keep on playing, no matter how hard it is.

You listed 1984 in your favourite books on Facebook because it was the only serious book you read in high school. Now you can play this game and feel like an intellectual for participating in gaming as social commentary. When you're done, maybe you'll make a thread about it on Reddit.

Another weirdly addicting game. I accidentally spent six hours playing it because it really has that 'just one more turn' gameplay you usually find in Civ games. It's also pretty difficult at times! You'll be surprised how tired you get from attempting to quickly process people while also keeping your eyes open for mistakes or false info.

i really love doing paperwork but I just don't get the chance to do it anymore. if you're in the same boat as me then you'll really enjoy multiple game award winner Papers Please. basically, what you do in this game is examine paperwork and then you find out if anything's wrong with the paperwork and then you can choose whether to let the person into your country or not. it's weird how realistic this game is, because when I went to LA's airport in the united states of america, the people also took 20 minutes to look at my face and then look at my passport and then look at my face again before letting me into their country. it was an experience that i wanted to relive and thats why i got this surprisingly addictive immigration sim.

It was a pretty cathartic experience being on the other side of the glass window, and it amazed me how much story, character, and moral struggle came through with such simple details and graphics. Believe the hype, the game will test not so much your attention to detail but the strength of your character and resolve.

This game is so awesome. It has a great sense of humor. A great branching tree of endings. It is actually considerably hard to get a stable income/family early on. I know some people recommend the game based on the tough moral choices and what not, but it is fun from a sadistic / schadenfreude perspective too.

'Papers, Please' is a fun puzzle game set around the unlikely theme of a Communist border control post. As the border guard for Arstotzka you are under pressure from the authorities to accurately process entrants according to ever-changing criteria, whilst juggling your meagre salary to keep yourself and your family alive. As your pay is linked to processed entrants, you have to push through as many as possible without making mistakes; mistakes are deducted from your pay. A stream of entrants queues outside your booth, meaning you only have a few seconds to make a decision - yes or no - on each. Will you help through the refugee without papers? Will you take a bribe? Will you help a dissident?  I love the grey, bleak 1984-esque world of Arstotzka and how, as a minor official, you find out about changes through the state newspaper and visitors to your booth. This is a challenging, fun puzzler, with surprisingly deep story writing and I'm really hoping there we'll get a chance to return to Arstotzka in future games from the same developer!  Glory to Arstotzka!
One of the best indie titles I've played in a while. completely engrossing with great gameplay and retro-cultural feel. totally worth checking out.

Prob one of the most simple yet enjoyable games you can find has a great artstyle. Game may seem dull but once you get your hands on it expect to say goodbye to about 5 hours of your life on your first sitting.

At first glace, this game doesnt seem that fun. 'Wowie, you're a guy working as a border patrol agent. How can this be a good game?' But it's so much more than that. Set in a foriegn European country, you are set with the task of approving and rejecting people into your homeland of Arstotzka. You get paid per correct citizen you allow in, and you get penalized for every mistake you make. The rules and regulations the country gives you makes the game more and more challenging. At the end of each day, (level) you are given your pay, but you also have bills. The food, heat, and rent expenses pile up. Often leaving you to not pay for one, leaving your child, wife, and uncle either cold or hungry. Or both. This game challenges your morals. Do you let the young wife into Arstotzka to be with her husband? Or do you reject her becuase of a missing work permit and follow orders? There seems to be only one music track in this game that plays when you start it up, and at the end of each day. While the music track is good, I would like more. But on the other hand, the lack of music during the actual gameplay makes it seem all the more realistic. The graphic style of this game is quite good. It reminds me of the early '90s PC pixelated graphics

I only meant to play ten minutes and ended up playing over an hour lol!!!

GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Well, this game was kind of sitting on my wishlist so one day I figured I would get it to see what everyone is liking about it, first i'll say this, for a simple game it holds a heII of a lot of weight on it.  PROS:  Story: The story is a little simple, you are a man who got a job at a border controll station into Arstotzka, some kind of Russian like country, you're job is to make sure that whoever doesn't have their paper work in order gets a 'Denied' stamp, and who has it correct gets a 'Approved' stamp.  Money: You have to get money to care for your family, your son, father, wife, and *shiver* 'Mother-in-law', how it works is every Deny you make you get paid, every Approve you make you get nothing (least I think you do), so you want to clear as many of those people as you possibly can.  Paperwork: Yes, this game is basically a paper-work simulator, but it's a heII of a lot more than just that, theres a whole background network of stuff that happens, organizations wanting in, other countries Arstotzka can't trust, democrats who could be possible terrorists.  Characters: The characters you meet are a little weird at first, like a guy who wants into Arstotzka but doesn't have the right paper work on him, or a woman who wants to go through the checkpoint cause her husband went first but she doesn't have the paper work to be allowed in, or the organization who wants into Arstotzka with their spies to see what's going on, choices you have to make and could have consequences.  Choices: Throught your one/many playthroughs you'll have to have some choices, whether it be help or disregard the Organization, not or let the husbands wife through the checkpoint regardless to be nice, let that little d%$khead through even though you REALLY don't want to cause of how annoying he can be. Be careful with what you decide to do, because one wrong move can mean you lost the whole game. Honestly at times when I had to pick choices I was kind of scared, I was afraid of what the outcome would be, and since i'm on a timer I have to be very careful about what I picked.  Paperwork/What Civies need: When you start off in the game, it's simple, every Arstotzkan is allowed in if they have the right passport, everyone else isn't allowed in, but later on the paperwork just starts piling up like crazy. Permission to come in Arstotzka, permission to work, permission to go through, permission to go to the bathroom, permission to walk, permission to talk, it starts to get annoying at times, but after a while you start to notice errors in documents without so much as even blinking or going to the handbook. But every once in a while even I end up screwing up the simplest of things.  Pay attention to details: What I mean by this is you need to look at every little detail about the paperwork, the names of people, passports, expiration dates, the stamps, the city and district names, the persons height, their weight, their gender, EVERYTHING, don't overlook anything, if you think it's fine check it anyway, you'd be surprised. Cause if the person misspells their name just once then it's off to the guys with guns and they go into the building people go into but don't come out of so much.  Discrepency machine: This machine is basically a analysis tool and I like it a lot, say it's hard to read the screen and you can't tell if the persons name on the passport matches their entry permit or work permit, you hit SPACE BAR or click the button on the bottom right, click one name, then the other, it scans it for any errors and if it's clean you are fine, if it's a discrepency then a icon appears over the little 'Talk machine' and you click on it (without going out of the discrepency machine) and it asks the person a question to whatever it was you scanned, sometimes you need to do fingerprints, others it may be a search.  Upgrades: Your booth ends up getting upgrades that you can pay for, they aren't big, they are a little simple, like for the handbook for rules and country city names you have to manually flip through the pages, later you can buy a upgrade which gives it 'tabs' so you just click on the tab and get sent to the area you clicked whether it be rules or stamp symbols, or the deny/approve slider, instead of clicking it you get a upgrade where you hit TAB and it comes out automatically, hit TAB again to put it back, and for the discrepency machine you hit SPACE BAR to bring it up, and SPACE BAR again to put it away.  CONS:  The Citation Error Machine: I hate this f#$ker with all of my heart and soul, I call this thing the 'F#$k Up' machine, because everytime you f#$k up, it makes this irritating noise and comes up saying what you missed or didn't look over, and after a while I sometimes want to just throw my monitor out of the damned window. Yes it's annoying but atleast it tells you what you missed or didn't look at, good job Arstotzka, I feel great that a machine can do my job better and yet it's free. This thing is basically a invisible scanner, on the way out of the checkpoint it scans the person for if they had everything correct or something wrong and tells you what it was.  Endless Mode: This isn't in the cons section because it sucks, it's a little fun actually, especially if you play the Papers, Please theme while you do so, you can pick what you want to do and how much paperwork is required to pass, but honestly after a while it can get a little dull, what I think they should have done is put some kind of randomized game in, where you pick how much paperwork is required but you don't know what could happen, the guards could all die from a terrorist or something if you accidently pushed someone through who had incorrect permits or something, seriously, would add a lot of replay value.  Easy game overs: I only beat 1 of the 20 endings that there is but you need to be very careful about what you do SPOILER ALERT, at one point if you let one of the Organizations spies in you get 1k, yes, 1 thousand bucks, but if you keep it and don't use it or something the government takes it and puts you in jail, as well as your family members. Another time was I had to let this d*$khead advisor for the checkpoint, make me let a woman through yet she wasn't supposed to, and I forgot the woman's name so I ended up putting her in jail, then I got ANOTHER game over, and it gets annoying to have to resort to previous days and go through ALL the work again and try not to let the f$%k up machine go off just to get to a certain point.  WHAT I THINK: I think this game is something very special, it's so simple yet so amazing all at once, 'EA would never make something like this, infact it would probably remind them of their Customer Support Services.' = Yahtzee Croshaw. All and all though, it gets a damn good 9/10, minus the f$#k up machine and some things I think would have enhanced the game, it's pretty damn good, but i'm sure after you get all of the endings it could get a little dull. This game is totally worth it as it sits and when it's on a sale.

This game is great. It has nice gameplay and pixellated graphics that enhance the experience. Complete with moral choices, clear conflict, and amazing story. This game is a wonderful experience and is definitely worth the ten dollars.  7/10. Highly recommended.

I was actually very surprised by how immersed I was in this game. I bought it on a whim because it was in the autumn sale and I heard some things about it so I thought, 'Why not?'. You start the game off and listen to the really catchy music with the title going slowly upwards as it bobs to the rhythm of the music. I thought the music was also very thematic as well, telling me the kind of setting I would be playing in, so that's a plus.   Okay, then I started a new game and, at first, it starts up kind of slow, showing me what to do and how to use the certain controls in the game. I'll get back to that in a bit, though. But just as I as getting bored with the game, thinking that it was becoming repetitive, it started to add story elements. On any random day the border can be attacked by a terrorist bomber or a group of them kill all the guards around the border and its up to you to take them out. And then there is also a secret organization that tries to get you to help them with their cause.   It was all of these things that kept me interested in the game, more immersed. I really couldn't stop playing it because I wanted to see what happened next, if something even happened next. Well, I guess I also got a sense of satisfaction of being given the power to dictate whether a person can enter or not. Anyway, I thought it was a really good game, very creative because of its unique gameplay and style that it gave me. Plus, it also multiple endings! So you have tons of replayability if you're done with the first playthrough.   I do have a complaint though. I just kind of thought that one of the upgrades was kind of useless. Like the 'double click to use inspection mode'. There was already another upgrade to activate it with the spacebar so I didn't think there was any need for that upgrade. I'm not sure what could've been in place of that but I'm sure that the creator could've thought of something. I would say the same thing about the book shortcuts but I found those useful so I'll leave that one be.   Other than that, I had a great time playing the game. It required me to be real attentive and I think it actually helped increase my perception because sometimes there is just one tiny thing that you can overlook and you can get a citation for it. So you have to really pay attention to the dates, genders of the people, serial numbers, and even the cities in the passports that they're using. Sometimes they try to trick you with that so be careful. Also the dialogue with the characters can sometimes feel very natural so that is another aspect that can immerse you into the game.   Now, Papers, Please definitely won't be the most exciting game you would ever play but it will pull you in with its unpredictability, interesting setting, and very intuitive gameplay mechanics. So if you're in the market for a PC game I highly recommend Papers, Please. If you are on the edge of whether or not to buy this, do it. You won't be disappointed with it at all, and it's only 9.99 so it's a really good price for what you get with this game.   My rating for Papers, Please is a 9/10

1000/10 This game hands down feet on the floor is my all time favourite game. This is about a man that checks passports at a border. It might sound boring but OMG is it not. There is a lot of plot twists and its humor is very entertaining. BUY IT NOW OR ILL FIND U
Really Fun and Addicting game thats hard to stop playing. A must buy

This game is incredibly frusterating. I've had to restart a few times, but I still keep coming back. I discovered early on to let everyone in your family die but one person, and it makes the game way more bearable. It is virtually impossible otherwise. Despite that, the game keeps my attention, I like that there are choices and consequences for your choices, and I enjoy the fast pace of the day to day job. I'd recommend it solely on the fact that it is a unique, addictive game.

Boyfriend gifted this to me. I thought it was just a unique job simulator but there's so much more. The storyline and characters are great, especially the silly guy who keeps trying to get through the check point, in one case with a passport made with crayons. I believe his name is Jorgi or something. I freaking love that dude.  This is a thoroughly wonderful game that is often stressful but with plenty of humor to keep you going. I really freaking love this game. I'd say it's the most entertaining and unique game I've come across in a long time and I'll be replaying it several times in the future just to see all the endings and really explore the full storyline. One final note is that this game can be quite difficult at times playing on normal mode. For me, usually the only thing that gets my family by day by day is taking bribes from people at the cost of a demerit. You want to do your best in this game and save those two warning demerits per day for bribes and other activities that require you to do illegal things. I haven't played on easy mode yet but I might just to see how it is to have disposable cash and afford stuff I haven't been able to afford like adopting my niece. You get 20 free credits a day supplement in easy mode. But I thouroghly reccommend playing on normal first just to get into the stressfull atmophere of poverty and experience the sadness when you can't afford a gift for your son's birthday. On the other hand: I didn't really mind. This is ♥♥♥♥ing Arstotzka. You know we're freaking poor as poo so why you asking me for such a damn expensive crayon set. 20 credits? What the hell, son. You really set yourself up for dissapointmen. 'Here, I have crayon for you, son. I make it from wax and my tears. Draw proud Arstotzkan soldier beating papa up for accidentally admitting Obristani terrorist what killed 2 guards and stole many, many turnips from Arstotzkan turnip reserve. Now eat that crayon!'    Glory to Arstotzka
Glorious.

A gripping and emotional story that seriously makes you question your morals. Also, the gameplay itself is surprisingly tough, with you having to pay attention to each and every detail, and rather than chucking everything at you at once and overwhelming you, it slowly adds more and more pieces of paperwork and rules, so you have plenty of time to understand each one before you have to learn a new one.

Papers Please is a fun game, you deal with a rebelling group while trying to keep your job and keep your family safe and sound, it gives a fine look on how gamer's look at communist countries with stamping a passport with it getting more difficult as the game progresses. it sure does take some patience to finish the game as about 4 hours if your trying to get to day 31, it also gives a real life problem as if your boss likes your employment or not, and i cant forget the inspector, he'll throw you in jail for almost anything that is off. Papers Please surely does make gamers try to keep their job while trying to keep arstotzka safe.  9/10  -this message is approved by Gabe Newall. all rights reserved for valve and the creators of Papers, Please. send more feedbackto the game at  http://papersplea.se/

The Greatest Paperwork Simulator to be written. Until a game developer creates a 'Work at EA Help Desk SImulator: Origin Edition', there won't be another to top the working conditions of living under a bureaucratic regime fraught with moral choices. Please be nice to Jori. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
This game is an incredible experience. I haven't felt so much tension in a game in a long time. Very original.

This is one interesting game. A simple game of morality, a game of doing your job and supplying for your family, a game where the choices you make can determine if you live or die.   All you do is file paper work! It may not seem like it at first, but this game gets intense, quickly. The amount of things that you have to do quickly escalate and you have to remember who and what are allowed and what aren't. The story is crazy, terrorist attacks, rifles, poison powder, secret organizations, and even murderers!

Glory to Arstotzka!  The game is quite different. You're the border entry point official dude who gets to decide if people can come in or not. At first it plays like a game where you spot the error and decline entry... but then your son gets sick...  Then it becomes a game of how much you can bend the rules to not be fined or punished too much for trying to make a few illegal bucks to pay for rent and heat  It's deep.
Was not expecting this to be so good. 10/10

There isn't a better way to spend $10 anywhere. It's simple and easy to pick up and play for fun (even though when I first watched the game I thought to myself 'this just looks like work'). The game has a fantastically done learning curve and teaches you step by step as it builds upon itself to become something extremely complex and challenging. On top of that they throw in tough personal choices and a well done story with branching paths and 20 endings. This game will keep you hooked for hours. Glory to Arstotzka!

a very diffrent and interesting game. It really forces the decisions in your face all the time, and that's a good thing. This is the only game that really blurs the decisions, its not bad guy choice and good guy choice, its family, money and morals. While the game can get slightly repetitive, it changes it up after almost every day. Unique in every way. 9/10

I would say the subtitle of 'dystopian document thriller' is partly correct. The setting and mechanics in this game are fairly unique I think, where you play a border agent in a country with an oppressive government.  The gameplay itself is actually fairly routine, and can be summarized as rule memorization and observation skills. This is fine, as it works and makes sense within the story. The sound design and aesthetic lend to this very well. There were no performance issues.  I don't think there is that much replayability to the story despite the variety of endings. There is an unlockable endless mode, which could make this fun as a pastime too Still, I'd reccomend this game for its unique experience. Its really not something you see every day.
Incredible game with simply amazing narrative, by far one of the best games of 2014

I have to say upfront that i have never really loved or even liked this game, that being said buy this game, its just amazing, personally its not my cup of tea but i still recomend this because its a perfect mix of mechanics and story in a way that everything you need to know is told directly through gameplay, never taking you out of the game for a text dump or a cutscene, man its just a good game.
This is a wonderfull game. You must pay attention when you play this game. I like this game very much and I give this game a 9/10!
A fantastic game full of drama and mystery, all while inspecting papers, this is a game you simply can not miss.

I put off buying this game for quite a while, after all it doesn't really seem that interesting, but it truly is a great game.  If you're considering buying this game but aren't sure then just do it. As you progress through the game the story, or should I say your story really develops. New rules are introduced by the government and old ones removed. It's constantly a challenge to deal with the barrage of documents that are thrown your war.  The save system is excellent, allowing you to return to any single day and make a different decision regarding certain people in order to change the outcome of the story. The game is a humourous but morally challenging parody of what would be an impossible job.  Well worth playing, this game will be a classic.
Dystopian monotony turned into an investigation game.  I never looked forward to paperwork as much as i did this. So much emotion as well.
This game gave me the biggest bureaucratic boner ever.
Nothing more to say than GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

This is a lesson in morality and beurocracy: A paperwork simulator. It's small and cheap and very deserving of your time. Better check those transit papers to prevent the wrong people from gaining entrance to GLORIOUS ARISTOTSKA!

It's been quite a month. New house, new job, new responsibilities. Work was hard, but an honest day's work brought an honest day's pay. Of course it's never really that simple. Everyday, from my little booth, I've had to make decisions that could affect people's entire lives. It's weighed pretty heavily on my own life, and possibly more so on my family's. It's been incredibly stressful, and I've done some pretty dark things. I've seen innocent people taken away, I've stolen and taken bribes, I've even killed. But what else could I do? I had people counting on me. Tensions built and something terrifying was brewing in my country - in the end I did what I had to to protect my family.  I hope one day we will be able to return to the new Arstotzka, and my son will be able to see what it was all in aid of. As for now, we're safe, and I owe an old friend a few drinks.
Really good game. If your looking for a fun indie game that's simple yet full of moral decisions, this game is for you.
Who knew 8-bit office work could be immersive?

The simplicity of this game means that you write your own story within it, and you become your own character. You are not playing as a defined character - this game has even more freedom in your actions than The Walking Dead.   You meet 10+ people every day and each one of them has a different reason for wanting to get into Arstotzka, and each decision you make (including the time you take to make it) affects how the game continues and eventually ends.   I will definitely be playing the game again and taking a different approach to see how the story changes. What an amazing and original idea.
I absolutely adore this game, had a blast playing it. A bit of a dark setting but brilliant for a light-hearted playthrough ;)

This game is very addictive and engaging in a way that is difficult to define. It's one part matching and one part Oregon Trail. I started playing it because it was unique looking, and haven't stopped playing since!
Damn addictive and a refreshing type of gameplay. Me mucho gusta.

Glory to Arstotzka!  A must-have for any serious collection of games. Just as you think you're settling into a routine this game brings up something new. Very enjoyable, dystopia or no.
The dystopian reality creates an atmosphere where this game, as plain and simple as it may seem, becomes something profound, inovative, and unapologetically good.

First of all, this game is depressing.  It puts you in the boots of a poor paper pusher at a border-checkpoint of a dictatorship(ed?) country .   While you are struggeling to keep your family fed and warm, you are deciding over human lives in a always shorter timeframe. Why this? The faster you check the immigration papers of people seeking refuge, the more money you earn each day. But if you make mistakes you can loose money as well. This gets harder every day as the administration releases more and more rules and admittances for you to check. At the same time the game throws you into some moral decisions, where there is no right or wrong. Do I turn down the human-trafficer, although his papers are ok? This could lead to a fine and I could not afford the medicine for my son. Do I take the bribe from the nice man claiming to smuggle medicin for his sick wife?  As I said... this game is depressing. Would I recommend you to buy and play it?  Yes!   Because this game manages something only few games manage to do. To get you involved and question your own morality.  And even if you do not get involved in this depressing atmosphere. The game is still a very good reaction-puzzle-like game that needs you to figure out where the small mistake in the forged immigration documents in front of you is.

To be brief, Papers, Please is a game that is unlike any other in terms of gameplay. The best way to describe it is working in Stalin's DMV, sifting through enough papers throughout a day to make a redwood tree flinch in horror. Unique gameplay itself is more than enough to give Papers, Please a look, but what really makes the game pop is its story. Everyone has problems, and you are no exception. The game puts you in a mentality that lets the little details get to you, taking perfect advantage of its setting to make you worried about even getting to work another day. This game is an interactive experience like no other, and I recommend it to any gamer look for something different.
Incredible gameplay, this is really something new and tasty!

Apparently you don't need graphics or any form of conventional gameplay to create a compelling game. Somehow it's more fun to cross reference documents than it is to shoot any number of anonymous soldiers in most games. Who knew?
Pretty Awesome!! This game is fun and frustrating...Feels like you are always in a lose lose situation...
i was not really sure what to expect with this game but am glad to say i found it surprisingly addictive!

I just bought (for a mere $4.99, btw - another reason I absolutely *love* 'indy games') a game called 'Papers, Please'. Very original, innovative... 'different'. Very 'detective-esque'. I like it a lot.   You play as a border checkpoint guard in a cold-war era sovietesque fictional country called 'Arstozka' (surrounding countries are fictional, as well) to process immigrants and citizens entering the country. The reasons are numerous - allegedly for work, permanent move, visiting parents, children, marriage, passing through, etc. You are the sole decision-maker as to their 'Approval' or 'Denial' (of which you literally stamp one way or the other).   The game starts off simple enough... immigration controls are very loose to start, and you just need to ensure that their passports don't have any discrepancies. Over time terrorists start to attack the border, and other things happen throughout society / the economy that 'dictate' immigration reform, with immigration controls becoming more and more strict. This necessitates more and more paperwork (and other 'controls' and so-called 'random searches') needed to be approved for entering the country, and of course more potential for discrepancies...  But that's not just it. You get paid based on how many people you 'process' in a given time (or 'work day'). They allow a few 'violations' on your part to pass through as 'warnings', but after too many violations, you get penalized by losing part of your money.  The other issue is that your family relies on your salary to survive. They need food, heat, payment for rent, and sometimes medicine. There are also upgrades you can pay for to make your job more efficient or easier, potentially allowing you to 'process' more people at the checkpoint. You can accrue savings, for what purpose I'm not quite sure yet (it looks like maybe you can pay to have more of your family brought over and given passports for a 'better standard of living').   If you're not careful, and if you're not efficient enough, you may not have enough money to pay all your bills. You need to make choices as to what to pay for and what to forego. Family members can die, or with sufficient delinquency on your part, you get sent to the gulags and lose the game.  Moral and ethical dilemmas pop up frequently - with regards to your family, choices on who to save and who to let go cold or hungry or even die, and other ethical dilemmas surrounding the people trying to enter the country.   The music is very cold-war sovietesque, which is fitting as something akin to East Germany during the Soviet era. The graphics, in wonderful indy fashion, are delightfully retro and charming.  Very interesting, indeed. I definitely recommend it! For $5, the cost of a Starbucks Latte, it's totally worth it.  Glory to Arstotzka!   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_QP5X6♥♥♥♥M
This might be one of the best indie games ever made.
hilarious

This game is surprising. It seems dull looking at it from the outside, but it turns out to be surprisingly addictive. There's a good bit of conspiracy, and a few stories and sideplots play out as you play the game. It has a very good level of challenge to it as well, which was refreshing to me.
Bought it on a whim and ended up being one of the most impressive games I've played this year.

Glory to Arstotzka.  This game is wonderfully unique, easy to play, and constantly engaging: one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. I would recommend this game to people that enjoy rapid process puzzles, or people that just want to try out something new and original.

A gripping and emotional story that seriously makes you question your morals. Also, the gameplay itself is surprisingly tough, with you having to pay attention to each and every detail, and rather than chucking everything at you at once and overwhelming you, it slowly adds more and more pieces of paperwork and rules, so you have plenty of time to understand each one before you have to learn a new one.

Cold War era Eastern Bloc customs agent sim...  Surprisingly enjoyable and thought provoking gameplay. The game is basically your doing identification checks on people trying to get admission into your country. You have to balance speed and accuracy of your check-ins, deal with daily bureacratic rule changes in processes, and try to keep your family alive on rations, or risk accepting bribes.

For an indie game, this little gem has definitely surpassed my expectations. From making one laugh out loud at running gags (yo, Jorji) to questioning one's moral standpoints, this game has all the elements that makes it one of the smartest games I've played all year.   You're allowed to make choices - but with natural consequences that affect how you manage to care for your family, how loyal you want to be to your country and other random things one would otherwise not think about. Do you want to let this woman in to see her long lost love? Do you help the rebels trying to overthrow the government? Do you accept the bribes given to you in exchange for entrance into your beloved country?   The game can also be replayed a number of times without it getting tiresome or tedious, which is great plus point. Best $5 spent in a good long while.
is actually pretty entertaining

I aided the rebels, they got me a lot of money, I was at the top for a while, like 3 days, Soon I was ratted on, lost all my money, then Uncle died, few days later rebels stop helping me, My sister went to jail, and I couldnt adopt her daughter, was too poor, next day I buy medicine for mother in law and son, and in the morning everyone died including my wife, I was fired, No money, no family, no home, started from the bottom, was at the top for 2 days, sent back to bottom, now everyones dead, Glory to Arstotzka. 19 days in game, 3:20:01 play time.   Better than the SIMS.

Welcome to the mind of the frontline bureaucrat!  Yes, you're repeatedly reviewing documents, but it's strangely addictive... and enlightening.  Do you callously do your job without regard for the person in front of you, or do you use what little power you have to show kindness to the poor disenfranchised soul? What will you do in the face of conflicting imperatives? Will you put your own safety and well-being above that of your countrymen… or even your family?  Sometimes depressing. Sometimes monotonous. Always thought provoking. Papers, Please is an impressive accomplishment in gameplay and storytelling.

A simple game with complex elements. The story may seem basic but some characters provide a laugh. The decisions made can affect the game so much, thankfully in any save you can go on from any day past. The game is addictive, takes time, requires thinking, and is entertaining. Highly recommend.

Oddly satisfying. On paper (!) it seemed like it couldn't be more boring. A paperwork game? It seemed so different though that I gave it a shot, and I'm glad I did.  The game does a nice job of giving you a sense of urgency to keep your family healthy. There is a small learning curve, but it's easy to pick up.  I haven't come across anything like it before, and that can be really hard to say these days.
Papers, Please is an amazing game, it has excitement, mystery, thrills and a game mechanic that is simple to grasp but never gets boring!

Games provide us with systems and ask us to master them. We learn to jump at the right time, hit the mark, ask the right question in the dialogue tree, navigate the maze, push the block, kill the enemy.   On the surface, Papers, Please is a game with novel mechanics about document examination. You play the role of a border control agent who must ensure that everyone's papers are up to date, authentic, and match the immigrant. You are given a rule book and are asked to highlight problems with the papers by matching up a rule to an offending line or image. In a couple of clicks, you tease out contradictions, stamp the passport Denied, and call for the next and the next.  As the game rolls along, new wrinkles and rules appear and the documents become more complex. The faster you work, the more salary you take home to care for your family, so it behooves you to master the mechanics and become an expert agent who doesn't make mistakes and processes the line impartially.  Over time, you come to realize that the game is asking more of you. It puts you in situations where it could be wrong to follow the rules you have invested so much time to learn. To deny the passport of someone's loved one. To take a bribe. To look the other way for a local official. To detain people for money.  In other words, the game asks you, in a way I found very emotionally honest, to stop playing so well.  The first time through, I did my best to follow all the rules in the book, for good or bad. I played the role of a faceless functionary. It was mechanical in every sense of the word. But the second time through, I let my conscience be my guide. To my surprise, things played out very differently.  This is the best trick of Papers, Please. It makes you uncomfortable to play. It asks you to stop and think about the no-win situation it hands you. It rewards you for changing your mind.  One of the best games of 2013.

Best role-playing game of 2013.

Papers, Please is a game where you play as a border inspector in the dystopian society of Arstotzka. To do so, you verify documents and pick up on potential discrepancies to determine when to approve their entry or deny it. This descritpion make Papers, Please sound like a boring monotonous grind.  Well it is not.  Papers, Please offers one of the most intense single player experiences in the indie gaming scene. As you get paid based on the number of people you screen, you are forced to work fast. Make too many mistakes, however, and you receive citations resulting in your salary getting docked. You become indoctrinated to dread the fax noise that comes with every citation. Your family lives on the edge of poverty and you are forced to budget accordingly.  As the government relaxes or strengthen their policies, your job changes with it, where the foreigner who was let in a day earlier may not be today, which allows for some essential variation to prevent the game from becoming stagnant. This comes in the form of detention of criminals, fingerprint and X-ray scanning and seal verification.  The game also does a good job questoining your morality. For instance, do you allow the guy with good documentation pimp in Arstotzka, or deny him and get reprimanded by your superiors? Do you buy food for your starving uncle or a present for your son's birthday?  Papers, Please is an indie game done right, in which it is not a pretentious, bland game that boasts of subtle depth while being ♥♥♥♥ to play, nor is it another 'retro styled' hardcore platformer. It is a unique game that manages to tackle heavy morality issues while still being amusing to the player.  Two thumbs up!

This is not a game you have 'fun' with. It's a very bleak tale about the nature and abuse of power, the burden of knowledge, and above all, hope. The gameplay, which escalates throughout the story into more and more of an intellectual challenge, is a vehicle for the game to toy with your emotions. The choices you make have a wide range. Should I arrest the old woman for having false information on her passport? If I do, I will get a bonus that may well mean affording medicine for my wife. But then again, the old woman is hardly responsible for what is likely a typo made by an immigration officer as fallible as you. Should I listen to the mysterious revolutionaries? On one hand, they may bring about a better world; on the other, I may well end up under arrest along with my innocent family. Should I accept the bribe from the man who claims to be just smuggling harmless medicine for a friend? These are the kind of choices that I would impulsively make, knowing I had to process more people to make enough money, and then ponder over for the next fifteen minutes, turning the moral dilemna over in my head. You rarely win in this game, and that's the point.

It is not easy being inspector at the Grestin Border Checkpoint. At first, I think is not too difficult -- how hard could it be to check papers? One month later, I see more clearly. It is not just the documents, but the people.   This man's papers are in order, but he looks like murderer in newspaper. This woman lacks entry permit, but will be killed if she returns to her country. I decide their fate -- but Ministry of Admission docks my pay if I do not follow rules, and medicine for my infant son costs money. As well, I have some dealings with a suspicious group-  IGNORE ALL PRIOR MENTIONS OF SUSPICIOUS GROUP. GRESTIN BORDER INSPECTOR IS EXCELLENT AND REWARDING JOB. OPEN MANY EXCITING OPPORTUNITIES. APPLY FOR POSITION NOW.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA.

A husband and wife wanted into glorious Arstotzka. The husband cleared the checkpoint. The wife did not have an entry permit permitting her into glorious Arstotzka. She said she would die that night if she were not cleared. ♥♥♥♥♥ didn't have her papers.  A girl wanted into glorious Arstotzka in order to work. She warned me that her employer was coming after her and she would be sold into a sex ring if he were let through. But the man had his papers.  Papers. Please.  Glory to Arstotzka. Praise Arstotzka. Kolechian scum are scum.

Wow!  This game has no right to be as brilliant as it is. Who would have thought that the job of a passport inspector on the border of some fictional dictatorship could be so entertaining, so time consuming, and worth far more than I paid for it?  I'm sure that the games graphics will put many prospective players off - it's hardly the latest Call of Duty iteration. But that doesn't matter in the slightest. As you get into the nitty-gritty of checking passport details against diplomatic accreditation, or deciding whether to accept a telling-off in return for letting a border guard's long-lost love through without the correct paperwork, you'll soon forget about the graphics, the time or even your real job!  And if that's not the mark of a great game, then what is?

While Papers, Please is at its core a micromanagement game (maybe the closest comparison is 'a really brutal Diner Dash'), it's thematically like no game you've ever played. Set in a fictional Soviet country in 1982, the player has 'won the Labor Lottery' and is permanently assigned as the sole border inspector on the country's war-won political border.  You recieve new and increasingly limiting instructions from an ineffective bereaucracy, double check for forged documents, earn a bare wage that forces you to choose between medicine for a sick son or food for your whole family, have work days cut short by suicide bombers-- and even man a sniper rifle when security staff is cut short.  The game's strength is in the brutality of its presentation. It's all dark humor painting a surprisingly nuanced picture of the Cold War era, of immigration, of third-world countries, of governments; but altogether never overdoing it, or even tongue-in-cheek. The game's strength is that everything it needs to communicate is effectively communicated through gameplay.  Papers, Please is a really tremendously unique game that should be owned for the experience. It's ♥♥♥♥ed up in all the best ways, and, let's not forget, is the most entertainment I've ever gotten out of forced bureaucratic paperwork in all my life. Definitely check it out because I promise there's no other game like it.

So you are a borders control officer in this simple looking game.  To begin you are checking passports - yeah that guys face matches his picture, passport number mhm... simple enough. Daily you are assigned new tasks, soon immigrants require further paperwork which all must be checked and stamped so you know it isn't a forgery. Then they require proof of vaccines as polio hits the country... then there are faces of the country's most wanted you must watch out for as well as doing your job.  The game becomes a test of your scrutiny and vigilance towards the documentation and dialogue as you approve or decline individuals and hope as you call 'next' that a little print out doesn't appear on your desk telling you why the last person's checks were incorrect.  You are monitored!  To add further problems, you encounter various characters coming through your booth. There is the chap who seems nice enough with his hand drawn passport but no you cannot just let through anyone! Then there is the guy who dumps a bomb at your window! Then there is the ever elusive order. It is up to you how you deal with this vigilante group. Do you support them with their promises to keep you safe or do you maintain your honesty and deny them their requests. At the same time there is corruption and you are ordered by your superiors to let certain individuals through against the rules.  At the end of every day you go home with whatever scrapings you made from bribes, rewards and efficiency at your work. You can save money by denying your family heat and food but they will get sick and you must pay for medicine.  This game for whatever reason is addictive! I enjoy playing it and am curious to discover all 20 endings and somehow unlock the endless mode. People complain about the price but for the hours you get out of it, it is not to be sniffed at.

Government Admin Simulator 1982.  Or, that is how it would be if this game weren't addictive, engrossing and filled with misery everywhere you look.   You are a lowly citizen given the opportunity to admit people into the country. You need to be alert for any problems with their documents, a typo here, the height of the person, anything can be wrong, and you need a sharp eye.  Having worked in admin before make me realise it's easier when you've done this kind of focused examination of documents to ensure the people have everything they need.   Pre-scripted events like terrorism, bombs, a secret government organisation, bribes from applicants, favours from officials appear to make you question the orders you receive from above, along with potential opportunities to give your family a better home. And yes, you do have a family, though you don't see them, you need to inspect enough people each day to earn money for rent, food, heat, and medicine etc when needed.  Multiple endings, so plenty of chances to get it wrong or right. Overall, a very well made game which harkens back to the era of the fall of the Soviet union, East and West Germany and the breakup of Yugoslavia.
I always feel like I'm doing something wrong but it seems like there's so many possible outcomes, fun game.

It's hard to be a kind person when you son is dieing of flu, your family is freezing and hungry and foreigners find throwing firebombs at your workplace to be a worthwhile pasttime. This game puts you in the shows of a minor character under the foot of a despotic government. How you deal with that is largely up to you, and you quickly find out how high the stakes really are.  A great game all around. Glory to Arstozka

This game is compelling in a way I can't even describe because it is so different from anything I've experienced before. Essentially, the gameplay boils down to being a TSA agent, but the setting, atmosphere, and music somehow manage to turn that into something so much more. You find yourself doing to people what you would hate having done to you if you were attempting to get through security at an airport or border all because of orders handed down to you and the family you are trying to protect. Do you deny someone you know is going to do something terrible despite him having all the correct documents? Do you turn away someone desperate to escape a terrible situation because his passport expired a day ago? Do you invade a person's privacy to determine their sex? It's a strange position to find yourself in and all of these scenarios add an interesting level of morality to your decisions. You keep wanting to play to see what happens next, what rules change, and what people show up at your gates. The endless mode and the multiple possible endings in the story mode add to the replayability of the title, and trust me, you will want to know what else can possibly happen based on the choices you made throughout the game. Overall, it's a fun and very interesting game. 8/10.

(Experience: Made it to Day 28) (Time spent: 11 hours at the moment) (Bought price: $3.29 cdn)  'Papers, Please' is a simple yet addictive game that utilizes your abilities to follow the rules. You are an inspector, and your job is to DENY or APPOVE people who are trying to cross the border to Arstotzka.  Here's the twist ... Papers Please makes it incredibly satisfying to follow the rules and weed out the crooks, false positives, forged passports and other information. As you progress with each day, you get a certain amount of money to feed your family based on your efforts at your job. If you work fast, you get more pay. If you don't have enough money, your family gets cold, sick, or hungry. You want to keep them alive.  Bottomline: You should DEFINITELY try it out!

I knew I'd love this game as soon as I finished the demo earlier this year and the full game doesn't disappoint. Its tagline 'A dystopian document thriller' perfectly describes a game experience I've yet to find in any other game. The game has beautiful pixel graphics and its color palette and music set the tone from the getgo. Checking passports might sound easy enough but as the tasks you have to perform get harder you also discover that doing things by the books might not always be the right thing after all.  All in all this little game really makes you think about the society we live in, especially about immigration and how sometimes seemingly arbitrarily rules can define one person's whole life. That being said, the game also has a lot of genuinely funny moments.  As you can see I can't recommend this game enough.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
