A glance at Papers, Please might cause someone to think 'Why would anyone want to play a game about checking for errors in documentation? That sounds like a job.' But if there's anything that we can learn from simulation games is that they don't have to be fun to draw you in, because once you find that each document is a window into a person's private life, and that you are reluctantly given the tough decision 'Should I let this person into my country?', you find that there is a dangerously comfortable flow.  This game confronts you with sequences of people who provide you documentation for immigrating to the ficticious country Arstotzka (based on the Soviet Union). You must carefully search their documents for errors and make sure that everything is in order before letting them in. But the genius behind this game soon becomes apparent. You have limited time, and the more people you let into the country before the end of the day, the more money you get. What do you need money for? Well, you have a large nuclear family who all rely on your income to take care of heating, food, medicine, and you will never be able to afford all of these things.   But you can't just let in everyone, because every time you permit a person with incorrect documentation to enter, you receive a citation, and eventually get docked pay. This creates a wonderful tension between wanting money and not loosing your job. And checking documents isn't easy, it's often tedius to compare spelling of names, or social security numbers, or expiration dates, or remembering what type of identification each person should be having, so making mistakes is a matter of a keen eye and a good memory for rules.   To make it even harder, you only have a third of the screen to place documents, so you can never see all of them at a time. But that wouldn't be stressful enough, because each person often has a story and in such a dystopian world, you find people who empathize with, but have bad documents, or people who are evil but have everythign in order. And the game will often send you reminders of decisions you made that ruined someone's life, or sometimes saved it.  And on top of all of this there is a plot about a group of revolutionaries who try to recruit you to their cause. And with the horrible bureaucracy you see around you, the revolutionaries have a good point, but you must decide whether to risk helping them, or to play it safe with a government that will hopefully leave you and your family alone.  What all this adds up to is a game that causes you to have to make the decisions that people in stressful bureaucratic jobs must make. In a way it forces you to begin to think more openly about why people at the DMV seem unhappy, or even show us how people in an authoritarian government may seem heartless, but are really trying to protect their family.  So purchase this game for your own education, if not for its compelling and intricate gameplay.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is an exciting game where you are playing as an volunteered inspector in a fake Communist country called Arstotzka after a six year war with Kolechia. Because of this you may experience a terrorist attack if a Kolechian passes. The game feels real and when I play it I feel like its really my duty to make sure everybody passes the border correctly without making any mistakes. What makes it feel more realistic is how you don't forget you have a family and you have to take care of them by making sure they are healthy, they have food to eat, and you have to buy things for their birthday. Even if you do have a crappy computer/laptop you can still play this game because you aren't moving around or going anywhere. The graphics are in 8 bit so that makes it better if you have a bad computer. You sit at a desk and make sure people pass the border without flaws. In some parts of the game you may have to go back levels which isn't very happy to find out, but it just made the game better for me. And even though sometimes you may be a bit low on cash you can turn on easy mode and earn an extra 20 bucks a day/level. Also, the music in this game makes it even more fun and playable. The only flaw I could find is, how nobody really likes you besides your family, Jorgi, and a guard. So on a scale of 1 to 10, this amazing game deserves a 9 out of 10.

What kind of person am I?  I like to think I’m loyal to my friends, as honest I can possibly be, hardworking and generous. Everything I keep around in my life seems to point to those things to some degree. I’ve had the same friends since elementary school, I try to be as upfront as possible even when it can knock me down, I get consistent work from quite a few outlets, and I like to give my time, my love, and even gifts. There’s a beautiful joy in doing that. In fact I love giving people presents more than I get them.  So I must be a good person, right? …Right?  But what would I be if circumstances were different? What would I be if, say, I had a sick family that counted on me to get medicine, pay for food, make sure the amenities were paid for and running such as heat, or simply paying rent to keep a roof over our heads? Would I be as honest? Would I be as loyal? I like to think so, but given my time playing Papers, Please, I’m starting to wonder about myself.  This PC game is a self-described “Dystopian Document Thriller”. I prefer the term “Dystopian Emotional Rollercoaster That Rips Out Your Morals, Waves Them In Front of You and Laughs While You Pretend You’re Not What This Game Lets You Be”. But I can see why they went with that one. It’s a bit easier to roll off the tongue.  You start the game as a rookie Immigration Inspector working at the newly acquired border town of Grestin after a six-year war with the neighbouring country of Kolechia has finally ended. The game begins on a positive note – you’re given a job, an apartment, and a seemingly easy enough task. You check over immigrant documents – much like a border guard does – and make sure the person coming through is clean.  How is this done? Cross-referencing ID cards with passport numbers. Matching pictures, making sure no document has expired, questioning minor discrepancies, checking their permits, etc. Normal things most of us have experienced one time or another just on the other side of the screen.  When I played for the first 10 minutes nothing seemed odd to me. It was just a different kind of puzzle game with a unique outlook. Rather than find the right pieces to mash together, I looked over documents and cross-referenced them with my Immigration’s rulebook, just to be safe. All in all, a pretty uneventful first day. I turned away some people and let others through.  Day two was when I realized this game was, as Michael Caine would say about Batman, something more.  I started my morning off as usual: I walked over to my booth, checked over notes my government had left for me, and proceeded to call in the first person wishing to enter the country. This was when I noticed the atmosphere this game is just oozing out its pores. The colour pallet is somber: blacks, browns and dark blues cover just about everything. On the top half of the screen is a bird’s eye view of the border. There’s my booth, a few guards, and a massive line-up of immigrants waiting to cross. Here’s what caught my eye – each person has no identity in that line. They are just a black silhouette. Another cow in the herd. I can’t connect with a person who has no face, so I don’t. Given the depth of this game and the sheer brilliance in its questioning of humanity, I know this was an intentional design choice. Emotion can only tangle logic and affect your decision. Or perhaps it’s not my view of them, but the government’s? I’m still not sure.  When I called in my first person to inspect, a black silhouette slowly dragged themselves over inside my booth. In steps a small man, standing just about 5 ft. tall and he hands me nothing. He tells me about how proud he is of Arstotzka and he excitedly recounts his itinerary. I ask him for his passport and immediately the excited tone goes away. “I need one?” “Yes.”  He promises to return with a passport and apologizes for wasting my time.  I found it a bit odd, but oh well, I moved on and called for the next person. In comes this tall, skinny woman and she hands over her passport, work permit and even slips me a card for a nightclub she says she works for. She tells me to call and let her know if I’ll be stopping into town and her girls will take care of me. I left the card on the counter and started reading her documents. Her passport number seemed OK, the names on the permit and the passport matched, she said would be staying to work for two months. Everything seemed hunky dory. I stamped an approval on her papers and gave them back to her and told her not to cause any trouble.  She smiled and walked past me.  As I call in the next person to inspect I notice this woman’s black silhouette isn’t moving in the same direction the others did. Instead of taking a right and heading off screen, she turns left and walks towards the border guards. Suddenly, the game stops. This woman takes out a grenade and tosses it near her and the guards. Before anyone can do anything it explodes, killing her and the three men on patrol. The game fades to black.  Oh god, what did I do? I’m responsible for that? Was it game over?  No. Up pops a newspaper headline about a bombing from the Kolechian terrorist that I let through. The deaths. The terror. It’s all there. Then the game fades back in and guess what? It’s day three on the job. I failed, but the game isn’t over. That’s just part of it.  It turns out I made a mistake and had my paycheck docked some. So I couldn’t pay for medicine for my sick son and food for my family.  This is when I started to pay attention to the game a bit more. Each person in the line-up wouldn’t have a face until they were in the booth with me. When they were, I was so crazy about not having another terrorist come through I would detain anyone – anyone – who looked at me wrong. Work permit says you’re here for three months but you said 7 weeks? Search and detain. That way I’m cracking down on enough people to lower the odds of a psychopath getting through and getting a few extra dollars. I was fine with this procedure and thought I would be good doing this for the rest of the game.  (Gah! There's a word limit I hit. The rest of my review can be found on my blog at  http://gamesnshit.wordpress.com/) .

'Papers, Please' is a fun puzzle game set around the unlikely theme of a Communist border control post. As the border guard for Arstotzka you are under pressure from the authorities to accurately process entrants according to ever-changing criteria, whilst juggling your meagre salary to keep yourself and your family alive. As your pay is linked to processed entrants, you have to push through as many as possible without making mistakes; mistakes are deducted from your pay. A stream of entrants queues outside your booth, meaning you only have a few seconds to make a decision - yes or no - on each. Will you help through the refugee without papers? Will you take a bribe? Will you help a dissident?  I love the grey, bleak 1984-esque world of Arstotzka and how, as a minor official, you find out about changes through the state newspaper and visitors to your booth. This is a challenging, fun puzzler, with surprisingly deep story writing and I'm really hoping there we'll get a chance to return to Arstotzka in future games from the same developer!  Glory to Arstotzka!
One of the best indie titles I've played in a while. completely engrossing with great gameplay and retro-cultural feel. totally worth checking out.

Throught the gameplay you have a tingling sensation that YOU DO MATTER, even though the other players trying to get in are NPCs,   The game drives you forward not by self improvement or a leaderboard, but by a list of necesseties that you need for yourself and your family. Making matters worse most of the time you WON'T be able to puchase all your neccesities, so you have a driving decision to send medicine to keep your son healthy or to go without food for another day, Or go without heat and risk yourself from getting sick as well.

Papers, please is a dystopian game about the land of Arstotzka. You play the winner of the October Labor Lottery, and must start the job ASAP. Your mission is to check peoples passports as they come through. It starts off very simple, Arstotzkans only. As you progress through the days it gets harder, and you will most likely get less people through, meaning less money. At the end of every day you get to manage your household, with upgrades for your booth, new apartments and food/heating cuts. The game is simple but enjoyable with amazing sounds. The game also has many achievements (some are hidden) and quests that you can choose to accept or deny. The game has 20 endings and is a nice challenge trying to get them all. The game only has 1 task, but it is a fun one. 7/10

Bizarrely addictive considering its premise, this game is half puzzle, half survival simulator. Essentially you're given a changing set of rules of varying complexity and have to compare the passports and other documentation of immigrants to your brutal Communist home country. Enjoy features such as your wife, son, uncle, and mother-in-law dying as a result of cold, hunger, disease, or any combination of the three as you fail to bring home enough money to save them all. You're going to lose in this game, but there's a lot of fun to be had in the process. Highly recommended at a sale price.

Visually set in a late cold-war era country that was recently closed off, so they need you to be vigilant and process any many people as you can without violating restrictions or allowing unofficial papers to be processed wrongly. You know, this is a f#cking weird game and I f#cking love it. I was not expecting myself to like it, but as usual, it has things that thick me off. As usual, I will start with those, so you know what to expect:  Now, being honest, I only found two things that caused trouble. The first of them is the limited space. 99% of the gameplay is spent comparing papers and looking if they’re legit, and to do so you have a desktop. The problem is that the desktop is small as hell. The thing is, I’m pretty sure this was made on purpose, but it doesn’t stop from being annoying. It also doesn’t help that when in fullscreen, the game has quite big black areas surrounding the game area, which do nothing and serve no purpose. The game could at least expand the window, instead of surrounding it with blackness and nothing... But then again, it's a game that you might as well play on Window mode.  The second thing that I didn’t like and caused trouble has to be with the graphics. The game is done in a pixelated style that suits it quite well, however when you have to compare photos to the people who hold them, those pixelated graphics backfire at times. A lot of times I got citations because “ID/Passport photo wasn’t the same” and crap like that when it was quite difficult to spot any difference! I ended up constantly checking them with the investigate option, and multiple times the game found differences I could just NOT spot by myself. It also doesn't help that the game bugs out at times and tells you that something matches or doesn't match when that's complete horse-sh#t and it looks like it would/wouldn't. Like the ID saying he's 1,55m tall and he seems to be nearly 2m tall, however the game will tell you that there's nothing wrong with those papers. It's hard to trust the game when crap like that keeps happening.  Lastly a third little problem, it’s not a game-breaking bug or anything, but rather an observation: You get paid by who many legit people get through. However, there are days when, I sh#t you not, only one or even no one was qualified to go through, meaning I didn’t get paid ANYTHING. That happened in two days already, and every time it happened I just restarted the day as with no pay, I would be pretty much screwed and forced to get a Game Over.  But besides that, what do you have left? A quite interesting interactive documentary about how sh#t the mid areas of Europe felt during the wars. And even though the countries in the game are fictional, they’re all based on actual countries.  The biggest point the game has running for it has to be the moral choices. It’s up to you who goes through and who doesn’t, and letting the right or wrong people in has consequences.  The audio is also good, fits quite well with the graphics. The main theme is catchy, and the rest of the game usually has ambient sounds with the made-up languages of the characters. Nothing stands out, which is good as it makes everything feel more or less natural.  The graphics, as I’ve said, have a few problems when it comes to the faces, but that being said they fit the game perfectly. Specially the still-images for what happens in special events.  The characters are also surprisingly well written, and could easily pass for real people. From corrupted douchelords to people who only want to survive, from soldiers who are forced to go through this sh#t everyday to jackasses like Jorji who are just lovable in every damn way.  Do I recommend this game? Yeah. It will put your brain to work, looking for what’s actually wrong with all those damn papers, while having a laugh or two with the current, rather sad events. The game also has, for what I know, around 20 or so endings, so that’s a good enough reason to play the game a few times. On a sale, this game is quite worth it for people who look for more casual and relaxing experiences.  TL;DR Edition: Relaxing game about people constantly trying to pass through a frontier with illegal drugs up their #sses. Well written and fun to play, it’s a good pick for any casual player who just wants to have a good time.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Wow! I'm considering this one of the greatest games I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. This game takes me back to the golden age of gaming, with for instance the game based on Fredric Forsyths 'the Fourth Protocol' and Sid Meyers 'Covert operations' particularly in mind, and at the same time brings a whole lot of new to the table. Who would ever imagine that sitting in a passport booth all day long would feel so rewarding and exciting? Please, all creative and able developers of the world, learn from sole developer Lucas Pope and make more games like this. The world needs YOU!

Scraping together enough money to buy my son crayons after a day of denying visa entry to person after person was immensely satisfying. Trust me, you need this game.

Addictive gameplay in this one, you play as an immigration officer on the border of fictional pseudo-communist-eastern block country of Arstotzka. Every day you must check immigrants' IDs, permits, work passes and so on, trying to not let down your superiors and in the meantime taking home as much money as possible, even by being corrupted, in order to guarantee your family food, heat and medicines.  Every day new regulations are established and being fast, without committing errors, checking every single document with the right tools, is really hard and stressful, but really fun!! 20 different endings are available, together with many unpredictable twists, and include mysterious plots uncovered, breakaways to foreign and safer countries, terrorists attacks, personal richness and so on.  Technically is a really basic game, but Papers, Please strengths reside in its peculiar mechanics, it was a really nice surprise and I would suggest it to anyone interested in something fresh and unique, easy to learn but difficult to master, a good example of ideas winning over graphics awesomeness!

Glory to Arstotzka. At first the job was easy. An easy way to earn money for my family.  But then it became hard. I had to accept bribes simply to keep my family alive. I was immoral, denying innocent men and women who simply wanted to leave their past demons behind. I accepted many forms of payment. I participated in a shadowy organization whose goal was to overthrow my own government.  I could not even protect the poor guard who grew up in my hometown. What else was I to tell his poor lover, who showed up days later? I watched as shouting guards and smoking guns cut down the unlucky ones. I endured the hard labor camps. I was sentenced to death for treason of the the highest order. I escaped to Obristan with my family with the help of a reformed drug smuggler. I am a traitor. I am a coward. I am a refugee. But I am a hero to my son. He still brings joy to my heart as he draws pictures with his crayons, pictures that I used to take to work. Even as my beard grows grey, I hug my wife and son in the snowy fields and think to myself: Arstotzka can have its glory. I only want my family.

A simulation of what it is like to be a border guard. What seems to be a trivial matching game on the surface is actually a much deeper simulation with surprising complexity.  PROS: -A simple 'gimmick' mechanic that is expanded upon in a surprising way leading to surprising depth of play.  -Amusing secondary decisions and backstory (managing finances, choosing who to let in at cost to yourself, and other political impacts in the fictional world).  CONS: -The font is a little hard to read at times. -The large graphic at the top of the screen showing the line of people is rather unneccessary and takes up critical screen space. It would have been better if this graphic was shown whenever something happened rather than just being there all the time.

There are few games this simple that are this fun. I love the dark, oppressive setting, the subtle humor and the thought involved with progressing through the game. There is something so oddly satisfying about finding discrepancies in the papers you're given and denying someone entry; there's also satisfaction from reviewing all of the documents and letting someone through, knowing you haven't missed any detail.  With multiple endings and lots of replayability in both the story mode and the endless mode, Papers, Please is a game everyone should try.

Papers, Please is a game that looked incredibly boring on first glance but I was so wrong. The $10 price tage kept me away for a while so I waited it to go down to $6 but I would gladly pay $10 or even $15. The simplicity is what makes this game so great, just checking passports, ID's, and documents on and on. I can play this game for hours on end and still have fun. Simply great.

Papers please is a great game, the story line is good and all the achievements you can get is nicely made.  In my opinion I think it is one of the best games of 2013, The randomized falses on the passports can make the game more challenging because you dont know if the next foreigner is allowed to go through or not. 7.5 out of 10. - The story can get a little repetitive at times but it is still a great game.

With the game on sale, I think now would be a good time to try and cheer on the community to purchase it.  Made by a single man, Lucas Pope, Papers Please places you in the role of a Border Checkpoint Inspector, your job is simple, allow any cleared entrants entry to Arstotzka - the country you hail from - and deny or detain any entrants with inconsistant information, illegal items, forged documents, the list goes on, there are alot of bad and/or poor people trying to get into Arstotzka and it's your objective to stop them.  You enter your booth, you read your bulliten informing you of these new Entry Permits to help control traffic into Arstotzka, you acknowledge them and open your shutters, you click the speaker, 'NEXT!', A forienger enters your booth, 'Papers Please.', He hands you his passport and this new permit, Very well, he hails from Impor, Enkyo, thats all good- Wait, his entry permit is out of date, you inform the man of this discrepency, he replies with 'I could not come until now.', You deny him and he makes his leave, 'NEXT!'.  Now, you could of chosen to let the poor man through, however you would recieve what is called a citation, meaning that you have allowed someone access to Arstotzka whose papers were false in one way or another, your first two citations will be mere warnings, make more mistakes and it will begin to impact your payment ultimately at the cost of your family, at the end of each day you are given a report of your progress as well as the current status of your family, you are struggling to provide for four family members and on your first playthrough, you'll likely be consistantly having trouble with rent, food and current family health at constant risk of dying.  Making this even more troubling is that you are on a timer each day, so you can't really take your time with people, but at the same moment you're trying to make sure they're all clear for entry, with an incresing difficulty curve, to avoid getting even a single citation is a challenge that only the very best inspectors will beat.  What carries this game from being more than just Border Checkpoint Simulator is a deep story about a six-year war with Arstotzka's neighbouring country, Kolechia and the consequences of opening a new Border, alongside corruption, morale dilemmas and terrorism.  The game really grips you into the role as well, even the sound effects of stamping deny or approved onto a passport or moving the ID Supplement over the Entry Permit sounds crisp and believable, clear attention to detail has been made on every aspect which helps this game draw you in over the course of your daily duties.  Lucas Pope should be proud of himself, he did the unthinkable, a border checkpoint game, being fun and engaging, I respect the man for his accomplishment and I highly urge anybody on the fence about this game to pick it up, the £7 price tag is well worth it, but £1.74 is a steal you should take while you still can.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Voted best 'Stop the boats' Simulator for '13

This game is incredibly frusterating. I've had to restart a few times, but I still keep coming back. I discovered early on to let everyone in your family die but one person, and it makes the game way more bearable. It is virtually impossible otherwise. Despite that, the game keeps my attention, I like that there are choices and consequences for your choices, and I enjoy the fast pace of the day to day job. I'd recommend it solely on the fact that it is a unique, addictive game.

Boyfriend gifted this to me. I thought it was just a unique job simulator but there's so much more. The storyline and characters are great, especially the silly guy who keeps trying to get through the check point, in one case with a passport made with crayons. I believe his name is Jorgi or something. I freaking love that dude.  This is a thoroughly wonderful game that is often stressful but with plenty of humor to keep you going. I really freaking love this game. I'd say it's the most entertaining and unique game I've come across in a long time and I'll be replaying it several times in the future just to see all the endings and really explore the full storyline. One final note is that this game can be quite difficult at times playing on normal mode. For me, usually the only thing that gets my family by day by day is taking bribes from people at the cost of a demerit. You want to do your best in this game and save those two warning demerits per day for bribes and other activities that require you to do illegal things. I haven't played on easy mode yet but I might just to see how it is to have disposable cash and afford stuff I haven't been able to afford like adopting my niece. You get 20 free credits a day supplement in easy mode. But I thouroghly reccommend playing on normal first just to get into the stressfull atmophere of poverty and experience the sadness when you can't afford a gift for your son's birthday. On the other hand: I didn't really mind. This is ♥♥♥♥ing Arstotzka. You know we're freaking poor as poo so why you asking me for such a damn expensive crayon set. 20 credits? What the hell, son. You really set yourself up for dissapointmen. 'Here, I have crayon for you, son. I make it from wax and my tears. Draw proud Arstotzkan soldier beating papa up for accidentally admitting Obristani terrorist what killed 2 guards and stole many, many turnips from Arstotzkan turnip reserve. Now eat that crayon!'    Glory to Arstotzka
Glorious.

A gripping and emotional story that seriously makes you question your morals. Also, the gameplay itself is surprisingly tough, with you having to pay attention to each and every detail, and rather than chucking everything at you at once and overwhelming you, it slowly adds more and more pieces of paperwork and rules, so you have plenty of time to understand each one before you have to learn a new one.

a very diffrent and interesting game. It really forces the decisions in your face all the time, and that's a good thing. This is the only game that really blurs the decisions, its not bad guy choice and good guy choice, its family, money and morals. While the game can get slightly repetitive, it changes it up after almost every day. Unique in every way. 9/10

This is one interesting game. A simple game of morality, a game of doing your job and supplying for your family, a game where the choices you make can determine if you live or die.   All you do is file paper work! It may not seem like it at first, but this game gets intense, quickly. The amount of things that you have to do quickly escalate and you have to remember who and what are allowed and what aren't. The story is crazy, terrorist attacks, rifles, poison powder, secret organizations, and even murderers!
eh very stronk game u learn become russian border controler very good simulator for old cccp yes da

This game is compelling in a way I can't even describe because it is so different from anything I've experienced before. Essentially, the gameplay boils down to being a TSA agent, but the setting, atmosphere, and music somehow manage to turn that into something so much more. You find yourself doing to people what you would hate having done to you if you were attempting to get through security at an airport or border all because of orders handed down to you and the family you are trying to protect. Do you deny someone you know is going to do something terrible despite him having all the correct documents? Do you turn away someone desperate to escape a terrible situation because his passport expired a day ago? Do you invade a person's privacy to determine their sex? It's a strange position to find yourself in and all of these scenarios add an interesting level of morality to your decisions. You keep wanting to play to see what happens next, what rules change, and what people show up at your gates. The endless mode and the multiple possible endings in the story mode add to the replayability of the title, and trust me, you will want to know what else can possibly happen based on the choices you made throughout the game. Overall, it's a fun and very interesting game. 8/10.
Great game. Wow. Such good.
THIS IS GOOD GAME. BE BUYING THIS GAME. GAME PLAY IS CHALLENGES AND INTERACTING ARE LIMITED BUT HAVING MEANINGS. BE BUYING THIS GAME. THIS POST WAS WRITE OF FREE WILL. BUY GAME. BUY GAME.
Almost as bleak as the queue at the student admin building during freshers' week.
Papers, Please is more fun than you can imagine. I wouldn't want to work in a real border checkpoint, but the one in Arstotzka is an exception.

Welcome to the mind of the frontline bureaucrat!  Yes, you're repeatedly reviewing documents, but it's strangely addictive... and enlightening.  Do you callously do your job without regard for the person in front of you, or do you use what little power you have to show kindness to the poor disenfranchised soul? What will you do in the face of conflicting imperatives? Will you put your own safety and well-being above that of your countrymen… or even your family?  Sometimes depressing. Sometimes monotonous. Always thought provoking. Papers, Please is an impressive accomplishment in gameplay and storytelling.
Feel this amazing game slowly suck away your humanity as you detain poor people who have sadly let their permits expire :( Who knew checking papers could be such gut-wrenching FUN
Great game, truly a lil steam Gem to find. I have spent hours trying to get good at it; and I feel it was time well spent. You will need to make a cheat sheet those for countries and districts.

The Greatest Paperwork Simulator to be written. Until a game developer creates a 'Work at EA Help Desk SImulator: Origin Edition', there won't be another to top the working conditions of living under a bureaucratic regime fraught with moral choices. Please be nice to Jori. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

Surprisingly, very addictive. I was quite skeptical of this game when I first heard of it. But I decided to give it a try and fell in love with it. It gets quite difficult the further you get and have to make some hard choices. This game is the definition to 'Don't judge a book by its cover.'

Amazing little game. The concept is so mundane but it is genuinely so entertaining to hold these little simulated lives in the palm of your hand waiting on the stamp to fall. Slowly but surely increased the difficulty. A few hours in your are scanning 5-6 different bits of paperwork but the ramp is so gradual you dont even see the difficulty increase.   Starts to introduce little things to play on your mind, that maybe the place where you live isnt so good? Maybe I should start letting in these decent people even though their paperwork isnt so good? What about these shady resistance characters? What about this guy who is clearly mentally ill trying to get home but his passport is written in crayon? You need to balance all of this with your family who rely on your wages, wages that will be cut if you get caught letting people in illegally/erroneously.  The graphics look simple, the concept looks simple, but this game will stir things inside of you. It will make you realise how much of a bureaucratic fascist or peace loving do-gooder you are. That, to me, is what games are all about. Buy it.
The comunism is the best.

Next time you want to go to the movies but there isnt anthing you want to see buy this game insted. Its simple, fun, addictive, and has tons of backstory that you can figure out after you play it a few times. The people who made this game stould hired by valve to make Half Life 3.

I would say the subtitle of 'dystopian document thriller' is partly correct. The setting and mechanics in this game are fairly unique I think, where you play a border agent in a country with an oppressive government.  The gameplay itself is actually fairly routine, and can be summarized as rule memorization and observation skills. This is fine, as it works and makes sense within the story. The sound design and aesthetic lend to this very well. There were no performance issues.  I don't think there is that much replayability to the story despite the variety of endings. There is an unlockable endless mode, which could make this fun as a pastime too Still, I'd reccomend this game for its unique experience. Its really not something you see every day.
Dystopian monotony turned into an investigation game.  I never looked forward to paperwork as much as i did this. So much emotion as well.
A fantastic game full of drama and mystery, all while inspecting papers, this is a game you simply can not miss.

I put off buying this game for quite a while, after all it doesn't really seem that interesting, but it truly is a great game.  If you're considering buying this game but aren't sure then just do it. As you progress through the game the story, or should I say your story really develops. New rules are introduced by the government and old ones removed. It's constantly a challenge to deal with the barrage of documents that are thrown your war.  The save system is excellent, allowing you to return to any single day and make a different decision regarding certain people in order to change the outcome of the story. The game is a humourous but morally challenging parody of what would be an impossible job.  Well worth playing, this game will be a classic.

At first, I didn't think I would like this game. When I first saw it, I thought Papers, Please looked ugly, dull, and boring. But it actually turned out to be an exciting and fun game. I originally got this game for $5 during a steam sale, but I think this game is still worth it for the full $10 price. Buy this game and experience what it has to offer!

This game is incredible. The gameplay, which sounds sort of boring and tedious in theory, is actually surprisingly addictive. The main focus of this game, however, is the player's own morality. As the border inspector, you will have to keep your conscience, the well being of the country, and your family's health in balance. In general, one of these 3 factors will have to suffer in order to keep the others afloat; it is possible to reach the end without any problems if you are quick and accurate, but chances are you won't be able to do this on your first playthrough, which brings me to my next point: this game has 20 (twenty!) endings, but be warned that a lot of them are fairly similar. If you love games about player choice and/or themes about morals, I would highly recommend this game.

Even though it consists of rough pixel graphics and comes up with an almost ridiculous gameplay idea, this game provides great immersion and atmosphere.   You inspect passports and either deny or approve immigrants. Time is running and if you can't check enough immigrants or make too many mistakes, you won't earn enough money to feed your family.   Soon you won't notice the faces in front of you anymore. What you see is numbers and details. And mistakes, letting you press the 'detain' button to get a little more money. Take bribes, still deny. More money. Something wrong with passport? Why did you even bother to come here and waste my time? 'Oh didn't know passport was required'. ♥♥♥♥♥, please. DENIED! DENIED! DENIED! Out with you, Glory to Arstotzka!  The desk is always too small and always filled with papers. Passports, permits, supplements, work certificates, id cards, vaccination certificates, various bs the immigrants drop. There are stories told, you can make your own decisions wether and how to get involved, and there will be terror and blood as well.   The game hardly ever gets boring, too much is happening and often you have to take care of many things at once. It's a masterpiece when it comes to game design and storytelling. Play and watch what it does to you.
A story of a poor commoner whose decisions affects people’s fates or even more… a future of the whole Arstotzkan Nation
Watched my entire family slowly starve to death before my eyes because I refused to let an old married couple be forcibly separated in the immigration line. 10/10.

Bizarrely compelling. I couldn't put it down. The gameplay is oddly satisfying but the minimalist but excellent story is the real draw. Recommended if you want a slower paced game with some political/historical commentary.
Yay for Papers,Please!
One of my favorite games of all time. Easy.
Passport stamping has never been this tough before! 10/10

Definately one of the best 8-bit games i've ever played. a perfect mix of Puzzle, and excitment. upgrades, and jokes. 8/10
This game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.
Great story, quirky graphics, and a great twist on a classic simple 'matching' game
This manages to take a beaucracy simulator and do something interesting and memorable with it. That alone makes it worth experiencing in my opinion.  All glory to Arstotzka, comrades.
Maybe it doesn't look like a very good game, but I believe it is worth your money and time much more than any AAA game. When Steam will make a sale, you have to buy it. Glory to Arstotzka.
Nasty pixlated boobies.

The game is really well done. Your in-game actions (passport and document checking) contributes A LOT to the atmosphere. It can be very immersive if you really try to be consistent on your actions - will you help evetyone who moans about how badly they need to see the doctor on the other side? Or maybe you are so hard coded on rules, that you won't let pass a girl, that one of the guards is in love, or your bosses lover (I guess, as she mentiones something about his endurance). Also how you follow the routine makes a difference - until you are forced to state a reason for the rejection, you can simply deny entry to anyone with missing documents without asking, or you might take some extra time to investigate, as they might be admissable after all.  The game is in a dark setting. Especially when at some point you start to feel how Arstotzkans are blatantly oppressed by their state. Imagine, that for many people on earth, that still IS reality.  Fun, immersive, makes you think - what do you need more from a simple game?

Interesting game. Not flashy at all in graphics department but not meant to be I guess. Not easy to play as the rules are always changing and sometimes you are presented with situations that don't apply to rules I guess much like real life. Playing it I can only imagine what it must have been like to live and work in a country that operates like this. It's not ever going to be game of the year, just a nice way to casually spend a little time.   My only con is the interface isn't entirely intuitive. Plus you either remember all the issuing cities by heart or refer to the manual book on your desk. In game documents do not clearly state how you should do something. So a little bit of googling is requiring.

Papers Please is fun for a while, but after you fail and have to restart a couple of times it sarts to get pretty tedious. I believe that the entire game was meant to be played through in one sitting, because its hard to continue the game once it is started. But overall its pretty good for a game about reviewing immigrant papers. I think it gets,  4/5 for art, the graphics blended well with the gameplay and you could easily distinguish what was going on.  5/5 for soundtrack, It was very relaxing and easy to listen to.  3/5 for gameplay, it does get tedious but is entertaining most of the time.  7/10 overall, its fun and entertaining   *EDIT* can be played in more than one sitting and isnt that tedious after further investigation.

This game shouldn't be fun. You play as a passport inspector. Sounds horridly boring right? But it's not. Searching through the details is oddly part of the fun. There is a slight story line with 20 different endings and choices you'll have to make. It's graphics are simple yet charming and full of nostalgia. The sound effects while not many are spot on and the characters will make you laugh. Glory to Arstotzka! 9/10

'Congratulations. The October labor lottery is complete. Your name was pulled. For immediate placement, report to the The Ministry of Admission at Grestin Border Checkpoint. An apartment will be provided for you and your family in East Grestin. Expect a Class-8 dwelling.'  That is the quote that greets you as you start your job as the immigration inspector in this game, called Papers, Please. This game has a nice retro look to it. In story mode, you are the working man of the family, taking care of your wife, mother-in-law, uncle, and son. The more people you let in, the more money you get, so work fast, but be careful, make too many mistakes, and you lose pay and savings. It doesn't seem hard at first, but then as the game progresses, you have to deal with more papers and have to scout for the 3 wanted criminals of the day. You also see recurring characters throught the story. You can work with or repel a cult group. Oh, and did I mention there are 20 different endings? Get to the end of the 31 day calander, then you can unlock endless mode. However, it can get boring, feeling more like an actual job than a game. In the end, its definatly worth every penny. I give this game an 8.5/10

Truly a GOTY. Deep, meaningful and frightening experience about onself as a gamer and human being. OCD gamer will have the time of thier lives  Vraiment, le jeu de l'année. Une expérience enrichissante qui vous fera vous questionner sur vous en tant que joueur et être humain. Les obsessionnels compulsifs vont adorer.

It’s a fairly short game with elements of puzzle solving and choices with lasting consequences. I absolutely respect the mechanics imitating how confusing and frustrating bureaucracy is but combined with the binary, out of the blue ending system I just don’t feel like playing it again to get for example the EZIC ending. While the moral conflict and dystopian setting is interesting I wouldn’t look at it in absolutes. Things like strict border policy are absolutely fine if the country is built that way and as long as people of different mentality are free to leave. Unless obligated otherwise, a policy of a country is its business. Score 70%.
I personally feel this game helps my memory be less awful and stimulates my mind. It's great to waste time with yet it also has an interesting plot :)

In 'Papers, please' you play as the immigration inspector of a fictional communist dictatorship; you have to control passport and documents of the immigrants, and you need to learn how to identify swindlers and terrorists. Not many mistakes are allowed or you will loose your job or, worse, you will be prosecuted.   The game is certainly unique, surprisingly addictive and pervaded by a marvellous cynism: you can really win the game only if you behave as a faithful citizen of Arstotzka. You can resist and oppose... but you will simply loose the game.   I found it brilliant.   9/10
Absolutely Brilliant! It's somewhat amazing how what seems to be such a simple game on the surface, is full of harsh moral choices. A must play!

This is probably my game of the year. I'm not sure why it keeps bringing me back. It is, objectively, very repetitive. But the atmosphere is great and you are confronted with many morally dubious choices - that is both choices you can make may seem like the moral one depending on your point of view. I'm sure someone more eloquent than me can go one about the various questions about society the story raises. Highly recommend!
Perfect in every way, shape and form. If you don't think this is your kind of game, think again. The utter simplicity, yet complicated gameplay makes Papers Please one of my favorite games.
Papers plz   This game shouldnt be as hard, as realistic, and as awesome as it is. But it do.

Going into Papers Please I didn't expect much, and what I got was a very well thought out game. Which, in my opinion, is one of the best games I have ever played.   The game is set in a fictional country called Arstotska, and you have the job of being border control. You let immigrants into the country and if they don't have valid paperwork you send them on their way (later in the game you get the option to detain them). This is what I saw in the trailer, so I figured this was one of the boring of the dozens of simulators that are out on the market. So I started the game up, and realized that it was 3 in the morning.   I wouldn't say that this is a fun game, but rather I very entertaining and tense game that gets you very well intrigued with the other countless stories of other immigrants that come into your country. The stress that comes with making enough money each day to keep your family healthy is something that not even Dark Souls could replicate with it's teeth grinding difficulty. Your job becomes more and more difficult as the rules constantly change and you have to check more paperwork until your desk is flooded with it. The last couple of hours were the tense I've had in gaming for a long time. For the cons of this game, well, I can't really think of any. The only thing that comes to mind is the paperwork does become a bit less interesting by the end of the game, and becomes more of a task.   Overall I very much recommend this game, and if you haven't already, buy this game. You will be amazed at how good a paperwork simulator actually is.
If you trust me, you'll buy this game.
Nasty pixlated boobies.

A really playable little game made by Lucas Pope. It's unique in that its the only game i'm aware of where you assume the role of a boarder guard assigned to determine whether to let someone through or not. It gets more and more interesting and complex as you progress through the game having more and more paperwork to deal with and more things to check. There's always new and interesting people and twists to the story and multiple endings. Also I think has really cool 80s style graphics that suits the game well. Totally playable and great fun.
For 5$ and 34mb; this has to be one of the best games I have played so far.  Buy it.

Papers, please is a great game. You play as a border inspector, which has to decide if people can enter the country (Arstotzka). Sometimes, theres a choice between the law and common sense. It is a very original game, which makes it very fresh and enjoyable. You can compare it with the Portal series, you wont play for hundreds of hours, it is a game you visit ever now and then, if you feel like having some mental challenge (and no, i dont mean meantally challenged)  *Pros:* - The game design and music give it a great atmosphere - Great story and very hard desicions, which makes it very enjoyable in my opinion - relatively cheap - 20 different endings  *Cons:* - Some things are predetermined, such as the names of all the EZIC members, it would be cool if they were random - You can't play it for too long, otherwise you'll loose your concentration, and you are going to make a lot of mistakes, which can be very frustating

Interesting game. Not flashy at all in graphics department but not meant to be I guess. Not easy to play as the rules are always changing and sometimes you are presented with situations that don't apply to rules I guess much like real life. Playing it I can only imagine what it must have been like to live and work in a country that operates like this. It's not ever going to be game of the year, just a nice way to casually spend a little time.   My only con is the interface isn't entirely intuitive. Plus you either remember all the issuing cities by heart or refer to the manual book on your desk. In game documents do not clearly state how you should do something. So a little bit of googling is requiring.
Maybe it doesn't look like a very good game, but I believe it is worth your money and time much more than any AAA game. When Steam will make a sale, you have to buy it. Glory to Arstotzka.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_yU4rKLLkE   I usually HATE 8-bit games and I'm rarely a fan of RPGs. This game, at face value, seemed like it would be INCREDIBLY boring. I watched someone play it on YouTube, tried the free demo (Google it... it only has the first 8 days and is missing a lot of features added in the final version, but it's a good test of whether or not you'd like it), and I'm now in love with this game.  It has a very engaging story that has high stakes. Despite being 8-bit with text bubbles, I found myself caring about the characters. I did anything I could to keep my family alive.  There are multiple outcomes all dependant on your deliberate (and sometimes less deliberate) choices. I've only experienced about half of them so far.  The game is also very challenging. The first ten days or so are pretty easy (especially after a first play through), however, as you progress all of the information you need to check and be aware of becomes, at times, borderline insane. I love it.  Please feel free to check out my Let's Play video introducing and reviewing this game.  I highly recommend this game. This is a prime example of not judging a book by its cover.
This game makes me have brain aneurysm whenever I see a mistake in my school work now.  10/10 Glory to Arstotzka!
Great game!

A very fun game!! I thought i am the kid who plays FPS and ♥♥♥♥ BUT NOOOO....THIS GAME IS AWESOME. If you have the money, then definetly buy this game, even if you dont play titles like this one. ok, now onto the pros and cons: Pros: A very smooth gameplay Very interesting story Many choices, endings to pick You can replay it for as many times as you want and still have fun Many interactions are very interesting, funny Jorji Costava  Cons: Very ugly people Very stupid people
Great game! Challenging but fun at the same time! Love the characters and the side quest are pretty cool! A few problems but I find it a good game to play.

Who would have thought something as mundane as checking papers would be so addictive?   When I first saw Papers, Please in a gameplay commentary, I was immediately convinced I had to buy the game. I played the absolute bejesus out of this game as soon as I tried it out and completed 100% of the game in just a little bit over 20 hours. No regrets!  In Papers, Please, you play as an inspector at a border checkpoint in a fictional country called Arstotzka. Each day you are required to check the documents of applicants who wish to enter Arstotzka, which means paying attention to every little detail of information you are given by the applicants (what documents they're supposed to bring, the expiration date of said documents, stamps, etc). At the end of each day, the game shows how much you've made and whether you'd like to spend your earnings on food, heat, and/or other expenses for your family whom you've got to look after throughout the game.   If you're one who's attentive to little details, I highly recommend you to try this game. While the entire game may sound repetitive, you will be introduced to new NPCs and scenarios that will affect the way you play the game. It's a relatively small game so it can be played on pretty much any computer. So after playing this game for a while, I think it's really fun. The story is interesting and the way you have to keep your family alive is really just a good idea. Brilliant idea for a game! I can recommend everyone pick this game up and try it for yourselves to see how good of an inspector you can be. The endless mode in the game is another big adition. If you didn't get enough with the great story you can play on forever in endless mode if you unlock it. It's just the more reason to go buy the game. Ok, I know most of the people reviewing it is saying this, but IT IS AWESOME. It makes you have fun by just CHECKING PASSPORTS. How cool is that????  Highly highly highly recommended
Glory to Arstotzka! It can be sad. It can be funny. It's simple. It's got tough decisions for you to make. 10/10 would play again.

this game is awesome and puts you're morality tothe test. Do you be a sheep of the government or do you rise against them??????? It's you're decision.
The story and the experiance are just worth it playing this game.

I know this game is well over a year old but I felt that it was good enough after me finally completing it to come back and do a review. 'Papers Please' is a deeply immersive 2D simulation. It gives you the relatively boring and repeditive job of being an immegration control officer and makes it fun with it's rich narrative and complementary art style. The mechanics of the game also change based on the narrative and really make the communist and authoritarian world your playing in feel all that more real as the ruels to immegration change based on the will of your nation. The many multiple endings and the achievements for the game also add to the experience and don't just feel like last minute 'tack on's' to make the game look or feel like what many would conisder 'a real game should look like'. No instead each achievement and each ending earned is something unique and either gives you context to the world in which you find yourself or it makes you question things such as the value of freedom in our own world. While I was a tad dissapointed with the meer 4 - 5 hours of game time in the main story mode of the game, none of that 4 - 5 hours was in any was dissapointing. This game will definatly leave you with a yerning for more and while I am a tad upset to have heard that Lucas Pope does not plan to do anything further with this title, I would still STRONGLY RECOMMEND it to be part of any decent steam library.
This darkly comedic game is highly addicting. I never would have guessed checking immigration papers could be this fun, and sometimes even soul crushing. All for glory of Astotzka!
Nothing more to say than GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
This manages to take a beaucracy simulator and do something interesting and memorable with it. That alone makes it worth experiencing in my opinion.  All glory to Arstotzka, comrades.

It's been quite a month. New house, new job, new responsibilities. Work was hard, but an honest day's work brought an honest day's pay. Of course it's never really that simple. Everyday, from my little booth, I've had to make decisions that could affect people's entire lives. It's weighed pretty heavily on my own life, and possibly more so on my family's. It's been incredibly stressful, and I've done some pretty dark things. I've seen innocent people taken away, I've stolen and taken bribes, I've even killed. But what else could I do? I had people counting on me. Tensions built and something terrifying was brewing in my country - in the end I did what I had to to protect my family.  I hope one day we will be able to return to the new Arstotzka, and my son will be able to see what it was all in aid of. As for now, we're safe, and I owe an old friend a few drinks.

I got this game when it came up during the summer sale. I didn't know what to expect but the reviews sounded like it would at least be worth the small amount of money that I spent. I've played two days in a row now and the game is super fun. I recommend it to anyone.

Now judging which people should pass in an immigration station might look easy, but the amount of depth this game has is mind blowing. The more days that pass, the more things you have to look for when judging if someone can pass or not.  Along side that, there's also the moral part of this game, as you have to face some seriously hard deciesions. Some people can't pass your station, but if they go back, they're doomed. And every mistake you make in this game will never fade from your memory.   And in the end of the day, you still have to make sure you family is health. You still have to pay rent.  And all of this stuff goes through your head when you decide if someone can pass or not.  To sum it all up, this game isn't something you could spend endless time on, but if you wanna have an intresting experience and have fun when you're at it, then go for it.

A really playable little game made by Lucas Pope. It gets more and more interesting and complex as you progress through the game having more and more paperwork to deal with and more things to check. There's always new and interesting people and twists to the story and multiple endings. Also I think has really cool 80s style graphics that suits the game well. Totally playable and great fun.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n_yU4rKLLkE   I usually HATE 8-bit games and I'm rarely a fan of RPGs. This game, at face value, seemed like it would be INCREDIBLY boring. I watched someone play it on YouTube, tried the free demo (Google it... it only has the first 8 days and is missing a lot of features added in the final version, but it's a good test of whether or not you'd like it), and I'm now in love with this game.  It has a very engaging story that has high stakes. Despite being 8-bit with text bubbles, I found myself caring about the characters. I did anything I could to keep my family alive.  There are multiple outcomes all dependant on your deliberate (and sometimes less deliberate) choices. I've only experienced about half of them so far.  The game is also very challenging. The first ten days or so are pretty easy (especially after a first play through), however, as you progress all of the information you need to check and be aware of becomes, at times, borderline insane. I love it.  Please feel free to check out my Let's Play video introducing and reviewing this game.  I highly recommend this game. This is a prime example of not judging a book by its cover.

Take a boring desk job that has you reviewing papers, apply dark magic and infuse it with personality that makes it fun (or maybe interesting is a more appropriate word) and you get Papers, Please. And now excuse me, but I must find the money to cure my virtual son.

This game is a perfect example of 'don't judge a book by it's cover'. It appears to be a mundane game of checking papers and doing nothing, but when you play it enough, you'll realize that it has a realistic setting, you'll be developing strategies, and loving some of the reoccuring characters. So the only true way to experience this game is to play it yourself. Buy it.Buy it now. If you don't, I'll cry.

Papers please is one of the best independantly developed games i've played lately. It's suprising just how involving and addictive it can be just playing as a border security guard, some random Jobsworth type, a small cog in a much larger machine. You spend all your time dealing with the most horrifyingly ugly people in a fanstasy version of what i think is meant to be Europe and determine whether their entry documents are valid. Along the way you'll have to manage your expenses for your own family to make sure their warm, fed and healthy(or at the very least one of the three) and there's rarely any money to spare as you just barely scrape through each day, going from paycheck to paycheck. You'll find yourself becoming pretty absorbed in the experience after a while and after seeing so many people who all seem the same, it becomes harder and harder to give a ♥♥♥♥ about other people's stupid little problems while trying to look out for you and yours. Papers Please stands tall above its competitors on the indie market, going for half the usual asking price and lasting twice as long and every ending feels natural and involving. The writing and behaviour of characters can be a little predictable at times, enabling players to rather easily side-step any big consecquences so long as your doing your job well; but all in all I feel richer for playing it and really want it to do as well as it can. Plus, I have to commend it for not immediatley yelling 'BAD ENDING!' just because I let my mother-in-law die so we'd have less mouths to feed.

'Papers, Please' is a game with logic, memorization, and observation puzzles but not in the way most people would expect. The solution to these puzzles involve meticulous readings of passports, government documents, and other miscellaneous pieces of identification. What is interesting is that these puzzles may look boring on 'paper' but in execution, they elevate the game to artistic heights that few indie games can reach. This is all thanks to the game's story which is both fascinating and depressing due to the real world implications.   Playing as an immigration officer for the fictional country of Arstotzka, the fate of countless strangers depends on both your skill and judgment. There will be instances where you must choose whether or not to be charitable to the needy or loyal to your family & country. How the player chooses to make these decisions is done entirely through the game's mechanics and not through a quick time event or cutscene. Though the gameplay is simple, the story is intriguing enough to prevent monotony. Due to the fact that the size of your pay depends on your speed and precision, there is a constant pressure to improve and maintain. With that much burden surrounding the player, is there any time left to think about personal morals?
Very complex.  A game where you basically a straight OG. all hail trump amirite
Amazing simple as that yet it has a lot to offer
Papers, Please is one of the best games I've ever played. It takes you through times of stress, panic, and cliff-hangers. If you need a new game to play, play this one. You won't regret it.

Glory to Arstotzka. At first the job was easy. An easy way to earn money for my family.  But then it became hard. I had to accept bribes simply to keep my family alive. I was immoral, denying innocent men and women who simply wanted to leave their past demons behind. I accepted many forms of payment. I participated in a shadowy organization whose goal was to overthrow my own government.  I could not even protect the poor guard who grew up in my hometown. What else was I to tell his poor lover, who showed up days later? I watched as shouting guards and smoking guns cut down the unlucky ones. I endured the hard labor camps. I was sentenced to death for treason of the the highest order. I escaped to Obristan with my family with the help of a reformed drug smuggler. I am a traitor. I am a coward. I am a refugee. But I am a hero to my son. He still brings joy to my heart as he draws pictures with his crayons, pictures that I used to take to work. Even as my beard grows grey, I hug my wife and son in the snowy fields and think to myself: Arstotzka can have its glory. I only want my family.

I. LOVE. THIS. GAME. You NEED to play this game!!!! You are a airport checkpoint inspector, you inspect peoples documents to ensure they are valid. It is a shame the developer has decided not to make a sequel.

A simulation of what it is like to be a border guard. What seems to be a trivial matching game on the surface is actually a much deeper simulation with surprising complexity.  PROS: -A simple 'gimmick' mechanic that is expanded upon in a surprising way leading to surprising depth of play.  -Amusing secondary decisions and backstory (managing finances, choosing who to let in at cost to yourself, and other political impacts in the fictional world).  CONS: -The font is a little hard to read at times. -The large graphic at the top of the screen showing the line of people is rather unneccessary and takes up critical screen space. It would have been better if this graphic was shown whenever something happened rather than just being there all the time.

Ah, Papers Please, how I have spent countless hours playing this super addictive game! Why it is so addictive I know not, yet somehow, it is. It seems as each day goes on you want to be faster and make more money. If no money is made then you cant buy food, medicine, and heat. And, if you cant buy that then your family will be sick thus resulting in later death, thus ending the game. And each time I made a mistake I found myself trying even harder next time to spot the discrepency. I almost think it is like a spot the difference game but more fast paced. So I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to spend countless hours owning a passport station.
100/10, great game. Can easily become addictive and provides a butt load of gameplay and 20 different endings. GLORY TO ARTSTOTZKA!
I'd say most people will understand Cold War related socio-economics better after a single ~5h playthough of this than they ever will learn in 15+ years of education.  Believe the hype. This is gold.

Papers Please has no right to be fun. It's a game about doing paperwork on behalf of a Communist police state. You get to do exciting things like check people's work visa, check their medical status, confirm their passport isn't a forgery, and then use an official stamp.  And yet, somehow, the game is awesome. The plot is intriguing, the individual character stories are compelling, and it has the best moral choice system ever used in a game. Do you do what is best for you, or your nation? Do you place yourself at risk to help those in need? How do you handle corrupt superiors? How do you react to terrorist threats?  All these questions and more are yours to answer. Other games might have you saving the world from Dr SpaceBad, or making such gripping moral dilemmas as 'will you buy candy floss for the orphans or douse them in petrol and burn them alive?', but Papers Please makes a mockery of all that nonsense by putting you face to face with ordinary people. Your actions decide whether a missing travel visa means Boris Borishnakov gets to visit his daughter on her birthday. Your actions could unite an illegal immigrant with her long-lost love. You can accept a bribe and let a drug smuggler pass, or turn a blind eye to someone whose interests align with yours.  Papers Please is thrilling in ways I never imagined it could be. What else can I say but 'Glory to Arstotska!'

Wow! I'm considering this one of the greatest games I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. This game takes me back to the golden age of gaming, with for instance the game based on Fredric Forsyths 'the Fourth Protocol' and Sid Meyers 'Covert operations' particularly in mind, and at the same time brings a whole lot of new to the table. Who would ever imagine that sitting in a passport booth all day long would feel so rewarding and exciting? Please, all creative and able developers of the world, learn from sole developer Lucas Pope and make more games like this. The world needs YOU!
Who knew paperwork could be so much fun?

'Arstotzka so great, passport not required. Right?'  Wrong! Well, most of the time. It depends. Those are the rules, but sometimes the rules need to be broken. Maybe for moral reasons. Maybe because you just slipped me a bribe to stamp 'APPROVED' on your passport.  'Papers, Please' is an amazing game. It is charming, thought-provoking, and tests your powers of observation to the limit. You will fall in love with some characters, hate others, and maybe even hate yourself a little when it comes to moral dilemmas.  When a woman without proper documentation begs you to let her in so she can see her son, do you deny her? When you think of your own young son at home, do you feel for this woman and let her in? But that could mean a dock in pay, and the risk that you may not be able to feed your own family. What about the guy who is smuggling harmless medicine across the border? And what do you do when a friend of your boss tries to illegally enter, and threatens your job if you don't let her in? Do you put your foot down because rules are rules, or do you back down so your boss doesn't fire you?  Gameplay-wise, you are literally checking paperwork to ensure that people's passports and other documentation are all in order. It starts off simple and increases in complexity. Oh, and the rules change pretty much every day. Work quickly, get people through your line fast so you have enough money to pay your rent, feed your family and keep the heat running through the harsh winter. Oh, but don't go so fast that you get sloppy, because mistakes cost you -- literally. Less wages for you, you inaccurate speedster.  I know, it sounds weird and kind of boring and a bit like work, but it's incredibly engaging. If you're a good worker in the storyline, you can unlock the endless modes. There are three endless game modes: Timed (process as many people in a set amount of time), Perfection (game over at your first error), and Endurance (keep playing until your points balance goes negative). I really like the Perfection game mode. That's saying something when you can take away the story elements and the gameplay still stands as entertaining by itself.  'Papers, Please' is not really a puzzle game. It is not really a simulator. It's not really an RPG. It's something else entirely, and it's awesome.
Amazing, great for anybody at all, great music, even better plot. Papers Please is an all around wonderful game

The complexity and difficulty scales up as the game goes on, and it's always *just* enough to keep you feeling under the pump. Truly a game that understands the process of weaving exposition into the narrative, with enough story to keep you feeling immersed, but not overwhelmed as your priorities become ever foggier. Definitely a game that deserves to be played.  Oh, and Glory To Arstotzka!

It gets more and more interesting and complex as you progress through the game having more and more paperwork to deal with and more things to check. There's always new and interesting people and twists to the story and multiple endings. Also I think has really cool 80s style graphics that suits the game well. Totally playable and great fun.

Papers, Please is simply put a game that'll make you think whilst pushing you further than you should go.  In Papers, Please, players must try to get through as many people as possible making the least mistakes possible. The longer you spend checking someone's passport and details,the more money you end up loosing out on. So you have to be able to notice the smallest abnormalities as quickly as posible.  You also get people with sob stories and beg to be let in, it's up to you whether you wish to do your work right or be a nice guy. You also have a family to look after, which adds to the stress of hurrying and is what can make you slip.  Papers, Please is a wonderful game with great music, great story progression and is able to absorb you into it and get you to question everything you do.  9/10

I resisted this game for awhile because I felt like it wouldn't be fun. Like many others, I compared it to real life work. It doesn't feel like I'm at (real life) work. It takes a little while to build up momentum so don't judge the fun factor too quickly. Once it gets going, it's easy to see what all the buzz is about. Alot of indie games try to be intelligent, Papers Please is one of the few that actually is. The game scores points on: STORY (thoughtful and satirical narratives are seemlessly woven into the game) , GAMEPLAY (smooth innovative gameplay mechanics), VISUALS (though they are admittedly retro, the visuals are stylish and fit the overall tone of the game perfectly), and SOUND (not amazing, but very effective). I personally love all the ethical decision making vs. bureaucratic procedure...and the overwhelming priority to provide for your family (I could go on and on about the significance of the subject matter). In short, you have never played a game like this before. If you can approach it with an open mind, you will have a lot of fun. (plus you get to shoot stuff...if that's your thing.)

This game is very interesting and addicting. You work at a entry checkpoint to the great country Arstotzka! You check documents for inconsistencies such as expired documents, non-match photos, incorrect issusing city, incorrect gender, incorrect seals, and the list goes on. The number of people that you process will determine the amount of money you make and you use that money to pay rent, buy food, pay for heating, and buy medicine when you need it. As the days pass some events take place. Terrorist bombings and shootings, inspections, and a mysterious group contacts you. All these and how you choose to handle the situations will determine the safety of you and your family. There are 20 different endings so the trick is finding them all.

I have seen almost all the endings, including the non-ending methods. It's a lot more intricate then one would think and it can be quite a challenge to figure out all the endings.  I would recommend this to anyone.

Papers, Please is one of 2013's new cult classics and I'd say for good reason. You play the role of an inspector at the border checkpoint of two fictional Soviet sattelite states. The game itself is pretty simple. You look over doucments and look for anything out of place. As you progress there are more things you have to look out for, and eventually you will have the choice to arrest and even defend your checkpoint with a sniper rifle and a tranq gun. Game Informer put it well. There is just something oddly satisfying about locking up a terrorist or finding something wrong with someones passport. The game also gives a good look into what sattelite states were like in the 1980's. Overall I think Papers is a good game, albeit short. While the game is short (the entire game takes place within just thirty one days), there are twenty possible endings so the replay value certainly is there. If you got ten bucks lying around, and you like puzzles and games that present you with moral decisions, then Papers, Please is definitely a good choice to spend that ten bucks on.

Papers, Please puts you in the shoes of a father, husband, nephew, and son in-law who has been selected in a labor lottery to be an immigration inspector. You decide if the people going into Arstoska are allowed in or denied. Your job is to check the papers or each person and make sure that everything is in check. At the end of each day, you get your paycheck and decide how it is spent. This game can get frusturating at times when you need to decide what gets payed for and what does not get to be payed for. You will lose family along the way, but that is just part of the job description. Each day will be a hectic one and terrorists are to be expected.
