'Papers, Please' is a 2D adventure game rendered with old school graphics that allows you to follow the life of a border inspector in the fictional country of Arstotzka. Your objective is to control the papers and documents of every person trying to cross the border and interact with the other characters you will meet through several days of work. While at the beginning the controls you are tasked with are pretty simple, later on you will recive new orders that will require you to examine the papers you are given more and more carefully, in an effort to let pass, detain or reject the right people.  'Papers, Please' features an evolving story: you will recive tasks or orders from several characters and your actions will reflect the final outcome of your adventure. The game itself has a total of twenty different endings and you can choose to replay whatever day of work you wish, should you want a different outcome.  Another important element of the game is your outcome: at the end of each day you will be noticed with all the expanses you can cover, especially the ones involving the well-being of your family or the opportunity to purchase automatic control systems. Neglecting some of them could bring an abrupt end to your career, as well as accepting money and gifts from the wrong people. Making several mistakes during your dury is also sure to cause you some trouble.  All in all, 'Papers, Please' is an excellent adventure game, with a simple but engaging gameplay and a branched story that offers a lot of replay value

Papers, Please is an indie game developed by Lucas Pope, in which you play an immigration inspector whom is working at a border checkpoint in a country named Arstotzka . The goal of the player is to inspect documents using a set of tools and in some occasions to inspect the individual per se, in order to keep criminals out of the country . Everything is a bit unknown, until it will be disclosed , the more you play .  Every work day, you receive a document with informations about particular things you have to notice about, the arrival of important people and/or if you have to take some measures if a specific occasion happens, like having to do body scanning to all civilians who belong to the country of Kolechia . We also have a rule book all the time, so we can know what is allowed in the documents we inspect and if there are any discrepancys, you have to reject the entry to the person and later on, if you want, arrest them . A situation with a spy, terrorists and smugglers with not be uncommon, and you will decide if you will let them pass, because you can bribed and even threaten .  After a day of work, you receive a wage, which depends on how well you did your job, and you will have to decide where your wage will go, some option include 'food', 'medicine' and 'heat', also as you progress in the story you will be able to choose to move to a better house, but it will also have bigger expenses . You also have freedom of will in basically everything since the game changes with your decisions .  Be careful too, this game will play your emotion and will play mind games with you, sometimes you must choose between doing your job or doing the right thing sometimes, there will be families slip apart because of you, but if you decide to let someone passe the border without the correct documents so he or she can be with her/his family, you will face the consequences . Your gaming experience with this game could end in 20 different ways, each occur depending on what decisions did you take in a certain way because you actually have a lot of choices throughout the story, some of them may include, being part of a conspiration group named EZIC against the government of Arstotzka, accepting bribes and even saving money on medicine or food, which will let to the starvation of members of your family .  This game is worth all your attention, since its incredibly addicting, has a great plot and the gameplay its really original, you will not regret it .  15/10

Papers, Please is a wonderfully constructed experience detailing both the banalities and the terrors involved with heavy-handed bureaucracy in a former Soviet Bloc satellite nation.  Pros:   Simple, yet challenging   Delightfully grim setting   Coherent and engaging plot   Thwart terrorist attacks, human trafficking, and smuggling   Pleasant 耽美的 a e s t h e t i c 耽美的   Fail to thwart terrorist attacks, human trafficking, and smuggling   Upward mobility   Let your anemic son succumb to his cold because Class 5 dwellings don't pay for themselves   Ogle people's supple naked bodies against their will   Jorji Costava™   Cons:   Gulag   Can't actually visit the Pink Vice   Days are too short to adequately ogle   Your useless, anemic son   Immigrants   If you're a fan of JRPG's, first-person twitch shooters, or racing sims, this is definitely a game you'll grow to love as much as I have. However, if you're looking for relatively authentic recreation of day-to-day bureaucratic tedium, sprinkled lovingly with a carefully realized, thought provoking plot and a distinct art style to match, you may want to look elsewhere.

Papers, Please asks you a few interesting questions: after being assigned to man the border checkpoint what'll you do? Follow your corrupt and oppressive government laws by the letter or try and sneak a few poor souls in? Will you accept bribes? Will you try and help the rebels or just see how things pan out? How far will you go to make ends meet and ensure the safety of yourself and those you love?   PROS:   -despite sporting a minimalist art style the game graphics are convincingly bleak and oppressive   -simple yet catchy and appropriate music  -the game throws you several moral dilemmas, some decisions will give positive results, others won't change much while a few might be the end of you  -an engaging and branching storyline with a 20 different endings  -save system saves each day separately, you can also go back to a certain day and make different decisions thus generating a new save branch: this lets you experiment freely with the various outcomes  -smooth difficulty curve, new documents and rules are slowly introduced  -you'll get to meet interesting characters  -some examples of dry humor help balance the overall grim story  -having to correctly process enough entrants to ensure you have money to pay for rent, food, heating and surprise expenses really makes for a tense experience   CONS:   -since you're stamping documents and looking for discrepancies the gameplay is, by itself, pretty repetitive in nature  -some levels really throw alot of different documents and permits your way, making screening for discrepancies quite stressful (ofc this is a design choice)  -the simple graphics sometimes make spotting differences in facial features harder than it'd be   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=457423093   Papers, Please ends up being a quite engaging experience: you'd easily be fooled by its straightforward gameplay but the truth is there's way more to it. Its depth comes from how you can shape the story, the moral choices you'll make and their results on you and the characters you'll be meeting. All things considered the best question the game asks is 'What kind of person are you?'. Your decisions and their outcomes will be the answer.

Taking place in a fictional Communist-state (very similar to the USSR of yesteryear), you're forced to use your powers of deduction to verify if people crossing the border into your country are valid residents -- then things get a little fuzzy.   There's something both addicting and terribly sad about this title. The lines begin to blur as you realize that the rules you're following are causing genuine hardship on others. Need I mention that you'll be sent to prison (and your family will be thrown out to the streets) if you fail to do your job right? A stellar 'art meets adventure' experience.

Papers, Please is a terrific puzzler developed by Lucas Pope. You work as an inspector for an Arstotzkan border and have to check all of their papers to be sure they are valid for entry.  The graphics of the game are extremely simplistic, lovable and eye catching. After every day, you get to see how your family is doing and have to buy food and/or heat for them. There are many interactions you can have with your family, such as your son having a birthday and you buying a gift for them. Leaving them without food or heat for too long will eventually kill them, but hey, less mouths to feed and warm.  Sometimes, there are terrorist attacks and you must stop them with your tranquilizer. You get a bonus for this. Also, while we're on the topic of terrorists, an infamous group called EZIC will contact you during the game. You will get bonuses from them, and a few of the endings revolve around EZIC. You do not have to do all of what EZIC tells you to do, but it's more enjoyable (in my opinion) following them.  You can upgrade your booth for easier inspecting. Some of the upgrades include pressing tab to open your stamps, space to check their papers for discrepencies, etc.  While there is fun moments, the discrepency detector can be a bit buggy, which could kill the fun. I think overall, Papers, Please is a terrific game and if you have the money lying around do get it.   9.5/10   (Jorji lives!)

A 2013 release that really stands out for its gameplay, Papers, Please is not for everyone. If you're looking for the perfect break from all the grindy MMOs and shoot-em-ups, this may be just the title you're looking for.  In Papers, Please, you play out the role of a border inspector working in a dystopian country. Each potential immigrant presents you with a set of papers that may or may not fit the rule of the law, and it's up to you to find discrepancies in the paperwork - and to occasionally let humanity win out and break the law to help others. It's a truly memorable game that you shouldn't miss if you have any interest in releases that help define gaming as an art form.

The game is simple in its graphics, but offers some very challenging gameplay. The story is great, keeps you intrigued and immersed. I am particularly fond of the autosave system (the game autosaves at the beginning of each day). Besides, for all those who like soviet accents and dystopian societies, this game is perfect.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Papers, Please is the best desk space management simulator I have ever played.  To be truthful, I never would have bought this if I hadn't tried it for free, first. Trying to figure out why people loved the game so much, all I came away with was that you worked at a thing and you looked at papers and you had to make tough decisions that could affect you, your family, or the people you meet. Which, you know, doesn't sound bad or anything, it just doesn't hype me up to the level of the people who understood it better.  So if you get the chance to play it, do it. That's what I'm telling you before we get into this. If you know somebody who has it, ask them to let you play to, say, Day 5 or something on their computer. It will be on your Steam wishlist that evening, sure enough.  In Papers, Please you are the head of an eastern European-esque household, and you have been selected by the Labor Lottery to do your part as an immigration inspector at a border checkpoint. Got all that? Your job is to sit in your booth on the Arstotzka/Grestin border and check everybody's paperwork for incorrect info and falsified documentation. You will be checking for anything and everything across the board. From incorrect genders to slight differences in weight, to wrong photos, to mismatched birthdates, to missing copies of newly required identification, to forged stamps, to possible aliases. On top of it all, the rules are constantly changing. You may be asked not to admit anybody from a certain country. And then the next day you're asked not to, anymore. It keeps you on your toes, and keeps you paying attention so you don't become complacent and bored.  It seems daunting, at first. It truly does. But as you go, you get the hang of things. Your first playthrough might not be great, but that second one will undoubtedly be much, much better.  Now, this is not all that you'll have to worry about. Your family needs food, heat, and of course a place to live (among other things). These things cost money. You receive $5 for every properly processed traveller, $0 for your first two mistakes of the day, and an increasing penalty for each mistake after that. In a typical day, I can usually manage about 10-12 correct assessments, although not all days are exactly typical, and you may find yourself going home early on occasion for this reason or that.  Then comes the real decisions. You hold the cards, here. You could let somebody pass with incorrect credentials, but you will receive a citation. Rack up enough citations, and you can expect a chewing out down the line. Plus the aforementioned lack of pay/penalty. On the other hand, some people give you good reasons to let them through. A story of love or revenge. Bribery. Or perhaps you just like the person and figure you don't need $5  that  badly at the moment. You will need to weigh the pros and cons, and maybe take a few chances as you just try to do your job and keep your head down... or maybe a little more.  There are 20 endings in all, but that's a little misleading. Several groups of those are just variations on a single ending. Only a handful of endings will grant achievements. And only one will unlock Endless Mode.  It really probably doesn't sound amazing just having it described to you. But trust me when I say that the fun gameplay and unique personality and atmosphere of Papers, Please will thoroughly draw you in if you just play it a little bit for yourself. For that, it's worth the buy.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is a true gem, and more intruiging than any game about a customs agent has a right to be. Though it uses ficticious countries the inspiration seems to come from the divide between east and west germany, with you in the place of a low level beraucrat for a soviet stlye communist country, living in a government issued apartment with your family, trying to put food on the table and keep the heat on, while there are people trying to bribe you, or tell you sob stories so they can get past without the correct paperwork but which would incur a citation for negligence. After a while you begin to become suspicious of everyone, and paranoid about your superiors finding out about bribes you've taken to try and keep your family fed, safe, and warm, and there's more but... I can not even fully explain the feelings I felt as I played this, its just something that must be experianced. I feel like you could write a deep, dark. and moody russian novel out of it and I love it.
Love the high octane thrill of being at border control!

Rushing to get more people procese to make more money causes you to make more mistakes and thus lose money instead of gain. Everytime a citation pops up it's like looking at your test results and slapping yourself for missing such an easy question.   9/10
Great game! Very entertaining!

Papers, Please is one of those rare games that looks horribly boring on paper (hah!), but has an uncanny ability to pull you in if you give it some time. As an inspector working at the border of the made-up communist country of Arstotzka in 1982, your days are spent looking at passports and legal documents for entry (God knows why so many people WANT to go there, but I'll easily forgive that plothole).  The gameplay is basically cross-examining the information on said papers with the current rules for immigration. As the days pass by, the rules change. New papers may be needed, you have to scan people for contraband or validate their gender, and every now and then you get some people who try to appeal to your human side and beg you to look the other way.  It's an idea that should not work. But it does. Papers, Please is a delightful little indiegame that really proves how innovative and entertaining games can be - even when there is only one person on the development-staff - if that one person knows how to play to his strenghts. The low-fi graphics are absolutely essensial for setting the mood of a country behind the iron-curtain in '82 and the artstyle is perfect.  Easily worth the price of admission. All glory to Arstotzka.
This game was extremely difficult and not fun in the sligh- *gunshot in the background* ... ... GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!!!

You might think that a game that's essentially a second job wouldn't be fun. You'd be wrong. If you like spot-the-differences games and dystopian settings then you'll have fun with this.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Nice game to get away from the hyper sensory games of today.

The source of the fascination that this game invokes is quite hard to fathom. Maybe it is the mixture of everything combined that makes this game stand out so much. Most notable are probably the depressing and simple yet fantastic soundtrack and atmosphere mixed with the comic relief that certain individuals in your queue for an entry into the country portray. Glory to Arstotzka.
This is a great game which has a really easy concept to grasp and is just a fun little time-waster. 9.5/10

If you haven't played this game, you're missing out. It's not the pretentious indie game you would come to expect. It was worth every penny and my playing time proves it. It's not some gimpy social commentary, it's a well-rounded game with a thoughtful premise and despite the outdated graphics you get something that isn't commonly seen in games today: style. Everything is sylized and despite the obvious indication that you're playing a game, you WILL be immersed after playing a few 'levels'. Like a good book, you will not be able to put this game down. Most games will get you emotionally invested in a character after several pages of dialogue if not more, but 'Papers, Please' masterfully draws you into each and every character with only several LINES. The weightiness of each situation is real, the consequence is real, and if you thought you knew who you were before this game I assure you that you will see yourself for who you really are after your first playthrough. Your choices actually have consequence, and the choices themselves are carefully constructed to test you. It's not just black and white, as you define who you are as an inspector you in turn shape your nation. It's literally nationstates: the game. I love it. I'm reccomending this game to everyone I know, it's just that good. As a puzzle game goes, this quirky thing is way up there with Meteos and Professor Layton. It can compete with the best of them. Don't play easy mode, play the way the developer intended. If you feel the time limit is too overwhelming for you, don't feel bad and drop this game. It's supposed to be overwhelming at first, but as time goes on you'll start to assess situations more effeciently (Like a real job! Go figure.) and it will simulate the feeling of 'becoming a cog' in a system that is seemingly out of your control.   PICK. THIS. THE F**K. UP.

Taking place in a fictional Communist-state (very similar to the USSR of yesteryear), you're forced to use your powers of deduction to verify if people crossing the border into your country are valid residents -- then things get a little fuzzy.   There's something both addicting and terribly sad about this title. The lines begin to blur as you realize that the rules you're following are causing genuine hardship on others. Need I mention that you'll be sent to prison (and your family will be thrown out to the streets) if you fail to do your job right? A stellar 'art meets adventure' experience.

A 2013 release that really stands out for its gameplay, Papers, Please is not for everyone. If you're looking for the perfect break from all the grindy MMOs and shoot-em-ups, this may be just the title you're looking for.  In Papers, Please, you play out the role of a border inspector working in a dystopian country. Each potential immigrant presents you with a set of papers that may or may not fit the rule of the law, and it's up to you to find discrepancies in the paperwork - and to occasionally let humanity win out and break the law to help others. It's a truly memorable game that you shouldn't miss if you have any interest in releases that help define gaming as an art form.

This game is a great one to play if you're looking to kill a lot of time. It seems to suck you into it's world where you work as a border control personel. Not only does it focus on a keen eye for detail but it also has many personal decisions that must be made in relation to your family's health and wellbeing. An interesting feature is the multiple endings, meaning every decision you made may be crucial to how the game plays out. I dislike that you can't tell what endings you have already achieved and have to restart from the beginning to work on a different path (it's easier than trying to find out where crucial moments happened because nothing on the 'episode' screens tell you exactly what major or minor events occured. I would definitely recommend this game still since it is extremely addicting. A great way to kill some time.

Simple interface, simple graphics, simple enough way to explain how this game works. But it draws you in quick. It's a paperwork simulator, sure, but it's engaging and interesting. You are in charge of a border checkpoint and have to make sure only those meeting certain criteria are allowed in. If that were it, it would be fairly boring. But underneath it all, there's little things that affect how you play. Do you take a kickback to help pay for rent? How about saving up for your son's birthday? Do you let the person with expired documentation in, or send her back to her country where she will be killed?  It draws you in with the little stories. I don't think any other game has presented moral choices in a light such as this. Yes, you can do good and try to help people, but in doing so, you may be fined, and your family might starve. Do you show compassion and watch your family suffer, or do you protect your family, at the expense of being seen as the cold uncaring bureaucrat?
It's fantastic.

I took a leap of faith when I decided to purchase Papers, Please. It's a game I heard great things from but never really appealed to me when I saw some footage of the game. When the game won the Community Voter's Choice during the Steam Holiday Sale I decided to see if my $5 would be a good investment for something new. I'm happy to report that Papers, Please not only impressed me, but turned out to be one of the most addictive and intelligent games I've ever played. Papers, Please is a game that puts you in the role of a border patrol agent. Your task is to take passports from many incoming immigrants and citizens and either allow or deny them access to the dictatorship that is Arstotzka. The people you meet all have varied personalities and some are more patient than others. The game challenges you as you constantly have to review information for any discrepancies that you may find. This may result in invalid gender, issuing city, or an false identity. Even more so is many of your clients will come to you and beg for entry or bribe you so they can access the country and not delay their plans. Your role is to ofcourse, make money. You have to survive but also take care of your family which consists of your son, mother-in-law, uncle, and wife. These people can get sick, hungry or cold. You'll have to balance your money and choose whether to feed your family, turn on the heat, or give your sick family member medicine before they die. There is also a conspiracy theory going on deep within the city. Some people you meet will be secret agents, government officials, or members from a dark old organization. This game will challenge your moral standpoint as you'll have to decide whether you can trust someone or whether the person who's supposed to be someone, really is that person. The game will take up more time than you'd expect but will constantly challenge you and pull you into it's well crafted gameplay. Papers, Please is truly a game that you'll get value out of. It will make you question your morals and make you feel the emotional weight of your every decision.

Never knew working at a border checkpoint could be so interesting. everything was going well until a terrorist got through with proper documents. as a countermeasure, i am now allowed to inspect every person from said country. but because of that. that same country is angry at us for doing so. well.. that would not have happened if they didn't send terrorist to arstotzka.  but hey, i'm just a salaryman. working at a border checkpoint.

So I bought Papers, Please on a whim. I didn't really bother looking at the reviews or researching much into the game. It was on sale, I had some extra money to use, I thought it looked vaguely interesting and Steam recommended it to me. For the longest time, I avoided the game. The more I thought about it, the more I regretted buying it.  But then I opened it.  Then I quit for a while because it was slow and boring.  BUT THEN I CAME BACK.  It was a much different experience than what I am used to in games, sitting and analyzing as quickly as you can, so risk losing everything. I came to feel the path I was taking from cold apathy to the people behind the papers or forgiving sympathy, from the quiet, burning passion of hating the repressive government with all of my being to hating the group who dared destroy the life I was making for myself. The game makes you feel for what is going on around you while also forcing you to analyze at breakneck speed and I love it. After playing for so long, I have all of the issuing cities memorized ((except for a few hiccups)) and I find myself getting faster and faster every playthrough. I find this greatly satisfying, and I love the new procedures because they add a whole new element, even though they can be tedious sometimes, especially when you add the ocassional work pass. The game still manages to lace in well-placed humor, though, even when you're working at a job where you have to deal with miserable people in a desolate place.  Somehow, the way that your choices aren't extrememly consequential is also pleasing, because it shows that, in real life, certain things you do really won't matter in the big picture, but it mattered to someone, and that's what's important.   On to less of my feelings, the game play is smooth, although, at the beginning, it can be frustration to have to use your mouse for everything, but once you get a little further, the booth upgrades work wonders; plus, when you don't have the opportunity to upgrade, it's mostly in the part where you can cast a single glance at the documents and decide their fate. The game isn't very large, either, so it's easy to run on your computer without having to deal with much lag, unless you are severely overloading your computer.   I keep coming back to this game again and again when I want to get away from everything, and I would highly recommend it to anyone.

Please read my full review at my personal blog:  http://www.megabearsfan.net/post/2016/06/27/Papers-Please-game-review.aspx   Exerpts from review: 'Papers, Please is a funny little game in that it is so dedicated to its theme that the game actually does start to feel almost like a real job. You have to click and drag to open up documents, sort through papers, check dates, make sure the document was issued in a valid city, and so on. It's a lot of mundane work, and if you miss any little detail, then you have an omniscient boss who will print out a citation. I quickly came to anticipate the sound of a citation being printed with a Pavlovian anxiety after sending applicants through, even for the ones whose documents I thought I had thoroughly checked. You get two warnings before your omniscient boss starts docking your pay, which keeps constant pressure on you to try to be as close to perfect as possible. Paying for this game is almost like paying for a second job that you, yourself, don't get paid for. And it's kind of a crappy job, at that.'  'But even though the job you're simulating is a crappy job, the game isn't crappy by any stretch of the imagination. The mechanics are fairly simple and straightforward. You just click and drag to shift papers around on a desk surface, and click to turn pages. If you notice something in one document that violates a rule or contradicts with another document, you press a button to highlight the two contradictory items and then click another button to question the immigrant about it. You then line the passport underneath an 'approve' or 'deny' stamp and then drag the documents back to the immigrant to either let them through or send them away. It reminds me of the interrogation segments of L.A. Noire distilled down into an entire game. Except that it manages to avoid the ridiculous tone shifts and somehow manages to create a more natural and engaging process with the possibility of genuine failure.'  'You shift from following simple procedures, to following more complicated procedures, to eventually making judgement calls and moral decisions. It's all very smoothly integrated and creates a growing escalation of tension and stakes as you have to balance your own individual budget with the demands of your government, the bribes of a mysterious insurrection organization, and the requests of the people who you are supposedly trying to serve. As you're playing this very simple, small role of checking passports at an immigration checkpoint, an elaborate story of war and political tension slowly reveals itself and escalates around you.'  My only complaint is that it could maybe use a better tutorial, as the interface does take a little bit of getting used to. Other than that, this is an outstanding game that I highly recommend.

Excellent game, and at around 4 hours for a playthrough, it only slightly overstays its welcome. The document checking aspect slowly gets more complex and then kind of flattens out for the final 10-15% of the game, which makes things maybe a bit anticlimactic. Story wise, it's nice and branches into 2 main arcs, but the gameplay is a bit too tedious for a second playthrough imho.  I highly recommend printing a 'cheat sheet' with the different countries' seals and cities; if I was a border guard I would probably tape up a cheat sheet to the window, so why not do it in game? Alleviates a lot of the frustration with having to fiddle through the in-game book a few hundred extra times.  While it's been overhyped ad nauseum, I do think it's worth a play regardless. It's a unique game which doesn't necessarily make it great, but a 4 hour unique experience is worth it if you can find time between other games or need a break from 'normal' games.

Papers, Please is definitely my favourite game this year. You take on the role as an Immigration officer needing to choose if you put your family between others. There is a choice of either taking a bribe and letting the person in, but risking your job or you can take the bribe and not let them in. There are also different orginisations that will try to get involved with you. These orginisations are very risky as one is Anti-Government. If you are caught being associarted with them you will get sent to prison and your game will be over, but if you don't get caught you will gain a lot of money. This game is a lot more than just a paperwork simulator, but still somehow manages to keep simple. Overall I give this game a 9/10

To do so you need money, and the more people you pass through the border successfully, the more money you make.  8/10. (I lost my dear in-game son to illness btw so nobody's perfect)

I have just discovered that game and I'm not quite sure what makes it great. Is it the fact that you deny entrance to your country to poor people who have nowhere else to go? Is it the fact you strive to earn enough money to feed your family and always seem to fail? Perhaps. Or not. If I had been told that checking passports, I.D cards and work permits was so much fun, I would have studied to become a border guard.  The game depicts in an extreme but humorous way, a communist country which has recently re-opened its borders. You have just won the work lottery. Congratulations, you are one of the only ones to have an actual job now. You still won't be able to pay the rent or feed your family, but at least, you have work!  The game in itself is very smart, the difficulty increases slowly but surely. You must verify the expiry dates, check all documents, the gender, weight, height, passport number, diplomatic seals, issuing cities, etc. Once in a while, events occur and the policies change. You dismantle bombs, get extra earnings by shooting at people or detaining them. Sometimes, you even get 'special' visits. With about 20 different endings, this game is as deep as it can be while remaining 100% entertaining.

Warning: This game is a masterpiece that may cause severe cases of addiction. It is common to feel the need to inspect a couple more passports after finishing the game. In Arstotzka, everyone loves their job. If you don't want to give it a try because you think the graphics suck, you have no place in the true paradise of Arstotzka. 10/10 golden potato.

Papers, Please is a wonderfully constructed experience detailing both the banalities and the terrors involved with heavy-handed bureaucracy in a former Soviet Bloc satellite nation.  Pros:   Simple, yet challenging   Delightfully grim setting   Coherent and engaging plot   Thwart terrorist attacks, human trafficking, and smuggling   Pleasant 耽美的 a e s t h e t i c 耽美的   Fail to thwart terrorist attacks, human trafficking, and smuggling   Upward mobility   Let your anemic son succumb to his cold because Class 5 dwellings don't pay for themselves   Ogle people's supple naked bodies against their will   Jorji Costava™   Cons:   Gulag   Can't actually visit the Pink Vice   Days are too short to adequately ogle   Your useless, anemic son   Immigrants   If you're a fan of JRPG's, first-person twitch shooters, or racing sims, this is definitely a game you'll grow to love as much as I have. However, if you're looking for relatively authentic recreation of day-to-day bureaucratic tedium, sprinkled lovingly with a carefully realized, thought provoking plot and a distinct art style to match, you may want to look elsewhere.

Many games tout having choices that effect the story line and even you the player in a profound way. Rarely do they have it so well integrated into the actual gameplay itself; as many have it thrown in a dialogue tree (usually after killing a small country's worth of populace).   Papers, Please   has raised the bar on how to combine story and gameplay in a simple to learn manner, while cranking up the tasks and making even the toughest border patrol agent slip-up here and there. First it is just ID card and country, then those plus work pass. After a big event, now you have to have armed guards. It's hard to talk about the mechanics without giving away the story, that is how intertwined they are. There are many endings as well but I really feel this game shows what games really do well: creating the story through gameplay. If you would have told me in my teenage years that I would fall in love with a game about playing a checkpoint agent at the border of a somewhat Eastern European country where my family depended on my job performance but so did the possible outcome of my country, I wouldn't believe you. There has never been (and probably won't be again) a game where I have felt some much power and joy pressing a stamp.

Papers, Please is a very unique and entertaining game. Why is it unique? Because you play a role that is not often played in a game. A border guard in a corrupt communist country constantly dealing with forged documents and terrorist attacks. Additionally, the gameplay in general is not very common. Thoroughly inspecting papers and stamping them? Try and find another game that offers you that. Now, I know the idea of a game which has gameplay centering around basically doing paperwork doesn't sound very entertaining... but trust me on this one, it is.  Let me talk about the pros and cons of this game.  PROS: * Brilliantly written story * Interesting universe that you're always wanting to learn more about * Characters that you know little about and yet get invested in so quickly * Unique gameplay * Pixely but good graphics  CONS: * Slightly dull and boring gameplay * Fairly difficult gameplay * Jorji Costava  This game is definitely not for everyone. However, if you like things such as alternate history (especially communist timelines), games where you remain in one spot, and a game where the universe is likely the best part, Papers, Please is no-doubt for you.  Even if you feel like it's not aimed at you, give it a try. It's worth your money. I would highly recommend Papers, Please to anyone.  As for those of you who are too damn stubborn to try the game...  - The Ministry of Justice has become aware of your stubbornness and refusal to play Papers, Please. - You are under arrest for your horrible crimes. An investigation will follow your imprisonment. - Your family's safety is unknown. - Your Steam account will remain running under a replacement. - Glory to Arstotzka.  I'd give Papers, Please a 9/10. It certainly deserves that high of a score.
*Game is based in communist socety *Uses U.S dollar  10/10 would logic again

Ever want to reject someone based on bias? Ever want to pass a terrorist into the country? Ever want to pull a gun on said terrorist? Ever want to join a rebel faction bent on taking down your home country's government? Ever want to manage your family's well being while trying to upgrade to a better apartment complex? Ever want to possibly kill them off? Papers, Please is the game for you.  You begin as a lowly worker in the greatest country ever, Arstotzka (Glory to Arstotzka). You get to decide whether people pass or if they get rejected and are refused asylum from their countries war. As you progress through the days you will get the chance to read important documents, or don't and let Lady Luck decide if you get fired or thrown in jail for not being able to pay the fines. Or if you do pay your fines your family may suffer.. Choose wisely! Oh, also watch out for Cobrastan... nasty place that.

Papers Please isn't like any other game. Papers Please has a amazing story with unique gameplay centred around a job at border control. But as the game continues so does the story and you have many different interactions. Its great because a very small act can send you to the top or can send you to jail. The best thing is the moral choices such as: do you take a bribe and risk being caught? Do you buy medicine for your child or heat the house?  The game seems very basic and boring at the start but as you play on it becomes much more interesting.  Final Verdict: 9/10

I resisted this game for awhile because I felt like it wouldn't be fun. Like many others, I compared it to real life work. It doesn't feel like I'm at (real life) work. It takes a little while to build up momentum so don't judge the fun factor too quickly. Once it gets going, it's easy to see what all the buzz is about. Alot of indie games try to be intelligent, Papers Please is one of the few that actually is. The game scores points on: STORY (thoughtful and satirical narratives are seemlessly woven into the game) , GAMEPLAY (smooth innovative gameplay mechanics), VISUALS (though they are admittedly retro, the visuals are stylish and fit the overall tone of the game perfectly), and SOUND (not amazing, but very effective). I personally love all the ethical decision making vs. bureaucratic procedure...and the overwhelming priority to provide for your family (I could go on and on about the significance of the subject matter). In short, you have never played a game like this before. If you can approach it with an open mind, you will have a lot of fun. (plus you get to shoot stuff...if that's your thing.)

A cool game! Also a very weird game, most definitely not for everyone. You are a man providing for your wife, kid, mother-in-law, and uncle, and possibly more family as you go on. You work on the border of your communist country, deciding who does and does not get to enter, and are faced with some difficult decisions at times. The game gets more and more challenging, and if you mess up too much, or go in debt, you could end up in prison.

Before I played this game, if someone had told me that I would find comparing and evaluating paperwork to be at all enjoyable I would have called them a liar and a couple other names to boot. After having played Papers, Please though, I have to admit that - at least in this game - paperwork can be fun.  It doesn't seem like such a difficult concept at first: receive documentation from person, examine documentation (and sometimes the person) for any discrepancies, approve and deny as appropriate. Like many things though, what is explained simply is not so easy to do. While the game starts off with one document you need to examine, before long you're looking at as many as 5 pieces of paperwork for any one person, each which must be examined for consistency within itself AND compared to all other documentation. It could be overwhelming, but the difficulty curve of Papers, Please is ramped up perfectly, neither too fast nor too slow. By the time you're faced with this wall of documentation you're prepared... mostly.  I know, I know, what I've described sounds like a harrowing experience. Yes, it can be tense at times, but for some reason it's also rather fun. The precise reason why escapes me in part, but a good deal of the enjoyment comes simply from the challenge of trying to figure out when someone is attempting to slip something past you, potentially for nefarious reasons even. Every forged document, stolen identity, or smuggled bit of explosives you find is a satisfying emotional payoff, a virtual pat on the back for having stopped someone up to no good.  Truthfully though, what makes Papers, Please an enjoyable experience isn't so much the gameplay as the story. Not that the gameplay isn't solid, but much of the appeal would be meaningless without the personal drama that comes across on any given day of it. Love, death, loss, joy, sadness, humor, all come across in the small conversations and interactions the player character has with the various people he encounters. Mindlessly approving or denying paperwork all day is somewhat trivial, but what if your decision to approve or deny a passport could make the difference between a family being reunited and one being torn apart? Between true love and tragic loss? What if it could shape the very future of the country you serve? All of these things come up as part of the plot of Papers, Please, and there's no right or wrong answer to each. Your actions have consequences, and for better or worse you can see them out.  Bluntly put, Papers, Please is a perfect example of how decent plot and unique gameplay can combine to form something greater than the sum of each. Examined separately, the plot of Papers, Please is a bit derivative, while the gameplay is mostly unique rather than truly gripping. Combined as expertly as they are, however, leads to a final result that is both highly enjoyable and very memorable.

There aren't many games that when I finish I immediately start over again, but PapersPlease has done it. I smiled as I reunited lovers. I cried when I had to arrest Jorji and he simply said, 'Ah, is ok.' My heartbeat trebled when I had to shoot down terrorists. I felt joy as I slowly worked on securing my families future. I felt gutted when I was told I was going to be executed tonight. ♥♥♥♥-totzka indeed.  The pacing of this game is unreal. It just never lets up. Just when you think you can catch a breather, it grabs you by the throat with something new. I genuinely want to pack in my job and stamp visas all day in hope that it's exactly the same. Although that damned printer would probably cause me to flip.  Absolutely cannot recommend it enough. Just be warned it's not a game, it's a second life.

Papers Please has no right to be fun. It's a game about doing paperwork on behalf of a Communist police state. You get to do exciting things like check people's work visa, check their medical status, confirm their passport isn't a forgery, and then use an official stamp.  And yet, somehow, the game is awesome. The plot is intriguing, the individual character stories are compelling, and it has the best moral choice system ever used in a game. Do you do what is best for you, or your nation? Do you place yourself at risk to help those in need? How do you handle corrupt superiors? How do you react to terrorist threats?  All these questions and more are yours to answer. Other games might have you saving the world from Dr SpaceBad, or making such gripping moral dilemmas as 'will you buy candy floss for the orphans or douse them in petrol and burn them alive?', but Papers Please makes a mockery of all that nonsense by putting you face to face with ordinary people. Your actions decide whether a missing travel visa means Boris Borishnakov gets to visit his daughter on her birthday. Your actions could unite an illegal immigrant with her long-lost love. You can accept a bribe and let a drug smuggler pass, or turn a blind eye to someone whose interests align with yours.  Papers Please is thrilling in ways I never imagined it could be. What else can I say but 'Glory to Arstotska!'
High octane passport checking action in a wonderful collectivist utopia.

You could honestly believe the game was conceived behind the Iron Curtain. Utterly fantastic. 9.9999999/10

Will you obey or subvert the powers that be in your motherland?  Good luck!  NEXT!

This game has NO right to be fun as it is. The game boils down to you scanning documents for inaccuracies, and approving or denying entry to various citizens of the futuristic world trying to enter your home country; Arkotsk. You were drafted into working there, and you and your family were forced to move to a new rent-controlled home. You are expected to pay for their food, heat, medicine, and other needs as well as a hefty rent on your measly salary as border/customs agent.   What's really cool about this game though, is that while at first you struggle with the simple basics of the 'job', it soon becomes second nature. Once you become a jaded ♥♥♥♥ at the customs office you start to notice weird things happening around you; corrupt guards, terrorist attacks, ethical dilemnas relating to your post, bombs, murders, and of course forged documents.  It takes only a very short time to get into, and you'll likely want to play it more than one time since you'll fail the first time and recieve the 'worst; of the 20 DIFFERENT ENDINGS. One playthrough takes about 3 hours but checkpoints are created at every day, allowing you to explore all the alternate endings easily.  Don't trust your common sense, buy this game that is literally about fact-checking documents. You will love it,

It’s October 1982 and your name is pulled from the labor lottery which makes you the newest employee of the Ministry of Admissions in Arstotzka . You are immediately assigned to a newly acquired Grestin Border Checkpoint which is not all that secure a lot of people are trying to get in and it’s your job to make sure that the right people are getting in and the wrong people are staying behind.  Although the gameplay is simplistic you will find that the difficulty ramps up very quickly as you are given more documents to sort through. This difficulties compound by the fact you are trying to earn as much money as possible by processing as many people as you can in order to feed and support your family. While this creates a lot of tension in the game it has unfortunate side effect that also makes the interface more cluttered which can have a disadvantageous effect when you are trying to juggle all the different papers, it can become very confusing and very frustrating.  This is really a minor complaint because overall the game is absolutely excellent, the story is immersive and there is a lot of interesting characters throughout but what makes this game so special is its atmosphere, from the RT soundtrack to the excellent dialogue, you legitimately feel that you are a part of a war-torn communist steep.  In conclusion, Papers,pleas is an incredibly unique game that I think everybody should experience.

They say 'Papers, Please' is a game about 'morality.' But I feel like the game can be summed up in one question. How quickly can you decide wether this passport needs a green stamp or a red stamp? This isn't necessarily a bad thing. It's fun as heck to hecticly sort through all of the different slips and forms.  The game's style is very gritty grey and pixilated. An unapealing style for an unapealing world. Nice touch. The combination of the dialogue and info on the passports really makes it feel like every immigrant has its own story.  The game definitely has it's emotinal moments. It had the times I went 'D'awww', and it had the times I went 'YOU FREAKING ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!'  Bottomline, I'd recommend it. You get into the rhythm of things once you start memorising what you need to check on the forms, and there is a ton of replay value from all of the different endings you can get. Every character has a story, and you're the judge deciding wether they shall pass or not. Like Gandalf.  Glory to Arstotzka.

i've found myself regretting in-game decisions saying 'oh ♥♥♥♥...' more than a handful of times. this isn't 'cards against humanity' playing a cheap shock value card, but an emersive, thoughtful, and satyrical exploration of nationalism, xenophobia, human rights and human nature itself. it's a very smart and polished production that succeeds on both technical and expressive ends. i could easily see 'Papers, Please' being used in classrooms or as part of an academic curriculum, but it stands more than well enough on its own as an entertainment title with enough replay value to justify the asking price.   8/10

10/10  Papers, Please is a game that can never be matched, purely by the perfect way this game was executed. You are an immigration inspector at the border town of Grestin. Your goal is simple; do your job correctly, get the money, and keep you and your family alive. But no, it is not this simple. You are the person that changes peoples lives entirely. To allow an individual into the country is completely your choice; a power that should not be given to a single person.   For a game with such a simple as well as unique concept, Papers, Please showed just how in-depth something so simple can go. From any person's perspective, it's a simple process: Accept. Deny. Accept. Deny. However, Something that simple is something that you cannot afford in Papers, Please. Passports, Entry Permits, Identity Supplements; all documents that each person must present to you; the inspector. Your duty is to correctly accept and deny immigrants into the country, (who may very well be terrorists, smugglers, and murderers,) in the country of Arstotzka.  What makes Papers, Please the brilliant game that it is lies in every fiber of its design. From the art style to the dialogue., this game will present new ideals into your mind, making you wonder what the true right or wrong thing to is. Papers, Please will make you want to keep your job more than any real world job ever will, that is a given fact. Getting penalized by the Ministry of Admission for incorrectly allowing people into Arstotzka will fill every inch of your body with paranoia. Even as you skim down someone's passport you will feel a small pinch in the back of your head, worrying that you checked something wrong. Being thorough means everything in this game, in the booth or at your Class 8 Apartment.  Papers, Please is a game that you have never seen or played before. With perfect atmosphere, story, and dialogue, this game has quickly made its way to my favorite games list. For the small price of only 10 credits, this game is less expensive than your son's birthday present! Buy it already!  Glory to Arstotzka. Back to work.

This is an amazing game and demonstrates how independent developers excel in creativity. The world they have created is immersive and the characters throughout have compelling reasons (both good and bad) why they should be let through the checkpoints. Small stories carry throughout the game, and may end differently depending on how you decide their fate. The decisions you make may impact how far you make it in the game, as deviating from your job description can land you in jail (and end this game short). These endings are great and allows you to reflect on your decisions. You can restart on certain days in the story to before you made the mistakes and see how the world may unfold differently.

In 'Papers, Please' you are a customs agent for a Soviet-esque nation. Charged with safeguarding the borders from illegal aliens, smugglers and ne'er-do-goods, yet paid for every legal individual allowed past your checkpoint, you must find a compromise between pro-bono and quid-pro-quo.  Do the right thing and possibly force your family members to go hungry? Or take a potentially-incriminating bribe and keep the heat on and bellies full for another day?  This game is a masterpiece. One of my top 5 games of 2013, and likely to be amongst the most well-designed, intricately planned games of all time. Get it.

Papers, Please is fantastic. It combines a charming artstyle, engrossing narrative and a truly unique set of core mechanics for a one-off experience.  You assume the role of a border inspector, and the gameplay revolves around allowing people to pass into a state, denying them, or detaining them. You don't want to know any more than that: the first run through is best done blind, experiencing all the plot twists/quirks as you choose and shape your own adventure. There are twenty endings. The game offers a nice difficulty curve, adding extra documents or rules with each 'day' to keep you on your toes. It is never unfair.  The atmosphere, too, is great. The music recalls every Soviet stereotype you can think of, while the art style channels the bleak misery of 20th Century Post-Soviet Europe.  As a broader comment, the game also makes you appreciate/understand to a greater extent the job done by border guards. As a frequent traveller, border guards often seem obtuse or rude: in reality, as this game goes some way to demonstrate, the concentration and vigilance needed is remarkable.  For $10/£7, you cannot go wrong with Papers, Please. If it is in a sale, you have no excuse. Highly recommended.

Papers, Please is one of those rare games that looks horribly boring on paper (hah!), but has an uncanny ability to pull you in if you give it some time. As an inspector working at the border of the made-up communist country of Arstotzka in 1982, your days are spent looking at passports and legal documents for entry (God knows why so many people WANT to go there, but I'll easily forgive that plothole).  The gameplay is basically cross-examining the information on said papers with the current rules for immigration. As the days pass by, the rules change. New papers may be needed, you have to scan people for contraband or validate their gender, and every now and then you get some people who try to appeal to your human side and beg you to look the other way.  It's an idea that should not work. But it does. Papers, Please is a delightful little indiegame that really proves how innovative and entertaining games can be - even when there is only one person on the development-staff - if that one person knows how to play to his strenghts. The low-fi graphics are absolutely essensial for setting the mood of a country behind the iron-curtain in '82 and the artstyle is perfect.  Easily worth the price of admission. All glory to Arstotzka.

If you haven't played this game, you're missing out. It's not the pretentious indie game you would come to expect. It was worth every penny and my playing time proves it. It's not some gimpy social commentary, it's a well-rounded game with a thoughtful premise and despite the outdated graphics you get something that isn't commonly seen in games today: style. Everything is sylized and despite the obvious indication that you're playing a game, you WILL be immersed after playing a few 'levels'. Like a good book, you will not be able to put this game down. Most games will get you emotionally invested in a character after several pages of dialogue if not more, but 'Papers, Please' masterfully draws you into each and every character with only several LINES. The weightiness of each situation is real, the consequence is real, and if you thought you knew who you were before this game I assure you that you will see yourself for who you really are after your first playthrough. Your choices actually have consequence, and the choices themselves are carefully constructed to test you. It's not just black and white, as you define who you are as an inspector you in turn shape your nation. It's literally nationstates: the game. I love it. I'm reccomending this game to everyone I know, it's just that good. As a puzzle game goes, this quirky thing is way up there with Meteos and Professor Layton. It can compete with the best of them. Don't play easy mode, play the way the developer intended. If you feel the time limit is too overwhelming for you, don't feel bad and drop this game. It's supposed to be overwhelming at first, but as time goes on you'll start to assess situations more effeciently (Like a real job! Go figure.) and it will simulate the feeling of 'becoming a cog' in a system that is seemingly out of your control.   PICK. THIS. THE F**K. UP.

The further I get into this, the more absorbed I get in the game. Brilliant design, oft-times amusing and worth every penny paid in my opinion. Be careful, you might loose more time that you expected to Papers Please.

Informally dubbed 'Slav Simulator 1984', this is by far one of my more favourite titles.  Like Orwellian themes? This is essentially a must buy. The dark communist eastern vibe that is painted within this game is nothing short of amazing.   What's so unique and great about this game is that it shapes it's gameplay in a unique fashion pertaining to the scenario of the game, as opposed to being a fixed genre that the game's narrative and world has to at least somewhat acommodate. Have you ever seen a border control 'simulator' before of a similar ilk? Me neither.  You are the father figure of a poor village family that lives in Artztotzka, a totalitarian country held together with pride and an iron fist. You work as a border controller officer, checking passports of all border entrants. The story itself is very neatly tied together, with a plethora of decisions you can make in the scenarios of the game and consequence that will unfold because of your actions. Everything is moody and gloomy, as you would expect from such a world. It can hold moments of light-heartedness, and it is definately something that should be experienced and appreciated firsthand.   The gameplay itself is fast paced and very thorough. You need to check every meticulous detail too see if documents are in check and valid, corresponding to the entrant correctly. The difficulty curve in the late game gets even harder as more documents that you need to check pile up as the game progresses.  Should you buy this? If you hold an appreciation for a dark, Orwellian world, absolutely. If you enjoy unique, intuitive gameplay that will keep you on your toes and isn't too pretentious, take it into heavy consideration. It can hold a little less ground when it comes to complete replayability (frankly I can't see myself playing this game for TOO long in say, endless modes, as it can get somewhat repetitive, albeit challenging), but it is still very much an amazing game for it's price and you should seriously buy it if you haven't.

We all find comfort in the drudge of the mundane and familiar. In the repetition of the same and the routine, and apathy is all too easy to experience. Try and look past it though and see what's there. Why do people do the things they do when they know it is 'wrong' or 'inhumane'? Sit down and experience why people do these things and why they think it needs to be done. Decide for what you stand: for the familiar, or for the new. Glory to Arstotzka!

One of the smartest games I have played in a long time!  Such a simple game mechanic, that gets complex as time goes by (the more bits of paper work you have to check) yet still has an engaging enough storyline and characters that make you try to do a good job or question your judgement. It's also great to slap a 'denied' stamp on some guy who is giving you too much lip ;) game play lets you be hard to the letter or a bit more relaxed (maybe a few bucks on the side) with multiple endings it has great re-play value.  Summary: Great indie game, with easy to pick up mechanics and a great atmosphere that makes you want to play again!

Your first impression of the game will be monotonous and fastidious but very soon you will develop a rhythm of being a proficient immigration inspector.  If you cannot there is an Easy Mode option in settings.  This game requires your undivided attention and quick reflexes; you will have to take notice small details. When you play this game, you are going to enter a mesmerising state of mind and the music is very appeasing; you won't notice how much time has passed.   This game is not just about being a immigration inspector, its about the struggle of making moral choices. Would you condemn this lady to die, with expired passport, by refusing her entry or deprive your sick son of medicine by losing your paycheque? Would you let a wanted murderer pass because revenge driven father wants to kill him or would you get him arrested, where he might not be sentenced justly for his crimes? Would you help the terrorist organisation EZIC over-throw the corrupt government or stay loyal to the dystopian Arstotzka? These are but a few of the question you have to ask yourself. The story is not that long but the best part is that you can start a semi-new game from any day and make different choices. You also have more option as you make progress, such as ability to check fingerprints and full body scan.  This game is not everyone; being an immigration inspector is the most exciting job of all, some may find that boring. If you do not mind doing same thing over and over, then you should definitely give it a try. Even with a linear story, it will get you emotionally engaged with the various choices it presents you.   Glory to Arstotzka

ANd the controls are clunky. My arms are sore after a few hours of play from clicking back and forth, back and forth. As you progress the controls get easier if you buy upgrades, but why not just have those from the start? It's annoying, not engaging.

Papers, Please is a terrific puzzler developed by Lucas Pope. You work as an inspector for an Arstotzkan border and have to check all of their papers to be sure they are valid for entry.  The graphics of the game are extremely simplistic, lovable and eye catching. After every day, you get to see how your family is doing and have to buy food and/or heat for them. There are many interactions you can have with your family, such as your son having a birthday and you buying a gift for them. Leaving them without food or heat for too long will eventually kill them, but hey, less mouths to feed and warm.  Sometimes, there are terrorist attacks and you must stop them with your tranquilizer. You get a bonus for this. Also, while we're on the topic of terrorists, an infamous group called EZIC will contact you during the game. You will get bonuses from them, and a few of the endings revolve around EZIC. You do not have to do all of what EZIC tells you to do, but it's more enjoyable (in my opinion) following them.  You can upgrade your booth for easier inspecting. Some of the upgrades include pressing tab to open your stamps, space to check their papers for discrepencies, etc.  While there is fun moments, the discrepency detector can be a bit buggy, which could kill the fun. I think overall, Papers, Please is a terrific game and if you have the money lying around do get it.   9.5/10   (Jorji lives!)

I saw a couple of people give this game of the year for 2013, so I saw it on sale and thought I'd give it a go, and for a game with files so small, it offers a lot. Story driven, simple gameplay which stacks up becomiing harder, it offers a challenge and gets you thinking. Highly recommend.

Your job is to run a checkpoint on the border of two countries, approving or denying the entry of people to the country. While this may seem pretty cut and dried, a lot of times you will find decisions that play on your moral compass. The consequences of your decisions are usually viewed in the paper the next day. There are 20 different endings in all based on the decisions you make in-game, and along the way you will meet very memorable characters. The game has an amazing feel to it and certainly was worth every hour I put into it, and I plan on playing it much more to unlock all the endings. If you find that you really enjoy the technical aspect of checking papers and stamping passports like me, when you're all done with the story you can play endless mode too.

I've enjoyed several aspects of this game. Although it is minimalistic by design, it is enough to submerse you in a progressively chaotic envirnoment. It may not make much of a difference to some people, but I'd recommend playing this game with headphones on. Reasons: the soundtrack for this game, although repetitive, is very catchy, adding to the authoritative environment that is Arstotzka. Second, *spoilers* when the opportunities come to use the tranquilizer/sniper gun, the sudden surprise of the alarm sound made me jump and realize how attentive I was looking for descrepancies. As you play through the game multiple times, for the tokens, achievements, endings, or endless mode, you will be able to adapt faster and more efficient ways to correctly grant or deny access to incoming people; it wasn't easy for me my first playthrough, but it began to be easier after a few playthroughts to process about 15 people on most days (except on the days where certain events happen).  My only problem, slight at that, is the last upgrade. I understand it may make it easier for those that use their trackpad on their laptops, or those that find it easier that using the space bar. It's a hit or miss, I didn't find it helpful; if anything, it made finding descrepancies more problematic.   Excellent game, I'd highly recommend this game.   GLORY TO NEW ARSTOTZKA.

Surprisingly enjoyable for a game about bureaucratic red tape. It's essentially a memory game where you try to spot possible discrepancies in entrants' documentation before letting them through. You can always double check all of the rules and notifications you've received, but doing so will slow you down and you will earn less money for processing fewer entrants. The game has a fair about of cynical humor in it, the challenges are changed up often enough that it keeps you on your toes, and the few characters are as memorable and enjoyable as any I've seen in other games.
