This is a YES and NO.  If you like a small game with some interesting dictatorship theme this is it. Other than that I found it pretty boring after a while, and the worst thing (that probably ruined it) is that you have to race the clock to process the people because you're paid per-person, rather than shift work.   Which doesn't make sense. And it's really annoying having to race the clock and stamp people's documents trying to avoid mistakes and be punished. It just gets... annoying.

This is an award-winning game hailed for being innovative beautiful commentary.  Meanwhile, I found it alternately boring and frustrating, but never managed to find the fun. It is what I would consider an 'arthouse' game; I realize that the boredom and frustration are both features and not bugs, that the stultifying repetition of having nonsense shoved in front of you which causes you to consult a guide which there isn't enough room to open on your tiny desk to see if the information matches, is all a wonderful recreation of bureaucracy. I get it, and for people who appreciate that sort of commentary and a look inside that world, this game does convey that feeling. What it does not provide is entertainment value. So, I have embraced my inner philistine, and give this bold innovative game a thumbs down.

This review is only a qualified negative...let me just say that I am a huge survival game fan and that I spend all of my time playing games where you *expect* to die multiple times from starvation, cold, etc. That said, Papers, Please makes the Long Dark look like the LIttle Mermaid. It is so freaking stressful and bleak that I don't really even want to play it anymore, even though the game itself is well-created, interesting, and has good mechanics. In the first three in-game days, I became an agent of an oppressive regime, my son got sick, my family got cold and hungry because I wasn't getting paid well, I accidentally let a terrorist get by me and blow up several people, and I had to send someone to their death because of bureaucratic rules -- it was ether that or not be able to afford to buy medicine for my sick son. It didn't matter, though, because by day 3 I had racked up too many citations and was sent to prison, game over. It's one thing to play a game where you are responsible for your own impending death, quite another to play a game where you are forced to be responsible for others' deaths. There is a reason I avoid overly violent games and this game is violent emotionally, which is just as bad. But again, the game is well-made for what it is.

On the surface, both the idea and execution are great... but the game is such a chore. I honestly didn't expect gameplay to be  that  similar to real bureaucratic work. You really are pushing papers all day, then struggle to feed your family for the minimal wage, the go back to pushing more papers in the morning. I wasn't expecting that this would be the aspect that is portrayed in such a daunting manner. Despite all the truly clever things this game has, my god is it a god damn chore to play, Jesus H. Christ.

Edit: I've just discovered that there is an 'easy mode' you can activate in the options menu. I will update this review after I play some more. This might change my recommendation.   I've got to say. I like games with a unique, even story telling type, style. That being said, I don't like this game. Not because it is a bad quality game. But, I didn't find it fun. This game puts you in charge of a border control station. All that stands between a terrorist attack and safety, is you. As you progress, the game get's harder, giving you more and more information to check in order to carry out your duty. Did i mention this is a husband simulator as well? No? Because you have to get through as many people as possible in the time limit in order to get payed enough to feed, heat, and care for your family. Oh, and also pay rent. This is where my enjoyment ends. I like the idea of picking what necessities are, well, important right now for your family. Skipping out on food to pay for medicine, or heat. But, I am terrible at this game. I can't slow down and enjoy the atmosphere, or the writing, because i'm too busy trying to speed through this 'Job.' both aspects are unique, both are clever, but put them together and it kills both parts of the game. I might give this game another shot. I've learned and grew my skill, but this game plays like a proof reader job. And focusing on just gameplay, it's a little boring. The writing would definitely pick things up, but I can't enjoy the writing because of the 'come on, move it' nature of the gameplay. Maybe adding an easier mode would change this. I know some people will enjoy this game. Many already have. But, it's not for me.

I really truly don't understand all the excitement over this game. It must be some sort hip indie game thing.  This game is frustrating, obnoxious, confusing and not at all interesting. You are expected to (literally about 5 minutes in) memorize several gibberish names of cities for each of a bunch of countries. Then it tests that by changing only one letter in the name (a 'c' to a 'k' for example), so you need to memorize the spelling as well. You COULD check the map in the rule book but this takes forever and your family dies due to you not making enough money per day. At the same time, you are to check a myriad of other things for validity, many of which are never made clear to the player. It never told me I had to check ID number for validity and I still don't know what makes an ID number valid or not. I had to google how to tell a man that he needed a passport as this wasn't adequately explained either and the game refused to progress until I dealt with it.  On top of this, you need to make sure the passport photo matches, which is a complete crapshoot considering the character portraits lack any detail. Usually at least once a (in-game) day the game tells me I was wrong just because I don't know what constitutes a good enough match.  And this is all just a few levels in. Supposedly it gets considerably more tedious and confusing. Becuase that's somehow an enjoyable game mechanic? You actually have to UNLOCK hotkeys from the storyline. What.  On the plus side the music is pretty great.   I'd never recommend it, but apparently I'm the wrong one and everybody simply loves processing paperwork according to confusing, obnoxious, unexplained beaurocratic rules. I simply did not enjoy it.  It's probably some sort of 'art' thing.
Seems interesting first 5 minutes, but quickly becomes tiresome and repetetitve. Nowhere near worth the $3 I paid for it.

Let me share a brief anecdote:  Do you remember at uni etc, after having finished an extended question for maths, having got the answer wrong, and then having to sift through several pages of working to find where the error was?  Papers, Please is a very interesting game, and I can certainly see why it is so popular and well rated, but for me it felt like sifting through pages to find one small error. Once you get to the stage where forgeries are possible, there are all kinds of stuff you have to watch out for; incorrect copies of a variety of symbols, incorrect cities f4rom various countries, and so on. It's not so bad at first, but having to do this faster and faster to save your starving family, it gets very annoying to have to flick through several pages to check symbols and city names.  This is a good game, don't get me wrong, but it just wasn't my style. I found it too repetitive, and very hard to come to grips with in the first few rounds - my family died in three days because I couldn't process fast enough, didn't know what to look for. And later on, the fines get a lot harsher for the slightest mistake, you have to take bribes to survive and risk the fines, but simply missing one detail and getting a huge fine gets rather annoying.

If being anal-retentive excites you, this game is for you. You have to be really attentive to detail but you also have to be fast. If you work in a menial admin type job, beurocrocy or any kind of job that requires you to check I.D.'s this game is not for you. I felt like I was wasting my time off doing something I would normally do at work. Why would I want to play a game that reminds me of work unless i have no life? x3

This is probably the most underwelming thing i've ever purchased, and that includes some incomplete and unplayable early access games. Papers, Please was so completely outside of my comprehension that I had to write my first review about it just to get closure.  The gameplay consists of looking at a picture and making sure all the numbers & letters on it match up to some other numbers & letters distributed around your screen and filed away in leaflets that you must flip through to find the correct page. Essentialy this is the worlds least interesting and most frustrating 'spot the difference' game. It is tedius, cumbersome, and unengaging. Which is what I expected, to a degree.  My ability to track every detail of small grainy images is apparently lackin,g because after the first game day it took me a minumum of 2 minutes per passport to comb for all the minutia, and I still had a failure rate of 1/3. Once it cited me for an incorrect photograph, and I honestly had not noticed a discrepancy between the two pictures despite comparing the two; I had thought they were similar enough having the same face, hair, and beard, but apparently not. I played half an hour before I could bear no more, my levels of irritating and impatience. It was over a year before I gave it another try, inspired by all the praise I had read. My experience was no better than the first, and I cannot see myself trying again ever.  When I began I cut off all food and heat expenses, since the game offered no incentive to keep them on. Processing the amount of documents necessary to maintain those expenses is beyond my capabilities, so letting my 'family' die would be the optimal choice from a gamey perspective. From a story perspective, if you can call it that, the game gave me no reason to care about them: just letters on a form, after all. They didn't even have names.  The game punished me for my apathy when the game suddenly ended on the forth day. Apparently the family dying causes instant loss. Since I am not capable of playing the game quickly enough to pay for their expenses, this is as far as I progressed and as far as I coupld ever potentialy progress in this game.  But that is the gameplay. As I understand it the real reason this game gets praise is for its story, art and atmosphere, apparently. After playing the game, I am legitamately questioning whether all this praise is some kind of elaborate joke, as far fetched as that sounds: the coordination required would be astounding.  The story in full as I experienced it is, you are a man who checks immigrant's paperwork. You have 4 family members. the job gets harder every day. I kept waiting for some kind of twist or element that would explain the hype, suddenly make it engaging, or at the very least make me feel someing, or care even slightly, but in never came. If it comes later in the game, I am both unwilling and incapable of reaching that point.   Occasionaly the immigrants say things or beg to be let in, etc. but seeing as there is no apparent gameplay benefit or narrative pay-off to be had basing your decisions on anything but whether or not you earn a citation, I quickly tuned them out.   As for the atmosphere and art, there are some grey pixels, some black pixels, and I think even some white pixels. The intro and failure screen has red and orange pixels. There may have been some blue pixels but I cannot confirm or deny this.   So as should be clear at this point, did not enjoy this game. The gameplay is unbearable but I could have forgiven this if there was at least something outside of the gameplay to experience. I personally play games more for their story, characters, narrative and world anyway, but there are almost none of those things in Papers, Please, and I am given no reason to care about what little there is.   Above all I am left confused. If all the things that the game is praised for barely exist, and the other elements are addmitted to be terrible even by the fans, where does the praise come from? I found no redeeming qualites in this game whatsover and am completely baffled that most players did. What am I missing? What have I overlooked that explains why people liked this? I am genuinely baffled.

Can we all just please quit pretending this game is good? its like the bagle of the game industry, ppl only like it because everyone else does.   First: can we get some more pixels? Theres been atleast 5 times the picture on the i.d. wasnt matching the face, but was extermely hard to tell that  second: Plot? in this game when i see that my family is cold or hungry, it doesnt afect me, so why should i care?  third: the complexity and diffaculty increases dramatically from lvl 1-3, so much i cant keep up.

The premise is fairly unique: you play the part of a customs agent reviewing people's papers, admitting people who have everything in order, denying people with missing or expired documents, and detaining people with the audacity to try to fool you with a forgery. Depending on how much you believe someone's story or if you are pleased with their offer of a bribe, you may choose to let through someone you aren't supposed to. Admit someone you shouldn't or deny access to someone who deserves it and you get nastygrams from your boss that shift into fines. There's also a plot to mess up the government you can assist or ruin and as many as twenty different ways to end the game.  There's just one problem: it gets boring. It actually reminded me quite a lot of a job reviewing documents that I quit because ... boring. The difficulty here is largely in your attention span to minute details - after a while, even when you know what all to to look for, your attention will drop off and you will make mistakes and start racking up nastygrams.   If you enjoy studying numerous documents for any appearance of a contradiction, forget playing this game - get a job as a policy services analyst for an insurance company and get paid to do it instead of just doing it here for pretend.   Final verdict: An excellent tedium simulator. If only that weren't what I'm trying to escape from.

Papers, Please or Red Tape of a Red State  I enjoyed this game and I certainly got my money's worth. It is executed brilliantly and the music, sound, scripted events and design are great. The bleak tone of a red state is presented well and should appeal to a child of the 80s who remembers the closing decade of the Cold War.  However most gamers in general may not enjoy the relentless bureaucracy; let me explain. Each in-game 'day' normally lasts 12 hours (about 10 real minutes) and your income depends on how many entrants you process (too many mistakes penalizes your income). In theory this is a good risk/reward balance and keeps things moving. In practice it gets pretty grueling.   If you don't have an eye and attention span for detail this game won't be very appealing. If you've ever worked a desk job it will feel very much like real-life work. On my second playthrough (achievement hunting) I actually found myself checking the in-game clock to see if my shift was almost over. That's when I realized I couldn't give this game a thumbs up to the general public in good conscious.  Lastly I do recommend this game to achievement hunters. It's not difficult, extremely inexpensive on sale and easy enough to get to 100% in <10 hours.  Glory to Arstotzka, glory to relentless bureaucracy!

This is one of those games that I both love and hate at the same time. They capture the mood of Cold War-era paranoia and bureaucratic insanity perfectly, and most times it's relatively funny what new nonsense they come up with for me to check. The problem I have is I just don't find it fun. Obviously this sort of thing is subjective, so I'll give my reasons why I don't enjoy this game. The biggest thing is it doesn't feel like a game. It feels like a job. I'm put under the same nerve-wracking stress I feel when I'm doing something for payment. Am I going to miss one tiny little detail and be thrown yet another violation message? Will another bomber get through and, as a result, the AGB will kick down my apartment door and gun down my entire family? Am I breathing correctly, or does my posture sitting at this border crossing booth suggest I'm a traitor?  The whole thing feels like I'm at a job. I didn't pay 10 dollars to do a job. I paid ten dollars to have fun. I know the whole point of the game is to put you under stress and make you scrutinize the tiniest details of 1,000 rules and subrules that just keep on piling up while your whole family starves and dies, but that just isn't my idea of fun. It'd be like if I bought a game where I had to answer the telephone and worry about accidentally letting a telemarketer through to my manager. It'd be like playing a game where I'm a janitor and if I miss cleaning the floor somewhere I'm reprimanded, but if I clean it and someone slips I'm reprimanded, etc.  Stress is a part of any decent slightly challenging video game. I understand that. This is work stress, though. This is something I play games to try to escape. I don't want more of it when I'm actually playing a game and not doing menial labor for menial payment. I feel like the developers should be paying /me/ for every hour I'm playing Papers, Please. All in all, it's certainly not a bad game. It's certainly not the worst game. You might even enjoy it. This is about whether I recommend it or not, though. If you want to feel like you're at a job without the payment part, or really, REALLY like Cold War history/satire, pick it up. If you don't, buy 10 dollars worth of pancakes or something.

Good game? yes... Fun? Not for me. This is an interesting, challenging, and unique game... so why isn't it fun? It's as if the goal of the game is to leave you as frustrated as a real TSA or Border agent who's job sucks, family is scraping by and your work place rules are never consistant. The mechanics are tedious despite the game's simplicity.   Maybe that is supposed to be part of the challenge, but clicking and dragging and flipping through the rulebook frantically looking for that thing I know is wrong so that I can highlight it to begin the process of detaining, asking for papers, etc. takes much of that fun out for me. Especially when you know there is a descrepancy, but you waste time thumbing through things until you get to it just to use the game's rigid and unwaivering mechanic that allows you to move on.  Complaints aside, it is very interesting to see how how things pan out with your decisions made. Knowing you helped capture a murderer, or finding out later you let one through hit home in a weird subtle way. Having played it, i'd never recommend it at full price. I might at half price to a select few, but I think this one is going to fall into a small cult following. I

Despite it's retro graphics, Papers Please's art style is delightfully charming. It's gameplay is surprisingly challenging. It's setting is imaginatively grim. It seems to have all the hallmarks of an excellent game. So why did I stop playing it after only a couple of hours? Because it plays too much like real work! Not that I actually have a job like that, but at tedious paperwork that makes up the core of the gameplay is the sort of stuff I use video games to escape from! And then it makes me worry about my virtual-families finances on top of that? Honestly, I was starting to stress out more from the game than I ever actually did in real life. No thank you!

So as far as I can tell:  If you like immersing yourself in games, then this is for you. Play the exciting life of a customs booth officer as he tries to work as hard as he can to save his poor unfortunate family from being eaten by wolves (probably) while deciding what to do about the the poor unfortunate immigrants who only sometimes want to bomb your country.  On the other hand, if you're a munchkin and always play to win, expect a really boring experience was you can't quite get your head around why you have to care about your mother-in-law in the first place.   Thumbs down, because I'm the latter, and I just can't recommend a game that I didn't enjoy myself.

I picked this up in the Steam Sale yesterday and was very happy with it on my PC until last night. I saved my game and uploaded it to the Steam Cloud, knowing that I was spending the evening at my girlfriend's house, I figured it was something I could play on my laptop. This is where the problems began.  I got to my girlfriend's and ran the game, whereupon it asked me if I wanted to download the save I had. I definitely clicked 'yes' but it uploaded the laptop save to the cloud anyway.  'Fine' I thought to myself. 'I'll just start again now and load up my old save when I get home tomorrow.'  So I get home the next day and booted up my PC, only to have it automatically download my laptop's save from the cloud.  'Fine' I thought to myself. 'I'll just play from where I left off last night on my laptop.'  Alas, regardless of what day I load the save up on, it simply starts from day one. This is a great game and I know that a lot of people have had a lot of fun with it, but I honestly can't reccomend it to anyone with such a horrendous, game-breaking bug. I don't have the heart to re-start for the third time in 24 hours. So I have essentially wasted my money and my time.

It's a very smart game, but I wouldn't call it fun. Playing for about an hour made me feel ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the rest of the day. Pick it up if you want to learn something about game design, but don't expect to have a good time.

Papers please has some major flaws but also a few positives. Lets start with the positives: It makes every single statistic into a individual. by this i mean each person u decide to allow into the country (or deny depending on your choice) has there own individual story, these seemingly pointless people are individuals. This is the main selling point for the game and i can see why people like it so much.  Another good point is the way youre thrown into this game its quite immersive, u have to slave for hours over a desk deciding peoples fates. However (now for the bad parts) with this immersion it essentially just what it would be like irl, u slave over a desk clicking accept or deny and for me that can be a bit boring. Yes u hear peoples stories but at the end of the day it doesnt effect me or phase me in the slightest. I really couldnt give 2 ♥♥♥♥♥. If i want that ill watch a film atleast then it has more character and action. I wouldnt recomment this however i can appreciate the game for its charm and i believe thats why so many people like it. also to recommend it u must have so pretty boring friends because if i got recommended this and spent money on it based on that persons opinion i wouldnt take them seriously again.

'Papers, Please' is a stressful rage-inducing work. As far as I've played, I haven't felt any sense of accomplishement, only increasing stress as each day is painfully spent racing against the clock to have enough persons going through to meet the necessary quota while making sure not to let unauthorized persons in... Or authorized out. On top of that, I find the voices' SFX absolutely ear-grating - but of course that will probably differ from person to person. The game itself runs smoothly, and has no major bugs... Or if it does, it'll make you think it's your fault for missing a discrepancy on a passport... Maybe :)  In conclusion, if you're not looking for something to play to relax but instead something to stress yourself over, this is your game, albeit on the pricy side. Which is mainly why I do not recommend it.

Interesting concept but it's just so fiddly. I'm sure that's the point, but I felt like the interface got in the way substantially more than the actual tedium that they're trying to simulate. I found myself getting more and more frustrated with the game, and even knowing there's a deeper story, I just couldn't stick with it long enough to get over the interface troubles.

First and foremost, this game has a little something called 'atmosphere' going for it. Everything about the aesthetic, the music, and even the gameplay is carefully crafted to achieve a certain feeling to the game's world, and if that's all you want from a game, then great, pick this up.  However, the gameplay quickly becomes Paper Pusher Simulation 3000, with new gameplay features being little more than another checkbox on your list of tasks. Again, this helps contribute to the game's world brilliantly. However, a couple of things ruin the sense of immersion the game is going for almost as badly as the infamous Conversation Wheel did for Oblivion:  1) Slowing down to appreciate the game's world and feeling are punished. You only receive much-needed money for each case you complete, and each day introduces its own timer. Feel like slowing down and examining each person in the checkpoint throughly, perhaps understanding a bit more of their history or any quandries they may face from being rightfully denied? Want to take time to think over moral choices? OOPS, TOO BAD, YOUR FAMILY IS DEAD BECAUSE YOU DIDN'T HAVE MONEY FOR FOOD. WORK HARDER, SLAVE.  2) You, the player, are meant to be a border inspector, ensuring that no criminals or undesirables enter the country through illegal means. To ensure quality, the player is warned and then fined for mistakes. However, this raises an irritating question: if your employers can instantly detect that the person you waved through has fake papers, why in the name of Odin are they paying you?  However, I will admit that the gameplay is deeply intuitive, and I appreciate that there's no hand-holding tutorial. However, at the end of the day, what I come to a video game for is gameplay. And when the gameplay amounts to cross-referencing data and double-checking statements with few results that the player can see beyond the pocketbook? It grows staler than a 'Hammer Time' joke.  In conclusion, I enjoy when games aspire to be art, but if a game sacrifices being fun for the sake of art, then fornicate your art; if I wanted a dull, repetitive job, I'd apply to one or play EVE Online.

In this game, you check passports all day at the border of a communist nation. That is the gameplay of Papers, Please in its entirety.   There is some story involved, but it's the same cliched 'oppressive communistic USSR type gov't rised to power' cliche. If I wanted a good story about an overpowering government, I would read Fahrenheit 451 or 1984, and then I wouldn't have to stamp passports all day, starving my family in the process.

While I understand that it's supposed to be a bleak look at the brutal reality of life in a totalitarian dictatorship, games also need to actually be fun. Failing constantly in every conceivable way isn't fun. Perhaps if the game had a learning curve that was a little more forgiving I'd be willing to press on, but as it stands a constant parade of 'Everyone in your family dies, you fail' and 'Their documents were wrong, but because you can't mindmeld with the game and predict which two things to connect to tell the game you know they're wrong we'll just penalize you constantly instead' is just demoralizing and inane. If there was some sort of reward for catching the mistakes or the criminals to help make up for the myriad of mistakes one can make, to add some of that animalistic joy brain-drug, that would improve things as well. Basically, it needs an easy/training mode.  I play games to have fun, even if it's a grim kind of fun, but this game only delivers grimness. If that's your thing, it's your thing, but it isn't mine.

I really wanted to like this game. The premise was interesting and creative. But now I sort of wish I hadn't bothered. Previous reviewers were right, the game ultimately feels like work. You're essentially doublechecking a ton of slips of paper and as the game goes on it just finds different reasons to give you more slips of paper. It's hard to get emotionally involved in this game. Somebody says 'I was too poor for x slip of paper' I have no reason to give a ♥♥♥♥. They're not giving me any reason to care. I have family to take care of but you never meet them and you never care beyond the fact that if they all die the game ends. I only felt emotionally compelled to make a 'hard' decision once and it was after 5 hours of shuffling through customs papers. I might feel compelled to pick this game up again at a later time, but it'll only be because I've purchased it and I'll feel like I should probably just finish it. Or because I got fired and want to know what it feels like to be employed again as a border agent.

Sure, it's interesting and immersive at first, but past the first hour or, this game becomes mind-bogglinly boring. I found getting completely fed up with the story mode (which is probably the more interesting mode) half way through.  The game is great as a demonstration of the type of story one can tell using an interactivley medium, but it's not one that's fun to play.

I can't say I can recommend this. I enjoy the game, I really do. It's interesting, unique, and in a way, critiquing typical game design. But it isn't a game I can see anyone devoting a lot of time into. The gameplay is essentially spot-what's-wrong with a risk/reward time limit. The atmosphere, soundtrack, and theme are all well done, but the gameplay defines it, as well as keeps it from rising above. Overall I like it, but I don't feel I should recommend it.

Not really a game, but more of a test of your patience. You're an immigration official and you deny or allow people into the country. Easy at first with only a few items to check for, but eventually you have to check for a large amount of prerequisites and time is always running out. So within a few days of game time, you’re either having fun rushing through as many people as possible trying not to make mistakes, or you’re wondering why you’re not spending your time on something more interesting and rewarding.   If you like repetitive tasks and indie experiments, you might find something worthwhile here. For someone who enjoys adventures and action games, it's about as fun as real social work. Not exactly what I want after coming home.

You can cheese the difficulty with an easy mode (adds twenty credits per day) and by simply holding the taskbar while cross referencing the documents.

At first glance of Papers, Please, the game seemed very creative and different from all the other games. You verify their identification to get into the country. This could be checking photo matching the person, expiration dates, and crossing checking an access list for the day. You are playing a control point sentry guard or as a club bouncer simulation. As the game continues, the issues for entry becomes more complicated and must completed quickly. After a while, the gameplay becomes repetitive and mundane. I don't recommend this game to those who check papers or identification for a living because you'll be essentially playing your job. I wouldn't play this game any further than my less than 20 minutes of game time.

I was very intrigued by the concept of the game, seeing as I had never played anything even remotely comparable before. Papers, please truly is a unique experience - alas - not an enjoyable one for me.  The biggest problem I had with this game was the core gameplay, the paper checking. As you progress, the game grows more complex as it challenges you to review more and more information in the same amount of time. You'll be granted new ways to check up on and process people, and sometimes characters will slip you unexpected offers/bribes/etc. with their passports. However, most of what you do is just that: checking papers for matching data. That is not fun. It's... paperwork.  While for other people, this activity might take a backseat to the other facets of the game, I couldn't bring myself to sit through this bland, monotonous grind just to experience what else the game might have to offer. If you've ever had to work a really boring job and felt like it was the wrong decision to take it in the first place, you should know what I'm talking about. Maybe the creators of the game wanted you to feel bored and disengaged. Perhaps they wanted to use the game as a medium to recreate this feeling of working a horrible job. If they did: kudos, mission accomplished. But I can't help but feel like this may have worked better as a choose-your-own-adventure book, where you would have gotten to the story bits faster and wouldn't have had to drown yourself in repetitiveness in-between these parts. The game managed to make me quit because it was too boring. That can hardly be its intention.  Something else that bothered me is the visual style of the game. Although I consider myself a fan of pixelated graphics, I feel like Papers, please could have profited from more detailed character models. If the face of the people whose life depends on you is almost expressionless, you will have a hard time mustering up the empathy needed to feel anything toward these characters - no matter what happens to them. The often monosyllabic dialogue or the mumbling voices don't really alleviate this problem. Even if the creator's plan was to create an impersonal, dystopian setting, the human interactions at least should feel a bit more personal. Otherwise it'll just keep people from immersing themselves in the game.  I did not complete any of the game's branching paths. So naturally my review can cover only parts of the game. Although there seemed to be interesting stuff going on story-wise... after the eighth (in-game) day of stamping papers I just didn't want to anymore. I recommend this only if you do not mind enduring depressingly dull gameplay for the sake of narrative.
no thanks.

Just dumb. And annoying. I really like the idea of this based on the other reviews, so that's why I bought it. You do your best to see if people have the correct credentials, but it will always give you a citation if you miss something - like there is someone watching over your shoulder who already knows whether they do or not. Infinite wisdom of the AI I guess. It really is depressing too - from the graphics to the sounds. People do this kind of stuff for their jobs, so why would anyone want to do it as a game? Please take my advice and pass on this one.

Grade: C/B-  Summary Review: Good- An creative idea for a video game with definite potential; unique design Bad- Awkward UI, An unfulling experience  Description: You play as an immigration inspector at a border checkpoint for the country of Arstotzka. Your job is to deny or accept people's request to enter the country based off their paperwork. Failure to deny access to those with false paperwork (such as terrorist, criminals or just those with legitamite reasons) will cause a loss of pay which will have significant impact on the wellbeing of yourself and your family.   Review:  Um I don't exactly know what to say about Papars, Please. After playing for one run through and about 1 hour and a half I don't really think this is a good game. There is certainly potential in this game. While simple it was engaging to play border security- it was almost like a detective sitting at the desk. Not to mention it offers a unique perspective on the effects of authoritarian regimes (like the USSR) on average everyday people. But there are to many issues for this to be a good experience. For one the way you examine paperwork is unwieldy and given that your on the clock (you have til 6:00 til your shift is over) time wasted going back and forth between ever increasing pieces of paperwork becomes iritating and impossible to see errors or mismatching information. I understand that this is an attempt to simulate reality but this doesn't really bring anything to a videogame's experience. Literally this games need 'Less Papers, Please'. I will perhaps give Papers, Please further attempts but I don't see myself getting anything more out of this game.
Some people might find it fun but i couldn't get into it. Maybe if I played more I might, but I found it to be tediuos.
This game.. Mai god. It's, tedious, at best. Someday, somewhere, someone said 'Yaknow what doesn't exist? Papers please.'

I'd be wary before purchasing this game. If you love challenging puzzle games, that have an outstanding degree of choices and outcomes from your actions, then this is that game for you. But While the start of the game is fun as it prgresses the novelty of it wears off.   While it has dozens of hours of replay value, when it's at the point in it's progressing. It's just no longer satisfying. In which there are so many things to go wrong to get penalized on, and that at that point it's easier just to pick people at random (without inspecting anything) just let them through regardless. And now with playing a few hours of it, I'm starting to regret my purchase, and that I have wasted my money on a game I'll only play once.

In this game, you play as an Immigration Control Officer of a fictional dystopian country. This means you will be doing tedious stuff like ensuring that the passport and other documents have not expired, that a potential immigrant's work permit passport number matches with his presented passport, that the picture on the passport actually matches the person and other trivialities. You do not have the luxury to peruse the papers at your leisure because you have a limited amount of time each day to process immigrants - your daily pay is based on how many people you accurately serve.   If you want to be good at this game, it will demand that you memorize the *geography* of this fictional world, like which cities belong in the country of Republia, and which districts are in your home country of Arstotzkan. So if you enjoy filling your head with completely useless trivia, then go for it! I'd personally spend that time learning real world geography if my inclinations ever took me in that direction (although for censorship/political reasons, the game creators wisely refrained from adding any Real World countries).  The game is a monotonous drone of menial work. Playing it felt like work to me. Story mode offers occasional flashes of excitement when you are asked to perform some 'cloak & dagger' operations or resolve some moral dillemma, but this happens around 10% of the game and is not enough reward to chore the rest. The developers could have chosen to add a lot more 'custom events' to make the game more engaging, but I guess it was not done due to time/budget constraints, laziness, or possibly a desire to achieve realism. I guess a border official's life is pretty boring - in game you meet a former border official and he tells you something to the tune of 'I'm glad I'm no longer in that business'.  In a nutshell: This game is work. If you want work that badly, then go get a job instead of playing this game.

Another example, I am penalized because the photo does not match. But they look like the photo just fine. Is this a bug or is it trying to simulate the arbitrariness? Maybe the intent is for the implementation to be so bad that I can't tell, but that just doesn't work because it makes me think the game is poor instead of the situation is heartless and hopeless.

Maybe if I was unemployed I could enjoy it more, but I don't think so. I still have no interest in enforcing draconian rules for a totalitarian regime. Even if your greatest dream is to see the world dominated by an oppresive jack boot on the throat, who would want to play the schlub enforcing mudane rules on the general public who hates you.  If your greatest aspiration was to work at the DMV, but you didn't make the grade then get this game. You will love it. 'Um, no, I'm sorry sir for that you need form 31B-zeta. You find them over there, fill one out and get back in line. Have a wonderful day. I really mean it. NEXT!!!!!' Ugh.  This game must be some kind of test for a government or a corporation bent on global domination. This game is a waste of your time and your money. They should have sold this as a training simulator for the TSA / border patrol.  Really bad gaphics that try to be 'indie/edgy' but just come across as cheap and lazy, especially when some of the gameplay hinges on your ability to determine details that you can't see because of the low graphics.  The 'story' is non existent, it takes an incredibly long time to 'progress' if it can be called that, it's REALLY slow, uninteresting, and not engaging AT ALL.  The gameplay is literally the most boring thing I have ever experienced in my life. You will literally have to check every line of info on the various documents that are presented to you against a 'rule book', to make sure that everything is correct will take anywhere from 1-3 minutes, and you have about 10 minutes in a 'day'. If you don't process at least 15-20 people in a day, there is no way you can possibly 'survive' much less 'win' the story.  This game is a failure on every front.   Graphics: 4/10  Sound Design: 3/10 (same sounds, music repeated ad nauseam)  Story: 2/10  Gameplay 1/10  This is the classic example of an indie game getting praise from people for being 'edgy' or 'different'. But guess what? That doesn't = good game. In this case, it has resulted in an 'artsy' game that is not fun to play, severely over priced even when on sale, and the frustration of seeing people praise it just for the sake of it being different.

I don't know if I'm just not cut out for this game, but I found it to be quite tedious. There are games that make tedious tasks fun, and others that don't feel tedious at all, but Papers, Please felt like coming home from work, and doing more work. In a much less rewarding and happy atmosphere as well. I may give it another try, but after 4 hours of playing, I was done.

Have you ever been stuck in line at customs, waiting with passport in hand to visit or return to the United States and watched as a uniformed TSA agent peers intently at your passport deciding if you get to enter or not? Did you ever think, ‘By golly! Somebody should make a video game about this!’ No? Neither have I, but Indy game maker, Lucas Pope has in his “dystopian document thriller,” Papers, Please available on Steam for $9.99.  In Papers, Please you have been selected by the clearly communist government of East Germany – I mean Arstotzka to be a border checkpoint inspector at the recently opened border crossing between there and some made other made up country. Seeing as how vital this job is to the national security of Arstotzka you are given a detailed training course and after a long six weeks of shadowing an expert border crossing agent you are finally on your own to prove yourself after learning all the tricks of the pros! Ha ha, just kidding. You are given a tiny handbook, a weird stamping gizmo, and off you go!  So you walk to work and start checking passports! How thrilling is that? Actually it’s not, it’s incredibly tedious as the game is overly complex. There are a million different reasons to deny entry and each day your job gets more and more complex as government edicts make your life a living hell. There are not just the obvious things either that could be wrong on the passports, sure there’s the obvious of the picture not matching or the wrong sex, or the id number on the passport doesn’t match the id number on a travel permit. But then really nitpicky things like the issuing city doesn’t match, since all the nations and city names are fictional, something you’d only know by flipping through your rule book for each and every passport.  So you spend usually a minute or two scouring and comparing all the papers. When you find a discrepancy you are supposed to interrogate the person. You do this by selecting the comparison icon in the bottom right corner and select the two mismatching items. If the name on the work permit doesn’t match the passport, click on both and then interrogate the person. You can even have them detained by your guards if you feel it necessary. But this system is incredibly clunky if someone does not present proper documents or the city does not match as you have to flip through your rule book and select the broken rule. Now that you’ve handled that person in line, time to do it all over again! If this all sounds like a lot of work, that is because it is! After eeking my way through the first couple days in game I felt like I had just paid $10 to work a second job and even a particularly exciting one!  Underneath all this work there are a few story lines which I guess are kinda interesting in the way you get weird customers at a boring retail job can spice up your day. But the payoff is just not worth the work required to get through the game. I think somebody forgot to tell the maker of Papers, Please that we PLAY games, not work at games. Just because a game is incredibly complex and intricate does not make it fun and actually can make it far far too tedious, cumbersome, and ultimately dull.  While it can be kinda satisfying to detain some idiot for trying to pass through your checkpoint with phony papers or even approve a lady entry who’s running for her life but doesn’t have all her required documents the game still drags. Work. Work. Work. Work. And eventually I’m sick of it. I want to give at least a kudos to the developer for trying a new idea of intertwining a story into a mundane every day experience but there is far too much work to get there. Even worse it feels like my job is pointless as somebody must be watching everything I do. Each time I make a mistake a computer printout reprimands me and after more than two mistakes each day starts hitting me with fines. Get too many fines and you can’t afford your rent and you’re fired and arrested for delinquency. Lovely.  Each day add up your pennies, pay rent, and then go broke. Just like real life! Apparently you are paid $5 per person who passes through your booth as long as you get them through before closing time. However good luck affording luxuries like heat or medicine when your family is sick, especially if you are hit with even one or two penalties during your work day.  In the end, I’d probably pass on Papers, Please even if it was half the price. Unless you are really into comparing documents or you ever really really wanted to be a TSA agent. Papers, Please is too much work and not enough actual fun for me. Final Score: Graphics: 5/10 Game Play: 3/10 Music / Ambiance: 8/10 Story: 5/10 Value: 5/10 Overall: 5.2/10  Read more indy game reviews on my blog!  http://markofithian.com

★ out of four.  I imagine Papers, Please was constructed around its main action of processing in-game paperwork at a border crossing. Papers, Please doesn't actually have any commentary to make. Validating the paperwork itself is the strongest part here, as you try to do your best in the timed work day. Indeed, more rules are added over time and it is up to each player to physically organize their desk and the placement of documents, but also to mentally process how to approach things. What is the best order (for you?) to check information? Is there enough time during a suspect's body search to do anything useful? The binary choices you make on a personal level are just interesting enough to entice replaying them. Yet, these choices have little payoff, which is true of Papers, Please overall.

It is not a bad game, it's just not for everyone. Personally I had a few problems with it that prevented me from enjoying the game.   No morale choice Yes, it is possible to let people enter. But some mysterious checking system immediately gives you a warning if they weren't allowed entry. Because you only get paid for people that enter, you want to let as many people in as possible. Which brings the next problem...  Time based You only have limited time. Meaning if you get a difficult case, you automatically get less income. It's counterproductive. It's also unfair, but I guess that's how the regime works. Anyhow, the time based events made worse because of a ...  Cumbersome UI The UI is annoying. Especially when you need to compare things to point out discrepancies, because you need to keep flipping pages back and forth. It's just tiresome and no fun.

Let me get this out of the way; yes, Papers, Please is a very unique game which does a good job at making something as boring as stamping papers at a border stop actually engaging. It’s definitely worth a look at – and that’s it.   The whole time I was playing this game I felt like its message was hammering itself on me with a jackhammer the whole time making me feel like the game was very pretentious. I just could not get into the game the whole thing pretty much forced you to memorize the entire guide book on the countries symbols, capitals, etc… And yes, I am well aware this is probably the point of the game, but it still makes it a not very user friendly experience.   Again though, the game is definitely worth a look, but it's really not for me...

The control is faily straight forward, but still annoying as you have to manually pull books and papers across the desk.   ALL of that would have been ignored had the game been fun. It's not. It's tedious, boring, and requires almost wrote memorization of multiple made up regulations. I know what the developers were going for here, but they completely failed because they forgot that games are meant to be entertaining.   Papers Please? No thank you.

A wonderful and depressing game. I'm a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who follows rules to the letter. But if you are a bleeding heart, Papers, Please will make you conflicted on whether to do your job appropriately or show concern for your fellow man. It takes those 'what's different between these two images' from old Highlights magazines but adds a very human twist to it. Very well-designed and deserving of your time.

Papers, Please is one of those games that you will go back for more. For a small game, there is a lot of content in there. Story lasts about 4hrs and continues with Endless mode which is a lot of fun. I would like to see more characters, different papers and just more of everything. Great indie title!
A great sociopolitical commentary on immigration in the past... and now.

'Observation Skills: The Game.' I find this game pretty interesting. You play as a documents inspector working at a border checkpoint. Oh yeah, this is a checkpoint that leads into a corrupt, dystopian, and fascist nation.  The game goes out of its way every so often to test your sense of right and wrong. Will you let a woman who lacks documentation but is in need of an experimental surgery that is only available in your country past the checkpoint? Or will you deny her entry in order to retain the job you need to provide for your family?  Gameplay is pretty much just examining people's passports, permits, work passes, etc. and then issuing a stamp of denial or entry. Curveballs get thrown at you though which mix up the variables that ultimately decide whether a person can pass or not. And with about twenty endings, the game knows how to keep you engaged.

Papers, Please is a strange game to recommend.  It's not a bad game, far from it, but the game is rather special. Much like Cart Life or Cooking Mama the game has you doing relatively simple and mundane actions for almost no reward.  Unlike Cooking Mama though, there's a huge story at work here one, which you as an inspector at a border checkpoint, get to experience first hand.  You will meet several characters, see the arcs they go through, reunite families and desperately try to care for your own, because the glory in Arstotzka is gone, but time races ever forward and you have to meet the standards set by the government or your job, family and freedom will be taken from you.  If you want something different, interesting and thought-provoking then get Paper's, Please.

'NEXT!' Is one of the things you'd be saying the most, you take role as a person who is the only one to tell if someone is allowed into the country of Arstotzka.After 6 horrible years the borders now finally open, but beware. Fake Id, fake passes, and fake asses. It is your job to approve, or deny peoples entrance, and if someone seems dangerous for the country you got the option to detain him.  This game was hard for me to pick up, due to its somewhat 'stale' looks, but i am more than impressed for how adictive this is. It has humor, tension and action in it. Its definetly worth a try!  I will rate this game a 7/10
The most original game idea ever. But I can't help feeling a great opportunity for something better has been thrown at a low budget game with terrible graphics. Still, it's an interesting game 70%

This is not a game for everybody.  It will not be a relaxing gaming session if you decide to play Papers Please. Instead, you will be required to really focus and try to do your thing the best possible way you can. Even though you might think that what Papers Please has to offer may be boring or not interesting, it is surprisingly intriguing as you realize that the storyline of the game is more than you thought. Papers Please has 20 endings, all of them are dependent on the player's actions. There are entire storylines that can end differently depending on what you do in the game and I recommend playing through the story mode a couple of times just to see how many things could go the opposite way.  After 2 full playthroughs I think it's the engagement the game requires from the player that is so appealing to me and I have to say that I've had a lot more fun with Papers Please than with any other video game that came out this year. Definitelly worth the price if you think you might like something a bit different in gameplay.

I recently wrote a review on this game for Defunct Games, however I really enjoyed papers, please. It's really fun and the gameplay mechanics are unique, although it was one frustrating at times and occasionally it made me rethink my own life which made me retract from the game at had, and I lost my concentration, and the game because of it.

There's something immensely gratifying about a game that rewards you not for cutting corners, cheating the system or getting one over on someone but for being accurate and efficient. Papers please is a game about spotting errors and mistakes, essentially an elaborate 'spot the difference' set in a humourous dystopian communist soviet state. Just like its solid unwavering theme tune, this game is a masterpiece of simplicity and good game design that really builds a sense of tension waiting for the inevitable citation slip every time you give someone the go-ahead to enter. Every time I start it up and the relentless plodding theme tune begins all I hear is yet another nail being hammered into the coffin of big game studios. Glory to Arstotzka.
Feels more like a job, then a game. Decent similator I guess. But the mechanical repetition tasks are 24/7 in this game.  I can't really recommend this game, support the makers though.
I never would have thought the life of an immigration officer could be that captivating. No offense meant to all the immigration officers out there. ;)

If you guys think this game is all about passport checking... you're all wrong. you need to manage your money to save your family you need to act in order to cooperate or not with some assassin you need to be quick to shoot those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that cross the border you need to be perfect in order to save a soldier that you've known  it's must more complicated and more fun than you have thought  buy it already
Haha... This game is so simple but addicting... LOVE IT

However unlike Phoenix Wright it is not required to get it right to progress although you get punished for getting it wrong. Deliberately passing people with missing or incorrect papers may even pay off in the story!  Even though the limited color palette and fits the setting really well it gets a little dull after a while. Similarly the gameplay gets very repetitive but I also feel it is part of the charm

Papers, Please seems almost like a joke at first glance. I got this game in a Humble Bundle, and I don't think I would have purchased it otherwise.  The idea behind the game is simple. Who do you let past the border? The idea is a boring one and you wouldn't expect someone to ever make a game from it. However Papers, Please has me pleasently surprised.  It starts off fairly easy, simply giving you one instruction. However as the days go by you need to be more thorough and you start to question yourself in the end. The difficulty curve is perfect in that it presents you with a challenge and just the right amount of time to add it to your already existing arsenal of abilities that will build up over the time playing the game. The 'story' is actually somewhat compelling.  Overall I do recommend this game, especially for the price,  You would usually look at this game, chuckle to yourself and then move on. But I recommend stopping to check it out.

Such an addictive game.  What looks like a shallow puzzler quickly reveals itself to be a complex problem solver in a race against time.  It's got its own style, and couple with it a branching story with up to 20 endings, Paper, Please offers hours of play for a cheap price.
I like Papers Please for a number of reasons, 1. It's creative 2. It's different 3. It has cool 8 bit graphics, if you are thinking of buying this indie masterpeice I suggest you do

In short it's a border checkpoint simulator and it conveys it's message incredibly well. There are different aspects to take notice of like passport expiration dates and much more. It has it's replayability and is sort of based on roguelike money management  Yet I find it hard to recommend, because personally this is not my type of game. Though it has it's own audience that it pleases.
This is one of the best games ive ever played i'd have to say. It has a great story line and fun mechanics. I wish that this game was longer though. This is a must get. :D

Like most poeple, I thought how can an 1980s Soviet-style immigration border control simulation be at all interesting? But it is amazing! It is the first game I've played where I have felt that I am presented with genuine moral dilemmas with significant in-game consequences. I dont know how many endings there are, but I've played it a few times and each time the ending is different. Some are more favourable than othesr but none are perfect. A few rounds in and the game becomes a bit of a challenge as you have to adapt to the constantly changing rules, increasing layers of beurocracy and an ever-changing political climate, while at the same time trying to protect youself and your family from destitution. Very interesting game and worth a go!

Bizarrely enough, the gameplay here becomes hypnotic and engrossing. Be careful of doing everything the secret society (I cannot recall their handle) asks, as you will soon have enough money to remove a great deal of the tension.

Papers, Please is unlike any game I've played before. It says so much with so little, and is incredibly well executed. Stark, cold, and highly enjoyable.

After having heard several sources recommending this game, I finally decided to give it a go. I was not disappointed. On the surface it is a very simple game. Survey each subject's paper work and judge if they are acceptable for entry into your Soviet hell hole. Though the constant juggling of checking that their papers are in order, with trying to process as many applicants as possible to earn money to support your family becomes very addictive. That is before you mention terrorist attacks and anti government plots.  All in all, this is a very innovative and oddly fun game. With the cheap price in mind also, I highly recommend it. Glory to Arstotzka!

I throughroughly enjoyed this game! It took me 5 hours to play through to the last day, only to find out that there are 20 different endings! Being able to start a new timeline from a day I already played was a lifesaver. Gameplay immerses you in the story, and made me feel for the character I was playing. Not many games change the way I think, but this was definitely one of them. Glory to Arstotzka! 9/10

At its core, Papers, Please is about reading papers and pressing a stamp to them. You play as a border inspector charged with examining the papers of everyone seeking to cross. This sounds terribly dull, and it's meant to.   But through an expertly crafted narrative, the thankless, monotonous task acquires momentous significance. The player's choices will affect others' lives, whether due to breaking up families by denying a visa or arresting a terrorist attempting to smuggle a bomb through the checkpoint. In this way, paperwork checks can become more important than making sure names and expiration dates are valid because the rulebook tells you to.  Ultimately, the game is a struggle between the player and that very rulebook. The rulebook demands a particlar result in each situation. Early on, you learn that you are rewarded for following it, and punished for deviating. The rules often change from day to day, which can make your task easier or more difficult and thus affect your relationship with the rulebook. But as the game unfolds, you are encouraged, and even pressured, to use more and more discretion even when the rulebook gives you a procedure. By the end, you have a number of competing priorities, and where the rulebook stands on that list is up to you.  Winning in Papers, Please is not about catching all of the discrepancies. It's not even about obtaining a specific ending. It's about taking ownership of your decisions back from the rulebook.
I wouldn't expect to have fun sitting at home on Friday night making sure that some guy's vaccine records match his passport, but here we are.

I became friends with a drug dealer I got detained at a border checkpoint, felt legitimate hate towards citizens of a fictional country I haven't even seen solely because they were from that country, and spent 20 hours doing a menial job that this game made fun.  11 passports/10 would remove Kolech again

Papers, Please is an intriguing story with a surprising level of complexity. Just when you think there's no more to it something else gets thrown in. Plus there are 20 different endings to try and find. The only negative I have is that your desk quickly becomes crowded. I would've liked a little more room. A real gem though.  8/10

This game, during the first days, looked like it was going to be easy, but as the game progressed I had no idea it was going to be so stressful! First, you always have to keep an eye out for forgeries, mistakes and other discrepancies. Second is the pay which is at an all-time low, so it makes it quite hard to feed your family. Third is all these offers from other people claiming that they will give you money, but sometimes, you can't accept because then your job would be at stake. But hey, that's what makes the game so fun! The part that stands out to me most though, is that at every ending, it says 'Glory to Arstotzka.', which I've found can have different meanings depending on how the game ends. If ended in criminalization, 'Glory to Arstotzka.' can mean, 'You don't deserve to be a part of Arstotzka. Glory to the rest of us.'. If ended in doing your job well, it can mean, 'You are accepted as one of us. Glory to all of us, including you.' Three words that say the same thing, but mean different things. This game is definitely worth playing.  Glory to Arstotzka.

This game is great for casual players like myself. It's gameplay really leaves you feeling emotional, good or bad that's your choice. There are many choices to make that change the way the game plays out, but the goal is to just survive. With that being said, this is a game I'd recommend to anyone.

As a mindless bureaucrat, I can't help but condone this game for all of its mind-bending rules, regulations and your either strict adherence to government policy or finding out every last little story down to whether or not there is a Cobrastan. An incredible concept that is well executed. There really is no game like this, it is truly unique. It is hard to describe, but it is basically a point-and-click game with challenging choices to be made. You will be confronted with strange and bizarre situations, but the real challenge is getting your head around all the rules and regulations that need to be followed in your job at a border checkpoint. The art style is clear in the screenshots, but if you don't like it, please try it out anyway. You will be surprised at how enjoyable this game really is!

In this game, you are an inspector working at the immigration office, controlling who comes in and who not. While Papers, Please has simple graphics and looks easy to play, it actually isn't. As an inspector, you need to follow strict regulations such as checking the person at the counter if he or she has all the right documents. And whether those documents could have been forged; information are correct etc. You flag them out if they are not who the documents specified, or they are suspected smugglers etc.   In the story mode, the checks get harder by the days following the daily news that is happening, and there are cases whereby the immigrant has special reasons to want to get through, but does not have all the necessary documents; or a bribe to get entry when you need the money for your family etc. It all boils down to choices as an inspector, whether it is morally right to allow entry at the expense of breaking the rules, which would mean there will be penalty, or go strictly by the book in a heartless, unwavering fashion.   Overall, the game is well-made and is fairly addictive, and there is an endless game mode which can be unlocked when you meet certain requirements in the story mode.

This game is like Customs simulator and every time I grant someone entry I always get afraid I'm going to get a citation. Hmm.....Does this person in front of me have a gun? a grenade? a bomb?  It's so much work, but it's entertaining. When you don't get a citation at all one day you'll feel like patting yourself on the back. Then you might want to mess that up because someone's wife has no papers, but the husband is all set or if someone needs medical attention. What do I do? I have no idea...GRANTED ENTRY!! BYE PERFECT RECORD!!!!
Learning curve probably slightly steeper than the average game, but surprisingly addictive and compelling.

I have a lot more respect for paper pushers after just a little time in this game. The way the world is presented (through a rather narrow lens) is also quite provocative.  Worth picking up while on sale.

It's sheer genius - and I look forward to this formula being applied to such raucously fun activities as toenail clipping, hinge-oiling and lightbulb inventory-taking.

I didn't know what to think of when I walked into this game. A border inspector? No thanks. But then I bought it and omigawd it's amazing. I feel the most human when I play this game. The choises you must make are true to life. Should I unite this family or keep them apart because their papers are false? Can I afford food for my family tonight? It really makes you think.  There are twenty different ending to this game. I've probably played it three times using different ethics each time. Should I stay loyal to my country or should I try to overthrow it? There are so many possibilities. Buy this game.  10/10

Papers, please.  Congratulations.  The October Labor Lottery is complete. Your name was pulled.  ~~~~~~~~~~~~  If you feel the need to simulate work or pretend to be what a TSA is suppose to be then this is the game for you.   As every day passes you will become mired in more and more red tape giving stipulations and rules for granting access to the glorious Arstotzka. Just as you feel you adapted to them all, they will change it again and fine you for almost every misstep.  All the while you will have immigrants pleading for entry, promising sex, muscles, drugs, and giving bribes. They will be tugging at your heartstrings for sympathy, 'just this once'. But...You have your own family to feed and keep warm. Is it worth the cost? Are you willing to risk it?  Glory to Arstotzka!

I'll admitt I wasnt sure what I was thinking when I bought this game. In fact, I remember being pretty certain I was wasting my money, and judging from the trailer I was about to waste some good money on a glorified Spot The Difference game.  Thankfully I was both undeterred and wrong. This game is seriously addictive, with a constantly changing set of rules, reoccuring characters, intense story and high pressure moments that you can only hope to keep up with, rather than prepare for.  I find myself more and more these days being sucked into indie games rather than AAA titles, and it's because of games like Papers, Please that this is happening. I'm spending a fraction of my money on a more in-depth story and experience whilst getting something much more replayable. As a result I'm getting much more use of games like this per pound/dollar/euro spent.  If you're getting to this stage in your gaming life too, then Papers, Please is perfect for you. Get through the first few beginner days and experience the pressure of all the checks you need to do all whilst attempting to maintain a quota of customers in a day so you can feed your family. And remember: trust no-one!

Jorji Costava... one name, face, and smile that you will never forget...   Papers, Please: a game played for hours and hours... I sat down drinking my Kool-Aid, sorting passports and papers; stressing over whether to 'pass' or 'deny' passports because a citation awaits for any small mistake. This game will test your morale, loyalty, and ethics... may the mighty passport gods be in your favor.
Good little time waster and a neat game concept. Plus it's always good to support the independents! After a while I startd to feel like I was at work, but it's a fun game just to experience.

It's kind of surprising how fun this game is, considering the overwhelming feel of misery and oppression the game has. Papers, Please is a game where you play as a border inspector, checking over paperwork, looking for inconsistencies, and making choices that impact many lives, including those of your family.  The gameplay can get intense at times as you hurry to process as many people correctly as possible. Papers, Please had me hooked very quickly, and never let go. I'm planning to continue playing even though I've beaten the story twice, just to get all the endings and maybe try out endless mode. There's not much music, but what's there is great and fits the game incredbily well. The graphics are beautiful. Arstotska is mostly devoid of color, and this game looks as it should. The game controls almost entirely with the mouse, allowing keyboard shortcuts if you have the money to buy them and increase your efficiency.  I picked up Papers, Please at full price, and it was absolutely worth it. This is one of the best indie games I've played, and I think it's absolutely worth $10. I'd recommend it to just about anyone.  Note: the game has a little non-sexual nudity that can be disabled in the options.
This Game is absolutely amazing.
awesomely addictive game. Very happy for the level of entertainment for the price. fully recommended.

Excellent. Gives great insight into life under tyranny, from an unexpected point of view. Even more important are the parallels to the modern day nanny-surveillance states of the West. Being subjugated to intrusive and humiliating airport security theatre, illegal NSA wiretapping, CCTV monitoring, and constant nanny-state intrusion into our daily lives is the antithesis of being free citizens of a free and democratic state.  Papers, Please should be part of the school curriculum, along with lessons about the nature of tyranny.
Ridiculously underated if its on sale definitely buy it has some funny moments.  Glory To Arstotzka

I picked this game up purely because I saw it on several recommended video games you have to play due to its unique setup and game mechanics. The premise is deceptively simple but I was shocked over how stressed I was and how intense the gameplay is. The 8-bit graphics add charm and a dystopian feel that I fear that a full-fledged AAA budget would ruin. The sounds are appropriate, the multiple endings means that I still have plenty to discover, and there's a surprising depth to the relationships one forms through very simple interactions with other characters.   Not a game to play if you're trying to hold a conversation with others or there are distractions nearby. Being a Border Agent is serious business.

Papers, Please. Is a very hard game to talk about. It's literally a paperwork simulator, but it's so oddly engaging.It becomes engaging to a Where's Waldo kind of level when you're trying to compare over 6 different papers to make sure they all match up with each other. Beyond the paperwork, there's such a clever use of narrative without telling that makes this game great. Something I loved was the set up of you having a wife, son, mother in law, and uncle to support. At the end of each day nearly all your money goes to their food and heat, so if you ever want to move up to the upper-class apartments, you've pretty much got no choice but to kill off family members.   This says a lot about who your particular character is. You've got the option to abandon them all and leave the country. You could stick by them and suffer in poverty. What kind of man are you? Who are you?   Is your family more important? Is freedom? Is your country?  Who are you?
'You need to try this game'  It's UNEXPECTABLE !!!  and  Glory to Arstotzka...

A very unique game that is seldom very pleasant or enjoyable (though often satisfying, the way any other soul-crushing job can be), but very immersive and thought-provoking. The consequences of your choices are not as straightforward as in most other games (where 'do the -one right thing- and karma shall reward you' is prevalent). Love it.
Depressing. Unfun. The worst game to play after you finish work. 5 stars.

Love this game! It's stressful and has great music!

I like the game, the concept, the atmosphere, and the art.   I dislike the UI and the artificial slowing you down by giving you a clunky interface. It'd be nice if the upgrades to them were permanent but as it stands you're gonna be annoyed by them half of every game. And the lack of space.  I think it's just the combination of time pressure while being explicitly hampered that lowers the overall experience for me.  Regardless still a thumbs up.

Negative reviews in a nutshell: 'I love the game' 'It's sooo amazing' 'Great game, I just don't think anyone else will like it'  I recommend this game because even the negative reviews are mostly positive 10/10 Negative Reviewers

Papers Please is an interesting concept pulled off in a unique style. Each day truly becomes harder, both to do ypur job right and to be a good person. This game gives a whole new feeling to tedious paperwork and it certainly makes a change of pace from all the hardcore military shooters out there. Don't think, just get this game. Glory to Arstotzka!

Great game, one of the more fun games I have played recently. The simple art style works great and adds to the dark feeling of the game. While the gameplay is pretty simple, it stays interesting by constantly changing and adding rules.  Even though the title screen theme is pretty cool, the game lacks music during the levels. I also found it hard to play for hours on end, it's more of a play for 40 minutes and then do something else kind of game.  Still; 9.5/10
