Excellent. Simple design, deep interesting story and, a interesting take on 'game.'
Cruel heartbreaking adventure game. Patience is necessary: a story told in the deliberate monotony of an unfair job. Do the first two sentence grab you; if so you should avoid or buy immediately.

One of the Best I've played this year, yet so small and simple...  If i had to nitpick I'd say story mode could last a little longer... I'm still missing a bunch of tokens and endings, though. haven't played endless mode yet, either.

GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!  While thematically depressing, Papers, Please is a brilliant little game where you decide who pass the border into your nation's territory.  You need to look for descrepancies and comply with the rulebook that can change from a day to day basis.  Simple in theory, brilliant in execution.
Entertaining and really makes you pay attention. Definitely has replay value.

If a 'Dystopian Document Thriller' sounds like it might be enjoyable to you, it will be. As Yahtzee said, 'this game makes paperwork fun.' You will be engaged not only by the intricate story, but by the tough daily decisions you have to make (which give this game a complex morality system), and even the mundane task of checking documents as quickly as possible for any sort of discrepancy.
Checking passports, is suprisingly addictive, challenging and fun. There's not a single game out there like this one.

This game was a shock to me. It just looked like a boring strat game where you stamp a yes or a no, but it was so much more than that. There were moral deliemas that gets under your skin. A task no video game has done before. It is worth the price, even if it was $50. There is 20 endings to find so the replay value is outstanding.
Fun game, but too simple to play long term, and not worth $10. I would suggest buying for around $2.50 if you are interested.
This is a great game for passing the time. It can be hard at times if you aren't quick and efficient, but it's still really fun. It's worth the $10.

The game itself seems like a very simple 'find the differences' game to start, but it evolves quickly into a game of dexterity and concentration. You realise that you can't always just take your time to get it right and be perfect. You have to process a lot of papers just to keep your family fed and warm, and sometimes you have to sacrifice food, or heat, or that present your kid wants, or medicine. You also realise the while someone has all the right paperwork, you might want to take that hit and warning and deny them. That works the other way where you may let someone in intentionally, take the warning or penalty, but it could be for a good reason or bribe. I've seen 1 ending so far, and there are 20 different endings to this, so the choices you make will mean many different possibilites. I got it for $5 but I would say it is worth the retail $10.

I don't normally play indie games, but Papers, Please is one of those rare titles that everyone should at least try. Set in the fictional communist country of Arstotzka, you take the role of an immigration inspector at a border checkpoint. You must look over documents and use various tools in order to keep spies, smugglers and other unwanted bad people out of the country all while on the clock. On top of this you have to make enough money to support your family and survive yourself. Will you follow the rules or turn to taking bribes to make ends meet? It may sound easy and perhaps even boring, but trust me that once you dive in it is really exciting. Glory to Arstotzka!

Deeply moving.   Getting the negatives out of the way first. The game is a little slow paced though, definitely wish there was a slightly easier difficulty, with shorter day-cycles to give more of an opportunity to enjoy replaying it. People may say 'The game is meant to be slow, it's the whole idea' but there is definitely a feeling of wading through the marshes that are put off by this game.  Now for the positives. This game is an incredibly singular experience, having never seen anything akin to it in any form of media I really did enjoy it. I highly recommend giving this game a go, even if you aren't big on emotional experiences.
Lots of detail, always changing the rules. I found it fun. Lots of different choices can be made that affect the way the game plays through.
It's very interesting game.

This is a game for those seeking a new experience. It is part adventure puzzler part investigation. The website quotes are not kidding, this game will make you think, you have to manage the job, income for your family and the safety of a country.  This game is fantastic.

I'm not going to beat around the bush- this game is perfect. It is without question the best indie game I have ever played. It is worth $10 and then some. If you have a chance to pick this gem up, do so without hesitation.

Papers, Please is more than just stamping passports, it is a cynical examination of life as we know it, where small differences can mean the difference between life and death. While playing, the player faces many choices, tasked with rooting out the small differences in people in order to keep them separate. The player can choose to be the humanitarian, or they can choose to safeguard themselves. In these choices, which seem small at the time, the true message of Papers, Please; emerges. It shows that we are all not so different from one another, though we always exploit those differences.

Very good and thought provoking game if you know how to pay attention. Interesting subtle storyline as well with many different endings based on the choices you make in game. Only annoying thing is the booth upgrades and the sometimes indiscernable hight differences. 9/10  Down with the Commies! Obristan above all!

this gayme aint bad. i stamped books and decided people futures. and i done that for a while and then the game ended. thats just what i done. and i wont argue the fact that that didnt happen or that ytou wont do that

To be honest, I didn't know what to expect when I started playing 'Papers, Please'. Some friends of mine recommended the game highly and as it was on sale, I bought it. Though the concept behind the game is simple, you're a border cop who is to grant or deny access to your country to people based on the papers and other evidence they provide, it can get quite complex.  The first days of the game introduce new concepts at a fast but manageable pace, steadily adding to the complexity of your task. Though the concept may sound boring, it's actually quite entertaining due to the colourful characters that appear at your booth (some are humorous, some address real-life issues like human trafficking), the puzzle work involved, the cheesy coldwar era communist state setting and the 'reward' overview at the end of every day.  I've only played a couple of hours yet, but am really enjoying the game. Only drawback I have identified is that sometimes people with ok documents and motives blow themselves up after I've granted them access to the country. I've 'retried' these people several times and can find nothing wrong. Maybe these are scripted events to increase difficulty? If so, I would have gladly known about it, as I'm currently unsure what I'm doing wrong. Otherwise a very enjoyable experience.

The game is simple: Check people's passports and other papers for irregularities and approve or deny them. The appeal of this game is through the complicated situations it puts you in throughout the storyline. You get more money for letting people through, but any mistakes get you a citation. More people (correctly) through the border means more money.  The fine line between keeping your job intact and watching out for your family makes long runs of this game worth the wait.

So far as I know the only game of it's kind. The art style is beautiful, as is the soundtrack. The gameplay is by no means easy. As soon as you think that you have got the hang of all the little details you must check, another is slammed into your face. Do not think for a second that you can be lazy on the job! The game is pretty unforgiving, if you screw up 3 times in 1 day, a fine is coming your way, making the already very small amount of money you have to take care of your home and family even smaller. The story of the game has multiple endings, based on different choices you make from behind the booth. I won't give anything away, but at one point earlier on in the game you are given a legally questionable choice. It is not until much later in the game that the wrong decision comes back and bites you. You have the ability to go back to any day in all of your playtime which proves very useful for the previously mentioned screw ups.   If you are a fan of indie games, want to hardcore run through a very well developed story, do so. If you just want to chill for a bit, you can do so in the endless mode. I absolutely would recommend this game to anyone.
Addictive!
Unbelievably good game. Way more fun than it may seem. Subtle moral choices, corrupt Soviet government, document inspection. So goo.
Fantastic game!
A wonderfully unique and cathartic experience.

This game is perhaps one of the best I've ever played.  Very simplistic in its graphics and gameplay, Papers Please will take you on a joyride full of moral choices and difficult decisions in the Communist country of Arstotzka.  You play as The Inspector, who was unwillingly chosen to man the border of the newly-opened checkpoint in Grestin, an analog to real-life Berlin. Arstotzka and its neighbor, Kolechia, have just fought a war and, with the peace, the border is now open for Arstotzkans to return to the homeland.  Quickly decisions pile up. You can detain people for more money, which could mean the difference between life and death for your family. You can let in a man's love, who has no papers but her passport.   There will be attacks on the checkpoint, in which you are given a rifle and told to fire at the attackers. All while this happens, you are given critical choices which can decide the fate of the nation of Arstotzka.  There are twenty endings in this game, and each one provides something a little different. But with any ending and any playthrough, the writing is absolutely outstanding. You almost feel sympathy for the people as you hammer down 'DENIED' on their passports. The poignancy of this game is never far from the surface. As a simple cog in a vast machine of corruption and depression, you can change lives for the better, or for the worse.   This game deserves every praise it gets. It deserves nothing less than a 10 out of 10.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Great game hard to truly get into... but you will have fun playing this game no matter what!
It might look simple, but this game is addictive!
Very good game, very good writing. I managed to feel oppressed even after I turned it off.

Get this game! It's premise is really simple, but the choices are very hard. It's a rather calm gameplay with the many stories being told in between. Each person has their own story and you have to be careful about how truthful you want to be or how generous you want to be. Everything has conciquence. Get it, you won't be sorry.

It's an interesting game with a fascinating idea, well-written and immersive, and will really put you in the shoes of a faceless bureaucrat and to empathize with a kind of person you might otherwise never really see from their viewpoint.  That said, expect to put in a bunch of hours into the game if you like it, and then abandon it. It ratchets up complexity in a way that at first makes the game more challenging and immediate, but eventually just becomes frustrating. Also, since the game never lets up, each new day is far more complicated than the one after that, and so a mechanic that lets you put yourself in the shoes of an opressor ends up feeling far more distancing. Acknowledging the joylessness of a totalitarian state still doesn't make the game fun.
I never thought I would enjoy such a game, but I did! Recommended for a few hours of fun!

I have no idea what makes this game so fun. The concept doesn't actually sound that appealing, but you will get so focused and into this game. After playing it, working at airport customs never looked so fun. Definitely worth it.

There is only one bad thing, when you complete the game you cant really do anything for quite a while until you forget that you had the game so it is fun again to complete. If your good it takes about 6 - 8 hours to complete. Still get it though, surprisingly hard.

Excellent story with various endings. Makes you reevaluate your own moral compass and abillity for human compassion. At least I managed to save my wife and niece. 10/10 would stamp passports and detain again.
its a much better game than people give it credit for!
It makes you think, your family? Or theirs?

Papers, Please is perhaps one of the most interesting games I've ever played. It's a totally new slant on the criteria for an addicting game. Who knew that doing actual administrative work would be a catch?  In the game, you are shown to have several family members who need food, heat and also medicine. Your salary is tight and a lot of it is spent on your loved ones. This story is told only by plain text after each day's work and checkboxes that allow you to choose whether or not you want to spend money on heating and/or food for your family. It feels as though this is the aspect of the game that provides you with a motive to keep going. Not only this, but the developer has certainly drawn on our inherent nature to find enjoyment in successfully completing tasks that aren't part of our normal lives as they are too difficult or too time-consuming. There is an added frustration aspect when you fail to notice a discrepancy in the documents, which makes getting it right all the more sweeter, just like on a racing game where NOT crashing feels somehow incredibly fulfilling. It is the same case for Papers, Please.   It feels like you build your own strategy on how to complete the game successfully, which is one vital factor that the majority of popular games use to draw you in; building your own strategy and skill grants you more success than others. It’s a single player game but with its timed work clock, it makes it feel like a competitive bubble, where you’re fighting through countless immigrants to feed your family. (Yikes, I wonder how many I can process today!)  The only negative to the game is that due to the fact the game provides you with opportunities to make your own decisions on who to accept, who to help and who to deny means that there are 20 different endings to the game. Sadly, basically all but the last couple of endings warrant a failure of the game. Your inspectors will pull you up on mistakes you make and you will find yourself being quickly arrested if you’ve accidentally ♥♥♥♥ed up somewhere. I’ve played for hours and I keep getting arrested for mistakes I didn’t even know I’d made, I’ve got ending 17 so far. Although the game lets you retrace your steps and choose a workday to restart from, it means that you’re never really sure where to restart from if you mess up. The game only gives you a reason for failure, and you do not get fired for your mistakes until inspection days and official assessments; you don’t know where you messed up so you can’t know which day to go back to. This ultimately ends with giving up. If the developers simply had an indicator of which point you made the mistake, it would be far more appealing to continue playing again, even from an earlier point. Overall, highly addicting game, especially if you don’t make any mistakes. Otherwise, can be frustrating but generally a good gaming experience. You won’t regret buying it, and yes, for once, this game is worth the full price.

I really liked this game, it's really interesting and has a lot o replay ability, and even when you've finished the game with every possible ending, you can always play free mode. Also, the game becomes even more interesting with secret organisations and terrorist attacks. You can also choose what to do with your money at the end of each day, witch is really cool. That why my final rating for this game is 8/10!!!! BUY IT!!!!!

Great game! It's not really a game, it's art, it has a message, it makes you think, It's an eastern bloc country, with a Berlin Wall style border.

I just bought this so I'm not an expert, but I really like it so far. Yes my whole family except for my uncle is dead but still its actually pretty fun to deny people entrance to a country. If it needed a sequal I would expect it to be a DMV simulator.

I've only played for roughly 40 minutes as I write this, but I can safely say that this is one of the most immersive and depressing gaming experiences I have ever had.  You rapidly find yourself pouring over documents and the rulebook, trying to find the lie. Even when there isn't one.  I thought I could get away with not feeding and heating my family for one night. My son became sick. Now, the rent rises. I never imagined that a game so simple in it's appearance and premise could provide this kind of emotional depth.
I never wanted more to become a border guardsmen in a soviet era eastern european country before playing this game.

I think Papers, Please, is a game that really needs to be played by everyone in a privaleged country, who hasn't lived in a totalitarian regime. It'll make you really appreciate what you have, if you're lucky like I, and perhaps open your eyes to how bad it can be for everyone else.  It's also a wonderful example of why, and how, horrible systems such as the German Nazi Party can come into power and stay in power. Why people go along with it. Why does the passport officer not rebel? This game will not simply tell you why; in this game, you will experience a shadow of the depressing weight of why.

on the top the game looks borring. it is not, the game is made to test your atention to detail and is actually very fun. you need to find errors in passports, vesas, IDs, and diplomat documents. the longer you go the harder it gets. its difficult to explain, but i if this game is on sale i deficanitly recoment it
super fun. enjoyed it much more so far than i would have thought.

10/10 would deny Jorji again

absolutely, it's cheap, it's great, it's grim and it's evil, and above its genius! Never have i been so happy to go to my work! Glory to Arstotzka!!  Simple, just check passports, visas, working permits and the right nationality and all the discretions and lie's the citizens bring to the border.   You feel like a member of the stalingrad regime as your wife and children starve and you are unable to pay for the heat...while your father is ill and you need to pay for medicine. Suddenly the choice of letting people through the border gets you to the next day... will you let them pass so you earn some more or will you do the right thing and get them arrested.  Either way the game has 20 different ways of ending. i've seen 4 endings now.  Glory to Arstotzka!! 11/10

Its a really good game once you become good at it, your first and second playthrough will probbably be really short. But once you get it its an interesting and complex game. I would recommend it to anyone who is patient and not a blunt, trigger happy cod fanboy.

Ok. Quick review this time. Papers, Please has a very basic story. You are forced to take up the job of being the man who decides if you should cross the border. You have to check people's I.D.'s and your government keeps adding new things that you have to check. I played for an entire hour, sometimes even saying,'No sir, this passport is expired,' without realizing that I was not even paying attention to any other thing but the game. To me, it was super ingaging, and well worth the money. I got the game while it was on sale for 75% off, but even if it isn't on sale, you should still get it. My score for this game is a 7/10.

Years ago I was flipping through TV channels and saw that Phone Booth was on. I was curious how a movie confined to more or less a single locale could be interesting. I didn't see it in theaters because I wasn't convinced, but watching it on TV was ultimately worth it. A decade later I saw pixel art style game advertised as a border crossing / document verification simulator. I'd like to say that my biases about judging a book by a cover had been eliminated, but let's be real, they haven't. There are and will continue to be plenty of pixel-art games worth the price of admission, but the subject matter of Papers, Please wasn't immediately exciting.  Papers, Please is as cathartic as it is tense and addicting. Specific elements of the game become almost Pavlovian, and the presentation immediately puts you in the inspectors shoes. It didn't feel like a far-fetched scenario from the stories that I've heard, but it was an immediate experience that always returns instantly whenever the game begins. From the soundtrack to the excellently implemented sound effects.  This game is incomparable. Like a...

I cannot describe this game. If I do, no way you will play it. Take my word for it, just buy this thing.  Be part of the system. You are nothing. Do your job, do what you're asked.   Papers, please.  *stamp*  NEXT.

GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA! Ahem. This game will take you into the darkness behind that cheerful slogan. Just remember to check your rulebook often, try to do some good where you can, and 'cause no trouble'...unless that's your thing.

Papers Please was a highly immersive, beautifuly executed game that conveyed a dreary feeling of hopelessnes. In my review below, I break down the game into categories and analyze it thoroughly.  STORY (Spoiler-free): In 'Papers, Please,' you play as an unnamed border processing guard in the distopian country of Arstotzka, and it focuses on bureaucratic efficiency. I personally loved its story telling and thematic choice system. The entire game presents you with mind-racking choices that have to be made throughout gameplay, but the primary dilema focuses on whether or not you will care about others and their woes, or only look out for you and yours. For example, on one occasion you have the option to wave the rules to reunite a pair of lovers (one of whom has invalid paperwork) but doing so will give you a citation, and can potentially cost you crucial money to keep your family happy & healthy. Choices like these kept the tension high, and present the player with a moral conundrum. Many of the choices you make throughout the game influence the ending in a huge way, with most of the endings differing in content drastically. This highly increases the replayabilty of the game, as you'll want to experience all of the different endings. Overall, the story was well done, oozing with atmosphere, and I give it a 9/10  GAMEPLAY: The Gameplay of 'Papers, Please,' is simplistic, but effective. This is a stress management game, as the goal is to process as many people as possible in the time allotted. As a game should, the gameplay becomes steadily more complex as more layers of paperwork are added for you to check. It starts simple, only having the player check the person's passport, but gets progressively harder as you begin to start checking work permits, discrepancies in various papers, etc. Although the gameplay can become repetitive as time goes on, the new layers added on help to prevent total stagnation. It may nopt be to everyone's liking, but I found it effective and fitting. All-in-all, the gameplay gets a 7/10 from me.  ART & MUSIC STYLE: The graphics in 'Papers, Please,' are simplistic and old-school. It has an almost SNES style of graphics, and it looks pleasing to the eye. The art style conveys the bleak, distopian feeling of the game witha heavy gray color palette, and it adds a fitting atmosphere to the game, as it takes place in a circa 1980 distopian, communist, Eastern European country. Although I can see how the art may not be for everyone, so look at the scfreenshots for exampes of the graphics that are to be expected in the game. The music in the game is low, dark, but paired with a slowly increasing melody of some kind of stringed instrument. It sounds very Eastern European, almost Russian, and is paired well with the setting. When both of these are combined, it paints a picture that fits well with the story, and builds a strong atmosphere. The Art & Music gets an 8/10.  CONCLUSION: 'Papers, Please,' is a well done game, and I applaud the creator for doing such a fantastic job. Even though the gameplay is simplistic, the tension is high and the feel of the game is complementary to the setting. The experience that I had while playing this game was one of intrigue, nail-biting intensity, and mind-breaking dilemas. It's not for everyone, and I think it's best suited to a more story-driven gamer, (as the gameplay consists of little fighting and is mainy reading and the occasional button press) If you enjoy a fun experience that is story driven, unique, and dripping with atmosphere, 'Papers, Please,' is for you. 'Papers, Please,' was a gem that should not be passed up on, as most the gameplay sucks you in and addicts you, and this was one of the best games I've played in a while; so for that reason, my 'Papers, Please' overall rating is a 9/10, and I highly recommend it to people who enjoy thought-provoking games, as this is a thinking man's game.  Thanks to anyone who read this, it took a while, and I hope you enjoyed my analysis of the game.

The premise of this game seems incredibly simple, and doesn't sound like something that could be fun (unless you adore paperwork), but with actually fun gameplay, interesting scenarios that pop up from time to time, and complications that make the gameplay just challenging enough, this is a fantastic game. Don't go in expecting incredible graphics, but a couple hours of fun, oddly difficult decision making, and smart gameplay mechanics.  Also, there are 20 different endings, so it's absolutely replayable. I'm not somebody who particularly enjoys replaying games immediately after finishing them, but I found myself playing days over to see another ending, without ever feeling like it was a chore.  Overall, a brilliant game that had me hooked almost instantly. Glory to Arstotzka!

Manning a checkpoint and stamping visas may not sound like gripping gameplay but Papers, Please somehow manages it. With your family on the brink of starvation, political trouble brewing and a cast of characters whose lives you briefly glimpse (and possibly permanently alter) the impetus to be alert and make the right choices is very strong. It's a very hard game to put down.  The graphics may seem basic but they serve the dual purposes of paring back extraneous detail to help you concentrate while simultaneously reinforcing the dreary Cold-War era atmosphere. The moral quandaries you frequently find yourself in (you can barely go a day without being offered multiple bribes for a start) don't usually have clear right or wrong answers. Indeed, whenever I lost (often) I didn't get the impression it was because of any moral failings on my part, just making choices (or mistakes) with harsh consequences.  On the subject of losing, this game has one of the best save systems I've seen. It saves at the end of each day so that you can go back and restart from any day of any playthrough you like. You can go back and fix a mistake you realised from two days ago, or try something different or whatever you like and it displays it all in a way that is easy to navigate.  I'll finish by saying that this game might not be for everyone but I have personally loved it. If the idea of a game that's a bit different, that will make you think, that can actually draw you into the life of a poor worker stuck between a rock and a hard place, this is definitely worth a try. It won't break the bank and it will definitely leave you with an impression.

6/10  Frustrating, but with redeeming qualities.  Papers, Please is not a fun game... You are a immigration inspector on the boarder of a fictional eastern European country. You have to check the papers of people getting into the country, and must follow the rules dictated by your superiours. If you don't, you will be fined. There are opportunities to break the rules to help people and sometimes, you may feel like you should take a fine to allow them to pass. At the end of the day, you have to support your family by paying your rent, paying for medicine, food, whatever it takes to survive which you can barely do.  The gameplay is hard and it's easy to overlook something and make a mistake. You have a very limited time to check people in each day and you are payed by how many you check in. There are many different endings, and your choices matter drastically. The endings are basically just a few lines of text though.  I think playing this game gives a unique experience, but not a fun one.

It's funny--in the age of ultra-realistic graphics and sprawling even-the-kitchen-seek AAA titles, the games I remember most are often the games where I can do the least.  Here, you see people at a checkpoint, then try to keep your family fed and warm at home. People might invite you to post-workplace events ranging from the sordid to the friendly, but you don't go there. They might claim to have interesting lives, but you don't know for sure if you're lying. All you know is the documents they have, the stories they tell, and the regulations that dominate everyone's lives.  Strangely enough, I found myself loving this game's side characters, precisely because I had to imagine their lives, and also because their lives are so obviously more interesting than the task of comparing yet another passport number to yet another government-issued ID.   This isn't the most fun of gameplay (though, despite its similarities to a rather sub-par desk job, the gameplay is strangely hypnotic and relaxing.) But it's a fascinating narrative exercise, and experiment in empathy.  I got to the end of the game once after a few hours of gameplay, and I may not re-play it. But I also can't imagine forgetting it. This is an interesting little restrained story of the game.

Papers, Please is a interestingly fun game to play. When I first seen this game, my initial thoughts was that it would be boring but how wrong I was. You take on the role of an immigration inspector that controls the flow of people entering. Among the many people entering, looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists are rampant. Taking a look at the provided documents by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested. It takes time to look through the documents and then cross checking them with the book and instructions you have been give to decide if you will approve them passing or not. A really different and interesting take on something for a game. Brillient game to play and have fun with.

While my first impressions was that the game was a little underwhelming, as I progressed through my first run I realised the many intricacies of this game and some of the subtle objectives that keep you going for just one more day.

Pros: +Suprisingly addicting gameplay, conisidering that you feel like you're at a day job +Sufficiently intiguing story +Twenty storyline 'outcomes' dictated by player decisions  +Amazing auto-save system. At any point in the story, you can go back and restart from any previous level WITHOUT saving over the original playthrough's saves, essentially creating an alternate save 'branch'. Once you see the save menu, you'll wonder why it's not the standard for all games. Makes achievement hunting a breeze.   Cons: -Low replay value. -No music variety. The songs works, but by the end it got annoying. -Player controls are unlocked like character abilities. For example, at the beginning of the story, the approve/deny stamp is brought out by clicking a small tab at the side of the screen; later on, you buy the 'desk upgrade' that allows you to open the stamp with a keyboard button (a much more convenient and logical control for the most used function in the game). This makes a second playthrough quite annoying, since your muscle memory adapts to the button controls. Seems like a gimic that should've been scraped in testing.   Oddly, I felt that it was too long. The idea works, but 'checking passports and ID's for consistency' is simply too repetetive of a task for a 5-6 hour playthrough. I just think it might've been cleaner if it were shorter. By mid-to-late game, I stopped having any fun and only played through it because I felt invested in the story. Still a thumbs up for a unique and well-executed indie title. At $5, go for it.

Papers Please, a very grim and sad game. Let me just tell you this right now: Buy it.  Now that that's been said, allow me to explain a bit about the game itself without spoiling it.  You're a border inspector for cold war, communist, Russia-esque country. There's not much gameplay in the game itself except for stamping passports, which you're probably thinking to yourself now 'Why should I buy a game about stmaping passports?'. Because, at the same time while you stamp passports, you're attempting to maintain your family, giving them food, paying heat, paying off rent. So, you essentially have your sob story. HOWEVER, while you're stamping passports you'll have people without some of their documents and they'll tell you their sob story. They'll either attempt to bribe you so they can go through or just hope that you'll be a saint. So you're juggling around whether you can't afford the tickets for your bills or maybe you'll help this guy. But it only gets worse. You have to do this difficult decisions under time. All the while terrorists are invading you borders, independence factions, smugglers, drug dealers, etc.  There's a LOT more to this game, but unfortunately I don't want to spoil it. Anyway, good game is good, so good that it's on my top 10 list for 2013, so you should buy it.

It's really hard to convey with words what makes this game interesting. On the surface, this game feels exactly as if you were doing real life work:  - You get a job.  - You are assigned your tasks.  - They feel like a chore.  - You screw up - You get reprimanded - Your responsibilities grow, while your salary stays the same  However, throw in the realities of having a 6 member family to provide for, and it starts getting complicated. Fail to bring home enough money and some family members may have to starve, or freeze. If one of them is sick, you may have to choose between medicine, food, or heating. Will you take bribes then to offset these costs? Will you cooperate with terrorists to get a pay cut? Will you try to get through that gate as many people as you can, since you get paid by the person?   At first it's really easy to make these desicions since you have no sense of what's really going on. After the first few hours go by, and you're grinding along day after day, you start to feel more like playing the character. You start to feel compassion for some of the pixelated people that desperately beg for entry. You start to make judgement calls based on how your family is doing. The game begins to develop into an extremely interesting experience where you're constantly being morally tested.  The game has about 20 or 30-something outcomes (can't remember off the top of my head). So far I've managed to see about 9 of them. Every time I finish I'm finding new paths and possibilities to explore in order to see where the story goes. This is one of the 10 best experiences I've had with video games this year, and I wholeheartedly recommend you give this one a chance.

Have you ever wondered what it must feel like to have people curse you out, attempt to coerce you, bribe you and threaten you, then go home to your shoddy apartment only to find that you didn't make enough money to feed your family, or buy the medicine your child so desperately needs?   WELL THEN YOU'RE IN LUCK!!!!  This game is a true exploration of what a video game can achieve. Video games aren't all about fantasy, war, dragons, magic and monsters. Papers, Please proves that this medium is limitless. In Papers, Please, you are put in the shoes of a border control agent in the fictional soviet country of Arstotzka, where you are charged with either allowing or denying access of your great country to foreigners and citizens alike, based on an ever-shifting policy handed down to you each morning. You must check backgrounds, passoports, work visas, and make sure everything matches up. But be quick, because you only have so many hours a day and you get paid per customer, and if you try to rush it, you might mess up and cause the poor woman who came through before to be murdered by the man you should have just denied access...  You get the point. This game is an amazing study of the human condition and a harrowing insight to one poor man's life in Arstotzka.

I can definitely recommend this game as a decently challenging indie title.

Entertaining, as it is. As you progress even further, you may have to examine an endless avalanche of government-issued documents before you stamp the passport, even if we get careless because of the discrepancies we have to examine, and risk being fined 5 credits for a simple yet serious mistake.  For the game's theme, it's a reminescent of the latter cold war years, such as the Divided Germany up until 1989 and its reunification the following year (Sorry, Korea won't count at all). The whole of the Soviet Union under the toughest of entry conditions before the crumbledown on Christmas 1991, in which the key countries: Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, and the Baltic States of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, have eased a bit on the entry restrictions. Talk about present-day USA, more than 76% of individuals entered the country legally without even caring that they're classified as terrorists, while the rest of us, law-abiding people, are flagged as terrorists for no reason, even we can't leave the country (Less than .0015% chance on having our exit visas issued)  Even it gives me emotions on an old lady trying to desperately see her own son after six suffering years, and have to deny entry because she doesn't have the documents, or the one she has are purely invalid, but this is the checkpoint officer's duty, nothing else.  The BGM there, yep, that was the remains of Soviet Russia. Graphics? 8-bit creativity in the modern age, and whoever complains about 8-bit creativity in the present day then that's their problem.   So if you're looking for the most entertaining, keeping you hours glued to this seat, and to relax yourself after a tediously long session, then this one's for you!

This is a game like no other. Experience the always exciting world of paperwork. Your job ,working the border, to make sure everyone has their passports and the rest of their paperwork completely perfect so they are allowed in your country. This is simple at first but everyday your government increases the rules such as tickets or people from certain countries not allowed in. You have to work as fast and accurate as possible so your family can live while also thinking about every life that you hold in your hands for each person that you disapprove potentially is a life you destroyed. It is a game that firmly grasps 1 of the best advantages video game has as a medium and that is choice. Some people are desparate to enter the country and you have the choice to shun them since the paperwork was not properly set or accept them at the cost of your money which could leave your family starving. A game about filing papers has had a more emotional impact on me then any Triple A title out there.
Perfect.
Absolute fun. So much different than any other game I have played. The game is so simplistic, yet the story gets complex the more you play

I really don't know if I should recommend this game.  It is a perfect representation of how the immigrations of any country feels like; dry and boring. Yet, this game poses to you moral issues that test your moral values, and at the same time your integrity. It makes you reflect that you actually have the power to define their destiny. What happens to their lives as they leave your little workspace is ultimately determined by your decision.   Do you deny entry to a person whose relative you just approved because of a one-month expired passport? Do you help a refugee who is to be excuted in their home country, but has no valid visa? Do you detain a person who claims they changed their name but is not reflected in your country's records? How about that repeat offender who keeps coming to you with drugs on him? Do you let him go after the third time, or detain him?    I swear I didn't blink for 20 minutes straight at one point, making sure details were correct before giving my verdict. If you like games that challenge you to stay focused/awake and check for discrepancies, this game is perfect for you. Forget 'spot-the-difference' picture games, this will make you feel more accomplished than ever.  Overall, 6.5/10. Get it on a sale.
Very good. A brilliant game with a great storyline. Cannot flaw it in any way, it is genuinely a masterpiece!

This game is way more intense and serious than any pixellated game I've ever played. You're forced to make some possibly life-threatening and heart-wrenching decisions, all while trying to keep your family alive working at your awful job. Played a demo of it once upon a time, and couldn't wait for the full story. Prepare to have your patience and morals tested.  Glory to Arstotzka.

An oddly entertaining game that is both semi-morbid and insightful, showing the bleak nature of human lives. I would say give it a try before you quit the game because of its graphics. This game gives you choices...whether you choose to be a drone and serve a country blindly OR make your own choices and affect the lives of the characters. The philosophy behind this game is both haunting and fascinating.  I would recommend this game to any of my friends.
Bought it during Sale and it's worth every Cent. Love it.
Played for about two hours which flew by in the blink of an eye. Harder than it looks. Let in a terrorist and also my baby died whoops. Simple, difficult, great.
A new experience. Fun and quite the brain tickler.

Easy to learn, diffcult to master. Who would have thought that a game about an anonymous immigration officer would be so enthralling? Excellent execution of the concept and a masterful realisation makes this game a must everyone who loves indie games, and to anyone who like me loves old school point and click adventures...
all i can say with out ruining it is that i love the game you have to find out why for your self to injoy it to the fullest!

This brings the tedious nature of working in a cold bureaucracy to your pc ... that you could never afford working in an environment like this!   It is great fun though, and I recommend this to anyone that likes to play innovative games.
Excellent game, who would have thought stamping passports would be fun, chilling and thought provoking all at once.
It seems pretty simple at first but gets more complicated as you go. The music is top notch and its amazingly fun and addicting.
Great humor, well designed, very addicting - will keep you on your toes

This game does a great job of making you feel like your in the worst job ever. I was working over the summer when I started playing this and I every time I played my job seemed ten times better in comparison. It gave such a strong feeling of dread that I don't get in other games I play and I loved it. The only thing that I believe could be added is the ability to see you're family at the end of each day; this would've to me add more the overall feeling of despair that the game gives.

I was a little sad and happy when I beat the game and got ending 20. I was happy because I got through all of the frustration the game might've caused me whenever I received a citation. And I was a sad because this beautifully crafted story had come to an end.  Glory To Arstotzka

Not a game for everyone, but this game does incredible credit to story-telling in video games. Worth every penny.  Especially enjoyable if you have OCD~
The most fun I've ever had doing some of the most mundane tasks I've ever done.

Very original Game. Yes you need it, simply because it's such a unique thing, but not for 10 bucks. I've spent approximately 20 hours with it - and that includes time spent replaying the game. I may get back at it one day.  Now that we got that out of the way - the Review.   STORY: So you are an immigration inspector at the border of an exagerated communistic nation. Maybe it isn't even THAT exagerated, but the situations posed and the narration make for a deeply comical - but critical - atmosphere. There is a lot of Orwell's '1984' in this game (yea like EVERYBODY talking about that nowadays... OBEY!... but it really fits! *ducks*).  GRAPHICS: The graphics are retro-simplistic but good. I like the graphics, they get the job done.  GAMEPLAY: Now this is where Papers Please defines itself - well apart from the bizarre scenario it imposes upon you. You have to grant people access to your country - or deny them - based on the correctness of the formulae and documents they present to you. You need to check if their Birthdate, Gender and Photograph match and make sense - and the further you progress - the more things need checking. For example after a certain day all immigrating workers also need a working permit, and the game expands upon this more and more the further you go.  If you make a correct decision, you earn money. If you make too many incorrect decisions - you have to pay a fine. Simple as that.  Paper checking is done by dragging and dropping the documents on your tiny desk (you well need to do A LOT of paperwork readjustments on your tiny wooden table in the late game) and comparing the given documents to the 'Rules and Regulations'. If there are inconsistencies, you need to highlight a the incorrect thing in the passport (or any given document) and the corresponding rule that states that it is incorrect. Simple as that, but it sounds utterly confusing in text. After you have done this - the passport needs to be stamped with either 'Access Granted' or 'Denied'.  Basically it's like a paperwork simulator!  Based on your successes at the job, you then need to make sure you can pay for your family's nourishment and the heat in your apartment. So if you have a bad day - they might just starve to death and you are game over. And just to screw you up, occasionally it turns out you need to feed your sick uncle and mother or whathaveyou.  STORY2: Now i know, i have already talked about the story, but this game's gameplay is like its story that's why i pick it up again. It's an odd interweaving of events that make your decisions of letting people through - or not - matter. Basically every immigrant has something unique to say (the writing is excellent btw), but some of them are even more unique and the plot is dictated by whether or not you let them through. But there is no indication that this is the case, which is what makes this game so awesome in the first playthrough. You have this really weird feeling sometimes that the games got you by the balls, and you have this strange fear of screwing up. It must be the weirdest thing i have played and there is nothing i can really compare it to - but it has this really deep atmosphere, like in Gothic 1 - the first time you played it 15 years ago. That's as accurate as i can get, and i know comparing it to a 3D open world RPG from 200X must seem ridiculous, but that might just prove how crazy this game is.  AUDIO: Super crisp paper sounds. I mean seriously. Stamping a document in this game is as satisfying as firing a gun in an immersive fps! So odd...  Now i know this review might not manage to sum up the game in it's entirety - but due to the fact that it is very story reliant, i would probably start spoiling the fun if i wrote more. Just get it and be surprised by it.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

Basically a lot of ♥♥♥♥ Hannah Arendt said about totalitarian regimes persisting by normalizing their totalitarian policies in the eyes of their constituents: the videogame. Play it if you want to experience the banality of evil firsthand, or if you just like stamping stuff.

I love Papers, Please. It keeps you playing because of the feel that you have to provide money for food, rent, and others. You basically look at peoples passports and accept them into the country or not. Almost everyday you get a strange visitor that comes to your office. And if your family all dies you lose. its pretty fun

Amazing game! Glory to Arstotzka!
9.6/10, please. Good game.
Very, very oddly addictive. The whole art style of this game makes it even harder to play than it would be otherwise, but somehow even that ties into the game's theme.

This is the most jarring and stressful paperwork/bureaucracy simulator in the games industry, but it still manages to be fun and tense. It has a very good story, interesting characters, and great replayability.   My issues with it are nearly non-existent, the stamping method irritates me, I'd prefer seperate stamps, and my other, much larger issue is the fact that the 'invisible' checkpoint immediately after yours ALWAYS notices discrepencies.These are relatively small compared to my overall love of the game. Get it.   9.7/10

'Glory to Arstotzka' Papers, Please is a true gem of an Indie title. With It's minimalist graphics and dreary color pallete, the feeling of an iron curtain border checkpoint is conveyed without equal. The game mechanics start out simple, with you only needing to examine one or two pieces of information, but by the end, you will need to be on the tips of your toes, scanning many documents for discrepencies in a matter of seconds. The game has 20 different endings, but only 3 or so of them are actually different. You have the option of doing your job without question, supporting the insurgent group trying to bring down the government, or fleeing the country. All of these different endings have fun twists to them, and are all worth trying to get. If you are looking for a fantastic game, this is it.
Beuracracy at its finest, 10/10
Totally unrealistic. No way is it this much fun to be a border agent. Or is it?

A work of storytelling genius, with gameplay that offers insights into some of the world's less desirable jobs, and less desirable places. This game is difficult in many ways, not least because it encourages you to think about real issues and real poeple.

A great indie game, well worth the price. I played through a couple of possible endings and had fun trying different options - eventually this gets a bit boring and unless you like to hunt achievements, the game becomes repetitive. Still, the concept is very original and the gameplay really makes you feel like you're working at a border checkpoint! There are a lot of funny moments and tough decisions to be enjoyed, which makes me recommend 'Papers, Please'

This is an interesting game and surprissingly fun, you take a look at paper work and see if it is right or not with an interesting story line in this dystopian world, you get a chance to hone some of your skills, there really isn't too much to say about this game and really you need to look at videos to see if this is for you(or try it out somehow)
I had to accept the bribe because of a freeloader (aka uncle). I got arrested and got thrown in jail.  10/10

Papers, Please stands out from the rest for being unique. You are an immigrant inspector, from a country that is reminiscent of East Germany during the Cold War.    The game requires you to be very attentive as you need to make sure that all the documents are in order. You also need to make personal decisions on whether to let people in despite the fact they lack the required documents, but are facing persecution or are part of a group trying to make a revolution in Arstotzka, among others.    The retro graphics and colors suit the game perfectly as it tries to portray a very depressing setting. A game that actually makes you think about society!
Great game, and interesting story line, overall its a good game.
Who thought that checking documents could be fun? Highly recommended, especially to people living in former communist block countries.
A really great game! A lot of fun
You ask for papers and deny people entry to your amazing country
With music at the beginning this amazing, it doesn't matter if the games good       glory to cobrastan
It is a great game, it has a bit of a learning curve. Still a truly great game, one for the ages.

A masterpiece in recreating the modern mundaity of work and its dehumanising effects on us in a modern era of targeted workflows and admin jobs. It managed to make me think about what a game can be, what my attitude towards my working life is and the hierarchies of families. The truly incredible thing is it achieved all this while still somehow managing to deliver a game experience that was still a game and most importantly, fun to play.
Surprisingly good. Basic gameplay mechanics yet very appealing.

Never did I think that a game with graphics that make MS-DOS games feel groundbreaking, a repeditive gameplaym barely any sound mentionable, shallow story and few objectives could be so good, This game really show that the sum is greater than it's parts. I don't know what is with this game but it is magical.  Basically the game is about you being a border guard checking papers at a border between two fictional nations. It all gives the impression being in some sort of eastern-European state during behind the iron curtain during the Soviet era. Your task is to either admit och reject those who seek to enter based on the papers provided and the requirements set by your superiors. You simply scan these papers for faults. You have to do this fast enough to feed your poor family as the time is limited and you are paid per person reviewed. All errors lead to a salary reduction. Sometimes you stand between wrong admitting a person who just wish to be with its beloved, sometimes to accept bribes and sometimes you choose between aiding a terrorist organisation or fact the consequenses of not doing so.  I suppose it is all the context of the game that makes the magic. You strangely enough get sucked into it.
Is good game. Is best game. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
Wow and game that really makes you work to move ahead. Not only are there many possible endings and ways the story can go, it also is a great re-play game value. So recommend this game. 9/10

working as bank teller irl, this game is strangely compelling and feels all too familar to me.   while years of abuse from customers working in banks and retail has made me numb to the moral dilemmas that you face in the game, I can appreciate the game's attempts to pull at my heartstrings and morals as they throw all of the 'immigration' cliches at me: -Let a terrorist in, or, apprehend a terrorist at the gate while yelling ALL GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA -Wrongly accuse someone of being the wrong gender -Seperate man and wife at the gate.  -Get irritated with the crazy old man who comes everyday with the wrong paper work -prevent the plot of Liam Neeson's 'Taken'   the only real problem I have with the game is pacing. After like 30-40 people in a row, I'd like to think most normal people get nauseous or bored. The fact that there is 20 different endings based on how you play and who you let in greatly extends the replay value if you can physically and mentally will yourself to play the game more than 2 or 3 times all the way through. And there's even a endless mode for the most mentally depraved of us out there  I can definitely recommend the game if you can pick it up for cheap in a Steam sale. Maybe try the game first before paying full price if you're not quite sure it's your thing
Remember those HIghlights Hidden Pictures? This is almost exactly like those except missing objects can result in your family not getting fed.
This game makes me stress out. So much work to, so little time.
Simple, Clever and a hell of a lot of fun! Everyone should own this game.
THIS GAME IS GREAT! It's such a simple but addictive game! Plus the 20 different endings makes it easy to stay involved with it.
My entire family is dead. 10/10.
If you enjoy 'Spot the Differences' then this game is for you.

This game is definitely interesting, not something you really see or think about. I can only imagine that this is what it's like to be a European customs officer, but there is so much more to it than that (terrorist bombers, secret societies, spies.) I'm definitely intrigued by it, and the salary menu at the end of each level kinda terrifies me. Pretty much, if you don't make enough to support your family they'll get cold/sick/hungry and will die. Sure, this is a worry people have in real life, but a digital family that has no names or faces, just 'Son' and 'Wife,' is a little unnerving. Overall, if you want an experience, especially to help you identify with the stress of customs officers like the TSA, pick this up. $9.99 isn't too bad, and I really do find this game to be enjoyable, especially because it makes me think.

I recommend this game to those who have too much time and not enough entertainment. It achieves its goal of creating a seemingly boring game, with a very intricate story mode, and endless mode. All in all, 10/10
More fun than I thought it was going to be
Really addictive. Difficulty increases as the rules change,forgery of documents look pretty legit and on top of that, making sure you have enough money to keep your family alive.

First of all, please don't judge this game without playing it. Although it looks like this game is all about paperwork, it's more than that. There are so many different outcomes that can happen based on your decisions.Tthe game is too addicting. If you're still wondering if you should play the game or not, at least try the free demo you can download on the papersplease website!

Very interesting. Sort of a memory game/job simulator. Be quick or your family dies of starvation...be too quick and you'll make mistakes that will cost you. Accepted bribes, let family members of coworkers and friends through, harrassed other. Overall a 9/10.
I really enjoy this game. Certainly off the 'beaten path' of game styles, and that's quite nice.

I was curious after hearing about this game as to how being a passport officer could be 'fun'. It is though, impossible to explain to other people, yes but really involving with a lot of heart and humour scattered throughout. Buy it, buy it now!

Proof that you can achieve a lot with a little. Compelling story backed up by surprisingly addictive and engaging gameplay, considering you're basically just doing data validation. Maybe the DWP should take advantage of gamers as a potential source of free labour? Maybe I should keep quiet in case they get any ideas...?
Excellent game, very clever.

Gameplay - this game make you prevail in working for mother Russia or you will die. Love the gameplay, simple, frustrating and fun. Controls - no remarks on this. It just works. Graphics - I think that the bit graphic makes this game justice as modern graphics would leave you with the presumption that there would be more to the game than it it. Music - One of the things I like the most with this game. Got me hooked instantly, I'm all set to serve the motherland. Score of 9/10.

I love this game because it's an experience unlike anything I've ever played before. As someone has said before, by explaining the brass tacks of this game it can sound very boring -- but there's just something about it that keeps me coming back. Maybe it's the story that seeps through reading between the lines. Maybe it's the immersive atmosphere that forces the player to make tough (very tough in some circumstances) decisions for the sake of your job, your family, and your country. Despite the vintage graphics and simple set up, 'Papers, Please' manages to string together catchy gameplay with a surpisingly deep story. 10/10.

This is a fun game, but there are some flaws that I feel are often swept under the rug because of the game's admirable, but indie status. The game makes you believe that this is a game that will revolve around choice. The truth is, it's quite the opposite. Much like the strong communistic element present in this game, the choices in this game come sparingly, and the consequences are almost always fatal. This game is more akin to a platformer in that there are a few but very linear paths you can take to reach the 'end.' Stray from that, and the game is absolute. This isnt always bad, but nearly is always punishing. Its a fun game, but I found it greatly overhyped, and equal parts fun and frustrating.

Ive been playing this game for a while, and boy is it fun. I would have never thought a game about border patrol checkpoint would be so fun. It gets a bit tougher as you keep going, you get confident and thats when you slip up. The look of this game is great, I cant wait for a sequel or an update. I highly reccomend this game.

It is a great game. I needs you to be smart and check every single detail under presure. It is a lot of fun and as you advance in the game it gets more complex as you go along, for example there is passport fogrey and more. I recommend this game to anybody who is interested in this kind of stuff.
A very innovative puzzel game. I was surprised at how much fun I had.
Incredibly hard and well made! The replay value is almost infinite and the storyline so vivid!

This game is hard. And it's brutal. However it's not brutal like I wanna Be the Guy is. NO, playing Papers, Please requires mental fortitude. The constant pressure to perform, to perform correctly, and to perform quickly is almost too much at times. The added moral pressure of whether or not to let in the young couple without documents who will surely be killed without an approved visa notwithstanding. This game will have you tearing your hair out in locks.   Thing is though, Papers, Please isn't about having fun. The game is about winning. It's about beating the corrupt Arstotzkan government, with small victories like being able to pay your rent, or full blown revolution. It's about the small satisfaction of catching the tiniest discrepancy in four pages of documents.   This game is amazing, totally original, and immensely challenging. But every victroy, no matter how insignificant, feels huge and important. Papers, Please is a fantastic game at regular price, and a must play on sale.    Glory to Arstotzka
Crushed the hopes and dreams of hundreds of third world refugees. Would recommend.
I don't know that I recommend this as a game as much as I recommend it as a spot-the-difference, thought process puzzle/exercise.

It's entertaining to investigate passports and other documents and try to find frauds and then decide if the person can enter Arstozka or not. And when the decision is made, there're the painful few seconds after which you know whether you made the right choice. Papers, please is really exiting, distressing and addictive.
It's definitely worth the 4.49€ i have paid for it. It's very simple, but very very enjoyable and good.
Makes you want to keep playing to find out more -- despite the fact that the game is intentionally designed to be repetitive and dreary. Glory to Arstotska.

An incredible achievement. With a depressingly simple game mechanic, it manages to surpass most other offerings in terms of immersion and narrative. In a world where there's an increased focus on gamefication, I could easily see this being applied to a grammar school curriculum, helping to make young people understand how horrifyingly simple it is to become a spook in the wheel.  This game belongs on everyone's bucket list.
Awesome game! Never played anything like it before.
great game

This game looks surprisingly simple, but is surprisingly difficult as well. What seems to be just stapming papers, quickly tirns into a web of espionage, terrorism and smuggling. A very good game, which will keep you busy for longer than a lot of the so-called 'AAA' titles out there. Must buy.

Curiously adicting game. Fun story and good gameplay. You'll see yourself replaying levels to try and catch everyone.  Would highly recommond purchasing this game if your into indies and its on sale :)  9/10 :)

This game is certainly... different. I was intrigued by the premise: running a border crossing in an eastern-dystopic styled country, however in the end the game was just so depressing and repititive that I lost interest. It definitely is unique, and may be worth it on sale, especially if attention to detail is your thang.  Be ready to deal with your family starving to death because you let the dying old man into your country.

Brilliant game with unique idea. You really can see how ♥♥♥♥ is the job of a customs officer. Buy if you want to spend some hours checking random peoples papers while there is a interesting story developing behind the scenes as you work your days.

Like the game says, it is very much a dystopian document thriller. It's one of those special games that really makes you think and consider what you're doing and how it's affecting these digital people.   It's basically one of those 'spot the difference' pictures with logic thrown in and much, much more complicated rules. Despite how boring it may sound, it's actually strangely compelling. It's hard to acurately describe it. If you're at all interested, try the demo at  http://dukope.com/  .  Glory to Arstotzka.
