Oddly enough, this game is far more interesting than I thought at first hand.  There is alot of humor, it's 'stressfull' to check everything (In a good way), and you get punished right away for mistakes. It's one of the odd and quirky games that you either love or hate.  I'd give this one a 8/10 to be fair, it's rather entertaining, and the graphics are ideal for the game along with the sound.
Awesome game for the bureaucrat in you!

Is most realistic depiction of glorioius Arstotzka. The cruel monatany of every day life: the constant paperwork, the random searches, the loss of family day in and day out. It even have realistic portrayal of terrorist attack that took my son, Beshlevic. His struggle is over.   9 out of 10 potatoes.
I payed $5 to play a game where I slowly realized how tedious, boring, and stressful any job truly is. And I couldn't have it any other way.

This game is great however the difficulty spikes after everyday. It's difficult to do thorough searches while trying to get as many people approved/declined through your checkpoint so you make more money to support your family. This game is great.

This game is brilliant in all his sillyness. Every time you play, you will have a new day where you can decide who is allowed to enter the beautiful land of Arstotzka. You'll feel sorry for the poeple who are denied, or you will laugh at them and wave them goodbye. In this game you can sort of create your OWN story. Do you want to be part of the rebelion? Or do you want to stay loyal to your country? Do you want to keep your family alive? Or do you spare money on food and heat and let them die? This game is perfect for a rainy day, when you can't go outside. I love the game, I hope you do too.   Glory to Arstotzka
This game is somewhat depressing, but a great game to play nonetheless.

Very strange and innovative game, I really liked it. It becomes pretty difficult, after some time. Try it if you're looking for a different and kind of realistic game. It's not 'funny', but really enjoyable.

Nice little gem, got it on sale, well worth it! Kinda starts feeling like work after you've played for a while (I think this is part of the charm, plus I may have played for too long at a time) but there is plenty to explore in the early parts of the game as well as some very creative writing. I'm impressed with its ability to make you actually care about the avatar's family and the immigrants he processes through the daily grind of his work.
One of the best games I've played all year.
This is the perfect simulator for a border man.
A bland looking work of art. Check out reviews on line for more info.
Quite an interesting game with many endings. It isn't as tedious as you might think, but the user-interface emulates limited desk-space almost too well.

One of the funnest games i have ever played. Simply amazing. This game can bring out anyone's bad side. Your hunger for power will emerge and you will deny access to innocent people and grant other's access for a little money on the side.
I love coming home from work, to play a game about working.
Forget everything you know about pushing papers, and enjoy this crazy weird game that has no right to be as interesting and fun as it is.
Fun game, but after 3 hours of playing I feel like i just worked a full day.

A gripping, unique, and thrilling game, despite the seemingly dull pretense. The game is sublimely cohesive in everything it does, and presents it's well-woven narrative entirely through the gameplay systems it lays out. Everything from the visuals, to the sounds, to the characters, is presented with minimalist charm. The game instills complex moral and political decisions into little more than a red or green stamp. One of the year's best, and a must play.
Brilliant game, fun, and tense all at once, making you choose between what you tihnk is right and wrong...

I have no idea why this game is so fun, you're literally doing paperwork. It's so engaging tho! I wanna know what happens with the terrorists and spy guys...Idk, it's a cool game with a cool concept. Give it a try!

Its an interesting twist with a great story, you really feel involved when you make certin choices. I really like to play with my drawing tablet it makes it all the more immersive so if you have one use it!
is good should buy
You ask people for Paper's in a polite fashion. People insult you. You kill them. 10/10
Intresting game, best played with a guide open next to it though...

It's a simple game with basic graphics, but it quickly becomes far more complicated. The ethical issues are probably my favorite part of the concept. To be good at this game, you have to harden your heart and be willing to ignore the plight of others. Yet you can't be entirely heartless either, or you'll find yourself without allies when you're the one with a sad tale to tell.
Quirky, simple, and strangle addictive. Papers, please will have you playing for hours until you've mastered all the appropriate specifications needed to let people in to Arstotzka!

Regardless of whether you'll end up loving it or hating it - this game is worth buying at any (within reason, obviously) price..  For me I was happy as soon as the main menu appears with its fantastic music and the graphic thudding up and down menacingly.  That is what I love most about Papers, Please - It is so perfectly atmospheric. All the small details add up to produce a scene and atmosphere that you would think impossible given the simple interface and graphics but it pulls it off quite brilliantly.  Another thing is, unlike mainstream AAA huge title releases, this game simply works and needs barely any bandwidth (which has to be a welcome relief if you are at all like me and have about half the internet queued up pending download!)  Most people will really enjoy the experience of Papers, Please - Especially those of us who see video games as an artform.  If you play games for the EXP, killstreaks and DLC / pay to win then Papers, Please will fly right over your head - and it's your loss...  Everyone else - BUY THIS GAME! - And Enjoy!!!
Failed to stop terrorism but captured a killer who murdered his wife, 100/10 this games good
I watched the tragic downfall of my family as I continued to fail them at my impossible job.  5 Stars
i done bought this game and now i won't let my ma and pa back in the gott dang house unless theyve got their gott dang documents!
Such emotional. Very unique gameplay. Wow.
Pretty good, nice art, depth. Then you realise you're doing someone's job. Worth buying.
Very casual, but really makes you think at certain points.
This game is really fun and there is so many people that want to enter Arstotzka. Some will enter and others will not, its just the way the cookie crumbles. Glory to Arstotzka!
Great way to make a game. The game as a whole is simply awesome. You quickly lose track of time trying to progress just a bit further and see what happens the next day.
Great game. Really makes you think and you can tell a lot of work was put into it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
At first glance, it might seem boring and endless but it's much more than that. It includes and makes you question your morals and loyalty to your country Arstotzka.
Don't get paid enough. Make hard choices. Family gets sick and dies. Go to prison because I do not get paid enough.  Glory to Arstotzka!
My favorite game on steam by far.
Awesome game, my favorite thing about it is probably Jorji
Fantastic game. It'll make you notice more details in real life and make you suspicious of everyone, like the clerk at the grocery store and the mail carrier.
amazing concept, hours upon hours of gameplay.

Papers Please is a game many people i've met think is perfect. While I disagree with this for the reason that the day that a game is perfect is the day that world peace becomes a reality, I still think that this game deserves all the credit it gets. In the game you are a worker at a boarder checkpoint, but this is covered in the discription so i wont go into much detail. Most of the gameplay consists of managing papers and deciding if all the papers are in order and sending off into the county. It starts off easy but slowly becomes harder as you have to manage up to 15 things to check by end game. I do not want to spoil too much of the endnings as there are 15 i belive, however I encorage you to get this game. It is a look into your own self conscious. Will you listen to the sob story of a random person you have never met and let them in or will you save that five dollars you get for turning her away to buy medicine for your dying son. The choice is yours. It took me about 10 hours to finish my first run, but with 15 diferent endings and all of them being from 6 hours to 10, you will get your moneys worth out of this game.   10/10
Well worth the 4.99, may look very strange but it's an excellent THINKING game to pick up and play whenever. The story mode has some unique moments that really make the game.
This game is so unbelievably addictive and immersive. The multiple endings make it worthy of several play throughs.

Dont let the look of this game keep you from buying it. This game is so fun and it gets harder as it goes. Its all about letting people into your country or denying them access. They will provide paper work and it is your job to make sure you go over every documentation they give you and make sure it is valid. This game really helps you acquire a keen eye for details. You must provide for your family and keep them safe but you also have to make moral decisions. This woman will die if you dont let her through but she dosnt have the correct paper work. Do you let her in or do you send her to her demise? Every action you do alters the story. Very well designed game and before i knew it i had already played 10 hours in one day. 9/10
I can't completely explain why 'Papers, Please' is addictive or even fun at all. It has to be something about the narrative and atmosphere it creates. Well, that and the depressing tuba music :P
A Dystopian paperwork simulator, one-of-a-kind game... surprisingly addicting.
went 5 buck in debt one night, got sent to debtors prison and had my family deported.  10/10 would play again.
This doesn't seem like it would be fun just going by the concept, but jeez, I can't stop playing it. It's deceptively complicated, and it even has a story going on if you pay attention. I love it!
Simple, fun time passing game without the 9-5 feeling.
Fun and captivating game that requires attention from players while incorporating interesting events and gameplay.
Glory to Arstotzka! Is best game yes.

An amazing game of choice and consquence, its been a long time since I played a game not having any sense of where its boundards where and what possibilities may or may not be avaliable to you. Be warned though this is a game literally about checking peoples passports, thats techncally what you spend 95% of your time doing. I mean actually checking facts and dates and cross referencing things.Its what you think and feel while you are trying to do that is where the game really happens.

The concept sounds horrible: your job is to check passports at a Cold War Eastern European country. Yet somehow the game is utterly compelling. There's a larger storyline, plus some smaller ones and I found I really got ino them. Very addictive. I also love the minimalist blocky look & feel of the game: it fits perfectly with the subject matter.

Papers, Please is a nerve-racking immigration officer drama that, despite feeling repetitive about 8 levels in, still entertains in a terrifying way. Does this game prove that less is more in the future of video games? Possibly.

Papers, Please is my pick for the best indie game of 2013 without a doubt. It has a unique indie charm, fantastic characters, multiple endings and is just plain fun to play again and again. Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please trains your observation and memory skills, and rewards you with a fresh experience that you absolutely need to play.  20 different endings can be achieved and with the safety of you and your family at stake, you will be very careful about your every step. Do yourself a favor, and make Papers, Please your own personal experience by not reloading a save-state in your first play-through.  Glory to Arstotzka!
Arztotska is the Best Country and Game in the World!  Glory to Arztotska!
3RD BEST GAME EVER MADE BEHIND MW2 AND GTA V. YES I BLOOMIN DO RECOMMEND THIS 100% WORTH THE PRICE. NO WONDER THE GUARDIAN THINK ITS THE GAME OF THE YEAR!

Papers, Please, is defintely worthy of all the attention it is receiving. Under the frankly underwhelming premise, lies a great game, with a story that emerge from its mechanics. It is as bleak as games get, and one that should be played by all, for its warnings against totalitarianism and blind adherence to rules.
extreemly entertaining, very replayable, Fantastic game
Glory to Arstotzka! Please have documents ready for inspection.

Papers, Please is bleak, mechanical and harsh. You run the border checkpoint into the glorious country of Arstotzka, and your job is to let authorized individuals in, and keep any undesirables out. At the end of the day, you receive a meager paycheck which you must divvy up wisely to keep your family warm and fed. Along the way, you'll meet all kinds of people -- some angry at the ever-increasing bureaucratic web, some desperate to see their families and loved ones on the other side of the border, and others both weird, and suspicious... The documents you'll have to scan will become increasingly complex as the game continues, and you will be presented with choices. It is up to you to decide whether to stick to your job, or to let your conscience potentially cost you your job. This game is definitely worth picking up. Glory to Arstotzka.
in papers please, you play as a man in some sort of winter-hell sorting papers. its VERY good and VERY please.  would buy.

A surprisingly complex and morally ambiguous game, in the best way. There is a distinct subtleness to the gameplay -- balancing your own moral code against the needs of your family and the time management aspect of the game. Definitely worth a try as long as you enjoy non-standard games.

This is a silly little game which will suck you in, and make you spend hours playing it. You play the role of a border agent who is responsible for letting people in to a soviet era country. The game starts out simply enough where you just allow locals in, and deny foreigners access, but the difficulty ramps up quickly, where you need to start checking for forged passports and other documents.  There is a bit of a story line which I've only gotten a glimpse of. There are also some moral decisions to make as to whether or not to grant access to people, who don't have the correct documents but claim that they are in danger. Do you risk your limited income to possibly save someone, do you take a bribe from a smuggler, or do you play by the rules?
Many games advertise 'tough moral choices w/ consequences', few actually deliver on their promise. This one certainly does.
Fantatic premise, the gameplay might get old after a few playthroughs but it is definitely an unique game expirence
This game is weirdly addictive.
combines the intense pressure of working under a harsh dictatorship with the fast-paced world of processing paperwork!

Has to be one of the best 10 dollars I spent. This simple seeming game on the outside has hours of fun on the inside. Who knew customs could be so fun?! With many different endings as well as an infinite mode, this game will keep you entertained so well that time will just fly by. Little visits by a few recurring potential citizens are always fun. Highly recommend this game if you're looking for some cheap time to kill on steam.
I don't know why this game is fun, but it is.

I have played for only an hour and already think this is one of the most imaginative, interesting and unique game i have ever played. It is a very good game with a player determined endings (as there are 20 of them). They all are good endings. The actual gameplay does NOT get boring at all as whenever you complete a day more stuff is added to the next. For instance Day 1 you only are aloud to let in people from the country you are based in and then in Day 2 you can let in foriegners which make its it even more challenging. You need to make enough money to pay your family or they will (suprise suprise) DIE! I rank this game 10/10
It's fun game, yeah!

If you like being in control you will love this game. You check. You detain. You check. You get bribed. You check. You get wrong. You check. You lose money. You check more carefully. You die. You check. You check again. Love, hate, mystery, drama, 8-bit-style-music and 80s-graphics all in 41 MB.   Buy it! Glory to Arstotzka!

I knew about the strangely compelling-yet-soul-crushing gameplay, but I was surprised by the amount of intrigue and suspense. Do you take that bribe to let someone without the right papers in? Do you listen to the mysterious masked man and follow his instructions? Your choices decide your fate, and the fate of your family. I've only completed one run-through so far, but I know this is a game I will come back to again and again, seeking out those different endings and seeing how far things can go.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Rating: 9/10 Genre: Indie  Personal Review: Odd in Concept, Perfect in Exectution. This is How I would rate Papers, Please. You play a border guard in the fictional country of Arstotzka, and as any border guard could tell you, 'You see some weird ♥♥♥♥'... Glory to Arstotzka

LANGUAGE OPTIONS!!!!!  You pretty much get the idea from any other review about this fantastic, one of a kind game. What really sold me on this game was the ability to switch between languages. I have studied Russian for years and have never found a way to make customs/airport vocabulary fun or engaging in a meaningful way. Papers Please does just that, and the effortless and in-game language translation toggle is superb. I actually feel like this game was meant to be played in Russian given the bleak Soviet themes. I cannot speak for the other 6 or 7 languages offered, but I found that a replay of Papers Please (Докумктеы Пожалуйста) in Russian was as completely different and rewarding experience, one that I can actually apply in a real world setting. How many games offer that? Buy it! Ha zdorovye!
This game made me rethink who I am as a person.

If you enjoy Ace Attorney style games where you have to test your powers of observation, critical thinking, and deduction then you should totally play this game. High stakes, stressful, and an occasionally hilarious game where you're an immigrations officer working in a corrupt fictional cold war nation that can only let people in under specific parameters.
So far I've played it twice and there hasn't yet been an end point where I wasn't arrested. Addictive game. ~
bad game family dead no food too hard 10/10
The simplicity, plus the music, plus the overall feel of the game is amazing. It's amazing how much stress you can get from keeping your fake family alive, knowing you cant screw up.

This game is incredible. There are a million great stories and every person that comes to your window can be it's own little self contained adventure that will may have repercussions down the line. Phenominal story telling and brilliant little puzzle game.
Papers, Please is a surprising gem of a game which will hook you in. It may look boring, but it is anything but.

A simple game that, despite it being all about checking paperwork, is really a lot of fun. You get a strange sense of accomplishment anytime you detain a criminal or reject someone with incomplete paperwork. It's a lot of fun, but beware! If you have stuff to do, this game will take all of your time away! 4 1/2 out of 5!

Do I recommend this? Yes. Yes, I do. Upon looking at the description of this game, I thought to myself, 'this seems like a boring game. I'm an immigration officer? What blasplemy of a game is this?' Looking at the reviews and then watching the trailer, I became intruged. What can be so interesting simulating a day to day work process of stamping papers at an immigration checkpoint? Seeing it on sale, I had to give it a try. Boy was I am surprised. This indie game definietly packed thriller in a dystopian society where there are betrayals, terrorist attacks, taking up arms, and etc. Even though the concept is simple, hearing the typewriting sound of a citation printing up bugs me, which indicated I had made a mistake in my job. Perfecting your job as an immigration officer is no easy task. The game's 20 endings give it lots of twists and turns, where your actions will lead to another ending. I played this 2 full days straight, completing two good endings and 16 out of 20 possible endings. I figured I shall take a break from the game to recommend everyone that they should definietly give this game a try.  P.S. The music and the subtle comical aspects of the game is great as well.

Nothing better than getting out of a day at work and go to another day at work, getting citation for letting a terrorist get into your country while, at the same time, having your son dying and not being able to afford his medicine.  Still, the hookers at the strip club are nice
This is not one of those games that you sit down and play for a half hour or so. This is a game that will suck you in for hours on end.
Glory to Arstotzka. Dirty Kolechians, keep out.
I got arrested for owing the country 5 dollars. Glory to Arstotzka.

This game could be qualified to be displayed in the 'Video games are art' arguement. Its simplistic graphics help the feeling of the game tremendously. It seems simple, and what it comes down to is green stamp, or red stamp, but it gives morally complex situations for you to ponder about. One time, not spoiling anything, it made my heart beat so fast, I felt like it would jump out of my chest.   The game can be frustrating at times, with sometimes vague mechanics, that aren't explained well, but once you get past these, by mere practice, the game will be far more fun for you.  I highly recomend this game to anyone who wants to experience one of the most intruiging premises ever. 8.95/10 (I'm a hard rater.)
Stress stress stress stress. Work faster, let people in, don't let people in. I am no tratior. Glory to Arstotzka.

I didn't believe it was possible to make stamping passports and cross-checking information tense but somehow Papers, Please has done just that. It's an indie game in every sense of the phrase, as the entire game was allegedly built from the ground up by a single man, Lucas Pope; that in itself makes it worthy of a look. While it won't appeal to everyone as it is essentially a point-and-click and others may find it a bit repetitive, I was pleasantly surprised at how involved in the game I became which I credit to the story. Additionally, twenty different endings to that story guarantees replay value and the branch-off save system makes it simple to explore them all. If it piques your interest, the beta is still free to download so you can see what you think.  Glory to Arstotzka
It is a really addicting, really fun game. It gets annoyingh after a while of playing though. When I first got this game I played for a few hours straight then stopped and never played again.
Join mighty border patrol and stamp your way to the revolution! Or detain everyone. Best puzzle game is pride of greatest nation! Glory to Arstotzka!

I discovered this game on youtube....at first when I watched the gameplay video I laughed, honestly because this game looked soooooooooooooooooooooo bad, but once you play it, it's really quite enjoyablye. The game itself starts out easy but as you go on throughout the days it gets increasingly more challenging. I can see how this game would get boring but if you're looking for a game thats a quick download, quick gameplay, cheap price, and something to just keep you occupied, then this is a game for you. 7/10

A fantastic way to test your morals as you decide whether you want to save money for your famliy or help out strangers in need at your job of a customs officer. I cannot find anything wrong with this game. It is incredible.
Amazingly good fun. It gave me a real insight in to my own psyche as well as making me question my own morals. Fantastic work.
Odd at first, fun and original game

Fantastic game! Very simple premise but as it goes on and you get more things to do, it becomes easier to overlook small things and tests your observation very well. The story is very intriguing and deep and i look forward to delving deeper into Arstotzka and finding out what's going on in the country! Glory to Arstotzka!

Most will enter this game thinking it is going to be boring. The premise: stamping passports all day, allowing or denying entry into your country, doing your civic duty. The truth behind this game could not be farther away. The game is really about survival, as you will soon see once you experience this very intelligently put together game. Party approved.

Thought the reviews were trolling to just get me to waste money to buy this game. But after playing a couple hours it gets really in-depth with the decisions you have to make on whether or not to let someone through. Tons of satire with memorial characters makes this game really funny at times. If this game was on flash sale will definitely make some more copies so my friends can play too.
Absolutely phenomenal. This game actually makes you think and trying to get all the endings is endless fun.
Intresting llittle game, simplistic game, but does an excelent job of making you pay attention to details.

May the glorious beard of Karl Marx bless you as you enter into the most depressing Communist state I have ever seen since North Korea! Your task, in Arstotzka, will require you to allow more people into the blessed Motherland! Nevermind the death threats you will recieve, or the terrorist attacks that happen almost daily, at the East Grestin boarder! Better it happen there instead of in the glorious country of Arstotzka! Your fast-paced job will have you working at 5 Rubles per entrant, which is plenty to feed your family and heat your home! Glory to Arstotzka!
A challenging, absorbing game that makes you question your obedience - a sort of self-awareness that is sadly rare in video games.

This game is about three things.  1. How boring and meaningless average bureaucratic job really is ... and how fast you start imagining your demi-godly importance once becoming half-way efficient in doing it :)  2. There's a non-linear storyline which offers 20 different endings for you, your family and banana republic you represent. It's interesting enough to complete the game more that once (takes about 5 hours on average).  3. And there's this terrifying realisation that you'll do just about anything (bribery, espionage, vengeance, murder) to achieve your goals, however righteous they may seem (providing for your family, compassion, patriotism). Good thing, this is only a game ... right ?!  Seriously, playing this game, left aftertaste in my brain, that of reading some small interesting book. Try it. This not an excuse for not reading any books kids ;)   P.S. Jorji rules !!!
More fun than you can imagine. Intense and terribly ironic. Who would have thought a desk job could be so much fun?
this game is like as addicting as heroine 10/10
Not kidding, its actually a fun game.

Glory to Arstotzka indeed. The game seems simple from the get go, but actually gets increasingly hard and stressful as time goes on when you have to check so many details, keep your family warm and fed (And giving medicine to your damn son who has the weakest immune system in history), and then let your morality decide for you when you need to let undocumented people through like the soccer player, or the married couple when the wife has no papers. Also following or denying the Order is intense. There are so many endings, and I've only just cracked the tip of the iceberg with them.
Can't...stop...playing...  Great very original game, and cheap too. Laptop/older computer friendly.
glory to arstotzka comrade

very fun game. worth.

Just got this earlier in the sale and after playing it for only a few hours I've realised I should have grabbed it ages ago. Trying to balance keeping your family afloat while helping the people is brilliantly dark. However the inspection mode can be a annoying in places, especially when you are trying to find out which of the many possible options it wants you to highlight as the clocks running out. 4 crushing Communist regimes out of 5
Someone gave me poison to poison someone else. I touched it and died instead. 10/10

As a predominant shooter fan, I was skeptical of this game. It's core game mechanic is stamping forms. And when I started playing the game, it was exactly that. But the genius is that the developers managed to turn it into an exciting and interesting game. Anyone can make a fun shooter, but to make a fun paperstamper, that's skill.
So Simple and still fantastic, something oddly satisfying about denying access to poor unfortunates

Looks boring but actually lots of fun and really engaging.

The thing I like the most about Papers, Please is that it makes no attempt to be typical. It is what it is, and what it is just happens to be a very captivating experience. Though simplistic, the level of intricacy involved in trying to be perfectly accurate during every passport inspection in the game is mind-boggling. I am having a lot of fun with this game, and cannot wait to play more of it.
its bretty gud
While slightly depressing, this game is addicting and very entertaining. It's clever and mysterious, I love playing it.
This is the best soviet-style administration game I have ever played.

It's dark, dreary and a great summary of how the U.S viewed the Iron Curtain nations during the Cold War. 'You do not meet standards?' 'Go to prison!' Your family starves, you rot, and the game is over. Alternatively you help Ezic. You flee with forged passport, and your family dies, game over. There are a lot of different endings with hilarious outcomes, and many depressing easter eggs for a our comrade. At first glance it looks like an over tedious strategy game with bad graphics, but after you start to align yourself with your character and put yourself in this Cold War drama, you start to have a lot more fun.
Saved a life, lost my own. 10/10
Simple, but very entertaining. Once you start playing this game, you will go straight to the ending.

I would not describe this game as fun, but hands down it is an experince worth having. I never thought I could be so wraped into a gave based around paperwork, but after starting, it was hard to stop.

A very enjoyable lean-back-in-your-chair-and-have-fun type of game in my opinion. The graphics are outstanding for the atmosphere of this game, and as you advance it does become rather challenging. I don't like using backgrounds with quick-references in this game, as it ruins the authenticity for me. I like the idea of really flipping through the pages of a book (in-game) looking for the references you need and comparing them to the documents presented to you. Feels really great. The addition of feeling the pressure of processing as many people's papers as you can possibly manage in one shift to earn as much money as you can so you can support your family is also great. You don't have vast expanes of time to sift through every possible thing there could be wrong about the documents or you simply won't earn enough money. That plus the fact that when you make too many mistakes your paycheck gets cut back makes this a nice challenge. It's intrigueing to realise that you really make a system and routine for yourself without really thinking about it. Some people say this game sounds like working an office job, that might be true for some people but I find it highly enjoyable! 8/10
My entire family died and I was fired. Glory to Arstotzka, 10/10.
Depressing but it sucks you in.
This game is amazing, I have found the job perfect for me. Screw becoming a doctor, I want to be a border guard in eastern Europe.
I arrest people for typos in their passports, my son is dying and my wife is cold.   Awesome. 10/10
great game
Challenging and fun.
Simple, challenging, depressing, and it makes a lot of great statements about loyalty, nationalism, empathy, and morality with very simple graphics and mechanics.
Words cannot describe my love for this title.
This game may seeml ike it will get dry and boring after a couple of hours, but i can see myself playing this game for a while. For what it is its very entertaining.

I play this when i am currently jobless and on jobseekers allowance. It mimics my life perfectly. I am poor, my ingame family is poor. I contemplate letting terrorists in for an extra 5 rupees just like I do in real life.  ++stamping simluator ++Document checking simulator ++GLORY TO ARSOTKZA  -- Desk gets cluttered easily --When you buy this game you are paying to spend your free time out of work, playing as a border officer working. wat?? -- Stamping skills do not transition well to real life border officer job role.

Good fun test to see how good you are at discerning small details and juggling progressively larger amounts of paperwork under time duress. I enjoy it. I love the setting and it's strangely compelling. There's a free demo from the site  (http://dukope.com/)  but it only lets you play 7 days of the story. The full version has the rest of the story and an endless mode with three different modes (How many you can do in 10 minutes, first mistake and you're out, and last until you run out of money for living expenses).    Also, obligatory patriotism: KOLECHIANS GO HOME! GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
Amazing story. So many endings.

Unique title that is surprisingly good at challenging your memory and ability to detect small changes in a time sensitive environment. Can be mentally exhausting yet engrossing. Should only be played when your brain is fully alert.

Played this game when it was in the beta and absolutely loved it. It's amazing how such a boring idea like being a checkpoint officer can make such a fun and engaging game. For the small download size and lack of amazing graphics, there's so much content packed into this game with a in-depth story that can take a sudden turn at any moment depending on what you do. That man you just let in could have been a spy, maybe he's helping a secret agency to overthrow the government and you're now part of the conspiracy, or maybe he really is just a guy coming to work. You can only really know if you say the magic words; Papers, please.
So much fun. Can really burn away time that you don't know what to do with (in a good way).
A suprisingly addictive game, one of the best indie games I've played.

Now, I just recently beat 'Papers, Please' and thoroughly enjoyed myself.  In this game, you live in the made-up Communist nation of Arstotzka and your name has been drawn in a 'labor lottery' which I have never heard of before, but I imagine is similar to jury duty in America. The particular job you have been given (regardless of whether you want it, because hey, it's communism) is to be a border checkpoint worker. Your family is given a house to live in, but you must provide enough money to keep them safe and sound.  This game starts off quite linear and intriguing as you admit or decline people based on their paperwork and the rules you are issued everyday before starting. As time goes on however, events happen and more rules are added into your book to help ensure the safety of Arstotzka. Each day, you only have so much time to process people and that puts a lot of pressure on you because you have a family you have to pay the bills for.   This game presents you with many choices throughout. Some of these are moral choices or opportunities to make some money. Not all the opportunities are legal though...How much are you willing to do to compromise the nation's security to make sure you have food on the table? There are twenty different endings and the game makes you feel like your decisions actually matter.  As far as gameplay alone goes during the process of admitting applicants, it is actually exhilarating. You know you need to do a good job of examing their paperwork so that you don't lose money or even your job, but you also just want to work as fast as possible to get more money for your son's medication, or to pay the heat bill, or whatever the game throws at you. The rules constantly change and evolve with the times and it makes gameplay an enthusiastic struggle of work ethics, money, and guilt.   I cannot say how thoroughly impressed I am that one man alone made this game. It is definitely worth playing. 10/10.
Papers, Please is incredibly stressful and somewhat depressing. 10/10 highly reccomend.

C-64 graphics but high quality sounds. You are an inspector on the borders of a (fictional) communist country in the early 80's. You decide who enters, who has to leave and sometimes who will be detained. The paycheck isn't really worth to mention, so you have to keep your eyes open for opportunities, that are always containing some risks.   An amazing, dark atmospheric game, well balanced, with intresting descitions to make. Multiple endings complete a nice game that contains story elements but doesnt feel too linear at the same time.   Really love it!

Brilliant game where you play an immigration officer in fictional cold-war state. The concept is easy enough to understand, but the game is very strict. A new rule or regulations regarding immigrants is added nearly every day.  This means you have to check more documents for validity, all while trying to process enough people every day so you can make enough money to feed your family and keep them warm. The story mode (which has 20 different endings!) adds an extra dimension to the game, terrorists and secret organizations are trying to get into the country and it's up to you to prevent them or not, but your choice will have consequences either way. This all is interspersed with some great humour which is the proverbial cherry on top. I would recommend this game to anyone ever!
As interesting as I was hoping.
before i bought papers, please, i saw it played all the way through by DeceasedCrab. despite this, i bought it myself. i have to say, i love this game. it's unique and strangely relaxing.
Glory to Arstotzka! Awesome game, innovative play type and creative setting. 10/10 would play again.
This is one of the greatest time wasting game ever I got it and just got sucked right into it.
its pretty good game thats all i can say

'Papers, Please' is a game that I did not expect. There are those indy games that you play for a few days and then never really look at again, but 'Papers, Please' grabs your attention with a slow build of very intense character interactions that are all based on whether or not you have all the correct papers to gain entrance at a immigration check point. It delves into corrupt politics, threatening scare tactics, and dealing with bomb smuggling terrorists, and people offering you bribes for entry into your gate. Its more intense and connecting that I thought and all the hidden espionage is definietly something that keeps your playing just to figure out how you got yourself into this situation where you are left with bombs, tranq gunning people down, and hoping not to ♥♥♥♥ of your over-seers.
addicting 8 bit game. sweet lord jesus prepare to waste countless amounts of tiime

This game is excellent. The music and mechanics really set the stage to put you in an eastern bloc country which provides an introspection as well as excellent game mechanics. This is the type of game that you quickly forget about the quality of the graphics and the execution of the game controls because the environment the game is conveying is absolute and it sticks with you weeks afterwards.
Very clever game design. Fun and intense with a particular 'humour noir'. Well worth the small price.

A really interesting game with a unique play mechanic - you work as an immigration inspector at the border of the ficticious nation Arstotzka. Both natives and aliens will attempt to cross the border and you must fact check their legal documents to make sure they're not entering the country illegally. Toss in a little espionage and bribery along the way in story mode, and you've got a very entertaining little game.

Most of us are blessed not to live under an oppressive communist regime.   Papers, Please   gives us the opportunity to step into the shoes of someone living there in a few hours.  As a border inspector, the gameplay consists of mundane checks on the authenticity and ever-changing validity of documents. The charm of   Papers, Please   comes from the various side events and your constant struggle between your duty as an inspector and your responsibility of providing to your family.  I find the low fidelity art and music rather apt to the narrative of the game and the booming theme is forever seared into my brain.  While not exactly a ‘fun’ game, I recommend   Papers, Please   to learn more about yourself through living a month on the Gretin border.  ( Glory to Arstotzka! )
Very expansive story!
Who knew stamping papers could be so fun? Music is also great

I really like this game. You are essentially faced with a challenge every 20-80sec, and everytime you mess up, it just makes you want to try that much harder.   It's not just the gameplay that makes it enjoyable, I really liked the addition of so many details that added to the immersion of the game. You really get a sense of what life might be like in an eastern european country during the cold war. If the game had none of the extra details added, it would be a waste of time and money, but those extras really show how a simple game can be made to be so rich and full of depth.   I also liked that although you are essentially doing the same thing over and over, there are little additions that you keep aware of the larger story and allow you to make subtle decisions that impact the ending.
I have alot of fun with this game and the twist of the story is really cool.

I won't lie, I picked it up just because the title and the idea of the game made me laugh in a twisted sort of way. This game surprises you by actually developing a pseudo-story line halfway through and is a nice bit of mental exercise along the way.

It's just so compelling. The graphics remind me of the Where in The World is Carmen Sandiago (Apple IIE) GUI. Wonderful story told in a very unique way which makes us realise of lucky we are. Great stuff.
Glory to Arstotzka ! Detain all Kolechian scum to feed sick mother in law. Worth every credit to buy this.
Its a nice way to waste time, and you make decisions in the game that actually matter and affect you. its nothing fancy, but i rather enjoy it. there are 20 different endings

This is a game about papers, but is so much more it is about choiches will you support the rebels? Or will you stick with your govrement because they might hurt your family? Will you accept bribes if your son is sick? This and many more in a cheap very good game

This is way more than a game. This is a masterpiece. A game in which a simple choice can ruin your or others' life.   THIS is true art. I believe everyone should experience this. I seriously cannot recommend this enough.

Brilliant game, possibly one of the best indie games I have ever played, up there with KSP, Monaco, Hotline Miami and all the other stellar games people rave about. Would be willing to pay $20 for the amount of fun I had with this game.

I spend all day at work IRL doing soul-crushing, oppressive, bureaucratic tasks and I hate it. Then I come home, ready to unwind, and play Papers, Please and do soul-crushing, oppressive bureaucratic tasks.,, and I love it.

Papers, Please does not seem like much when you look at it, I expected nothing more than an artsy indie game when I purchased it.  And the first day I played it I played for 8 hours, only breaking once for dinner.  This is not a game for everyone, but you find yourself drawn into the methodical rhythm of bueracratic work, the stress of outside forces preventing you from keeping your family fed and healthy. And the small stories and acts of kindness or cruelty you influence day to day choosing who can and who cannot make it across the border at your checkpoint.  This game will surprise you and is well worth your time.

Still amazes me how the developer made a routine, boring job into a fun and interesting vidya.  But he or they did. And did it well. The more you play, the more added difficulty comes along, the more you have to check on their papers, more things you have to remember to check whether there are any disrepancy.  I suggest it even at full price, the visuals are quite pleasing to look at, the gameplay is surprisingly fun and addictive. It pulls you in and gets you asking yourself 'Why is this so much fun?'.  Also the fact it has multiple endings and some story to it is just MORE reason to buy it and play it RIGHT NOW!

Have you ever come home from work, hours of paperwork, filing, playing games on government time? Wasn't it exhausting? Would you like to continue in a fictional world? Then all hail Arstotska! While the game is very punishing, it also isn't too hard to get into the swing of things. As far as 8-bit games go, this one is a winner.

Play as passport control and scrutinize over various documents from both citizens and foreigners. A seemingly boring job simulation game—but it’s not. This game is a lot deeper than it seems at first and contains an engaging story. Highly recommend at the $5 range.

A chilling, yet amusing game that will never fail to frustrate you when you realise that guy you just let through into your country  is wanted for killing several children (screw you Simon Wens). Glory to Artstotzka!

Fantastic corruption simulator, with a great save system that allows you to experiment and branch your storyline accordingly. A shame repeated playthroughs aren't as varied as expected but absolutely worth the money.

Cant say enough about this great game:  recap: follow the distopian tale of a totalitarian eastern European like country as its border crossing guard, faced with the day to day challenges of moral ambiguity and government regulation.   Personal synopsis: This amazing game is a marvel of simple game-play put to the very best use. Attention to detail is king as you monitor the comings and goings of immigrants, refugees and expatriated rebels in this amazingly addicting game. Unlock time and free mode for a real challenge and see how you rank against the best. I feel like this would be a great training simulator for customs and border agents in the ever more security conscious world.
Great little game with a unique concept.

I really, really like this game. The first thing that I love about it is the dark, foreign, uncomfortable atmosphere mainly achieved through the art style, dialog and music. At first, reviewing a bunch of papers may sound boring, but it is really well done and it a satisfying experience when you get it right. If you are a meticulous person then I think you will definitely like it.  But the game isn't really about reviewing papers without making any mistakes. It is about the choices you make in this poor, communist, conflicted society. Do you allow an ill woman to pass through the gates without having all the proper papers so that she can receive the treatment that she requires, knowing that you will be punished for it and lose the money you need to feed your starving family with? There are bigger decisions to make out there, and they are all yours to make. They will lead you in one of the twenty endings.  Very refreshing game, highly recommend it!
It could be named 'Brazil: the game'. And I am referring to both my country and Terry Guilliam's movie.

Bizarrely addicting game. It's very cleverly done.  I process aerospace paperwork for a living. I compare dates and specifications. I check procedures and verify things. I already do this game for a living. Yet I still think the game is fun.
I recommend this game, glory to arstotzka.

Papers please gives you the chills. It makes you wonder and think about yourself. How you can enjoy scanning people, not letting them into the closed country youre protecting as a customs-officer. On the other hand you have to work against the clock to prevent your family from starving and dying. The pressure keeps buildung up, you will make mistakes. I promisse.   After all. This game is addictive, plain and simple. I bought it today and then promptly lost myself in it for 4 hours. I'd still be playing if I hadn't accidentally poisoned myself. I realize that this game doesn't seem to be all that exciting, and for those who only play FPS or high octane games, it might not be your cup of tea. I liked watching how the decisions you make during your workday effect what happens politically, and in turn what changes for you day to day. I'm looking forward to my next play-through. If you like games that seem simple on the surface, but have a complexity that unfurls the longer you play, you could do far worse than Papers, Please.

I grew attached to my character to have him imprisoned and my family killed. That is the saddest I've ever felt playing a game. The Oregon Trail isn't as good.

Definitely worth it, this game makes me respect border security a lot more, their job is not easy. This game is hard and unforgiving, but the challange worth your time. Trying to keep your job, your family alive and happy all the while making sure your country stays safe and secure is an intense but fun little adventure. A good game for anyone, it's easy to pick up and play but gets quite indepth as you advance which will keep you busy for hours on end.

This is definitely one of those games you're bound to be skeptical about, when you see the premise of the game. But rest assured, if you enjoy games that make you think against the clock, while balancing the facts with your moral compass, you'll enjoy this game.  You're a border guard for a small, fictional Eastern European country, and you're the family breadwinner. You're paid per applicant processed, but fined for your mistakes. So what do you do when faced with a question of compassion against the need to feed your family?  This game doesn't do it in a preachy way at all, but it's bound to make you walk away thinking differently about immigration as being about real peoples' lives rather than just statistics.

This game is not what it seems!  Working at a border checkpoint, your job is to ensure each person passing through has the proper documents and requirements to enter your country. But all is not what it seems. With constant fake passports, visas, terrorist attacks and more, this game tests every bit of your moral values.   So you let this man through, but his wifes passport is wrong.They are fleeing their country in fear of death. Do you follow orders and deny her, sending her to an uncertain death? Or do you let her through and take the penalty, even though you need the money for medicine for your dying son?  This game is challenging as fake passports, fake work permits, fake visas and the like, become harder and harder to spot. Plus you are on a time limit. The more you process, the more you get paid then the more money you have to care for your family. (Basics like food, heat and rent!)  Papers, Please is an excellent game and has a various amount of endings which can play out based on how you play the game. Highly recommended!  8/10
I found myself playing this game a lot longer than I expected.  And even more shocked with how much fun I had.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

You can side with Exic, a group determined to fix the corrupt gov. of Arstotska, or you can choose to not side with them. Some people want you to let them or there family members even though they do not have the right documents. Oh, and the terrorists can get really annoying. I'll just let you figure out the rest!

A lot of fun I would recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind a slower pased, mental chanellenging game. Shooter fans rejoice - You do get a gun at a few points in this game.  8/10

At the core this appears to be a simple 'spot the difference' game; a joke that would put it in line with 'TSA Simulator' or 'TurboTax Adventures'. But the game quickly develops and you see the lives & reality around you change from your decisions. The story soon becomes your life when the game reveals the dark realities of political turmoil, personal struggles, war, love, and espionage. Somehow @dukope turned a boring job into a Mystery, Thriller, & Suspense novel.

A delightfully bleak Cold War satire that, while it seems tedious at first blush, is maddeningly addictive and fun. Highly recommended.

Papers, Please is a very fun and addicting game. It starts out pretty simple but after a few days you'll find yourself struggling to keep your family from starving. Make choices that will affect the entire nation and shape its fictional history. Overall a very fun game. I recommend it highly.

Have you ever wanted to scour paper after paper for the smallest of inconsistancies, hear the sob stories of countless individuals hoping to flee from terrible places to a slightly less terrible place, get berated by your boss for the smallest of screw-ups and force yourself into moral grey areas involving the family you never really get to see and immigrants with no where else to go? Yes? Then Papers, Please is the game for you. Much has been made of the immersive world born from this simple paperwork simulator, and, from what I've experienced myself, its no joke. I could feel the world around me turn grayer as I delved into the glorious land of Arstozka. Its a world that terrifies and interests me in equal measure. If you want an experience like no other, this is the game for you.
The worst idea for a game ever.  10/10. Loved every minute.
Awesome ~40mb of Art! :)

Death in video games is something that usually has little impact upon a player. You routinely kill thousands upon thousands of virtual foes and death or failure means teleporting back to a checkpoint. But here, death and failure are extremely psychologically taxing. The sound of a printing citation telling me that 5 credits would be deducted from my pay because I misprocessed someone was a sound that I dreaded and made me flinch everytime I heard it, because it meant I wouldn't be able to cure a family member of disease. A friend died and I replayed a day 6 times over just so that I could save him, because he was the only friend I had. The pixel art faces that come up to your door begin to feel more human than most video game characters rendered in 3D. This game is a masterpiece.

Surprisingly one of the most intense games I've played! So many difficult decisions while trying to keep a family from starving...While a terrorist plot evolves before your eyes...Very interesting gameplay, puts a lot of pressure on the player if you get into it.

A lot more fun than I would have initially thought. My friend told me about this game and I thought 'What's so fun about being a border guy?' and I've never looked back!  Great game a lot more fun that expected, definitley worth the buy.

I haven't even finished this game yet and it still haunts me. It's simple premise and retro 8-bit graphics are a smoke screen for a game that is emotionally daunting. This game literally manages to stare into your soul and reveal who you really are or at the very least who you could be given the right circumstances. It reminded me of the Democracy games from Positech in the sense that you think it's a one-person-made-this point and click game with simple graphics but very soon you all of a sudden realize what it's like to be in that character's shoes and why characters like that are the way they are in real life. In the Democracy games, you understand why politicians act the way they do. In Papers Please, you understand by government security bureaucrats act the way they do. It's sounds silly but you will not regret the experience. In terms of most important games of all time that have an emotional impact on you, I'll easily put this up there with Myst, Final Fantasy VII, and the Bioshock series. Buy this game. Let it change you.
Great Indie game!!!!!!! used to play it when it was a demo. Will not be dissapointed!!!!

A fantastic game. Much more than just paper shuffling and bureaucracy, it actually made me conflicted and made me feel for the generic pixelated characters and their back stories, and question my entire moral system.  A gem of a game :)

This is a wonderfully done game, while it may not seem very interesting/look bland it was anything but for me. It's extremely innovative and immersive, sucking you in as you deal witht these slighlty unreal-real world problems and gives the ocasional laugh all while showing just why the guys and gal's behind the desk of the DMV or any other government building are so pissy all the time.

Papers, Please is a game where you take on the role of an Arstotzkan (Russian) immigration inspctor and you must follow strict rules that change each day or else you won't make enough money to keep your family alive...   When you start playing this game it kind of feels like you actually just got a new job. You learn as you go but learn fast because you only get a handful of warnings before you're fired   sent to jail  . This is by no means a bad thing however as it adds a sense of constant worry and actually gives you a reason to want to do very well. The game throws moral choices at you and can actually get you pretty emotioanally involved. My fist time playing the game, I was so into the story that when I finally lost, I realized that 2 hours had gone by.   If you like a good story with retro graphics, memory skill, and reflex based gameplay, then this one's for you. I know that sounds like a weird combination so even if you're not sure, I'd recommend you give it a try.

This game is MEANT to simulate the mundanity of a job at a border checkpoint. But it throws something in every so often to get you excited, like a terrorist attack or someone with a passport drawn by a kindergardener. You get paid based on how many people you check each day, and every day it throws in something more to lenghten the time with each person, Like the requirement to search anyone from a certain country. Get something wrong and you'll get 2 warnings, then a fine. At the end of each day you have to manage your costs to provide for your family. This game is worth a buy. Glory to Arstotzka.
Go buy this masterpiece! Glory to Arstotzka!
Pretty Good!

For a game about stamping passports, this game did an exceptionally good job. It somehow takes a menial, repetitive task and puts it in a story and setting that manages to keep the player entertained and engaged. Glory to Arstotzka.
Great commentary on statism
Now I can finally relive my fantasy of being a border control officer.

Papers, Please is the sort of game I can recommend, but not for an extended amount of time. A game that appears designed eventually destroy you in the manner of an old-school game of Frogger is deeply stressful for me, especially when combined with bureaucracy and the sound of a dot matrix printer reporting my failure.  The goal is to pass people through your gate. Each person you admit gives you some income, which you will never have enough of. Each day the time allowed remains the same, but the requirements grow more and more elaborate and detailed, and you lose money if you admit someone or deny them incorrectly.   It's well made, and after a while you find yourself concocting patterns for how to get through the various searches as fast as possible, but the games whole point is the futility of an ever thickening bureaucratic set of rules and permissions without increased time and labor to support it.  There's this notion that people and charge can demand things 'better, faster, cheaper' and get results, but the phrase 'Good, fast, cheap, pick two' more apt when it came to results. While Papers, Please is a perfectly fun game on the surface level, it quickly demands you ask some uncomfortable questions. It's the rare game that actually makes its point through its own mechanics.
This game is awesome. Didnt take long to start getting corrupted. 9/10

An interesting game that starts you off with the intent to be the best border control ever. That changes however when you get paid for your efficiency on the job, and as a result, need to earn enough to keep your family warm and well fed. Sometimes you will be thrown into a scenario that tries to play the sympathetic card, and as a result may find yourself letting in people you shouldn't. All in all, it's a simple concept executed well with some nice mechanics to give that Iron Fist, Cold War setting.
More fun than it sounds like it should be
this game is just amazing and its just omg just play it

Very dark atmosphere, with some deep and life changing choices. An indie game totally worth a few quid!
Probably one of the best games available Check passports, shoot terrorists, help revolutionaries, etc.  20 different endings and 5 or 6 different collectible tokens. Well worth the money.
I love this ♥♥♥♥ing game.

Something about this game was really enjoyable. It's not action packed but it has an intriguing story.  It's a bit of a point-and-click your way through your job, but that seems like it would be fairly realistic. The player is forced to monotonously dig through dates and seals of approvals to spot fake paperwork, just like the real border guards. The rules for required documentation was also changing from day to day which makes life harder for both border guards and immigrants.   One component of the game is feeding your family. If you can't work fast enough your family will go broke and you will go to jail for unpaid bills. I was playing on a trackpad and had a hard time with this. Fortunately the game comes with an easier difficulty setting that gives you some help with reaching your quota. Even with this setting on the game can still present interesting dilemmas and moral decisions.   It has a few different endings depending on the choices you made. It was fun but for me it did not warrant a second playthrough to experience an alternative ending.

This game. THIS game. I completely underestimated this game. It seems really simple from the looks of it, but it's easily one of the most complex games I've ever played. It reminds me a lot of Harvest Moon 64. When anyone asked what that game was about, the answer (quite honestly) was 'Work.' People would go, 'Really?' And it's like....'yes, you're working. On a farm.' And until they played it, they didn't 'get' it. Why it was so amazing. Why it was so fun. That's EXACTLY what this game is like. You're at a customs desk, checking passports. The challenge is in the way you have to check them each day. Who gets through, who doesn't? Who tugs at your heartstrings---I completely recomend this game for anyone who's even thought it might interest them, if only a little bit.

This is a great game and well worth the Purchese.  In this game you are stationed at the border checking passports.(I know it sounds dull but it really is quite interesting) The game has many endings aswell as moral choices that effect the ammount of money you make and if you end up in prison or not. If you do decide to play Pay attention to small details, there's no counting how many times a date screwed me over. this is a great title that should not be missed and is well worth the money.

Papers, Please is the best game I have played in the last year.  On the surface it is a biroucratic simulator where the only thing preventing terrorist, human trafickers and smugglers is your ability to find discrepanices in their paperwork. There are also moral decisions to be made when people are begging you to let them through even though they don't have the necessary papers. You can follow the rules and doom them or you can let them slip but that comes at your expense because you are getting penalized for every mistake you make and you have to earn enough money to feed your family.   If you follow the rules you are the bad guy, if you let every sob-story affect you your family will starve. And the game is brilliant because of it. Every aspect of it - ugly graphics, dark colour palette, primitive tools that are at your disposable add to the atmosphere. And when in that dark atmosphere arrives a moment of humor it really brights you up.  The game was done by a single guy and he has done a great job. This is the game you should really play.  Glory to Arstotzka!

If you ask me what this game is about, I can't tell you. To describe it would not only give you the wrong impression, but it would be insulting to the game.  'Papers, Please' is an addictive masterpiece, encompassing hummor and morality, as well as mortality. As simplistic tasks become more and more complicated, taking longer to perform, and holding a more intense weight over the livelihood of you and your loved ones, our ideas of morality change. Between bribes, corruption, sabotage, and simple cold-heartedness, the game knows exactly how to get at you, as you race to the end, trying only to survive.  When I tried to explain the game's mechanics to my friends, they were put off by the concepts. In our minds, a paperpusher does not make a great game. Yet everyone whom I've demonstrated to, or let play have expressed their own interest, many of whom bought the game for themselves. So yes, I suggest this game to anyone who wishes to explore humanity at it's finest.

This game shouldn't have been fun. End of story. It casts the player in the role of a border control inspector in a fictional, soviet-like country shortly after the end of a brutal war with its neighbors. It's almost impossible to get to the end of story mode without screwing someone over at some point, you feel like a d**k and you seriously question the government you work for and yet... it works. Having reached the majority of the 20 possible story mode endings, I still can't work out why I enjoyed 'Papers, Please' and yet I really, really did! It was probably a combination of the simple, but soul searching storyline, the addictively fun mechanics and the variety of paths through the game that give it good replayability. Nothing I can say here will truly convince you, but please try it out and I don't think you'll be disappointed.

Let me start of saying this game isn't what you think it is. It's not a border checkpoint simulator. It's what it says -- a document based thriller.  This game makes you develop an actual character with real choices and makes you choose morality or family. This game seems to be dividing the indie community. Some call it a bland 'data checking' simulation, and they'd be right. Some call it a fantastic insight into 'eastern block' mentality and they'd be right.  In brief, in this game you play a border visa inspector, you perform well and do your duty, the state will reward you. You made mistakes, get sloppy, even get sympathetic to the resistance... then you better watch out.  In a very discreet way, this game probes your good and bad from your right and wrong. Very often you'll have someone who comes to the border that you know you SHOULD grant entry to, as all the paperwork is correct, but you know it may have negative results. Then again, you have someone who has no legitimate paperwork and yet you know the right thing to do morally is to let them in.  Overall, it is rather a bland, mundane game... but that's exactly the point, the subject matter ISN'T exciting or stimulating, if you were an actual border guard, your job simple IS to check the details are all proper and correct, but the scenarios and moral questions this game poses is quite unique and well worth playing.  As above, you will either love it or find it boring, personally, I love it.
What a great value; $10 for a game whose beauty lies in between the lines. It gleefully embraces the mundane and makes it fun and addictive. Best indie I've played this year.
An addicting game that makes you feel like you have the fate of the world in your hands!

A really great game. The gameplay is used to really great effect here, with moral choices occuring as a natural, organic element of the design, rather than isolated, black and white choices you might find in, say, Mass Effect. Does a really great job of maintaining the stressful, high-pressure feeling one would have in that situation. The art style is effective and it is well polished, with plenty of charm and character, and the right length to feel substantial, but not padded or dragged out.  Overall, a really polished, well thought-out and refined game, with great moral choice mechanics. Highly recommended.

Yes, that's a red thumb. Don't get me wrong this is a good, innovative and surprising game. But it has a major fault you need to be aware of before buying it.  >This game is about WORKING.  Like a real job, maybe like your real job. You spend the daytime in your office, doing a repetitive task, in a dull and boring environnement. You go back home in the evening, worried about your family members getting ill and bills to pay. And you have to perform well at work, for you salary is based on your productivity.  This is quite stressful and you definitely don't want to go for another work routine when you log on steam.  Moreover everything in this game is so... depressing. It can't be explained with words, but I find that the feeling you get while playing is not enjoyable at all, almost repulsive. Right now I remember the graphics, the music, the suffocating atmosphere and I just want to run away and finish this rating as fast as possible.  I know there's a lot of positive ratings for this game already and I got their point : the game is good and unique obviously.  But do you seriously feel like working in a video game and going through all that implies ?

Don't be mislead by the whole 'art game' thing. It has (more than?) enough gameplay going for it to be an actual game. This game actually is fairly solid at it's core, with interesting gameplay mechanics. You'll quickly be amazed by how easy it is to make mistakes in judging someone's legal documents and how many layers of control this game offers. It has more depth than meets the eye. It's great even at what it does. Do keep in mind that the aesthetics are a bit rough in this pixel art style and it remains to be seen how all things combined will influence the game's longetivity. But I've already had a good few hours of fun with this and probably will occasionally play some more. It's also the only game I know of in it's genre of 'border patrol' style gaming. Add to that random events like terrorist bombings, people you have/can detain for human trafficking and it's quite a cool spin on the simulation genre. The stalinistic setting is nice and adds to the overall experience. The low pay with a direct impact on your own family can be a bit crude at times, but it's a nice touch.  It does seem to have a bug or two on at least the Mac version where sometimes clicking doesn't register when calling for people to show their passports.

I really liked Papers, please. It has a interesting cold war era story, multiple endings, and the checking for errors in the documents puts me into a tetris like playing zone. It is strange that something like that is so compelling, but it is really fun and I like it. Before you buy, you can simply test the game, there is like a free demo on the authors website. Just google for it.
Solid 8.5/10. Would be 10/10 if I had a way to kill my snitching neighbors.

Very original Game. Yes you need it, simply because it's such a unique thing, but not for 10 bucks. I've spent approximately 20 hours with it - and that includes time spent replaying the game. I may get back at it one day.  Now that we got that out of the way - the Review.   STORY: So you are an immigration inspector at the border of an exagerated communistic nation. Maybe it isn't even THAT exagerated, but the situations posed and the narration make for a deeply comical - but critical - atmosphere. There is a lot of Orwell's '1984' in this game (yea like EVERYBODY talking about that nowadays... OBEY!... but it really fits! *ducks*).  GRAPHICS: The graphics are retro-simplistic but good. I like the graphics, they get the job done.  GAMEPLAY: Now this is where Papers Please defines itself - well apart from the bizarre scenario it imposes upon you. You have to grant people access to your country - or deny them - based on the correctness of the formulae and documents they present to you. You need to check if their Birthdate, Gender and Photograph match and make sense - and the further you progress - the more things need checking. For example after a certain day all immigrating workers also need a working permit, and the game expands upon this more and more the further you go.  If you make a correct decision, you earn money. If you make too many incorrect decisions - you have to pay a fine. Simple as that.  Paper checking is done by dragging and dropping the documents on your tiny desk (you well need to do A LOT of paperwork readjustments on your tiny wooden table in the late game) and comparing the given documents to the 'Rules and Regulations'. If there are inconsistencies, you need to highlight a the incorrect thing in the passport (or any given document) and the corresponding rule that states that it is incorrect. Simple as that, but it sounds utterly confusing in text. After you have done this - the passport needs to be stamped with either 'Access Granted' or 'Denied'.  Basically it's like a paperwork simulator!  Based on your successes at the job, you then need to make sure you can pay for your family's nourishment and the heat in your apartment. So if you have a bad day - they might just starve to death and you are game over. And just to screw you up, occasionally it turns out you need to feed your sick uncle and mother or whathaveyou.  STORY2: Now i know, i have already talked about the story, but this game's gameplay is like its story that's why i pick it up again. It's an odd interweaving of events that make your decisions of letting people through - or not - matter. Basically every immigrant has something unique to say (the writing is excellent btw), but some of them are even more unique and the plot is dictated by whether or not you let them through. But there is no indication that this is the case, which is what makes this game so awesome in the first playthrough. You have this really weird feeling sometimes that the games got you by the balls, and you have this strange fear of screwing up. It must be the weirdest thing i have played and there is nothing i can really compare it to - but it has this really deep atmosphere, like in Gothic 1 - the first time you played it 15 years ago. That's as accurate as i can get, and i know comparing it to a 3D open world RPG from 200X must seem ridiculous, but that might just prove how crazy this game is.  AUDIO: Super crisp paper sounds. I mean seriously. Stamping a document in this game is as satisfying as firing a gun in an immersive fps! So odd...  Now i know this review might not manage to sum up the game in it's entirety - but due to the fact that it is very story reliant, i would probably start spoiling the fun if i wrote more. Just get it and be surprised by it.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

Basically a lot of ♥♥♥♥ Hannah Arendt said about totalitarian regimes persisting by normalizing their totalitarian policies in the eyes of their constituents: the videogame. Play it if you want to experience the banality of evil firsthand, or if you just like stamping stuff.

A great, original game. Get this game if you're an immortal with only $10 to spend on the rest of eternity. Sure it might be repetitive, but the atmosphere and music compensate. This game is a nice break from the common gore and mmo of a lot of popular games today.

The X-Ray scanner is a horrifically unwelcome addition- people are hideous.  Pixels, papers, and political undertones. Oh, and poverty, poor health, perishing people, and several other things that start with 'p'. This game has 'p' all over it.

Have you ever wondered what it'd be like to experience actual emotions from a video game, Literally feel good/like a pile of poop/helpess/happy/pants crappingly afraid/paranoid, etc?   Then play Papers Please. If all those sorta things don't appeal to you, then go back to your First Person, cover based shooter. There is a gun in this, but it won't satisfy your cakey dull brain.

First time I've been compelled to write a review.   This game is amazing! Original and interesting plot, that keeps you coming back for more!  Pros: Original Plot Fun Game Mechanics New Twists (Bombings, secret missions, fights) Many more features in game. A ton of content for an indie game.  endless mode! Me: 'Papers, Please.' ME: 'This isn't you' *DETAIN* HIM: 'You fools better not touch me.' GUARD: 'OUT!' HIM: 'I will explode like wild tiger!' *rifle butt to head* *dragged out, presumably to die* ME: 'NEXT!'  Unique game. Must play.

Having seen many immigrants in my own country that is located somewhere next to the South China Sea, Papers, Please is a great thriller that challenges you to be an immigrant officer who either approves or reject immigrant for the glory of Arstotzka.  The UI is simple to understand and use while the overall presentation reminded me of the good old school graphics of the late 80s which I enjoy a lot (brought up with Sierra adventure games). The low resolution display couple with the limited colour help to enhance the abstract feel of the game with the player filling in the extra details in their own mind.  Papers, Please can be quite addicting one you get to know the core gameplay with 'one more immigrant to process' that will leave you wanting for more.

You're a tiny cog beneath a soul-crushing bureaucracy. I struggled to manage the ever-increasing immigration controls and paperwork yet still move the line along. You're paid per person. I faced corrupt guards, mysterious visitors and various others at the gates, all while my family died from cold, starvation and illness. I took bribes, looked the other way and sent strangers to their doom just to eat and maybe keep the heat on. At last, I gave up and just let everyone in. Being sent to prison was a reprieve.  What this game set out to do, it does well. Glory to Arstotzka.
