I really really like this game. It is intense, it makes you think. Basically you work at a checkpoint, and you choose who gets to enter the country or not. You have to look through their papers and determine if there are any discrepencies. Then you stamp their visa green for entry or red for denial.   Each day the rules change, different papers are needed or no longer needed, and sometimes you can be bribed to let people in etc. You have to choose when to break the rules and their are consquences for doing such.  Overall an intense and creative game, i have never seen anything quite like it and I recommend it to anyone who likes using their brain to solve problems.
Day 3. My child is sick and starving.  Do i regret it nope. >.<.  It is a fun game and its not for everyone, many people will trick you and you will regret it in the end.

Compact, solid, little game, It's got a fairly simple plot, on the surface, yet it manages to be deep and engaging. Characters have not all that much screen time, but somehow manage to endear themselves to players in the time they have. Gameplay can be broken up into short bite size chunks, which keeps the game from getting boring. My only issue is that the game is too short... I would have loved more of Arstozka. Good value for money, just wish there was a sequel or expansion! Been recommending this game to friends, and no one has anything bad to say about it!

Oh man, this game. It's really interesting, but it's so draining. I feel like Lucas Pope did an excellent job of capturing the essence of what life would be like in a job like this. Extremely well-done, I say.
This is a simple, yet complex game. Even though there are scripted triggers, the multitude of endings increases the replayability.   I would love to see and update to it.

There is so much to be said about Papers, Please. I prefer to say it's the most mind-rattling and gut-wrenching game out there, for the people looking for games that leave you emotionally scarred, this is what you're looking for. There's no great tragedy, no brave hero turned evil. Just you, trying to support your family, and being forced to make decisions. One day in the newspaper you get a profile on this man named Vincent, who killed some people in a different country. Then, the next day you might see him in the booth. Do you let him in? Or, are you willing to potentially take a citation? These many, small, choices affect your entire playthrough, and it's a wonderous experience throughout.

You will genuinely be surprised by how interesting a game which is principally based around confirming the legitimacy of documents can be.  Aesthetically pleasing, morally challenging and completely innovative. Buy it.
Its a fun game that try's to really challange your skills in Deductive reasoning and working in a fictional land of radical authoritarian nationalism.

Great game but only when you start getting good at it. Helps if you write out some info from the manual on paper. Things like Issueing cities, entry and work permit stamps and the districts of Arstotzka.  Glory to Arstotzka.

WAY more fun than it sounds. Art style evokes 'Glorious Motherland' dystopia feel well. Shuffling papers around is surprisingly tense. Time limits and a family to feed are a lot of pressure. Storyline is very interesting. Morality and ethics come into play often. You work for the corrupt government, but you have to make money to take care of yourself. Even more (spoilery) stuff comes in later. Seriously, it's really good. Glory to Arstotzka.

ID states female, but looks like a man. Interrogate person with discrepancy. Me: 'Are you woman?' Them: 'What is this question?' Me: 'You have been randomly selected for a search.' Xray shows a bomb on her butt. Detained.  Would check ID again. 10/10

Papers, Please had me hooked for a short while. In a weird, yet fun way I would start it up, bob my head to the music, and pretend that I was 'going to work' again.   The game starts you off tame and picks up momentum, forcing you to remember initial tasks and methods while learning new ones each day that passes. I had great fun in these mini-games (if that is what you would call them) such as denying a citizen or finding that tiny discrepency that allowed me to use an X-ray and find that contraband or weapon only to have the poor person hauled away (most likely for execution).   However, for whatever reason I stopped playing and although I have thought about picking back up where I left off several times over the past few months, I haven't been able to get myself to do so. This is where I ultimately land with this game, that is, its fun if you play it and stick with it (and if you have an interest in this sort of puzzle-ish, organizational memory-game). However, if you allow any amount of time in between playthroughs that is too great, I think you'll find it somewhat tedious and difficult to get back into the swing of things. If I were to go back now, I'd have to basically re-learn everything from the beginning just to keep up with where I was when I left off - and this is not the most appealing thought, at least to me.   Papers, Please is unique and definitely well crafted. The gameplay is tight, the visuals have a pleasing, retro feel, and the challenge is definitely there for those that love to one-up themselves on a second or third playthrough. It just, for several reasons mentioned and not (as I'm sure I missed a few), doesn't hold my interest enought to want to actually play it - and this is why I'd give P,P a 7.5/10.   Maybe it's just not for me after all.... :/

Damn, is this game tricky. Not in the 'How do I get past this jump that looks impossible?' way, but the 'How the hell did I miss that?!' way.  Your goal is to get as many people through the border checkpoint as possible without breaking the rules. The more people that you deal with, the more you get paid. But the rules change day by day and based on what actions you take; let a bomber through? The day ends and you have new rules to follow. Miss a violation? Do that 3 times and you lose money for the 3rd time on. If you were on your own I could care less, but you have 4 other family members to take care of so every penny counts. 5 days into my first playthrough and my Son is dead, my Uncle is sick and everyone is cold and hungry... holy ♥♥♥♥.  It's bleak, the art style has you wondering where the nearest suicide booth is and generally it's just a dull trudge to get your guy through each day on the job and not kill your entire family... so in that sense, it's what I imagine working in the formor Soviet bloc was like.  Definatly a game that I count as an 'art game', but not one that relies on weird visuals and wonky mechanics to try and evoke something in the player. This game has smile mechanics and a washed-out color pallet that, again, makes it feel as if you really are trudging through each work day and just managing to get by. Just from that, it does what it set out to do and evokes something in the player.   It's worth picking up if you can find it cheap or on sale. There's not a lot of story here aside frrom the newspaper articles you get at the start of each workday to help you ID potential problems and some interesting dystopian elements mixed in with the immagrants, but it's worth playing to see a simple concept done right.
I wasn't really expecting much from this game, but I decided to give it a try and I am glad that I did. It is really quite interesting. Glory to Arstotzka!

Do you love stamping papers? Love checking expiration dates and checking sex?  Well do these people have a game for you!    While it is reviewing papers and such, it is almost relaxing ...Not sure why.
A unique, simple and challenging game with an interesting story and characters. Definitely one of the best indie games out there today.

Player choice and story telling made right. If you thought choosing between several answers in a dialog between fighting your way through enemies is the pinnacle of modern gaming you haven't played Papers, Please. This game puts you into the shoes of a father in a dystopian world and congratulations! You have won the job lottery and are now stationed at the border of your glorious country and are responsible for checking the documents of everyone trying to get in. Will you be fast enough to earn enough money to pay for food and heating for your family? Can you afford to let the poor friendly guy through even though you can't afford another mistake for today? Do you feel alright, scanning everyone who comes through? If you think checking papers can't be entertaining let this game prove you wrong! This a game to introduce gaming to sceptic people, showing how enriching of an experience it can be if you open yourself to it.
It is a fun game at first but gets boring later on. it gets grindy.
It doesn't seem like much from the outside, but this game is pretty fun. You turn into a border control machine after the first couple of playthroughs.

This game unrealisticly portrays there being negative consequences for strict adherance to rules. RULES MUST BE FOLLOWED!  The people at the checkpoint who break the rules are bringing it upon themselves and you cannot be held responsible for what happens to them. Not at all.

this has to be the most pointless 'game' I've ever played. seriously, don't waste your time or money on this utter garbage. the game already knows if you're wrong or right and there is absolutely no room for error - human error or otherwise. there is no story line, there is no story for that matter - your actions prove to be utterly in consiquential as you will be penalised regarless of your actions. don't buy this rubbish... seriously

This game is just  brilliant . I'd like to give kudos to the creator, Lucas Pope, who did about everything (code, artwork, sound, story) this is a darn good accomplishment, and even more so with its success.  However, like many games it's  not for everyone . Its not an action/shooter/platformer twitch reaction type game (though a few segments are reflex based). Its closer to a 'point and click' or a 'spot the differences' type game, only many times there aren't any differences and/or there's multiple actions you could perform with various results some long term.  What would normally be considered work is somehow fun in this game. I don't quite understand it which piques my interest even more. Verifying passports and documents and stamping them sounds like a terrible game, but somehow its not. Trust me after the first few days/levels you'll be questioning why this is fun.  The story mode is great and builds up the difficulty as you progress. It is also rather humorous and as previously mentioned some decisions have reprecussions later in the game. The save system is great; saving for each day and allows you to go back to any previous day and start a new timeline and make different choices save each day of the new timeline.  Once you 'beat' the game, basically finish each levels/days   and escape   you unlock the endless modes. Where you can compete globally or locally/against yourself or just play for fun in 4 different modes with 4 different difficulty levels (in effect 16 combinations).  There are 20 different 'endings' I believe, several are being jailed/executed for different reasons, some have a 'happy' ending at least as happy as an ending can be in a dystopia, some are based on decisions you make halfway through the game. On top of the endings to complete there are various tokens and achievements to get if you are into that sort of thing. These last few things and endless modes give replayability but not an enourmous amount; 5-15 hours I'd say maybe more if you're a completionist and/or very competitive.  If you are into puzzle/mind thinking games pick this up. If you just want to kill terrorists/robots/aliens/monsters/etc then as I said at the beginning, this isn't for you.
A Man walks into my Checkpoint:  Me: Your Passport says you're a woman. Man?: Yes, I know.  -9.5/10
Great game!  It may be too easy once you get used to it.  But, you would enjoy a lot this game ~30 hours. Must play!
This is the only game to have ever done moral choice correctly.
An incredibly fun and addictive game, there's lots of replay value too as there are 20 different endings. i can't stop playing it honestly :)
my computer can run this i r8 gr8
Fun game, love the story and the quirks to it. Probably not for everyone
Played this in beta and it was awesome then, now in full release it has a few upgrades. I've never played anything like it <3
About as fun as a game about sorting paper sounds
Paper work has never been so fun.
I put this on my resume when I became a Customs Agent. Got the job  10/10
If you are looking for a very fun game with an intersting concept, then you will find it in Papers, Please. (it's only $10 and worth it.)
i feel like im a nazi finding out who's a jew and who's german  11/10

This game's kind of depressing, so it's hard to play a lot of it. But it's pretty impressive. It did a good job of giving me the feeling of being in the person's shoes and got me to think about how I might act in those situations. It also taught me that it sucks to live in cold-war era Slavic countries. It presents you with interesting moral choices. So if you're looking for a game that's not necessarily 'fun,' but one that's insightful, go here.
Cool game!

Want to review alot of documents? No? That's what I thought as well, until I got Papers, Please.   This game is incredibly unique, It's hard to find anything like this. This game is not for everyone, if you prefer action packed games, Papers, Please is definetly a game that you will not be intersted in. Every little detail in this game matters, and missing something, or taking too long to make sure you don't miss anything, could kill a family member. Another thing about this game is choice. Many people will give you the wrong papers, But will try and bribe you with Money, or a sad story. You can let this people in and risk your job, or just follow the rules and deny them. There is no right answer, and you can never be a good person. It's deppressing, and while they have 20 different endings, none of them are really a 'Good' ending. I've played through this game 6 times, and I still have fun with this game, but I doubt many people will play this game more than twice. I would recommended this to many people, but don't be expected a standard sort of game.   8/10.   Glory to Arstotzka.
Get This Game Its Awesome Doing The Fun Stamps 'Approve Deny Deny Detain Deny Deny Detain'

This games is so good. If your thinking about buying it, buy it. It's absolutely worth the price. It's fun to play while making you question your own morals and giving an simplified insight into how a system can become corrupt. Also as some one who struggles with things like filing and sorting papers due to dyslexia, it was actually quite helpful at getting practise to work out a system to deal with paper work.

Wow, this game is so realistic that it made me feel I was really an immigration inspector, risking my life to make some money for my poor family. This game includes sacrifice, as I had to decline the most innocent people to get my money's worth; which was very hard to do irl. Also, I had to make the biggest decision of making my son happy by buying him THE MOST EXPENSIVE CRAYON KIT I HAVE EVAR SEEN FOR 25 DOLLA, or buying cheaper medicine for my dying relatives. Its either get a beetiful drawn picture, or have my relatives live. I guess that's probably an easy choice.  I also think its the best FPS game I evar played and the most realistic one. Better than CoD, Battlefield, Counter-Strike, Gears of War, Halo, etc., combined. Two weapons, best first person view for instant killing!  GG and GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA  ~ 9/10  IGN

Papers Please is a game in which you take the role of a new Border inspector for the 'glorious' country of Arstotzka. The first thing I noticed about this game was the music. Masterfully composed, it conveyed the perfect feelings through out the game. Your first objective is to make enough money for food and heat for your family, though other things will come up quickly, emptying your pockets. Quickly you come into contact with the mysterious organization: The Order Of the EZIC star. I quickly fell in love with the organization attempting to save a failing dystopian civilization and decided to help them. You can choose not to as well. I recomend this ghame to anyone who find the premice and the gameplay interesting. My final score for this game is: 8.75/10
this game is like as addicting as heroine 10/10
Not kidding, its actually a fun game.

Glory to Arstotzka indeed. The game seems simple from the get go, but actually gets increasingly hard and stressful as time goes on when you have to check so many details, keep your family warm and fed (And giving medicine to your damn son who has the weakest immune system in history), and then let your morality decide for you when you need to let undocumented people through like the soccer player, or the married couple when the wife has no papers. Also following or denying the Order is intense. There are so many endings, and I've only just cracked the tip of the iceberg with them.
Can't...stop...playing...  Great very original game, and cheap too. Laptop/older computer friendly.
glory to arstotzka comrade
You will find this idea weird until you play it. Then you will not stop playing it. Ever.
So simple, yet very entertaining.

This game is a really interesting concept with some great ideas. It builds great amounts of tension and stress. It does, however, feel a little too much like hard work. It's becomes a chore to go through every paper and can get a little tedius id played for too long. Still, had a good experience with it and it's a good example on how games can still be fresh and entertaining without the need of AA graphics.
a very good game      glory to arstotska
This is a really weird and at the same time (I don't know if it's the right word for it!) enjoyable experience. Highly recommend it, especially to people who want something new.
Surprisingly good. Basic gameplay mechanics yet very appealing.

Never did I think that a game with graphics that make MS-DOS games feel groundbreaking, a repeditive gameplaym barely any sound mentionable, shallow story and few objectives could be so good, This game really show that the sum is greater than it's parts. I don't know what is with this game but it is magical.  Basically the game is about you being a border guard checking papers at a border between two fictional nations. It all gives the impression being in some sort of eastern-European state during behind the iron curtain during the Soviet era. Your task is to either admit och reject those who seek to enter based on the papers provided and the requirements set by your superiors. You simply scan these papers for faults. You have to do this fast enough to feed your poor family as the time is limited and you are paid per person reviewed. All errors lead to a salary reduction. Sometimes you stand between wrong admitting a person who just wish to be with its beloved, sometimes to accept bribes and sometimes you choose between aiding a terrorist organisation or fact the consequenses of not doing so.  I suppose it is all the context of the game that makes the magic. You strangely enough get sucked into it.
Is good game. Is best game. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
This game makes me stress out. So much work to, so little time.
Simple, Clever and a hell of a lot of fun! Everyone should own this game.
THIS GAME IS GREAT! It's such a simple but addictive game! Plus the 20 different endings makes it easy to stay involved with it.
My entire family is dead. 10/10.
Just started the endless mode, great game. Can't stop playing.

'Papers, Please' is a mesmerizing game that presents you with moral dilemmas that test your loyalty to your family and country, your commitment to your work, your ability to show or suppress compassion, and your desire to rise above your lot in life to make a difference. The game designer managed to accomplish all this in an elaborately crafted branching narrative, told through a simple, though somewhat repetitive, immigration investigation game. It's definitely a game that will appeal more to the cerebral gamers.

Papers, Please is a masterpiece. Intuitive, tense, flow-inducing, yet deep and varied gameplay, perfectly contextualized to expose the subtext of its mechanics. Every interaction is both a skill-testing challenge and a moral expression that contributes to a simultaneously emergent and crafted, branching narrative, achieved through precisely modulated procedural generation. This game is meaningful, resonant, and features more cohesive, focused integration of story into gameplay and vice versa than I have ever seen. That it was a low-budget, one-man operation merely makes the state of AAA games all the more shameful by comparison.
Documents, Please
It is a funny game.....
It's one of the best game I played in the last year.  Pixel art never get oldy only Classic!

Very interesting and original little game ! It's amazing how its minimalism conjures atmosphere, much like a good book. I like how the story unfolds (and changes depending on your choices) while you do your seemengly unimportant, mundane job.   Glory to Arstotzka !

Papers Please is a game that is at once brilliant and depressing. It has multiple endings, of which I'm sure I may only truly play through to two or three.  It has a gripping storyline despite being about one of the most boring parts of any profession-- doing paperwork. That said, it is a game that goes out of its way to make you uncomfortable. The moral choices you have to make throughout, and the cramped, claustrophobic nature of the game's layout is brilliant, and unnerving.   In short, it is excellent, but not a game I would play very often after completing it. Definitely worth the purchase, however! It is one of the most unique gaming experiences I've had.
Graphics are basic and the game is tough to win, but really addictive and fun to figure out. Excellent stratgy game and entertaining (if dark) humour.

I got this game in a bundle of others and for the longest time thought that it was a bit of a joke. Checking passport numbers? pictures? stamping card? oh, what incredible fun </sarcasm>  Then, I played it... Sure, memorising the countries, major towns, districts and keeping an eye on the date was a pain... but when sabotage, espionage, complicated underlying struggles of day-to-day life and the strange memory of my time doing similar things as an actual job... I am actually enjoying this game! hang on, need to scan someone for a bomb because their weight does not add up to their ID card. Their city matches, but I saw them earlier with a fake passport! I need to make sure I don't let a terrorist through or it might be me they blow up next! ACK! I didn't check the name on that last worker permit! After stuffing up the forged stamp on the other two, i'm getting my pay docked! Thank goodness i'm in with a guard who'se cutting me a slice of his bonus for my arresting folks with illegal info or I wouldn't be able to feed my family, pay for my sick mother-in-law's medicine or keep the house warm... I'm trying to save up for a bigger apartment too, but I doubt i'm going to get enough money after that incident with the secret sect I turned in...  It's not for everyone, but if you have a halfway decent memory (or a handy note-book like me) you will do well from the get-go. Work fast, focus hard and provide for your family...  Stay sly, work on the side and crack the code given to you be smart, keep yourself under the radar and don't get arrested. Day by day, you will face discrete small-world problems... but other days, you may find you help make the news!  This is not your standard game. This is a bit of a work-sim! I think this should be played in schools to teach kids to spot-check info quickly. There's a strange beauty to this game!  You won't believe it until you try it!
This game is satisfyingly discouraging. Play it and you'll know what I mean. ;)

Papers, Please is a very fun and addicting game. It starts out pretty simple but after a few days you'll find yourself struggling to keep your family from starving. Make choices that will affect the entire nation and shape its fictional history. Overall a very fun game. I recommend it highly.

Have you ever wanted to scour paper after paper for the smallest of inconsistancies, hear the sob stories of countless individuals hoping to flee from terrible places to a slightly less terrible place, get berated by your boss for the smallest of screw-ups and force yourself into moral grey areas involving the family you never really get to see and immigrants with no where else to go? Yes? Then Papers, Please is the game for you. Much has been made of the immersive world born from this simple paperwork simulator, and, from what I've experienced myself, its no joke. I could feel the world around me turn grayer as I delved into the glorious land of Arstozka. Its a world that terrifies and interests me in equal measure. If you want an experience like no other, this is the game for you.
The worst idea for a game ever.  10/10. Loved every minute.
Awesome ~40mb of Art! :)

Death in video games is something that usually has little impact upon a player. You routinely kill thousands upon thousands of virtual foes and death or failure means teleporting back to a checkpoint. But here, death and failure are extremely psychologically taxing. The sound of a printing citation telling me that 5 credits would be deducted from my pay because I misprocessed someone was a sound that I dreaded and made me flinch everytime I heard it, because it meant I wouldn't be able to cure a family member of disease. A friend died and I replayed a day 6 times over just so that I could save him, because he was the only friend I had. The pixel art faces that come up to your door begin to feel more human than most video game characters rendered in 3D. This game is a masterpiece.

Surprisingly one of the most intense games I've played! So many difficult decisions while trying to keep a family from starving...While a terrorist plot evolves before your eyes...Very interesting gameplay, puts a lot of pressure on the player if you get into it.

A lot more fun than I would have initially thought. My friend told me about this game and I thought 'What's so fun about being a border guy?' and I've never looked back!  Great game a lot more fun that expected, definitley worth the buy.
The best and most fun CBP training out there! 10/10
Very entertaining. Though it looks rough around the edges, it gives you some laughs as well as great gameplay. Get it on sale it is a steal. Glory to Arstotzka!
This is a great game. It tells an amazing story, that ends up being the most depressing greatest story ever. If you get a chance to play this game, PLAY IT!

This game is absolute brilliance. The graphics, the sound and the music all fit quite well with the setting and theme of the game. The gameplay itself is quite simple, get some documents, verify their authenticity, approve or deny entry. You might need to shoot a couple of people along the way. This game basically made me feel like being a Customs Officer because of how fun the game was.  Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who appreciates a well polished indie game.

This game is really something else. I can't believe how great the story and the graphics play along (and the sound is really compelling). If you like to see how it goes with a theme of mental issues and loyalty to the people (or to governments) you should really play this game. It's both addictive and daunting. For me it's a must have.
Supricingly entertaining and extremely addicting. Yet another game proves to be great without needing all that crap AAA titles get. 7/10

This game is nice and you can have fun playing it.  If you dont have it yet, I recommend on buying it, but beware that there's not so much replay value. After 10h or so, you already have been through the main story and there's not much left to see.  PS: Dont worry, its waaaay longer than Gone Home :p
GLORY TO ARISTOKA FELLOW ARISTOKANS! Check papers for much money, and many terrorist threats!
Highly recommended.
NA
Definitely worth a look. I haven't actually got all the endings and I sort of got a bit over the game... but still worth a look.

This is a game that sounds bad on paper, one which has been falsified and you will be escorted by these nice men with guns to the nearest sorting office. NEXT.  But seriously, the game is simply you as a normal guy stamping passports at a communist checkpoint. Money is per person sorted and jesus do you need ever cent you can get, which makes the genuinely nice and needy people really hard to allow through. It says alot of just how miserable people can be and how easy it is to just do your job and let the misery solve itself, or you can do something about it. Stamping papers provides a absorbing experience where you get into a grove of stamping efficently to the point where any interuptions to the method like wall jumpers or bombers provide a insight on just how routine life can be. Its unnerving when you think about it. Anyway the game provides insight and the rules it gives you provide context and excellent challange that escelates nicely.
If you haven't played this game yet, just do. It's awesome! It's really cool to see how the simplest of gameplay can turn into a super immersive experience.

Hello, comrade. I have excellent game for you! Is cheap, and will make you feel amazing. Bright colours, beautiful women, good music. We have all here! I not lie, feel good game of decade! Buy now! Glory to Arstotska!    Death to Kolechia.
Paperwork has never been this fun and humourous.

This is THE finest 'paperwork processing beaurocrat in an opressive dictatorship' sim that I have ever played. The simple act of allowing / denying entry into your little hell-hole country plays out in fascinating and complex ways.  Papers Please is a unique treat that should not be missed by players with patience and a brain. A+

In short, I enjoyed this game quite a bit. I'm the kind of person that enjoys actions that require thought, vigilance, and has an impact and purpose, despite it maybe looking mundane from afar. This game is an execptional example of how something that looks sooooo boring can honestly be fun. Each decision, wether done correctly or not, will either compromise your morals, or your family. I feel that this game balances it's new concepts exceptionally well, although maybe failling once to see that you need to do more things faster. I truly am addicted to this game. The characters, though short lived, and few make reappearances, have thier own story. It is amazing how this game says so much about a single character through their face, and a few short sentences. The endings are grim and plentiful, always imbuing a sense of ridiculous failure despite the game's often unreasonable difficulty (which I don't think is a flaw in the game, but more an element of the world [or at least the countriy] the characters lives in). I reccomend this game to people that enjoy the story in a game more than the gameplay, because the only way of the gameplay evolves is through adding more things to do on top of what you already have, making each immigrant more time-consuming to deal with each day. I can't really say that more action orriented gamers or people with low attention spans will enjoy this. Also, if you have a low threshold for sad events, you probably won't like this game either.  This game recieves a 8/10 I feel it hits most of the marks I look for in a game. The story is enthralling, the presentation is absolutley stunning, but the gameplay is somewhat lacking variety and kind of repetive. I haven't found all the endings yet, not even close, but I expect that the true ending (did I mention this game has 40 endings?) will be fulfilling or, more likely, disasterous.
An extremely clever game concept, which I am always happy to see, and monotonously fun gameplay.
Most original game of the last decade: 10/10

Love the soundtrack. For some reason it never becomes irritating. Love the depressing mood and atmosphere, the tough choices you have to make, and the colorful characters you meet. A very good game overall.

This game absolutely feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job in a totalitarian regime. Miss one small detail, and get reprimanded. Miss some more, and lose some of your pay. Bureaucracy gets ever more complicated. You arrest people, turn them away, tear families apart. Your own family is going to be hungry, sick and freezing most of the time. Wow, just wow. If this description intrigues you only a tiny bit, absolutely get it.
Depressing.  Play at least once. Begin and continue therapy thereafter.
You'd assume this job/game would be boring but it definitely captures your interest and attention to detail . Would recommend for shiggles
A work of art.

Papers please at first might seem like a game that is boring on paper, but if you have even slight OCD, this game is TOTALLY for you. There is several endings, and the dry humor in the game makes the game worthwhile.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Helped the resistance, starved my family. 10/10.
Oscar goes to Papers Please for best Indie Game
A stunningly simple, but addicting and different little indie title. Worth asmall sum for hours of entertainment.
There's something strangely soothing about clerical work.
You're a border guard in a cold war era soviet nation. It's much more fun than you think.
This game is pretty addicting for how simple it is.
So addictive, and makes you feel really bad about some choices. Would definitely recommend this game, I mean, it's only $9.99, and don't let the style of graphics fool you.

Every turn starts with you asking rather politely for papers. However the politeness ends there. The rest of the game is quite rude and tugs on your heartstrings in places. The X-Ray scanner is a horrifically unwelcome addition- people are hideous.  Pixels, papers, and political undertones. Oh, and poverty, poor health, perishing people, and several other things that start with 'p'. This game has 'p' all over it.

Papers, Please starts low, but even in the beginning the dark, dystopian theme draws you in. The simple mechanics quickly become a desperate race as you try to serve as many potential border-crossers as you can before the end of your shift. The cost of failure could very well be the life of a family member, or imprisonment. The game has a gripping story, and I must honestly say I have lost sleep playing this game. 10/10

A sublime example of what an interactivity can achieve. 'Papers, Please' achieves that same effect as 'Hotline Miami', catching you up in a taxing gameplay loop that dehumanises your actions, before suddenly making you aware of what exactly you are doing. It forces you to make tough decisions andit forces you to become a person you don't like. It's a better tester of morals and principles that anything I've come across.  A masterpiece.

Superb example of storytelling weaved with original gameplay. Well written and game design so that actually drives people to roleplay the character and project themsleves in very interesting moral themes.
An absolute must play.   Papers, Please has an incredible narrative, atmosphere and complexity, and is one of the few games I've come across where I truly question my actions and motivations.
I originally thought this game was bad, but after playing it, it is actually an ok game. 8/10
For those with a very sharp eye, this is a good game. For me, it's a very hard game. I love the challenge though, as it definitely sharpens my observation skills.
This is easily one of the most unique games you will ever play, and as a fascism/human rights/communism simulator with 20 endings, it's well worth the price of admission.

Really intriguing. More importantly the chore (not game) helps me feel less pathetic while I'm doing mine. And...have to say it is very indiscreet for EZIC to select me (who did whatever he told me to do only to   make ends meet and then got arrested  ) as comrade.   9.5/10 (The 0.5 is for appraising the value of Elisa's gift)
lol, hand drawn pasport, make me smile a little :v

This game is fun. Not in the action packed seat of your pants way but in the fact that after the tenth, twentieth or so individual you process, you begin to see them as just ID papers and such, not as human beings. Balancing your morality in helping a husband and wife stay together even when one's passport is expired, at the expense of maybe not making rent or being able to feed your kids or buy them medicine makes for an exciting balance between doing your job and being a human being. it's a lot of fun, even if the pictures and trailer make it seem mundane.

Its nice to see a game that can make my sympathize with my enemy in such a through but petty way. I've always thought of immigration officers as a specific kind of demon. All and all, this is the best paperwork simulator ever made and I'mnot sure thats a compliment. Good fun!
One of the most original games I have played in years. Highly recommend.

You play a border inspector of a soviet-ish country. Its surprsingly challenging and addictive. The way the stories develop and the choices it forces you to make are also interesting. We wound up playing days over again to try out different decisions.   It sort of feels like a 90s era mac game, both graphically and in terms of the mechanics. You have a desktop where you investigate paperwork with limited space, and you have to pick up the papers and move them on to the desktop, etc.  Check it out!

At first glance, 'Papers, Please' might appear to be a monotonous, boring game. However, after a few minutes you discover this isn't the case at all. It really does a wonderful job of pulling you into the story and ramps the difficulty up until it becomes amazingly difficult to meet your quota. Each day begins with a new rule to use when deciding to allow people into the country or deny them. Don't let enough people though? Looks like your family doesn't eat that day. Make too many mistakes? Go to jail. Let in the wrong person? Right this way, comrade -- we have some questions for you. We'll find a new worker.   An amazing experience and highly recommended. I love it.  Glory to Arstotzka!
NEVER BEFORE HAVE I BEEN SO HONOURED TO BE A BOARDER GUARD FOR MY COUNTRY. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA
This game is somewhat depressing, but a great game to play nonetheless.

Very strange and innovative game, I really liked it. It becomes pretty difficult, after some time. Try it if you're looking for a different and kind of realistic game. It's not 'funny', but really enjoyable.

Nice little gem, got it on sale, well worth it! Kinda starts feeling like work after you've played for a while (I think this is part of the charm, plus I may have played for too long at a time) but there is plenty to explore in the early parts of the game as well as some very creative writing. I'm impressed with its ability to make you actually care about the avatar's family and the immigrants he processes through the daily grind of his work.

This is a great game that can make you feel terrible for trying to keep your family safe, fed, and warm at the expense of well meaning people who just haven't caught a break in trying to enter your country.

You are the border inspector, tasked with validating documents. It is as dull as it sounds, but the time and money constraints, coupled with great story and actually meaningful choices make this a surprisingly great game.
need a lot of patience but is a great game. must be observant.
I thought it was stupid... got it in steam sale... Glory to Aristostka...

Oddly enough, this game is far more interesting than I thought at first hand.  There is alot of humor, it's 'stressfull' to check everything (In a good way), and you get punished right away for mistakes. It's one of the odd and quirky games that you either love or hate.  I'd give this one a 8/10 to be fair, it's rather entertaining, and the graphics are ideal for the game along with the sound.
Small simple game, fantastic story and challenging playthrough. Multiple endings make this games replayability addicting.
Nothing more satisfying than denying foreigners into your motherland!

A lot of people at the interwebs have hyped this game a lot, and they have also said pretty much anything that there is to say about it. I suppose I can try to summarize my own thoughts about it though. So here we go.  This game does exactly what it sets out to do. It puts you into some interesting situations, and your choises will have en effect on your own story. I really like this system that they have, and I also like the fact that there are many different endings you can get. Get arrested, get your entire family killed and so on. Real fun stuff.  It is quite interesting to interact with people in this game. You meet them, they give you papers, you check them, and the people leave. But sometimes, things can go very different. People can attack the border,give you secret messages, and beg for you to let them into the country when they don't own a passport. You can choose how you handle those situations. Brake the law in order help someone, or arrest a murderer without having proof.   The game does get harder when you get closer to the end. More things to remember, more choises to make and more papers to please I mean check. However, this does mean that the start of the game is not nearly as interesting as the end game.The length of Papers, please pretty much debends on your own skill. I'd say that clearing all 31 days does take about 5-6 hours. However, I don't really think that this game has huge amounts of replay value. Sure you can try to unlock all the endings, but I highly doubt that most people will.  So do I think that Papers, Please is worth all the hype? I would not say so. Don't get me wrong, I do like the game, I would even call it pretty good. But I still think that some people give it way too much credit. My overall rating for Papers, Please is a 7 out of 10. Simplistic yet complicated. The theme of the game is captured perfectly, while also evolving with each day you progress in the game. Great replay value, definitely would recommend it.

This is a silly little game which will suck you in, and make you spend hours playing it. You play the role of a border agent who is responsible for letting people in to a soviet era country. The game starts out simply enough where you just allow locals in, and deny foreigners access, but the difficulty ramps up quickly, where you need to start checking for forged passports and other documents.  There is a bit of a story line which I've only gotten a glimpse of. There are also some moral decisions to make as to whether or not to grant access to people, who don't have the correct documents but claim that they are in danger. Do you risk your limited income to possibly save someone, do you take a bribe from a smuggler, or do you play by the rules?
Many games advertise 'tough moral choices w/ consequences', few actually deliver on their promise. This one certainly does.

8/10: Work loyally as border inspector, decide who may enter glorious homeland or return from whence they came. Survive attacks and thwart smugglers until audit comes at the end of thirty days! Glory to Arstotzka!   This game is heavy. The atmosphere is heavy, with the only music being the deep march of the starting screen. Meanwhile, the graphics, reminiscent of NES graphics and earlier, combine well with the garbled speech that only ever seems to sound like 'gestaht' (gestalt? get out? pretty authoritative and germanic sounding) or 'hayaku' (japanese for faster?). Even the core action is heavy, forcing you to focus on the tedium of finding discrepancies in the paperwork of immigrants lest you return home with less pay for food and heating.   Yet just because it isn't strictly fun in the 'Saints Row' sense of reckless abandon and indulgence, doesn't mean 'Papers, Please' isn't engaging. The stress of living out each day, pulled between the attention of your family, your country, and the enigmatic Order of the EZIC Star. Loyalty has its rewards, but any inkling of seditiouis activity may lead to a most miserable end. Thus, it is up to you who to help, both on an individual level and on society at large.   Personally, I was intrigued by the procedurally generated people interspersed between the scheduled characters. Jorji Costava was undoubtedly the one glimmer of comic relief amongst the procession of separated families and sly smugglers. Right when I saw that passport from 'Cobrastan' I knew he'd be my number one source of warnings, though I thankfully managed to never have pay taken away via excessive citations.  While I generally took pride in getting no citations and returning with plenty for my family, I took exception with truly momentous events, especially since I wanted to get all the foreign coins in one playthrough. In particular, reuniting Sergiu with his love was sweet, and there was a grim satisfaction in going along with the vengeful fathers plan to murder Simon Wens, the man who killed his daughter.   Nonetheless, this is definitely a melancholy game as a whole, and is all the better for it. Rather than the shiny, happy veneer one might find in free to play or corporate games, 'Papers, Please' confronts the anxiety of being an unassuming, yet critical, cog in the machine. Feeling powerless, yet potentially influencing the development of these shifting nations, with you being the decider of who permeates the membrane between them. It's an interesting position to be in, even if the mechanics aren't as exhilirating as one typically expects from a game.

It is not a game for everyone and I can't explain why I like it so I'm gonna list the positive and negative features: Positive: +Good Music (Very Memorable) +Story gets more challenging with each Day +Very intresting Art Style +Can get intense when you don't know if you can afford food heat rent and so on +Oddly Addicting& satisfying +At least I could really project myself in the Game +Story is somehow intresting because you can change your fate  Negative: -It is boring sometimes -Only one Piece of Music -Pretty annoying later on when you have to check multiple documents at once and still need to correctly sort the people  Thats all I got to say about this Game. If you can keep up with the negative parts you will definitly have one of the strangest but also one of the best experiences that you can get for 10 bucks on Steam.
This is really a wonderful game with many endings and many styles to play this game.

Amazing. This game is a tedious yet heart warming yet makes you want to have a heart attack as you wait for a violation. This game takes place in a made up country called Arstotzka, and you are a person pulled in the labor lottery to work at the new border checkpoint. Though at first it seems very simple elements are quickly added to make you decide between speed and quality, and the wrong choice could get you exacuted. Random events happen throughout the pre-made story to make you go against or for your country. Also you meet intresting characters that you see time and time again and make you smile and you are evaluated on how well you do your job, needless to say you will probably be told you are scum several times over each day. There is a struggle that feels almost too real in this game where you are trying to make ends meat, making almost nothing and supporting an entire family on that. There is far more i could say about this but in the almost ten hours i've played already i know this game is like non i've played before. If you like being challenged, experiancing something new, or even deciding who lives or dies. This game is for you. If you want a unique game that will challenge you to add to your library, Welcome To Arstotzka.

Having always wanted to pay for the pleasure of doing menial tasks whilst living under the oppression of an Orwellian state, I went into Papers please with very high hopes.  On starting the game, I was pleasantly surprised by the sheer number of digits and names that had to be cross-checked and I was enjoyign my first day as a guradian of the Democratic Republic immensely before the day ended and I was forced to return home to my parasitic family. This opened up the second key part of the game, being depressed as loved ones die because you, as sole family provider, were too busy apprehending criminals in the name of mother  Russia  Arstotzka. This in the end turned out to be very useful as one family member dying really frees up funds to pay for medicine or expensive crayon sets and keep the others alive.  As the game went on I found that a significant amount of nothing happened, which really livened up the experience and made me wish that exciting things like dening people entry would happen less frequently, however I then began to see the value of things happening in video games as it helps to compartmentalise the long stretches of enjoyable bureaucracy.  In conclusion, more games need to make me feel completely bored and slightly depressed, then maybe they too could have as much praise as I'm dropping onto Papers Please. Also Papers Please is what we in the industry call 'enjoyable', we also say that it 'contains gameplay' which may sound strange in this day of 10 minute long cutscenes, but surprisingly it actually contributes to the experience if the player is occasionally allowed to take control of the protagonist.  -Glory to Arstotzka  -Your Comrade Delta_Lemon

This game isn't what you'd typically consider fun, but it's still a brilliant game driven by a story of moral choices for yourself, a passport inspector, and your family in a fictional post-war county. With 20 different endings there's a wide varety of routes you could go, and while the game itself isn't crammed with action you do tend to lose track of time while playing. It's a deep little game that's absolutely worth the $10.

If you like repetitive, soul sucking, paper pushing, then this is the game for you! 'Papers, Please' is an exercise in futility and misery- a surprisingly enjoyable one at that. At first glance, this game seems simple but it's charming graphic styling and soundtrack will quickly draw you in, whilst the growing challenge of keeping out those undesirables from your glorious nation will keep you playing for hours.

A man came up to my glorious counter, and he set upon me his passport. I scrutinized every bit of information on it as to make sure a terrorist/counterfeiter/jaywalker wouldn't enter into Glorious Arstotzka. I noticed the man's gender claimed to be female on his passport. Upon asking the 'man' in question as to what his true gender is, 'he' told me that it was as the passport said. Needless to say, my glorious booth sprung into action, and I proceeded to scan the 'man' for a view of 'his' 'hardware'.   Upon seeing she wasn't packing a python guarding two eggs, I proceeded to aggressively stamp her passport with the denial stamp. I didn't even use the reason stamp.   Anti-LGBT/10

I had heard quite a bit before picking up this game, but I still wasn't sure what to expect. Again, as with FTL, the only way is to try it out for yourself. Papers, Please surprised me with how addictive the gameplay was - which exists mainly of checking documents to spot any errors or omissions - but it was truly the few (major) choices you get that shape the timeline that were interesting to me. I experienced most endings before getting 100% achievements, certainly all the more notable ones.  As an achievement enthusiast I wouldn't have minded a few achievements tied to the 'Endless Mode' that unlocks after you finish the story game.  Recommended for something a little different. It certainly will resonate every time I walk through a customs :p

Unique and engaging gameplay. The little surprises, developments, and family expenses created a personal investment and insentive to press on and discover what the next day would bring to the DOA... Department of Admission - Dead on Arrival... I just got that.  Unlocked features like the sniper rifle and tranquilizer gun kept me on my toes throughtout.  Tons of replayability, Immersive Setting, Satisfying agency; every choice is important!  Money/time well spent.   Just don't touch the powder and you'll be fine.
For everyone that wanted to work at the post office... or in the eastern dictature, checking entrants on the border. Glory to Artotzka!
A landmark in gaming, moving papers around on a desk should not be this fun, or disturbing. Paper's Please is the most unique interpretation of a horror game out there.
even though its pixel graphics its amazing.just watch out for bomers

Accept bribes or pay rent. Reunite families, or feed your own.  time spent playing game, 10 hours. time spent think about games, a whole god damn year.

I will keep it short; This game is not basic. The story, the gameplay are all solid. As far as gameplay goes its a decent game, but the story and event make it so much better. It is a must.

The game is a repetitive, clerical game that relies on easy, uncomplicated puzzles. You'd think that would make me dislike it... but I very quickly got caught up in the plot, which seems for the most part to be going on outside of my little booth. The game is unlike any other I've played, and it was weirdly intriguing to play a game in which I'm just some random outsider just trying to get into the 'in' crowd.   Somewhere out there, a revolution is brewing... and the player has almost nothing to do with it. But still, it's exciting, and by the time you start thinking, 'OK, that's enough paperwork...' the game throws another curveball. The only thing that seems under-done is the main character's life outside of work -- there's some peripheral talk of food and health and heat and whatnot, but it's mostly as a lever to give the player incentives to act one way or another. It'd have been nice to get more involved in that side of the story, but it would definitely have taken away from the droll toll-booth drudgery that somehow makes the game so interesting.

Surprisingly eventful and exciting. I can't remember a time when I've ever said that about doing paperwork, but I've said it now. I can see myself playing this a few times a week.   Also, Glory to Arstotzka. We are watching you.

Don't let the graphics fool you (well, it's an Indie-game, so that's pretty much a given)! This game is awesome in it's own right. You feel immeresed in the given universe immediatley after you start your first day in a border checkpoint. Your job get's harder from day to day (yes, that is possible in a checkpoint), whereas you still have to get enough money to care for your family but accepting and declining the 'right' persons in the always same time. I cursed a lot, when I wrongly accepted a citizen and got a penalty.... but that's life. I enjoy this game, really much!

Papers, Please puts you in a setting, time, culture and gives you something that imerses people no matter where they are: a job.  It never breaks character while you play, consistantly reminding you of your place and what your supposed to be doing--it's your job to be repetitive and to notice unwelcome changes.  As a checkpoint officer, your tasked with checking the passports of people coming in to Atrokska. After awhile, your job gets difficult with the fluxuations of rules tailored to the changing laws of your country.  Through it all, you must remain consistant, vigilant, and aware. ...unless you simply don't want to.   Papers, Please offers you multiple oppertunities to stray from the mundane repetitive nature of your employment, but simple choices could lead to huge outcomes; bad and good.   This title can offer you immersion without the player entirely realizing it, and indeed they do this very well. Before you know it, you step back from your PC wondering why you just spent three hours looking at passports.  No, seriously.  Passports.   In a game.    I suggest this title to anyone looking for a quirky but satisfying sim. Glory to Atroksa.

working as bank teller irl, this game is strangely compelling and feels all too familar to me.   while years of abuse from customers working in banks and retail has made me numb to the moral dilemmas that you face in the game, I can appreciate the game's attempts to pull at my heartstrings and morals as they throw all of the 'immigration' cliches at me: -Let a terrorist in, or, apprehend a terrorist at the gate while yelling ALL GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA -Wrongly accuse someone of being the wrong gender -Seperate man and wife at the gate.  -Get irritated with the crazy old man who comes everyday with the wrong paper work -prevent the plot of Liam Neeson's 'Taken'   the only real problem I have with the game is pacing. After like 30-40 people in a row, I'd like to think most normal people get nauseous or bored. The fact that there is 20 different endings based on how you play and who you let in greatly extends the replay value if you can physically and mentally will yourself to play the game more than 2 or 3 times all the way through. And there's even a endless mode for the most mentally depraved of us out there  I can definitely recommend the game if you can pick it up for cheap in a Steam sale. Maybe try the game first before paying full price if you're not quite sure it's your thing

I circled this title for quite a long time before finally giving in and purchasing it. I read reviews, watched a little gameplay, and tried to understand what the draw could be. The concept is seemingly very boring, putting you in the position of an average border patrol agent. However, various events quickly transpire and the game reveals its true soul. Within this quirky game lies conspiracies, bribes, politics, undercover agents, and much more. It becomes almost impossibly to not assume the life and world presented to you within this game. After playing a few runs, I've still only been able to come out with one of twenty possible endings. I'm still going back to find the rest and, though I have to replay some basic gameplay, I'm not overwhelmed or upset with the idea of redoing previous actions. Of course, if you'd rather not start from scratch, you may pick up any game from any point. It's really a very well constructed title, and definitely worth the pricetag (even at full price). Of all the games I purchased during the summer sale, this is my favorite. I could not reccommend this more. The writing, the gameplay, top to bottom it's great.  Five Stars.
It's engaging, it's fun, it's an unique concept, brilliantly executed.

This isn't just a good game, it's an immersive and emotionally involving game about paperwork of all things. This is currently my number one pick for proof of games as art. I've never played a game that used the actual gameplay to evoke emotions and thought. I own games that exist solely to be both fun and art, such as To the Moon and Proun, but this is the only one that uses the unique aspects of video games to tell its story and build its world.  Also, real life experience as a paper pusher makes this game a lot easier than many people suggest.

I totally did not expect to like this game as much as I did nor did I expect to spend that much time on it :)   The gameplay may seem repetitive but that is the intention I think because you are playing an immigration officer and his life clearly sucks in a communist country. The banality of his job is punctuated by the occasional drama that heightens the game story but the drama never felt overwrought or overwritten.   I liked the fact that there are multiple endings, depending on the decisions you make in-game. Many of those choices reflect the tension of compassion vs duty but the tension was never really pointed or pronounced enough for me.   I liked how the game was designed in such a way as to allow you to go back and replay a day differently. That gives this game tremendous replay value.  Overall, I highly recommend this ~ give it a shot because it is an entirely unconventional game with a unique story.

This game is quite a piece of art! The graphical direction set the tone perfectly, and the messages the developer was trying to get out are clearly there. At first I didn't think I would get into a game that had some kind of political aspect to it, I'm not a real big Social Studies person myself. However, after seeing gameplay, and actually playing this myself, I can asure you that anyone can pick this up and learn easily. If I was given the choice of putting down a 1-5 star rating, I would say this gets a 3.8 on the scale. Although limited, the background, variety of characters, intuitive gameplay and wonderful style add for quite the recipe to turn any topic into something fun!  I recommend this game for anyone curious about this whole 'document thriller' genre or for those just curious enough to pick up and play it!  I will be looking forward to Lucas Pope's future works!

Lemonande Stand meets the Cold War. Papers, Please puts you as an immigration inspector for a fictional Eastern European country. The game is surprisingly deep and challenging for something that at face value looks kinda boring. The game is constantly forcing you to make a choice between helping yourself or helping others. It also doesn't take itself too seriously, there are frequent chuckles in between the dytopian glum. Art and Music really fit the atmosphere. I will be playing this one for awhile. WARNING: Part of this game is memorizing things, the information is always availible to you to check, but since you are paid by how many people go through your line, you are motivated to go as fast as possible. Memorizing the names of proper issuing cities makes you that much faster.

I've had more fun reviewing and stamping documents in this game than shooting aliens, exploring worlds, or casting spells in dozens of more action-packed, expensive titles.  It's a master class in satisfying, tense gameplay: every second of poring over documents costs time, every mistake takes food out of your family's mouth, and every time you spot a discrepancy and slam down that red stamp, it's immensely satisfying.  My wife and I played it together: she kept a cheatsheet with the cities, districts, and seals on it. I checked weight, height, pictures, and made sure their passport numbers matched up.   It was glorious.  Glory to Arstotzka.

But what makes  Papers, Please  so immersive are the multiple stories going on with the backdrop of a Soviet-esque era in the background, and how you, a simple border guard, can affect them all.   Who knew stamping papers could be so...engaging...

I incredbily enjoyed this game, probably one of the best 2d games I have ever gotten the privilage to play. The theme was original, the pixel art put into it was beautifully done, and best of all: the storyline. The storyline itself was in fact a branch game (A game based on your actions) so you as the player had partially gotten to sculpt the majority of the game. The game took place in a foreign country boarder checkpoint and you as the man who was chosen from a random draw to check passport information. After you would complete said storyline you would unlock 'endless mode' which would enable you to play for as long as you desired. The game itself was challenging and required quite a bit of patience, however still was easy enough to be able finish. I strongly encourage playing it no matter what type of gamer you are.

Never have I thought that a rather simple looking passport checking game could turn out to have such a complex mood and story told simply through the world and minor interactions with npcs. AAA games tell less of a story with so much more, and no game I have played recently has managed to create such emotions with so little. Buy this game.  The description may scare you away. The simplistic, boring-seeming theme may scare you away. The difficulty may scare you away. But this game is engrossing. And the story is deceptively appealing. You have to piece it together yourself. The people you encounter while you are doing your job, your family - that you don't see, but have to support - as you are conscripted into your government work. The choices you make that seem to make no difference, that there are no good options, everything has an impact. This game is a brilliant showcase of minimalism and atmosphere. This is a game that had everyone talking, and for good reason. If you haven't had a chance to try it, you owe it to yourself to see what all the buzz was about.

One of the most unique games I have played in a long time.  A very easy to learn puzzle game of sorts, where you take the place of an employee at a border checkpoint. There isn't really much actual puzzle solving outside of some 'side quests' that appear throughout the game, you spend most of your time scanning passports and entry slips for discrepencies.  The pacing of the game is excellent, starting you off with just 1 document to look over, but throughout your time spent in Arstotzka regulations will change and your desk will be flooded with papers for each new person you see. The game becomes a race against the clock as you check over stamps and personal information to admit or deny entry without making mistakes. With mistakes come penalties to your daily earnings, which will quickly make it very difficult for you to keep your family safe and healthy.  An interesting story that is changed by a combination between choices you make and your performance definitely adds some serious replay value to this game. You can continue your progress from any point to change decisions and uncover more of the 20 different endings available.  The only complaints I have are the 'upgrades' in the game are poorly executed, there are only 4 total, one even overrides the purpose of another. Also because of the art style it can be dificult to match faces to small pictures, leading to some misplays later in the game.  I would definitely recommend this game to anyone regardless of what type of gamer they are.

This game is great! I can with total confidence now claim that I know how it feels to be a lowly worker in a communist republic. Before I begin, I should note that my friend named themselves 'kebab.gif', with a Turkish flag as their avatar, in reference to the Turkeyball's 'Cannot remove kebab!'.  This game also takes place in a parody of 1980s Eastern Europe.  So now to begin.  Typical day passing papers in glorious Artsotzka, denying feces out of everyone. Cloudy weather as usual. 'FOR KOLECHIA!', he screams. He explodes, all three guards die. Crowd is running away screaming.  And as this happens, I see on the top left of the screen, a Steam notification... Lucas Pope has quckly become for me a dev who is the king of simple games that get really hard as you go. Papers Please at first seems like a really boring game at first. You sit at the border of two ficticious countries, deciding who can get in and who can't. The fun comes from the unique controls and the hidden storylines that emerge as you play.   The gameplay is simple throughout the whole game but gets increasingly difficult as you play. You are in charge of the Grestin Checkpoint of Arstotzka. You do this by clicking and dragging the many items you are in charge of. Your first day is very easy: only let people with Arstotzka passports in, everyone else must be denied. Of course you could let anyone in with a dock in pay. You can let anyone in on the second day as long as their passports aren't expired. The whole point of the game is to follow the rules. It's easy to look at them in the first page of your handbook, but making sure all the conditions for entry, especially in the later part of the game, is difficult.  As far as those hidden storylines go, you are also in charge of getting paid enough money to feed and warm your family. There's also some people who want you do do things that might be unsavory to the dilligent border officer, from accepting bribes to be let in without a passport, to corrupt governments and a rebelious cult. All these elements mix together to add up to over ten different endings. It is possible to get through the whole game without getting a paper check wrong, you can do so poorly that you starve your family to death, you can help corrupt people, or have them taken care of. The choice is yours...  In short, the satisfying and simple controls to a complicated and dynamic pixel world make for a fun and stressful game.

Although this may not SOUND like an intriguing and fun concept, it really is. With the help of great graphics catchy and fitting music as well as an engaging and exciting storyline with 20 endings, this is a really good game; and affordable too! Loved it!

A refreshing game of which the goal is _not_ to kill people, but rather deciding who gets to enter the country and who doesn't. Intersting political narrative and moral decisions (do you accept bribes so you can feed your family, or will you do the 'right thing' while letting your son starve?) Contrary to what I expected, there is enough variation over time to keep it interesting.
Why can I not stop playing. This game is a real job. I need to clock in before my boss finds out I'm late.

Papers, Please is a fantastic little indie game set in a fictional Eastern European country called Arstotzka in the fall of 1982. You play as an Immigration Officer at a check point into Arstotzka. The gameplay compromises checking passports and other required documentation in determining if they can enter the country. Even though the game play sounds simple, it very quickly becomes complicated by adding more and more rules and requirements to allow people entry. Depending on how you play, how well you play, and which story line you follow, the game offers a variety of endings. If you can get past having to stamp passports for gameplay, Papers, Please offers a great gaming experience.

Papers, Please is a game in which you play as the customs of the city Artstotzka. You have to identify passports, papers, licenses, permits and ID cards and decide wether or not they're allowed to come into the city. Whilst that, strange and unusual things happen...  PROS: + Unique gameplay + Replayablilty + Nice pixelized graphics which requires only 40 mb of space + Trading cards   CONS: - The game does not provide an option to see what you did wrong - Can get repetitive  A funny little game for a fair price.   My rating: 7.5/10

I'll admit, when I first saw this game, I was only mildly interested in it, just from what the trailer showed. Then it was on sale one day, so I decided what the heck, I'll try it.  It's a hit. It may not seem like much, but sometimes its hard to stop. 'Just one more day, or maybe naw...' I thought there wasn't a story mode but that's all there is at first. The policies and documents get compounded further and further as relations between the fictional country of Arstotzka and the other nations of the Seven Member Forum slowly deteriorate. The game is relatively open-ended. There are TWENTY possible endings (most of which involve the player getting arrested, but hey, do your job and you've got nothing to fear). There is a degree of suspense too.  Sometimes my siblings watch me play it. And when I told them it was available on the iPad as well, my brother wasted no time buying it for himself. Everyone loves playing it.  Great for all types of players.  Story mode of 31 playable days, 20 possible endings, achievements and an unlockable ENDLESS mode. I highly recommend this game

My parents came to America from Cuba as children back in the 1960's, so we talk about Communism a lot. One particular story my mom brings up is how she had a brand new story book that my grandfather bought her to read as entertainment on the long plane ride and a watch to keep as a memento of her country she was now abandoning. The customs official confiscated both FOR THE REVOLUTION!!! and let them leave with only one suitcase each. It was weird playing that jerk for this game, but my family said the atmosphere was correct. They were just confused how this is a game about people going IN to a Communist country instead of breaking down the door to get OUT! Enough personal stuff, to the game itself.  Positive: -Suprising amount of choice in the game. Are you a corrupt official taking bribes from criminals and terrorists? Are you a noble patriot helping refugees and resistance fighters? Or are you souless automaton only following regulations? -Good replay value with lots of endings except they can be boiled down to just being variations of Three major endings. -The game is hard in a good way. Gets your brain working overdrive as you have check every tiny detail of multiple documents in only 10 seconds. -The atmosphere of oppression is well made with dark depressing colors and communist iconagraphy.  Negative: -The story is a little thin, but I think they squeezed out as much as they could given the game's structure. -Some people might be turned off by the graphics, but its reasonable given the price range.
Spend hours at a time checking documents and paperwork. Get paid nothing to do so. Have fun doing it.

This game is in-frickin-credible, and you can tell it comes from a real place. I'm just glad I can pretend to be in Eastern Europe/Russia rather than actually deal with this BS. All the crap you're made to deal with at your pretend desk in this brilliant game is wholly analogous to the creative ways that people dehumanize others by way of bureaucratic mazes, inadequate training whilst expecting the employee to do any and everything, and good ol' tattling.  I laughed out loud when they set a key on your desk and instructed you on how to use a gun. You start out simply stamping papers and all of a sudden you're on the front lines of their counter-terrorism operation. And the guy who walks up to the window, plants a bomb on your desk, and suffers the chastisement of a guard very unimpressed with the shoddy construction—clearly Russia is a different world altogether.

Congratulations, as games go ‘Papers, Please’ has left me feeling a little confused about how to behave when playing, if I take the true to ideological behaviour approach I will fail, if I take the hardliner approach I might fail just because I slipped up.   The world painted in this game is bleak and fearful, the more I allowed myself to be immersed in the narrative the more compelled and conflicted I become.   Visually and audibly the game is simple, I find this adds to the bleak vision being crafted by the creator, amplifying the horrible nature of the world in which I was interacting.   The game is simply so consistent in its approach and delivery that it breaks down many modern preconceived expectations for videogames and delivers what makes a good game great, an experience that effects the player, possibly at a core value level.   Papers, Please is a beautiful game because it is so ugly.

Initially looks like it was programmed in machine code from the 1980's Passport booth is upgraded to 16 Bit programming.  You probably wouldn't want such a job in real life, why suffer it in the game world? To keep your family alive of course!  The game manages to turn a seemingly dull concept into an interesting and poignant one.  The retro graphics somehow don't seem out of place and along with the music create a bleakness in keeping with a red army state behind the former iron curtain, and the game survives this as the focus is on the gameplay.  Checking passports! No fancy scenery needed.  You feel pressurized to get people moving through the queue and stamped in. You feel pressurized to avoid making mistakes. You feel pressurized to keep your family alive and maybe get out of this craphole situation. Damn... was that woman really a bloke? Maybe no heating this week then :(   Doesn't offer much in the way of replay value, but the time spent on it does immerse you. You just need to get away to a better life.

Paper's Please is one of those rare games that you don't really even consider to be that amazing or even enjoyable at first glance. However, once you put in your first hour into the game, you begin to realize the big picture.   In Paper's Please, you enter the job as an immigration inspector and you have to regulate who enters the country of Arstotzka and who doesn't, all while trying to barely earn enough money to keep your family alive. This may sound stupidly boring but the game begins to question you as a person as you make choices on whether or not to help the people how enter your booth. Do you choose to help out a married couple by letting both the husband and wife into the country, despite the fact that if you let the wife in with her inaccurate documentation, you will receive a citation, causing you to possibly lose money, the money that you now need to buy your ill son the medicine he needs to get better? That's one example of a choice your going to have to make. This game, of course, has you checking the documentation of those who wish to enter Arstotzka. The process itself starts off simple, but more layers get added to the inspection process as time passes while you play. This requires you to think fast, as only if you correctly approve or deny any visitors will you actually receive the money that you need to keep you family alive. If you incorrectly approve or deny, you'll receive a citation noting the mistakes you made along with how much money you are being penalized with as you rush to make enough money to last until tomorrow before the clock strikes six and you are done with your work for the day.  If you are someone who would enjoy or finds interest in a game where you have to think fast, but without all of the typical action sequences you would get in something like you would see in something like counter strike or would like to play a game that will bring out your inner morals, then I highly recommend you pick this up as I'm sure you'll enjoy the games complex nature and 20 different endings. Glory to the 'New' Arstotzka.

Throughout late 1982 I dutifully maintained the border checkpoint in Grestin, although I had worked with teh rebels I generally stayed on teh side of the law. Then Sergio the guard came. He was friendly and we worked together to take down any terrorists. One day Sergio told me that his long lost love was coming through the checkpoint. When she did she didn't have the right paperwork but I still let her in. I had already docked multiple citations that day and because of her my family didn't have heating or food. I was still happy though, I had reunited two lovers. Minutes before the day ended however, a co-ordinated group of terrorists attacked. I and Sergio took them all down but I shot the last one a second after he threw a grenade... that killed Sergio.   Don't think I've ever become more distraught when some pixels died in my entire life. 10/10
