Nothing sounds like a worse idea for a game than Papers, Please. The sales pitch had to have gone something like this: Dev: Ok, I've got an excellent idea for a game here. CEO: Ok, shoot. Dev: The player lives in a dysytopian country... CEO: AND SHOOTS ZOMBIES! Dev: No. CEO: Oh, ok, continue. Dev: So he sits in an office... CEO: AND THEN GOES ON AN EPIC SHOOTING ADVENTURE! Dev: No. CEO: Oh, ok, continue. Dev: And stamps passports. CEO:... Dev: But! CEO: Good, I was about to fire you. Dev: He has a family that he gets money for rent, food, heat, and medicine... CEO: AND HIS SON IS ACTUALLY THE PROTAGONIST AND GOES ON AN EPIC SHOOTUMUP TO SAVE HIS DAD! Dev: No. CEO: Oh, ok, continue. Dev: And money is only given to the player when he... CEO: SHOOTS THE...! Dev: NO! LET ME FINISH! CEO:... Dev: (sigh) when he correctly assigns either a Aproved stamp or a Denied Stamp. The game gets progressivly harder. CEO:... Dev: But! CEO: Good, I was about to fire you. Dev: And he has to make moral choices... without a morality bar. CEO:... Briliant! It goes without saying that this is tied for my favorite game of all time

Who knew a realistic bureaucracy simulator could be so fun. In “Papers, Please” you play an immigration officer in a fake communist country in 1982. You stamp passports, ask for documents, and check every detail from the dates on forms, to the height and weight of the person. The game gets progressively harder adding more details to cross-reference. The person might look a bit different from their passport photo so you fingerprint them and compare it to their record, or if the person’s stated gender doesn't match their appearance you take a scan of them and check their junk. But the best part of the game is the hard moral choices you have to make along the way. You have a family and have to pay for things like rent, heat, food, and medicine. You earn money for each passport you approve or deny but get fined if you make more than 2 mistakes per day. If you suck you might have to take kickbacks form the guards, or even take bribes from terrorist, just to feed your family. If you’re good you can afford to give your kid a gift for Christmas or even move into a better apartment. This game is truly brilliant. It takes what sounds like the worst premise for a game and turns it into one of the most well-executed and bizarrely addictive games I've played in a long time.

My favorite part is (SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER) when you have to decide whether or not to let the green guard's girlfriend in. Even though I got a citation, seeing them hug and reunite literally made my heart melt. The game really plays on your emotions, and every time I turned down someone who had a good reason to get in, I felt like an awful person. A phenomenal example of how to present true moral choice.

This is an excellent game that lives up to the hype. I'd seen a bunch of praise for it on gaming sites I respect, and finally decided to take the plunge for myself. I absolutely do not regret paying full price for such a great game in many respects. First of all, although not marketed as such, this is a fantastic detective simulator that will reward you for careful attention to detail. The sparse story is written well enough to evoke true emotion from you, leading to gut-wrenching decisions that force you to balance your humanity with your survival instinct. While the gameplay is fairly repetitive, the story is rewarding enough and the scenarios are varied enough that it's not really a problem (but if you're wary of the repetitive gameplay, you should still buy it, just wait for a sale.) While this game is not for everyone, if you're into puzzles, looking for clues, paying attention to detail and slower games that make you think, go ahead and give it a download.

Who knew border patrol could be fun? Well, I guess not necessarily fun, but it engages you in a way you wouldn't expect. Plus, it has a unique way of weaving a story, and several roles you can play in it. The choices you make impact the world in ways that might eventually come back to bite you, or might help you out in the end. On your first time playing, you have no idea if the choices you make are good ones. But you have to make them. And no matter what happens, you have to brush it off as best you can, because you're getting paid based on how many people you let in. And every ruble goes towards keeping you and your family afloat.

Handling documents in an Arstotzkan immigration checkpoint can be tough. Struggling with the upkeep of your sick and starving family with your meager salary isn't easy. All kinds of individuals seem to want to come to the Arstotzka too. Among the decent people there are smugglers, conspirationists and other unwanted elements, including the man who decided that hand drawn passport is a valid document. The game has multiple endings depending on how you choose to deal with some of these people.  Lucas Pope has a beta version of the game available. It gives a good demonstration of the game's mechanics.

I enjoy leisurely games like everyone else, but after a long day of menial and degrading work, the last thing I need is to take my mind from my dead end job and my dead end life with the cheap thrills that video games are known for. Instead, what I need is a game to give me a pile of paper work to sort through, and a family that is either dying, dead, or a significant drain on my meager wallet. Life is bleak. Why not make it bleaker? Papers, Please.

This game is addicting. It's got diverse characters. It's got important choices that will affect you and your own family. The story is amazing. I love this game.

Difficult to understand this game the first time around; there is some intended trickery from the game designers to try to trip you up. It can be very confusing how to determine who to admit into your country. A unique game, probably unlike any other in its design.
This won't be for everyone but if you can pick it up cheap play it!

This game totally worth $10 ! Glory to Jorji Costava !

Imagine you’re living under a communist regime, in the early 80s, and working at a border checkpoint where you verify the credentials of people wishing to enter the country. The ministry for which you work passes down various orders and new requirements for entry-approval. Your workload increases with each new edict. The amount of information you’re required to verify borders on the absurd. Make more than a couple mistakes and your wages are penalized (and it’s very easy to make mistakes). It becomes increasingly harder to provide for your family because your salary is docked to depletion. And because it’s so hard to earn money legally, bribes and trafficking start to look attractive.   I’ve just described the game Papers, Please to you. You’re thinking, “that sounds incredibly boring. Stressful, even.” Yet, somehow, I found it be one of the most fun gaming experiences I’ve had in recent memory (and I’m not alone).  At its most basic, the game works like this: Person enters your booth. You inspect their credentials (passports, permits, etc.). You either approve or deny them entry. They leave. The next person enters. Repeat.  There are, of course, other gameplay and story elements littered throughout, but that’s the gist.  It’s set in the fictional country of Arstotzka, just after a war with neighboring country Kolechia. The major city that sits on this border, Grestin, has been divided for some time, and the border is finally open once more. It’s your job to inspect those seeking entry.  The design of the game screen is deceptively elegant. Your workstation manages to be both streamlined and inefficient. I found myself, at times, intensely frustrated that I couldn’t move people through faster. And that somehow added to the enjoyment. The recognition of that frustration intensifies the feeling that you’re some lowly border clerk being asked to do a job that no one could do well.   And when you do get the hang of that workstation, you can make it sing. I learned to immediately place documents where I needed them, readying my cursor for a printout of some supplemental material or other, developing a workflow that would identify elements that were easily verified before moving on to the items that were buried deeper in the documents. It was incredibly rewarding once you could get people flying through that booth.  And no matter which way you choose to play the game, it’s fun. When you adhere completely to the rules, denying entry often, ignoring pleas from the destitute and hard-luck cases there’s a (sick?) satisfaction in keeping Arstotzka “safe.” On the flip side when you do all you can to help those in need, often sacrificing your job and livelihood, the game becomes even more fun and rewarding.  The art is suitably grim and lo-fi, complementing the dystopic nature of Arstotzka perfectly. Everyone is unattractive and sad. The design of the documents feels authentic and plays a key role in identifying forgeries and the like.  The absolute best part of the game is the sound design. Every little mechanical click, punch, and stamp is weirdly satisfying. The strange gibberish used in place of dialog feels impersonal and emotionless (as it should). It greatly enhances the gameplay experience.  Papers, Please is self-described as a dystopic document thriller. And it totally makes good on that promise.

One of the most impressively atmospheric games I've ever played, definitely noticeable for its apparent simplicity. Arstotzka feels like a real place, all gritty concrete buildings and cold wind, and until you get good at your job it is worrying having to provide for your family. Slip up once and you'll never be better than 'sufficient'. Want to get out of the country? Bad luck pal you got executed. Strangely gripping and a lot of fun.
A seemingly boring premise that actually ends up keeping you on your toes.

Fantastic game lots of different endings to find never gets boring although the game is very simple. If you think it looks good and you are thinking about getting it just get it you wont regret it(that rhymes) Also you need a good eye!
You think checking papers at a border checkpoint is boring? You're probably right... But despite that, this game is very compelling and I would recommend it to pretty much anyone. Glory to Arstotzka!

I may never finish off this game b/c I don't want to handle to responsibility of being able to shoot a guy bombing the border b4 he gibs the new border guard who's from my hometown. A passport checking simulator invoked that fear into me... well done.
Perfect mixture of entertaining story, 8 bit art direction, and emergent, yet simple gameplay mechanics. Lots of challenge modes after completing the story too. One of my favorite games. 9/10
Absorbing and addictive.  Great replay value in the speedruns. Filled me with a guilt I will never be free from. Would recommend.

It starts off like a normal puzzle game. When everything gets harder and harder (But more importantly, more interesting and deep). Some moral choices as well. Helping people gives you a strike and eventually it will start giving you tickets. Keep in mind that helping people that don't talk to you is pointless, since you have your own family to feed. But if they talk to you much that means you could get a badge out of it. The badge gives you a acheivement and that's it.   Fun but way too easy. Give your family heat one night, and food the next. Every 3 days or so you have to get medicine for you'r son since he is a little ♥♥♥♥♥. Only costs 5 dollars though, and food is like 20 so it doesn't matter. Take bribes whenever you can since there is no penalty for it. And detain everyone none-stop (like 5 bucks for everyone you put in jail).  Oh, and you can detain people in this game. Did I mention that? Well it becomes a little rediculous when you detain people for calling you a ♥♥♥♥♥. Or for demanding to be paid when you brake their watch.  Worth the price, I haven't completed it. But I have seen some endings already (Some endings end the game prematurely)
10/10 would paper again

Excellent game!  The graphics didn't impress me at first (don't really care for all those pixel-fonts and such), but all the little animations make up for the choice of 'retro-graphics'. I also liked the UI and all the dragging of the documents as it makes me feel like I'm sitting behind a real desk.  The game deserves all the praise it has gotten. Full points for the idea & the execution.  Definitely a must-have game.
Not only a great gameplay experience, but also a unique story that is discrete but sweet
this game is ♥♥♥♥ing hard!

Another game that should be really boring, its passport and document checking after all but its great and there are some unexpected events, with people trying all sorts of crap just to pass the border control, like distract you with conversation and people trying to sneak weapons or drugs in. 20 different endings too.

Oregon Trail, except instead of a hopeful settler headed into a west rife with opportunity, you're an immigration agent in a communist nation with grinding poverty and hopelessness. Even if you win, you lose, but its so compelling and equipped with numerous endings that explored the heart of darkness within the cogs in the communist machine. 9.5/10

Absolutely fantastic game! However, it's not for everyone. The mechanics are simple and the rules are straightforward. The challenge comes in when you miss little things like the person’s height or one letter in the passport. You also need to make enough money for your family but you need to be careful not to get deductions. If you like paying attention to detail this game is perfect for you! I recommend this game and I rate it 4.5 out of 5.
I like both the story and the gameplay of this game. The story is captivating to those who are intersted in communist regimes. The gameplay is just fun.
The Best Arstotzkan Game since Collective Farming Simulator 1985. Worthy of Commendation. 10/10

GLORY TO [can't remember how to spell the fictional country]!!!!  Papers, Please is a unique enough experience to easily recommend. That said, I don't think there is a ton of replay value beyond standard achievement hunting and the gameplay did wear out it's welcome after about 8-10 hours. Don't hesitate if it's on sale, even if it's not something you'll play for days on end... it is a very memorable experience while it lasts. HAIL JORJI!

This game is absolute brilliance. The graphics, the sound and the music all fit quite well with the setting and theme of the game. The gameplay itself is quite simple, get some documents, verify their authenticity, approve or deny entry. You might need to shoot a couple of people along the way. This game basically made me feel like being a Customs Officer because of how fun the game was.  Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who appreciates a well polished indie game.

This game is really something else. I can't believe how great the story and the graphics play along (and the sound is really compelling). If you like to see how it goes with a theme of mental issues and loyalty to the people (or to governments) you should really play this game. It's both addictive and daunting. For me it's a must have.

This is a game that sounds bad on paper, one which has been falsified and you will be escorted by these nice men with guns to the nearest sorting office. NEXT.  But seriously, the game is simply you as a normal guy stamping passports at a communist checkpoint. Money is per person sorted and jesus do you need ever cent you can get, which makes the genuinely nice and needy people really hard to allow through. It says alot of just how miserable people can be and how easy it is to just do your job and let the misery solve itself, or you can do something about it. Stamping papers provides a absorbing experience where you get into a grove of stamping efficently to the point where any interuptions to the method like wall jumpers or bombers provide a insight on just how routine life can be. Its unnerving when you think about it. Anyway the game provides insight and the rules it gives you provide context and excellent challange that escelates nicely.
If you haven't played this game yet, just do. It's awesome! It's really cool to see how the simplest of gameplay can turn into a super immersive experience.

Hello, comrade. I have excellent game for you! Is cheap, and will make you feel amazing. Bright colours, beautiful women, good music. We have all here! I not lie, feel good game of decade! Buy now! Glory to Arstotska!    Death to Kolechia.

Think that this game looks aged and dumb? That the graphics blow and the actual gameplay looks more like work than play?   Forget everything you think you know.  Add it to your cart, purchase, install, and play. Right now. Forget that you ever thought anything other admiration for this game.   Kick the spouse and/or any mates out of the room, shoo away your kids, and silence your pets. Once you're playing this you're not going to be able to pay any attention to any of them anyway. Besides, you're concentrating.  You're in control of the border to Arstotzka. Your job is to process as many people in a day as possible, check their papers, and make sure that everything is in order and up to code. If all looks good, then they're allowed in. If not, you have the right to yell aloud 'DENIED!' Then you get to press a big red stamp on their passport and essentially tell them to ♥♥♥♥ off. Unless, of course, they're a criminal or trying to conceal some sort of contraband. Even better! 'DETAIN!' The more people you process, the more money you make. Your family is relying on you for income, and it's up to you to provide for them, or not? Tell them to fend for themselves, shut their heat off, and leave them cold and hungry. If you're good enough, you can even upgrade your dwelling to a much higher class. Maybe one more fitting of an upstanding citizen such as yourself.   Arstotzka depends on you to keep the riff-raff out. Better get to it.  Bonus: This game fights Alzheimer's disease. (not proven) ;P

Papers, Please is a masterpiece. Intuitive, tense, flow-inducing, yet deep and varied gameplay, perfectly contextualized to expose the subtext of its mechanics. Every interaction is both a skill-testing challenge and a moral expression that contributes to a simultaneously emergent and crafted, branching narrative, achieved through precisely modulated procedural generation. This game is meaningful, resonant, and features more cohesive, focused integration of story into gameplay and vice versa than I have ever seen. That it was a low-budget, one-man operation merely makes the state of AAA games all the more shameful by comparison.

Papers Please is an interesting concept pulled off in a unique style. Each day truly becomes harder, both to do ypur job right and to be a good person. This game gives a whole new feeling to tedious paperwork and it certainly makes a change of pace from all the hardcore military shooters out there. Don't think, just get this game. Glory to Arstotzka!

Great game, one of the more fun games I have played recently. The simple art style works great and adds to the dark feeling of the game. While the gameplay is pretty simple, it stays interesting by constantly changing and adding rules.  Even though the title screen theme is pretty cool, the game lacks music during the levels. I also found it hard to play for hours on end, it's more of a play for 40 minutes and then do something else kind of game.  Still; 9.5/10
This game is one of the best indie games I have stumbled across in a while, and be prepared to become part of the Arstozkan cult

Strangely absorbing and nail-biting if you're not turned off by the older-looking graphics and gameplay that relies a lot on observation. A real gem that isn't your stereotypical 'game' and definitely worth a look at if you're looking for a shorter, but exceedingly worthwhile, gaming experience.
Nice little indie game, I play it when I want to relax a few minutes. The game is NOT repetitive as you may think before buying the game, every day comes new rules and challenges :)  Great job dev!

I was first introduced to Papers, Please by a friend, and instantly fell in love. Papers, Please is a phenominal game. With it's combination of atmosphere and character, it makes for a simple and fun play while demanding your attention. It has good replay value as well, due to the various choices you're able to make throughout the story. This game sparked a love for simple pixel art games, and now I'm hooked! 10/10 would recommend

If a game is created by lucas pope it is automatically incredible  papers please is a game so good i can't even explain it. from now on i want every AAA developer to look at this game and think: huh..we've spend millions of pounds on a game which involves two ending where you choose the one you want and this game on the other hand does it all ingame with 20 endings (i think)  this game is evil and difficult but not in a bad way. if you fail the game there is only one reason for it: you are not good enough for the game. where as in other difficult games they are difficult because they are glitchy, unballanced and poor.  AAA companies make games serious by going: LOOK I KILLED A CHILD! where as this game is properly serious and you will feel awful for the things that you have done.  papers please is what i can describe as the perfect game with no cons

If my job was actually like this, I'd have quit. Yet, I'm willing to play a game that simulates the soul crushing struggle of mediocrity. The kicker tho, is that it's fun. I really wasn't expecting that.

One of the best games I've ever played. Challenges attentiveness while putting up work ethics against morality. As I grow older I'm less and less able to pull all nighters with games, but even now PP has the kind of magic that keeps me going after midnight, even if I have to wake up 4:30 for my real life shift.
Who would have thought processing papers would be this fun? Lucas Pope did an amazing job

Papers, please is and incredible game. You play as a man who works at an entry checkpoint between two countries. And no, not sarcasticlly speaking, it may sound dull and bad, but litsen. You are torn apart between working at minimum wage for an insane and tyranic country to provide food, water, rent, heat, and medicine for your family, or helping the rebels fight aganist the tyrant country while getting little or no money to help your family.  One of my most memrable momnets:  A man comes up with his passport and papers and i approve him after im done checking, but then he says: 'Please be nice to my wife up next, i beg you' So his wife comes up and gives papers, and everything seems fine until i see an out of date passport and say: 'This passport is out of date.' I was torn apart between paying rent for me and my famile's room or helping this women.  A real tear-jerker this is.  10/10
This is a great game. It tells an amazing story, that ends up being the most depressing greatest story ever. If you get a chance to play this game, PLAY IT!
Paperwork has never been this fun and humourous.

'To his credit, Lucas Pope has crafted an experience where you truly feel like you are an immigration inspector. What may appear to be a fiendishly difficult and unfair game gradually becomes easier and more rewarding with each additional play through. Papers, Please may not be for everyone, but there is an abundance of content and charm to satisfy those who pass through the border and explore what lies beyond. Glory to Arstotzka!'  For my full written review, check out Critical Indie Gamer at  www.criticalindiegamer.com/2013/08/papers-please-review-pc
This game is fun, but challenging. I find myself commiserating with DMV workers now.
a very good game. despite the boring sounding nature of the game it is genuinely very exciting. shame its quite short though. a graphically simple game, but definitely worth playing.

Great game. On first sight it looked like a simple and fun game, but it is more than that. You have to make difficult choices. You even have to decide who lives and who dies. This game really makes you think.
An engaging moral and philosophical journey makes this GOTY 2013.
If art can be judged by how much it makes us feel, this game belongs in a museum.

Absolutely loved it! It's very easy to understand how it works and the pace of difficulty is good enough for you to get into it. However, it IS difficult to master. You really, really need to have a good eye because later on there will be so much documents and rules to take care of. It can get pretty dark as well. Not only do you need to do your job well (I know, I'm shocked too) but you also have to take care of your family. Guess what? I wasn't good enough on my first playthrough and all of my family died because I couldn't afford to pay the bills as well as the medicine and food for them.    It also deals with terrorists attacks as well as other government issues that will test your morality. And yet, it's a lot of fun and addictive. The screenshots may intimidate you but trust me, you will get the flow of the game rather easy. You just need to have great, and I mean GREAT attention to details in order to stop bad people from going through.   The price could be discussed but on the other hand it does offer a lot of depth and strategy. If you're reticent about it, grab it on sale like I did. It's worth it. Trust me, I'm an actor.
Glory to Arstoska (didnt spell it right)

In short, highly recommend to buy it and play it for the experience.     Personal opinion below --    Art style:  Love the 8-bits retro style.  Sound & Music:  Consider it average, but does hit the right notes.  Gameplay:  Very interesting, the sole reason why to pick up this title.  This game empathize heavily on the philosophy aspect, while copes really well with the game mechanics. This is what made this game so intriguing.   Replayability:  Diminishing really quickly after a few play-through; however, will always re-surface for replay.
Very 'stressful' and unique game!!Buy it!!
An amazing game. The puzzle ratio and unique storyline of the game are a great quality to have. Would definently play for all 18+ endings.
I do recommend this game but only slightly its a good and creative formula but can get boring fast.

Because there is nothing like this game out there - it's so unique and yet so simple. Well worth the investment. Glory to Arstotzka!
Very fun simple game. I wish that they will make more storylines as the main story was interesting.

GG! but its not a game you play for a long time in a row

This is a game where you are in a room just checking papers for people that want to get to a different country. It may seem like there is not much to the game, but the story makes the whole game realistic with terrorist attacks, secret groups of people to take down countries, and checkups from authorities that don't trust you at all. Not only is the story really good, the gameplay balances the whole game out. It gets so overwhelming trying to keep up with all the new rules, all the attacks, and the lack of trust, that if the art style was different, it would feel like i was right in the game. I reccomend this game to all the gamers looking for story driven games, or a challenge

Just buy this game, do it.   It is a lot of fun, you have new things to check/new rules to follow almost every day, which just continues to expand the gameplay.  I like that there is multiple ways to play this game, for example, you can take the EZIC path, or be a good inspector and be loyal to the government.  Overall, great game.
Somehow managing to be fun and boring, this is an amazing, story based game.

This game is innovative, unique and perfect in excecution. The music and sound creates an amazing atmosphere. To describe the gameplay mechanics in short, it would be a memory puzzle game with a mix of adventure.  Beyond 8 Hours it becomes a chore to play. Still, it deserves bonus points for originality rather than being one of those indie ('Just like that AAA game, but our way, fund us or we will hold you randsom with our Indie rights') games with mspaint as a rendering engine.
So addicting and fun. I recommend this so much!
Train your skills for your future Border inspector career!

I recommend this for being very different than the usual, and very well realized. What I got from it is the very clear message of how the ones that suffer most from bureaucracy are the common folk.  Though I must say this is not a game I actually liked, for some reasons. I had/have to deal with bureaucracy a lot in my regular life, although I can understand why it can be an eye opener to people who don't. Also I must say I dislike generally negative messages/worldviews about stuff, because it dehumanizes everyone.

This game is actually the reason I got Steam in the first place. It is absolutely addicting. I've never had an issue with bugs of any sort. The storyline is great. And you can choose everything: who you let in or not, who you make exceptions for. You can even decorate your post with rewards from the government and items from your family. I LOVE this game. The fact that there are multiple endings to the game is great so it is hardly ever the same game twice. Definitely worth the money.
Perfect game when you're bored. If you want a unique and refreshing game, check this out.
Strange guy of guy give me a silver key Find out key is to a gun locker. 10/10 - 'It's like Skyrim with paper'.
add like a creative thing to endless mode that you can start a terrroist attack and approve and deny anyone and reason anyone and detain and search and fingerprint

If your idea of a good time is feeling like you must stamp passports all day long so you can make money to feed and clothe your family while maintaining rent and heat in your welfare apartment, this is the game for you. It gives you dilemmas that offer different paths to different endings (20 in all). I absolutely love it. The graphics are poor, but who cares? You're just stamping passports. It's a lot of fun.  Glory to Arstotzka.  10/10
Be the corrupt ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you always wanted to be ^_^ Now buy this game, NEXT 10/10 glory to arstozka

Have you ever wondered what it must feel like to have people curse you out, attempt to coerce you, bribe you and threaten you, then go home to your shoddy apartment only to find that you didn't make enough money to feed your family, or buy the medicine your child so desperately needs?   WELL THEN YOU'RE IN LUCK!!!!  This game is a true exploration of what a video game can achieve. Video games aren't all about fantasy, war, dragons, magic and monsters. Papers, Please proves that this medium is limitless. In Papers, Please, you are put in the shoes of a border control agent in the fictional soviet country of Arstotzka, where you are charged with either allowing or denying access of your great country to foreigners and citizens alike, based on an ever-shifting policy handed down to you each morning. You must check backgrounds, passoports, work visas, and make sure everything matches up. But be quick, because you only have so many hours a day and you get paid per customer, and if you try to rush it, you might mess up and cause the poor woman who came through before to be murdered by the man you should have just denied access...  You get the point. This game is an amazing study of the human condition and a harrowing insight to one poor man's life in Arstotzka.

Gem. Addictive. I knew few things about the game before I bought it but my first impression was like: damn, did I pay for THIS? And then I started to realize how deep and twisted it is. Looks like made in 80's. And that even makes immersion better. There are 20 endings so the game might be played over and over again. Totally recommend.

This game is way more intense and serious than any pixellated game I've ever played. You're forced to make some possibly life-threatening and heart-wrenching decisions, all while trying to keep your family alive working at your awful job. Played a demo of it once upon a time, and couldn't wait for the full story. Prepare to have your patience and morals tested.  Glory to Arstotzka.

An oddly entertaining game that is both semi-morbid and insightful, showing the bleak nature of human lives. I would say give it a try before you quit the game because of its graphics. This game gives you choices...whether you choose to be a drone and serve a country blindly OR make your own choices and affect the lives of the characters. The philosophy behind this game is both haunting and fascinating.  I would recommend this game to any of my friends.
Good game and really unique concept. I am sure many people will get hours of entertainment from it, but I did find my self not really compelled to keep playing but thats just me.
Although simplistic on its face, this game shows a hidden depth and is strangely compelling.

How difficult is it to check documents when you are an immigration officer? Of course, 'Papers, Please' is in no way an exact simulator of this kind of work. But it is a very entertaining title that will keep you entertained for long hours. In my opinion, the gradual increase in difficulty is well thought through and will let you adapt step-by-step to increasingly difficult requirements by your virtual bosses at the 'M.O.A.'  I can definitely recommend this game as a decently challenging indie title.
My family and I were put in prison for taking money from a suspicious organization. I should have never moved to a better apartment! Great game!

My girlfriend really got into this game. I watched her really get into the vibe of it as she happily denied people entry into Arostoska. She was so happy when her mother-in-law and uncle died as they were 'moochers'  10/10, would watch her become a monster again.
I really thought this game was lame until I played it. This game is so clever and original. If you have test your perception skills, you will love this game!!!

Somehow, despite all odds, this manages to be one of my favorite indie games. The game certainly doesnt look like much, and the gameplay is simplistic, but it is the simplicity that makes the game great and engrossing. This game will also make you feel like a terrible person for, say accidentaly killing your neice or letting a terrorist through your checkpoint. My only regret about this game is that Im not a better border gaurd. Anyway, buy this game. Glory to Arstotzka!
You can be a ♥♥♥♥ and win. Or be a nice guy or lose. Never knew that stamping passports was hard.

An indie game that is unlike any other I've played. Who would have thought looking at documents could actually be FUN? Papers, Please is a game that tests the skills of more basic gaming and cognitive ability, which is a great change in pace in this age of shooters and RPGs. Sometimes you'll want to quit the game, only to grit your teeth moments later and throw yourself at it again. It's a game where you, besides the occasional bug, can only blame yourself when you make a mistake.  And for a game with such a simple concept, it has the added bonus of giving you moral dilemmas. You have the power to reunite families and save lives, at the expense of your own family. Or do you do your job to a T, relentless following the rules of the Soviet-esque regime you live under?   While I'm hesitant on recommending this game at full price, it's definitely one I recommend on a more general scale. If you're looking for a change in pace from your typical gaming, Papers, Please is just right.

I rate the game Papers Please 4/5. Good.  If you can get past this game's terrible graphics and ugly colors it's actually pretty fun considering this is essentially a game that revolves around following bureaucratic procedures, comparing codes and other information between different simulated pieces of paper, doing other simulated paperwork and stamping people's simulated passports (and doing all this as quickly as possible and learning how that usually isn't fast enough).   The game has a good, detailed story mode plot and can end with any one of 20 different possible endings. This game (and its plot) appears to be heavily influenced by George Orwell but is also influenced heavily (as George Orwell was also heavily influenced) by Soviet Russia and its various border states. This game (which starts simple but becomes increasingly complex) is also often funny but in a very dry and tragic manner. For added replayability it also has two difficulty modes (one mode causes your character to be paid adequately while the other difficulty mode gives you inadequate pay). The amount of money you make affects your family who must be kept warm and be fed and if they are not, will suffer and die (in a sort of oregon trail style menu which says how poorly they are doing).   Ultimately, this is a desktop game which can be quickly opened and closed like a round of solitaire which tests your gameplay ethics in a situation which is, to say the least, full of ethical uncertainty and injustice. The biggest downside to this game is that it can get boring pretty fast (the ugly colors, the ugly graphics the 1 piece of music the game has, the paper-shuffling gameplay all contribute to this) requiring a break from it now and then. This is still a good game if played for short durations and a nice reminder of how bad it can be (even (if not especially) if you really try hard to be upstanding citizen) in a soviet-fascist styled nation-state. And it has dry humor. Don't forget the dry humor because that's a whole lot of what makes this game as good as it is. That and the really cheap price. No bugs.

Glory to Arstotzka. Papers please is a basic game about a Russian ripoff dictatorship and how they have made you play the passport checker. You must try to earn enough money to keep your family alive as well as choose who enters the country.  the game seems to be about simple paperwork at first, but soon it becomes enthralling as you worry if you can feed your fake family their fake food or if you want to let this poor woman pass without the paperwork so that she can see her long lost son or something. The game progresses very nicely in difficulty and has such rich lore even though the whole game you sit behind a booth checking if the paperwork is right. There are multiple endings giving the game replay-ability and overall the atmosphere is perfect for the situation. Pros: +well done story telling +simple but meaningful player made choices +proper difficulty inclination +wonderfully depressing atmosphere +Jorji +0 micro transactions or dlc to speak of  +very low computer requirements Cons: -can get repetitive in endless mode -could use more depth into other countries -passport pictures are hard to compare to faces  fun fact: Arstotzka's soccer team is called the Arskickers

An immersive look at the life of a customs agent working for a totalitarian regime, though with only enough content for one look.  Stand Out Features: Hot rubber stamping action.  Pros: Decision points in the game mesh well with the overarching mechanics to drive home the sensation of being an overworked, underpaid, and overall terrified agent. Writing has a good mix of humor and humanity. Multiple endings based on performance and choices.  Cons: The actual gameplay gets stale after a while. Decision trees do not change unless you follow previously unexplored branches (you'll get the same decision points on the same days). Most of the memorable moments of the game come from 'gotcha' experiences that don't hold nearly as much gravitas after the first playthrough.  Would Recommend To: Gamers looking for a thought provoking or immersive experience who can tolerate some samey gameplay. People looking for about 2-4 hours of a unique gameplay experience.

An excellent videogame. Papers, Please is a very deep and sometimes moving game. You play as a border inspector, accepting and denying people into 'The Great Sovereign Nation of Arstotzka'. There's stamps, entry permits, ID supplements, contraband, guns, terrorism, drugs, smugglers, nudity, passports, bribes, fingerprints, and behind it all, the M.O.A (Ministry of Admission). My only complaint is I've played 6.4 hours, and recieved no card drops. But that's besides the point. Your name was pulled in the October labor lottery. You are obliged to buy this game. 10/10  P.S. Always let in Jorji, he ends up smuggling drugs and then bribing you to let him in.

This game makes you feel like a detective. It's almost like L.A. Noir without all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t filler in between detective work. It also has a hint of Oregon Trail, since your family can become sick and hungry and you have to support them so they don't die. It's really rewarding to notice small discrepancies with people's info and deny them access to your country. There are some funny easter eggs, as well as moments that are dead serious. It seems like anything can happen at any moment. Reply value is moderate, things can turn out differently, yet the game always starts the same and it can be annoying re-playing the same stuff to get to something different.   The art style is very nice and makes it possible to spot things you probably wouldn't if it was photo realistic, although it's still a challenge. The small details make this game. For example, people will usually look   slightly  different in their passport pictures than in person. Their hair could be different, the lighting could be off, or they could have recieved a scar.  The main gripe I have however is that $10 is a bit pricey, $5 seems more reasonable. I'd pick it up when it's on sale. The beta however is free and can be downloaded at  http://dukope.com . It's basically like a demo.  Glory to Arstotzka.

A 'document simulator.' You review documents of an endless, dreary parade of people trying to enter your crappy country from one of its crappy neighbors, granting or denying entry as you see fit. Some sort of omnipotent oversight system penalizes you for technical mistakes. Or technical *cough*'mistakes,' since that last guy slipped you a $20, causing your finger to slip and hit the wrong button, of course.  An excellent diversion from the usual videogame moral dichotomy of 'to be or not be an (donkey is censored?),' where there's actual difficulty in making a decision. As you're usually some variant of The Chosen One, games have to find a way to let you keep playing even if you prove to be a total (censored, evidently) who no one would ever trust to do anything. As such, you're usually free to be as much of a (censored again) as you'd like, and some characters might scowl at you differently, but otherwise with little or no consequence. Or to chase the carrot-on-a-stick they included to try and get you to  not  do so. In Papers, Please, however, I feel they've done a much better job giving your choices positive  and  negative consequences. Do you help the rebels, knowing it could lead to your imprisonment or death? How about if it can lead to your  family's  imprisonment? Do you let a probably-not-terrorist trying to escape an even worse country in, if it means you can pay rent? Or that it could result in a demerit? Do you let your boss violate the rules he continually berates you with? Do you turn in the guy with forged documents, knowing he's probably harmless? Or just turn him away? How about if the guard promises to pay you for each person you arrest, regardless of guilt?  Most of these are not necessarily  that  questionable, I suppose - it's still just a game, basically restricted to what the designers intended, but it is quite a refreshing change from choosing to kill or save the Little Sisters, or selecting the Paragon or Renegade responses (and usually receiving an obvious tangible benefit, regardless of what Peter Molyneux promised you this time around). It's just pleasant to have a game give you pause for thought, rather than pause to calculate reward. Or figure out which of the things is going to actually make Commander Shepard say what you want him to. But in Papers, Please: Does your family go cold tonight?   Or do they go hungry, instead?

I love this game so much. I really do. It makes me feel important being able to determine whether or not people are allowed to pass through my checkpoint.  I wish the story were longer or there was a sequel or something. Endless mode will suffice for now. However, I wish there were a mode in endless that was just endless. No timer or point system. Just working to get through the never ending sea of immigrants.  Overall, I love this game. It's got choices that will make your moral compass hurt, sharpshooter skills, and a 'puzzleish' aspect to it with determining who to deny and who to allow. After playing for a few hours straight in endless, it can get to be a bit motonous, but during story mode, it's hard to put down.  I would reccomend this game to pretty much everyone. It's almost a genre of it's own.

When starting this game, you might think it is a simple and fun change from your average game.  Until you are sixteen hours in and realise that being a virtual border guard has become a way of life, and you know all Arstotzkan immigration laws off the top of your head. It's fun and simple until you realise that you cross-reference passports with ID supplements with work permits without a second glance. It's fun and simple until you realise you know all issuing cities and can tell a genuine dimplomat stamp from a forgery with the corner of your eye. It's all fun and simple until    they find you helped the rebellion and then kill you.    Glory to Arstotzka!  The Actual Review:  The game is fun and is very easy to become serious about as it progresses. It starts off easily enough, making sure passports aren't expired and they are Arstotzkan citizen, but it becomes much deeper very quickly. I haven't gotten around to playing endless mode, because story is intriguing enough. When you begin, you want to let the poor immigrants in and help the people who need it, but you will not last long playing like this. To keep you and your family alive you need to be logical and uncaring, even to your family. Money is tight as well. My tip is alternate nights with food and heat, and those without. Only buy medicine when they are very sick. However, this game is a commitment, best saved for when you have time and effort to direct towards checking virtual passports.
Gave me a Vietnam Flashback

This game is a staple for breaking the mold of normal game genres, and my God does it work well! This pixelated stress-fest will definitely leave you on edge and enjoying ever second.  Story: Nothing too complicated. You're a low-class citizen of the lovely country known as Arstotzka, and while living there you're a 'lucky' winner of a raffle. Your prize? Working low hours as border patrol to barely sustain enough cash to take care of your family and health, and possibly make a few bucks on the side. You'll have to decide and manage betweem food and health, and making sure your family isn't dead by the end.  Gameplay: This is definitely where the game shines. The gameplay is all about understanding what can and cannot go through the border. You'll have to scroll through books and passports to decide if they meet the correct requirements to legally pass, and the pressure is solely on the player. Over time the rules get more strict, and you'll be racing against the clock to make sure you get enough people through (without penalty) to earn some cash. There's a gradual curve, so you shouldn't be too overwhelmed in the beginning, but it can be a real hair-puller by the end when you have dozens of small penalties to find.  Difficulty: As I just said, there is a curve over the course of each level. It'll start with simple tasks such as which countries can go through and which can't, all with their own special emblems to easily differenciate. But, as time goes on, more rules such as work passes and body searches get implemented, and this is where it gets tricky. Every new day you get two warnings for hiccups while working, but after that you get money deducted, and this can be painfully nitpicky. But, with enough focus and a keen eye, this is a really well done mechanic, even for people like myself who don't like playing games under pressure.  Graphics: If it isn't already obvious from my profile picture, I *love* pixel art graphics, and this is no exception. The dull colors and gritty look really show the sort of sad side to this game, and it works beautifully well. Every new citizen is different, and even some continuous characters have a familiar look you'll always remember. So, if the look seems interesting to you, you'll enjoy it no problem.  Score: 4.5/5  In short, if you enjoy really simple ideas like this that ramp up over the course of the game, and are willing to pay attention to play it properly, it is an absolute joy that will be hard to put down.

The game is a repetitive, clerical game that relies on easy, uncomplicated puzzles. You'd think that would make me dislike it... but I very quickly got caught up in the plot, which seems for the most part to be going on outside of my little booth. The game is unlike any other I've played, and it was weirdly intriguing to play a game in which I'm just some random outsider just trying to get into the 'in' crowd.   Somewhere out there, a revolution is brewing... and the player has almost nothing to do with it. But still, it's exciting, and by the time you start thinking, 'OK, that's enough paperwork...' the game throws another curveball. The only thing that seems under-done is the main character's life outside of work -- there's some peripheral talk of food and health and heat and whatnot, but it's mostly as a lever to give the player incentives to act one way or another. It'd have been nice to get more involved in that side of the story, but it would definitely have taken away from the droll toll-booth drudgery that somehow makes the game so interesting.

Papers, Please is a surreal indie game in which you play as a border inspector working for the communist country, Arstotzka. The game is full of gray areas that force the player to make difficult decisions. The 'puzzles' get increasingly difficult as the game progresses, with more and more rules being put in place for you to follow. This game is not perfect by any means, but the pros heavily outweigh the cons.   The game starts with you finding out you had been chosen in the 'lottery,' and that you are now forced to become Arstotzka's border inspector. They had recently opened the border, so crowds of people who want to get in are large and unruly, with instances such as terrorism becoming a somewhat common occurance. Everybody who comes up to you for entrance to Arstotzka has a reason for going there, whether it be work or family. It is up to you to decide if they are fit to enter by checking their passports and other documents to make sure they are not counterfeit or missing completely. If you let someone in who doesn't have the proper documents, you will be penalized. This is where the concept of choice appears, as it is up to you to decide if you want to let the desperate people in even if they are not qualified. No matter your decision, the game makes you feel terrible for what you have done. If you let them go, you lose money that you need to spend on rent and medicine for your sick family, which results in a fail-state if it happens to often. If you deny them, you will have to see their hopes and dreams crushed as they discover they may not see their family again.    The game plays fine, but the repetitive gameplay gets old rather fast, so you will often have to take a break to avoid getting too sick of the game. The puzzles start off easy, but get harder as the game progresses. It is a gentle slope, so you will never feel overwhelmed by the amount of things you have to do. It is worth noting that you will likely have to do a lot of reading in order to fully understand how to play the game, and a perfect run is pretty much impossible. The more people you get through the more money you make, but if you go too fast you may make more mistakes which result in more penalties.   The art style of this game is interesting to say the least. People look deformed and sad, which fits in with the bleak setting of the game. There is nothing noteworthy about the graphics, but the gray and brown color scale of the game portray a perfect atmoshere.   Overall, this is a great game that really makes you wonder about the choices you make. The gameplay is quite repetitive, but the tone and setting of the game seem to always bring you back for more. This is a must buy for fans of surreal, atmospheric games.

I wanted to say that this game is amazing and I would like to thank TotalBiscuit and Gourmet Gaming to introducing this game to me (I don't know why, but I'm always attracted to Indie games).   This game describes life as a Arstotzkan border officer living in the Arstotzkan border town of East Grestin (possibly a reference to East Berlin being in East Germany, a communist country. Being a socialist myself, this game gives a lot of critique to socialist regimes, which I totally disagree about the Berlin Wall, but that's a different story.  The game begins with the Ministry of Information giving you information about your new job as a Arstotzkan border officer. You are told info about your job and what to do (keep in mind, make sure your family is well, it doesn't have to be all of them, but just make sure at least one family member is alive).  The game then starts you off denying all foreigners like Kolechians (damn Kolechian scum), and only approving Arstozkans. Like all games, the game will eventually get difficult along the way and might get slightly frustrating or confusing. The gameplay is amazing and makes doing paperwork a lot more interesting (since it's a game where you do paperwork in the game.)  I would like to end it saying that the game is very interesting and detailed in its atmosphere and almost makes you think in a way (like choosing to either deny or let someone in because of something like a family member dieing or something). I would like to give this game a:  9/10  The game might get frustrating for people (believe me, it happened to me) and might annoy them, but you'll eventually get over it.  GLORY TO ARTOTZKA, COMRADES!

I love this game. I'm a bit anal-retentive about desk organization and paperwork, so this game was a perfect fit. You can follow the rules and have a good experience, but the replayability lies in bending the rules. As a bit of a completionist, I'm always interested in experiencing the different endings, and there are plenty in this game. The games are also short, so it's a good way to kill a half-hour or so at a time. I'm revisiting the game after about a year, and I still find it as enjoyable as the day that I got it.

The game always keeps you alert and some levels can be quite challenging. The aesthetics and humour are totally on point, the game really gives you the dreary vibe of the cold war / soviet union era. Who knew working the border could be so fun?

Years ago I was flipping through TV channels and saw that Phone Booth was on. I was curious how a movie confined to more or less a single locale could be interesting. I didn't see it in theaters because I wasn't convinced, but watching it on TV was ultimately worth it. A decade later I saw pixel art style game advertised as a border crossing / document verification simulator. I'd like to say that my biases about judging a book by a cover had been eliminated, but let's be real, they haven't. There are and will continue to be plenty of pixel-art games worth the price of admission, but the subject matter of Papers, Please wasn't immediately exciting.  Papers, Please is as cathartic as it is tense and addicting. Specific elements of the game become almost Pavlovian, and the presentation immediately puts you in the inspectors shoes. It didn't feel like a far-fetched scenario from the stories that I've heard, but it was an immediate experience that always returns instantly whenever the game begins. From the soundtrack to the excellently implemented sound effects.  This game is incomparable. Like a...

The communist state of Arstotzka has just ended a 6-year war with neighboring Kolechia and reclaimed its rightful half of the border town, Grestin. Your job as immigration inspector is to control the flow of people entering the Arstotzkan side of Grestin from Kolechia. Among the throngs of immigrants and visitors looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists. Using only the documents provided by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested.

Border Partol! Checking documents is oddly satisfying and rewards the sharp eye. The learning curve isn't too steep. The story is something I enjoyed more than I expected for this type of game. You have to manage your abysmal finances to feed your family and heat your home every (or every other) day. Pick it up when it's on sale.

OVERALL  9.5/10 SUPER FUN GAME  I GOT IN ON SALE BUT I STILL THINK ITS WORTH THE FULL $10 ANYWAY

I don't know how, but this game is amazing. The gameplay is extremely clever. On the surface, it is probably most similar to many 'workplace process simulator' games out there, where the challenge is to, as quickly as possible, accurately step through an increasingly complex procedure. The cognitive workout this game provides is reason enough alone to play it.  But that hardly scratches the surface! The game plays on interesting cognitive biases that make the process more difficult. And the production values are so perfect. The art, the music, the humor, all of it fits perfectly. This title stands alone in its genre as a completely novel and entertaining experience.

Papers Please is one of the most creative and intuitive games I have ever played. The story is really good but not just that but the way the story is told is solid. Most of the story is not told through cutscenes or giant blocks of text but through the gamelay which is how storys in games SHOULD be told. The story also branches off in different parts depending on what you do and there are many different endings you can get. The art of the game is really nice and all the characters in the game are special and unique and help tell the story. The game also has me make tough decisions like do I let this guy go through the checkpoint for 10 extra credits to help feed my family or do I deny him to not risk a citation. To think that this game originated from a Ludem Dare compitition is awesome and im glad the mastermind behind Papers Please Lucus Pope continued to make this game the creation we all love today.  Buy this game right now!

Every turn starts with you asking rather politely for papers. However the politeness ends there. The rest of the game is quite rude and tugs on your heartstrings in places. The X-Ray scanner is a horrifically unwelcome addition- people are hideous.  Pixels, papers, and political undertones. Oh, and poverty, poor health, perishing people, and several other things that start with 'p'. This game has 'p' all over it.

Papers, Please   is a very unique game. 3909 Studios knows how to make a game about simply manning a checkpoint into questioning the ethics of Arstotska while simultaneously questioning my own morals. Through the game things don't get easier. In fact, its quite the contrary. You'll find yourself getting beat over the head with family needs of food, medicine, and heat. All requiring money to obtain, money you don't have. In the beginning of the game I was just a worker keeping criminals and other evildoers out of my country. Then the rent wages went up, my family was getting sick. I noticed that as time went on I started to get more and more desperate for money, accepting bribes whenever I could. I was slowly becoming the person I was originally supposed to keep out. It may be too repetitive for some, but as for me though, they spiced things up enough for the game to not grow stale. The musty pixel art sets the tone in this beautiful game. 3909 Studios did an amazing job, and I look forward to see what else they come out with in the future. 10/10

I first found out about this game from a YouTube review about a year ago. I immediately bought it afterwards. If I were to try and explain Papers, Please to you it would see extremely boring. Because it's so much more than what it appears to be.  It's a timed puzzle game. You have to make moraly based decisions, where there usually are no 'good' choices. It's also packed full of social commentary. It's got simple but oh so catchy music. It's deceptively difficult.   Just play it.   Come to Arstotzka, best country in world!

Maybe it's getting plaques from my supervisor. Maybe it's getting my pay deducted when I don't hang the plaque up. Maybe it's checking people out in the scanner. ;)

A fine paperwork simulator.   Everyone I know who has played this game loves for being a dark, well-executed moral dilemma of a game. Looking at it from that perspective, I can see why they would think it's awesome.   However, for those of us that make hyper-logical decisions in life, and have extremely loose concepts of morality, this game is just a paperwork simulator. I, personally, don't care if the sad refugee woman that has no passport wants to be with her husband on the other side.. if ♥♥♥♥♥ doesn't have her paperwork, ♥♥♥♥♥ steps aside.   That said, it's a mighty fine paperwork simulator. Increasing difficulty, more and more stress added to situations, faster paces with each day. All you need is someone over your shoulder all day asking if you got the memo. Why you'd want to play a paperwork simulator is your business. But if you're a high school kid with limited emotional range, wondering what the next 20 years of your life in a bleak data-entry job is going to be like, this game has you covered.

Although $10 is a little pricey for a game that is not very long, it makes you think in a way many games do not.  This full-fledged game should be no surprise to those familiar with Lucas Pope’s work.The free versions found on his website are unique and explore seemingly simple ideas for a greater purpose. For example, the Republica Times game explores the complex notions of the power behind media, government corruption and political unrest. These same themes spread into Papers, Please, which makes it a very powerful experience. It helps to split the screen into an overall border watch view on top, which shows people standing in line, the person approaching the booth and the movements of the guards. It will also show terrorist attacks and where you will go when given the tools needed to sedate (or kill) people rushing the wall.  For more on why you need to give this game a shot, visit  http://fovgames.com/2014/01/13/papers-please/

The game is simple: Check people's passports and other papers for irregularities and approve or deny them. The appeal of this game is through the complicated situations it puts you in throughout the storyline. You get more money for letting people through, but any mistakes get you a citation. More people (correctly) through the border means more money.  The fine line between keeping your job intact and watching out for your family makes long runs of this game worth the wait.

So far as I know the only game of it's kind. The art style is beautiful, as is the soundtrack. The gameplay is by no means easy. As soon as you think that you have got the hang of all the little details you must check, another is slammed into your face. Do not think for a second that you can be lazy on the job! The game is pretty unforgiving, if you screw up 3 times in 1 day, a fine is coming your way, making the already very small amount of money you have to take care of your home and family even smaller. The story of the game has multiple endings, based on different choices you make from behind the booth. I won't give anything away, but at one point earlier on in the game you are given a legally questionable choice. It is not until much later in the game that the wrong decision comes back and bites you. You have the ability to go back to any day in all of your playtime which proves very useful for the previously mentioned screw ups.   If you are a fan of indie games, want to hardcore run through a very well developed story, do so. If you just want to chill for a bit, you can do so in the endless mode. I absolutely would recommend this game to anyone.

Papers, Please stands out from the rest for being unique. You are an immigrant inspector, from a country that is reminiscent of East Germany during the Cold War.    The game requires you to be very attentive as you need to make sure that all the documents are in order. You also need to make personal decisions on whether to let people in despite the fact they lack the required documents, but are facing persecution or are part of a group trying to make a revolution in Arstotzka, among others.    The retro graphics and colors suit the game perfectly as it tries to portray a very depressing setting. A game that actually makes you think about society!

'Papers, Please' is a fantastically detailled and immersive game that is full of surprises. I found myself marveling at the creation of difficult choices, shocking events, and meaningful moments throughout. Many choices will significantly impact gameplay, giving some replay value that similar games often lack.  the gameplay is unique and difficult, but this difficulty is balanced by its merciful leniency towards mistakes.  my one complaint: sometimes the story becomes so compelling that the gameplay seems somewhat tedious by comparison. As a result, this game is best played in bursts.  If you're someone who likes unique games with a great story, moments that truly test your empathy, and an immersive environment, I strongly reccomend this game.  Glory to Arstotzka!

This is a passport stamping simulator, and much more. The game starts off simple: You play as a passport inspector in a 1984-esque totalitarian country, deciding who to allow into the country, with a single stamp. As the game progresses, more and more odious regulations are added, making your job harder over time. At one point I had to inspect FIVE different documents just to decide whether that 80-year old bearded grandpa was a smuggler or not (he was). Right, and there's rents to pay and family members to feed at the end of each day. Tough choices are to be made every day - detain a poor sod for that extra 5 dollars in bribes, or let your son starve for a day. Fail to earn enough money over time, and your family starves to death and its game over.   The graphics, though rudimentary at first glance, as well as the simple 8-bit music perfectly complement the dystopic atmosphere of the game.  But the beauty of this game lies in its masterful storytelling. Through the stamping of passports and little dialogues between characters, you begin to learn more about the world of the inspector; the stories of the characters that pass through your passport booth (including the likeable/destestable smuggler Mr Jorji), as well as the truth of the country he lives in. Between the geopolitical tensions between Arsotka and its neighbours, the terrifying inspector from the 'Ministry of Information' and a border guard's long-lost love, the game draws you in with its simple, yet riveting storytelling.  Glory to Arsotska.

Omg. Amazing 112/10 score  First off i would like to say, any one reading this who missed the whole 'point and click' tag up above please go away. This is not the game for you.   Day one, you won the lottery! Not the money kind of lottery, you won a job! You get to run the new crossing point into your country! They country has been closed for 6 years from others.(How come we dont have that? Lottery for awesome jobs?)  Anyways. So right away, you feel some really good country pride. Either saying to people 'HEY! WELCOME TO THE COUNTRY MAN! SO HAPPY FOR YOU TO SEE YOUR FAMILY AGAIN AFTER 6 YEARS' or you're yelling at people 'GET THE HELL AWAY FROM MY COUNTRY'   Right when you feel like you're doing a great job, someone got by you and there is a terrorist attack with guns and bombs and you can't help but to feel like it's your fault. I mean, you let them in didnt you? Then there are more terrorist attacks. Then people start trying to get you to join a revolution, and you think hey! Thats something to do if i get bored. You start feeling split between your country and the other people.  Then people start giving you stripper cards. Then Drug money.  Serial Killers. People looking for lost loved ones. Then bribing you to let them through.  And you dont know what to do any more. You have to pick your own side. What should you do?   20 different endings to the game are possible, without having to restart it.  This game had me mad, happy, teary eyed and confused. Everyone should buy this game.

Paper's Please showcases the true abilities of a point an click style Indie game.  This game acts as an excellent satire of a Fascist society (obviously hinting to Russia in some areas.) The primary gameplay (stamping people's passports) is rather basic, though important and challenging at times, but the secondary gameplay (using your money on various things, deciding to side with an Anti-Arstotzkan rebel force or not, etc.) is what adds to the interesting story. This game also adds infinite playing options, for those who completed the game with the 'best?' ending.  One aspect that can be monotonous is the primary gameplay (see above), as stamping people's passports can sometimes get boring, but other than that, I would say that this game is worth your money.

Papers, Please is an award-winning puzzle game created by indie developer Lucas Pope in 2013. The game takes place in a fictional communist state of Arstotzka in late 1982. You will play as an unnamed border inspector who regulates the border checkpoint in a town called Grestin. What you will do throughout the game is to regulate who can admit and who can't by approving or denying their visas or even detaining them. The goal is to keep you and your family alive.  To approve a visa, you must make sure that there are no discrepancies in the entrants' documents, discrepancies like: expired documents, different ID numbers, and etc. The rules will change from time to time as the game progresses, for example: no entry from certain country, entrants must use certain documents, and etc. There are 31 days or levels in the game, and would take about 4 hours to complete the story mode. There are 13 Steam Achievements for the game, it should take you to finish the story mode at least twice to get them all. There are nudity in the game, so if you don't like it, you can always disable it in the options. Also, fun fact: the names of the entrants are submitted online from people all over the world.   PROS

Papers, Please is a interestingly fun game to play. When I first seen this game, my initial thoughts was that it would be boring but how wrong I was. You take on the role of an immigration inspector that controls the flow of people entering. Among the many people entering, looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists are rampant. Taking a look at the provided documents by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested. It takes time to look through the documents and then cross checking them with the book and instructions you have been give to decide if you will approve them passing or not. A really different and interesting take on something for a game. Brillient game to play and have fun with.

I remember watching a Let's Play of this game when it first came out. Back then I wasn't super into playing the games for myself but over the past 2 years I've found myself drawn back to the industry.  Papers Please caught my attention immediately and I even went as far as playing the demo because it looked like such a good game.  It's simple in it's concept - you're a border inspector for a fictional country and you have to either allow or deny people entry. But as the game progresses you uncover a plot to overthrow the government. The game gets far more complex as the days pass with new things to check, new rules, and the increasing attacks. If you can't afford the $9.99 price wait until this game goes on sale but it is for sure a must buy.

It's funny--in the age of ultra-realistic graphics and sprawling even-the-kitchen-seek AAA titles, the games I remember most are often the games where I can do the least.  Here, you see people at a checkpoint, then try to keep your family fed and warm at home. People might invite you to post-workplace events ranging from the sordid to the friendly, but you don't go there. They might claim to have interesting lives, but you don't know for sure if you're lying. All you know is the documents they have, the stories they tell, and the regulations that dominate everyone's lives.  Strangely enough, I found myself loving this game's side characters, precisely because I had to imagine their lives, and also because their lives are so obviously more interesting than the task of comparing yet another passport number to yet another government-issued ID.   This isn't the most fun of gameplay (though, despite its similarities to a rather sub-par desk job, the gameplay is strangely hypnotic and relaxing.) But it's a fascinating narrative exercise, and experiment in empathy.  I got to the end of the game once after a few hours of gameplay, and I may not re-play it. But I also can't imagine forgetting it. This is an interesting little restrained story of the game.
One of my favorite games, I love the ideas behind the gameplay, and how the story is woven into that.

For a game about stamping passports, this is a great game. It starts out easy, only people from Arstotzka may enter, then it gets more difficult. People from certain countries have to be searched, deny anyone with forged documents, ect. The more passports you process, the more money you earn, but the more mistakes you make, the more at risk you are of being fired. You have to find a fine line between Speed and Accuracy, so you can pay your rent, heating, and the like.  10/10 Great game!  Go Arsekickers  Glory to Arstotzka

It might not sound interesting at first to be an inspector of the border control but this seemingly simple game can keep you occupied for hours because it is really addicting. You want to know each of the possible 20 endings after all and find out every little secret the game has.  The atmosphere is also really well done, since you have to make enough money to feed your family, while you only earn money if you don't make any mistakes. At the same time, though, you are on a schedule so you can't take too much time.  All this is reinforced by the simple graphics which suit the game perfectly. And if you completed the story, there still is an endless mode with different features and difficulties, so in my eyes worth the money.  I give a 5/5, 10/10 or 100/100, whatever you prefer. Glory to Arstotzka!

- Let [name]'s girlfriend into the country even when papers weren't in order on first run; didn't save [name] in time next day. Continues game with a heavy heart of remorse.  - Does the same thing on second run, but managed to save [name]; finds out he'll no longer be stationed at the checkpoint and it's the last I'll see him. Cries for the rest of the game.   It's easy for me to get sucked into the gameplay, as you're trying to process as many people and as perfectly possible so you can earn enough to support your family. You'll find your morals being questioned many times throughout the game - a couple wants to escape the horror of their home country together but one of them doesn't have the proper documents?   What do you do?  Deny her and be a dutiful officer of Arstozka in exchange for pathetic wages, but at the expense of a human life and the couple's happiness?  Let her in at your expense of getting a citation, which could possibly lead to your having debts to your country and causing the downhill slide of your family?  Highly recommended. After all, nothing feels better than yelling 'DETAAAAAAINED!' when papers aren't in order.
