Papers, Please is possibly the most fun you can have in the most mundane setting.  It's 1982, and after the six-year war between Arstotzka and Kolechia comes to an end, the Grestin border checkpoint opens, reuniting families and allowing the safe passage of all sorts of characters. As the checkpoint inspector, it is your duty to approve or deny people based on the documents they have and the details therein.  Not only does Papers, Please immerse you in the fascinating world of excessive bureaucracy, but it forces you to make moral choices throughout, determining the fate of travellers and immigrants, aiding or hindering subversive elements, all while ensuring the survival of you and your family.  Such is life in  Glorious Arstotzka

Papers Please, A Fun REALLY REALLY hard game with many different outcomes. The games story is interesting and if you 'die' you have to restart becasue you have to find your mistake; Its an RPG with a twist in essence. Papers please allows you to judge your humanity with different dilemas each page. You have three different story archs to follow, The serious by the rulebook Immigration officer, The nice understanding Immigration officer or the Greedy/Do anything for your family Immigration Officer. You can mix these up to have a very interesting story. their are twenty endings and i've only experienced 5.    You really have to be in the mood to play Papers please, you can't just go 'Oh I want to play a random game' and pick this game. Its worth ten dollars but It ca nget boring once you lose the Mojo for it, But it is a great experience and definetly worth anything under twent dollars.

I came into this game with only a little knowledge of how it was going to play. I first found out about the game through one of my favorite Youtubers, OfficialNerdCubed. Immediately after I saw him play it, I went out, got myself a Steam card, then bought Papers, Please. I sat down the next day and decided to play a little bit of it, to see if I like it. Four hours later, my eyes were darting from paper to paper, trying to find the discrepancies, because whenever you let someone into your country, you automatically tense up, and wait to hear that damned printer noise, printing out your 'YOU WERE WRONG' ticket. It's honestly one of the most tense times in any video game I've ever really played. I've seen reviews on this saying 'Oh this is the boring job simulator and is stupid.' To those people, I would simply like to say that you are impatient morons who should really just go back to Call of Duty. There are only two games in the WORLD at the moment that I would consider, near-perfect. Those two games are, the orginal Portal, and Papers, Please. I'm currently only at about 14-15 hours on this game, but I'm soon going to shoot right up in hours played, because I remembered that I had 'Endless mode' unlocked. So, my record is 58 people processed without getting one wrong, and I intend to push that to at least 100. If I had to give this game a traditional score, it would be a 9.8-10. If you take anything at all out of this review, take the fact that it's an incredible, innovative game made by a genius man. Also, if anyone is interested, me and a group of friends have a very-amateur Youtube channel going at the moment. Division 4 Gaming. Please do check it out!   -That One Guy, CrisisSpectre

Fun indie game showing how WORK CAN BE FUN. Not so fun for the main character. This indie game is showing the world that there is so much potential for non traditional games out there and that not every game has to fit in there cookie cutter idea of what a game should be.

Proof that a game can be great without being traditionally 'fun.' I mean, you play as a border patrol bureaucrat (albeit in a dryly hillarious, artful representation of post-Soviet Eastern Europe) charged with cheching an ever-complicated, ineffecient book of paperwork protocols, for crying out loud. But it's a truly mature game that shreads the cload of black and white morality to a series of game-altering decisions in the same vein as 'The Witcher.' I highly recommend it.

A brilliant little game. A moment in game history and, like Gun Point, an outstanding Indy game. Short and sweet, with a solid foundational game mechanic and a great style. It was much more fun that I expected. Actually, I put off playing this game for some time after it was receiving a lot of positive press. I was not quite sold on it being 'fun' game, and it sounded on paper maybe a bit too cerebreal or possibly even boring. It is neither. Don't put it off. Play this game.

Recommended for those with an open mind to gaming, and those who find the concept of 'paperwork' intriguing.  For those who can tolerate the paperwork/puzzle-like mechanic, you get an interesting way of how a video game tells a story.
Awesome, addictive game. Challenging yet grinding. Awkward and funny.  Won a BAFTA. 'Nuff said.
For when your in the mood to play something diffrernt and a little more mellow. GLORY TO ARSTOTSKA!

This game may not seem exciting as a regular action game or FPS or whatever you are into, but once you start playing it and get addicted to the characters that you often see and denying people you can't stop. Papers, Please is your basic puzzle game. You are a inspector checking passports that let people through Arzentotka(?). You have this job to support your family of Uncle, Son, and Wife. Along the way, you can make deals with people who are passing through the border, get bribes for more money, help organizations, detain (jail) people, shoot tresspasers (bonus money if you hit them), and more. I would highly recommend this game for their are over 40 endings and if you lose once it doesn't make you start all over. It's pretty great for passing time aND HAVE YOUR HEART RIPPED OUT OF YOUR FLESH

It's is awsome feeling of power knowing what determines if someone gets into the country or not is determined by the Green or Red stamp you slam on their passport. The simplistic graphics really add to the overall feel to the game.  I'm encouraging to know that some games are still being made for solid indepth gameplay and entertainment, and not the pointless flashy bells and whistles.  Glory To Arstotzka!

Although a very simple concept and very seemingly easy game to play. Papers, Please is a much more interesting and fun game than I had orignally imagined.

Worth it at full price if you're the kind of person who really digs new-feeling gameplay mechanics. If you just want to play fun games, you might give this one a pass or wait for it to go on sale.  In general, watching a lets play would be a bad move - this is one of those 'the less you know, the better' kind of experiences, for me at least.  It's good, it's hard, and some might find it boring, but it's a game that's really *about* something, in a way so few games are. I liked it, but I can completely understand people who didn't.

You ever had one of those days? You know, that day where you wake up in you mostly unfurnished cement cube of an apartment huddled next to what little living family you have left bright and early before dawn in order to walk down to your job at the border crossing of your glorious nation to decline as many people entrance as humanly possible, even if they're in similar or worse situations as you, causing your own sanity and peace of mind to slowly drain away. Even if you succumb to your own human empathy you're immediately notified of it by some omnipotent government agent watching over your shoulder, making you wonder why you even need to be doing this job at all. It's not like it's stopping these...these FOREIGNERS from bombing civilians and terrorizing the wonderful government that provided you this job and your comfortable living quarters (Class-8). As the day wears on you start to wonder, what's the point? Why am I doing this?  It's because if you don't you and your sick, starving family will die in the cold Arztotzkan winter, exposed to the elements and nobody, not even your gracious and generous government, will care.  NEXT! Papers, please.

Addictive right from the second you start playing!  Uses a simple idea for a game and makes it so in depth, and you must make hard decisions fast. Makes you choose between helping an innocent person who could die without your help, and doing your job correctly. Never played a game like this before, but instantly fell inlove with it and just want more games like it.

Cant say enough about this great game:  recap: follow the distopian tale of a totalitarian eastern European like country as its border crossing guard, faced with the day to day challenges of moral ambiguity and government regulation.   Personal synopsis: This amazing game is a marvel of simple game-play put to the very best use. Attention to detail is king as you monitor the comings and goings of immigrants, refugees and expatriated rebels in this amazingly addicting game. Unlock time and free mode for a real challenge and see how you rank against the best. I feel like this would be a great training simulator for customs and border agents in the ever more security conscious world.
Great little game with a unique concept.

I really, really like this game. The first thing that I love about it is the dark, foreign, uncomfortable atmosphere mainly achieved through the art style, dialog and music. At first, reviewing a bunch of papers may sound boring, but it is really well done and it a satisfying experience when you get it right. If you are a meticulous person then I think you will definitely like it.  But the game isn't really about reviewing papers without making any mistakes. It is about the choices you make in this poor, communist, conflicted society. Do you allow an ill woman to pass through the gates without having all the proper papers so that she can receive the treatment that she requires, knowing that you will be punished for it and lose the money you need to feed your starving family with? There are bigger decisions to make out there, and they are all yours to make. They will lead you in one of the twenty endings.  Very refreshing game, highly recommend it!
It could be named 'Brazil: the game'. And I am referring to both my country and Terry Guilliam's movie.

Bizarrely addicting game. It's very cleverly done.  I process aerospace paperwork for a living. I compare dates and specifications. I check procedures and verify things. I already do this game for a living. Yet I still think the game is fun.

This game should not be entertaining. It's about double-checking paperwork. That should be boring. But somehow, this game is incredibly fun. I'm quite glad I found it because I have autoimmune neurological disease and my doctor is always bugging me to play matching games that will help keep my memory sharp, and I hate those types of games. This game is good for memory and attention to details, so it's not only fun, it's actually beneficial to me. I would love for the developer to make a sequel.

A great game with great story that delivers its point well.  Papers, Please is a game where you play the role of a border checkpoint inspector in a Communist dictatorship. It's your job to inspect everybody's paperwork, making sure there are no discrepancies, while dealing with managing family finances and supporting your family of five, dealing with terrorist attacks, a shadowy organization that plans to overthrow the government, and constantly,  CONSTANTLY  changing rules. The game ramps up the paperwork as it goes on, and it gets increasingly difficult to deal with it all, but the skilled will be rewarded with more money to help you live. Additionally, the game puts several different choices to you, all revolving around loyalty to your country, loyalty to yourself, loyalty to said shadowy organization, or loyalty to what's right, and it's up to you to choose what you think is right.  At the end of the day, it's a 9/10 from me.
This game is very fun and is much harder then it looks.

What you want red stamp, because you have better job else where? Ha ha, no way man, you come work for the Glory of Arstotzka!

An excellent game. Simple mechanics, great context. The result: an amazing experience. It is hard to believe that a game could present moral choices, and you honestly don't know what is the right option, as you have to choose between compassion and trying to earn enough to keep you and your family alive for another day. The fact that you genuinely feel like an idiot when you make a mistake shows just how well designed the game is, as this is despite the fact it is almost impossible not to miss the occasional discrepancy, at least if you want to process enough people to pay for food, rent and heating.

Do you have a lack of control over your life? Do you have difficulty with confrontation? Do you want to serve your glorious country of Arstotska? If you answered you to 0 or all of these questions this game is right for you. Be the decider of fate as you man a border station and choose whether or not to allow helpless people to enter your country! Break up families, ruin lives, end lives, have people arrested, allow people into your country because you thought they were funny! You dont need to pay for heat tonight, your family can freeze! Maybe you're here becasue you like stamps. If so then boy are you in for a treat because that is one of the only actions you can do in the entire game! All this and more in Papers Please.

PROS: Engaging story, great sense of humor, multiple outcomes  CONS: Doing well at the game without 'cheating' requires an exceptional combination of efficiency and attention to detail   I heard about this game some time ago back when it first came out, but I didn't give it a serious shot until I saw the first few days played by a popular Irish Youtuber. Playing it myself it really was unexpectedly fun! There's much more of a story than you'd expect -- there's even a bit of RP involved, as you get to decide what kind of inspector you'll be -- and I even found myself replaying one day over and over and over and over (etc...) until I finally got the result I wanted (TRUE LOVE CONQUERS ALL!!).   Sadly  Ironically, my IRL job means that I'm actually quite good at the game as well: after my first playthrough I had a citation/error rate of about 11%. My IRL government contracting job asks for not much more than that, only 5% error.  If you're considering the game, I'd certainly give it a gry. And if you're not willing to commit whatever the base price is at the time that you're reading this, then just wait for a sale. But IMO, it's worth it!  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

I have played through it and *SPOILER* *SPOILER*. Ok im not going to give spoilers but overall this game was very well designed in its game mechanics, overall difficulty and continuity of story, and art design. Kudos to the creator and I hope this game gets sequel or something. I recommend this game to anyone who is mature enough to handle the political and violent content of this game.

Games As 'Profound Social Commentary'  As a compelling medium for fundamental changes to the human psyche.   Virtual Reality is here. Occulus Rift. HTC Vive. Playstation VR. They have the potential to immerse human beings in experiences that the vast majority of us will never have. Exploring space. Being a pirate. Destroying the office at work. That's amazing, but the 'vision' and the 'message' of games like Paper's Please, are what truly capitalize on the gaming medium as a tool to make humanity grow for the 'better.'   A 'Masterwork' of game design in my opinion. Taking the premise of being A Border Control Officer/ A Paper Pushing Bureaucrat in a fictional Cold War nation (something seemingly dull beyond measure) and using easy to understand mechanics, the game crafts a poignant and surprisingly moving 'narrative'. Highs and Lows. Triumphs and Failures.   The game is hard, frustratingly so at times, but never as a result of poor game design, rather it is hard because the game simulates the conditions of a 'broken bureaucracy trying to maintain order through oppression, resisted by the people who demand being free, demand being treated as thinking, feeling, valuable human beings'. In the game, you are just a simple Father, trying to take care of his family with grossly insufficient state provided means, but your little actions, your small kindnesses and cruelties, can cast ripples that will change a single life or even a whole society.   I feel...like I have a greater understanding of what it was like live in a society with an authoritarian regime controlling/monitoring/ threatening your life. It is something that I feel an even greater desire to resist than I did before. Freedom is something that every human being truly deserves, and truly needs to thrive and be genuine to what it means to be human.   Paper's Please is a game that uses the gaming medium for its very best purpose, imo : to entertain and use that entertainment for the personal and humanist growth of the player.   $10. 100 MB Download. Graphics an original Nintendo could have duplicated. And one of the best, most important games (out of 100's) I've ever played.

Repetetive Gameplay with more freedom than alot of open world games. It is really the player himself who forges the story of not only his avatar, but of a family but for entire countries. One receives an incredible feeling of responsibility. Every stamp can mean death to you, your family or innocent people.  The game starts out slow but picks up on difficulty very quickly. Alot more papers to check, handling money problems, eventualy getting caught up in a plot of revolutioners or whatnot. I couldn't drop the game for atleast 6 hours upon starting initialy.  This game is strangely addicting.  I clearly recommend this to anyone. It is not just a game. It is a test of personality.  Gameplay 10/10. Yes it is repetative but the game manages to keep your concentration. Time management is important. Graphics 8/10. I really couldn't say that at any point I had wished for a graphical enhancement. No high end graphics but it fits the games atmosphere imo. Sound 7/10. Nothing special but neat. Replayabillity 7/10. Well I have only played for 6 hours now. Essentially, the game part of the game is about memory and pattern recognition/matching. Do this person's papers match with their other papers? With the official guidelines? With what you can see? Be sure, but be quick. The clock is ticking, and you need to make your quota to keep your family warm and fed.  If you were hot ♥♥♥♥ at the 'spot the differences between these two pictures' puzzles in children's magazines, you'll no doubt do well. But it also requires a bit of the mindset needed to get the same level of enjoyment out of the same type of puzzles in parody magazines, where you're shown two identical pictures and then told 'The doctor on the left is telling his patient he has an inoperable brain tumor. The doctor on the right is telling his patient he has bubonic plague.'

Tired of your run of the mill job? Well come home to your other run of the mill job and enjoy yourself! This is one of those niche games that is enjoyable, but little long term playability. I count it almost as a puzzle game. You are timed to see how many people you can appropriately get across the border. Comparing their passports, IDs, and paperwork to your guidelines and their responses.  Fun game for when you want to kill a little time.
Really enjoyable view into the politics of border control. Lots of moral ambiguity.

Amazing. This game is a tedious yet heart warming yet makes you want to have a heart attack as you wait for a violation. This game takes place in a made up country called Arstotzka, and you are a person pulled in the labor lottery to work at the new border checkpoint. Though at first it seems very simple elements are quickly added to make you decide between speed and quality, and the wrong choice could get you exacuted. Random events happen throughout the pre-made story to make you go against or for your country. Also you meet intresting characters that you see time and time again and make you smile and you are evaluated on how well you do your job, needless to say you will probably be told you are scum several times over each day. There is a struggle that feels almost too real in this game where you are trying to make ends meat, making almost nothing and supporting an entire family on that. There is far more i could say about this but in the almost ten hours i've played already i know this game is like non i've played before. If you like being challenged, experiancing something new, or even deciding who lives or dies. This game is for you. If you want a unique game that will challenge you to add to your library, Welcome To Arstotzka.

Having always wanted to pay for the pleasure of doing menial tasks whilst living under the oppression of an Orwellian state, I went into Papers please with very high hopes.  On starting the game, I was pleasantly surprised by the sheer number of digits and names that had to be cross-checked and I was enjoyign my first day as a guradian of the Democratic Republic immensely before the day ended and I was forced to return home to my parasitic family. This opened up the second key part of the game, being depressed as loved ones die because you, as sole family provider, were too busy apprehending criminals in the name of mother  Russia  Arstotzka. This in the end turned out to be very useful as one family member dying really frees up funds to pay for medicine or expensive crayon sets and keep the others alive.  As the game went on I found that a significant amount of nothing happened, which really livened up the experience and made me wish that exciting things like dening people entry would happen less frequently, however I then began to see the value of things happening in video games as it helps to compartmentalise the long stretches of enjoyable bureaucracy.  In conclusion, more games need to make me feel completely bored and slightly depressed, then maybe they too could have as much praise as I'm dropping onto Papers Please. Also Papers Please is what we in the industry call 'enjoyable', we also say that it 'contains gameplay' which may sound strange in this day of 10 minute long cutscenes, but surprisingly it actually contributes to the experience if the player is occasionally allowed to take control of the protagonist.  -Glory to Arstotzka  -Your Comrade Delta_Lemon

Working at a job that deals with people's well being can be incredibly taxing. Your decision determines whether their lives continue in bliss or go up in flames. It's hard to stare someone in the face and tell them they are wrong, despite their best efforts. Papers, Please gives you the task of being a border checkpoint agent.  With that comes tasks such as checking passport information and following the rules set out by your company. Should you disregard those rules, you will be penalized and may end up losing your job, family or life. It's a very serious game of give and take with people who are honestly trying their best and others that want to game the system.  Most people will never experience such a scenario in their own lives, but this game truly hits home for those that work in public services. Being a doctor, nurse, clinician, phychologist or any kind of care giver can put an incredible strain on your mind. Maybe you gave the wrong advice, or your administration of medicine was done too early; hell, maybe you just looked at someone wrong.  It's never easy to hear a sob story and then deny someone a basic human right that you take for granted. Denying passports and reading that the person is upset can be stomach turning. You feel desperately bad, even if they should have just followed the rules.  Mixed in with all these moral quandaries is a plot about a corrupt government and a rebel group attempting a coup. You can safely ignore them and still have a satisfying experience, but delving into the complexities of the plot in Papers, Please reveals something interesting; maybe you don't agree with everything.  It's easy to be a dutiful citizen and get nothing in return, accepting that life is ♥♥♥♥ and clocking out for the day. It's difficult to stand up to oppression and change the face of the world. Papers, Please gives you an opportunity to see what that change can do and how you can be the catalyst for a revolution.  Or you can simply do your 9 - 5 job and get a decent paycheck and a nice apartment. The choice is yours, but no choice is easy. Thankfully, your save file can be split into branching paths, allowing you to experience every possible scenario.  The graphical style and music bring home the entire package. It feels oppressive and familiar. It looks like an SNES game, but it feels unique. It sounds like the USA lost the Cold War, but it also shows a country in disarray. It's bleak, but beautiful.  The only flaw would be that the game is a bit short. Also, that branching path system doesn't make all of your choices concrete. Having a system by which one mistake ruins your game would be more in line with the self-reflection the game is pushing on you, but I can understand that it would make the game feel incredibly daunting.  Regardless, Papers, Please is worth a play by anyone interested in a more realistic look at humanity. A job that most people never thought of and will probably never see first-hand. It's truly a modern masterpiece and well worth the $10 asking price.  9/10

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Papers, Please is grueling, grim, tedious, and a bad choice if you are looking for lighthearted entertainment. You play a customs agent, trying desperately to make ends meet while filing border corssing papers for a corrupt dictatorship. This game is easily the _opposite_ of what people would normally consider fun.  And yet despite all that, or perhaps because of it, this game is amazing!!!  This is an incredibly well-made game! The attention to detail is amazing! There are countless little human touches everywhere whch constantly break up the inhuman levels of paperwork. And even though all you can do is stamp documents, your choices have a real effect on the world around you. People's lives are changed by your stamp, even yours! There are literally dozens of endings that you can get depending on your stamping decisions. The social commentary is also fatnastic, and the moral dilemmas that the game puts you in -with just your stamp- are gut-wrenching! You will never agonize over a piece of paper like you will in Paper's Please, and you will never look at a DHS or customs agent the same way again!  And that is the game's most amazing accomplishment. Without any traiditonal fun game mechanics Papers, Please manages to be engaging, agonizing, cathrtic, insighful, and a blast to play! You'll just have to pick up your stamp to find out what you've been missing!

It's pretty straightforward. You are an inspector at a checkpoint, in a very sh- I mean glorious country, and your job is obviously to inspect the documents given (or sometimes, not given) by people who wish to enter the country. If their documents are good, you let em through. If not, you turn them away or detain them depending on their papers (forgery = detain), and if you make a mistake, you are punished by losing your MONIES! If you fail keep your MONIES (credits), you and your whole family will likely die horrible deaths. As you play, more variables and things you must check for pop up, leaving you somewhat paranoid about letting people through (or at least for me, every time I used the green approval stamp I was just waiting to see what I overlooked). It's a very fun game, and the story is pretty great (there are multiple endings depending on what you do, and some pretty sweet token-achievement-things you can get by making some choices). This is another plain ol 'good' game that deserves much praise. If you haven't gotten it yet, I really do recommend that you do so.

This game is really different to anything I've seen. In a world where games are mostly violent shooters, or cute and cuddly games, or games with little variation churned out by huge companies, Papers Please is a breath of fresh air. In the beginning you want to obey the game, don't let in that woman, even if it will unlock a secret. Don't follow the order, even if doing it right gets you the best ending. Even trying to not care about your virtual family, who are never seen or named, only known as OK, COLD, SICK, HUNGRY, is not seen as a good thing to do. I must not accept these bribes, they could mess up my track record! My family can go without food tonight. After a while, your heart softens. This guy seems cool, and it's just a silly citation, I'll let him in. My son desperately wants this expensive birthday present. I'll buy it. My niece needs to be adopted. She can some, it's fine. By the end, you should either have a good ending, and the game does offer some replay with the different endings (20 + achievements and collectable tokens). There's only one thing left to say about this game.   GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Ever wonder what life is like? Need a job? Want to get laid tonight? Welcome to Papers Please. A game where you protect the borders of the proudly named city Arstotzka.  Life follows as such. Work for the day check papers and go through the regulations, and recieve pay to keep the home running for your family. Fail to do so, and your family suffers. I.E they die clearly Keep failing or falling behind on rent and you go to jail.   The whole point of this game is to work and view the world. The later half of the game presents the real juice of Papers please. However I reccomend playing this game in small doses, and not large ones for the sake of keeping some sanity.   I'd reccomend this game on a sale, and not for full price. As this style of gameplay is clearly not going to be for everyone.

Papers Please at first seems like one of those web browser games with the simple concept of just getting the highest score you can. It quickly turns into one filled with side stories, and an overall (non linear) arching plot where you decide the fates and futures of yourself, your family and the many different people you meet at your checkpoint. This is also one of the more challenging games out there as you eventually have to balance multiple different types of documents and search them for even more discrepencies with even more availiable tools. (There is an easy mode for those wary of the games initial difficulty level.) That being said, the main draw of this game is how unique it really is and how good the stories in such a simple game can be. I rate it so far the third best game of 2013 behind the likes of The Last of Us and Bioshock: Infinite. Quite good company to be around.
Don't touch the powder. Just don't.

This game is hilarious, creepy, repetitive, and engaging all at the same time. While its concept of accepting or denying people the right to entire a country may seem boring, or even idiotic to put into a video game, it works! The campaign focuses on paying close attention to detail so you don't earn penalties by admitting fraudulent people, all the while you get paid based on people let in and you're on a timer. Your family and yourself can all die of mutliple causes, and the game ends automatically if you run into debt. Everything is expensive, and the pay is little. The other gamemode, Endless, allows you to repeatedly play the game based on a few parameters, depending on the sub-gamemode that you choose. While the game may get frustrating at times, the frustration has a flappy bird effect, where it just keeps drawing you in to play more. For just $10, this game is a steal.

Never the less, if you can appreciate a subtle, yet suprisingly interesting story, you might just like it as much as I do.

8/10: Work loyally as border inspector, decide who may enter glorious homeland or return from whence they came. Survive attacks and thwart smugglers until audit comes at the end of thirty days! Glory to Arstotzka!   This game is heavy. The atmosphere is heavy, with the only music being the deep march of the starting screen. Meanwhile, the graphics, reminiscent of NES graphics and earlier, combine well with the garbled speech that only ever seems to sound like 'gestaht' (gestalt? get out? pretty authoritative and germanic sounding) or 'hayaku' (japanese for faster?). Even the core action is heavy, forcing you to focus on the tedium of finding discrepancies in the paperwork of immigrants lest you return home with less pay for food and heating.   Yet just because it isn't strictly fun in the 'Saints Row' sense of reckless abandon and indulgence, doesn't mean 'Papers, Please' isn't engaging. The stress of living out each day, pulled between the attention of your family, your country, and the enigmatic Order of the EZIC Star. Loyalty has its rewards, but any inkling of seditiouis activity may lead to a most miserable end. Thus, it is up to you who to help, both on an individual level and on society at large.   Personally, I was intrigued by the procedurally generated people interspersed between the scheduled characters. Jorji Costava was undoubtedly the one glimmer of comic relief amongst the procession of separated families and sly smugglers. Right when I saw that passport from 'Cobrastan' I knew he'd be my number one source of warnings, though I thankfully managed to never have pay taken away via excessive citations.  While I generally took pride in getting no citations and returning with plenty for my family, I took exception with truly momentous events, especially since I wanted to get all the foreign coins in one playthrough. In particular, reuniting Sergiu with his love was sweet, and there was a grim satisfaction in going along with the vengeful fathers plan to murder Simon Wens, the man who killed his daughter.   Nonetheless, this is definitely a melancholy game as a whole, and is all the better for it. Rather than the shiny, happy veneer one might find in free to play or corporate games, 'Papers, Please' confronts the anxiety of being an unassuming, yet critical, cog in the machine. Feeling powerless, yet potentially influencing the development of these shifting nations, with you being the decider of who permeates the membrane between them. It's an interesting position to be in, even if the mechanics aren't as exhilirating as one typically expects from a game.

When looking at the concept for Papers, Please, it sounds very dull. However, the game provides the player with choices that challenges one's morals. I recommend Papers, Please for this reason; It is the one game I have played that has made the job of Immigration Officer seem like a plausible career choice. 10/10 Would Recommend.

Papers, please is a story-themed game that revolves around you being the border control. Shifting through mountains of papers every day, you must be able to distinguish between spy, foe and friend. Is that man your countryman, or is that a terrorist with bombs on his body? Make one mistake and it will be costly. Balancing your funds, food, heating, medicine and the needs of your family, it blends to create a hardcore experience for players who want a challenging puzzle game.  I must say, I don't really like this game. It's great, what with the engaging music, and its challenging yet tedious, repeating tasks... but I'm sure others will find it great.

There is not a huge catalogue of politically themed games, and certainly not many as humorous as this one. Working as an immagartion officer overlooking the paperwork of people wishing to enter into the fictional country of Arstotzka, you are a low level bureaucrat struggeling to make ends meet. Without enough money you are unable to feed your family, pay the electricity bills and get medicine in case someone get sick. The gameplay focuses on making sure incoming documents meet the requirements in shortest amount of time possible, with rules changing from day to day and fines handed out for mistakes. It honestly feels closer to work than play, and the the suspicious atmosphere is bound to put you on edge.   Its an insight into what lives might like for the kind of people it is easy to look down upon and despise.The neat presentation, delightful humour and interesting story elevates it into a rare gem.

It is strange how a game about checking papers can be so captivating, but Papers, Please is just that! The music will linger with you for days, as you frantically check the expiration dates on all your real world identification.  All glory to Arstotzka!

The entire premise DOES seem boring. I'll admit it. Yet this game has a lot more to offer than stamping papers in a booth...oh wait no it doesnt...but its FUN! Aside from learning what its like to protect a border from criminals, this game has a secret or two up its sleeves involving a shady society of rebels. There is also fun funny foreign guy who keeps forging documents in crayons.  In all seriousness, the game is a morality decision simulator. You will encounter all sorts of 'grey areas' during your work. Will you split up a married couple with the wrong forms? Take a bribe to buy your kid medicine? Let a celebrity or politician through who sort of looks like a wanted criminal? YOU DECIDE!  I truly recommend it at its discounted price. If I had paid over 10 bucks I would consider myself ripped off...but for 4.99 this game has entertained me for quite some time.   WARNING!!!! - This game is incredibly addictive and if you are like every gamer or person with a steam account, and you posess an obsession with video games, be prepared to spend hours at a time stamping papers in a virtual world while your family or significant other cooks dinner and gripes about your lack of interest.

This game is addicting and the twists and turns that are thrown in keep the game interesting. Otherwise it would be the same task over and over again. I love the old-style graphics and how much character the game has at times.

To call Papers, Please a game would be misleading - it's an interactive form of story telling, with a bit of 'choose your own adventure' thrown in. The gameplay mechanics, while not complicated, are interesting, and the gradual addition of changes to the mechanics means the game has a kind of natural progression to it without being too contrived. The aesthetic is simple but fits well with the Soviet-era theme, while the storytelling is absolutely excellent. The brief insights you're given into the various characters you will interact with are well thought out, and serve to push the overall themes of the game. Some of those interactions will be funny, some touching, and a couple will shock you. The socio-political narrative is not complicated but should absolutely get you thinking. Couldn't recommend this 'game' more highly.

This game will make you feel like a real Arstotzka immigration inspector.  At first the game may seem simple, but it manages to create a great atmosphere. You get immersed in your tasks and you feel the pressure of it. You have to do your job properly, and quickly, otherwise your family won't have access to heating or food. But also, you will need to pay attention to the details, as the risk of terrorists attacks is on the rise, and it's on your shoulders if anything were to happen.  As the game goes on, the relations between Arstotzka and the other regions change, therefore changing the entry requirements you have to check, making the game challenging every day.  It's a great game, challenging and intriguing.

In this cheeky throwback not just to early PC games, but also to life on the wrong side of the Iron Curtain at the height of the Cold War, you play a fictional Eastern-European border official. You man the border checkpoint and stamp passports. But you've got a family to support, and so you must cut corners, and thus the remarkably sly satire of this game reveals itself, as you are put in the shoes of someone slowly becoming corrupted as they try to operate within a corrupt system. This game is deceptively simple, unexpectedly addictive, funny and Kafkaesque in equal measure. A very clever idea, executed brilliantly.
if paperwork was fun it would be like playing this game all the time

My first impression was rather good -- a feat in and of itself since I tend to hate everything the first time I try it. While learning the ropes of how to do my labor-lottery won job and having to feed me and my family *and* keep us warm for ridiculous amounts of credits each DAY, I felt a healthy and enjoyable amount of existential dread.  After the initial shock wore off I was able to analyze just how the economy is in this Arstotzka place -- it's just about as expensive as 2014 USA; this game managed to be a sneaky commentary, and actually fun to play while it was doing it.  If nothing else, this is a great time-sink that can keep you busy for hours, upon hours, upon..... etc.

The man was kind, had all the paper work, none of it expired. I let him pass, and unlike most, he thanked me politely. His next works were, 'Please be kind to my wife. She is right behind me.' She came forward, without the needed papers. I did a scan. Maybe she was like some others, and would say 'Here it is.' while hading me the missing paper. Instead she begged me, saying that they wouldn't give her the papers. My mind knew that I should deny her, as she was no more that a villager in Minecraft. Nothing would change irl. But my heart couldn't split these two. I had no penalties that day, so I accepted her with nothing happening to me. 20/10 would accept again.

An excellent game. Simple mechanics, great context. The result: an amazing experience. It is hard to believe that a game could present moral choices, and you honestly don't know what is the right option, as you have to choose between compassion and trying to earn enough to keep you and your family alive for another day. The fact that you genuinely feel like an idiot when you make a mistake shows just how well designed the game is, as this is despite the fact it is almost impossible not to miss the occasional discrepancy, at least if you want to process enough people to pay for food, rent and heating.

Papers Please is a game many people i've met think is perfect. While I disagree with this for the reason that the day that a game is perfect is the day that world peace becomes a reality, I still think that this game deserves all the credit it gets. In the game you are a worker at a boarder checkpoint, but this is covered in the discription so i wont go into much detail. Most of the gameplay consists of managing papers and deciding if all the papers are in order and sending off into the county. It starts off easy but slowly becomes harder as you have to manage up to 15 things to check by end game. I do not want to spoil too much of the endnings as there are 15 i belive, however I encorage you to get this game. It is a look into your own self conscious. Will you listen to the sob story of a random person you have never met and let them in or will you save that five dollars you get for turning her away to buy medicine for your dying son. The choice is yours. It took me about 10 hours to finish my first run, but with 15 diferent endings and all of them being from 6 hours to 10, you will get your moneys worth out of this game.   10/10

Your family starves, you rot, and the game is over. Alternatively you help Ezic. You flee with forged passport, and your family dies, game over. There are a lot of different endings with hilarious outcomes, and many depressing easter eggs for a our comrade. At first glance it looks like an over tedious strategy game with bad graphics, but after you start to align yourself with your character and put yourself in this Cold War drama, you start to have a lot more fun.

I work a full day at the booth approving or denying entry, only to go home and find that everyone in my family is cold, sick, starving, and there's nothing I can do about it. I'll bring as many people through as safely and accurately as possible, and can't earn enough income to keep my family from dying.   Too depressing, too stressful.

'Papers, Please' is a game that I did not expect. There are those indy games that you play for a few days and then never really look at again, but 'Papers, Please' grabs your attention with a slow build of very intense character interactions that are all based on whether or not you have all the correct papers to gain entrance at a immigration check point. It delves into corrupt politics, threatening scare tactics, and dealing with bomb smuggling terrorists, and people offering you bribes for entry into your gate. Its more intense and connecting that I thought and all the hidden espionage is definietly something that keeps your playing just to figure out how you got yourself into this situation where you are left with bombs, tranq gunning people down, and hoping not to ♥♥♥♥ of your over-seers.

Papers, Please is a strangely addicting game that starts out fairly simple at first. You man a checkpoint at the border and have to check immigration documents for validity and decide on if they meet entry requirements or not. You get citations for making mistakes, and there is a lot of unrest happening at the border outside of your station. You have to move fast, because you are on a per-visa pay basis and have to feed your family and pay rent.  Worth it.

You're playing a bureaucratic game, right? Well, not quite. What really makes this experience fun is the game-within-the-game that develops. No spoilers, but the plot plays out in such a way that you're forced you to make very serious decisions. Never has the mundane felt so engaging.

What should you do when you're sitting in an office and have nothing to do? Play a border guard simulator where you are in an office with nothing but stamping passports to do!  10/10 Glory to Arstotzka

So what do you do in this game? Stamp papers. You heard me, the whole game is focused on stamping papers. Lots of papers. To be specific, you play as an inspector who accepts or rejects passenger's passports. Make money at the end of each day by being as accurate as you can. Some passports are real, others... well they are fake. People would do whatever they can to get in Arstotzka, so be careful. What I personally love about this title is the choices you can make. You can choose to reject an individual's passport to avoid tickets and make money to support your family. OR you may accept their passport to save their dear life..but lose money because their passport is incorrect. It's your call; the power lies in your hands. The addition of special events, missions, secret organizations, news reports, and the ever changing requirements, makes this one very stressful game. It's stressful but rewarding. Glory to Arstotzka.

This quirky game tells a delightful story or cold war-era, sattelite state immigration in a choose-your-path adventure format. I could not belive how much fun I was having while filing through mountains of paperwork. I was completely immersed. The ritalin-popping hardcore FPSers will not be able to take a second glance at a game with such culture and pacing, but if you have the patience, let Papers, Please take you on a journey of endless eustressing decisions.

'Papers, Please' is one of the best games on the market currently. Lucas Pope has come up with an original way of interacting with the game's story; there are choices, rules and a family to care for. You can lose yourself in the passport-stamping gameplay in the Endless mode or work for your family in the Story mode. 'Papers Please' forces you into making decisions that make you feel puny, evil and completely responsible for all the bad goings-on in Arstotka. Mr Pope? You deserve a knighthood.

You win the lottery, but this lottery is the one that gives you the job as the guy that checks the passports or citizen cards (if they're citizens of the best country in the world (glory to Arstotzka). Oh, and then you have to check for entry tickets, vaccination slips (we can't let polio-infected-filth into our glorious country), working passes, and entry passes.  You commit yourself to this job in order to keep our glorious Arstotzka safe...well, and to keep your family healthy and fed, but that comes second (obviously). Everything starts out nice and simple. You let the people with Arstotzka passports in. No other passports permitted. Sooner or later, we find that these passports have false information. Discrepancy detected. Now we have to watch for false information and deny them access to our glorious country. No exceptions.  Then, a terrorist attacks our border checkpoint and we find it's committed by a piece-of-filth Kolechian. They may not enter Arstotzka, and even better, if they try to pass through, they can say bye to their passports because they have been claimed by our Glorious Leader.  In this game, we have this job, wait, no... we have this honor of protecting our glorious country from unwanted degenerates. We are faced with unworthy liars and traitors who are only out to undermine the beauty of Arstotzka. They will try to have you join 'their cause', but their cause is something cannot be trusted. All of your trust, as is mine, goes to the glorious Arstotzka. Your 'family' (Arstotzka is your family now) may die. My neice ran away and I did not have the money to house her because I wanted new equipment to help me keep Arstotzka safe. Sacrifies will be made. People will die. You may die. Arstotzka lives on. Glory to Arstotzka.

Cant say enough about this great game:  recap: follow the distopian tale of a totalitarian eastern European like country as its border crossing guard, faced with the day to day challenges of moral ambiguity and government regulation.   Personal synopsis: This amazing game is a marvel of simple game-play put to the very best use. Attention to detail is king as you monitor the comings and goings of immigrants, refugees and expatriated rebels in this amazingly addicting game. Unlock time and free mode for a real challenge and see how you rank against the best. I feel like this would be a great training simulator for customs and border agents in the ever more security conscious world.

I really, really like this game. The first thing that I love about it is the dark, foreign, uncomfortable atmosphere mainly achieved through the art style, dialog and music. At first, reviewing a bunch of papers may sound boring, but it is really well done and it a satisfying experience when you get it right. If you are a meticulous person then I think you will definitely like it.  But the game isn't really about reviewing papers without making any mistakes. It is about the choices you make in this poor, communist, conflicted society. Do you allow an ill woman to pass through the gates without having all the proper papers so that she can receive the treatment that she requires, knowing that you will be punished for it and lose the money you need to feed your starving family with? There are bigger decisions to make out there, and they are all yours to make. They will lead you in one of the twenty endings.  Very refreshing game, highly recommend it!
An amazing game that forces moral choices with lasting effect on you. Do you want to feed your family or let this man go through the checkpoint even though his papers are wrong?

Papers, Please is a fantastic little indie game set in a fictional Eastern European country called Arstotzka in the fall of 1982. You play as an Immigration Officer at a check point into Arstotzka. The gameplay compromises checking passports and other required documentation in determining if they can enter the country. Even though the game play sounds simple, it very quickly becomes complicated by adding more and more rules and requirements to allow people entry. Depending on how you play, how well you play, and which story line you follow, the game offers a variety of endings. If you can get past having to stamp passports for gameplay, Papers, Please offers a great gaming experience.

PROS: + Unique gameplay + Replayablilty + Nice pixelized graphics which requires only 40 mb of space + Trading cards   CONS: - The game does not provide an option to see what you did wrong - Can get repetitive  A funny little game for a fair price.   My rating: 7.5/10

Unique, funny and challenging, Papers Please is unlike any other game you've ever played. Set in a fictional totalitarian country, you act as a border checkpoint guard struggling to keep your family warm, fed, and healthy. Paid by the number of people you screen daily, you will encounter forgers, smugglers, and, even more morally challenging, people trying to visit sick relatives with improper paperwork. Do you call to your humanity, let them through, and risk your family's welfare and imprisonment? Or do you stamp denied on their passport to their curses and possible future retributions?  To say more of this very clever game would spoil it but it is a steal at the price for modern gaming ingenuity at its finest.

Get this game on sale while you can! It is a fantastic indie game that shows the potential of video gaming. Games with moral choices are often too simple and binary with predictable results. This game removes the boring of the binary and sometimes throws the player for a loop with the complexity of reality. It is impossible to play just once and is well worth the price.

'Gimme your papers, I need money and I close at 6PM.' Papers Please on a nutshell. 30 days of a simple yet awesome game that can get you hooked on from the moment you open it. Music is pretty cool if a little bit sad, and graphics are grey, yet they just add to the game's scenery that fits a Cold War-Post Cold War decaying country.

This is exactly my type of game. This game deals with global relations, from the eyes of the 'common man,' who has been given a slight amount of power. With the power to deny or grant entry into Arstotzka, you make choices to either better the state, or yourself, or perhaps even the immigrants, with all decisions ending in consequence. Arstotzka, a socialist state, has both elements of new technologies, mixed with the glory and look of the 'old world,' and I love it. This is a fun game, with all types of challenges, and I would definitely buy it.

when i first saw this game i couldn't believe i will love it like i do now that im playing it :) dont let the screenshots/video fool you, the game is awesome!

A true oddball game. Nobody would ever think that making a game about something a dull as checking passports could ever be made into a truly great game like this one manages to be. The story line has many branching points were you are given the choice to support the current weakened communist government or aid the well-meaning but somewhat foolish rebels, all the while deciding what to do with hordes of people seeking a better life in your “glorious” country.   How it handles the actual meat of the game is very well done, starting you off checking passports and adding to that slowly until you are armed with a sniper rifle, forcing people to do strip searches to make sure they aren’t bringing weapons or drugs, checking fingerprints and criminal records, all the while making sure that their passports, work permits, diplomatic papers, immigration pass, vaccination certificates and identity cards are all correct and not forged in any way.  This game will test your eye for detail and refine it down to a laser point. If you ever wanted to play a game that makes you feel as smart as Sherlock Homes without actually playing a Sherlock Homes point and click adventure game this is it.
Simply the best border control simulator on the market right now.
This game is absolutely amazing. Even though I have almost 9 hours on it, I would still advise you to get this game, it is highly addicting.

Lucas Pope has quckly become for me a dev who is the king of simple games that get really hard as you go. Papers Please at first seems like a really boring game at first. You sit at the border of two ficticious countries, deciding who can get in and who can't. The fun comes from the unique controls and the hidden storylines that emerge as you play.   The gameplay is simple throughout the whole game but gets increasingly difficult as you play. You are in charge of the Grestin Checkpoint of Arstotzka. You do this by clicking and dragging the many items you are in charge of. Your first day is very easy: only let people with Arstotzka passports in, everyone else must be denied. Of course you could let anyone in with a dock in pay. You can let anyone in on the second day as long as their passports aren't expired. The whole point of the game is to follow the rules. It's easy to look at them in the first page of your handbook, but making sure all the conditions for entry, especially in the later part of the game, is difficult.  As far as those hidden storylines go, you are also in charge of getting paid enough money to feed and warm your family. There's also some people who want you do do things that might be unsavory to the dilligent border officer, from accepting bribes to be let in without a passport, to corrupt governments and a rebelious cult. All these elements mix together to add up to over ten different endings. It is possible to get through the whole game without getting a paper check wrong, you can do so poorly that you starve your family to death, you can help corrupt people, or have them taken care of. The choice is yours...  In short, the satisfying and simple controls to a complicated and dynamic pixel world make for a fun and stressful game.

I didn't know what I was getting myself into when I bought this game. On the surface it's just a simple 'check things and press the right button' game, but there is so much more to it than that......The actual 'game' part turns you into this monster....Do you allow border crossing to a wife who wants to be with her husband, or do you want to feed your kids at the end of the day? Do you suck up to your boss and be a stickler for the rules, or you do you try to enjoy your work and bring some humanity to it? It's a game that makes you consider your actions like no game before or since. It will make you feel like a genius....and it will make you feel uncomfortable. And then MORE uncomfortable. DO NOT think this is a game about getting a high-score by getting all of the border decisions correct. That is such a small part of it. If you want a game that makes you think, and makes you feel, I highly recommend it.

Alot of details in the gameplay. Not the graphics. Paper's Please shows that the gameplay is more important than the graphics      Overall rating    8.5    I really recommend buying this. This game is interesting, pretty much, you are a border inspector who just inspects passports and all other documents in a cold war era fictional communist country called Arstotzka, while working you come across characters of interest and events that tangle with your job & life as you desperately try to feed and care for your family, pick up this game if you are looking for something original, this definitely has it. One of the weirdest games I own. Enjoyable in short bursts and the levels don't last too long. Interesting narrative with quite a few endings and a fair replay value. Eccentric, but not for everyone. I never though I could sit there for hours staring at passports but here I am. Papers, Please is one of those games that can make something mundane into an immersive experience. Its not just checking passports -you may feel that you must do anything in order to help your family survive, or maybe you may choose to show your undying loyalty to Arstotzka by ignoring the more than tempting bribes. You may have to question ethics, your government, your ingrained knowledge of what is right and what is wrong - all for the sake of your next paycheck.

Thisi s a really great game. On the surface it looks pretty straight forward, but it gets more and more complicated - but not so complicated that it stops being fun. You are basically a border worker who checks documents on people immigrating over. Your job is to make sure they don't have false information, fake documents, bombs, etc... all while saving money to keep your family alive and comfortable. I learn something new with each passing day (each day is a 'level') and if you mess up you can go back to a previous day and start over. For example, I accepted a bribe on day 11 for $1000. A few days later I moved into a nicer apartment. My neighbors reported my 'new wealth' to the athorities and they took my bribe money and are investigating the situation. I haven't found out what is going to happen yet, but if i lose my job i'm going to revert back to the day before I took the bribe money and be sure not to take it again :) Anyway, great game and definitely something to take about with other people who have played.
Colours of this game are 50 Shades of Gray.  10/10 for red stamp.

Do you let in the sick man to see a doctor that can save him, and in doing so have your pitance of a salary docked, or do you turn him away, so that you can afford to pay for heat in the cold december month?

This game is such a unique experience. Never would I think that this game would be as immersive, interesting and well-thought out as it was. A struggle to support your family, government corruption and an organization that you can choose to help, or carry on with your government job. Tough choices, interesting characters and 20 endings helps push this game's value further. It was surprisingly fun to look over people's passports, entry permits, vaccination documents and work passes to find any discrepancies. I was annoyed at a couple things, however. Why do you recieve citations immediately? It can seem really pointless if the invisible super inspector finds that one error you overlooked, making you wonder why you are there in the first place. It would have been better if it had shown you at the end of the day, perhaps with their name on the citation. Without a doubt my favourite character from all of this is Jorji Costava. This genuinly nice, pleasant guy constantly slips up in one way or another, but will return your friendship. He is a delightfully refreshing character, and he is more than just comic relief. Overall, this experience earns an 8/10.

'Cause no trouble.'  A typical month through the viewpoint of a border agent in Artstotzka. At least, that's on the outside. In fact, this is one of the most interesting months that could happen for your border agent. The plot is wonderfully constructed, with multiple branches and backstories to keep things interesting. Most of the people you file passports for are dull and boring, but there are a few who make it all worth it. The gameplay is surprisingly fun, as I played it as more of a puzzle game, trying to find the one missing piece in that person's data.  Overall, I would give this a 4 out of 5, and strongly reccommend you give it a try.

A gruelling but oh-so-valuable look at the life of a customs official in a communist dystopia, Arstotzka. The intricacy of the level progression and the desire to treat people fairly when your family will starve if you don't process enough applicants each day creates a wonderful backdrop for moral decisions you may have never previously considered.  My advice? Play with a friend. Agree each day on who is checking what, and share the glory and the pain of serving Arstotzka. That way, when you cry yourself to sleep afterward at least you won't be alone.

Glory to Arstotzka! That is the words I felt I have been saying over and over through playing this amazing game. Also DENIED, and a few swear words to vent out my anger.   Papers, Please is a weird game. It is ment to be a passport control simulator, but it delivers as at times, a really challenging game. All your control is the mouse. All you do, it drag stuff and click, but to say the least its not a point and click adventure. Your first day it is simple. Only allow people that are from Arstotzka. Then check all the passports. In the end, you will be checking so many documents, you need to stay on the ball or you will slip up. Massively. I wont be telling anything like said documents, since I dont wish to ruin what is around the corner. The game does have a goal. Do your job. Each person you clear or deny gives your a total of 5 credits. You have to clear enough people to be able to afford food and heating for your family. At times, it is hard. Once, I had to give up food for a day to afford the rent. So what stops you from clearing everybody? Punishments. If fail too many times, you lose your money. That money that will save your family from an early coffin. The problem is, the game can get to you. Occasionly, you will get these people who know they cant get through, but before you tell them to go away, they tell this sad story. Great. Do I seperate the wife from the husband and possibley let her die? Or do I risk it? Nah, it will be fine. The next day, she is in the newspaper. She got murdered. YAY... I feel like sh*t.   I am going to end it on this note. I over the 2013 year, I bought a total of about 70 games. Its my hobby to say the least. I would happy trade them ALL in for this game. Hands down game of the year 2013. I would even say GTA V was worse. If you have the money, just buy it. Why are you still reading, you donkey? GET IT!!!!!!!!!!!
Lovely game. Glory to Arstotka.
On paper, being a the border police sounds really bad. But what Papers, Please does is make you emotionally attached to characters and makes you question each little desicion. This game is stunning.

This game is fun and honestly proves wrong the recurring myth that better graphics mean a better game. I found more enjoyment playing a pixelated man in a booth, deciding who could cross the border than playing whatever brown, HD mess EA, Activision or anyone else decided to churn out. This game is inexpensive and worth playing over and over, with the game feeling almost like a communist Oregon Trail.  You check passports and identification to make sure people can or can not enter the country, your goal; make money to keep your family alive. It adds a strange balance because you can choose to be cold, calculating and dismissive for the sake of your family and not allow a wife or husband to get through because of improper papers but at the general cost of your humanity (there is no humanity meter, so don't worry about that), the characters have simple designs and yet very rich personalities that make the choices you make feel all the more real and at times all the more jarring.  This game isn't just the game that proves we don't need good graphics, it proves we need more games like it. The brown and gray sludge of repetitively regurgitated FPS titles can stay on the consoles for all they like, PC gaming has Papers, Please

Papers, Please! This has to be one of the most depressing games I have ever played, set in (sort of) the last days of the eastern bloc, your job is to check incoming travellers paperwork and then either allow or deny them access into the great nation of Arstotzka. This is a great game. Fact. It is a game that gives you a glimpse at the cold, dreary misery that these countries lived in for so many years. If you're looking for something small, cheapish and very engaging, this is the game for you. Glory To Arstotzka

This bureaucratic border security simulator is a lot more fun than it appears to be.

I have a ton of fun playing this game, but not only that, it makes me really question my choices and actions without forcing some sort of weak 'karma' system like in other games.   I absolutely recommend this game.

Surprisingly enjoyable.  First off I enjoy how complex it is. You always have to be on the top of your game, but quick about it. If you make too many mistakes or pass too few people, you won't make enough money to feed your family that week.   I also like how it also allows you to make some moral decisions. Willing to face a penalty to reunite a couple? Stop a criminal? Get an achievement? (Yes to all 3, by the way) It adds a bit more replayability to the game, where I can see what happens if I chose the different option.

Papers, Please is an amazing game given the fact that you are doing similar tasks everyday. The style is simple but it still feels real enough that you feel emotion toward some of the people passing through. There are so many different endings and most of the time you do not realize untill after the ending that one certain event caused your demise. That or you ran out of money, your family died, or a terrorist killed you after you failed to shoot him.  The deeper parts of the game are the moral choices you have to make throughout your time at work. Do you join the order? Do you stay loyal to your country? Do you take money that appears to save your dying family or burn it knowing the sender is unknown? Do you cure your sick wife or give the family heat? Or do you skrew everyone and upgrade your booth instead. One slip up, one missed weight or invalid seal, can be the difference between a suicide bomber getting into the country and you saving yourself and the guards.  This game is very entertaining and quite dark which makes it hard to stop playing because you want to know what comes next. I highly recommend Papers, Please.
Very interesting experience. It's good.

I like Papers, Please just because I like dystopia and the idea continually fascinates me. Also, I like how you can choose to be cold-hearted or be a little generous and each have its own consequences.

I heard about this game some time ago but didn't decide to get it and play it until now.   To my surprise, this game is quite addictive, funny and very challenging. I'm quite sure there's no other game quite like this one, so kudos for originality.

As it says 'dystopian document thriller' -- that's right on the money. Well, it should be: it's in the pic.   Anyways, this game is quite unique, atleast to me. It's simple and runs on the slowest of machines. Well, there really isn't much to this game graphically becaure you're reading documents the whole time. I'm a guy who loves some damn good graphics. This game doesn't have it. But that's OK. Why?   Because this game is awesome.   You work at a security checkpoint, and you have to find discrepancies in peoples' documents (passports, ID cards, entry permit, work permits, grants, diplomatic authorization, etc.) to locate criminals or people trying to fool the system to get throught the checkpoint.   Sounds booring but it's not. This game is pretty damn fun because you're working against the clock. Attention to detail and textual discrepancies is key for success in this game.  You'll find at first people successfully tricking you, but learning their tricks and stopping them in the future is pretty satisfieng. Working against the clock, having show much stuff to look out for, and having a family you have to provide money for adds to the intensity.   Overall a sweet game I'd highly recommend. Definetly a thriller. Not a good game if you're high, by the way.
Who knew spending time checking if passports are valid would be so much fun.

This game should not be good. It should bore your mind out. I mean who cares aboutt those little people and whether or not they get throught to see their son, or escape their life of slavery. But in those few seconds that these pixalated characters speak, they come alive. Their stories compel you and give you the tough choice of illeagally letting them through and facing a penalty that tales its toll on your unseen family, or be the hated, law-abiding man (or woman) who will take the blame for a life in slavery, or one with no son. Either way, the wait from your choice to the moment your penalty comes is sure to leave you on the edge of your seat and make you rage at the penalty.
