Fantastic gameplay, artfully constructed. This is what indie gaming should be. If you had told me you could make a fun game out of being a border inspector I'd have thought you were crazy. But this unexpectedness is what makes it great.
its a fairly simple game, but so addictingly fun. storyline was entertaining and i was invested from beginning to end. still trying to get a few more tokens. i highly recommend getting this game.

This is a fantastically unique game, that essentially is a fast-paced, highly detailed, border control rpg. You play as a border guard person for the arstotzkan borders, and you are paid quite lowly for this high stress job. while the game might start out nice and easy checking a couple of things, it picks up pace fast, where you will soon find that you have3 or 4 documents to check each with it's own fine list of details to check for. Now if you had the time to check everything at your own pace this would be quite an easy game, but you have a family to take care of, and at 6 o'clock the border closes and you finish up who ever you are attending to and go home.   The plot of this game is very dynamic as in, you make choices, and the choices you make will reward you with money and tokens and sometimes just the feeling of knowing you helped someone in need, while at the same time fining you and causing chaos that cuts the day short, making you miss out on some of the prospective cash you could have earned.  Never the less, this game is intense, rewarding, and has a very good feel to it that makes it so enjoyable to play. It is an experience that is very much worth while, and enjoyable.

Don't let the retro simplistic style fool you, this game is both utterly absorbing and a great challenge. In a glorious soviet nation of the 1980's you have the responsibility of border control... Will you: Be nice to the people and stick it to the man? Become an Iron hearted state trooper? A balance just to feed your family back home? In this game it really feels like your decisions matter. And there's 20 different endings to find too!
this is a sexy game for all of you sexy people on steam
Very well put together. Definitely one of the better 5 games this year.

Such a simple idea, how could admitting and declining immigrants and passerbys into a country be of any fun at all? Well when you're faced with terrorists, underground organisations, smugglers, lovers, families, corrput police officers, bribary and many more outlandish situations, a day at work is never, ever dull!   Should you sell a digital watch to someone in line to pay for you son's birthday present, or return it to the man who trusted it in your care? Should you be slack with a regular? Should you let someone through the border because a friend asked you to? All of these questions run through your head with evey new person you meet, and all the while, your family back in your apartment are starving, freezing and suffering from sickness... And every major choice you make, the world around you changes, as the daily newspaper will let you know.. So by admitting one too many smugglers, that drug-selling boom you read about while eating breakfast was entirely your fault. Oops!
best game i have ever bough for 4.99 (obtained during steam winter sale). goes to show you dont have to have a super in depth game for it to be extremely fun.

Be a paper pusher that decides the future of your country all while trying to feed and heat your family. Know that every mistake you make could be the difference between keeping your dying son alive or letting the rebels overthrow your great country. I never though such dread could be instilled in a game about working in a border checkpoint office.
I feel like I'm back in soviet Russia and not in that bad way where I'm forced to eat dried bread and milk every morning.

A game you'll love, that you hate to play. Papers, Please is a deep game where the odds are constantly stacked against you, and you must second guess your every move. And to top things off, you hold your family hostage. Very difficult, great concept.
I love this game, its such a nice break from all the other somewhat 'cookie cutter games' I've played. The art style and overall story are just incredible.

This game is totally hard core.  you work as a russian immigration officer at a border checkpoint. you have a wife and kids to support and pay your bills for your crappy apartment  you get paid piece work for the amount of imigrants you process at the check point. you work a normal 8 hour day. you have to work fast to get as many people done as you can in a day to support your family.  you have to be on the ball and analyse every detail on the documents handed to you by the immigrants. if you miss any vital discrepencies you get penalised and could possibly lose your job.  sometimes you have to make a judgement call on whether to let someone though or stick to the rules in your book.  sometimes you could be letting through a known criminal or terrorist and if you had picked up their name in the weeks paper you might not of had that incident where your work day was cut short by a bombing attack on the security guards and now you cant afford to by medicine for your sick son and he died the next day.  or.. you could have the genes of a cop in you and quickly process the days immigrants and deny those who dont stack up in a flash, earn a good days wage and start to lift your family out of poverty
Very nice game, funny too.

'Papers, Please' deserves its reputation for excellence. I played it first in Beta, and had already clocked up hours of play before the final product arrived on Steam. Most games give the player power - over a gun, or a car, or a team of small and aggressive monsters - but few provide the sort of authority that comes with the 'thunk' of a rubber stamp at the Arstoktzka border checkpoint. How the player uses that authority is at the heart of the game, and poses some difficult questions about freedom of choice, human rights, individual responsibility and collective security. Do you take a bribe to feed your family? Put your neck on the line to reunite someone else's? Detain a minor offender for a healthy kickback? The choices don't seem as clear-cut when you're sitting in that box, and that's the genius of the game: the choices become important. Out of very basic mechanics comes a believable world, and it's absolutely beautiful in all its depressing, overbearing glory.  You may find yourself regretting your actions, or quietly justifying them to yourself. You may frighten yourself with the ease with which you can have a person marched away, saving yourself the paperwork of processing them and earning a little pocket money to boot. By the latter half of the story, turning an applicant away over a slight clerical error saves a hell of a lot of checking, and they might hate you for it but you've got a deadline and mouths to feed. And besides, it can't be as bad as the terrifying 'rat-tat-tat' of a printed warning, and maybe a hefty fine. Personally, I was shocked to discover that I was developing nationalistic prejudices towards fictional people. (It's always the bloody Kolechians, isn't it?)  It's tough, it's complex, and while it may not be perfect, 'Papers, Please' deserves all the praise it recieves, and I can't reccomend it too highly.
It's actually hard to tell what this game is all about... but I think this is one of the greatest indie games ever made

Passport Checker: The Game.... Doesn't sound too exciting, but this game is actually pretty awesome. You have to be so keen about every deatail of every person that passes through; it's quite difficult but addicting. It's all about the details, right down to the heavy breathing of the boarder crosser when you are taking too long checking their papers. It seems like a pretty cheap, barebones looking game for the price, but yes, it's worth it for anyone who likes putting their mind to the test.
Immediately engaging, deceptively intense. One of the more unique games I've played in a long time.

You wouldn't suspect that a game about checking people's papers and passports would be fun but you will be surprised. As you progress you have to check different document types, look out for forgeries, and all the while feed and take care of your family. You get presented with some story choices as well - do I help this poor couple sneak through the border and risk getting fined and not being able to heat my crap apartment? Or do I have them arrested?   Definitely worth the purchase and playthrough and if you catch it on sale do not hesitate.
Very simple but yet very addictive! :)
this game should be played by many excelentgame

This is one of those oddball games I pick up on sales on a lark. Overall it's a very fun game, providing a good challenge with some very unique gameplay. You have to dedicate a lot of focus to be good at the game and you will often make mistakes. Multiple endings are nice, but to be honest I found many of them hard to figure out.  +Weird and different +Good challenge +Replayable - Requires a lot of focus - You end up making a lot of mistakes

This game is as close as it gets to an art game without the pretentious title and typically subpar mechanic to go with it. Your job is simple: to allow or deny access to people according to the requirements set by your superiors while trying to support your family with your meager salary. The mechanics are simple and effective, however, what makes the game truly unique is the variety of characters that pass through your checkpoint, many of which have their own stories to tell. There is a very playable beta on Lucas Pope's website if you still feel the need to verify its quality.  Glory to Arstotzka.

I would say it's one of the most interesting games I played due to how the game is structured on denying or approving citizens into the country they want to come into. Also it shows through it's gameplay (in my opinion) what story/consequences you face or happens through the country based on who you let in or deny without it ever telling you if it's good or wrong. I'd say if you want to play something out of the ordinary try this game out.

This game sounds terrible on paper (no pun intended); you are an inspector for a border of a communist country that is now just reopening its borders for the first time in years and it's your job to make sure that EVERY SINGLE bit of information lines up with EVERY SINGLE document of EVERY SINGLE person. Sounds like the kind of job your cousin complains about at family reunions.  But then you actually start getting enveloped in your duty as a citizen of Arstotzka.  Do you let the woman without the proper papers go through after her husband who went just before her? Do you turn away the ambassador because of his country of origin? Do you take the bribes or report your findings to the M.O.A.? Do you trust the masked figures? Will there be another terrorist attack today? If the day is cut short, can you make rent? Are you willing to kill an innocent for what you believe is right?   All of these questions an more race through your strained mind as the clock ticks the day away as you pour over document after document for discrepancies, all the while knowing that while processing more people gets your family much-needed money, failure to detect even the SLIGHTEST fault will result in penalty...and that penalty could mean the difference between saving the life of a loved one down to buying a present for your son's birthday.  There are 20 different endings in all, each varying from living happily with your family, to getting executed on suspension of aiding extremists. There are also secret achievements for performing certain tasks that may or may not contradict what your handy-dandy rulebook might say. All I can say is:  Glory to Arstotzka.

For a game revolving around paperwork, Papers Please proves itself to be remarkably engaging and oddly satisfying.  You are an impoverished civilian who has had the fortune of being selected to work in border control in the aftermath of War. Every day brings a new list of requirments and rules and failing to adhere to those rules may result in having wages docked - something you cannot afford given you have a family who depends upon you for survival.  Having said that, challenges arrive in the form of moral choices - will you have your wages docked so a woman can flee her ♥♥♥♥♥♥? Will you risk punishment in order to help a friend in need reunite with the love of his life? Or will you side with the rebellion, eager to bring down the corrupt goverment that runs your country?  Every day also bears the threat of having the border attacked by suicide bombers and terrorists, at which point you must take up arms and defend yourself and your collegues.  The game plays smoothly and offers a genuine challenge as the levels progress. Some of the NPCs are particularly memorable and the game will offer several moments of humour, horror and sentimentality.  I didn't expect to enjoy this game nearly as much when it was reccomended to me, and is a game I heartily reccomend in turn.
I love this game so much.

You need to play this game. Period.  It's not long nor expensive. It's a different experience from any other game, it'll make you question yourself and with time you'll get so fast at doing repetitive work under stress that you'll be impressed.
Ive never cared about a digital person so much. This game is a border checkpoint to hell. Worth a try forsure.
Looking at papers has never been more fun  9/10 - Worth Buying
A great gaming experience. It has an amazing story and is nailbitingly stressful when it needs to be!
This game is outrageously fun. Even if you lose, it's a bit like you're winning. I highly recommend this everyone

An excellent game set in a distopian society. It manages to be humerous, challenging and engaging through out with a story line that has numerous choices that will effect when and how your story ends. Great game.

You'd be surprised how addictive it can be to stamp passports all day.  The game does put you in moral dilemma situations where you either save a person from being killed or prevent your family from starving, but you can't do both.

This came is great! You may think working at the East Gretin border checkpoint is boring and has no plot but you are dead wrong. I am not saying every choice makes a difference but they their are many crucial choices you must make. Even without a plot this game is wicked fun and addicting. I never thought a border checkpoint 'sim' could be so fun!

Papers Please, A Fun REALLY REALLY hard game with many different outcomes. The games story is interesting and if you 'die' you have to restart becasue you have to find your mistake; Its an RPG with a twist in essence. Papers please allows you to judge your humanity with different dilemas each page. You have three different story archs to follow, The serious by the rulebook Immigration officer, The nice understanding Immigration officer or the Greedy/Do anything for your family Immigration Officer. You can mix these up to have a very interesting story. their are twenty endings and i've only experienced 5.    You really have to be in the mood to play Papers please, you can't just go 'Oh I want to play a random game' and pick this game. Its worth ten dollars but It ca nget boring once you lose the Mojo for it, But it is a great experience and definetly worth anything under twent dollars.
What a great title with an incredible, genuine atmosphere. Anyone wishing to play a slightly grimmer game with an original playstyle, this is for you!
A deceptively complex, utterly absorbing game about paperwork. I recommend everyone who values well-crafted, innovative indie games buy this now. Glory to Arstotzka!

Who in the world likes paperwork?! In this game its all you do...and it's absolutely addicting. Papers, Please is a well executed and abhorrently fun game that will just drain hours upon hours of your time. The pace of how the game developed and added work loads was well done. Too adding in permits to body scans uncovering who you thought looked like a female was a man or vice versa keeps things interesting. Heck theres even a sniper rifle! With that said this game just isn't for everyone, it's definitely going to be a hit or miss for most.
this game is good

One of the most compelling and creative games I've played in at least a decade. I should not be up writing this review at 1:30AM on a work night but I played it for so long I am! Do yourself a favor and spend 10 bucks, you won't regret it!

This game is weirdly addictive. It is easy to understand and it leads you in nicely, but it gets quite hard rather quickly and it kinda forces you to make difficult ethical decisions that have serious consequences. Lots of endings, I have only discovered a few so far.
It has taken over my life. Just buy it, play it, love it, squander your existence!

A brilliant little game. A moment in game history and, like Gun Point, an outstanding Indy game. Short and sweet, with a solid foundational game mechanic and a great style. It was much more fun that I expected. Actually, I put off playing this game for some time after it was receiving a lot of positive press. I was not quite sold on it being 'fun' game, and it sounded on paper maybe a bit too cerebreal or possibly even boring. It is neither. Don't put it off. Play this game.

Along the way, you can make deals with people who are passing through the border, get bribes for more money, help organizations, detain (jail) people, shoot tresspasers (bonus money if you hit them), and more. I would highly recommend this game for their are over 40 endings and if you lose once it doesn't make you start all over. I've only played this a little so far (4-5 'days' in the game), but it is really addictive. Each day adds complexity to your job as immigration officer at the border of some ficticious cold-war era country. The feeling is sad, totalitarian, hopeless. You're lucky to have this job, and your family has been put up in one of the ritzier concrete apartment blocks, where I'm sure there's only three rats instead of the normal ten. As the days progress and the government allows more entry with more fluidly changing requirements, you have to ensure that the documentation people present adds up. Names need to match, documents must be issued from the right place, do they have the right ticket, is it stamped and dated properly, etc. It's a seriously messed up brain game for adults! Oh you'll laugh your backsides off at some of the comments the people make, like trying to bribe you with tickets to the strip club. For the price of a cup or two of coffee, this is totally worth a few hours of your time if not many more.
best game i have ever bough for 4.99 (obtained during steam winter sale). goes to show you dont have to have a super in depth game for it to be extremely fun.

This game is totally hard core.  you work as a russian immigration officer at a border checkpoint. you have a wife and kids to support and pay your bills for your crappy apartment  you get paid piece work for the amount of imigrants you process at the check point. you work a normal 8 hour day. you have to work fast to get as many people done as you can in a day to support your family.  you have to be on the ball and analyse every detail on the documents handed to you by the immigrants. if you miss any vital discrepencies you get penalised and could possibly lose your job.  sometimes you have to make a judgement call on whether to let someone though or stick to the rules in your book.  sometimes you could be letting through a known criminal or terrorist and if you had picked up their name in the weeks paper you might not of had that incident where your work day was cut short by a bombing attack on the security guards and now you cant afford to by medicine for your sick son and he died the next day.  or.. you could have the genes of a cop in you and quickly process the days immigrants and deny those who dont stack up in a flash, earn a good days wage and start to lift your family out of poverty

Papers, Please. An inetersting concept. You play the role of a man working an immigrant checkpoint. It's your duty to allow people who have all correct documentations through said checkpoint. It's alos your duty to deny those with contradictions in said documents. Or those missing documents. Or those with contraband and weapons. It's also your duty to stare at pictures of naked people who look like men, who turn out to be women to check their passport's aunthenticity. It's hard running a check point station.

Strangely, this is the most serious game I've played. No, you are not some big-time war hero. No, you do not mow down millitary and civilians alike. No, you do not do any sort of millitary feat whatsoever. I guess you could say it's DEAD SERIOUS as you have to get as many people who have the right documents through to get max pay so you can provide food and heating for your family who can die. The joke I made earlier was really clever foreshadowing. So, why would your family need heating? Well... you aren't in america, you're in fact in Soviet Russia! (Otherwise known as Arstotzka) You're in the west side of the USSR, and it's november in the WW2 era. So what should you do? BUY THE GAME

Before I bought 'Papers, Please', a friend of mine told me that he'd heard it described as 'the most Soviet game I've ever seen'. It's a fitting description - as you attempt to eke out a living handling passports in the Grestin border checkpoint, it is clear that you are a small cog in a deeply dysfunctional machine. The game grows ever more challenging as you are presented with a proliferation of new rules and regulations, and still more so as you face the challenge of dealing with crooks, smugglers, revolutionaries, and desperate folk of all descriptions, of deciding who to allow through, who to reject, and who to arrest, all with the knowledge that your livelihood and that of your dependents relies on your ability to spot the tiniest of discrepancies in the ten or twenty seconds you can afford to spend examining this particular downtrodden would-be immigrant's documents.  'Papers, Please' breathes a tremendous amount of story and life into the world through the simple mechanism of passports and entry passes. On one day, a woman arrives joyous about the opening of the border, hoping to see her son for the first time in six years. On another, a man tells you about his days working as an immigration officer in another country, remembering how they rejected the majority of those trying to enter there. Still later, a woman from the town you grew up in arrives at your window, remarks as you study her papers what a brat you were growing up, and promises, as she leaves, that she will tell your old neighbors that you are alive and well. And these are characters you never meet again - those like Jorji, Calensk, and Sergiu are a great deal more than that, even as limited as your decisions are.  'Papers, Please' is hard, but more than worth your time.

Every dysopian lovers dream, the chance to effect the world through being an immigration officer to a powerful country that took annexed another country. Additionally, you are a poor fellow, the government has shined on you... Glory to Arstotzka!

It gives you the (surprisingly) fun task of denying or accepting entry to the fictional Communist country of Arstotzka. Some of the people you review for entry talk and the stroy quietly unfolds. I call this type of story a quiet story and Portal is the same way, you are given a task and very subtley you realize what's going on. 'Glory to Artotska!' When I bought Papers, Please, I expected a quiet, little border simulation. I never expected to be torn into pieces between what to do. While I just recently bought this game, (20.6.2014), I feel like I've already experienced so much, so quickly. Do you let the people in who try to weasel their way in, or the people who need their way in? If you chose the latter, you end up working against your government which negatively affects your family.  This is a game about life decisions. And its beautiful.  About the game: - Pixely art style - Cheap - Endless mode - Story based  9.5/10

Papers, Please is a bleak game, set in the harsh world of a Soviet-esque satellite republic. You and your family suffer for your every mistake, and even your efficiency is poorly rewarded.   It's a difficult game, built on recognizing documents and analyzing them as valid, in addition to spotting discrepancies. As your money dwindles, you begin to find moral quandaries: Do you take a bribe to let someone with invalid documents inside your country, or do you keep your meager earnings and reject them? Do you help the desperate at your own peril, or do you only worry about yourself?  With each day, the demands placed on you grow, and with every person you don't process properly, you find yourself unpaid at best, and possibly penalized financially at worst. Why would you play such a game set in such an unforgiving world? Because it's brilliant. It's compelling. Every mistake you make, you KNOW it was your fault. Every unsatisfactory ending makes you want to try harder for the next time, so you can find something, ANYTHING to make this story have a happy ending, even if it seems impossible.  This game is pure brilliance, distilled into a low res form. Unless you simply must have cutting edge graphics, or can't stand a difficult game, you owe it to yourself to buy a copy.  9/10

With its simplistic pixel art and its straightforward objective, Papers, Please manages to engage players in a way that only it can provide. As the immigration inspector of the great nation Arstotzka, you hold the power to approve or deny people passing through your country's checkpoint. While that may sound simple enough, the job gets more and more complicated as the days pass by, with you having to deal with forged documents, suspected criminals, desperate fugitives, a secret society, and Jorji Costava.   It becomes heavier by the day, and you can feel the risk grow higher when your family is in need of food, shelter and healthcare. Do you compromise a job to save some pour soul, or do you deny them to continue providing for your family? Exactly. There's no other game quite like Papers, Please, and it is well worth your time and investment.

This game is not fun. It is a grueling, despair-inducing process. Day after day doing the same thing, interspersed with prayer that everything turns out alright. That being said, it is amazing. You just have to play it.

Unique, funny and challenging, Papers Please is unlike any other game you've ever played. Set in a fictional totalitarian country, you act as a border checkpoint guard struggling to keep your family warm, fed, and healthy. Paid by the number of people you screen daily, you will encounter forgers, smugglers, and, even more morally challenging, people trying to visit sick relatives with improper paperwork. Do you call to your humanity, let them through, and risk your family's welfare and imprisonment? Or do you stamp denied on their passport to their curses and possible future retributions?  To say more of this very clever game would spoil it but it is a steal at the price for modern gaming ingenuity at its finest.

Get this game on sale while you can! It is a fantastic indie game that shows the potential of video gaming. Games with moral choices are often too simple and binary with predictable results. This game removes the boring of the binary and sometimes throws the player for a loop with the complexity of reality. It is impossible to play just once and is well worth the price.

This is exactly my type of game. This game deals with global relations, from the eyes of the 'common man,' who has been given a slight amount of power. With the power to deny or grant entry into Arstotzka, you make choices to either better the state, or yourself, or perhaps even the immigrants, with all decisions ending in consequence. Arstotzka, a socialist state, has both elements of new technologies, mixed with the glory and look of the 'old world,' and I love it. This is a fun game, with all types of challenges, and I would definitely buy it.

when i first saw this game i couldn't believe i will love it like i do now that im playing it :) dont let the screenshots/video fool you, the game is awesome!

A true oddball game. Nobody would ever think that making a game about something a dull as checking passports could ever be made into a truly great game like this one manages to be. The story line has many branching points were you are given the choice to support the current weakened communist government or aid the well-meaning but somewhat foolish rebels, all the while deciding what to do with hordes of people seeking a better life in your “glorious” country.   How it handles the actual meat of the game is very well done, starting you off checking passports and adding to that slowly until you are armed with a sniper rifle, forcing people to do strip searches to make sure they aren’t bringing weapons or drugs, checking fingerprints and criminal records, all the while making sure that their passports, work permits, diplomatic papers, immigration pass, vaccination certificates and identity cards are all correct and not forged in any way.  This game will test your eye for detail and refine it down to a laser point. If you ever wanted to play a game that makes you feel as smart as Sherlock Homes without actually playing a Sherlock Homes point and click adventure game this is it.
Immaculate and Gripping, every person is a threat and you are the only thing between life and death for the people of Arstozka.

Surprisingly addictive with simple graphics and storyline, loving the various endings and how your decision making can alter them. The game focuses on the emotional toll of working as an immigration officer, and that's what makes Papers, Please such a unique game.  Glory to Arstotzka!

She was ahead in line, and told me to do something about him. Even though he had legitimate documentation, out of the goodness of my heart, I refused him entry. After being penalized for mistakes earlier, my 'unfair denial' led to me being fined for it, and my family suffered without a necessity because of it. That 'goodness of my heart' led to my game being ended early, because I couldn't upkeep the rent, as of which led to me being detained.  10/10

A brilliant little game. A moment in game history and, like Gun Point, an outstanding Indy game. Short and sweet, with a solid foundational game mechanic and a great style. I was not quite sold on it being 'fun' game, and it sounded on paper maybe a bit too cerebreal or possibly even boring. It is neither. Don't put it off. Play this game.

Somehow, a game about something as tedious as checking papers at a border checkpoint, and one with rather clumsy and clunky controls to boot, manages to be gripping and tension inducing, compelling one to replay and restart from previous saves simply in order to see all the endings. A fantastic work of minimalist storytelling and the presentation of moral quandaries.

What bugs me about this game is one thing: it now will make me hate all games that claim to be about choice from now on, as they don't do it anywhere near as superb as Papers, Please. This is one of my favorite games of 2013, and one of my favorite games of all time. This is one that you really NEED to play. Glory to Arstotzka!

What a glorious game. Proof positive that megabytes aren't the defining feature of an excellent game. It sort of reminds me of playing the 90s Carmen Sandiego games, except a heck of a lot more mature and moody. I know it's not the same gameplay at all, but the way it works my brain is quite similar. Either paperwork is more fun than I realized or this game has a whole lot to say about our character. Either way, it's just good.

This game is deceptively fun...It starts out slow (with good reason) and like in real life your choices early on can REALLY screw you over...even if your doing the right thing. A dark color pallette works well for this game, and the straight forward concept makes it easy to jump into, but at the same time the game does a great job breaking the monotany of passport stamping by throwing curveballs at you (no spoilers). And of course, just when you think you've got a handle on checking d.o.b, gender, home country, work visas, etc, etc, you have to start cross checking more documents.  One particular mechanic that I'm thrilled by is how the timeline is handled. You can jump back to any previous day and branch a new story-line to see different consequences instead of having to start all over again. I don't know how many times you can do this, but even just once is nice, as opposed to starting back from day 1 to see how different day 29 could have been.  I hope to see more from this developer in the future.
Dear Papers, Please  What I expected You twisted into greatness And left me speechless  Glory to Arstotzka.

This was a real surprise. Sifting through the documents of an ever-changing eastern european beareaucracy sounds like a bore, but it's actually quite engaging. A much deeper game than it seems on the surface. You won't regret giving this one a try. *WARNING:* Not for those with a short attention span.
What an amazing surprise, Probably my indie game of the year. Wholeheartedly recommended. CANT WAIT FOR DLC

I really liked this game. I give this game a 9 out of 10. I give Papers, Please this rating because it was very good but they shouldn't have the easy option. It should be a game where there is no difficulty, you just play.
Nice way to play on the concept of choice. Fun, challenging and unique. I highly recommend it, even though it is a bit short.

got me addicted

The retro graphics style is nicely done, and i's a surprise someone didn't actually do this in the age of 8bit. It also demonstrates once again that good gameplay outrates HD graphics.
All the fun of your local bureaucracy in your own home! it's just like being on the other side of the counter at the DMV!

Indie GOTY, in my opinion. One of the best games I have ever played. Simply chilling.

This game gets to be fairly intense once you get a couple weeks into the storyline. One of my favorite things about it is that it requires both precision and speed, but no real dexterity; the precision required is entirely mental. (Though a quick mouse hand certainly helps a lot—there's an awful lot of clicking and dragging in Papers Please.) Good spatial reasoning is also helpful; a lot of people complain about there not being enough room on the screen for all the documents, but at no point did I fail to find a configuration which allowed me to compare all required documents simultaneously, with the rules a single click away. (And my keys in plain sight & easy reach!)  I made it about 2/3 of the way through the game without a citation before discovering (by looking at a wiki, for another detail) that you're allowed 2 'free' citations every day, and that (aside from impacting your income) they have no effect on which endings you can get or which achievements you can earn—there's no achievement for getting through the game without any citations!  On the morality side, though the tendency is to perceive Arstotzka as a totalitarian dictatorship, or at least to have a corrupt government, I noticed no such facts explicitly in evidence within the game. Certainly they are harsh, and through the tiny window we are given we can see little more than impenetrable bureaucracy which often institutes ineffective or unfair policies (usually with the best intentions clearly in mind), but I don't know whether they are democratic or what the country's economic status is beyond my own family. On the other hand, most of the government seems to function with startling efficiency; when news breaks one evening & new documents need to be issued, they are designed, printed, filled out, stamped, and in the hands of at least dozens (probably hundreds, from the looks of that line!) of people  in other countries  before 6AM the next morning; this applies to documents issued by both Arstotzka and all its other neighbors. Rule books are updated. Permits are issued. At one point, in the time between the morning paper hitting newsstands and me reaching my desk at 6AM, some sort of computerized stamping machine was developed and deployed which keyed into the voice transcription system and created custom stamps for every denied visa—a task which would take months-to-years in the modern age, and this is in 1982; the technical prowess of the Astotzkan is not to be denied. Arstotzka has advanced medicine, develops ground-breaking surgeries, offers affordable healthcare, and appears to have one of the best job markets in the region.  Before you decide to join the side of the terrorists, consider carefully the (in-game) reality of Arstotzka.

How in the hell does something that would seem infinitely boring in real life be so god damn addictive in a video game? It's like a bad drug addiction. You may feel ♥♥♥♥ afterwards but you want more all the time. Highly Recommended.

I played the beta of this, It's a really interesting game, 20 different endings, some slightly different, some completely different. It makes a repetitive task interesting, i never really got bored, the story is scripted to a point... there are different people with different documents, but some characters of the story are the same. Of course, in endless mode its all random. Very good time waster, and totally worth the ten bucks. The Soviet Era time period is interesting, the sound and graphics complement it well.
Discover how corruptible you are!
Beyond addictive. Fantastic little distraction.   For Arstotzka!!
Weirdly addictive game about being, basically, a customs agent.
This game is really difficult once you pass the first few levels but it gets really fun when you have multiple pieces of information to track. I highly recommend this game!

Words can not express. Papers, Please is a silently harrowing tale. This game represents everything that is oh so wonderful about indie gaming. A game that defies all convention and staggers the player to the very core. Very few big-budget games could ever hope to achieve the kind of nail-biting, psychological thrill that Papers, Please provides. It's terrifying, engaging, and chills on a level that has never been seen before. This game deserves our support; and if you value games as an art form, you'll give it nothing less.

This is a shockingly good game. Shocking because in something so simple, you get great pathos and good comedy, and great mechanics. More than that, you get an uncanny sense of immersion into this poor guy's life, and a glimpse into all these other lives. Weirdly lifelike lives. Unsettlingly meaningful, meaningless little lives. Bits of this game will likely haunt your dreams for a while.  And then you find out that just one guy made this. I recently played Ryse Son of Rome, which was gloriously beautiful and all, but it was as shallow as a puddle in the Sahara compared to this, and that was a couple of hundred people working for years.  There's some real talent at play here. You'll kick yourself eventually, if you don't at least taste test this game.
A very interesting yet addictive game! Different from most other games, yet isn't hard to learn and play. Glad to have bought it! :D
I come back with better passport.

I had heard good things about this game and while on the surface it didn't really look like it would hold my interest for long, I couldn't have been more wrong. After setting aside a half hour to play, I found myself enthralled in the fate of the immigration inspector of Arstotzka and before I knew it, the better part of almost 2 hours had gone by. The game is insightfull, thought provoking and highly intuitive. Everything from the soundtrack, through to the hard hitting decisions you have to make, keeps me wanting to go back. If you're a gamer of any form, do yourself a favour and check this gem out. Well worth it.
This game is surprisingly amazing, you think (at first) that after one playthrough you may get bored, but I've played it many times and still want more! :3

The decision to let a mother see her son, although she hasn't got the correct paperwork OVER the decision to make that money to feed your family, has never been such a difficult one.  Simple art design, simple gameplay and it's one of the best games of 2013, hands down.

Glory to Arstotzka! Papers, Please is a quirky but intense game. You are an immigrations agent at a totalitarian country's border checkpoint: juggling irate immigrants and citizens, dealing with forged documents, providing for the family, and even handling terrorist attacks. The fate of your family and many others are in your hands. While the gameplay is monotonous, Papers Please has grown on me. I would recommend it for those interested in the plot.  By the way, this game has won countless Game of the Year distinctions from multiple publications.
Easily worth the price of admission. If you find it on sale, it is worth a few hours of your time, though there are multiple endings, I find it difficult to motivate myself to play it too many times.

You will always feel terrified just before the person crosses a detection machine because if you make a mistake, there will be a beep and you will be given a warning, if you keep making mistakes you're gonna have a pay cut.  + Gameplay + Concept + Fun  Score: 10/10

'Papers, Please' is a game that I did not expect. There are those indy games that you play for a few days and then never really look at again, but 'Papers, Please' grabs your attention with a slow build of very intense character interactions that are all based on whether or not you have all the correct papers to gain entrance at a immigration check point. It delves into corrupt politics, threatening scare tactics, and dealing with bomb smuggling terrorists, and people offering you bribes for entry into your gate. Its more intense and connecting that I thought and all the hidden espionage is definietly something that keeps your playing just to figure out how you got yourself into this situation where you are left with bombs, tranq gunning people down, and hoping not to ♥♥♥♥ of your over-seers.

In this game you are inspector. Detain all threats to Arstotzka. Deny all Kolechian Scum. There seems to be an anomaly in your earnings. You are under arrest. Glory to Arstotzka.   10/10 Would serve Arstotzka again.

Papers, Please is a strangely addicting game that starts out fairly simple at first. You man a checkpoint at the border and have to check immigration documents for validity and decide on if they meet entry requirements or not. You get citations for making mistakes, and there is a lot of unrest happening at the border outside of your station. You have to move fast, because you are on a per-visa pay basis and have to feed your family and pay rent.  Worth it.
I have no idea why I bought such a crappy looking game. BUT IT IS ADDICTIVE Simple stuff but so easy to miss the small details. A good buy if you find it on sale

You're playing a bureaucratic game, right? Well, not quite. What really makes this experience fun is the game-within-the-game that develops. No spoilers, but the plot plays out in such a way that you're forced you to make very serious decisions. Never has the mundane felt so engaging.

What should you do when you're sitting in an office and have nothing to do? Play a border guard simulator where you are in an office with nothing but stamping passports to do!  10/10 Glory to Arstotzka
It amazes me how interesting can be boring life of some communist official! 10/10 would not let pass Kolechians

Brilliant game, possibly one of the best indie games I have ever played, up there with KSP, Monaco, Hotline Miami and all the other stellar games people rave about. Would be willing to pay $20 for the amount of fun I had with this game.

I spend all day at work IRL doing soul-crushing, oppressive, bureaucratic tasks and I hate it. Then I come home, ready to unwind, and play Papers, Please and do soul-crushing, oppressive bureaucratic tasks.,, and I love it.
Very good. A brilliant game with a great storyline. Cannot flaw it in any way, it is genuinely a masterpiece!
One of my favorite games, and actually explaining why I love it so much would require me to spend more time writing this than I have or care to use.

I feel If I was running a security checkpoint in real life I would use this game to train all my employees!  Papers Please pulls you in with its interesting concept, great music/atmosphere. You'll probably get frustrated with the first few levels at with everything they throw at you. But practice makes perfect. It just takes a little time to train yourself to become faster and more accurate at the game. The story does develop as you go but there is also an endless mode incase you do beat the main game.   Glory to Arstotzka!

A gem among indie games, Papers Please is definitely worth the deal. It has such a great depth, the gameplay and the story itself constantly make you question yourself. As you play, you are constantly forced to make moral decisions. There are no right or wrong choices — only valid or invalid passports and documents. There are multiple consequences and endings to this game, so the replayability makes it even more worth the purchase.  All in all, it's a wonderful demonstration of the indie game genre moving to another level, beyond what conventional games would do. Definitely get this if you seek something new, or just curious about how it feels like to work at a border checkpoint.
All Hail to Arstotzka - -/
It was a very intresting game to play. not only was the gameplay game the music is very awasome!

Omg. Amazing 112/10 score  First off i would like to say, any one reading this who missed the whole 'point and click' tag up above please go away. This is not the game for you.   Day one, you won the lottery! Not the money kind of lottery, you won a job! You get to run the new crossing point into your country! They country has been closed for 6 years from others.(How come we dont have that? Lottery for awesome jobs?)  Anyways. So right away, you feel some really good country pride. Either saying to people 'HEY! WELCOME TO THE COUNTRY MAN! SO HAPPY FOR YOU TO SEE YOUR FAMILY AGAIN AFTER 6 YEARS' or you're yelling at people 'GET THE HELL AWAY FROM MY COUNTRY'   Right when you feel like you're doing a great job, someone got by you and there is a terrorist attack with guns and bombs and you can't help but to feel like it's your fault. I mean, you let them in didnt you? Then there are more terrorist attacks. Then people start trying to get you to join a revolution, and you think hey! Thats something to do if i get bored. You start feeling split between your country and the other people.  Then people start giving you stripper cards. Then Drug money.  Serial Killers. People looking for lost loved ones. Then bribing you to let them through.  And you dont know what to do any more. You have to pick your own side. What should you do?   20 different endings to the game are possible, without having to restart it.  This game had me mad, happy, teary eyed and confused. Everyone should buy this game.
A game like no other. I felt the genuine stress of being a border agent in a totalitarian country. I would recommand this game to anyone. You owe yourslef at least a try!

Papers, Please is a very unique game. The art style is very retro, and the game adapts to the decisions you make while doing your job. I'm still working to figure it out and find myself making silly mistakes, but it is all in a day's work. If you like games without much action, but an ever-changing storyline, you might want to check this out. It helps that it was honored recently, aye?
Glory to Arstotzka. This is a reason to indie game.

It's a very interesting game that seems to hit every area that it needs to perfectly. There is a good balance between the background story of a fictional eastern european country and the kind of personal story going on with the character. I like the fact that, while the personal story is told in an organic and unique way.
this game is almost as perfect as portal

Simply put, this game is challenging, interesting and addictive.

It's a bureaucrat simulator. You work at the border of some dirty pinko nation, you can do your work right and let only the people who brought the proper paperwork in (and have people try to bribe or get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at you for actually doing your job), or you can be more flexible with the regulations and reunite lost lovers etc.  Gameplay is repetitive, environment is bleak, people are asses to you, it's the closest we'll probably ever get to a game that puts you in the shoes of someone who works at the DMV. The way it makes you kinda makes you feel like a robot just punching passports in is actually pretty cool.
This game was surprisingly, really good! There are several endings so you never know what is going to happen and it's got a very gripping, empathetic storyline. Worth a few quid
One of the most engaging games I've played in while.
I like this game but its a small game and its sorta pointless but it can be fun! 4-5!
Great Game, if you put the hours in you will uncover an amazing story. 7.5/10

its way more fun than it sounds.  and i'm sure i've played more than 1.9 hours. The day i got it i played from 8pm till midnight.  if you like games that make you think, try this one. its different and endearing.
I had no idea I would like this game as much as I do.
So checking paperwork at a border check point doesn't sound like fun, but it is. This game is one of the most unique and fun games I've played in a long time. Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is not a game that can be put into any pre-existing catagory, but that is by no means a bad thing. The reason it is so good is because it has never been done before, unlike a lot of the games out there that just reboot the same idea again and again. I don't need to tell you why it's good because everyone else has already told you that it's awesome.

The great thing about Papers, Please is that it manages so much with a core of very simple mechanics. It's complex story and multitude of endings blend perfectly and completely into the endlessly fun gameplay. Speaking of gameplay, it is choice. The mechanics are esay to learn and simple to comprehend but as more and more curveballs are thrown your way the process becomes hectic percise fun. Trying to balance percision with time management was always the greatest challenge for me, and I often found myslef actually speaking the actions I was executing just to keep it all straight in my head. The combination of percise fun gameplay and an immersive story and atmosphere make this a must play and a near perfect game.
Great great game! It looks simple and mundane, but it's not. Destiny of your country and other people is upon your decision. So do it well, or you will be sorry.

This game... is brilliant in its simplistic elegance and innovation. The boldness of its developers decision to grapple with some very real issues and their moral dilemmas. The concept, story & atmosphere convey so much in such a simple platform I was stunned by the depth that the game already achieves by day 3. The intensity and oppression of the game's premise really starts to get to you if you take the time to think about what you're doing. Are these people spinning lies with a honeyed tongue or are you the judge of their fate? Will it cost them their freedom? Their lives? Having heard stories in real life from mentors who lived through the core years of the Cold War behind the Iron Curtain, it is distrubing how the game brings them to life.  Papers, Please is a gem, that is a perverse, masochistic kind of fun in the most dystopian way. A stunning 10/10.
A simple looking game but don't let that fool you. Papers, Please is SO worth it. Such fun to be had.
GLORY TO A ARSTOTZKA. THAT IS ALL.

Like customs, only better.  This game seems like the sort of joke indie game such as 'Goat Simulator' that we've come to expect from small developers looking to make a quick buck. However, this game follows no such mould. The most impressive part of this game is the impact that your choices make. For example, at one stage during the game you are given the choice to get your son a crayon set for his birthday but as I did not have sufficent funds the entire family had to go without food or heat for a day.   Another key feature is the amount of detail in a each person that comes through your little booth. The amount of time you have to spend closley studing the documents in front of you increases everyday and shows how taxing it really can be to be a border control officer.   For what this game may lack in graphics or community it certainly makes up for in story and moral choices. One of the best indie games of all time. 18.5/20

I'm so glad I live in a time when papers, please can exist. It is a game at the forefront of proving that video games are a unique narrative medium, an art that, when crafted by skilled hands like this games developer, can be intensly deep, thought provoking and memorable. The narrative is crafted so expertly into the simple, yet challenging gameplay, that if someone ever asks how a game should tell a story while still letting the player have input, papers please is the perfect example.  You will not play any other game like papers please. If your a gamer who likes to find as many unique experiences in a game as you can, you can't miss this one.

YOU PLAY A BORDER COSTUMS AGENT AND YOU HAVE TO HANDLE WITH STRANGE SANARIOS SUCH AS: YOU DEAL WITH A SENILE OLD MAN AND A MAN WITH A BOMB STRAPED TO HIS STOMACH AND EVEN A PIMP SNEEKING HIS GIRLS INTO A DIFERENT COUNTRY AND THERE IS A MAN RUNNING FROM THE POLICE TO HIDE FROM A MURDER. THAT IS HOW GOOD THE GAE IS AND ITS GREAT

Sometimes it's not about what a game IS, it's about what a game DOES. This game IS a paperwork sim. But what it DOES is tell a story of political intregue through the eyes of a border crossing guard. That seems like an odd choice, at first, but as a border crossing guard, one sees a large range of different people from different backgrounds trying to get in. Very very very well made, and surprisingly immersive.
It just like living in Soviet Union, only fewer bread line.

Papers Please is an excellent example of an amazing Indie game that could be considered Best game of 2013 with contenders like Bioshock Infinite, Last of Us, GTA 5. and in my opinion i believe papers please is better than all those shooters.  Papers Please in the end is an amazing experience for everyone, either making you look like a good guy to all civilions or or and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to everyone you come across. You see people come and go and make some new friends, and new enemies. Papers Please is an excellent PC which could be considered Game of the Year for people who play it. I would rate it 10/10 2nd best game of 2013 in my opinion.
Lots of Memorization required. Very addicting and fun to play in your spare time!

Papers Please is a nice fun casual game. The 1st, 2nd or even 3rd time you play it you will get reports that you allowed someone with the wrong documents but you will get use to it all. A great game about the choices one makes when one's own job, family, and/or safety are on the line, and how one might inadvertently become a cog in the repressive machine (or not). And who doesn't love 8-bit looking explosions? My only complaint is that, I look at documents all day for my meatspace job, and I wasn't keen on doing it for funsies too.

When I first looked at this, I laughed. I laughed at how stupid this was and why anyone would purchase it. Little did I realise I would be installing this and recording it for my channel xD  I cannot beleive the ammount of fun this game provides and it really gets you to pay attention to detail. This is almost close to a learning game. Pay attention, question your morales, or will you be strict to your job?  A Great Game 10/10 Get it!

Would you belive me if I tell you you will enjoy being a public servant being employed in a pseudo-comunist Rusia's immigration checkpoint? You better do, because this what this game is about, and it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. You can start njoying the perfect made screen which you play in, which consist in the cabine of the checkpoint, the aerial vision of the outside with all the queue of people waiting for pass, and your desk in which you have to carefully read the documents each citizen gives to you. Do you think this is boring? Tell me the same when you have limited time in a day and you have to check the expiration date, the issuing city, the photos, the gender, the validation of each freaking detail on the documents, and other things. You better do it fast, because you get paid for each one you decide right, and you will get nothing if you fail in your decision. By the end of each day, you'll have to manage your salary to feed and keep your family alive, and the game gives you a lot of choices based on moral or your personal preference. Do you want to arrest everyone you can so the guard that works with you pays you a small amount of his bonus? Do you maybe want to help an order that truly wants to clean the government of corruption? It can cost yourself or your family the life depending on the decissions you make, and you have more than 20 alternative endings. Enjoy being a public servant and, trust me, this game is more than it seems. Glory to Arstozka!  Me creerías si te digo que te vas a divertir siendo un empleado del gobierno que trabaja en la aduana de una pseudo Rusia comunista? Más te vale hacerlo, porque de eso va el juego, y es buenísimo. Puedes empezar gozándote lo bien hecho que esta la pantalla en la que juegas, que se conforma de la cabina de la aduana, una vista aérea de toda la cola de gente que quiere pasar, y el escritorio donde deberás revisar cuidadosamente los papeles que quienes vayan pasando te darán. ¿Crees que eso es aburrido? Dime lo mismo cuando vayas contrarreloj en un día y tengas que comprobar fechas de caducidad, ciudades de procedencia, género, fotos, la validación de cada ♥♥♥♥ documento que te den, y otras cosas. Más te vale hacerlo rápido, porque te pagan por cada persona sobre la que decides correctamente, y no te dan nada por cada una con la que te equivoques. Al final de cada día, tendrás que distribuir tu salario para alimentar y mantener viva a tu familia, y este juego te dará un montón de opciones basadas en la moral o en tu preferencia personal. ¿Quieres detener a todo el que puedas para que el guardia que trabaja contigo te pague una parte del bonus que le dan por ello? ¿Quieres ayudar a una orden secreta que intenta de verdad limpiar tu gobierno de corrupción? Tu vida o la de tu familia podrían estar en peligro según las decisiones que tomes, y tienes más de 20 posibles finales diferentes. Que disfrutéis de vuestro trabajo como funcionarios y, creédme, este juego es mucho más de lo que podría parecer. ¡Gloria a Arstozka!

I absolutely could not recommend this game more. To me,  Papers, Please  is one of the best games of 2013, and one of the most unique games I've had the pleasure of playing. At it's face it seems like one of the most boring concepts imaginable for a video game--you play as a lottery-chosen man serving as a checkpoint official for a communist country, and to most people a game emulating government work wouldn't really seem like a blast.  Right from the first few in-game days, though, it provides an interesting challenge that slowly meshes with a branching storyline that depends on how you choose to play the game. Will you play as a patriot, proudly serving your country and preventing dangerous individuals from crossing your iron border, or will you sneakily aid a government-proclaimed 'terrorist' organisation in fighting against your country's tyrannical political system. How you perceive the situation will depend on you, as all in all it's a setting clouded by grey much more than black and white. There is incentive and reason behind running the checkpoint well, too, as you must manage entry properly to earn your salary, which is necessary to keep your family healthy and safe throughout the story.  In conclusion, this game was absolutely worth the ten-dollar price tag, and more, really, and has a reasonably amount of replayability to it because of the numerous endings. You'll probably manage to come across several in your first playthrough, because the way the save system works allows you to continue from the beginning of any day you've progressed to. I would guess that the average player who enjoys this game and plays it two or three times will probably get a reasonably eight to ten hours of gameplay out of it--the average full run for me seems to be about four hours, and I've so far gotten about 16 hours of enjoyed time out of it. I can't promise you'll enjoy  Papers, Please , but I'd be willing to bet you would.

I heard about this game from SourceFedNerd's 'Top 5 Indie games of 2013', watched the first video of a Let's Play, and then decided to get it.  It is worth every cent, easily my most favorite indie game.  The game idea is brilliantly unique, the campaign is fun and not too easy... It took me several attampts and 20h to finish it with my desired outcome, Ending N°1. Afterwards you have 3 modi to play, which are really cool.  In the first one you have 10 minutes to clear as many people as possible, the second one doesn't let you make any mistake and the third one keeps a balance, with an increasing penalty for choosing wrong.   Very fun game, I love it and still play it from time to time.

Although it sounds quite boring simply checking papers to make sure that people can pass or not, the game is actually quite fun. with funny moments and abit of story such as repeat charecters, terrorist attacks, and the struggle of making enough money to care for your family.   Papers,Please is a very fun game for what it is especially made by a single guy. I love this game although the only fault i have with it is sometimes I dont know what I did wrong or when i feel overwhelmed simply by all the stuff i have to check but at the same time the rush of wanting to hurry and be through. But then again thats why I like this game because you have to be fast and get people done with but at the same time you have to be careful.
If it wasn't so hilarious it would feel like work.

One would think a game about checking travel documents would be boring as hell, but I submit to you to try it and find out that it most certainly is -not-. Its a bleak game with a intriguing story about hardship and surviving under an totalitarian government as a border security guard. For just ten bucks its definitely worth your time.

Papers, Please is a hard sell, after all the sentence 'Eastern Bloc immigration official simulator' sounds anything but fun, let alone something that will maintain interest. Yet despite this apparent handicap, the game is totally engrossing, as you decide who can enter Arstotzka - and it really is a matter of life or death in some cases - and it poses so many questions about the gamers' ethics and morals.  Even though it seems to be a drudgery sim, with you doing little more than stamping passports for the duration, there's several storylines that run through the game and a sly streak of humour amidst the oppression and the dystopian greyness that stops the game feeling grim.  It may not be for everyone, as the game requires you to concentrate on the papers in front of you as well as keep a good memory of the nations and cities around you, but this gives Papers, Please an old school charm from the era where taking notes would get you through a game successfully, so if this is up your proverbial street this is a game for you. Be warned, though: you will be humming the theme tune for days.

Papers, Please is a testiment to the fact that a video game doesn't have to be 'fun' to be important. Papers, Please accentuates the mundanity of a run of the mill desk job in which the player is told exactly what to do by your superiors, and punished for not following the rules exactly. The game presents a lot of interesting scenarios in which the rules feel more like a grey structural outline for the player to either follow or bend a little bit in order to make meaningful, personal decisions. I found myself, on many occasions, stretching the rules to do the morally right thing, even if my cold-hearted superiors would vehemently dissagree with my actions. Papers, Please simulates being human in a very profound way.

So what do you do in this game? Stamp papers. You heard me, the whole game is focused on stamping papers. Lots of papers. To be specific, you play as an inspector who accepts or rejects passenger's passports. Make money at the end of each day by being as accurate as you can. Some passports are real, others... well they are fake. People would do whatever they can to get in Arstotzka, so be careful. What I personally love about this title is the choices you can make. You can choose to reject an individual's passport to avoid tickets and make money to support your family. OR you may accept their passport to save their dear life..but lose money because their passport is incorrect. It's your call; the power lies in your hands. The addition of special events, missions, secret organizations, news reports, and the ever changing requirements, makes this one very stressful game. It's stressful but rewarding. Glory to Arstotzka.
To be honest I wasn't sure about this game when I heard about it but decided to give it a go anyway and it is strangly addictive, I love it... I guess you can't judge a book by its cover.

Papers, Please is another wonderful game where the graphics dont matter. The beauty of this game is in the story and the choices you make throughout the story. This is not just a game about who you let into Arstotzka and who you dont, there is a wonderful story woven through it. Every 'mistake' that occurs, whether it be on purpose or not, results in a deduction of your pay for that given day. Will you let in Jorji because he is the funniest character in the game, even though hes on the wanted criminals list? Or will you detain him to keep your family alive? That is up to you, and believe it or not, it changes the outcome of the story completely! The music in this game is also fantastic, and very catchy too. In the end, this game is a good amount of fun, and I highly reccommend it to all players looking to have a great time. Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, please is superb. The gameplay is set up at a perfect pace...introduced slowly and varied just enough that it becomes neither frustrating nor dull. It's a pleasure to play a game that makes paperwork engaging...especially when there are so many games that somehow manage to make shooting things to bits yawn-inducing.

Papers, Please  is a fantastic indie game set in the fictional dystopian country Arstotzka, which is reminiscent of the USSR. Your character has been selected to work at a border check stop allowing or denying people from entering the country. Sometimes, you must stop criminals or terrorists, other times you must choose to allow or deny people in need of sanctuary. All in all, this is a fantastic game with compelling mechanics and style.   Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is a beautifully simplistic, yet addicting game. When I first played the game, I didn't expect to get too involved in it, but the plot and the gameplay are so well designed that it captures you from the get-go.  It starts out very simple, but gradually gets more intricate and fascinating with each passing day. You'll face moral choices where your actions actually feel meaningful, as every mistake or risk taken can greatly affect the game as well as you and your family's welfare.  There are 30 'days' of gameplay, but as most of the people you meet are randomly generated, the replayability is unmeasurable. Your numerous choices also affect the progression of the story so you can play other story paths you didn't take on your earlier playthrough for new experiences.  Though I wouldn't rule it out, I also wouldn't fully recommend this game for a person looking for a casual game to play, as the game can get very intense, especially later on. That said, the difficulty curve is fair, you have nobody else to blame for your mistakes but yourself.  I could ramble on about this game, but it is truly best experienced by playing it. It's definitely worth the price!

This game is simply astonishing. At first sight you might think this game looks boring, but that is far from the truth. The game has an intriguing story with a grim feeling to it. The gamelay of stamping the passports may seem repetive but it is actually a lot of fun and adicting. The concentration mixed with the feelings brought by the plot and characters, as well as the nerves of the time limit makes this game one of the best games I've played in a long time. Sadly after finnishing the story there is not much to do except endless. 'Papers, Please 2' would be a blessing by the gods.  9.5/10

A lot of games are about being a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, often taking the role as a faceless, personality-devoid drone, in a dark and dreary world. It is a reason to tire of modern gaming. Papers, Please is about being a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, taking the role as a faceless, personality-devoid drone, in a dark and dreary world. It is a reason to cherish modern gaming.  Placed in the role as an immigration control inspector, your job is to apply or decline entry to the fictitious nation of Arstotzka. Carefully checking through each persons documents for inconsistencies gradually becomes a more difficult task as the required paperwork piles up. It's a unique game where the core gameplay experience is essentially administration work and that makes it even more bizarre that it is enjoyable. It helps to have a clever story that builds up around the role you play. You feel as though have the scope to change things in slight ways, but at the same time, each tiny infraction is severely punished. Not only is Arstotzka oppressive to newcomers, residents like yourself must pay high living costs on a very low wage linked to work accuracy. Helping a poorly woman with an invalid entry permit so she can see her son may be the reason your son gets sick. Conversely, taking bribes or being a fascist prick might be the only way your little boy gets to eat tonight! Despite the game world being nothing but the daily newspaper and the cramped work space of your little office, everything you do feels so real and, consequently, important.  Spread over a maximum of 31 days, the main campaign can end in twenty different ways (most of them bad and occuring much earlier) depending on the choices you make and the efficiency with which you do your job. And it's a tough job, but someone's gotta do it. Glory to the Arstotzka!

Just marvellous. Never being an inmigration officer has been so engaging.
This game is perfectly demonstrating what would happen if there would still be some kind of a communistic Russia divided into different countries.

Most Satisfyingly Depressing Game of 2013 It’s a great strength of Papers Please that it makes the work you do feel dull and monotonous (just like a real border patrol guard) whilst also appealing to a particular part of your puzzle solving brain. It also makes you paranoid like little else. Dare I risk keeping my son’s drawing on the wall with that inspector around? The game has some irritating issues that I don’t often see addressed, but I won’t list them here. It's more than ready to screw you over at a moment’s notice. Set in a world of hypocritical, xenophobic authority figures, desperate, terrified citizens and refugees, rebels perhaps no better than those they seek to depose and a troubled family just hoping to eat for another day, Papers Please is a harrowing yet brilliant experience, made all the better by its thinly veiled roots in real history. Praise Arstotzka!
Best game gotta to spend hours on it.
This is the greatest job of All Time.

Fantasic game it defenitely captures the real world seriousness of a job that if you make a mistake you may it is a big deal it has so many amazing features look out for the small stuff, my game of the year and i am a prodominately playstation 3 and 4 gamer. It did go unoticed because it was a different type of game and it is a PC game but for only 10 bucks if you haven't picked it up already you should.
Very fun game. Makes you think and sometimes second guess yourself. Highly recommended
Really adictive and time wasting, however it's a great game.

This is one of those game. One of the ones that take your emotions and screw with them to the point where you dont know what is right and wrong. This is a dystopian game where you are a immigration officer. Sounds boring? well it isn't. You deal with family crisises (crisys?), terrorist attacks, conspiracy theories, crazy old men, and everything in between. 10/10
As it may look, terribly boring, i recommend this game 100%! It can be fun and, quite frankly, pretty cool! I rate it 5/5

Please believe the hype. First time in a long time I've looked up from a game to realize I've been playing for 3 hours straight. Replay value does fall off after the first playthrough as you start cherrypicking to get achievements, but the first time through is amazing if you can be disciplined and not read any guides or spoilers.

This game is rediculously hillarious! You would think a game where you are a border guard would be boring. Not at all. Very well written game, very clever. I love the fact that it is old school graphics and sounds as it really puts you mind set that it is the 80's.
If ever you wanted a game that reeked of the term 'Soviet'.. .this is it.  You should buy this.. but go get a fifth of vodka to warm your soul first.

Great little game. There's really nothing to it, it's hardly even a game in the traditional sense. All you do is check people's credentials as they try to enter the country. But as simple as it is, it's actually genius and really fun.  You need to earn money to feed your family, but your efficiency determines your pay so you have to be quick while avoiding mistakes. You have to turn away mothers trying to see their children because there's a typo on their permit, and deal with numerous ethical dilemmas where determining the right course of action is impossible, especially when you simultaneously have a position of immense power, and yet no power at all. All you're trying to do is feed your own family and everything else is secondary. Love it.

Who would have thought that 'Dystopian Document Thriller' could be an absolutley apt description for a game that is this fun. Papers, Please is an example of perfect execution of a video game idea. Bravo.
Its amazing that being so simple and that could have been done in the 80's is really fun, much more than some of the triple A with infinitely bigger budgets now released.
Enjoyable and very detailed there is a lot going on here for what seems to be a very simple game!
Great game it is actually quite fun and interesting to play definitley reccomend it for a nice casual game

After seeing this game on the frontpage from the Summer Sale, something about it intrigued me. So I looked up reviews and saw mostly good things. Only being $3, I jumped at the opportunity and decided to buy it, and it was well worth the money.  I didn't expect much from what I saw of it but it definitely surprised me. I love the retro look, even though the retro look is something people strive to do a lot these days, the game brings and I believe, at least to me, it brings me closer to the game. Looking for discrepancies in passports and other documents never seemed so fun. I played it for a good two hours to reach the one of twenty different endings, and I didn't get bored once. I highly recommend this game to everyone.
This is somehow really good
Worth the download.
