love. this . game.

Absolutely love this game. Has very high replayibility level, a weird but awesome take on a karma system, and keeps you on your toes looking out for details. Definitely recommend if you want a game that you can keep coming back to for a good while.

Great simple game, very easy to get the hang of after a few in game days. Even after you have completed it, it becomes a game of 'I bet I can do more the next time round'.  P.S. If you ever go through Immigration a lot or have just ever been annoyed by the process when ever you go through, this is a good chance feel what it's like to be them and just not care about how much people want to get into the country.
I never realised how much emotion and thought could go into checking people's immigration papers until I played this game. A must play for anyone capable of appreciating a game's story.

I became friends with a drug dealer I got detained at a border checkpoint, felt legitimate hate towards citizens of a fictional country I haven't even seen solely because they were from that country, and spent 20 hours doing a menial job that this game made fun.  11 passports/10 would remove Kolech again

Papers, Please is an intriguing story with a surprising level of complexity. Just when you think there's no more to it something else gets thrown in. Plus there are 20 different endings to try and find. The only negative I have is that your desk quickly becomes crowded. I would've liked a little more room. A real gem though.  8/10
Best TSA simulator on the market, you literally have to scan people in a full body scanner to check what gender they are

This game, during the first days, looked like it was going to be easy, but as the game progressed I had no idea it was going to be so stressful! First, you always have to keep an eye out for forgeries, mistakes and other discrepancies. Second is the pay which is at an all-time low, so it makes it quite hard to feed your family. Third is all these offers from other people claiming that they will give you money, but sometimes, you can't accept because then your job would be at stake. But hey, that's what makes the game so fun! The part that stands out to me most though, is that at every ending, it says 'Glory to Arstotzka.', which I've found can have different meanings depending on how the game ends. If ended in criminalization, 'Glory to Arstotzka.' can mean, 'You don't deserve to be a part of Arstotzka. Glory to the rest of us.'. If ended in doing your job well, it can mean, 'You are accepted as one of us. Glory to all of us, including you.' Three words that say the same thing, but mean different things. This game is definitely worth playing.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Quite unexpected. Who ever thought that being border control would pose an interesting challenge?
It's simple, yet challenging.

This is a game about papers, but is so much more it is about choiches will you support the rebels? Or will you stick with your govrement because they might hurt your family? Will you accept bribes if your son is sick? This and many more in a cheap very good game

This is way more than a game. This is a masterpiece. A game in which a simple choice can ruin your or others' life.   THIS is true art. I believe everyone should experience this. I seriously cannot recommend this enough.

This game is absolutely amazing, I can honestly say that its the BEST game i've played in a very long time. Since I purchased this game I havent switched on my PS4 once! This is what a game should be like, its not all about good graphics, its about how much fun the game is, and Papers Please DOES NOT dissapoint, in ANY way. Highly recommended to everyone.

Check the videos on youtube- it's prettymuch just like that... which is to say completely unlike anything else. Review papers, quickly, to changing specifications, keep sad little family alive in dystopian country. Surprisingly charming.

I consider this game to be really fun and interesting at times. You play as a person who got a passport checking job from the Country's 'October Labor Lottery,' and your job is to check immigrant passports on their way into your country of Arstortzka. It is a fun game with fun puzzle solving parts.

The first thing i must say is that this i an amazing game. But... there will be times when you are scanning a girl and it ends up being a guy... this can get quite distubing at times. so if you are a 13 or younger you will probubly get a boner. If you are a imature little prick you should not play this game.

Papers, Please is a rare combination that is both fun and thought provoking. Despite the depressing themes the gameplay and story is engaging enough to make you keep playing. I highly recommend this game.
Realy Nice, see how fast your morality can take a dive when your family is in need :+
great game!

A very intriguing and distinct polit-thriller set in an east european-like country in the 1980s. Main location is the border of Arstotzka, where the player takes the position as the border inspector. While the gameplay may look dull and simplystic since you do mostly paper work for 90% of the game, it becomes more challenging as you progress further. You have to watch out and point out every discrepancy in the documents of the immigrants, which becomes much harder since there always come more documents.  The Border is also the main focus point of the plot. Basically it all depends on you how the story will progress. Will you support the secret society who wants to bring change to the country or will you simply keep on doing your job and ignore them? Will you let the old woman who urgently need medical treatment pass or shoo her away because she hasn't brought the right documents? All of this and more depends solely on your actions.  There are a total of 20 endings and you'll have to replay the game a few times to see them all.  I'd really enjoyed Papers, Please and must say, it is one of these unique experiences that one must play by him/herself to appreciate.
Best game about border checks ever.
I love this game it makes me use my brain too much though lol I have my desk set up all figured out now though when I play this lol to make it easier for me to check passports :)
My Review:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NQU9ox2KNeE

I think I like this game more in therory than in practice. It wasn't terribly fun, but it was quite interesting. The problem with the game is that it is all paperwork. I just tend not to think of paperwork and fun in the same sentence. It is an interesting game though, and for that I'm glad that I played it. It was a real good test for attention to detail. The people that try to come through the border can be pretty interesting too. If you're looking for something interesting to spend some time with this is a good game.

If anybody in your vicinity questions whether or not video games can be art, just shove this game in their face and leave them alone with it for a while. Papers, Please thrives on hard decision-making and emotional attachment. Should you be the most brutal immigration officer possible, in order to insure the wellbeing of your family? Will you be self-sacrificing, and let through those who need it most at you and your family's expense? Or will you attempt to overthrow the system from within, to improve your family's life in the long-term? These questions are engrossing, and will keep you hooked to the story.  The gameplay itself sounds like it should be dull, but is instead utterly unique and addicting. If you have a good eye for details, and love fast-paced games with a gentle learning curve, then this game is for you.  Just play Papers, Please, dammit.

Played this game when it was in Beta lil less than a year ago and actually didn't like it much. But that's why you don't play Betas or Early Access, cause in most cases they have very little to do with a real game. To my surprise when I saw it again around a month ago, when my gf was playing it 5 or 6 hours straight, I couldn't resist to take a look and boy this game became quite entertaining (not too much of a replayability but still). The story is very thorough with lots of details, unique characters and many of endings (about 20) with the difficulty constantly increasing, but never ending being up THAT hard. Game mechanics are quite simple, though it has some lesser flaws (for example I didn't get, why you upgrade your booth to be able to use shortcuts for some useless actions, while real helping stuff is not introduced, like a button to call a next immigrant or a button to 'use a talking device'). I would recommend this game to someone who wants to play a game out of the box, had a dream to become a customs inspector and to everyone else. And I'm pretty sure that you will miss Jorji after you are finished with the Papers, Please =]

I was playing this for first time and I was having a blast. My roommate sees what I'm doing and he's like, 'so the game is about you doing paperwork...?' And I reply with glee, 'Yup!' and he walks away. What I love about the game, though, is that it is not just a game but also a documentary - documentary about what it'd be like to live in a country like USSR, and how intense and scary and difficult it would have been. Also after playing this game when I was going back home for vacation, I felt I connected with the people at the airport more now, because I understood (in my own little mind) what it means to look at passports and what to do about it. Overall, the game was pretty darn intense, and I'd gladly play more and more

I have never seen a game in which you care about the characters so much, you'd rather screw yourself over. Truly an amazing game, and with so many ending, you can easily put many hours into this dystopian document thriller.

On the outisde it seems like a monotonous repitition of stamping papers, and at first the game may also feel that way as well. HOWEVER, the more days you go to work the more complicated things become. People ask of you favors, you make errors and it costs you (and your family) money. Everything you do begins to have side effects, you may accidentally let a killer into your country and the next day there will be a headline about it in the daily newspaper. It's a fascinating game with 20(?) endings. You can take you and your family almost anywhere in the game. Whether your character is a die-hard loyalist, or even a revolutionary is entirely up to you!
Very Very fun game worth the money
Might be favourite game of 2014 MAYBE...........

This game understands the problems with immigration and boarder control better than most politicians. 'A Dystopian Document Thriller' delivers exactly what it says on the box. One of the most engrossing, involving and thought provoking games I have ever played.  After a while it is not like you even enjoy the game, but you must keep going to keep your family alive! I know that some of my decisions cost the lives of many, but I can live with that as long as my son gets his medicine. And this is the true genius of this game, it involves you. Each morning you read about the horrible things happening while walking to work, most of which you are more than likely instrumental in causing, and each morning you make more decisions that will have more horrible consequences. And you know all this and do them anyway. Not gladly but because you must! Glory to Arstotzka!

This game has absolutely no business being as fun as it is. If you can get past the design choice (read: graphics) it is strangely addicting. Be warned: attention to detail and good memory is a must. The devil is truly in the details in this game.

Honesly, im absolutly addicted to this game. I don't know why though! the graphics are admiably god-awful for todays standards, yet its just 'Fun'. I highly recommend getting it. I know im happy I did!

This is a game that I never thought would be so good. Its challenging and crazy fun. This game gets harder as you go along, but it never stops being entertaining for a second. This game was given to me as a gift, and It's the best game I got this year. If you have a copy to give to someone, give it to them - and if you don't have the game yourself, get it. It's worth the money.

This is a super fun game to play, It may not be the most action packed and exciting, but its got a great concept. Its actually quite stressful too just based on having to completely look over someones passport in as short a time as possible. If it goes on sale, I'd suggest buy it!

This game is great! The concept seems quite boring - check people's paperwork at a border - but it really is enjoyable. Although the gameplay is repetative, it changes enough to keep you working and thinking. There's also the pressure of trying to get through as many people as possible to earn money for your family, which, along with the increased pace later in the game, really adds to the thrill.

Truly one of the few games out there that will make you feel that your actions have ramifications, not just for you and your in-game familiy, but for the virtual people around you.  Papers, Please starts off simply enough, just looking for discrepancies in data, but quickly snowballs into situations where you question where your loyalties lie. Do you let the innocent-seeming woman go through even with the typo on her passport? Or do you risk your pay (and your family's wellbeing) to prevent entry to an angry patriot that threatens to blow up the city, even though his papers are all in order?   While I would not call Papers, Please 'Fun', it is an experience you won't forget anytime soon.
An excellent indie game with a nice communist retro graphic style and different endings
Glory to Artstotzka

The best game I have played all year. It may look like a beurocratic simulator, but 'papers, please' is original and darkly satirical at times. It often gives you many moral choices that are not always 'black or white' situations. The number of different endings makes the game varied each time you play through. If you a fan of games which force you to make meaningful choices and have a great story then 'Papers, Please' is game I would recommend you buy.
If you dont already have this game, you need it, nuff said
Everything from the music to the artwork fully sets the mood for this game. You feel the monotony and the depression of the daily grind. In a good way. This game is fantastic.
Reminds me of living in the eastern block

A really nice game. It looks quite boring, but i really like the way the dev's balanced this game. There is a pretty depressing atmosphere in this game, that makes you really go into the 'sovjet' era ;) 7/10
Insanely addicting despite the simplicity in nature and repetition, this came is incredibably fun. I wish it were longer. Don't let the graphics fool you, this is a top quality game

Although the premise is relatively simple, the game design, both artistically and functionally, is so clever that I cannot help but be drawn into my alternate life as a border control officer in Glorious Arstotzka. As I shuffle immigration documents around my desk I feel like a cold-blooded bureaucrat, who narrows his eyes as he glances across your information, sniffs knowlingly and loudly stamps your papers, deciding your fate. Will you be allowed through, or will you be sent away?
Surprisingly amazing, full of unexpected developments in gameplay  BUY IT NOW

Bureaucracy at its finest, 'Papers, Please' puts you in the shoes of a border crossing inspector. Players verify documents and must determine whether the poor souls in line deserve entry into the great nation of Arstotzka.  It starts out simply enough, with only the passport to inspect, but the game steadily ups the ante, adding new documents and clever ways to fool you into allowing entry. Eventually, as society collapses around you, players even get the opportunity to take down impatient applicants who attempt to cross the border prematurely.  Take bribes, serve justice, detain smugglers, scan crossdressers, deny your family food, heat or medicine... could you ask for anything more of a game?

Stamp. Rustle. Stamp. Rustle. Stamp. Rustle. An air horn blast shakes you out of your near stupor. You quickly pass the last few documents back to the stranger on the other side of the grill. And so ends another day. Check your finances and off to the next. That's Paper's Please in a nutshell. While it may not sound like much, this game is one of the most eerily absorbing games I've ever played. Simple and surprisingly real.

Papers, Please is one of the most monotonous, mundane, and all around not-very-fun-to-play experiences of 2013 - and that is why it is amazing. I have never wanted to continue to play a game that forces you to memorize minutia, and make decisions that range on a spectrum of grey from 'bad' to 'slightly less bad'. From it's flawless presentation, to it's fantastic music and sound design, Paper's Please is an indie darling through and through, and easily one of the best games of 2013.
I was confused as to what the appeal of this game was. I still am, but I'm addicted.
Best Indie Game I've ever played, Strategic, makes you think, and has some comedic value to it as well. A bit of replay value, worth more than 10$ IMO
this game is simple but great!
Best dystopian border guard sim I've ever played. Stamping documents has never been so fun. Glory to Arstotzka.
Awesome! This is my dream job!
Remember that rude a*s at immigration when you just landed after a 13 hour flight? Yes? Well, now you can be the same rude a*s.

At first I thought this was a boring game, but I tried it anyway.  And I played it for 4 hours on the first go. :)  For me, the interesting part is that you have to make choices in the game, and the game itself has different endings.  Though, I don't know if I am going to see all of them, since the passport checking part can become a dull process after a while. Nevertheless, would recommend, have to try it. ;)
Simplistic but addictive!

Originally thought it seemed like a bit of a giggle, 4 hours later I was grinning from ear to ear because my neice went missing because I didn't earn enough. Next time I'll deny my mother-in-law her medicine. A truly deep political satire.  Just one more turn....

94/100. When 'simple' means great.  Pro: - Addictive gameplay. - Learning curve not straight as it may appear at a first look. - Great atmosphere sustained only by short dialogues and a few lines of text. - Always running out of time (or this is a cons?).  Cons: - I've already played it.  Recommended to everyone who are not scared from (a great) C64 graphic style and looks for something different from the average AAA title.

GLORY TO ASTROVSKA!  But seriously, I got this game because a friend was playing it. I started playing it and the low quality of it got to me, but I stuck it out then I ended up getting really into it. I ended up finally finding out that there are multiple endings which was cool.  Lets delve into this a little more.  I started playing it, and all I was worried about was feeding my family and keeping them warm. Then some анти правительство группа started talking to me; and I ended up helping им из. The paid me well, I got citations for doing неправильное вещь but still, for the good of ezio я сделал это. After a while, the game got to меня. And now I cant stop speaking России. Its terrible because все, что я хочу сделать, это получить работу в охране границы сейчас . Но это хорошо в пути , потому что я теперь могу говорить свободно России .  Слава родине!

Yes, that's a red thumb. Don't get me wrong this is a good, innovative and surprising game. But it has a major fault you need to be aware of before buying it.  >This game is about WORKING.  Like a real job, maybe like your real job. You spend the daytime in your office, doing a repetitive task, in a dull and boring environnement. You go back home in the evening, worried about your family members getting ill and bills to pay. And you have to perform well at work, for you salary is based on your productivity.  This is quite stressful and you definitely don't want to go for another work routine when you log on steam.  Moreover everything in this game is so... depressing. It can't be explained with words, but I find that the feeling you get while playing is not enjoyable at all, almost repulsive. Right now I remember the graphics, the music, the suffocating atmosphere and I just want to run away and finish this rating as fast as possible.  I know there's a lot of positive ratings for this game already and I got their point : the game is good and unique obviously.  But do you seriously feel like working in a video game and going through all that implies ?

Brilliantly simple yet engaging and stimulating. This is one non-standard indie game that is a must have for all, double if you can remember the Cold War proppaganda of the 80s. May not be suitable for those who get seriuosly heart broken at the fate of fictional characters.

Very intricate memory game. Allows you to test your memory, while also pressuring you to process as many people as possible to make as much money as possible to support your family. Loved this game for the time I played it.

After hearing so much about this game I just had to give it a go. I poured myself a proper cuppa, set aside a few Garibaldis and got cracking...  ...And cracking it was! The gameplay is perfect for those who like a bit of order in their lives, and is slightly addictive to say the least. I really love stamping things, and you get to do a lot of that. It's epic.  The graphics and music are, of course, a tad crappy. But that's the point! The game is set in an alternate version of the 1980s, so I presume it's been designed to emulate the feel of games in those days. Furthermore, it provides real evidence towards the fact that a game doesn't need to look all spangly to be captivating. In fact, I genuinely believe the game benefits from the simplicity of its style.  The game isn't overly hard, and probably could be made more testing in later levels without destroying the fun, so a possible update from the developers in that way would be a lovely thing. But even if they never do, I will cherish my time at my checkpoint in Arstotzka. Yes I will.
Super addicting game. Definitely one of a kind and many endings depending on choices made in game!

What an amazing game! I don't think I've played a game where my political consciousness was more wide awake. An absolute must-play experience with a hidden yet strong political agenda that WILL make you think.

Clever, thematic and flavorful. You really are working on the clock, so you have to balance between rushing through passports in order to make more money, and studying them carefully in order to avoid infraction fines. Then after work, you have to choose between paying for the medicine your mother-in-law needs or the heat for your class-8 apartment. Excellent game with greater immersion than most non-pixelated titles.

Though I have only spent a few hours playing this game I have thoroughly enjoyed every moment and I want to play more. I am incredibley impressed with all aspects of the game. The developers and artists have considered a theme/style and have delivered a quality experience which is consistent and precise in its visual communication. From the pixel art style, the music, the sounds of the game and involvement of the player in story mode has delivered a new gaming experience, I haven't had before. It is games like this that open up new possibilities of what is considered a game. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for something different.

It starts as a linear 'stamping simulator' but, actually the game diversifies a lot from that starting point. You can simply play the game mechanically, doing your job, or you can try to approach it from other angles. I mean, the core mechanics it´s always the demanding validation of documents with different rules being thrown at you. But at certain point the money you do is not enough to support your family. Your son will get sick, your wife cold and you have to decide how you're going to manage your money and most importantly, you will be tempted to get corrupted.    And it´s in that point that the game gets more interesting. It´s impossible not to get corrupted, but how will you manage your corruption? Will you be content with the petty government corruption? Will you go for high level corruption earning more money but risking more? Will you get involved with drugs?   And there´s also the more 'emotional' side. Will you risk a share of your salary by wrongly stopping someone from entering the country because you know he is a human slaver? Will you allow the illegal wife of a legal immigrant to enter the country knowing that your denial will sentence her to death? Will you get involved in a conspiracy to overthrown your oppressive government, and if so, how much will you get involved? Will you kill for it? What comes firts, liberty or family?  All this, and not knowing the ramifications of your actions, because sometimes an innocent thing can end up being not so harmless, gives this game a depth like very few games I´ve played. It´s not a 'boring job simulator', but it does a superb job of putting you on the skin of someone with a boring job and showing that what defines one person is much more than the most immediate layer of his existence. But above all, it an amazing sociological tool to understand how easy it is for a system to get systemically corrupted, and most importantly, why this happens.

Awesome old-school game. Great idea, realistic atmosphere of communist state of Arstotzka, non linear game play. I even can't believe that all this could be fit in a primitive graphic. Glory to Arstotzka!!1111

Truly unique among games - Papers, Please appeals to your powers of perception, as well as personal ethics. I can scarcely mention anything that hasn't already been said in every other review. This game is about choices, the choice to protect yourself, your fellow man, your family. Are you a good worker, a good citizen, or a good person? Is the distinction relevant?  This game is detail oriented, and the faster you learn the rules at the beginning of each work day, the faster you can decide what's more important- to do your job well and protect yourself (and by proxy, your family), or to help those who pass through your check point. My guess is, if you enjoy the gameplay enough, you'll want to play through a few different times and your ethics will become more malleable over time. It's thought provoking stuff, which is a hallmark of good art. Careful, this game is a time vortex.
A very simple idea brought to life by a brilliant concept it is very unique and a must-play.
Brilliant idea.

Not many games can make that happen. The replayability is built right into the game play too, which is a plus. Give it a try!

Aaarrrgh! This should not be as fun as it is!  Paperwork and 'thriller' don't often go together, and when they do they tend to counteract one another, but not in this case. Being a border control officer for a fictional communist totalitarian state sees you enforce a list of ever increasing, and ever more complex, set of rules against a constant influx of would-be transients, visitors and immigrants. Speed and accuracy are the name of the game, you've got a family to keep and the more people you process, the more you get paid. Keep getting it wrong, and you'll be fined. Of course, the transient public don't always make it easy to do that, you'll get your fair share of timewasters, revolutionaries and purchasers of false documentation to hold you back, but you might find a lack of morals quite beneficial.  Every step of the way there are choices, and endings to reflect those choices. The 2D washed-out pallet gives a very Soviet atmosphere, and the soundtrack keeps your mind on the job. Nothing is distracting (that isn't intended to be) and you'll find that if you struggle with accurate work under increasing pressure, you'll find yourself getting much better at it. In this sense I adore the game - it doesn't reward mindless reflexes, it pushes you to focus and better your mental agility.   One of the most challenging games I have played, but somehow I always come back for more!

I have never truly hated a game before playing Papers, Please.  You may wonder why I still recommend this game even though the mere thought of it makes my face red with bitterness. But it is the hate that keeps the game from ever once being boring.  The game starts as you’re thrust into a new occupation in a field of which you have absolutely no experience. You’re paid based on how many people you can shuffle through the border gates, not just by the simple fact that you’re wasting your time at the booth instead of at home. Your savings are dwindling fast, and your family needs food and heat and a roof over their heads, all of which cost money.  So there’s a sense of urgency to this game, a feeling that if you don’t get as many people into the country as physically possible, some unspeakably horrible thing will happen to your family after they’re thrown out onto the streets, hungry and cold. This leads to a mad race to stick it to the people who forced you into this job, to become the fastest passport stamper they’ve ever known. There are only so many hours in the day, and you wouldn’t want to have to ignore the food bill just so you can make rent on time.  Do I recommend playing Papers, Please? Absolutely! Do I recommend that you willingly fork over your hard-earned cash for the privilege of experiencing what is quite literally Work: The Video Game? Well, that depends...  If you’re the kind of person who had money coming out of their ears, the kind of person who already owns at least half of the games on Steam, then by all means, drop ten bucks on it. You’ll probably find it a very humbling experience. If, however, your current occupation so tedious and poorly paid that pounding on books all day would be a marked improvement, and you just want a cheap indie title that will actually run on that clunker you call a PC, then I would strongly suggest waiting until Steam family sharing starts to try this.  (Note: There is a bug that if you “Launch (Windowed)” the game will not record your time playing.

Do I recommend this? Yes. Yes, I do. Upon looking at the description of this game, I thought to myself, 'this seems like a boring game. I'm an immigration officer? What blasplemy of a game is this?' Looking at the reviews and then watching the trailer, I became intruged. What can be so interesting simulating a day to day work process of stamping papers at an immigration checkpoint? Seeing it on sale, I had to give it a try. Boy was I am surprised. This indie game definietly packed thriller in a dystopian society where there are betrayals, terrorist attacks, taking up arms, and etc. Even though the concept is simple, hearing the typewriting sound of a citation printing up bugs me, which indicated I had made a mistake in my job. Perfecting your job as an immigration officer is no easy task. The game's 20 endings give it lots of twists and turns, where your actions will lead to another ending. I played this 2 full days straight, completing two good endings and 16 out of 20 possible endings. I figured I shall take a break from the game to recommend everyone that they should definietly give this game a try.  P.S. The music and the subtle comical aspects of the game is great as well.

Nothing better than getting out of a day at work and go to another day at work, getting citation for letting a terrorist get into your country while, at the same time, having your son dying and not being able to afford his medicine.  Still, the hookers at the strip club are nice

I look forward to replaying it for the other endings, there are some very unique paths you can take. Some of the personalities you come across in the game are hilarious.  100% recommend.

The truth behind this game could not be farther away. The game is really about survival, as you will soon see once you experience this very intelligently put together game. Party approved.

Tons of satire with memorial characters makes this game really funny at times. If this game was on flash sale will definitely make some more copies so my friends can play too.

Who knew how much tense checking passports can be?  The moral dilemas in this game are phenomenal. You constantly weigh how good you want to inspect the current passenger's certifications against how many passports will you check before the time runs out (because each checked passport gives you money, and your son is sick and needs medicine, and the rent just went up, and your wife is almost dead starving..). Plus, even though quite minimalistic, the art direction in this game is spot on to convey the grimm reality of a 1980 european state of decay. Two thumbs up!

Papers Please is the best game I have ever played. Many choose your own story games just tell you what your choices are, however Papers Please manages to let you choose your own adventure, without you even knowing that you could. You make a choice everytime you accept or deny any person. But there are moments where someone wants you to do something that opposes what you're suppose to do, and you are left with a choice: accept the person and face the penalty, or deny that person and face the consequences.  This game is amazingly bland! Many people are critisizing it because of how repetitive and bland this is... that's the point. This game makes you feel bored with the tasks you are doing, but you are still having fun and enjoying the game. Each person that passes through your booth has a different story, most of the time you don't hear that story, but when you do, you feel for the character and you want to accept them, but they don't have the right paperwork... and that is where the choices come in.  Papers Please is a great game that everyone should at least try.  10/10

This is a pretty simple puzzle game that touches all the right notes to be a masterpiece (at least within the Indie scene). You are tasked with handling the people that's trying to get into your country, which presents you choices with actual consequences in the story (None of which, I might add, are ham-fisted in cutscenes or other stuff like that).  Would you allow a criminal into your country if that meant you'll be able to put food on the table of your family that day? Would you allow families that have been separated by war to get together again? Would you take bribes?  Whatever your final choices are, the game do not judge you for them. After all you're just trying to get by, right?

'Papers, Please' is self described as 'A dystopian document thriller.' I couldn't give it a better description than that. Time is money, and you need to process as many passports as possible before the day ends. The more passports you process, the more money you can make, which keeps your family from suffering. The whole process of examing passports for correct data starts out easy at first, but gets tougher every day with more complex bureaucracy. If it wasn't tough enough to suffer through a hard day's work, you also may find your day ending short with a possible terrorist attack. Although this all sounds masochistic, that is where the true beauty of the game shines. The two problems I have with this game is the short amount of time they give you for each day (frantic indeed), and the fact that it retails at $10. I usually don't have a problem with the price of a game, but even at $10, it is a very simple game that could just as easily have been released as a Flash game on Newgrounds. If you love high stress puzzle games, or ever had the dream of working at your local DMV, you definitely need to check this out.

Such a simple idea, how could admitting and declining immigrants and passerbys into a country be of any fun at all? Well when you're faced with terrorists, underground organisations, smugglers, lovers, families, corrput police officers, bribary and many more outlandish situations, a day at work is never, ever dull!   Should you sell a digital watch to someone in line to pay for you son's birthday present, or return it to the man who trusted it in your care? Should you be slack with a regular? Should you let someone through the border because a friend asked you to? All of these questions run through your head with evey new person you meet, and all the while, your family back in your apartment are starving, freezing and suffering from sickness... And every major choice you make, the world around you changes, as the daily newspaper will let you know.. So by admitting one too many smugglers, that drug-selling boom you read about while eating breakfast was entirely your fault. Oops!

Although $10 is a little pricey for a game that is not very long, it makes you think in a way many games do not.  This full-fledged game should be no surprise to those familiar with Lucas Pope’s work.The free versions found on his website are unique and explore seemingly simple ideas for a greater purpose. For example, the Republica Times game explores the complex notions of the power behind media, government corruption and political unrest. These same themes spread into Papers, Please, which makes it a very powerful experience. It helps to split the screen into an overall border watch view on top, which shows people standing in line, the person approaching the booth and the movements of the guards. It will also show terrorist attacks and where you will go when given the tools needed to sedate (or kill) people rushing the wall.  For more on why you need to give this game a shot, visit  http://fovgames.com/2014/01/13/papers-please/

I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves a bit of puzzle solving, or critical detail checking, a bit of story, high pressure, attention to detail, and 20 different endings and various NPC interactions that reflect your actions on a daily episodic basis while under the suspicion of war/terrorist attacks at your border patrol station.  Don't let the graphics turn you off, the game play is amazing.
This game is somehow riveting and intense, despite it being a border checkpoint simulator. I love it.
Just brilliant. Glory to Arstotzka.

There is no way to describe this game to make it sound fun: you are an immigration official responsible for inspecting immigrants' paperwork before allowing them into the country. The 8-bit graphics, the MIDI sound -- it all seems like it should be a boring game, but the weird part is, the game is strangely compelling.  Using amazingly simple compnents, Papers, Please weaves a brilliant story that draws you in and makes you care about characters you never see, feel for a state that is truly oppressive, and strive to do the best you can at a boring and repetetive job. Add in a branching storyline with 20 different endings depending on your actions, it is well worth the $10 when at full price; at any sort of a discount, it is a crime not to buy it.

It still needs a lot of tweaking as the interface needs more accurate actions than the graphics let you believe. That is very unfortunate, it makes it a worse game that it could be. The game really let's you feel like you are in acting on the civilian side of a (cold)warzone in some East-European country. The originality of the game, and the fun it offers, makes it a recommendable game. 7/10 Better than average and the potential to become better than that with a fix of the interface.

Simple game with increasing difficulty and multiple endings. Torn between doing whats right and doing what you are told. Fun and slightly frustrating when you are trying to earn enough money to keep your family alive. Highly reccomend picking this indie game up! 8/10

If someone told me before playing this game that i'd end up loving a game where you just check passport and travel documents with NES era graphics i would have had them commited to a lunatic asylum.  However this is a game you really have to try to get the appeal and that is definitely worth doing. In the game you play a guy drafted in to work at a border point checking documents. You start off simply checking passports but as the game progresses this becomes more complex as you have to check and inspect ID's, work visa's and other documents. This is made even more challenging as you have a time limit and need to process as many people as you can within that time limit. Each succesful processing you do earns you money which is vital to feed and keep yourself and your family warm. If you make mistakes you can get fined meaning you have less money and a family member could die of hunger or sickness.  The game also has a story to it where you have to make choices about how to proceed. Do you let a poor refugee pass through even they don't have a passport or do you turn them away? Each choice can have benefits or consequences for you so this gives the game a replayability value.  This game shouldn't be so fun, but it is. 8/10

A boring desk job made into a game somehow turns into a fun experience. Look for minute details on foreigners documents and approve or deny their entrance into your country. But will you follow your job to the end or let yourself be corrupted because of ideals or money? Your family lives are on the line, make your choices.

Ostensibly, a boring game with very tedious gameplay. However, the gameplay is not what you're here for. The subtle subtext behind every decision in this game holds an incredible amount of weight, not only on yourself or the outcome of the game but on everyone you interact with. The amount of decision making that happens in this game is nothing short of massive. The differences between every decision that you have to make is what makes the game so compelling.
Amazing game and experience.

This really lives up to its promise of simulating a communist immigration inspector job ... moral choices both overt and subtle, steadily piling up democracy, and a perverse (and fitting) sense of humour. If the concept appeals to you, this is a must play!

Papers, Please is a game that answered a lot of questions for me. The main question is: why do people break the law? And this game illustrates it perfectly. Not only does it do this, but it has the best morality system in games I have ever seen. Your choices actually mean something, you have power over other people - but mainly because it's actually integrated into the gameplay. Almost every few people that come by, they give you a reason why you should let them through even if they have the wrong stuff, and you have to decide whether it's good enough. You also have your own family to think about, so you can choose to make your family happy or make your comrades happy. While you do have all of this power, the game doesn't fail to remind you that, despite these choices, your position is actually quite terrible. And it doesn't hesitiate to rub it in your face when you get a bad ending. TL;DR, buy this game and learn why people are corrupt.

When I think about art in gaming, this is what I think of. Not Gone Home, not Bioshock Infinite, not any of the legion of (very, very great) games with complex narratives and verbal characterizations and strong traditional storytelling. I think of this. I think of a game that impresses a feeling and sensation on you not just by words but by actions, a game where the mechanics themselves are the art as much as the setting.  Papers, Please is a game that raises the bar for what games can be.

Love this game! It can get really intense and has a lovely back story to it. Would reccomend the game to friends! 5/5

Papers, Please is not what it seems. You may see just a simple game where you accept and deny passports. If so, think again. This game has one of the best branching storylines I have ever experienced, and I highly suggest it for anyone who A. Likes a good story or B. Likes to think.  Glory to Arstotzka.

This game is extremely original and awesome, as I expected when I bought it.  It's so simple and yet so challenging! Some reviews say the game might feel repetitive, but on the contrary, I find it actually so fascinating it's hard to pull the plug once you've started, at least till one of the many many endings! I must also say that as a 20th century History geek, the setting of this dystopia really pleases me.  I just wished I sucked less at being a spy... Ah well!

The description of this game is a bit misleading-- in a good way. It's way more awesome than it sounds.  I spent hours trying to navigate through scenarios where one wrong decision or a slow reaction would affect the people I'd met.  I've played through tons of different ways to see how people react in different scenarios.  I'm the most loyal dude there is! I've also been a corrupt SOB.  I was nearly moved to tears. I've yelled at the screen, 'NO STOP DON'T.' I've been insulted and super angry. I've laughed my rumpus off. All from a game about a job where you look at papers and stamp 'Approve' or 'Deny.' It mimics life in that the job is way more complex than it looks on the surface.  If you want it, get it. If you're thinking about it, get it. If you don't want it, think about it again, then probably get it.   A++ will search Jorji again.
Is excellent game. I reccomend for purchase immediately. I am in no way obligated for to say how good this game. I swear there is no secret police holding me gunpoint. Glory to Arstotzka.
Amazing. Great gameplay. Great story.

Below its simple game mechanics lies a game with so much character it's staggering. It’s impossible not to fall into the mindset of a border control officer, pondering the way you are changing lives with your simple set of stamps.   A must buy!
YOU LOOK AT PEOPLES PAPERS AND YOU MAYBE LET THEM INTO COUNTRY. ALSO YOU HAVE A FAMILY TO FEED
Amazing gameplay mechanics, and more interesting than you would think.
I didn't imagine getting into the mindset of a border control agent can be this entertaining.
Brilliant. I thought that it would be boring but - IT'S SO GOOD.

Excellent game, shows that you can make even mundane ideas a really engaging game experience. Only real downside is that the game really needs hotkeys, but hotkeys are only enabled as upgrades later on in.

This game forces you to make choices based on your own moral code. It's definately difficult to make some of these decisions, but at the same time, it's easy. Making choices in a game has never made me more nervous than the choices I had to make in this one. I'm still working through this thing, and it does frustrate me sometimes. But, this is one game you certainly should pick up and play through at least once. The narrative, game mechanics, and action of the game are the absolute driving forces that keep me involved.
Very interesting and interntaining game.
Amazing game! It's fun, it requires concentration and study and I can't stop playing it! Buy it now!
wonderfully fun game. Beuracracy at its finest. if it's on sale, a definite good buy. glory to arstotzka
I've never felt so accomplished that my kids didn't die
Do you enjoy dystopian document thrillers? Of course not… It's tough to explain why poring through documents in a Soviet-esque customs booth circa '82 is fun, but it IS. 5/5
One of the most unusual games ever. Masterpiece in '1984' style.
This game is too cool for school

This game has easily come out of nowhere on my behalf, the entirity of my reasoning behind buying it, was a Zero Punctuation episode. Needless to say, if Yahtzee says something is 'not crap' then, seeing as he is a Banana, it must be true.  Papers, Please is one of the most addictive games i've come across for some time, it manages to throw out complex moral choices, and has twenty possible endings depending on your actions. Will you be corrupt, or law abiding? Will you help lost lovers reunite, or tell one of them to go have a chat to the men with guns.  There are moments where you yourself HAVE to use a gun, and in every scenario it comes almost entirely out of nowhere, and your failure to react will either cause the death of someone you speak to, or yourself.   I've no doubt i'll be playing this to uncover each possible ending, likely getting myself killed a few times to do it, but hey, that's the price of progress!   I can heartily recommend this to just about anyone I meet, so long as you've an eye for detail. This is happily one of my best experiences with Indie games, it manages to get a moral point across, without going into 'artsy' territory, which I find is just code for boring and pretentious.   Two thumbs way up, four stars, a nine out of ten! Easily a must play. So go buy it Comrade.

Papers, Please is an interesting look into border control. It puts you in the shoes of a guy who was essentially drafted into being one, and you get faced with all kinds of interesting propositions and ideas. You can choose to be loyal to your government, aid the terrorists, accept bribes, and more. There's quite a few different endings to the game, and you'll definitely feel inclined to play through at least a few of them. The art, while not fantastic in and of itself, sets a very nice mood and tone to the game, and you will stop noticing it after just a couple minutes of gameplay. It's definitely a game worth taking a look at.
Great dystopian document Thriller, with a surprising amount of content. You have nothing to fear. Glory to Arstotzka!
It's a bureaucracy simulator, but a weirdly compelling one. Much more interesting than it has any right to be.
it shoundn't be this addicting, but it is.

It puts you in the shoes of a guy who was essentially drafted into being one, and you get faced with all kinds of interesting propositions and ideas. You can choose to be loyal to your government, aid the terrorists, accept bribes, and more. There's quite a few different endings to the game, and you'll definitely feel inclined to play through at least a few of them. The art, while not fantastic in and of itself, sets a very nice mood and tone to the game, and you will stop noticing it after just a couple minutes of gameplay. It's definitely a game worth taking a look at.

On the surface, Papers, Please is not a game you think you'd enjoy. I mean, who wants to do paperwork in their free time?! This game, however, makes mind numbing tedium fun again! Each day in the glorious nation of Arstotzka brings new challenges and hardships, looking to make you and your family cold and hungry, and it's up to you, a lowly border guard, to keep the nation safe from threats and terrorists, looking to upset the balance.  Highly recommended.  Glory to Arstotzka!
is the beast gaem ever
This game reminds of the motherland, it feels like I was in Russia yesterday
Love this game.

Papers please is easily one of the most innovative game ever made. It is hard to believe, that paperwork at border booth can be so depressing, yet entertaining. You are just an ordinary man, who needs to feed his family and pay rent. Your job is to check passports and documents, you need to be correct and fast, otherwise your son will starve to death and you go to jail for depts. However people at borders are desperate to get in, they look for better job, just transiting or they are visiting relatives. You have the power to approve or deny their entry. The choices are really hard, every rule you break (say, to unite a couple) will cost you money and therefore indirectly your family will suffer.   Music and graphic style underline the main theme. The system is too strong and individual cannot win over the corrupt and greedy government. But it gives hope, maybe one day your little contribution will make things different…   Glory to Arstotzka!
Suprisingly addictive!

Papers Please was a highly immersive, beautifuly executed game that conveyed a dreary feeling of hopelessnes. In my review below, I break down the game into categories and analyze it thoroughly.  STORY (Spoiler-free): In 'Papers, Please,' you play as an unnamed border processing guard in the distopian country of Arstotzka, and it focuses on bureaucratic efficiency. I personally loved its story telling and thematic choice system. The entire game presents you with mind-racking choices that have to be made throughout gameplay, but the primary dilema focuses on whether or not you will care about others and their woes, or only look out for you and yours. For example, on one occasion you have the option to wave the rules to reunite a pair of lovers (one of whom has invalid paperwork) but doing so will give you a citation, and can potentially cost you crucial money to keep your family happy & healthy. Choices like these kept the tension high, and present the player with a moral conundrum. Many of the choices you make throughout the game influence the ending in a huge way, with most of the endings differing in content drastically. This highly increases the replayabilty of the game, as you'll want to experience all of the different endings. Overall, the story was well done, oozing with atmosphere, and I give it a 9/10  GAMEPLAY: The Gameplay of 'Papers, Please,' is simplistic, but effective. This is a stress management game, as the goal is to process as many people as possible in the time allotted. As a game should, the gameplay becomes steadily more complex as more layers of paperwork are added for you to check. It starts simple, only having the player check the person's passport, but gets progressively harder as you begin to start checking work permits, discrepancies in various papers, etc. Although the gameplay can become repetitive as time goes on, the new layers added on help to prevent total stagnation. It may nopt be to everyone's liking, but I found it effective and fitting. All-in-all, the gameplay gets a 7/10 from me.  ART & MUSIC STYLE: The graphics in 'Papers, Please,' are simplistic and old-school. It has an almost SNES style of graphics, and it looks pleasing to the eye. The art style conveys the bleak, distopian feeling of the game witha heavy gray color palette, and it adds a fitting atmosphere to the game, as it takes place in a circa 1980 distopian, communist, Eastern European country. Although I can see how the art may not be for everyone, so look at the scfreenshots for exampes of the graphics that are to be expected in the game. The music in the game is low, dark, but paired with a slowly increasing melody of some kind of stringed instrument. It sounds very Eastern European, almost Russian, and is paired well with the setting. When both of these are combined, it paints a picture that fits well with the story, and builds a strong atmosphere. The Art & Music gets an 8/10.  CONCLUSION: 'Papers, Please,' is a well done game, and I applaud the creator for doing such a fantastic job. Even though the gameplay is simplistic, the tension is high and the feel of the game is complementary to the setting. The experience that I had while playing this game was one of intrigue, nail-biting intensity, and mind-breaking dilemas. It's not for everyone, and I think it's best suited to a more story-driven gamer, (as the gameplay consists of little fighting and is mainy reading and the occasional button press) If you enjoy a fun experience that is story driven, unique, and dripping with atmosphere, 'Papers, Please,' is for you. 'Papers, Please,' was a gem that should not be passed up on, as most the gameplay sucks you in and addicts you, and this was one of the best games I've played in a while; so for that reason, my 'Papers, Please' overall rating is a 9/10, and I highly recommend it to people who enjoy thought-provoking games, as this is a thinking man's game.  Thanks to anyone who read this, it took a while, and I hope you enjoyed my analysis of the game.

The premise of this game seems incredibly simple, and doesn't sound like something that could be fun (unless you adore paperwork), but with actually fun gameplay, interesting scenarios that pop up from time to time, and complications that make the gameplay just challenging enough, this is a fantastic game. Don't go in expecting incredible graphics, but a couple hours of fun, oddly difficult decision making, and smart gameplay mechanics.  Also, there are 20 different endings, so it's absolutely replayable. I'm not somebody who particularly enjoys replaying games immediately after finishing them, but I found myself playing days over to see another ending, without ever feeling like it was a chore.  Overall, a brilliant game that had me hooked almost instantly. Glory to Arstotzka!

This game is very good if you want something that is heavy and thought provoking. The tale of a man working as a customs worker is one of the best experiences in recent memory. Although the graphics arent great, the art style fits the gam very well.
Great fun but im mostly being a jerk to people and just always decline them and lose alot of money
This has to be my favourite indie game I have ever played, (Who knew work could be fun).

Manning a checkpoint and stamping visas may not sound like gripping gameplay but Papers, Please somehow manages it. With your family on the brink of starvation, political trouble brewing and a cast of characters whose lives you briefly glimpse (and possibly permanently alter) the impetus to be alert and make the right choices is very strong. It's a very hard game to put down.  The graphics may seem basic but they serve the dual purposes of paring back extraneous detail to help you concentrate while simultaneously reinforcing the dreary Cold-War era atmosphere. The moral quandaries you frequently find yourself in (you can barely go a day without being offered multiple bribes for a start) don't usually have clear right or wrong answers. Indeed, whenever I lost (often) I didn't get the impression it was because of any moral failings on my part, just making choices (or mistakes) with harsh consequences.  On the subject of losing, this game has one of the best save systems I've seen. It saves at the end of each day so that you can go back and restart from any day of any playthrough you like. You can go back and fix a mistake you realised from two days ago, or try something different or whatever you like and it displays it all in a way that is easy to navigate.  I'll finish by saying that this game might not be for everyone but I have personally loved it. If the idea of a game that's a bit different, that will make you think, that can actually draw you into the life of a poor worker stuck between a rock and a hard place, this is definitely worth a try. It won't break the bank and it will definitely leave you with an impression.
great stuff!
The mood of the setting can change a whole bunch while just sitting in your booth. From wierd to hilarious, to romantic and terrifying. Great game to play whenever you have time to waste.
Depressingly similar to dayjob. 10/10. Hail Arstotzka.
A very interesting, challenging, and certainly a unique game. Just get it - you won't be disappointed - trust me!

This 'Games For Change' Award winning game didn't earn it's honor by luck or by chance.  Papers, Please is a relatively basic game set in an 8-bit style, point-and-click game. Working as a border checkpoint guard, you examine the ID and multiple pieces of paperwork that seperates the person standing before you from entry into the Glorious Mother Country. An 8-bit game has never made my anxiety drive nearly as much as this game does. For each person processed means more money earned, more money means a better chance at living in your cold and dank apartment. Terrorists, conspirators, and your higher-ups all bring about challenges and interesting decisions to make regarding your life and whether or not you spend the next day behind bars. This game is addictive and brings a surprising punch to it's rather simple gameplay with an intricate means of participation and rules to follow. It also sports a darker style of humor with the people you process in a contrasting dark setting.  9/10

What an unexpected pleasure to find a game that sounds so simple and, well, boring to be none of the above! You feel the strain of passing citizens into your country without any errors. You feel the stress to comlete as many passports as possible to make enough money to keep your family healthy and alive. When you have a son and uncle sick you make the decision which should get the medicine you can barely afford or should you pay the rent hoping they will live just another day. As the rules change and the different areas of the passports become more important you struggle to get enough correct and through the gate so you can afford necessities for your family and keep your job. I've only been playing a short time but have come to enjoy the decisions that you have to make to survive in a strict regime.   If you enjoy a game that can be played casually but requires heavy concentration then you need to try this out. I thought that everyone who recommeded this game was crazy after watching the trailers. It sounds easy but it causes emotions and attention to detail that I've never found in any other game. Try it out and I dare you not to feel what I stated above. You'll enjoy this game and you can deal with it in short doses or long intense bouts that might even make you have some compassion for those who have jobs like this.
GAME OF THE YEAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAR 2013!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Papers, Please is a interestingly fun game to play. When I first seen this game, my initial thoughts was that it would be boring but how wrong I was. You take on the role of an immigration inspector that controls the flow of people entering. Among the many people entering, looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists are rampant. Taking a look at the provided documents by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested. It takes time to look through the documents and then cross checking them with the book and instructions you have been give to decide if you will approve them passing or not. A really different and interesting take on something for a game. Brillient game to play and have fun with.

By far, this is one of the weirdest, but best indie games I have ever played so far. The games concept is something totally different than in other (indie) games. Not that it is just a game. Somehow, you even sympathize with some persons (like Jorji... God damn it Jorji, why did you abuse my faith in you? ;_;) and get some jokes.  If you consider to buy this game: DO IT NAO. Or later, when 'Papers, Please' is cheaper. But I have to tell you: It's worth every penny. Even if you pay the full price for it.

A really interesting game with a unique play mechanic - you work as an immigration inspector at the border of the ficticious nation Arstotzka. Both natives and aliens will attempt to cross the border and you must fact check their legal documents to make sure they're not entering the country illegally. Toss in a little espionage and bribery along the way in story mode, and you've got a very entertaining little game.

Most of us are blessed not to live under an oppressive communist regime.   Papers, Please   gives us the opportunity to step into the shoes of someone living there in a few hours.  As a border inspector, the gameplay consists of mundane checks on the authenticity and ever-changing validity of documents. The charm of   Papers, Please   comes from the various side events and your constant struggle between your duty as an inspector and your responsibility of providing to your family.  I find the low fidelity art and music rather apt to the narrative of the game and the booming theme is forever seared into my brain.  While not exactly a ‘fun’ game, I recommend   Papers, Please   to learn more about yourself through living a month on the Gretin border.  ( Glory to Arstotzka! )
Very expansive story!
Who knew stamping papers could be so fun? Music is also great

I really like this game. You are essentially faced with a challenge every 20-80sec, and everytime you mess up, it just makes you want to try that much harder.   It's not just the gameplay that makes it enjoyable, I really liked the addition of so many details that added to the immersion of the game. You really get a sense of what life might be like in an eastern european country during the cold war. If the game had none of the extra details added, it would be a waste of time and money, but those extras really show how a simple game can be made to be so rich and full of depth.   I also liked that although you are essentially doing the same thing over and over, there are little additions that you keep aware of the larger story and allow you to make subtle decisions that impact the ending.
I have alot of fun with this game and the twist of the story is really cool.

I won't lie, I picked it up just because the title and the idea of the game made me laugh in a twisted sort of way. This game surprises you by actually developing a pseudo-story line halfway through and is a nice bit of mental exercise along the way.

It's just so compelling. The graphics remind me of the Where in The World is Carmen Sandiago (Apple IIE) GUI. Wonderful story told in a very unique way which makes us realise of lucky we are. Great stuff.

This game is amazing, for some reason I don't quite know yet. You just start playing and suddenly you realise you've been stamping passports for three hours. Highly immersive and a unique style. It feels like you somehow play God in a world in which you are but a pawn of a totalitarian regime. One of the weirdest experiences of 2013 as far as gaming is concerned.

The idea is strange, the concept is boring, the excecution however, is amazing. You play a border agent struggling to feed your family. You must make decisions that will help or hurt them sometimes at the expense of people in line. You must also deal with moral issues, a woman and her husband try to pass the border but only one has papers, what would you do? I have not finished the story and I have not played the non-story (endless) game mode so I'm unsure of the replayability of the game. Very good game, better than most.

Do you like paperwork? Do you like oppressive eastbloc countries from the cold war era? Do you like nasty bureaucrats who make you feel unwanted in their country? Probably not. But I would still recommend you this game, because it is something quite unusual and suprisingly fun.

Get it for  under 5$  and you'll have a few hours of sadistic fun. But careful, you are not a god. Far from that. You are an immigration inspector checking people in and out of Arstotzka. The game looks like the trailer, the gameplay is straight forward, you move papers around on your desk. Your booth gets upgrades depending on how you progress.  Apart from the usual work of checking for discrepancies and validating stuff, you will meet various characters, make decision affecting the safety of your familly and eventually you will get in trouble with the Ministry.  Go to work now and hope. Hope that no terrorist will show up, hope that Big Brother isn't always watching you. Hope that you will survive an other day.   Glory to Arstotzka !

Never has bureaucratic drudgery been made so entertaining. Both wickedly funny and also challenging. A refreshing example that shows you don't need fancy graphics or multi-million-dollar budgets to turn out a good game.
bad game family dead no food too hard 10/10

A really great game. Visual and retro music but a completely innovative concept and design. Rather challenging and enjoyable. Don't let the visual and your preconception fool you because this is a really great game. Even the music that maybe strikes you at first but then you will find yourself humming it and wanting to hear the real deal over and over, specially the 'victory theme'.  There are so many things that can happen in the game that you will never get bored, even though your 'work' seems a lot like this. There are so many events that nets you over 20 possible endings with good and bad ones. Even the npc's gets your attention and empathy. Although it may seem the contrary you all the time need to make decisions that will affect yours future and the future of the people involved, and sometimes even the nation.  So to sum it up: a funny, enjoyable and creative game that will hook you.  Glory to Arstotzka!
Great game, but sadly realistic.

Papers, Please is a stunning achievement in game design. The gameplay is minimal, but the choices you make are frequently difficult and meaningful. A steal at the $8 I paid for it, and even at its full price of $10 is worth the price of admission.   » 10/10 «
I listened through the menu music 3 times before actually starting the game, it was awesome

One of the best games I've played. So simple yet so fun.
This game is pretty fun. Theres a bunch of different ways you can play and different endings. I hope they can add more stuff to this game.
Very addictive!

i just love this game , i love the different ending in it .
saw pixel ♥♥♥♥♥ for the first time. 10/10
This game is simple, yet incredibly enjoyable. I can promise that you'll find yourself caught up in the world of Arstotzka.

This game is unique, it's thoughtful, and it is incredibly well executed. In most games your choices generally come down to the black and white, but Papers, Please revels in the grey area of life, death, and duty. Although the concept may seem a little off at first glance, it provides a very interesting and complex backdrop for gameplay that is immersive and unique. This is probably the best $10 you can spend on an indie game right now.
This is surprisingly beautiful for being pixelated. The different endings were and are awesome. I'll always cherish the moment when that one man brought in a passport he had made with crayons. 9.5/10

This is an amazing example of story based gameplay. It's probably the best story telling game there has ever been. Not to mention that the mechanics can be somewhat absorbing.  I reccomend it to any other teary eyed 'Games are art' afficianados out there.

A truly unique game that everyone should experience. I can't remember another game achieving so much with so little. If ever there was a sign that the medium of video games is maturing, this is it - it's meaningful, poignant, confronting, challenging, stressful and charming.  While I was expecting the monotony of immigration paperwork verification, I was not expecting such a strong and intricate storyline to unfold.

So... you're working as a border control agent? All you do is check their documents to make sure they're legit? Oh, and if they're not you can deny or detain them? How exciting! That sounds like work, not a game.   I know it does, but it freaking works! Such a boring and pedestrian sounding concept that shouldn't be fun, but it is. For the most part, each day adds new 'things' you need to be on the look out for. As you get further into the game, entrants take longer to process just from the sheer number of documentation you need to check. But you better check it fast cause you're on the clock and your family needs to eat.  Your morals will be tested and you will get stressed out. And you will make mistakes. And they will be your fault. But you will still have a blast playing the game. Do yourself a favor and get this game.
♥♥♥♥ing brilliant game.
A truly great indie game. Great replayability! Wish the story mode had been longer, though.

Get out of my country Kolechian, terrorist scum. Your kind is the disgrace of this planet. I'd rather allow in dog before I allow your kind here. Arstorzka is too brilliant for your eyes.  Wow, a game that makes you racist against people that don't even exist and feel national pride for for fakeistan. But seriously, like half of the Kolechians are terrorists.

How much fun can it be to check people's passports? Well, it depends on you, but I like challenges that make me look for detail, work under pressure, etc. Maybe because I'm a software engineer. But in any case, depending on the type of challenge one finds 'fun' one will like this game a lot or hate it.  In this game you man a checkpoint, checking people's passports and papers to see if they should be allowed through. You also get a new set of directives each round from your fine bosses in the government: work papers required this time, no citizens from a particular country allowed, etc. And since it's a parody of an Eastern-Bloc country under iron fist rule, you are offered bribes and such - which you can take or not, as you see fit. You are also time-constrained because you're paid per-checkpoint person, and if you don't move fast enough you don't have enough money to feed your family, and that's one way to lose the game - your family starves or dies of illness because you couldn't buy medicine.  What makes a game fun is if one finds doing the same thing over and over fun: be it shooting monsters, hack/slash/loot, etc. So if you find this kind of visual challenge fun, you will love the game. If you don't, you will hate it because that's all this game is - checking passports, papers, keeping up with the politbureau dictates, etc.  One of the best off-the-beaten-path games I've played in a long time.
Basic puzzle game on the surface with a much deeper story intertwined. Beautiful job.

I have to give props where props are due... this game is quirky and weird. However, it's fun, interesting and the only TSA simulator on the market right now. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes indie games and interesting ideas.

This is a Bureaucracy Sim, which can be fun if you're entertained by scanning documents and rulebooks for discrepencies. It's slightly deeper than that, but not by much.  The conversations between you and the people coming to your booth are entertaining, as are the reactions when you decide to detain them. :)  The biggest challenge, is trying to keep your family alive on such a small wage. Bribes? We has them... but be careful that your neighbors don't turn you in for doing well. :)

A fantastic way to test your morals as you decide whether you want to save money for your famliy or help out strangers in need at your job of a customs officer. I cannot find anything wrong with this game. It is incredible.
Amazingly good fun. It gave me a real insight in to my own psyche as well as making me question my own morals. Fantastic work.

Fantastic game! Very simple premise but as it goes on and you get more things to do, it becomes easier to overlook small things and tests your observation very well. The story is very intriguing and deep and i look forward to delving deeper into Arstotzka and finding out what's going on in the country! Glory to Arstotzka!

The gameplay of this game starts out so ridiculously simple, but then it starts getting mind-numbingly annoying/complex. but it's so rewarding. So if you like calling people out on their b*llsh**t... maybe this is the game for you. But that's not all you get to do. You get to shoot b*llsh*tters with guns, disarm bombs, poison b*st*rds and earn cash for your family.  Also, you lived in a pretty messed up country... but don't worry. Change is coming soon. BE PART OF THAT CHANGE. GET PAPERS, PLEASE.  (Steam, y u no let me say B U L L S H IT ?)

Papers, Please is a GEM.  Simple Game, Easy to Play, Hard to Master, Highly Addictive. Very Old School type of computer game. A port of this on a phone would be amazing, I am VERY happy I bought this game.

Oh wow, this game.   I personally didn't hear about this until late last night. After watching some gameplay of this, I bought it first thing this morning, and spent the first 4 hours of my day playing it.  I wouldn't say this game is definitely a 'must buy', more than it's a 'must play'. I normally don't write reviews on games, but I ABSOLUTELY had to with this.  This game is absolutely worth the money, and the risk/reward for the different scenarios is just perfect. It almost has a little 'creepy' element to the game as well.  The only thing that I have a compiaint about is the upgrades for the booth. First upgrade is a hot-key for identifying discrepancies, and the 4th upgrade is 'double-click' to identify discrepancies. I don't understand the point of that, and personally, I think it's not needed.  If you're feeling unsure, just try the demo out. It has, I believe, the first 8 days in the game.  9/10

Be a border guard for Artozka! Greatest country on Earth! Papers, Please is a very fun game. Every few in game days you have to check more things then the last day, but the time for each day is increased. During the game, you face all kinds of stories. Such as a woman who's been waiting to see her son for years and her info is wrong, or a woman who would be killed if she goes back to her home. Human trafficers, killers and terrorists are all encounted in this game. Even a secret organization. This game has 20 endings. Along with earning money, you need to pay for rent heat, food and sometimes meds daily. You can even buy booth upgrades such as pressing spacebar for detecting info on documents, tab for the stamps and rule book shortcuts. When ever you mess up in this game you cant be mad at the game, cuz its your own damn fault you messed up. The first and second citations per day dont cost you any credits, but the rest cost 5 credits. 8.75/10
I would suck at being a border bureaucrat. Kinda fun pretending to be one though. I'm a softy, I keep losing because I let people through.
I would have to say this is one of the best indie games i've played to date. You can become so easily attached to games with such little features, Shout out to Jorji (A character in the game)
with 20 diffrent endings and 30 days to play through and a endless mode and made by one person this is addictive and enjoyable and worth every penny you spend on it

I was recomended this game by a friend a few months back, and seeing that it was on offer i dicided to give it a go. I would gladly of paid full price for it. the game is so much fun. Its a mix of spot the diffrence and a point and click game. Me and my girlfriend play it together ( she is much better than me ).

I never thought I would put 29 hours onto this game. Well worth it for the 100%. Lucas Pope deserves those tons of awards his game got recently. Don't let the graphics hold you back from trying this game, it's brilliant.
It is incredible what an awesome game can be made within 34 MB of space! If it would be invented in 1992, the developers would made their first billion by now! Absolutelly loved it!!! :)
I love this game!!! It's hard to describe. Something about checking documents, and denying people on details that most would overlook... just clicks. Buy it, you won't regret.   Glory to Arztotzka!!
All I can say is: More, Please
