I honestly don't know how to describe this game.. The whole point of the game is to deny or accept immagrants into a fictional communisty country during the 1980s.. ((Think Russia with heavy border control)). It sounds stupid and look stupid.. Though playing 30 minutes in and you just can't stop. Something about this game and the story it presents will keep you hooked until the final day.

Wasn't expecting to love this half as much as I did. Strangely compelling gameplay led to me completing the whole story (well 2 of the 18 endings) in around 5 hours and one sitting. There's a very human aspect to the game, challenging you to protect both your morales and your 'family' in a non-ideal setting. Gameplay is surprisngly hectic and you can feel a real jump in your efficiency as the game goes on.  Overall a thoroughly good play and well worth the price of entry. I doubt you'll find anything of a similar ilk anytime soon

It's difficult to give this game a proper review without spoiling any of it.   The story begins with you, a border inspector, in a fictional Eastern-bloc country circa 1982. The story is emergent, changing based on your interactions with various people that show up on certain days. Sometimes you must make moral choices and pay the consequences.  It's worth the $5. Go for it.
Excellent. Simple design, deep interesting story and, a interesting take on 'game.'
Cruel heartbreaking adventure game. Patience is necessary: a story told in the deliberate monotony of an unfair job. Do the first two sentence grab you; if so you should avoid or buy immediately.

One of the Best I've played this year, yet so small and simple...  If i had to nitpick I'd say story mode could last a little longer... I'm still missing a bunch of tokens and endings, though. haven't played endless mode yet, either.

GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!  While thematically depressing, Papers, Please is a brilliant little game where you decide who pass the border into your nation's territory.  You need to look for descrepancies and comply with the rulebook that can change from a day to day basis.  Simple in theory, brilliant in execution.
Entertaining and really makes you pay attention. Definitely has replay value.

If a 'Dystopian Document Thriller' sounds like it might be enjoyable to you, it will be. As Yahtzee said, 'this game makes paperwork fun.' You will be engaged not only by the intricate story, but by the tough daily decisions you have to make (which give this game a complex morality system), and even the mundane task of checking documents as quickly as possible for any sort of discrepancy.
The most fun I've ever had hating my job. 10/10
A good game, very deep, quite challenging and you will make mistakes. really feels like a job, brilliant game design.  Glory to the New Arizstoka.  COMPLETIONIST'S NOTE: Do everything
What a great title with an incredible, genuine atmosphere. Anyone wishing to play a slightly grimmer game with an original playstyle, this is for you!
A deceptively complex, utterly absorbing game about paperwork. I recommend everyone who values well-crafted, innovative indie games buy this now. Glory to Arstotzka!
Ridiculous gameplay and hilarious interactions with the characters you come across. Highly recommended for casual gaming and completion-ists who can try to get every ending.
Soviet boarderstation simulator 2014... I LOVE IT! so strangely addictive and intriguing...
Roleplaying elements and sardonic humour made into a game. What's not to love?

Papers, Please is possibly the most fun you can have in the most mundane setting.  It's 1982, and after the six-year war between Arstotzka and Kolechia comes to an end, the Grestin border checkpoint opens, reuniting families and allowing the safe passage of all sorts of characters. As the checkpoint inspector, it is your duty to approve or deny people based on the documents they have and the details therein.  Not only does Papers, Please immerse you in the fascinating world of excessive bureaucracy, but it forces you to make moral choices throughout, determining the fate of travellers and immigrants, aiding or hindering subversive elements, all while ensuring the survival of you and your family.  Such is life in  Glorious Arstotzka
Such a unique game, I had fun all the way through, and I still need to go back and try for more alternate endings. Definitely pick this one up, it's well worth the price.
So far this game makes me sad. I think I'm not a good border patrol dude. I'd suggest watching a 'Let's Play' or something. I might do that.

Have you ever dreamed of working a customs job at the airport? Well this is just like that! Only it's cold, communist, and heartbreaking! Make horrible decisions like, should I let this person through in order to get more money for my sick and dying family or should I detain them for being a terrorist who wants to blow up guards in order to make a statement about the corruption of the powers that be? Great fun for the whole family. A/5.
Alright... this game makes paperwork way too fun. I just lost an hour. Buy it while it's cheap.

This game has a truely original concept. It had a unique gameplay experience that somehow kept me on the edge of my seat as I looked at every detail. I felt an intense satisfaction as I clicked to stamp each and every valid or invalid document. A must play game

This game looks surprisingly simple, but is surprisingly difficult as well. What seems to be just stapming papers, quickly tirns into a web of espionage, terrorism and smuggling. A very good game, which will keep you busy for longer than a lot of the so-called 'AAA' titles out there. Must buy.

Curiously adicting game. Fun story and good gameplay. You'll see yourself replaying levels to try and catch everyone.  Would highly recommond purchasing this game if your into indies and its on sale :)  9/10 :)

This game is certainly... different. I was intrigued by the premise: running a border crossing in an eastern-dystopic styled country, however in the end the game was just so depressing and repititive that I lost interest. It definitely is unique, and may be worth it on sale, especially if attention to detail is your thang.  Be ready to deal with your family starving to death because you let the dying old man into your country.

Brilliant game with unique idea. You really can see how ♥♥♥♥ is the job of a customs officer. Buy if you want to spend some hours checking random peoples papers while there is a interesting story developing behind the scenes as you work your days.

It's basically one of those 'spot the difference' pictures with logic thrown in and much, much more complicated rules. Despite how boring it may sound, it's actually strangely compelling. It's hard to acurately describe it. If you're at all interested, try the demo at  http://dukope.com/  .  Glory to Arstotzka.

Brutal in it's simplicity, yet engaging. You have a very specific job to do, and not much time in which to do it, and time is a precious comodity. You also have to make some tough moral choices. Kill some guys wife or freeze your family, your choice. Unique, challenging, and fresh.

First I was a little confused, but it keeps you entertained and things can change fast, sometimes you get requests for something, either you do it and get in trouble or you don't and stay happy....I love it!

This game may not seem exciting as a regular action game or FPS or whatever you are into, but once you start playing it and get addicted to the characters that you often see and denying people you can't stop. Papers, Please is your basic puzzle game. You are a inspector checking passports that let people through Arzentotka(?). You have this job to support your family of Uncle, Son, and Wife. Along the way, you can make deals with people who are passing through the border, get bribes for more money, help organizations, detain (jail) people, shoot tresspasers (bonus money if you hit them), and more. I would highly recommend this game for their are over 40 endings and if you lose once it doesn't make you start all over. It's pretty great for passing time aND HAVE YOUR HEART RIPPED OUT OF YOUR FLESH
Glorious Supreme Leader Liger gives this masterpiece a soviet/10
One of the best games of 2013 (and not only for me...)!

If you hate this game, then you also hate America. Your job in this game, is to decide who is allowed to move freely in your country. Half the fun of this game is that you get the privilege of being a cold callous bureaucrat, a corrupt official with his finger in every illicit pie. For a change, you get to be the one giving everyone the business and not the one looking down the business end of such and such thing!   You can also be kind and benevolent and let every person through who has a sob story. Just know, that no matter how you choose to play this game, you (your character, not 'you' yourself) are the most miserable scum of the earth and you're damn lucky to have a job!     I will not lie, there are a few bad things about this game. You need to remember/learn a set of arbitrary rules that are subject to change at the drop of a hat. You're pinned to a small desk where important things are sometimes hidden below unimportant things. You might have to read the newspaper! You might have to see something that you cannot unsee. Anything helpful to you is in a book that you might have to read more than once. All of these qualities make this game confusing but at the same time real. If any of this sounds like too much work, I feel sorry for you. Unless you're some kind of movie star, you should already be used to this sh*t by now.   If I haven't listed everything awesome about this game, it's because I only meant to relate half of what's so good about it; the other half you must discover for yourself. Also, it's $9.99! I could've eaten ten double cheeseburgers for that price, but instead I chose not to feel like sh*t. Buy this game. Click the button that says 'ADD TO CART.'
A game in game,

Wow. This game is awesome. It really truely makes you feel for a line of people trying to enter your country. I was surprised at the decisions I had to make, in the end, to ensure my families survival. I had five different endings, and only when they were safe, was I satisfied. With that said, the other endings are all interesting for different reasons, and I can see playing this for at least 20 hours total. Very original, and very interesting. Highly recommend.
What a great value; $10 for a game whose beauty lies in between the lines. It gleefully embraces the mundane and makes it fun and addictive. Best indie I've played this year.

A really great game. The gameplay is used to really great effect here, with moral choices occuring as a natural, organic element of the design, rather than isolated, black and white choices you might find in, say, Mass Effect. Does a really great job of maintaining the stressful, high-pressure feeling one would have in that situation. The art style is effective and it is well polished, with plenty of charm and character, and the right length to feel substantial, but not padded or dragged out.  Overall, a really polished, well thought-out and refined game, with great moral choice mechanics. Highly recommended.

I can now take 'Work at a border check point' off my bucket list.  Papers, Please is a much better option. More amusing than the real thing and going back to work each day is less depressing. For reasons I cannot put a finger on, it was difficult to stop playing once you start going.  Despite it's old school graphics, the game itself wouldn't feel much different if it was digitally remastered.

The game, although mundane, makes you want to play longer. This game is basically evil; it forces you to make decisions based on how much money it will get for you. Because you have a family that is cold, sick, and hungry and you need that money, so when a wife wants to see her husband but has an invalid expiry date on her passport, you deny her, just so you can feed your family. The game is quite simple at first, but after a while the rules and paperwork increasing, it becomes overwhelming and highly complex. It becomes even more complex as outside parties begin to bribe you. The main game mechanic is its biggest let down, for most people, it is mundane, checking passports and paperwork for any discrepancies can, and does, get frustrating and boring, however this boredom is key to understanding the game. The people who enter your window, to find a job, etc. just become more paper work, you no longer care for the humans trying to enter. You will find yourself abusing your power just to look after your family; it is a great insight into the dehumanisation of outsiders by a society. There are also hidden achievements which might make some players think again, you have no clue when these achievements happen, they just do, and it is rewarding, even if you lose some money. The game has great pacing, starting easy and ending complex and hard leaving the player in a state of emotional wreck. There is 20 ending which means more replay ability, but some events seem to be scripted and take away the enjoyment, the highs and lows repeating isn’t good. One area the maker (yes, made by one guy) missed was the lack of images for the family, which would have added even more emotion.  9/10- Although mundane it is an emotional tug-of-war that will make you question your morals and help you too understand the people in that position.

This game is really really not fun. Wait, hear me out first. It's grinding and starts to wear on you. You make money for each person you process, but as the game progresses each processing takes longer and longer as the paperwork piles up. You have to choose between heat and food for your family. At times you want to do the right thing, but can't without risking your job or a penalty.  It's a long soulless grind that wears you down as a person.  Which is exactly what it is supposed to do. Border checkpoint had to be one of the worst jobs of the Cold War. You are faceless, but not anonymous, you are part of the machine, but not benifitting from it.  This game is well worth the money, if nothing else to make you feel better about your life.
This game is the Desert Bus of immigration. Tedious, mind-numbing, and quite brilliantly executed.

GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA  One of the few newish indie games out there I feel actually uses its primitive aesthetics to its advantage instead of it merely being there because it's LOL SO RETRO AND EPIK. The Commodore 64-esque visuals and sounds pair up great with the bleak 80s Soviet setting. Despite the limited amount of interaction you have as the protagonist there's a surprising variety of shallow but nonetheless charming characterization and plotlines that provide a decent amount of replay value. Overpriced as-is but worth checking out during a seasonal sale.
One of the best games I have played this year. The tone is brilliant and it incorperates moral choices better than any other game I have played.
This is the best oppression simulator of all time.

Honestly, when I try to descibe Papers, Please to my friends, it sounds like the most boring thing ever. And yet it's fun! More fun than a paper-pushing sim should be. It's challenging, and it includes one of the most realistic moral choice systems in any game. It's not a question of good or evil; it's a question of following the rules. Do you follow the rules and hurt some stranger's life, or do you break the rules for them and hurt your own life? These are the questions this game has you make over and over again. It's great, and you should totally buy it.

a strange game to say the least, simple in concept, but a very difficult game to master. it also plays with your emotions and moral stances as you come across people in need of your help to live, but by helping them you put your own family at risk. making hard decisions like that while being on a timer to get through as many as possible makes for one hell of a frantic game

It is absolutely unbelivable, that such a simple game can be such deep and surprising.   The basic idea is you beeing immigration inspector. Boring and too easy? After first day at work, I came back home with about 30 Arzotzkan dollars earned - not enough to pay rent, heat and food for my family of 5. Every day you work harder and harder, but the procedure changes so often, making it almost impossible to earn enough money. And here the bribes come from smugglers and immoral guards. Ill and poor people want to enter your country for treatment or work every day. Not mentioning the Ressistance...   One simply cannot understand how BIG is this game, before playing it.

Such a simple game and yet very addictive. Do your job or let people through. Help stop or cause crimes. Help reunite families or destroy them at the click of a button. I did not think I'd enjoy this game as much as I do now.
Great Game its alot of fun if you are into this type of gameplay. I would give it a 8/10.

Even the smallest of games can bring you the best experiences, and this little gem makes damn sure you never forget it. Working as a checkpoint guard in the Berlin-esque split city of Grestin, you have to decide who is able to enter the recently opened communist country of Arstotzka and who is denied or even detained. And some of these people stick around in your head for quite a while thanks to their personalities and how you interact with them. You're always facing moral choices with how you handle certain situations, like refugees fleeing for their lives to Arstotzka without the proper documents, victims escaping others in the checkpoint's line who must be dealt with later that day, and others simply trying to save their loved ones. But you must always remember... are you willing to help them at the cost of your own family's wellbeing? Or will you strive to be the best checkpoint inspector to make sure your family is happy and healthy, while giving those seeking help without documents the cold shoulder?  The main story isn't terribly long, but you can unlock a few modes after you finish to keep the game going, and there are up to 20 endings to explore for the main story as well, so you'll have plenty of time to keep the Grestin checkpoint going smoothly. For ten American dollars, you can't go wrong.

Major thumbs up for originality and enjoyment!

is the beast gaem ever

GOTY 2013, Hands Down  Papers Please is advertised as an Adventure title but I feel that it leans more towards Border Patrol Simulator. Although I imagine that it would have been easier to market the game as an Adventure title, but I digress.  The premise is simple enough, you are a border patrol officer working in a fictional Dystopian country whose main driving point is to simply get enough money to keep your family alive. Very straightforward, but the game shines by doing something that is rarely seen in video games; tackling ethical issues such as whether or not to let a woman in to reunite with a long lost relative or letting a man take revenge on the man who killed his child. Money issues are a part of the gameplay too, if you don't have enough money then you won't be able to pay for food or warmth possibly resulting in a family members death. Far more successful than something such as Bioshock Infinite I would say, being the complexity in that game just involved shooting everyone but the fate of people in this game are literally in your hands and can be turned away at the press of a stamp.  As the game goes on, laws become more strict and more paperwork is introduced making the game a chore as it goes on, but yet the game still manages to immerse you in the universe created and never seems to become dulldue to memorable moments where you have to defuse a bomb, or the memorable characters such as the comical drug dealer who attempts to enter the country with a crayon passport.  The art design makes the game instantly recognisable as opposed to 'SUPAH HYPA REALISM 3D OMG' instead choosing personalised sprite work. The game ultimately has a true identity of it's own.  If you let someone in or deny someone you weren't supposed to then the game will issue you with a penalty warning but you don't lose money until the third strike, this is a great mechanic because not only does it allow you to see where you went wrong with that person but it also prompts you to take bribes and you can get rewarded for bending the rules for your favour.  Overall Papers Please is not only the best game of 2013 but also easily one of my favourite games of all time.  FINAL VERDICT: MUST PLAY! GLORY TO ARSTOTSKA!

One of the more fairly interesting games that I've played. I didn't honestly know what to expect from this but it is actually one of the more morally ambigious games I've played in recent memory (aside from The Last of Us and Fallout New Vegas), you are tasked with being an immigration officer in a fictional communist country in the 80's. It's surprisingly tense with the fact that while you have to let certain people through and send certain people the other way, choices are presented to you from time to time, such as if you should let a certain person through even if they don't have the right paperwork. Do you let a girl's family through but not the girl due to her having the wrong papers? Can you make that choice and live with the consequences? Can you afford to do this as if you get to many citations against you then your pay can be docked which you surely need to support your family who suck up all of your money at the end of the day. It really makes you question your own morality and what you would do in that situation. Sometimes when you feel like you have made the right choice something ends up happening that you didn't expect. They could have been completly lying to you the entire time but you won't know until the end. With multiple endings and an endless mode available this is definitely a must buy if everything I have just talked about interests you. I definitely give it a big recommendation and I think you should totally buy this.

It's fun though when given morally conflicting situations that require you to make choices that can ultimately affect you, the people that live with you and the country you are trying to protect. Do you take bribes? Do you conspire against your country? If given the amount of discretion you have at permitting and denying citizens entry into your country, do you take the high road and risk yourself or take the low road and risk yourself? Once you break it down into the clever components the developers painstakingly put into this game, you realize why you can't just simply break away from it. Definitely worth the buy.

Papers, please is superb. The gameplay is set up at a perfect pace...introduced slowly and varied just enough that it becomes neither frustrating nor dull. The length of the game is just right, and the varied subplots add a surprising amount of interest to the dull life of a border inspector. It's better than it sounds. An excellent example of effective storytelling through gameplay, and on excelling by focusing on one aspect of a game and doing it very well. It's a pleasure to play a game that makes paperwork engaging...especially when there are so many games that somehow manage to make shooting things to bits yawn-inducing.
Was highly enjoyable and probably my favorite Indie Game of 2013. It's a very simplistic game that is able to convey so much with very little mechanics and choice involved.

In soviet Arstotzka, the game plays you!  Explaining the premise of this game really doesn't make you want to buy it: Who would really think that playing a game where you work at a Soviet nation's border station would be challenging, addictive as well as humorous and immersive? Add the fact that this game has the graphics of an early 90's game and it's surprising that anyone has even bought this game. It really is something I've never seen before, even the genre is somewhat hard to describe: It's a 'real time puzzle' game combined with roleplaying elements.  The core gameplay consists of checking people's passports and ID's and other various documents before you make the decision of giving entry or turning people away. It is really challenging and fun. And by challenging I mean 'makes you want to rip your hair out if you haven't lost it from the stress already', at least with the 'no loading allowed' playstyle that I employ.   You have to process people as fast as you can, but making mistakes will also cost you, so you have to balance the speed and the precision. After every day of work, you get to spend your earned money by feeding your family, paying the rent and heating bill, and if things are going well, you can buy upgrades for your toll booth. But there's never enough money for everything after the beginning, unless you're some kind of border guard savant.  It starts off easy: Check if the customer has a passport, if it has expired, if it has been granted in an authorized town and if the person is identifiable from the picture. Foreigners you must turn back. Next day, foreigners are allowed. The next day foreigners and natives both have to have a different kind of extra document to pass and you have to cross-check the information with the passport as well as if the information checks out on it's own. Before you know it, your desk is cluttered with all sorts of papers and you have to remember three faces of criminals that you can't let pass and a couple of names who you have to pass, while shooting people who try to do terrorist bombings at the border.  You find yourself screaming at the screen: 'What?! No way was that entry pass a forgery, you've got to be kidding me! Where the hell is that document? Who was I supposed to let pass and why?!' Things will get desperate soon enough, and maybe you'll let a missing document slide if the customer has some 'incentive' to let him/her pass. Oh, stop being so high and mighty, my son was very sick and I needed the money!  The roleplaying is intriguing as well. There are some really desperate people at the border trying to get you to bend the rules and you will be faced with the decision of either doing your job, or the right thing. Dereliction of your duties will first result in notices from your supervisors and then you will get fined, but you find yourself thinking: 'She'll get murdered if I decline her Visa, and it's only a 5$ fine if I don't, so maybe I'll do it just this once.' You can also team up with different political factions, which have real consequences. There are 20 different endings so the choices matter.  Papers, Please is proof that an excellent game doesn't need a marketable premise or top-notch graphics. On the contrary, it might allow the freedom of focusing on the gameplay aspects that truly make a game great. I know I haven't played this much yet, so this praise is to be taken with a grain of salt, but this might be one of the best games of 2013.
WARNING!!! Very addictive game ... and I hate doing paperwork!!!
you pay money to work how stupid is that
Surprisingly absorbing. Intriguing story arcs and challenging decision-making make this game highly entertaining.

Before I bought 'Papers, Please', a friend of mine told me that he'd heard it described as 'the most Soviet game I've ever seen'. It's a fitting description - as you attempt to eke out a living handling passports in the Grestin border checkpoint, it is clear that you are a small cog in a deeply dysfunctional machine. The game grows ever more challenging as you are presented with a proliferation of new rules and regulations, and still more so as you face the challenge of dealing with crooks, smugglers, revolutionaries, and desperate folk of all descriptions, of deciding who to allow through, who to reject, and who to arrest, all with the knowledge that your livelihood and that of your dependents relies on your ability to spot the tiniest of discrepancies in the ten or twenty seconds you can afford to spend examining this particular downtrodden would-be immigrant's documents.  'Papers, Please' breathes a tremendous amount of story and life into the world through the simple mechanism of passports and entry passes. On one day, a woman arrives joyous about the opening of the border, hoping to see her son for the first time in six years. On another, a man tells you about his days working as an immigration officer in another country, remembering how they rejected the majority of those trying to enter there. Still later, a woman from the town you grew up in arrives at your window, remarks as you study her papers what a brat you were growing up, and promises, as she leaves, that she will tell your old neighbors that you are alive and well. And these are characters you never meet again - those like Jorji, Calensk, and Sergiu are a great deal more than that, even as limited as your decisions are.  'Papers, Please' is hard, but more than worth your time.
Truely a Unique indie game. perfect art and a truely sad ending. Great comedy and APPROVE MY VISA

I bought the game during this year's Christmas Sales primarily out of boredom. The game has quite surprised me - in a positive way. Countless things have changed since the free, public alpha version and many were added as well. I just finished the story campaign and I must say the ending is quite original. I can't wait for tomorrow to play it once again. Papers, Please! is definitely worth the money.

Way more addicting than you would think by looking at it. You basically play as a Border check inspector in a communist country in 1982. Gameplay is just looking at people's papers and giving them the red stamp or the green stamp. But so many little stories and side plots come up and keep the game interesting. There are also more and more rules added on every in-game day so it gets harder to pick the right stamp. There's like 20 different endings too, so replay value is pretty good. Moral choice aspects are here and they are organic. The game makes it really hard to be a good person. Yeah you might be easy on a person and let them through because they'll die in their country otherwise, but then you'll get cited and oops now you can't afford food for your family that day. Great game for such a simple concept.

Forget heat. There's rarely enough money for heat.  Papers Please manages to tell stories only through moments desperately rushed as you try to just move people through a line. You might tell yourself, oh I don't care, I'm only focused on the passport itself, but it gets to you anyways.  Absolutely brilliant and unique. Play it.

Jorji Costava 4 lyfe.  In all seriousness I have to say this is quite possibly one of the most mentally stimulating games I've ever played. The amount of multitasking required to stay on top and not end up in debt to Arstotzka is staggering and this may even be educational because of it. As I play through I'd like to compile information into a guide for others so that they can enjoy the story on their own time and serve the country efficiently.  Unfortunately for my friend this doesn't work on Mac. He's very upset about this so adaptation would be much appreciated if possible. Aside from that it's a definite recommendation.  As a Windows 8.1 user I'd also like to add that this game is 100% playable in stand or tablet mode. It can be played entirely with touch screen, most likely not intended but a definite plus for those of us with those capabilities who want to lie back and not deal with mouse or keyboard. To me it actually speeds the process using that instead of sticking to the regular point-and-click method. Still enjoyable in laptop mode as well. Definitely not good in that awkward upside-down V mode, though. I have yet to find a game that's playable in that position. I'll get back to Steam when I find one. (Sorry this turned into a personal narrative.)

Papers, Please gets the stamp of approval.  This game straddles somewhere between a Spot-the-Difference and a Puzzler, and despite the purposefully simplistic pixelated graphics, it portrays a grim and desolate world, while also offering the faintest glimmer of hope.  You work as an Immigration Official (probably the first game ever that tries this), just trying to do your job on the border between Kolechia and Arstotzka, amidst the threat of smugglers, terrorists, and basically anyone the Arstotzka officials deem unworthy at the time.  Initially, you'll be tasked with just checking out if the immigrants have the correct papers, and the details within them check out, and so on. The amount of things to check up on steadily increase by the day, which adds to the stress of time management. Do you quickly rush through stamping APPROVED or DENIED to most people without a cursory glance? Or do you fret over every detail, ensuring that you're doing the right thing and letting no scum in?  The problem with the latter, is that you have a family to care for back home, which you'll manage at the end of each day. Food, heating, medicine; this all requires money, which you'll only get from admitting worthy people into the country. This is difficult to prioritise, especially if you make it later into the game when less genuine people are admitted.  Thankfully, there is some great humour sprinkled in to offset the cruel conditions, mostly from the lovable old man Jorji Costava... damn you, you old sneaky rascal.  Overall, there is some replayability, due to the harsh set-up which may take an attempt or two to get the hang of. Also there are many different endings that are possible, depending on the choices you make.  Glory to Arstotzka.
real life job - look after your family - get coerced by rebel groups - help drug dealers - deny everyone entry XD Glory to Arstotzka!
it looks looks so simple but yet it's so complex and difficult but yet is fun and addicting good game 8/10

If you can get this on sale, I would highly reccomend it. I'm sure plenty find it worth the full price- and I could certainly see that. Either way, great game!

A woman came to booth. Her husband had been in front of her. He had joked around. Asked me to be nice to her. His papers were in order. Hers were not. I asked why. She pleaded for mercy. Would be killed in her old country. Tears were in her eyes. Appeal to emotion. I once again asked why. She looked at me confused. I asked why she was wasting my time. Sent her back to Antegria. She cursed my name. Called next person.  His papers were in order. Family ate well that night. Such is life in Arstotzka for Inspector.
Interesting, fun, and challenging! As you progress through the days, you are assigned to new tasks as a checkpoint officer and have to keep your family alive. I recommend it for sure.

Papers, Please  is a fast-paced game that will put your brain to work. You become your own worst nightmare as you are immediately informed of your failures. What starts out as a simple click of a button soon becomes in-depth research as you fight against the clock to make enough money to keep your family alive. Nobody wins in this dark, contemplative game where your only enemy is yourself,   and the dirty Kolechian terrorists.    Glory to Arstotzka!

Great game, before you know it you have spent hours playing border officer and seeing how many endings you can accomplish!! You can be that to!! and Before you know it... its 6am and time to get to your actual work!

This game is a good simulator of a border checkpoint worker. It is no fun to work at a border checkpoint. Is hard work.

This game was fantastic.  You wouldn't really expect visually inspecting the customs papers of artistically low-res nobodies to be so engaging, but Papers, Please makes you stop and think, feel, emphasize, with the people passing through a fictional customs checkpoint in a fictional totalitarian state almost as casually as it has you also put them through full body scans to verify sex or check for drugs. It's truly a unique experience.   I haven't yet played through to every end yet-- a lot of the decisions you make on your 30 day journey have a big impacts you can't fully see. It's a beautiful, emotionally involved game, but even transcending that is the pure joy of being an efficient cog in the Arstotskan bureaucracy. The joy of this game is basically inexplicable, I can only ask that you give it a shot.   And hell, it's on holiday sale!!
It's pre-approved!!!
One of the best games I've played all year.

One of the funnest games i have ever played. Simply amazing. This game can bring out anyone's bad side. Your hunger for power will emerge and you will deny access to innocent people and grant other's access for a little money on the side.

One of the year's best, and a must play.

Strangely appealing, Papers, Please brings out the fun in the mundane task of inspecting folks before allowing them into the country. A definite must play for those who like a little indie on the side.

Papers, Please is a really fun game. I highly recommend it. It has many interesting storylines that lead to numerous fantastic endings. The achievements are mysterious and enjoyable to get, and you can even kill people in this game! It's fast paced and just, again, really fun.  So yeah. buy it :D

I cannot tell you the number of times I've been given weird looks while playing this.  That's simply because it's not a game that's designed with everyone's interest. But, on another note, let's actually talk about the game.  Papers, Please is a game about a border station admittance worker in a Eastern German-esque country known as Arstotzka. You are responsible for allowing or denying entrance into your country. Now, as a citizen in a communist state, you are subject to being fired and imprisoned at any time. With that in mind, you have to make decisions wisely. Full of heart-churning decisions that test every part of your mind, as to what is good and what is wrong.  Gameplay.  8/10 at best. While slow at times, there are moments where a person will get your humor side flowing out of your mouth. Others are causing you emotional pain cuz their passports expired and their spouse made it through but they legally can't.  AI  8/10. Somewhat predictable, except for the occasional terrorist attack. Story 9/10. Amazing. Intrique, excitement, and also action, you'll love it. Overall score: 25/30, or 5/6 for those scoring at home. Buy it, it's worth the $10
Attention to detail and the ability to follow orders. If you are lacking these things play this game. It should kick you into shape. Enjoyable game. But kinda hard to play too long after you beat it
Who knew that work could be interesting, and that over 50% of all the people entering a country are totally sketchy? Great game, somehow.
It's realy addictive and fun.

If you read a review that doesn't recommend this game, the reviewer was probably just upset that Papers Please wasn't CoD. Do not listen to these people.    This is a game for people who appreciate art. Glory to Arstotzka.

Before I played this game I never thought that doing paperwork in a shed could be so engaging. But now, having played even for just short time, I can definitely say that Papers, Please holds a special place in my mind. It's a game that gets under your skin, in a good way. It makes you think about the affect that one person can have on so many others. You are an integral part of hundreds of different stories, some big, some small. Papers, Please is a true example of games as art and games as a medium for presenting us with things we might not want to face.
Awsome Game

Fantastic game. The premise, which is checking documents at a border station, may sound boring, but ends up being anything but. The oppressive ambiance, stressful instant citations, and constantly increasing difficulty all contribute to make a challenging, tense, and overall surprisingly fun experience. There's even a story to go along with it. Definitely worth the ten dollars.

You may think, 'Hmm, it's just another retro-indie wannabe game.', but I assure you, you are ABSOLUTELY wrong. Papers, please is all about the story, about what you'd do. You know that a middle-aged woman is going to migrate and live with her family, but will you accept her VISA and allow her to enter, knowing that she does not have the specified documents and may end up in you getting a fine?  Not only is Papers, please rich in story, its endings also allows the player to be the judge of the story. With 20 endings for the inspector to indulge on, you never know what's going to happen. Buy and try it yourself today!
On paper, being a the border police sounds really bad. But what Papers, Please does is make you emotionally attached to characters and makes you question each little desicion. This game is stunning.
Glory to Arstozka but..... Obstrian above all

Glory to Arstotzka! That is the words I felt I have been saying over and over through playing this amazing game. Also DENIED, and a few swear words to vent out my anger.   Papers, Please is a weird game. It is ment to be a passport control simulator, but it delivers as at times, a really challenging game. All your control is the mouse. All you do, it drag stuff and click, but to say the least its not a point and click adventure. Your first day it is simple. Only allow people that are from Arstotzka. Then check all the passports. In the end, you will be checking so many documents, you need to stay on the ball or you will slip up. Massively. I wont be telling anything like said documents, since I dont wish to ruin what is around the corner. The game does have a goal. Do your job. Each person you clear or deny gives your a total of 5 credits. You have to clear enough people to be able to afford food and heating for your family. At times, it is hard. Once, I had to give up food for a day to afford the rent. So what stops you from clearing everybody? Punishments. If fail too many times, you lose your money. That money that will save your family from an early coffin. The problem is, the game can get to you. Occasionly, you will get these people who know they cant get through, but before you tell them to go away, they tell this sad story. Great. Do I seperate the wife from the husband and possibley let her die? Or do I risk it? Nah, it will be fine. The next day, she is in the newspaper. She got murdered. YAY... I feel like sh*t.   I am going to end it on this note. I over the 2013 year, I bought a total of about 70 games. Its my hobby to say the least. I would happy trade them ALL in for this game. (that quickly changed...) but then, I realized my family was dying, I was poor as heck even though I worked hard each day, people were in the same situation as I was, and to remain loyal to the government compared to being loyal to my morals-- well, that's where the line got hazy. A lovely and peculiar game, Papers, Please puts you on border patrol instucting you to keep the glorious country of Arstotzka safe from terrorists and ner-do-wells of all sorts. It is a fun new game concept, putting you in charge of getting people into a country or denying them access, making sure they actually are the gender they say they are. I recommend it.

Let me guess, you are looking at this game and thinking 'why would i want to play such a boring looking game?' Well do i have news for you. This game is nowhere near boring, infact its one of the most suspensful and captivating games i have ever played. You are playing as the one Man(or woman) who can save you country from the terror that is the world. From random terroists attacks to a human traffiking ring, there is never a dull moment. Yes, that's a red thumb. Don't get me wrong this is a good, innovative and surprising game. But it has a major fault you need to be aware of before buying it.  >This game is about WORKING.  Like a real job, maybe like your real job. You spend the daytime in your office, doing a repetitive task, in a dull and boring environnement. You go back home in the evening, worried about your family members getting ill and bills to pay. And you have to perform well at work, for you salary is based on your productivity.  This is quite stressful and you definitely don't want to go for another work routine when you log on steam.  Moreover everything in this game is so... depressing. It can't be explained with words, but I find that the feeling you get while playing is not enjoyable at all, almost repulsive. Right now I remember the graphics, the music, the suffocating atmosphere and I just want to run away and finish this rating as fast as possible.  I know there's a lot of positive ratings for this game already and I got their point : the game is good and unique obviously.  But do you seriously feel like working in a video game and going through all that implies ?

My definitive Game of the Year for 2013. Everything about this game is so great. While it may look dull and repetitive on the front, there are many different kinds of stories going along, with you as the person who says what happens. With many options and 20 different endings, this is a must-buy.

Really great game, but very subtle and difficult. Makes you pay attention to every little detail, and blends the monotonous work 'gameplay' with the narravtive elements extremely well. Some interesting characters in the game. Never thought working the border would be this enjoyable. Also, provides endless replayability with an actual endless mode, plus 20 different endings for the story. The gameplay becomes kind of addicting and you want to play more, and also want to uncover what happens in the a story. Papers Please, a very grim and sad game. Let me just tell you this right now: Buy it.  Now that that's been said, allow me to explain a bit about the game itself without spoiling it.  You're a border inspector for cold war, communist, Russia-esque country. There's not much gameplay in the game itself except for stamping passports, which you're probably thinking to yourself now 'Why should I buy a game about stmaping passports?'. Because, at the same time while you stamp passports, you're attempting to maintain your family, giving them food, paying heat, paying off rent. So, you essentially have your sob story. HOWEVER, while you're stamping passports you'll have people without some of their documents and they'll tell you their sob story. They'll either attempt to bribe you so they can go through or just hope that you'll be a saint. So you're juggling around whether you can't afford the tickets for your bills or maybe you'll help this guy. But it only gets worse. You have to do this difficult decisions under time. All the while terrorists are invading you borders, independence factions, smugglers, drug dealers, etc.  There's a LOT more to this game, but unfortunately I don't want to spoil it. Anyway, good game is good, so good that it's on my top 10 list for 2013, so you should buy it.

This game has absolutely no right being as fun as it is. If you're a fan of strange games that are pushing the boundaries of what gaming actually is, then you need to pick up Paper Please and give it a go.

Deny foreigners into your glorious nation, strip search suspicious travellers, examine entry permits, shoot terrorists, confiscate passports and watch as your family freezes to death because you spent all your money on rent.   10/10

I love games that are based in Soviet Russia, as the Russians were badasses who didn't give a fudge ... about anything! If someone died from a grenade blast they would just say 'Well, that was unfortunate ... BACK TO WORK!' Now back to the game! Paper Please is a brilliant idea where you serve as a border control officer who works to keep his family back home alive, and he comes across a lot of people trying to cross the border illegally, and they will either give you a sob story or try to catch you out! in short its either them or you!

A truly unique game that everyone should experience. I can't remember another game achieving so much with so little. If ever there was a sign that the medium of video games is maturing, this is it - it's meaningful, poignant, confronting, challenging, stressful and charming.  While I was expecting the monotony of immigration paperwork verification, I was not expecting such a strong and intricate storyline to unfold.

So... you're working as a border control agent? All you do is check their documents to make sure they're legit? Oh, and if they're not you can deny or detain them? How exciting! That sounds like work, not a game.   I know it does, but it freaking works! Such a boring and pedestrian sounding concept that shouldn't be fun, but it is. For the most part, each day adds new 'things' you need to be on the look out for. As you get further into the game, entrants take longer to process just from the sheer number of documentation you need to check. But you better check it fast cause you're on the clock and your family needs to eat.  Your morals will be tested and you will get stressed out. And you will make mistakes. And they will be your fault. But you will still have a blast playing the game. Do yourself a favor and get this game.

Life as a boarder control officer isn't easy, and boy, does this game hit home. I was pleasently surprised to find a charming, yet dark and depressing, game. The art style is unique and it fits perfectly with the sound effects and very little music the game has. The gameplay is easily graspable, fun, and challenging at times, even a bit saddening. It's a simple game about a heavy topic, and it tells a wonderful story which, depending on you, could end not so wonderfully, or just as much. With more than 20 endings, there's so much replayability, it's definitely worth a buy. You will not regret it. Glory to Arstotzka.

Wow, a game that makes you racist against people that don't even exist and feel national pride for for fakeistan. But seriously, like half of the Kolechians are terrorists.

How much fun can it be to check people's passports? Well, it depends on you, but I like challenges that make me look for detail, work under pressure, etc. Maybe because I'm a software engineer. But in any case, depending on the type of challenge one finds 'fun' one will like this game a lot or hate it.  In this game you man a checkpoint, checking people's passports and papers to see if they should be allowed through. You also get a new set of directives each round from your fine bosses in the government: work papers required this time, no citizens from a particular country allowed, etc. And since it's a parody of an Eastern-Bloc country under iron fist rule, you are offered bribes and such - which you can take or not, as you see fit. You are also time-constrained because you're paid per-checkpoint person, and if you don't move fast enough you don't have enough money to feed your family, and that's one way to lose the game - your family starves or dies of illness because you couldn't buy medicine.  What makes a game fun is if one finds doing the same thing over and over fun: be it shooting monsters, hack/slash/loot, etc. So if you find this kind of visual challenge fun, you will love the game. If you don't, you will hate it because that's all this game is - checking passports, papers, keeping up with the politbureau dictates, etc.  One of the best off-the-beaten-path games I've played in a long time.

What you come to expect from an indie game. Simplistic, engaging, challenging

(8.5/10) Papers, Please is a game unlike any other I have played. Sifting through paperwork sounds like work, and it is. This is not a mind numbing game. You play a border crossing inspector for a communist country, Arstotzka. You check and cross reference legal documents and either admit or deny entrance into the country. Will you be corrupt, or will you be loyal to your country? Will you be warm tonight, or will you eat? Do you care more about yourself, or more about others? The art style is different, and multiple screen support or full screen support would be nice additions to the game.
If you're a fan of dystopian futures and simple story-telling, then this is a game for you. It's graphics and pace won't wow, but it is as compelling as it is fascinating and repetitive.

Papers, Please is a brilliant exercise in cynicism and anti-authoritarian sentiment. The difficulty level is at a neat point where it's challenging enough for me to feel rushed and subsequently frustrated at my own mistakes, but not so much that I can't progress after taking a few swings at it. I've been enjoying the storyline so far, and I'm intrigued to see where it leads.

From 8-5 (and sometimes longer) I work as a Visa Officer in a U.S. Embassy. Every morning I stand at a window like this one, interview people not unlike those in this game, and experience a sensation that is captured wholly and completely by this game. Aside from one glaringly difficult mechanic (where you are paid only for the entrance permits, not for your refusals) this game is my job in a nutshell. The fact that it can do this, and that it can so thoroughly tap into the same part of my brain I use all day at work, makes it a marvel. It's a marvel I hate playing, and one I can be paid for. I recommend it to everyone who does not do what I do.

This game is incredibly fun. I do not understand. My friends and I have discussed it, and we can't figure out why it's fun. I bought it and sat down and played 5 hours straight. I don't do that.   If we take a look at what you do in the game, it should be boring and repetitive. It is extremely challenging and oddly amusing. I highly recommend this game.   Action and strategy games are my forte, and this is neither. Yet, it still gets a high rating in my books.
Fantastic. Thought provoking, humorous, and fun all at the same time. Buy it if you're the least bit interested

Mix 1980's dystopian setting with Phoenix Wright courtroom-esque gameplay, then add a whole lot of well crafted political games, and sprinkle with difficult moral decisions. And not the lazy moral decision making of most modern games of FRIENDLY ANGEL or VIOLENT DEVIL, interesting moral dilemmas like [REDACTED].  Maybe you played the beta and thought that was enou- IT WASN'T! There are apparently 20 ♥♥♥♥ing endings in this game now as opposed to the zero there were before, plus an endless mode.  Analyzing documents for errors, counterfeit seals, keeping an eye out for suspects, and deciding how to deal with chums with desperate pleas and insufficient documentation, is surprisingly very fun.  I can't say enough good things about this game. I want to say this is my favorite single player game of all time at the moment. Not enough games venture into uncharted territory like this one.  My only beef is that while a lot of the controls are intuitive, a lot of people get tripped up on what to do when a person shows up with no passport. Here's a hint, that empty surface is a discrepancy with the rule requiring all entrants to bring passports.

TL;DR Review:  Papers, Please is a an excellent game with some unique, quirky gameplay elements and a strong message, and could only have been made by an indie studio.  Long Review:  As a child of the 70's, I saw firsthand the tyranny of the Soviet Union, though I did not understand it all at the time. Even though the serial numbers are filed off, Papers, Please does such a good job of expressing the combination of boredom and terror that such regimes induce that it could easily cause flashbacks in anyone who lived there.  But the game doesn't hit you with its message like a pie in the face. No, initially you're just a civil servant, trying their best to do their job both for the security of the country and to keep their family from starving or freezing. Denying a correct application or admitting an incorrect one costs you money, so it initially seems simple - follow the rules, be meticulous and get paid.  Then the difficult choices come - slowly at first, then faster and faster as the game progresses. A man's documents are in order, but his wife's are not - what do you do? A superior tells you to let someone through even though their papers are incorrect - what do you do? A woman begs you to deny the man behind her, since she's afraid he'll force her into prostitution - what do you do?  And as the game progresses you realize that while you might be the one making these decisions, the real evil is in the system that forces you to do so - a system you are powerless to change. Or are you?  The game also has a unique save system. Your saves are arranged in a tree structure, and at any time you can click on any day in the game and branch off a new save from your existing ones so you can try new things - an excellent feature given how many different endings this game has.  Cons? Well...you're going to be peering at a lot of text in very small fonts - this actually gave my daughter headaches. The game's difficulty gets almost excessive towards the end, with you having to examine five different pieces of paper, any one of which could be incorrect. The interface for cross-referencing is a bit obtuse and will take some getting used to.  But the game does so much with so little - the graphics are simple, there aren't many sound effects and the overall storyline is minimalistic, but you will be sweating bullets as the game comes to a close. I highly recommend it.

Papers, Please is another wonderful game where the graphics dont matter. The beauty of this game is in the story and the choices you make throughout the story. This is not just a game about who you let into Arstotzka and who you dont, there is a wonderful story woven through it. Every 'mistake' that occurs, whether it be on purpose or not, results in a deduction of your pay for that given day. Will you let in Jorji because he is the funniest character in the game, even though hes on the wanted criminals list? Or will you detain him to keep your family alive? That is up to you, and believe it or not, it changes the outcome of the story completely! The music in this game is also fantastic, and very catchy too. In the end, this game is a good amount of fun, and I highly reccommend it to all players looking to have a great time. Glory to Arstotzka!
A simple concept with amazing depth. Highly recommended.

If you were born in the 80s and remember sitting in a dusty basement of your elementary or middle school playing Apple IIe games and just wanting to watch the music/pixels do neat stuff...this will feed that nostalgia. It's surprisingly light on memory, but deep in story. You can make choices that will make or break both you and the potential person(s) entering through your checkpoint.   If you also lived through the cold war, I'd recommend this, as it seems to heavily rely on that mantra and trope as well. I find myself picking it up when I need to kill some time and want a detective style game.
Interesting game concept. Check this game out, it is a really fun and interesting indie game.

If you feel that checking at a border checkpoint in a fictiontional coummunist nation where you have to support a family with what little you earn with a intresting story of infuncling the nation due to be one of the few checkpoints in the entire nation sounds entertaining in anyway,then this is the game for you.  The only bad thing about this game is the resolution support (Total of 3 resolutions) with black bars for the rest. If you run on a sorta low resolution or full 1080p be prepare to move around your entire desktop if your someone who doesn't have much elbow room ever time you change your PC resolution to play this game using your entire screen.

Papers, Please is more than just stamping passports, it is a cynical examination of life as we know it, where small differences can mean the difference between life and death. While playing, the player faces many choices, tasked with rooting out the small differences in people in order to keep them separate. The player can choose to be the humanitarian, or they can choose to safeguard themselves. In these choices, which seem small at the time, the true message of Papers, Please; emerges. It shows that we are all not so different from one another, though we always exploit those differences.
Beautiful game inspired by the USSR regeme! Recommended to all
Fun, surprising, inventive....it proves you dont need top of the line graphics or multi million dollars to make a GREAT videogame.
It is surprisingly fun and very addictive.
Very good concept, entertaining.

Entertaining, as it is. As you progress even further, you may have to examine an endless avalanche of government-issued documents before you stamp the passport, even if we get careless because of the discrepancies we have to examine, and risk being fined 5 credits for a simple yet serious mistake.  For the game's theme, it's a reminescent of the latter cold war years, such as the Divided Germany up until 1989 and its reunification the following year (Sorry, Korea won't count at all). The whole of the Soviet Union under the toughest of entry conditions before the crumbledown on Christmas 1991, in which the key countries: Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, and the Baltic States of Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, have eased a bit on the entry restrictions. Talk about present-day USA, more than 76% of individuals entered the country legally without even caring that they're classified as terrorists, while the rest of us, law-abiding people, are flagged as terrorists for no reason, even we can't leave the country (Less than .0015% chance on having our exit visas issued)  Even it gives me emotions on an old lady trying to desperately see her own son after six suffering years, and have to deny entry because she doesn't have the documents, or the one she has are purely invalid, but this is the checkpoint officer's duty, nothing else.  The BGM there, yep, that was the remains of Soviet Russia. Graphics? 8-bit creativity in the modern age, and whoever complains about 8-bit creativity in the present day then that's their problem.   So if you're looking for the most entertaining, keeping you hours glued to this seat, and to relax yourself after a tediously long session, then this one's for you!
This game is extremely good. Very challenging, very fun, and making a serious statement too. Awesome.
Simple, fun, and has a excellent learning curve. Don't let the price fool you, you could potentially lose hours to this game's 'one more turn' feeling
You get to deny people for no reason. AWESOME!!!

Great absorbing game its gameplay gets more and more complex as it advances and you have to be keen about even the smallest mistakes and sometimes you have to choose between re-uniting a family or being able to feed your own family sometimes your mistakes may not seem to have much of an impact until you realize you just let a suicide bomber slip through and it kills 5 guards or you just let a serial child killer into the country would recommend can run on just about any computer and is put on sale all the time
GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Honestly, there's not much to say about this game other than 'I like it' and 'you should play it,' because I like it and think you should play it.  There's something to be said about games that simulate actual work, and this game really takes on a life of its own. It has a real personality to it. You are a guy from what is basically a fantasy Soviet state and you were just assigned a position as stamp man at the newly opened border checkpoint in West Grestin, Arstotzka. At first you must check simple paperwork (valid ID, Arstotzkans only), but as time goes on there will be more government regulations regarding work permits, fingerprinting, contraband, diplomatic paperwork, counterfeiting, etc. that will have you on edge searching for what could be wrong.  It's not just the paperwork checking that is interesting here, but the human relations part too. Sometimes you are compelled to allow a person to slip by because of one reason or other, and other times deny a person who has proper paperwork because of certain tips. Sometimes you must choose whether or not to take a bribe because you have family that you need to feed. You get paid per person that you process as well, so there is also the dilemma of wanting to rush the papers and risk citation and potential fines, or making sure the papers are in order.
Surprisingly engaging and even though it's a brain game most of the time, the story arc that overlays everything keeps things interesting to the end.
This is super fun with both humor and alot of choices! And it got the best soundtrack USSR!
A very unique and immersive game, focused on atmosphere and consequences of your choices.
Oh god its so fun :D

This game has no right to be as fun as it is, small download, and simple plot. But its just ACE! There is also nothing I can compare it to. Its part puzzle part multi-tasking challenge. The setting is great and its worth a dabble :)

At first I thought this game would be somewhat boring because all you do is go over papers. This game is fantastic. I had no idea I would have so much fun playing it. The game even has a story to go along with all of it which I did not expect. Just buy the game already, you will not regret it.
One of the most interesting, enthralling and intense games I've played in a while. Great Game!

I'm gonna start out the review by saying that this game met my expectations. If you were expecting it to be a riviting story with a huge climax and lots of entertainment, then you completely missed the point.  'Papers, Please' is a brilliant take on the mundane job of being a border crossing guard. The thrill of the game comes from looking at every little detail in the ID's and paperwork you're handed and trying to find some kind of inaccuracy. It could be as glaring as their Date of Birth being in the future, to as subtle as a '0' instead of 'O' in their registration number. Your job is to sort through it all and only admit those who present the proper information.  That's not all though! You are also having to take care of a family at home, and you're paid by the job not by the hour. Every person you admit/deny gives you income. Make too many mistakes and they start docking your pay. It's quite the challenge to be fast, yet accurate.  Add to this your work area, which is far from efficient. It's virtually impossible, expecially later in the game, to have all your documents open in your workspace. You have to determine what to look at, and what to leave closed on the counter for the time being.  You also have little side events, like one of the guards making deals with you that'll net you a little more income. You also get approached by people and organizations who want you to allow/deny admitance to others no matter what their credentials. Do something wrong and you can land yourself in jail. Do something right and you can come out on top, while not quite following the rules. Work too slow and you might start to loose family members to illness or starvation. It's quite the puzzle!  There isn't really any excitement to this game. The enjoyment comes from working out a strategy that sees you staying out of jail, your family staying healthy, and your patritism remaining intact. It even has an 'Endless' mode if you just want to keep going and going.  I absolutely recommend 'Papers, Please'!
this game is like as addicting as heroine 10/10
Not kidding, its actually a fun game.

Glory to Arstotzka indeed. The game seems simple from the get go, but actually gets increasingly hard and stressful as time goes on when you have to check so many details, keep your family warm and fed (And giving medicine to your damn son who has the weakest immune system in history), and then let your morality decide for you when you need to let undocumented people through like the soccer player, or the married couple when the wife has no papers. Also following or denying the Order is intense. There are so many endings, and I've only just cracked the tip of the iceberg with them.
Can't...stop...playing...  Great very original game, and cheap too. Laptop/older computer friendly.

This game is a really interesting concept with some great ideas. It builds great amounts of tension and stress. It does, however, feel a little too much like hard work. Still, had a good experience with it and it's a good example on how games can still be fresh and entertaining without the need of AA graphics.
a very good game      glory to arstotska

I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle. Honestly when I saw the trailer this looked like crap. I didn't expect more than 30 mins of gameplay, the concept seemed boring with minimallistic artwork. Yet when I played this I was plesantly suprised.  The game turns the age old 'spot-the-difference' game into something with much more depth and playability. I ended up spending several hours on this game and upon completion am considering going back to play it again for one of the 19 other endings.  This is a game for people who like to multi-task, have a keen eye for differences and obscurities, and are fast with the mouse and keyboard. Has a bit of storyline and mystery behind it and also manages to incorporate economy/ money management. Much better game then I gave it credit for.   Don't judge a passport (book) by it's cover!
Highly addictive

If only i got payed to play this monotonies game, then i guess it wouldn’t be a game... maybe it’s not, maybe it’s a simulation. Good game

You walk to work and begin your work day as an immigration officer. You sit down and buzz though the first person trying to pass though your boarder, they present you with their papers and now it is up to you to see though their deception.  When I first heard about Papers Please I thought it would be the world’s most boring game, IT IS NOT! These are some of the things I love about.  1) Story: There are different paths which you can take each with their own ending meaning your actions have consequences. This also gives you the incentive to try out all the different possibilities.  2) Art Style: The art style in this game I personally love, it's dark and cold which gives the true feeling of working within an oppressed country. 3) Emotions: I guess this can be connected with the story but there are a lot of people which you can feel for, you feel oddly connected with them and their plight.  4) Difficulty: This game can be confusing, you need to stay on your game and look for the miniscule details and stay on top of your countries ever changing foreign policies.  5) Replay-ability: I warn you; once you start you may never stop. Although you may play little by little the hours add up and even after playing this game for a long time I can still come back to it and play again.  6) Soundtrack: There is nothing better to get you in the mood for playing in an oppressed dreary country than the drumming at the start of the game with classic eastern feel.   I hope those of you who have bought the game enjoy it as much as I did, it was developed by Lucas Pope I urge you to check out his other games.   GLORY TO ARSTOZKA

Papers, Please doesn't seem like a very engaging game on the surface. However, the searches for those subtle passport mistakes, the balancing of the family budget, the EZIC conspiracy, and all the times you risk losing pay to help those in need really draw in you in well.  Not bad for a so-called bureaucracy simulator. It's definitely one of the better games to have come out this year.

In this thrilling game you play as a border security guy looking at peoples papers. wow possibly most exciting game concept i have ever played, but i cry when man is let into country but i must turn away beautiful old wife. very sad game

Ok i have no idea how to explain this game other than to say it feels like a modern day Oregon trail... just try to keep your family alive and healthy while you follow the ever changing rules and regulations... will you take the bribe or not .. find out how it all goes down and play it again.

If you ask me what this game is about, I can't tell you. To describe it would not only give you the wrong impression, but it would be insulting to the game.  'Papers, Please' is an addictive masterpiece, encompassing hummor and morality, as well as mortality. As simplistic tasks become more and more complicated, taking longer to perform, and holding a more intense weight over the livelihood of you and your loved ones, our ideas of morality change. Between bribes, corruption, sabotage, and simple cold-heartedness, the game knows exactly how to get at you, as you race to the end, trying only to survive.  When I tried to explain the game's mechanics to my friends, they were put off by the concepts. In our minds, a paperpusher does not make a great game. Yet everyone whom I've demonstrated to, or let play have expressed their own interest, many of whom bought the game for themselves. So yes, I suggest this game to anyone who wishes to explore humanity at it's finest.

Awesome game!!! Very fun to play, its good feel when you can deny entrance from those f*ckfaces who try to come to your country. Glory to Arstotzka!!!! 9/10 Ps. Needed good english language, if not, leave this to shop, you dont need it then ;D

Suprisingly addictive. At it's base it is a 'spot the discrepancy' puzzle game but with a lot of charm and humor. Using the 'DENIED' stamp is very gratifying for some reason, and the responses can be quite amusing. Do a good job and you get a 'better' apartment (read: more expensive, you never get to see your apartment) and can afford heat and food and medicine for your family. Do poorly and your family might starve to death and you might eventually get arrested. Take a bribe and you might get arrested. Be honest and you might get arrested. No wonder poorly paid socialist border agents have no sense of humor! 'DENIED!' 'DENIED!' 'DENIED!' hahahahahaha

A border control paperwork-management game doesn't sound very interesting... but they've made it so compelling. The way the storylines eek out over your work days is so cool. I don't normally play more than a day or two at a time, because you really need to concentrate. But it's probably the most unique game that's come out this year. A definite recommendation.
Simple, and will make you question your every action.

Buy this game! I know it doesn't sound like it should be fun and engrossing, but it is! Buy this game to support developers like this to continue to think outside of the box, buy this game because it IS fun, buy this game because it is cheap (especially on steam sales). Just buy this game!

It's really hard to convey with words what makes this game interesting. On the surface, this game feels exactly as if you were doing real life work:  - You get a job.  - You are assigned your tasks.  - They feel like a chore.  - You screw up - You get reprimanded - Your responsibilities grow, while your salary stays the same  However, throw in the realities of having a 6 member family to provide for, and it starts getting complicated. Fail to bring home enough money and some family members may have to starve, or freeze. If one of them is sick, you may have to choose between medicine, food, or heating. Will you take bribes then to offset these costs? Will you cooperate with terrorists to get a pay cut? Will you try to get through that gate as many people as you can, since you get paid by the person?   At first it's really easy to make these desicions since you have no sense of what's really going on. After the first few hours go by, and you're grinding along day after day, you start to feel more like playing the character. You start to feel compassion for some of the pixelated people that desperately beg for entry. You start to make judgement calls based on how your family is doing. The game begins to develop into an extremely interesting experience where you're constantly being morally tested.  The game has about 20 or 30-something outcomes (can't remember off the top of my head). So far I've managed to see about 9 of them. Every time I finish I'm finding new paths and possibilities to explore in order to see where the story goes. This is one of the 10 best experiences I've had with video games this year, and I wholeheartedly recommend you give this one a chance.

Wow for a few dollars this game is really good. 2 hours went by as if it were only 15 minutes. Ugly game but well thought out and makes you really think about who should be let in and who should be detained/rejected.
It's way more fun than it would seem a first glance. Highly recommended!
This game is addicting! I need to play more soon.
Oddly addictive and fun to waste hours in. May not be for everyone.

I feel like I could love this game; the atmosphere, the visuals and what you end up having to do in order to prosper create a strange experience. This isn't a negative however, as the experience draws you in and makes you give a hoot about your family, who only appear as a list of names. The knowledge that someone you are expected to care about can be cold, hungry and sick based upon your actions weighs heavily upon your pixelated shoulders.  I come back to my opening words however, as I will recommend this to everyone who doesn't work in admin. If your job involves papers, dealing with complaints or the public and their documents, this game may not be that fun. I can appreciate the sentiment of this game, but when you work in similar fields, you feel a bit of a mug stamping passports and paying for the privilege, when you get paid to do similar work elsewhere!
Realy Nice, see how fast your morality can take a dive when your family is in need :+
great game!

A very intriguing and distinct polit-thriller set in an east european-like country in the 1980s. Main location is the border of Arstotzka, where the player takes the position as the border inspector. While the gameplay may look dull and simplystic since you do mostly paper work for 90% of the game, it becomes more challenging as you progress further. You have to watch out and point out every discrepancy in the documents of the immigrants, which becomes much harder since there always come more documents.  The Border is also the main focus point of the plot. Basically it all depends on you how the story will progress. Will you support the secret society who wants to bring change to the country or will you simply keep on doing your job and ignore them? Will you let the old woman who urgently need medical treatment pass or shoo her away because she hasn't brought the right documents? All of this and more depends solely on your actions.  There are a total of 20 endings and you'll have to replay the game a few times to see them all.  I'd really enjoyed Papers, Please and must say, it is one of these unique experiences that one must play by him/herself to appreciate.
10/10  Glory to Arstotzka

If anybody in your vicinity questions whether or not video games can be art, just shove this game in their face and leave them alone with it for a while. Papers, Please thrives on hard decision-making and emotional attachment. Should you be the most brutal immigration officer possible, in order to insure the wellbeing of your family? Will you be self-sacrificing, and let through those who need it most at you and your family's expense? Or will you attempt to overthrow the system from within, to improve your family's life in the long-term? These questions are engrossing, and will keep you hooked to the story.  The gameplay itself sounds like it should be dull, but is instead utterly unique and addicting. If you have a good eye for details, and love fast-paced games with a gentle learning curve, then this game is for you.  Just play Papers, Please, dammit.
