Played this game when it was in Beta lil less than a year ago and actually didn't like it much. But that's why you don't play Betas or Early Access, cause in most cases they have very little to do with a real game. To my surprise when I saw it again around a month ago, when my gf was playing it 5 or 6 hours straight, I couldn't resist to take a look and boy this game became quite entertaining (not too much of a replayability but still). The story is very thorough with lots of details, unique characters and many of endings (about 20) with the difficulty constantly increasing, but never ending being up THAT hard. Game mechanics are quite simple, though it has some lesser flaws (for example I didn't get, why you upgrade your booth to be able to use shortcuts for some useless actions, while real helping stuff is not introduced, like a button to call a next immigrant or a button to 'use a talking device'). I would recommend this game to someone who wants to play a game out of the box, had a dream to become a customs inspector and to everyone else. And I'm pretty sure that you will miss Jorji after you are finished with the Papers, Please =]

On the outisde it seems like a monotonous repitition of stamping papers, and at first the game may also feel that way as well. HOWEVER, the more days you go to work the more complicated things become. People ask of you favors, you make errors and it costs you (and your family) money. Everything you do begins to have side effects, you may accidentally let a killer into your country and the next day there will be a headline about it in the daily newspaper. It's a fascinating game with 20(?) endings. You can take you and your family almost anywhere in the game. Whether your character is a die-hard loyalist, or even a revolutionary is entirely up to you!
Very Very fun game worth the money
Amazing story, original gameplay and brilliantly executed mood and setting. 5 ♥♥♥♥ing stars.

Papers Please is a truly brilliant game. A unique concept and wonderful execution set in a grim world full of moral conundrums. The core gameplay of checking passports is oddly compelling in a way that I can't really describe, and the way that the game presents the player with moral decisions through that gameplay is highly effective. You have to balance your responsibilities to your country and your family while arbitrarily deciding the fates of dozens of random people. I spent more than enough time just playing the demo to justify the $10 to support the developer, and the final product has only improved. Money well spent.

One of the oddest and most fun games I have played. You are a border patrol agent who has to check peoples' passports and visas. You have to look for discrepancies such as wrong gender on passport, passport picture not matching and even nude scans to find hidden weapons. What sounds boring on paper becomes a very entertaining game, as it requires attention to detail and an alert mind. The graphics and sound are 8 bit, similar to the C64.
The hype is all true.

It's difficult (unless you turn easy mode on in the options, which doesn't make things easier, only more forgiving) but fun. You have 12 game hours per day to process people crossing the border into Glorious Arstotska. I've not finished at all, but there's a story of espionage and diplomacy unfolding as well as very human moments, such as making the choice to approve or deny a husband and wife for entry whenonly one has the correct papers. There are limited options but those options give the player a high amount of control. If you are interested by the trailer, give it a go.
Simple, yet very cerebral. This is one game that will have you constantly second guessing all your actions, both in the game and outside of it!
One of a kind gem, a mix of memorization, mystery, suspense and tactics. Absolutely worth the price.

Unique title that is surprisingly good at challenging your memory and ability to detect small changes in a time sensitive environment. Can be mentally exhausting yet engrossing. Should only be played when your brain is fully alert.

Played this game when it was in the beta and absolutely loved it. It's amazing how such a boring idea like being a checkpoint officer can make such a fun and engaging game. For the small download size and lack of amazing graphics, there's so much content packed into this game with a in-depth story that can take a sudden turn at any moment depending on what you do. That man you just let in could have been a spy, maybe he's helping a secret agency to overthrow the government and you're now part of the conspiracy, or maybe he really is just a guy coming to work. You can only really know if you say the magic words; Papers, please.
So much fun. Can really burn away time that you don't know what to do with (in a good way).
Most original game of the last decade: 10/10

Love the soundtrack. For some reason it never becomes irritating. Love the depressing mood and atmosphere, the tough choices you have to make, and the colorful characters you meet. A very good game overall.

This game absolutely feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ job in a totalitarian regime. Miss one small detail, and get reprimanded. Miss some more, and lose some of your pay. Bureaucracy gets ever more complicated. You arrest people, turn them away, tear families apart. Your own family is going to be hungry, sick and freezing most of the time. Wow, just wow. If this description intrigues you only a tiny bit, absolutely get it.
Depressing.  Play at least once. Begin and continue therapy thereafter.
You'd assume this job/game would be boring but it definitely captures your interest and attention to detail . Would recommend for shiggles

This game is as simple as its title. You are some guy in a border checkpoint who must check people's papers before letting them through.  Does it sound entertaining?  Not at all  Is it?  More than you could ever imagine.  The game is great and yet so simple. The story is gripping, and much more absorbing that you could ever give a game like this credit for. The gameplay is entertaining and challenging. Simply put, it is a piece of art.
This game is very addicting and surprisingly good. You shall be amazed at how looking over documents is extreamly entertaining.
If you were alive during the 80s in eastern or like I was NEAR eastern europe then this simulator is for you, or even if you're not you should definitely give this one a whirl :D

I'd heard of this little indie game a long time before I finally played it, and I was glad I did. The game isn't particularly complicated, it isn't a drawn out adventure to defeat evil. It's simple in it's premise: you get a job in the fictional country of Arzstoska as a border customs checker. You need to check the passports of people passing through, allowing entry to the people with the right identification and denying/detaining those without. But the game soon becomes lot more complicated and complex, and soon you have to decide whether to let people through to be with their husbands, despire the fact they don't have all the right papers, or to help stop a wanted criminal, or detain people who haven't done wrong, just so you can get a little extra money so you can get food, warmth and medicine for your family. It's a great game, with loads of replayability. It's fast-paced, complex, and has you questioning your moral choices. Brilliant.

Best puzzle game I've ever played. I call it a puzzle game, because you are essentially comparing documents and trying to find flaws. The game gets increasingly more difficult as you progress. At the point of this recommendation, It's normal for someone crossing the border to give me 4 documents to compare. The game is polished and worth the full price.

Papers Please is easily one of the most engrossing gaming experiences I've ever seen. It's been a long time since I was so invested in my character's well-being, which came as a surprise in a game about a border guard post.  Easily worth $10 and then some. Buy it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
An amazing indie-game. Succumb to the communist leaders of Glorious Arstotzka or try to help the resistance from your post as the border control agent.

This is not a game for everybody.  It will not be a relaxing gaming session if you decide to play Papers Please. Instead, you will be required to really focus and try to do your thing the best possible way you can. Even though you might think that what Papers Please has to offer may be boring or not interesting, it is surprisingly intriguing as you realize that the storyline of the game is more than you thought. Papers Please has 20 endings, all of them are dependent on the player's actions. There are entire storylines that can end differently depending on what you do in the game and I recommend playing through the story mode a couple of times just to see how many things could go the opposite way.  After 2 full playthroughs I think it's the engagement the game requires from the player that is so appealing to me and I have to say that I've had a lot more fun with Papers Please than with any other video game that came out this year. Definitelly worth the price if you think you might like something a bit different in gameplay.
This game is pretty much amazing and well worth the 10 bucks.

The story is excellent, in that the story is about you, a poor working stiff trying to survive day-to-day, and the things that happen to you as you push papers for a fascist state.  The mechanics of your paper-pushing are lovingly implemented in the game. Everything about the game makes you feel the right way - the music, how you are shown the guards, how you are shown the civilians, the way the game makes you feel about stamping a visa, everything.  The game is challenging. You are constantly presented with choices, and thinking too long about any of them means doing a poor job and most likely getting your pay docked.

This game is amazing. You are just a border guard stamping papers to either allow or deny people trying to enter Arstotzka (so basically it's a country under the soviet control in the cold war era). I'm not sure where I begin to explain why this game is awesome, wait, actually I do. The music. It is amazing. There is one theme to this game, and it's so bloody effective and perfectly captures the mood of the game; it is bleak, desolate, depressing and oppressive and I love it. The gameplay is deceptively simple and engaging, and considering how mundane the task of what you are doing it is hard to pull away. The game can be quite harsh to the player while asking you to make you to make decisions and the effects are not always clear right away. This game is the perfect marriage of theme and mechanics and is a masterpiece.
Really good little game with a great backstory and suprisingly very RPG like!

Papers, Please.  Ever wondered what it would like to work in the passport office? No? Ever wanted to play a game where you work as a passport officer?  .....No?   Well you wish you had.  This game is possibly discribed as a puzzle game, check the faults in the passport. however what if you were to bend the rules if it meant to feed your kids? or maybe overthrow a corrupt government?  anyway 5/5
Interesting concept makes review papers actually tense and interesting. It's nice to see some fresh ideas in the gaming industry as well.
Its fun if you can appreciate that kind of thing.

Absolutely great game. You play as a state officer who checks the passports to enter your country, and you feel the pressure of the government from minute one. Yet you have a lot of freedom in the way to act. You have the chance of deciding when to feel mercy or when to abuse your power; if you want to help the rebels or stick with the government; whether to let the press through even if they are rude, or let a drug dealer pass just because he's really funny. The graphics are simple and the actions, repetitive, but the game gets more and more complex as it goes on, and it's so effective that soon you'll find yourself tense, trying not to make any mistakes so that you can keep your family alive, and hooked to the stories of the characters that pass through your office.  100% recommended.
Tough, frustrating, fantastic. The admins among you will shine.
Climate and music are the best! One of not-so-many great games with good replayability value. After finishing this title you'll be suspicious at every airport.

First of all, 'Papers, Please' is awesome. Here's why:      it's a true indie game that achieves to be indie rather than trying to be triple-A    its art style fits perfectly to the game's setting    it's a great execution in user experience design as it purposedly limits the player's information and activity options    it's a consistent product in every way - setting, UI, story, art style fit together and are consistently presented   Oh, and of course the setting. Making a fun AND informative game about dictatorship and oppression is an achievement in and of itself!

this game is as soulless as its name automatically denotes. Papers please is quite obviously, a game made for the german populace: it is a simulator that sets itself to be as boring as possible. Visa Inspection simulator, to be precise. and although the screenshots and srt style look blocky and grey, the way the game is played will definitely make you think. It is not as adrenaline-inducing as Ground Zeroes or as hyper realistic as Arma, but it still provides a story and offers the player enough immersion into the game where it actually may affect the gameplay individually. simple terms, the game changes the more (or less) involved you are in it. you spend an 8 hour day inspecting and stamping visas and sending people into the country or back out the door. the rest of it it pretty much covered in the tutorial. it sounds boring, and for many, it is. but for those that like a game that requires a bit of wit and willingness to have fun in it, this is definitely a winner.

Glory to Arstotzka !! This game is really a time machine to cold war era in eastern europe... at the first time, you may find this game is boring as ♥♥♥♥.. but everything will change at the second day.  Nuff said : 9/10

Papers Please is a game that is well worth your time and money. When described, it may sound boring and worth dismissing but trust me, it isn’t. It is a game that u can pick up and casually play for a few minutes, or even a few hours at a time. Game play that is easy to learn, but will have you scrutinizing every last detail to maintain perfection. A simple, but compelling story, full of conspiracies and politics, where a simple drop of your stamp can affect a single individual, or an entire country. A well-executed game and highly recommend so why are you still reading this review instead of buying and playing Papers Please.
Great game!

Good fun test to see how good you are at discerning small details and juggling progressively larger amounts of paperwork under time duress. I enjoy it. I love the setting and it's strangely compelling. There's a free demo from the site  (http://dukope.com/)  but it only lets you play 7 days of the story. The full version has the rest of the story and an endless mode with three different modes (How many you can do in 10 minutes, first mistake and you're out, and last until you run out of money for living expenses).    Also, obligatory patriotism: KOLECHIANS GO HOME! GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
Amazing story. So many endings.
A fantastic little game. the story takes unexpected turns and is brilliantly written. The gameplay is way better than you would imagine. Addictive, funny, fantastic. Buy it now.
Good little time waster and a neat game concept. Plus it's always good to support the independents! After a while I startd to feel like I was at work, but it's a fun game just to experience.

It's kind of surprising how fun this game is, considering the overwhelming feel of misery and oppression the game has. Papers, Please is a game where you play as a border inspector, checking over paperwork, looking for inconsistencies, and making choices that impact many lives, including those of your family.  The gameplay can get intense at times as you hurry to process as many people correctly as possible. Papers, Please had me hooked very quickly, and never let go. I'm planning to continue playing even though I've beaten the story twice, just to get all the endings and maybe try out endless mode. There's not much music, but what's there is great and fits the game incredbily well. The graphics are beautiful. Arstotska is mostly devoid of color, and this game looks as it should. The game controls almost entirely with the mouse, allowing keyboard shortcuts if you have the money to buy them and increase your efficiency.  I picked up Papers, Please at full price, and it was absolutely worth it. This is one of the best indie games I've played, and I think it's absolutely worth $10. I'd recommend it to just about anyone.  Note: the game has a little non-sexual nudity that can be disabled in the options.
This Game is absolutely amazing.
awesomely addictive game. Very happy for the level of entertainment for the price. fully recommended.
This game is wicked fun! Border patrol simulator. 10/10 would detain again

Excellent. Gives great insight into life under tyranny, from an unexpected point of view. Even more important are the parallels to the modern day nanny-surveillance states of the West. Being subjugated to intrusive and humiliating airport security theatre, illegal NSA wiretapping, CCTV monitoring, and constant nanny-state intrusion into our daily lives is the antithesis of being free citizens of a free and democratic state.  Papers, Please should be part of the school curriculum, along with lessons about the nature of tyranny.

Papers, Please is, at its core, a bureaucracy simulator. It is perhaps one of the most unique games of its time, and the concept works very well. Each day (of in-game time) introduces new concepts and tasks that increase the difficulty curve without feeling tedious. The worldbuilding is subtle but deep, and will keep you actively paing attention to the most minor details.  If you're a fan of Orwell's '1984' or have dreams of working in a government office, this is your game.
This game is silly. And Horribly addicting!

Very impressive Indie game. The fact that I personally haven't seen something like this out there (although they may exist), the story line is very well thoughtout for a small gamme; the independent and single scenes that happen over the days have clearly had alot of thought and effort. A must buy. Seriously.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
Good. Is smart game. Funny. Dark.
It reminds me of Where in the world is carmen sandiago when I was young. You have to find the differences in the papers given to you. Surprisingly fun.

Thoroughly recommend this - addictive and good replay value to get all 20 endings. You become invested in the story, annoyed when you accidentally let someone through and sympathetic when you have to turn away a hapless immigrant with no passport who hasn't seen her son in years. Bargain on sale.
The game is certainly different than anything I've played before. If you like things where you need to pay close attention to details this game is for you.
Unbelievably good game. Way more fun than it may seem. Subtle moral choices, corrupt Soviet government, document inspection. So goo.
Fantastic game!
A wonderfully unique and cathartic experience.

This game is perhaps one of the best I've ever played.  Very simplistic in its graphics and gameplay, Papers Please will take you on a joyride full of moral choices and difficult decisions in the Communist country of Arstotzka.  You play as The Inspector, who was unwillingly chosen to man the border of the newly-opened checkpoint in Grestin, an analog to real-life Berlin. Arstotzka and its neighbor, Kolechia, have just fought a war and, with the peace, the border is now open for Arstotzkans to return to the homeland.  Quickly decisions pile up. You can detain people for more money, which could mean the difference between life and death for your family. You can let in a man's love, who has no papers but her passport.   There will be attacks on the checkpoint, in which you are given a rifle and told to fire at the attackers. All while this happens, you are given critical choices which can decide the fate of the nation of Arstotzka.  There are twenty endings in this game, and each one provides something a little different. But with any ending and any playthrough, the writing is absolutely outstanding. You almost feel sympathy for the people as you hammer down 'DENIED' on their passports. The poignancy of this game is never far from the surface. As a simple cog in a vast machine of corruption and depression, you can change lives for the better, or for the worse.   This game deserves every praise it gets. It deserves nothing less than a 10 out of 10.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Great game hard to truly get into... but you will have fun playing this game no matter what!
It might look simple, but this game is addictive!
Very good game, very good writing. I managed to feel oppressed even after I turned it off.

Get this game! It's premise is really simple, but the choices are very hard. It's a rather calm gameplay with the many stories being told in between. Each person has their own story and you have to be careful about how truthful you want to be or how generous you want to be. Everything has conciquence. Get it, you won't be sorry.

It's an interesting game with a fascinating idea, well-written and immersive, and will really put you in the shoes of a faceless bureaucrat and to empathize with a kind of person you might otherwise never really see from their viewpoint.  That said, expect to put in a bunch of hours into the game if you like it, and then abandon it. It ratchets up complexity in a way that at first makes the game more challenging and immediate, but eventually just becomes frustrating. Also, since the game never lets up, each new day is far more complicated than the one after that, and so a mechanic that lets you put yourself in the shoes of an opressor ends up feeling far more distancing. Acknowledging the joylessness of a totalitarian state still doesn't make the game fun.
I never thought I would enjoy such a game, but I did! Recommended for a few hours of fun!
Strangely addictive, alternative game. Makes you think, definitely worth a try.
Specs state OSX 10.8 but I have it running fine on 10.6.8. Definate;y worth a look!
Definitely worth buying
This game is just amazing. Unique perspective and story telling.

A fun game where you have to bust peoples' balls about not having the correct papers for immigration to Arstotzka. If you don't own this game, you might as well step out of line, because you don't meet all of the requirements to immigrate into the GREATEST COUNTRY EVER.  THAT MEANS YOU JORJI!
If you are a fan of dystopic society novels and indie games, this is THE GAME for you. Very interesting and refreshing experience from which you are bound to take away personal insights
This game is fantastic, and unlike probably anything else you've played.
A good game. At times it feels like actual work, however it has a very interesting charm that will keep you hooked. By all means give it a shot, it surprised the hell out of me.
Great game for some reason. I really enjoy it.
There are three words to describe this game...Addicting...Hard...Amazing...And fun....And Superb...Aaaaaaaaaand....Did I mention addicting?
Great game and very easy to get in and out. Storyline really sucks you in as well.

Who doesn't want to become a border control officer?! :) Fantastic game, well worth playing, no regrets buying it at all and highly recommend it. Multiple branching stories and 20 potential endings encourages multiple playthroughs too

When I started playing Papers, Please I initially thought 'this is kinda dull. Micromanagement in video game form? I'm good.' But as I progressed more I began witnessing a narrative that unfolded based solely on my own decisions, a story that actually revolved around my character and the world that this character exists in. But this narrative didn't end there as characters began entering into my checkpoint and asking for favors that spanned acrossed several days in the game; favors like allowing loved ones to pass through or to confiscate documents to aid another in pursuing a murderer. And to top all of this off, if you allow unapproved individuals through or prevent approved individuals from passing then your wages are docked and your family may not eat or have a place to live. But the most phenomenal aspect of this all? Every single little decision affects the outcome of the story, and your family's safety and security depend on you making the right decisions from day one. To summarize all of that into one small concise statement: never have I, not even in huge triple A titles, seen a world so immersive and incredibly, heartbreakingly real that I have actually felt bad for not achieving a goal laid out within the games' world.
Addictive Game, could not put it down.
This is pure genius. It takes a while to learn how everything works, but when you do; it's enjoyment all the way.
Very addicting game and actually feel like your in a cold war communist nation.

Can't believe it's actually a fun game, and I feel like I should be ashamed of myself for playing it, but that's being over-ruled by the guilt I feel for having a starving child, and sick wife, all because I let someone through immigration without the correct papers, in order to save THEM.  Yeah, that's the sort of game this is, that's all you need to know.
You wouldn't think a game about being border control would be fun.  You're right.  It's actually SUPRISINGLY fun and very addicitve!  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

Who ever thought that such a boring subject in life could be this overwhelming? Who thought that checking someones documentation could be, thrilling? Now also tell me this? Who ever thought that such a game that puts you in an immersive world, gives you such free will to change someones entire life, be only $10? Give it a try, and I gurantee you won't be dissapointed.
Great music, atmospherics, and game play. Stamping passports is strangely compelling.

Papers, Please is one of those games that you will go back for more. For a small game, there is a lot of content in there. Story lasts about 4hrs and continues with Endless mode which is a lot of fun. I would like to see more characters, different papers and just more of everything. Great indie title!
A great sociopolitical commentary on immigration in the past... and now.

'Observation Skills: The Game.' I find this game pretty interesting. You play as a documents inspector working at a border checkpoint. Oh yeah, this is a checkpoint that leads into a corrupt, dystopian, and fascist nation.  The game goes out of its way every so often to test your sense of right and wrong. Will you let a woman who lacks documentation but is in need of an experimental surgery that is only available in your country past the checkpoint? Or will you deny her entry in order to retain the job you need to provide for your family?  Gameplay is pretty much just examining people's passports, permits, work passes, etc. and then issuing a stamp of denial or entry. Curveballs get thrown at you though which mix up the variables that ultimately decide whether a person can pass or not. And with about twenty endings, the game knows how to keep you engaged.

Papers, Please is a strange game to recommend.  It's not a bad game, far from it, but the game is rather special. Much like Cart Life or Cooking Mama the game has you doing relatively simple and mundane actions for almost no reward.  Unlike Cooking Mama though, there's a huge story at work here one, which you as an inspector at a border checkpoint, get to experience first hand.  You will meet several characters, see the arcs they go through, reunite families and desperately try to care for your own, because the glory in Arstotzka is gone, but time races ever forward and you have to meet the standards set by the government or your job, family and freedom will be taken from you.  If you want something different, interesting and thought-provoking then get Paper's, Please.

'NEXT!' Is one of the things you'd be saying the most, you take role as a person who is the only one to tell if someone is allowed into the country of Arstotzka.After 6 horrible years the borders now finally open, but beware. Fake Id, fake passes, and fake asses. It is your job to approve, or deny peoples entrance, and if someone seems dangerous for the country you got the option to detain him.  This game was hard for me to pick up, due to its somewhat 'stale' looks, but i am more than impressed for how adictive this is. It has humor, tension and action in it. Its definetly worth a try!  I will rate this game a 7/10
The most original game idea ever. But I can't help feeling a great opportunity for something better has been thrown at a low budget game with terrible graphics. Still, it's an interesting game 70%
Unique game that sharpens observation skills. Very interesting to those that like this kind of games with a nice story mix in it. You get the feeling that you are in a real Border Checkpoint.

If you ever had unexplored questions how you would deal with being a civil servant of an opressive state, this game will bring them to the fore. A fantastic example of what videogames can do. Don't spoil yourself too much on how it works, just dive in.
Darkly humorous, Cold War Eastern European dystopian puzzle game. Definitely worth playing if just for the moral conflict that appears routinely!
detain filthy Kolech for Arstotzka I recommend
What lengths would you go to ensure your safety?  Your family?  Your homeland?  Glory to Arstotzka they say, those left alive.
An unusual game, which somehow makes stamping documents fun.
GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA !  This game is really good and makes you think a lot  It's very unique , you won't find anything like this anywhere  Must buy at this price in my opinion

This game has no business being as addictive as it is. But it manages to tell an interesting story with dark humor, tragedy and a surprisingly addictive game mechanic that keeps up the pressure and makes bureaucracy seem downright exciting. Definitely worth checking out.

The best bureaucracy simulator around. There's a reason the reaction to this game has been overwhelmingly popular. Better yet, it's a true indie game: The developer decided he wanted to make it, then coded it, then released a free beta, then finished it and sold it. That's it. No Kickstarters or crowdfunding. No team. No preorders. No delays. No feature bloat. He delivered a quality product on time with no frills, and I love him for it. That said, if the idea of a game consisting entirely of checking and stamping paperwork doesn't appeal to you, you might want to skip this one (and take a long walk off a short pier, you weirdo).
A unique, engaging, thought-provoking game experience. Highly recommended.

This game is a horror game. It reminds me of Amnesia. I got ending 16 of 20 and this is the first time that i'm happy enough about my first play through that I never want to play the story sgain. [Cupon] If it's ever 75% off, i'll buy it for you [/cuon]

I recently wrote a review on this game for Defunct Games, however I really enjoyed papers, please. It's really fun and the gameplay mechanics are unique, although it was one frustrating at times and occasionally it made me rethink my own life which made me retract from the game at had, and I lost my concentration, and the game because of it.

There's something immensely gratifying about a game that rewards you not for cutting corners, cheating the system or getting one over on someone but for being accurate and efficient. Papers please is a game about spotting errors and mistakes, essentially an elaborate 'spot the difference' set in a humourous dystopian communist soviet state. Just like its solid unwavering theme tune, this game is a masterpiece of simplicity and good game design that really builds a sense of tension waiting for the inevitable citation slip every time you give someone the go-ahead to enter. Every time I start it up and the relentless plodding theme tune begins all I hear is yet another nail being hammered into the coffin of big game studios. Glory to Arstotzka.
you would't think it would be this fun but it is 8/10
Very addicting i love it
Never thought doing your job would be so fun.
+Interesting, but not really a game in the classical meaning. +Very different.  -Not so much a game as it is a psychological experiment.  I enjoyed it, but it's not for everyone.  I'd give it a 75%

So I decided to take the plunge and go for a job as an immigration officer. At the interview they asked if I had any previous experience with this kind of work, I said well...I've played Papers, Please. Apparently I start tomorrow! This game got me a job - 10/10.
My son died within 5 days, RIP now ik my lesson..
That awkward moment when someone looks extremely feminine but after the body scan you find out they are in fact a man.
This game is amazing, an awesome addition to any steam libary out there.
It's gud.

I just spent 6 hours denying fake people into a fake country so I could feed my fake family whose existence I can only prove because my fake son's drawing is the only decoration in my booth, and I do not regret one minute of it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Unleash your inner bureaucrat!

This is a case study on interactive storytelling and moral choice in videogames, but it's not hollow. The personal stories and grim setting are built around the core of a solid (if unusual) game mechanic: stamping passports. Of course, when you play it you'll soon come to understand there's more to it than that. The challenge comes from struggling to keep on top of all the ever-increasing, bureaucratically mandated steps you have take to stamp each passport, but the game never feels grindy or unfair. Throw in a branching storyline and lots of surprises, and you have a truly classic game.
Wow is all I can really say, Great game, try if you can to catch it on sale!
... brings out that latent autocrat in all of us ...
I really Like this game, It's kinda slow in the start, but it gets interesting later on!

A fantastic game as it gets so complicated and you will have to repeat the same day or even go back a few days to undo your mistakes. I highly recommend it to everyone. There is only one bad thing, when you complete the game you cant really do anything for quite a while until you forget that you had the game so it is fun again to complete. If your good it takes about 6 - 8 hours to complete. Still get it though, surprisingly hard.

I'm not sure how someone made a paper work simulator nail-bitingly, heart-poundingly fun, but they managed to do it. Papers, Please is one of the few times that I can say everyone should play it. Even if it doesn't look all that interesting to you, because of the graphics, the gameplay, whatever, you still need to play it. It does something that alot of other games fail to do. It makes you care. You care about doing well at your job because all the money you make goes to keeping your family alive, and if you don't do well you get penalized for it. And yet, at the same time, it makes you care about the people you work with, which begin to present moral choices that make you question whether or not you should help them or just look after you and yours. Papers, Please succeeds all the way around, and, as I have said before, you need to play it if you have not yet.
Must. Avoid. Ticket 10/10 would shoot terrorists for a bowl of soup again
I love this game, it's challenging at first, but once you get used to it it's pretty easy.   9/10

This is one of the funniest conversations in the game,to me.  Woman: What is this Drawing on the Wall? Woman: My Dog Can Do Better Inspector: It is from my Son Woman: Oh Woman: Maybe He Should Try Sports Inspector: You Have made a mistake coming here Woman: Please Let Me through. *Gets Detained* Woman: What are you doing? Woman: Is this Because i make fun of drawing? Woman: I Take it Back! Woman: Picture Should Be in Museum!

One of the most unique games I have ever played. Little to no action and yet as tense as any action game. Nail biting, pulse punding. Who would have thought it would come from something so seemingly simple?  A unique experience that there is really nothing like.

If someone told me before playing this game that i'd end up loving a game where you just check passport and travel documents with NES era graphics i would have had them commited to a lunatic asylum.  However this is a game you really have to try to get the appeal and that is definitely worth doing. In the game you play a guy drafted in to work at a border point checking documents. You start off simply checking passports but as the game progresses this becomes more complex as you have to check and inspect ID's, work visa's and other documents. This is made even more challenging as you have a time limit and need to process as many people as you can within that time limit. Each succesful processing you do earns you money which is vital to feed and keep yourself and your family warm. If you make mistakes you can get fined meaning you have less money and a family member could die of hunger or sickness.  The game also has a story to it where you have to make choices about how to proceed. Do you let a poor refugee pass through even they don't have a passport or do you turn them away? Each choice can have benefits or consequences for you so this gives the game a replayability value.  This game shouldn't be so fun, but it is. 8/10

A boring desk job made into a game somehow turns into a fun experience. Look for minute details on foreigners documents and approve or deny their entrance into your country. But will you follow your job to the end or let yourself be corrupted because of ideals or money? Your family lives are on the line, make your choices.

Ostensibly, a boring game with very tedious gameplay. However, the gameplay is not what you're here for. The subtle subtext behind every decision in this game holds an incredible amount of weight, not only on yourself or the outcome of the game but on everyone you interact with. The amount of decision making that happens in this game is nothing short of massive. The differences between every decision that you have to make is what makes the game so compelling.
Amazing game and experience.

This may seem like a plain time management game, but ... wow, it is well crafted! This really lives up to its promise of simulating a communist immigration inspector job ... moral choices both overt and subtle, steadily piling up democracy, and a perverse (and fitting) sense of humour. If the concept appeals to you, this is a must play!

This game has no right to be as addictive as it is. Whilst the core plot remains pretty much unchanged on subsequent playthroughs, the stress/thrill of trying to quickly identify as many passports and documents correctly as quickly as possible and process them can easily leave you hooked.  For the price, I definitely recommend it.

I've only played this game for about an hour and a half as of writing this. However, sor far I LOVE THIS GAME. It is one of the most creative ideas for a game I have ever heard. Still, this may not be for you. Not a fan of pixelated style? You wont like the art style. Care more about action than story? You won't like this either. Never the less, if you can appreciate a subtle, yet suprisingly interesting story, you might just like it as much as I do.
I shot some people and got arrested. 10/10
Great border official nightmare simulator. Watch yourself slowly turn insane from the monotone work and just let terrorists in for some kind of change of pace.

World's first and best border checkpoint simulator. Time to walk to work and don't forget your organizational skills and OCD, you'll need them. This is a fanatastic little game that really shows what indie gaming is all about. A simple concept, fully realized and very entertaining. The game starts off simple enough: approve all Arstotzkans and deny all foreginers. Almost every day has new rules added, old rules revoked or new paperwork for travellers to present. It's your job to make sure all forms are correct, all paperwork is in-date and no shennanigans are being pulled.   There are also a bunch of subplots going on which require you to make decisions that may help others at your own expense. Some of these reward you, most don't. It's up to you to weigh the pros and cons along with your own morals. Not only is all this going on but it's all on the clock making for a tense and sometimes pleasurably nerveracking experience. But that's not all! During all this you have a poor family at home and you must balance your income and budget your funds to keep everyone safe, warm and healthy. For a game that basically only has one screen throughout the entire playthrough, it's got a lot going on. I can't recommend it enough. 10/10 Must-play.  Glory to Arstotzka.
Papers, Please proves that high budgets and an obsession with graphics is overrated. An addictive and challenging game with perfectly matched music. A work of art.
A thought provoking exploration of bureaucracy and oppression. Though not exactly 'fun,' it's certainly worth experiencing.

Satirical, entertaining, unique - all this things can be said about Papers, Please.   You play as an inspector at the border control of a fictional totalitarian state and have to manage your job as well as providing for your family by paying the rent and buying food and medicine. During the story, which lasts a maximum of 31 days depending on how you play, you will have to process dozens of people trying to gain entrance into Arstotzka the country you live in.   You will have to thoroughly check their passports, documents and statements in order to detect any discrepancies. The tasks and documents to check get more and more complicated throughout the game and you will have to face different dilemmas in the game, e.g. allow a woman to enter the country without her having all documents and risk a fine or will you deny her, but at the same time dooming her as she is ill and will die without proper medical treatment.   You should play the game if you are open to new unique experiences and do not mind the graphic which is not up to date, but fulfills its purpose and kind of gives the game this late 80s-early 90s look which fits perfectly. 8/10
it is a silly funny game and i like it
An incredibly fun and addictive game, there's lots of replay value too as there are 20 different endings. i can't stop playing it honestly :)
my computer can run this i r8 gr8
Fun game, love the story and the quirks to it. Probably not for everyone
Played this in beta and it was awesome then, now in full release it has a few upgrades. I've never played anything like it <3
About as fun as a game about sorting paper sounds

Out of the sea of indie games that populate Steam like sprinkles on a cupcake, this one is actually one of the better ones. However, do not go into this game expecting it to have been developed by a huge team of seasoned programmers, art designers , and writers. This game, although as bland as it looks and sounds, doesn't stay that way for long. It certainly is absorbing, thought provoking and interesting as far as game desgin goes. Definatly a must-play.

Great indie game, fun and challenging mechanics, nice story. Later levels really make you feel the pressure: make a mistake and you get a warning ticket, get too many tickets and your family will starve or freeze to death. That's cold, man. Also, can't get the theme out of my head. Eternal glory to Arstotzka!
Questioned a gender discrepancy; got a fat woman with a ♥♥♥♥♥.  10/10
One of the most important gaming experiences I have ever experienced. It's quite frankly not for everyone, but everyone should have tried it at least. Get the beta/demo from the developers website.
Kind of like having to do a tedious yet somehow fun job. Glory to Arstotzka!
This is an excellent and deviously stressful game. Customs agents have it pretty hard I suppose, especially in the fictional eastern Bloc.

Arstotzka welcomes you. Da, comrade we need more workers on the checkpoints. The Cobranistans are lurking and the filthy Impor seek entrance. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!!! Also. don't make the mistakes. Many people want the job checking passport and entry papers against the evil falsification. Plus free tickets to strip club! Your wifes mother doesn't need food tonight, and I think I know the guy at the door. He will let you in if you let his third cousin on his uncles side through the checkpoint! And Ursa, sweet Ursa, her cats former owner is stuck in Antegria. She will help you forget wife and son if you just help her cat see his former owner! Food? Who needs food? We are the kings of the world! A world of snow and concrete that everyone wants to come to. It is the greatest! Truly, Glory to Arstotzka! Papers? Please. What? No papers? Arrest him. NEXT
Very interesting real job simulator :d

Definitely worth buying, but at some point it's more work than play to unlock the content.  After an hour or two, the novelty of being a border guard wears off and you start really working to unlock the content, which I just didn't find as fun.  The amount of fun I did have, though, was totally worth the cost. The graphics, 'story,' and interface are all really top notch, and a pleasure to experience. Definitely a standard-setter for games like 'don't touch anything.'
It makes you think, your family? Or theirs?

Experience the bureacrautic nature of border checking. You need to keep busy so that your family can afford medicin, food, and energy to keep themselves warm. You get to feel bad about yourself many a time when you need to obey rules, and not your heart.   The requirements of border-checking change every day, and the inspection and pointing out errors in the papers are deliberately made frustrating, and you still need to focus to maintain high quality work in fast enough pace. Failing is ok because of saving system.  Papers, please has good focus with one central idea that is varied though gameplay bit by bit. It tells miniscule stories of many border-passers' life. In a way the game constrasts absolute cold rule system with humanity.   The simple music and artistic style work well for this kind of game. Especially recommended for game designers but it's such a good package that anyone should give it a try.

I'm finding it very hard to come up with the right words for this game. The gameplay is simple and repetative, yet I find it to be one of the most engaging games I've ever played. Papers, Please is probably one of the most satisfying and memorable titles I've played in a long time. I also have to say that, in my opinion, this may be one of the most important games to come out this year, becoming a game I would use as an example to argue that video games can be an artistic medium. This game may not be everyone's cup of tea though, so I recommend trying the free beta on the Papers, Please website before purchasing.
Somebody needs to make a kinect mod for this where you can move the papers around Minority Report style. 10/10 Would move papers around again.

Clear out a weekend, or sign up for a graveyard shift where you will be able to dedicate 8+ straight hours to it. Each round (or day, in the game world) goes through so quickly, it's easy to trick yourself into thinking you can play just one more day and quit.  LIZA MINELLI LIES. Just do yourself a favor and get it out of your system over a long weekend.
All that needs to be said, Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please might be one of the finest video games in recent memory.  The storyline is tense, drudgerous and hilariously satirizes the bleak and fatalistic Eastern European communist mindset. Brothel owners, killers, peasants and idiots come through your line, each with their own ridiculous story to tell, but all you want to do is do your work and go home and hopefully have enough money to keep the heat on.
I accepted a guy's bribe but still denied him entry. It was a good day. 9/10
Failed to stop terrorism but captured a killer who murdered his wife, 100/10 this games good

If you like repetitive, soul sucking, paper pushing, then this is the game for you! 'Papers, Please' is an exercise in futility and misery- a surprisingly enjoyable one at that. At first glance, this game seems simple but it's charming graphic styling and soundtrack will quickly draw you in, whilst the growing challenge of keeping out those undesirables from your glorious nation will keep you playing for hours.

A man came up to my glorious counter, and he set upon me his passport. I scrutinized every bit of information on it as to make sure a terrorist/counterfeiter/jaywalker wouldn't enter into Glorious Arstotzka. I noticed the man's gender claimed to be female on his passport. Upon asking the 'man' in question as to what his true gender is, 'he' told me that it was as the passport said. Needless to say, my glorious booth sprung into action, and I proceeded to scan the 'man' for a view of 'his' 'hardware'.   Upon seeing she wasn't packing a python guarding two eggs, I proceeded to aggressively stamp her passport with the denial stamp. I didn't even use the reason stamp.   Anti-LGBT/10

I had heard quite a bit before picking up this game, but I still wasn't sure what to expect. Again, as with FTL, the only way is to try it out for yourself. Papers, Please surprised me with how addictive the gameplay was - which exists mainly of checking documents to spot any errors or omissions - but it was truly the few (major) choices you get that shape the timeline that were interesting to me. I experienced most endings before getting 100% achievements, certainly all the more notable ones.  As an achievement enthusiast I wouldn't have minded a few achievements tied to the 'Endless Mode' that unlocks after you finish the story game.  Recommended for something a little different. It certainly will resonate every time I walk through a customs :p
If only bureaucracy was this engaging in real life.

Some people like first-person shooters, some like fantasy role playing games, personally I have long waited to find a game for my own personal liking. Papers, Please! is a cold-war bureaucracy simulator. Have you ever wanted to work all day ensuring that arbitrary and unexplained rules are enforced? Well you get that AND you have to jugle your funds between heat, food and medicine to keep your family alive and well, its basically the best two games possible ALL IN ONE. Glory to Arstotzka!
This game can drive you crazy and make you laugh at the same time. 10점 만점에 10점

This game feels almost like a job, having to be very particular and careful about every little detail or you will get fined. I can't say I've ever played a game like this one though, and that is enough to change my mind. It is incredibly addicting searching through each immigrants papers for flaws for some odd reason. I waited a long time to buy this game even though I had heard a lot of great reviews about it. I do not think I would pay the original 14.99 this game asks, but during a sale, wow, the low price definetely matched the game and I could not say it is not worth purchasing.
Surprisingly stressful and fun :)

It is absolutely unbelivable, that such a simple game can be such deep and surprising.   The basic idea is you beeing immigration inspector. Boring and too easy? After first day at work, I came back home with about 30 Arzotzkan dollars earned - not enough to pay rent, heat and food for my family of 5. Every day you work harder and harder, but the procedure changes so often, making it almost impossible to earn enough money. And here the bribes come from smugglers and immoral guards. Ill and poor people want to enter your country for treatment or work every day. Not mentioning the Ressistance...   One simply cannot understand how BIG is this game, before playing it.

This game is so simple in concept but is pulled off so well I can't say enough good things about it. It's brilliant in it's design with the throwback 8-bit graphics along with the simple sound editing. It's written like a mystery novel that you have to know what will happen in the end. You are pulled into the game with the very first time you hear the pulsing sound of the main theme.  It's addicting.  Just buy it.

OMG, this game is hell simple but REALLY well programmed and FUN!! By looking at this game you may conclude that graphics are not what matters sometimes. I feel like playing an immersive game on a 386 machine and I have nothing to complain about it.

Life as a boarder control officer isn't easy, and boy, does this game hit home. I'm not sure what I was expecting with Papers, Please, seeing as it was on sale when I got it and I knew little to nothing about it. I was pleasently surprised to find a charming, yet dark and depressing, game. The art style is unique and it fits perfectly with the sound effects and very little music the game has. The gameplay is easily graspable, fun, and challenging at times, even a bit saddening. It's a simple game about a heavy topic, and it tells a wonderful story which, depending on you, could end not so wonderfully, or just as much. With more than 20 endings, there's so much replayability, it's definitely worth a buy. You will not regret it. Glory to Arstotzka.
Very addicting and fun!
This is a game that everybody should play when it goes on sale. A great title to have.
'A man does what he must - in spite of personal consequences, in spite of obstacles and dangers and pressures - and that is the basis of all human morality.' - Winston Churchill
this gane is perfect in so many ways, its enjoyable, very cleaver and tricky. i love it!
Glory to Arstotzka!  (It's good you should like buy it.)
Just started the endless mode, great game. Can't stop playing.

'Papers, Please' is a mesmerizing game that presents you with moral dilemmas that test your loyalty to your family and country, your commitment to your work, your ability to show or suppress compassion, and your desire to rise above your lot in life to make a difference. The game designer managed to accomplish all this in an elaborately crafted branching narrative, told through a simple, though somewhat repetitive, immigration investigation game. It's definitely a game that will appeal more to the cerebral gamers.

You wouldn't think checking documents over and over again would be fun, but you'll be surprised. I was. The game is actually pretty deep and you'll learn a lot about history through its fiction. You can play it 10 minutes at a time no problem, and the game is very cheap ($2.50 at time of review)
i dont like kolechians  they can go suck a ♥♥♥♥

This is how a political works in videogame form, through making the gameplay THE STORY. instead of doing what other 'political games' (cough bioshock infinite) by adding superficial presentation and narrative over a blockbuster action game.    though the critique of communism may be dated--the idea of bueracracy, time limits and the limitations of your personal and moral desires when faced with a state or corporate strictures is timeless.

When I first heard about this game, I thought there was no way that this game could possibly be interesting. But I was completely wrong. Never has a game about checking paperwork been so addicting. The gameplay slowly gets more complex over the days you play it and my obsession with making sure everything was correct kept me coming back until I reached a viable ending. The story being told through newspaper clippings at the beginning of the day gave a purpose to your job every morning. Being a person who naturally despises authoritarianism, I appreciate the 20 endings that developer Lucas Pope decided to put into the game and you could probably guess which way I leaned towards the end. Kudos! Play this game! Now!
I love crushing the hopes of the innocent and destorying the lives of the undeserving.  Also I decided to not give my family medicine and they all died.  10/10
Made me question my morality and cry. 10/10
Best Indie game I ever played - great fun and, despite what it sounds like, this isn't a 'paperwork sim'. Humorous and very replayable.

Papers Please is a fun game the story gameplay is good the story is fine but I really dislike the endless mode. The endless mode is basicly where you just get these challenges where you have to be perfect or you lose. It was really misleading to me and I would have wanted it to be more like the story withless story. It's story is really fun and I recemend it for that, pluss it also has 20 allternitive endings so, get started.

Never before have duties of Grade 136 Bureaucrat be so much fun!  Pre-purchase impression make think it would be easy game, only serving for story-telling bus. Beginning gameplay, is surprised by challenge of trying to border agent, balancing accuracy inspection against ticking clock, increasingly complicated rules for the entry. Every time is pleased with work performance, I return home to sick, starving family. Barely enough rubles for rent. No potato. Is sad.

This game is alot better than I ever expected it to be. I'm not even joking from the second I've gotten it I've been playing it non stop. It's such a simple game but so addictive. If you have a few extra dollars to spare, this is where you should spend it! Top buy

A game about endless bureaucracy and controlling documents being fun? Naah.  Instead yes, it is fun and it's much more complex than the decription lets you believe. As a nameless border control officer for the glorious nation of Arstotzka your responsibility is keeping the conspirators. smugglers and everyone who doesnt have the correct papers out of the country. Or, let the conspirators in, so they can overthrow your government. Or close an eye on the occasional smuggler ad get some money, or medicine for your family. The decision is yours, but every decision you make changes the scenario and can help you advance in the ranks- or end up in front of the firing squad. You ll be controlling expiration dates, international seals, photographs and fingerprints on the documents of hundreds of citizens .Try to do your best because at the end of the day your poor family can only count on you for surival.  Simple graphics and sound but with an excellent idea, a new challenges with each day, dark humour and a low price Papers Please is a must get.
Didnt expect i get into this game.17.2 hrs in and this is probably my game of the year for 2013.never knew something mundane like chopping passport could be so interesting.:)

Definitely not something you'd call a 'fun' game, but it's certainly interesting. A number of interesting moral dillemas will force you to pause and think, and the requirement to work fast really adds to the pressure. Multiple endings (20 in total) and a reasonably variable plot make things interesting, but it's doubtful you'll want to replay this. Can be completed in 4-10 hours, depending on how many times you replay days to compensate for mistakes. Big shout-out to the save system too, as it allows for branching saves to grant the freedom to experiment.

Essentially, a game about stamping stuff, then giving the stamped stuff back. Somehow, that's actually fun. Very hard to describe, unless you actually play it for yourself and find out exactly what it's like. This is a game loaded with moral decisions. Do you let this man in because he offers money for it, even though he has drugs on him? Do you let Jorgi in, even though is passport is obviously totally fraudulent? What do you do? Why is your mother-in-law alive? What am I asking you for? Why don't you have this game yet?  With 20 different endings, there's always a reason to go back and try again.
Addictive ...

Weirdly compelling. Strangely emotional. Bizarrely relaxing. Impossibly tense. These, and so many more, are totally valid descriptors for 'Papers, Please'. It's frankly a tragedy that there isn't a demo, because this is one of those games where it's inordinately difficult to explain to someone else WHY they should play it, especially when it basically amounts to a pen-pushing sim... except that it also amounts to so much more..   Does someone you know own the game? Drop in for a cuppa and give it a spin.   Have you seen it on sale? GRAB IT.   Sure, there's a chance you reallyyyyyy might not see the appeal, but there's also a chance you might find yourself wanting to spend untold, mortifying, dedicated hours of your life on it.   (Someone save me from this game.)

This game is absolutely wonderful. It exercises your brain and memory and if you're like me, you find yourself really getting into character. A woman needs to get into the country for surgury but doesn't have the required papers. But I'm barely getting by and my son needs medicine. As sorry as I am for her, I cannot take a 5 credit penatly on my pay. And with bribes and the occasional bombers, you really have to consider your actions and screenings. I really enjoy playing this game.
You want to fell like son of a ♥♥♥♥♥ and not let cross the border lots of people for lots of reasons?Here is your game ;)

Never thought paperwork and stamping documents could be this fun. Love organising my desk for maximum efficiency of movement and getting the timing down to allow as many stamps as possible. Mini stories are great, from the corrupt guards and shady organisations, to the individuals who you deal with on a one-to-one basis. BUY THIS GAME!!
It's like you've actually stepped into a really depressing documentary
Hilariously good...and depressingly frightening....
I dont understand why this game is so fun, but it is! I think its because I read everything with a thick Russian accent
Very fun, very great game. It's very addictive and i had a great time playing it
Simple, yet very fun gameplay. The story is shockingly sorta deep. All in all it is a very good game.

Short version: This game is GOOD, just make sure you give it an honest chance and I promise it will reveal itself to you.   This is one of those games you have to experience to truly appreciate, as it is fairly unique. I wouldn't say it's a 'fun' game, that's not really the point, but it is enjoyable and rewarding once you learn the rules. That being said, there are definitely some humorous moments that break up all the seriousness.  The game has a certain grace about it, it's very small from a content-perspective, but has enough variety to keep you on your toes. Without spoiling anything, there are several moments that will likely surprise you and you'll realize the developers really put thought into this. Even the standard game over screen is a mix of sadness and humor.  For better or worse, the game doesn't tell you much, which is nice because you learn and experience on the fly but that also means it takes some time to get the hang of, and definitely multiple tries to beat the campaign. Also, a few things seem arbitrary (example, closing/opening the shutters seems pointless?)  Some of the 'find-the-difference' details require a very specific cross-match, and takes some trial and error (or internet searching) to learn what needs to go with what.  On a final note, holy crap is that country's financial laws harsh: I only owe $5, please don't throw me in jail!!!

I tried to explain to a friend of mine about this game and how good it was, but after telling him that you play an ordinary border immigration clerk in a fictitious Soviet-esque state where you process their papers deciding whether they can enter or not....I didn't do a very good job.  Instead...just buy this game. Music is spot on, top down 8 bit graphics suit the game to a tee and the frantic scanning through papers just to earn 5 more credits for your family keeps you coming back for more. Brilliant.
For some reason this game, and the need to check everything for correctiness while looking for faults, is super addicting!

Excellent game. It seems overly simplistic and almost ridiculous when you first hear the premise, but the game does an excellent job of making the player feel the horror and guilt that the passport inspector goes through.

Glory to Arstotzka! You are a border passport agent in one of the most unique and inventive games I have seen in years. It's challenging enough inspecting every form as the number of forms and things to inspect increase on a daily basis under the increasingly onerous regulations. Under the surface is a surprisingly human game pitting your moral compass and the regulations of your government against the lives of the people in the checkpoint. Make too many mistakes and it may cost you and your family's health and maybe your life. Your choices matter as the game can end in a multitude of ways.   You will grow to hate the sound of a dot-matrix printer.
Really great indie game and has a intresting story line with 20 diffrent endings.

A frustratingly fiddley game that concentrates on attention to detail. New unlocks and story keep the game fresh as you play. Good setting and some humour too.  I can't see the game having much replay value, but i don't grudge buying it for sale price.  I only wish my document desk was bigger.
Papers, Please offers a unique gaming experience. Highly addictive if you're a perfectionist and wish to find out how far you can go.

It's quite entertaining and immersive. It can get a bit repetitive, but it's fun for some hours, mainly due to it being so different from anything else. Also, since it has various endings, the replayability is high. Since it costs less than 5Eur, pick it up.
More, Please  Lucas Pope should be working on dystopian games all the time. It's wonderful. Art, as someone already said.
One of the best games i have ever played
What an awesome game! So simple, yet you just can't stop enjoying this depressing dystopian nightmare =D
i love this game. challenging at times but fun

This is something everyone needs to play; a shockingly engaging simulation of cold war era beauracracy. The subtle way the plot unfolds through your indirect influence is brilliant, and the game will continue to tax your mind as the difficulty and number of rules ramp up.

I didn't know checkin' passports would be so interesting and funny. tho I passed this game months ago, I still find myself coming back to this game often. I don't have deep analysis on this game here, check out yourself if you're into interesting slow-tempo indie games that requires alot of perseption/concentration, and shows you a small story of a passport inspector.
this game is very addictive and fun!
Simple at first but get's very fun and complex in time. Sometimes you miss a small detail that matters whether they should pass or not.
This game deserves a GOTY award. waiting for part 2
Wow I did not expect this much enjoyment out of such a 'simple' game. I'm afraid I could lose many hours denying applications into the greatest country on earth, Arstotzka! Very much recommend.
The most fun way of playing this game to be a souless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me.
Very good game. Much thinking and moral. Maybe not the funniest. But an great experience.
Fun and unique game with a very engrossing atmosphere.

This game is outstanding. It's a revelation how it plays on the cognative overload of the task of stamping passport to keep you caring about your own success, the safety of your family and looking after the people who can look after you. The art style, music and writing fit so brilliantly with the cold war setting. I highly recommend investing the 7 - 10 hours it takes to explore the various paths of this game. Short, sharp and supremely special.
great story and mechanic

Papers Please is an amazing, addictive and thoroughly enjoyable experience. This is compleatly out there game that is diffrent to all other games i have played. But is certenly one of the best games i have ever played in my whole life.
Brilliant game and well worth the price. If You like to cocentrate and find the little details while being fast at the same time, this definetely is the game for You.

The concept sounds horrible: your job is to check passports at a Cold War Eastern European country. Yet somehow the game is utterly compelling. There's a larger storyline, plus some smaller ones and I found I really got ino them. Very addictive. I also love the minimalist blocky look & feel of the game: it fits perfectly with the subject matter.

Papers, Please is a nerve-racking immigration officer drama that, despite feeling repetitive about 8 levels in, still entertains in a terrifying way. Does this game prove that less is more in the future of video games? Possibly.
The man who made this is a genius, who would have thought a game where you check peoples credentials at a border crossing would make an epic game.
If you are bored with FPS games, this game is a good alternative. This game brings great joy/suffering.
Interesting, but not for me. I just couldn't emphasise with any of the characters and my only concern was getting it right by the book.
Very good, much narative, great job ! Its the game that most resonates as reality

One word that sums this game up - 'interesting', but a little bland. It's almost a world similar to George Orwell's '1984'.  To sum it all up, you're a character working at the border patrol for a dystopian and authoritative country. Each day, you decide who goes through, mostly based upon if they have the right documents or not. Making a wrong decision can be horrific, resulting in a terrorist attack (probably an inside job); as time progresses, the requirements for entering the country skyrocket. Sometimes letting people through is a question of morale - perhaps they forgot one document and their visa expires the next day... do you risk your job performance for another man's happiness?  One thing that is unique with Papers, Please is the various endings your game can have.  For being what it is, this game is alright. I would recommend it, but I wouldn't recommend it over a lot of games. It's a little quirky, quite dark, and you might be wandering what the hell you are doing on it... but at least you're entertained.
An emotional rollercoaster built on the frame of a game about checking documents. WTF score 9/10
I can't believe I bought this game, but even more surprising is that its actually pretty fun!
Passport Simulator  ♥♥♥♥ you Sheela .
Great game. Unusual premise that seems boring/banal becomes totally absorbing.

Purchased this game a while back on the recommendation of some friends, and while the game won't be a hit with everyone, it definitely was with me. It is slower paced, but still tense. It is simple, but with each added layer of paperwork, it gets complicated. It is hard to describe, and if you can look past its graphics, the meat and potatoes of it are quite enjoyable.

Papers, Please is a brilliant example of two things:  1: I am pretentious as ♥♥♥♥, and 2: That any kind of gameplay can be made engaging.  Papers, Please is a paperwork simulator, which on the surface sounds either absolutely stupid, or you think it's a game made by the same guys who made Goat Simulator and the upcoming Rock Simulator. Well, it's not. Lemme put you on track here. You live in the eastern-bloc country Arstotzka, which has just been in a 10-year war with the neighboring country Kolechia. You are given (more like forced) the job of checking the papers of all the poor sods who want to try and enter Arstotzka, and you have the final descision of giving them green stamp or red stamp. Over time, the bureaucracy intensifies, and the amount of paper that the immigrants supply you with increases as well, until they're handing you entire ♥♥♥♥ing scrapbooks. And if there's even one little flaw, then it's off to talk to the nice men with guns; in the building where people seem to go into a lot, but not out so much. Papers, Please is also probably the game that does moral choices best. It gives you many opportunities to: for example; a man has just entered, and his papers are all clear. Right before he exits the building, he tells you to be nice to his wife, who is just after him. She happens to be missing some of her papers, and so the decision manifests. You can let her in, allowing the two to reunite, but deduct from your salary that you need to pay for food for your family; or you can prioritize your familiy and tell her to ♥♥♥♥ off. It's a legitimate ethical question, that you'd never see in Mass Effect or ♥♥♥♥ like that.  All in all; Papers, Please is what I call good. That's all there is to say.     FNARR
Wow and game that really makes you work to move ahead. Not only are there many possible endings and ways the story can go, it also is a great re-play game value. So recommend this game. 9/10
Excellent game, great story!
Be wary, if you defy Arstotzka, they will know. Glory to Arstotzka!
This game is simple and yet incredible.  Such intelligent design and story.

Ok, hear me out: the premise of this game is paperwork, and a lot of it, but it's awesome. No really, it's awesome. A truly unique game with a gripping story, that has so little but so much going on at the same time. Fun to play as a wind down game, after a long day of toiling away at Counter Strike (or your preferred stressful game). Definitely recommended.

What is there to say about such a strange experience.....   I most certainly enjoy this game. It is odd though. I wouldn't so much as to say this game is super fun.... how fun can searching through documents looking for descrepensies really be? More than it sounds, that is for sure.  I started out thinking ok.... this is weird but I will give it a shot. Glad I did! Surprisingly addictive and simple. You start off kinda slow and gradually you find yourself flying through the rulebook, laying down the laws, and shutting people down! Making alliances with the guards to make more money by detaining people, great.   The more people you process the more money you make. You want to be quick but you don't want to overlook details and send someone through with false documentation, hello citations! You want to be quick, thorough, and precise. You want your dear family to live do you not? Then you must work. Hard.   My son died cold, hungry, and very sickly... will play again!
I really enjoy this game. Certainly off the 'beaten path' of game styles, and that's quite nice.

I was curious after hearing about this game as to how being a passport officer could be 'fun'. It is though, impossible to explain to other people, yes but really involving with a lot of heart and humour scattered throughout. Buy it, buy it now!

Proof that you can achieve a lot with a little. Compelling story backed up by surprisingly addictive and engaging gameplay, considering you're basically just doing data validation. Maybe the DWP should take advantage of gamers as a potential source of free labour? Maybe I should keep quiet in case they get any ideas...?
Excellent game, very clever.

Gameplay - this game make you prevail in working for mother Russia or you will die. Love the gameplay, simple, frustrating and fun. Controls - no remarks on this. It just works. Graphics - I think that the bit graphic makes this game justice as modern graphics would leave you with the presumption that there would be more to the game than it it. Music - One of the things I like the most with this game. Got me hooked instantly, I'm all set to serve the motherland. Score of 9/10.

I love this game because it's an experience unlike anything I've ever played before. As someone has said before, by explaining the brass tacks of this game it can sound very boring -- but there's just something about it that keeps me coming back. Maybe it's the story that seeps through reading between the lines. Maybe it's the immersive atmosphere that forces the player to make tough (very tough in some circumstances) decisions for the sake of your job, your family, and your country. Despite the vintage graphics and simple set up, 'Papers, Please' manages to string together catchy gameplay with a surpisingly deep story. 10/10.

This is a fun game, but there are some flaws that I feel are often swept under the rug because of the game's admirable, but indie status. The game makes you believe that this is a game that will revolve around choice. The truth is, it's quite the opposite. Much like the strong communistic element present in this game, the choices in this game come sparingly, and the consequences are almost always fatal. This game is more akin to a platformer in that there are a few but very linear paths you can take to reach the 'end.' Stray from that, and the game is absolute. This isnt always bad, but nearly is always punishing. Its a fun game, but I found it greatly overhyped, and equal parts fun and frustrating.

Ive been playing this game for a while, and boy is it fun. I would have never thought a game about border patrol checkpoint would be so fun. It gets a bit tougher as you keep going, you get confident and thats when you slip up. The look of this game is great, I cant wait for a sequel or an update. I highly reccomend this game.

It is a great game. I needs you to be smart and check every single detail under presure. It is a lot of fun and as you advance in the game it gets more complex as you go along, for example there is passport fogrey and more. I recommend this game to anybody who is interested in this kind of stuff.
A very innovative puzzel game. I was surprised at how much fun I had.
If only bureaucracy was this engaging in real life.

Some people like first-person shooters, some like fantasy role playing games, personally I have long waited to find a game for my own personal liking. Papers, Please! is a cold-war bureaucracy simulator. Have you ever wanted to work all day ensuring that arbitrary and unexplained rules are enforced? Well you get that AND you have to jugle your funds between heat, food and medicine to keep your family alive and well, its basically the best two games possible ALL IN ONE. Glory to Arstotzka!
This game can drive you crazy and make you laugh at the same time. 10점 만점에 10점

This game feels almost like a job, having to be very particular and careful about every little detail or you will get fined. I can't say I've ever played a game like this one though, and that is enough to change my mind. It is incredibly addicting searching through each immigrants papers for flaws for some odd reason.
