You stamp passports to let people in to glorious Arstotzka. Sound easy right?  Make sure face matches. Make sure height and weight matches. Make sure they have proper identification. Make sure they have proper paperwork. ...A bribe? Press the detain button. Search them. Make sure they are not smuggling goods in. Please present your passpo-  He's jumped over the barricades! Quickly now! Grab key! Use box! Grab gun! Load gun-!!!!!!  The terrorist detonated bomb strapped to body. Glorious Arstotzka now increasing security measures.  Help the resistance? Memorize paper and hand back. They'll come through later. Allow them access?  Jorji... you again? I have to call police. Yes, friend, I am sorry.  Day is over... now, should I feed my family or provide them heat? They are starving, cold and sick... they are all about to die.  All glory to Arstotzka.  This game is a document checking simulation. There is nothing fancy about it, but it will keep you playing to find out what happens next.  My tip to you comrade?  ...  ...  ...Deny those ♥♥♥♥ing reporters.  Glory to Arstotzka.

You become friends with certain guards and certain people.   I definitely recommend it!

Don't let the graphics fool you (well, it's an Indie-game, so that's pretty much a given)! This game is awesome in it's own right. You feel immeresed in the given universe immediatley after you start your first day in a border checkpoint. Your job get's harder from day to day (yes, that is possible in a checkpoint), whereas you still have to get enough money to care for your family but accepting and declining the 'right' persons in the always same time. I cursed a lot, when I wrongly accepted a citizen and got a penalty.... but that's life. I enjoy this game, really much!

Papers, Please puts you in a setting, time, culture and gives you something that imerses people no matter where they are: a job.  It never breaks character while you play, consistantly reminding you of your place and what your supposed to be doing--it's your job to be repetitive and to notice unwelcome changes.  As a checkpoint officer, your tasked with checking the passports of people coming in to Atrokska. After awhile, your job gets difficult with the fluxuations of rules tailored to the changing laws of your country.  Through it all, you must remain consistant, vigilant, and aware. ...unless you simply don't want to.   Papers, Please offers you multiple oppertunities to stray from the mundane repetitive nature of your employment, but simple choices could lead to huge outcomes; bad and good.   This title can offer you immersion without the player entirely realizing it, and indeed they do this very well. Before you know it, you step back from your PC wondering why you just spent three hours looking at passports.  No, seriously.  Passports.   In a game.    I suggest this title to anyone looking for a quirky but satisfying sim. Glory to Atroksa.

This game is definitely interesting, not something you really see or think about. I can only imagine that this is what it's like to be a European customs officer, but there is so much more to it than that (terrorist bombers, secret societies, spies.) I'm definitely intrigued by it, and the salary menu at the end of each level kinda terrifies me. Pretty much, if you don't make enough to support your family they'll get cold/sick/hungry and will die. Sure, this is a worry people have in real life, but a digital family that has no names or faces, just 'Son' and 'Wife,' is a little unnerving. Overall, if you want an experience, especially to help you identify with the stress of customs officers like the TSA, pick this up. $9.99 isn't too bad, and I really do find this game to be enjoyable, especially because it makes me think.

In a word: Fascinating. This game is so ridiculously simple at first, but it spirals rapidly within a matter of a few in-game days (about an hour of play or less). The elegance and minimalism of the retro graphics is a perfect backdrop for this multi-ending little paper-stamping adventure. You are a border checkpoint inspector, charged with allowing only sanctioned entrants into the fictional country of Arstotzka‎, run by a totalitarian regime of the 1980's. Each decision will affect you in some way, whether it increases your daily stipend through stipend or bribe, get you cited and penalized (causing you to be docked pay) or puts you squarely in the middle of international intrigue, possibly at the cost of your life or the lives of your family members.  If you are a highly detail-oriented person, like me, you will find the early stages of this game a snap. But watch out...and keep your finger in the digitally rendered rulebook!
Oddly addictive and fun to waste hours in. May not be for everyone.

I feel like I could love this game; the atmosphere, the visuals and what you end up having to do in order to prosper create a strange experience. This isn't a negative however, as the experience draws you in and makes you give a hoot about your family, who only appear as a list of names. The knowledge that someone you are expected to care about can be cold, hungry and sick based upon your actions weighs heavily upon your pixelated shoulders.  I come back to my opening words however, as I will recommend this to everyone who doesn't work in admin. If your job involves papers, dealing with complaints or the public and their documents, this game may not be that fun. I can appreciate the sentiment of this game, but when you work in similar fields, you feel a bit of a mug stamping passports and paying for the privilege, when you get paid to do similar work elsewhere!

Paper's Please - Documents not in order? Access to country denied. What I love about this game is the moral choices and the grey areas of moral choice it plays with. Also there is a great sense of yay, I found a discrepency, detain him/her. It certainly gives me a new appreciation for border control officers/security. The clever backdrop of pay per processed applicant and penalties if you get it wrong too often, means you cannot buy food, heat or medicine for your wife, son, uncle and mother in law.   The story is so clever, although it could be argued you have the power to let terrorists in, the Country is a dark communist dystopia, and you are poorly paid. Maybe you might agree with the terrorists and let them in to sort out the dictatorial state. I've read from another player there are twenty different endings, well this gives it some re-playability, however, that said, my only concern is that given a few months of stamping visas and passports, I might get fed up. For what it is though, an indie cleverly and well thought through game, I'd give it 8 out of 10. Plus you can get it for an amazing £3.49 while it's on offer so buy it now - or entry across the border may be denied!!

This is one of the best retro looking games and a unique (to me) concept. It is initially strangely addictive  playing a customs official for a centralised beaurocratic, I guess communist, state. You have to check documents for  people coming through your border check point and decide who to allow into the country depending on the authenticity of  the documents. Too many mistakes and your wages are docked and your family falls ill or starves due to lack of  heating, food, medicine etc. It strikes a fine balance between moral judgements and keeping your family alive. It  gets hard very quickly when you have to perform increasingly more complicated checks. That's its problem for me it  becomes too hard too quickly and feels more of a chore than a game to enjoy. It anyone wants to know what it feels  like to work 9-5 in an office job, particularly a customer service call centre, this is close.

I've only played this a little so far (4-5 'days' in the game), but it is really addictive. Each day adds complexity to your job as immigration officer at the border of some ficticious cold-war era country. The feeling is sad, totalitarian, hopeless. You're lucky to have this job, and your family has been put up in one of the ritzier concrete apartment blocks, where I'm sure there's only three rats instead of the normal ten. As the days progress and the government allows more entry with more fluidly changing requirements, you have to ensure that the documentation people present adds up. Names need to match, documents must be issued from the right place, do they have the right ticket, is it stamped and dated properly, etc. It's a seriously messed up brain game for adults! Oh you'll laugh your backsides off at some of the comments the people make, like trying to bribe you with tickets to the strip club. For the price of a cup or two of coffee, this is totally worth a few hours of your time if not many more.

If you think you've learned all the rules after a few days, think again! This game will make you check, double check, and triple check your decisions, all while upping the difficulty with each day. This game keeps you on your toes, engaged with each passing second. Every second counts; you need to earn enough to support your family, or it's game over. This is one of the reasons why I love this game; the other, because of the recurring characters and many choices 3909 presents us with. For example, would you like to spend a portion of your salary on a booth upgrade, or save it, not knowing if you'll have enough to pay for survival necessities in the future? Do you accept a large bribe, or play it honest?  Your job seems simple enough; admit or deny people into Arstotzka, according to the rules. Are you always going to play by the rules? Maybe you'll bend the rules to save a life, or accidentally admit a wanted criminal. Apart from the occasional instant recognition of a discrepancy, leading to either denying a person access to Arstotzka, or detaining them, most encounters demand meticulous scrutiny to avoid being penalized with a citation. Every day, the first two are warnings, then the M.O.A start docking your income per mistake.  You can revisit the timeline, and replay any day in the storyline. Will you go for a better score, make a different decision that alters your fate? You can do both. Not to sound clichè, but you don't need to spend blockbuster dollars to get blockbuster quality. If you're looking for a great distraction, get Papers, Please.

Even though I have to check documents at work in a similar fashion (though for a much different reason), I still found myself having fun using my skills to play this video game. Anyway, I say get this game and have fun playing it. DEATH TO ARSTOTZKA!!

One of the most fascinating games I've played and my #1 game of 2013. It understands a little something called subtlety...something that other triple a games don't understand. It gives you the (surprisingly) fun task of denying or accepting entry to the fictional Communist country of Arstotzka. Some of the people you review for entry talk and the stroy quietly unfolds. I call this type of story a quiet story and Portal is the same way, you are given a task and very subtley you realize what's going on. You make your own decisions in such an intricate way and it shocks me how many different endings there are. It's something you have to experience. Who would have guessed that a game about stamping passports would be the most fun game I've played all year.

Papers, Please is a masterful piece. You play as the lone border inspector at the only crossing of a secluded eastern european nation only just beginning to open to foreigners. It is amazingly deep and each day has something new, introducing game mechanics in the form of more stringent immigration policies, work permits, frauds, and even weaponry. I was hooked onto this game, and I love the dystopian setting. Even though the graphics are barely there in an aesthetic that harkens back to early PC gaming. it serves just enough to have purpose and I think it works perfectly.  There is also a surprising amount of choice to the game. From determining the fate of those seeking to gain entry without the proper papers to things much deeper, and perhaps more sinister. I've found myself playing a cold man following protocol, until certain events eventually led me to sacrifice nearly everything for the wellbeing of my nation. And guess what, that's maybe one out of 20 or so endings. One playthrough will probably get you a few hours, but in my opinion, the story mode is worth replaying for everything you might have missed, not to mention an 'endless mode'.  Additionally, it's not all easy. You must also use your meager income to pay rent and care for your family, which makes the idea of bribes and other incentives all the more appealing.  I heartily recommend this game, even if for the fact that it serves as a very good narrative of what the United States and other nations have done with their travel policies.

At first glance, the game looks like Tedious Desk Job Simulator 9000. But when delved deeper into the story of an Arstotzkan Immigration Inspector, you find that the job is not so easy as it looks. New days mean new laws, and potentially new terrorist attacks. Between keeping your job, getting arrested, getting killed, fleeing the country, or becoming an anti-government freedom fighter, Papers, Please really hit the nail on the head for a very gripping story with constantly changing and challenging gameplay.

Proving once and for all that good, solid gameplay and an engaging story will beat bleeding-edge graphics any day in a video game. Not only does it put next-gen console games to shame, but it does so with the most ridiculous handicap -- the premise of the game is based ENTIRELY on stamping 'Approved' or 'Denied' on passports at a border crossing.  The game stays intensely challenging from the first 'day' till the last, adding new rules each day to accomedate game events. About halfway through you start realizing that stamping 'Accepted' or 'Denied' requires far more thought and consideration than the multitude of rules the game throws at you.  There was not a moment I was disappointed in this game. Would recommend to literally anybody.

'First, you say 'where are your papers?' If it goes further than that, it's too late to be saying anything at all...'  Welcome to Paper's Please, a game about being a low level beaurucrat whose job is to make sure that people who enter your country have legitimate papers, are not criminals, and are not smuggling contraband.  Working at your post pays poorly, and you are overworked by an uncaring, faceless government, but you need the money. Your family is at home, and you provide for all of them. If you don't make enough money, they will starve, grow sick, or simply be forced to scavenge for whatever they can because you have been taken to prison because of your debts.  Of course, if that's not enough, there are terrorists who want to tear down your government, and they think that you might be perfect for a new position that just opened up...  Papers Please takes the form of a simple eight bit game where the screen is split into three parts. The top part shows you your workplace, and everything that's going on around you, from the massive line trying to get in, to the armed, poorly trained guards there to keep order and shoot anyone who breaks rules. The left side shows the person trying to get in, and a small desk where all documents are placed, and the right side is your workspace, where you drag documents to and check them against a list of rules that is prone to politics, random changes to fit world events, and other problems.  Not only, however, must you keep these rules in mind, but corruption is the game of the day, and between trying to make more money in not entirely honest ways, to having to bow down to a corrupt superior, life is hard. And your job keeps getting harder.  You only have twelve minutes per level to process as many applicants as possible, and they have a lot of paper work for you. You only get paid for who gets in, however, so be careful not to send too many away. Of course, you can choose to activate an easy mode that sees you get 20 dollars a day regardless of performance, but that's not enough to cover everything.  Ultimately, this is a surpisingly tense game that is more about atmospshere than action, a game that asks hard things of you, and makes you question the rules. How far will you go to feed your family, and how much will you do to help others in a world where there are penalties for doing so?  That's up to you, I suppose.

To paraphrase Orwell, fascism is an inspector stamping on passport photos forever. Further spiked with narrative incidence and moral choices it's also a deceptively complex game, much more interesting then it's presentation initially led me to believe. Recommended if you're looking for something different and challenging.

I'll admit, when I first saw this game, I was only mildly interested in it, just from what the trailer showed. Then it was on sale one day, so I decided what the heck, I'll try it.  It's a hit. It may not seem like much, but sometimes its hard to stop. 'Just one more day, or maybe naw...' I thought there wasn't a story mode but that's all there is at first. The policies and documents get compounded further and further as relations between the fictional country of Arstotzka and the other nations of the Seven Member Forum slowly deteriorate. The game is relatively open-ended. There are TWENTY possible endings (most of which involve the player getting arrested, but hey, do your job and you've got nothing to fear). There is a degree of suspense too.  Sometimes my siblings watch me play it. And when I told them it was available on the iPad as well, my brother wasted no time buying it for himself. Everyone loves playing it.  Great for all types of players.  Story mode of 31 playable days, 20 possible endings, achievements and an unlockable ENDLESS mode. I highly recommend this game

This game can be a chore, it can be flat out boring and at times even feels like performing a real job.  And I absolutely ♥♥♥♥ing love it.  Papers, Please achieves what it strives to accomplish flawlessly, it haves you deal with choice, morals and monotonist work with the anxiety of the real struggle of providing for a family. The game sits you at the seat of a checkpoint for the fictional country of Arstotzka where you must asses people and decide whether they will be accepted entry into your country or denied based on a set of ever changing rules and guidlines. Once you open the checkpoint each day you are put on a timer, when this timer is finished the day will be over and you will be rewarded for every person you correctly assesed or penalized for each person who wrongfully accepted or denied entry. You will also be given a screen displaying your family including your wife, son, daughter and mother-in-law (as well as the possiblity of others depending on the path of your story) as well as their independent status' your financial screen which will show your savings, wages, rent and if you are low on funds you will decide whether you wish to buy heat for your appartment or food for your family as well as optional upgrades to your booth which are essentialy hot keys.  Throughout the game you will be given moral choices as to who you accept or deny as an example fairly early on the game (around day 4 or 5) a man is trying to escape a country with his wife as due to some sort of political issues they will be excuted similar to that of prejudices during WWII, his passport checks out fine so you let him through and his wife follows suit however her information is improper so now you may either accept her into the country and be penalized for it or deny her and let her die wrongfully and alone. While some may ignore these choices as neither of these characters are heard from again further in the story you will be given much larger choices which will impact the story, the way your checkpoint is run and even your family.  On the subject of your family they are one of the few short comings of this game, while you need to pay rent (if you are unable to pay rent the game will end) your own well being is not dependent on food or heat, this is simply to provide for your family. Your family is never actually seen nor is there any sort of interaction or dialogue between them and yourself, they are simply a status screen at the end of the day and you are not given any reason to care about them other than 'they're your family'.  As I said at the begining the game can be boring and at times will be hard to find enjoyment in actually playing but that's part of this games beauty, it manages to have you feeling like you're performing menial work and as if you truly are just trying to get by but there's something about it that just keeps you going and wanting to continue. However on that note I would reccomend playing the game in sessions as I found myself getting tired after long sittings with the game and ended up messing up more often, once again much like being exhausted with real work.  While I may not agree that this game is 'art' as some may call it I will say that the game is a beautiful piece and a powerful statement on many aspects of politics and human nature. That all being said I highly reccomend this game and encourage you to play it.  Glory to Arstotzka.

The entire premise DOES seem boring. I'll admit it. Yet this game has a lot more to offer than stamping papers in a booth...oh wait no it doesnt...but its FUN! Aside from learning what its like to protect a border from criminals, this game has a secret or two up its sleeves involving a shady society of rebels. There is also fun funny foreign guy who keeps forging documents in crayons.  In all seriousness, the game is a morality decision simulator. You will encounter all sorts of 'grey areas' during your work. Will you split up a married couple with the wrong forms? Take a bribe to buy your kid medicine? Let a celebrity or politician through who sort of looks like a wanted criminal? YOU DECIDE!  I truly recommend it at its discounted price. If I had paid over 10 bucks I would consider myself ripped off...but for 4.99 this game has entertained me for quite some time.   WARNING!!!! - This game is incredibly addictive and if you are like every gamer or person with a steam account, and you posess an obsession with video games, be prepared to spend hours at a time stamping papers in a virtual world while your family or significant other cooks dinner and gripes about your lack of interest.

A lot of designers and publishers want you to believe you get to make meaningful moral choices in their games. I don't think I've ever played a game where moral choice was so convincingly integrated with gameplay as in Papers, Please.  There's so much to admire in this game. That said, if you don't like checking documents for accuracy, you're probably not going to like the gameplay -- and you have to like the gameplay, at least on some level, to really admire the rest of the game.

So I don't plan on playing it again in the foreseeable future (partly due to the many games entering my inventory via the sale) but I had a fun night with it, and would recommend it.

'Glory to Artotska!' When I bought Papers, Please, I expected a quiet, little border simulation. I never expected to be torn into pieces between what to do. While I just recently bought this game, (20.6.2014), I feel like I've already experienced so much, so quickly. Do you let the people in who try to weasel their way in, or the people who need their way in? If you chose the latter, you end up working against your government which negatively affects your family.  This is a game about life decisions. And its beautiful.  About the game: - Pixely art style - Cheap - Endless mode - Story based  9.5/10

Papers, Please is a bleak game, set in the harsh world of a Soviet-esque satellite republic. You and your family suffer for your every mistake, and even your efficiency is poorly rewarded.   It's a difficult game, built on recognizing documents and analyzing them as valid, in addition to spotting discrepancies. As your money dwindles, you begin to find moral quandaries: Do you take a bribe to let someone with invalid documents inside your country, or do you keep your meager earnings and reject them? Do you help the desperate at your own peril, or do you only worry about yourself?  With each day, the demands placed on you grow, and with every person you don't process properly, you find yourself unpaid at best, and possibly penalized financially at worst. Why would you play such a game set in such an unforgiving world? Because it's brilliant. It's compelling. Every mistake you make, you KNOW it was your fault. Every unsatisfactory ending makes you want to try harder for the next time, so you can find something, ANYTHING to make this story have a happy ending, even if it seems impossible.  This game is pure brilliance, distilled into a low res form. Unless you simply must have cutting edge graphics, or can't stand a difficult game, you owe it to yourself to buy a copy.  9/10
Really good addicitive game.
10/10, would stamp again.
Pretty damn cool, I had my doubts at first but this is turning out to be quite a fun game. Definitely recommend.

I guess my life has hit a new level of sadness.  In my normal day to day job im an office worker, public sector, work with lots of data and figures, challenging but rewarding work.  So i download papers please and now im obsessed with the tiniest details on peoples passports lol.  Such a simple premise for a game yet has me hooked.  Also i guess im the wrong person to be struck by the 'moral' choices in the game, i guess my day job has made me desensitised to the excuses  Whats that your son is sick and you need to get into the country to see him, ohh well im sorry your surname on your passport doesnt match your permit. This is phenomenal indie game that does a good job of making you feel like an actual immigration officer. It starts out fairly simple and easy, but as it goes on it becomes more and more difficult to the point of being stressful(which isn't a bad thing, since that is how you're meant to feel). The game also has a lot of quirky characters that you meet throughout the story mode - some of them are funny, and some of them will try to guilt trip you into accepting their passport.   It is a truly unique experience that is well worth the money.

Unique, funny and challenging, Papers Please is unlike any other game you've ever played. Set in a fictional totalitarian country, you act as a border checkpoint guard struggling to keep your family warm, fed, and healthy. Paid by the number of people you screen daily, you will encounter forgers, smugglers, and, even more morally challenging, people trying to visit sick relatives with improper paperwork. Do you call to your humanity, let them through, and risk your family's welfare and imprisonment? Or do you stamp denied on their passport to their curses and possible future retributions?  To say more of this very clever game would spoil it but it is a steal at the price for modern gaming ingenuity at its finest.

Get this game on sale while you can! It is a fantastic indie game that shows the potential of video gaming. Games with moral choices are often too simple and binary with predictable results. This game removes the boring of the binary and sometimes throws the player for a loop with the complexity of reality. It is impossible to play just once and is well worth the price.

The only bad thing about this game is the resolution support (Total of 3 resolutions) with black bars for the rest. This is a great game! However, I can see it not being everyone's type of game. This is the kind of game that you will either LOVE the subtle detailed beauty and gradual climbing challenge and complexity... OR the kind of the game that you get INSTANTLY bored of. It appeals to a very specific kind of player, in a very rich rewarding way.  The game challenges the player to go to the same office (same screen), and encounter a routine job that requires the player to balance their character's needs, with doing a great job that requires a GREAT deal of attention to detail. This is a game of bureaucratical paper-work and power to change the lives of hundreds of little people. One of the great things about this game is how it gives us a glimpse into the complexities of the old cold-war countries and their struggles with challenges to their way of life, but not as most games where you are an all-powerful head of state, but as a lowly appointed officer, just doing their beurocratical job, a job at the border.

Surprisingly addictive with simple graphics and storyline, loving the various endings and how your decision making can alter them. The game focuses on the emotional toll of working as an immigration officer, and that's what makes Papers, Please such a unique game.  Glory to Arstotzka!

She was ahead in line, and told me to do something about him. Even though he had legitimate documentation, out of the goodness of my heart, I refused him entry. After being penalized for mistakes earlier, my 'unfair denial' led to me being fined for it, and my family suffered without a necessity because of it. This game shouldn't even be fun. I can't explain why I'm enjoying stamping passports.  Maybe it's my pride in catching the subtle errors in forgeries. Maybe it's the moral dilemmas - Do I let this man's wife pass without a ticket and get a 5-credit citation, or do I deny her entry so I can buy medicine for my son? Maybe it's the revolution that's occurring around me that I have a key position in stopping or supporting. Or maybe it's just because I get a kick out of detaining people for no reason.  Whatever the reason, this game makes a monotonous job into an intriguing and enjoyable challenge.

I came into this game with only a little knowledge of how it was going to play. I first found out about the game through one of my favorite Youtubers, OfficialNerdCubed. Immediately after I saw him play it, I went out, got myself a Steam card, then bought Papers, Please. I sat down the next day and decided to play a little bit of it, to see if I like it. Four hours later, my eyes were darting from paper to paper, trying to find the discrepancies, because whenever you let someone into your country, you automatically tense up, and wait to hear that damned printer noise, printing out your 'YOU WERE WRONG' ticket. It's honestly one of the most tense times in any video game I've ever really played. I've seen reviews on this saying 'Oh this is the boring job simulator and is stupid.' To those people, I would simply like to say that you are impatient morons who should really just go back to Call of Duty. There are only two games in the WORLD at the moment that I would consider, near-perfect. Those two games are, the orginal Portal, and Papers, Please. I'm currently only at about 14-15 hours on this game, but I'm soon going to shoot right up in hours played, because I remembered that I had 'Endless mode' unlocked. So, my record is 58 people processed without getting one wrong, and I intend to push that to at least 100. If I had to give this game a traditional score, it would be a 9.8-10. If you take anything at all out of this review, take the fact that it's an incredible, innovative game made by a genius man. Also, if anyone is interested, me and a group of friends have a very-amateur Youtube channel going at the moment. Division 4 Gaming. Please do check it out!   -That One Guy, CrisisSpectre

The best you can get out of a simulation game like itself. It is unique, it has no cons. Everyone should get this game and it is definetly worth the money.   http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V4GWyd7vhj0  - Glory to Arstotzkan  10/10

Essentially, the game part of the game is about memory and pattern recognition/matching. Do this person's papers match with their other papers? With the official guidelines? With what you can see? Be sure, but be quick. The clock is ticking, and you need to make your quota to keep your family warm and fed.  If you were hot ♥♥♥♥ at the 'spot the differences between these two pictures' puzzles in children's magazines, you'll no doubt do well. But it also requires a bit of the mindset needed to get the same level of enjoyment out of the same type of puzzles in parody magazines, where you're shown two identical pictures and then told 'The doctor on the left is telling his patient he has an inoperable brain tumor. The doctor on the right is telling his patient he has bubonic plague.'

This is quite a unique puzzle game. It really gets you thinking about the throught process, difficulties, and compromises that a border control officer has to go through.  The game mechanics create an awesome sense of heightening difficulty as the political situation surrounding immigration changes. As more and more regulations and checks were applied, I had to think - do I carefully scrutinize every person, or do I take a chance and sacrifice accuracy for speed in order to make more money to feed my family? Among that was a host of other interesting choices the game presents you with. And it has 20 endings!  This is a game I'll be playing for quite a while. My first playthrough clocked in at 2 hours, so if you explore every option in story mode, you'll get 40 hours at least, easy. Very much worth it.
Pretty fun game even though the premise is kinda boring. interactions with people in story mode are funny. The game slowly adds more rules to follow in order to keep it challenging.

“..it is absorbing, brilliantly written and causes you to question your every instinct and reaction - both in the game and in real life.” Eurogamer   This is all i can say about this , simple and short. Glory to Arstotzka......!!!
Better than COD.- 10/10 IGN
The best pound sterling I ever spent.
This game in less than 15 minutes makes you a declared bureaucrat, who would sell his own mother (ok, mother-in-law) for 5 bucks if given the chance. Zimbardo experiment for gamers. 10/10
I spent my life, yearning for purpose. Finally, my borish luck has changed! my identification number has been pulled from the employment roulette. My family will have a feast tonight!
Awesome game with hours of play. It would be awesome if they came out with dlc's!
i dont know why i keep going back to play thiz game ?? maybe itz good !!!
Very different sim game. I was intrigued when I purchased it and though I have just began I found it to be rather fun.
Strangely addictive immigration officer simulator... just when you thought Indie games couldn't get any weirder!  Jorji Costava rocks ;)
If you like activities that include stamping passports, taking bribes, making morally questionable decisions and struggling to keep your family alive, this game is for you.
Pretty fun and addicting game, its perfect to kill time
My second favorite game of 2013, and Pikmin 3 first isn't on Steam, so...

Probably the best game (of any genre) I have played in a long time....and for a game whose premise is verifying documents at a border post during the Cold War, that is more than a bit impressive. The game play is tough, but interesting with more creative solutions available than it even seems initially. It is part puzzler, part morality tester, part cold-war satire, all awesome.

'Papers, Please' is a seemingly monotonous concept on its surface, but the game quickly takes the player on a journey through the life of a Border Checkpoint Official working for family and the citizens of outlying countries fighting to survive between high tensions of this European Cold War dystopian era.  Those who are hesitant to pickup a game that seems to be a simulation desk job about processing paperwork are already missing one of themes of 'Papers, Please'. The games challenges the player to not view the both the in game world and real world as if it is black and white. But at the same time 'Papers, Please' punishes you if you act with morals but shames you for acting against what is right vs. wrong thus adding to the tension of this intense adventure.  Each day you will meet new people, from high class citizens who wish to escape the 'pathetic lesser countries'. To middle class and below who are trying to run from something or someone, and they must now ask you to decide the next step of their life. Either you ignore the discrepancies and take a citation and pay cut for letting someone in without a Passport, or you send them back to where they came from and possibly sentence them to a life of sex slavery or worse. But what if they are lying? What if its a ploy to sneak into the country? What if this is one of those terrorists who is about to disrupt the border and not only dock your pay for making a mistake, but cut your work day short with a bombing-thus causing an even shorter salary pushing you down this slippery slope to another life changing decision; cut out rent in this salary's budget and face the rent raising, or cut out medicine for your sick child and hope the sickness does not progress. You cut out food last budget to help pay for heat this budget, your child should be OK... Right?  The fate of these countries and its citizens, and also the fate of your family is yours in 'Papers, Please'. With multiple endings, the player has many ways to journey through this story of, right vs wrong, conspiracy and revolution. All with one simple answer, 'Approved' or Denied'?  Glory to Arstotzka
This game is simply amazing. I dont really know what to say but I do reccomend you check out Nerd3 videos on it.

Glory to Arstotzka! This grim border checkpoint sim pulls of an amazing combination of the drudge of bureaucracy colored by hard moral choices between blindly carrying on your work to feed your family versus showing compassionate mercy.

When I first heard about this game I thought is was some pretentious social commentary game, and to some extent it is. But it is really so much more than that. The gameplay is very addictive, and the various sub-plots, choices, and characters kept me interested despite the relatively small size of the game. The 20 different endings and endless mode give it lots of replayablility, and for a one song soundtrack... it sure gets in your head.
Interesting gameplay, cool style, slightly cumbersome controls. I'm enjoying it so far though.

Like when i saw this game i was all like ' Damn this game is like damn.' Then i proceded to kill myself and by this game right after. Mah boi bought this game for me and it's fo reals fun and I'd recommend this game for people that want to live in a country like Russia or want to control the boarder. Mostly though I'd recommend this game for mounties that want to catch the Mexicans jumping the boarders.

Hesitant at first... seems monotonous (which it is!), but turned out to be really addictive. More than just a paperwork simulator, it shows the mentality of being the immigration inspector of a communist society. Definitely one of my favourites.   Glory to Arstotzka.
Simple, fun, and has a excellent learning curve. Don't let the price fool you, you could potentially lose hours to this game's 'one more turn' feeling
You get to deny people for no reason. AWESOME!!!

Great absorbing game its gameplay gets more and more complex as it advances and you have to be keen about even the smallest mistakes and sometimes you have to choose between re-uniting a family or being able to feed your own family sometimes your mistakes may not seem to have much of an impact until you realize you just let a suicide bomber slip through and it kills 5 guards or you just let a serial child killer into the country would recommend can run on just about any computer and is put on sale all the time
GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Honestly, there's not much to say about this game other than 'I like it' and 'you should play it,' because I like it and think you should play it.  There's something to be said about games that simulate actual work, and this game really takes on a life of its own. It has a real personality to it. You are a guy from what is basically a fantasy Soviet state and you were just assigned a position as stamp man at the newly opened border checkpoint in West Grestin, Arstotzka. At first you must check simple paperwork (valid ID, Arstotzkans only), but as time goes on there will be more government regulations regarding work permits, fingerprinting, contraband, diplomatic paperwork, counterfeiting, etc. that will have you on edge searching for what could be wrong.  It's not just the paperwork checking that is interesting here, but the human relations part too. Sometimes you are compelled to allow a person to slip by because of one reason or other, and other times deny a person who has proper paperwork because of certain tips. Sometimes you must choose whether or not to take a bribe because you have family that you need to feed. You get paid per person that you process as well, so there is also the dilemma of wanting to rush the papers and risk citation and potential fines, or making sure the papers are in order.
This is a great game for passing the time. It can be hard at times if you aren't quick and efficient, but it's still really fun. It's worth the $10.

The game itself seems like a very simple 'find the differences' game to start, but it evolves quickly into a game of dexterity and concentration. You realise that you can't always just take your time to get it right and be perfect. You have to process a lot of papers just to keep your family fed and warm, and sometimes you have to sacrifice food, or heat, or that present your kid wants, or medicine. You also realise the while someone has all the right paperwork, you might want to take that hit and warning and deny them. That works the other way where you may let someone in intentionally, take the warning or penalty, but it could be for a good reason or bribe. I've seen 1 ending so far, and there are 20 different endings to this, so the choices you make will mean many different possibilites. I got it for $5 but I would say it is worth the retail $10.

I don't normally play indie games, but Papers, Please is one of those rare titles that everyone should at least try. Set in the fictional communist country of Arstotzka, you take the role of an immigration inspector at a border checkpoint. You must look over documents and use various tools in order to keep spies, smugglers and other unwanted bad people out of the country all while on the clock. On top of this you have to make enough money to support your family and survive yourself. Will you follow the rules or turn to taking bribes to make ends meet? It may sound easy and perhaps even boring, but trust me that once you dive in it is really exciting. Glory to Arstotzka!

Deeply moving.   Getting the negatives out of the way first. The game is a little slow paced though, definitely wish there was a slightly easier difficulty, with shorter day-cycles to give more of an opportunity to enjoy replaying it. People may say 'The game is meant to be slow, it's the whole idea' but there is definitely a feeling of wading through the marshes that are put off by this game.  Now for the positives. This game is an incredibly singular experience, having never seen anything akin to it in any form of media I really did enjoy it. I highly recommend giving this game a go, even if you aren't big on emotional experiences.
Lots of detail, always changing the rules. I found it fun. Lots of different choices can be made that affect the way the game plays through.
It's very interesting game.

This is a game for those seeking a new experience. It is part adventure puzzler part investigation. The website quotes are not kidding, this game will make you think, you have to manage the job, income for your family and the safety of a country.  This game is fantastic.

I'm not going to beat around the bush- this game is perfect. It is without question the best indie game I have ever played. It is worth $10 and then some. If you have a chance to pick this gem up, do so without hesitation.

Papers, Please is more than just stamping passports, it is a cynical examination of life as we know it, where small differences can mean the difference between life and death. While playing, the player faces many choices, tasked with rooting out the small differences in people in order to keep them separate. The player can choose to be the humanitarian, or they can choose to safeguard themselves. In these choices, which seem small at the time, the true message of Papers, Please; emerges. It shows that we are all not so different from one another, though we always exploit those differences.
Beautiful game inspired by the USSR regeme! Recommended to all

This game is fun. Not in the action packed seat of your pants way but in the fact that after the tenth, twentieth or so individual you process, you begin to see them as just ID papers and such, not as human beings. Balancing your morality in helping a husband and wife stay together even when one's passport is expired, at the expense of maybe not making rent or being able to feed your kids or buy them medicine makes for an exciting balance between doing your job and being a human being. it's a lot of fun, even if the pictures and trailer make it seem mundane.

Its nice to see a game that can make my sympathize with my enemy in such a through but petty way. I've always thought of immigration officers as a specific kind of demon. All and all, this is the best paperwork simulator ever made and I'mnot sure thats a compliment. Good fun!
One of the most original games I have played in years. Highly recommend.

You play a border inspector of a soviet-ish country. Its surprsingly challenging and addictive. The way the stories develop and the choices it forces you to make are also interesting. We wound up playing days over again to try out different decisions.   It sort of feels like a 90s era mac game, both graphically and in terms of the mechanics. You have a desktop where you investigate paperwork with limited space, and you have to pick up the papers and move them on to the desktop, etc.  Check it out!

At first glance, 'Papers, Please' might appear to be a monotonous, boring game. However, after a few minutes you discover this isn't the case at all. It really does a wonderful job of pulling you into the story and ramps the difficulty up until it becomes amazingly difficult to meet your quota. Each day begins with a new rule to use when deciding to allow people into the country or deny them. Don't let enough people though? Looks like your family doesn't eat that day. Make too many mistakes? Go to jail. Let in the wrong person? Right this way, comrade -- we have some questions for you. We'll find a new worker.   An amazing experience and highly recommended. I love it.  Glory to Arstotzka!
NEVER BEFORE HAVE I BEEN SO HONOURED TO BE A BOARDER GUARD FOR MY COUNTRY. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

You would think that it would be boring being a passport checking bureaucrat of a dystopian soviet-esque country, but you would be wrong - it's actually quite fun! Do you let the weird guy through who comes back day after day with bad credentials until finally he has good ones? Do you let the man's wife through, even though she has none? Remember, you need to feed your own family and bring glory to Arstotzka, and you can't if you're not doing your job properly!  The soundtrack, effects, and overall artistic atmosphere are simple, and yet they're more masterful than many other games out there. 'Papers, Please' is worth the money. Get it and support the devs. Seriously.
Who knew it would be so fun? All glory to Arstotzka. It starts off simple and gets increasingly challenging, it's an odd blast!

Good. Damn good. Weirdly damnly good. Set aisde a couple days, and set aside your preconceptions, and play a damn weird little good game that's not like anything you've played before. Well. Unless you work in data entry, I guess.

This game is awesome!   Who knew that being a bureaucrat would be so much fun?!   The music is cool, the art is cool, the gameplay is cool. This is one of those games that you can lose a couple hours in.   What's even better is, there is some real replayability in it. Maybe the first time through (if you finished), you sided with the rebels. Second time through, you sided with the state. Third time through, you tried to save your family. And so on!  Buy this game (for under $10).

Best puzzle game I've ever played. I call it a puzzle game, because you are essentially comparing documents and trying to find flaws. The game gets increasingly more difficult as you progress. At the point of this recommendation, It's normal for someone crossing the border to give me 4 documents to compare. The game is polished and worth the full price.

Papers Please is easily one of the most engrossing gaming experiences I've ever seen. It's been a long time since I was so invested in my character's well-being, which came as a surprise in a game about a border guard post.  Easily worth $10 and then some. Buy it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
An amazing indie-game. Succumb to the communist leaders of Glorious Arstotzka or try to help the resistance from your post as the border control agent.

This is not a game for everybody.  It will not be a relaxing gaming session if you decide to play Papers Please. Instead, you will be required to really focus and try to do your thing the best possible way you can. Even though you might think that what Papers Please has to offer may be boring or not interesting, it is surprisingly intriguing as you realize that the storyline of the game is more than you thought. Papers Please has 20 endings, all of them are dependent on the player's actions. There are entire storylines that can end differently depending on what you do in the game and I recommend playing through the story mode a couple of times just to see how many things could go the opposite way.  After 2 full playthroughs I think it's the engagement the game requires from the player that is so appealing to me and I have to say that I've had a lot more fun with Papers Please than with any other video game that came out this year. Definitelly worth the price if you think you might like something a bit different in gameplay.
This game is pretty much amazing and well worth the 10 bucks.

The story is excellent, in that the story is about you, a poor working stiff trying to survive day-to-day, and the things that happen to you as you push papers for a fascist state.  The mechanics of your paper-pushing are lovingly implemented in the game. Everything about the game makes you feel the right way - the music, how you are shown the guards, how you are shown the civilians, the way the game makes you feel about stamping a visa, everything.  The game is challenging. You are constantly presented with choices, and thinking too long about any of them means doing a poor job and most likely getting your pay docked.

This game is amazing. You are just a border guard stamping papers to either allow or deny people trying to enter Arstotzka (so basically it's a country under the soviet control in the cold war era). I'm not sure where I begin to explain why this game is awesome, wait, actually I do. The music. It is amazing. There is one theme to this game, and it's so bloody effective and perfectly captures the mood of the game; it is bleak, desolate, depressing and oppressive and I love it. The gameplay is deceptively simple and engaging, and considering how mundane the task of what you are doing it is hard to pull away. The game can be quite harsh to the player while asking you to make you to make decisions and the effects are not always clear right away. This game is the perfect marriage of theme and mechanics and is a masterpiece.
Really good little game with a great backstory and suprisingly very RPG like!

Papers, Please.  Ever wondered what it would like to work in the passport office? No? Ever wanted to play a game where you work as a passport officer?  .....No?   Well you wish you had.  This game is possibly discribed as a puzzle game, check the faults in the passport. however what if you were to bend the rules if it meant to feed your kids? or maybe overthrow a corrupt government?  anyway 5/5
If you are a fan of dystopic society novels and indie games, this is THE GAME for you. Very interesting and refreshing experience from which you are bound to take away personal insights
This game is fantastic, and unlike probably anything else you've played.

Unique title that is surprisingly good at challenging your memory and ability to detect small changes in a time sensitive environment. Can be mentally exhausting yet engrossing. Should only be played when your brain is fully alert.

Played this game when it was in the beta and absolutely loved it. It's amazing how such a boring idea like being a checkpoint officer can make such a fun and engaging game. For the small download size and lack of amazing graphics, there's so much content packed into this game with a in-depth story that can take a sudden turn at any moment depending on what you do. That man you just let in could have been a spy, maybe he's helping a secret agency to overthrow the government and you're now part of the conspiracy, or maybe he really is just a guy coming to work. You can only really know if you say the magic words; Papers, please.
So much fun. Can really burn away time that you don't know what to do with (in a good way).
A suprisingly addictive game, one of the best indie games I've played.

Now, I just recently beat 'Papers, Please' and thoroughly enjoyed myself.  In this game, you live in the made-up Communist nation of Arstotzka and your name has been drawn in a 'labor lottery' which I have never heard of before, but I imagine is similar to jury duty in America. The particular job you have been given (regardless of whether you want it, because hey, it's communism) is to be a border checkpoint worker. Your family is given a house to live in, but you must provide enough money to keep them safe and sound.  This game starts off quite linear and intriguing as you admit or decline people based on their paperwork and the rules you are issued everyday before starting. As time goes on however, events happen and more rules are added into your book to help ensure the safety of Arstotzka. Each day, you only have so much time to process people and that puts a lot of pressure on you because you have a family you have to pay the bills for.   This game presents you with many choices throughout. Some of these are moral choices or opportunities to make some money. Not all the opportunities are legal though...How much are you willing to do to compromise the nation's security to make sure you have food on the table? There are twenty different endings and the game makes you feel like your decisions actually matter.  As far as gameplay alone goes during the process of admitting applicants, it is actually exhilarating. You know you need to do a good job of examing their paperwork so that you don't lose money or even your job, but you also just want to work as fast as possible to get more money for your son's medication, or to pay the heat bill, or whatever the game throws at you. The rules constantly change and evolve with the times and it makes gameplay an enthusiastic struggle of work ethics, money, and guilt.   I cannot say how thoroughly impressed I am that one man alone made this game. It is definitely worth playing. 10/10.
Papers, Please is incredibly stressful and somewhat depressing. 10/10 highly reccomend.

C-64 graphics but high quality sounds. You are an inspector on the borders of a (fictional) communist country in the early 80's. You decide who enters, who has to leave and sometimes who will be detained. The paycheck isn't really worth to mention, so you have to keep your eyes open for opportunities, that are always containing some risks.   An amazing, dark atmospheric game, well balanced, with intresting descitions to make. Multiple endings complete a nice game that contains story elements but doesnt feel too linear at the same time.   Really love it!

A total different type of gameplay. Very addictive. I think I'm a heartless bureaucrat. But what should I do? My child and mother in law died. No money to pay food. It's a hard life in my beautiful little country.  It's a great game if you enjoyed other games like Cart Life, Proteus, or Organ Trail.
This is one hell of an addicting game!!!   Glory to Arstotzka!!!
You wouldn't think a game about being border control would be fun.  You're right.  It's actually SUPRISINGLY fun and very addicitve!  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!
It's pretty great. 8.5/10

A great game where the mechanics alone sucked me right in. If that didnt meet your fancy, the story might, with moral choices of whether to put your family first or advance into the corrupt government.
On the surface, this game seems to be all about stamping passports. I was crazy enough to buy the game based soley on this.  I was so happy that there is more to it.  Glory to Arstotzka.

Surprisingly eventful and exciting. I can't remember a time when I've ever said that about doing paperwork, but I've said it now. I can see myself playing this a few times a week.   Also, Glory to Arstotzka. We are watching you.

An interesting look into a distopian country, not only does the game provide interesting gameplay mechanics, but as you go through you learn about the lore of the game and keep on playing just to learn more
addicting, I thought it was going to stink, but I'm hooked on it now.
Glory to Arstotzka 10/10 would detain Kolechian scum again.
There where budget cuts somewhere in the ministry of admissions and somehow I ended up with a gun, my son is dying so I got him crayons instead of medicene. 8.9/10
Interesting concept. Recommend this game as long as it's on sale. Too bad there's no workshop support :/

What an amazing game with such a simple concept. I really didn't think I would play this game as much as I did after purchasing it. But logged over 30 hours of just having so much fun with it. The replay value is phenomonal if you want to unlock the achievements, and there are a lot of endings!  Absolutely worth it to keep you entertained for hours. Also it will definitely help your brain develop as you have to pay attention or you are done ... for perfect games.  100% recommend.

Easily one of the most odd, monotonous, and darkly amusing games I've ever played. The game somehow manages to make you feel oppressed, intrigued and stressed with such simple graphics and sounds, yet you just need to go back for more.
Interesting and well-made game. Also nice memory and visual attention trainer :) Storylines not very long-building as it is in Long Live The Queen, but this game is different anyway.
One of the most immersive and strangely enticing indie games of all time.

A surprisingly great game that I lost many hours to. I did not expect the level of difficulty and story that was in this game. It just blew my expectations out of the water and I just loved it from start to finish.
Such an addictive game. Reall enjoyed the various endings and storylines you get to glimpse from your booth.
The next step towards the understanding of how gameplay talks about meaningful narrative themes.

You stamp papers you get to shoot people with a gun sometimes too. Its pretty good lots of endings and is like a tv drama and each day is a episode worth 5 bucks on a sale for sure and worth full price if you are into strange things.
Love this game. Thought it would be a simple game, but boy was I wrong. Not to say that it is completely hard, but you gotta be really careful with what's going on. Very nice.
One of the most original and enjoyable games I've played this year.

This is a hard game, let me repeat that, this game is hard. It is also not your standard game, you probably have no experience in playing this kind of game. Like any other game, it starts easy but the learning curve is very steep. Also, the interface does not help. It still needs a lot of tweaking as the interface needs more accurate actions than the graphics let you believe. That is very unfortunate, it makes it a worse game that it could be. The game really let's you feel like you are in acting on the civilian side of a (cold)warzone in some East-European country. The originality of the game, and the fun it offers, makes it a recommendable game. 7/10 Better than average and the potential to become better than that with a fix of the interface.
Makes you want to keep playing to find out more -- despite the fact that the game is intentionally designed to be repetitive and dreary. Glory to Arstotska.

An incredible achievement. With a depressingly simple game mechanic, it manages to surpass most other offerings in terms of immersion and narrative. In a world where there's an increased focus on gamefication, I could easily see this being applied to a grammar school curriculum, helping to make young people understand how horrifyingly simple it is to become a spook in the wheel.  This game belongs on everyone's bucket list.
It's literally a game about paperwork and pencil pushing, and yet I enjoyed it more then any of the big hit titles!
Fun game, I would recommend if it's £5 or less
I get turned off by indie games that are all style and no substance (gameplay), but this one walks the line just perfectly. But it when it's on sale and you won't be disappointed.
NA
This game is so strangely addicting. There is so much more to it than just checking people's immigration papers. It seems to be a political commentary.
Ridiculous gameplay and hilarious interactions with the characters you come across. Highly recommended for casual gaming and completion-ists who can try to get every ending.

Papers, Please is possibly the most fun you can have in the most mundane setting.  It's 1982, and after the six-year war between Arstotzka and Kolechia comes to an end, the Grestin border checkpoint opens, reuniting families and allowing the safe passage of all sorts of characters. As the checkpoint inspector, it is your duty to approve or deny people based on the documents they have and the details therein.  Not only does Papers, Please immerse you in the fascinating world of excessive bureaucracy, but it forces you to make moral choices throughout, determining the fate of travellers and immigrants, aiding or hindering subversive elements, all while ensuring the survival of you and your family.  Such is life in  Glorious Arstotzka

I really enjoy playing this. It really makes you pay attention to those who might be trying to pull a fast one on you. I love how you can control the engind of the game in many ways. Certainly a good game to pass time. Thumbs up.
Painfully heavy. Different feeling to a game. You learn to be efficient and not be attached to anything.
This game is ♥♥♥♥ing rad
A woman showed up with an entry permit but no passport, then proceeded to ask me what a passport was. So I jailed her. 8/10

So what do you do in this game? Stamp papers. You heard me, the whole game is focused on stamping papers. Lots of papers. To be specific, you play as an inspector who accepts or rejects passenger's passports. Make money at the end of each day by being as accurate as you can. Some passports are real, others... well they are fake. People would do whatever they can to get in Arstotzka, so be careful. What I personally love about this title is the choices you can make. You can choose to reject an individual's passport to avoid tickets and make money to support your family. OR you may accept their passport to save their dear life..but lose money because their passport is incorrect. It's your call; the power lies in your hands. The addition of special events, missions, secret organizations, news reports, and the ever changing requirements, makes this one very stressful game. It's stressful but rewarding. Glory to Arstotzka.
Funny, thrilling, stressing: Great!
I tried to write a draft of this review, but i ran out of Papers, Please.
Very addicting.

This game is addicting and the twists and turns that are thrown in keep the game interesting. Otherwise it would be the same task over and over again. The upgrades are nice and helpful and the setting is very well played out. I could play this game for hours without a failure on my part. I love the old-style graphics and how much character the game has at times.
Maybe not for everyone, but if you enjoy finding the differences and solving puzzles, it could be for you. I can't get enough of it, myself.
Simple and addictive gameplay with a steady progression of rules to apply and items to review. Check it out if you're looking for something different and interesting.
Extremely unnerving, entertaining and has a very dark feel to it. You may find out some things about your personality.

[No Spoilers] Papers, Please is a pretty cool game, but it's too simple for the price tag. I would only recommend you get this on sale. There is a lot of replay value in the game, as there are 20 endings and a bit of random generation throughout, but there is no achievement for unlocking all 20 endings or a log to keep track of it if you are a perfectionist like I am.   The overall gameplay would be completely different for every person however. Every mistake or choice can lead to a different outcome and experience for each player. That's why I like this game, and although the mechanics are simple, it's still very fun. But I just feel that there could have been much more impactful elements added into the game. There were a lot of opportunities to add immersion to the character in the game, like giving more detailed backstory on the government, making the daily events directly affect you and your family (not just your work), and actually having a benefit to moving to higher class apartments, etc.. I know this game was like a runner up for Game of the Year with Gone, Home, which I have heard has little mechanics and just story, so I was a bit dissapointed that this game wasn't overwhelming me with story elements along with it's gameplay.   You WILL have fun playing this game, I still do recommend it. I will definitely purchase the sequel if it's released. But comparing this to a game like Binding of Isaac, which is $5, this game is not worth the $10 price tag at all. The fact that Gone Home was $20 and these two games were mentioned a lot together makes me suspicious as hell. Not sure why they are so overpriced.   TL;DR STILL A GOOD GAME. Just wait for a sale.

I get the biggest meanest baddest headache after finishing work every day in this game, but somehow it makes me sit through another without any complaints.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!   Jorji is my bestest friend :P
Just pushing papers, right? WRONG. YOU ALWAYS WRONG IN ASZTOTKA. BEST GAME EVER. GLORY TO ASZTOTKA.
Checking passports, is suprisingly addictive, challenging and fun. There's not a single game out there like this one.

This game was a shock to me. It just looked like a boring strat game where you stamp a yes or a no, but it was so much more than that. There were moral deliemas that gets under your skin. A task no video game has done before. It is worth the price, even if it was $50. There is 20 endings to find so the replay value is outstanding.
Fun game, but too simple to play long term, and not worth $10. I would suggest buying for around $2.50 if you are interested.
Quirky, fun and hard...
It's hard to image having more fun while making morally ambiguous choices under extreme stress.
Some hours of fun, Excelent story!
Absolutely compelling and a stellar example of how to use gameplay to reinforce a narrative

Congratulations, as games go ‘Papers, Please’ has left me feeling a little confused about how to behave when playing, if I take the true to ideological behaviour approach I will fail, if I take the hardliner approach I might fail just because I slipped up.   The world painted in this game is bleak and fearful, the more I allowed myself to be immersed in the narrative the more compelled and conflicted I become.   Visually and audibly the game is simple, I find this adds to the bleak vision being crafted by the creator, amplifying the horrible nature of the world in which I was interacting.   The game is simply so consistent in its approach and delivery that it breaks down many modern preconceived expectations for videogames and delivers what makes a good game great, an experience that effects the player, possibly at a core value level.   Papers, Please is a beautiful game because it is so ugly.
Buy now. Not later.

Great game with simple but compelling mechanics, more depth of story as you start to get into the game, and troubling moral choices that should be less fun to make.  Example: man and his wife were political refugees of some kind, fleeing their home country. I got tasked with examining their papers. The man's papers were in order, and as he was leaving he told me his wife was behind him in line, and to be nice to her. His wife shows up, but doesn't have the proper documentation. I denied her entry because if I let her in, I'd get a citation and not get paid (my own family was starving). 'Why?' she pleaded. 'You've doomed me.'  10/10 would doom her again.

This is a suprisingly addictive game. At first glance, you may see linear gameplay. But it is far from linear. Every day, this game provides you with a challenge and keeps you on your toes with the storyline. It will keep you actively playing due to needing money for your family. Every night, it could get worse. Or every night it could get better, it depends on how fast and well you work. I also want to talk about this game's many hidden gems. It reminds you that although you have a strict job, you are still human. Sacrificing for others just because you felt bad for them. Or maybe, you just wanted the token. Ending this off on a good note, I'd like to mention one more thing. Jorji. Jorji was easily my favorite character in the game. He'd brighten up the day every time he came and gave me a good laugh. Overall, this game may seem simple on the outside. But when you get to playing it, it's a very dynamic and enjoyable game. I highly recommend Papers, Please.

What a delightful treat of a game for only ten dollars, though I'm not sure if the term 'delightful' fits well with the game's dreary Cold War environment.   You play a border inspector for Arstotzka and you have to determine whether or not an individual should pass the checkpoint. The game challenges your ability to recognize pattern discrepancies and memorize information, so if you enjoy that sort of thing you should definitely give it a try. I would say that it isn't the most difficult game I have ever played, but you can unlock Endless Mode after you complete the story for a greater challenge.   There are many, many possible endings to the game, and its well-designed save system encourages you to explore all of them. Most are pretty bleak, which is to be expected considering how crappy your job is, but you can get a few hopeful ones.   It's an Indie game with retro graphics, but I liked the gloomy art style. It looks like Lucas Pope is the sole creator, too, which is very impressive considering how well everything runs. I think I ran only into one bug (I couldn't pick up a document and had to restart) so that's pretty good.   I enjoy dark humor, too, and this game has loads of it. Those of you who enjoy 'gallows humor' will probably love this game. It's certainly one of my favorite Indie titles.
I don't like pixel art. And I'm utterly uncomfortable with the pressure the ticking clock gives me. But I recommend it for being innovatively different from any other games I've played.

If you ask me what this game is about, I can't tell you. To describe it would not only give you the wrong impression, but it would be insulting to the game.  'Papers, Please' is an addictive masterpiece, encompassing hummor and morality, as well as mortality. As simplistic tasks become more and more complicated, taking longer to perform, and holding a more intense weight over the livelihood of you and your loved ones, our ideas of morality change. Between bribes, corruption, sabotage, and simple cold-heartedness, the game knows exactly how to get at you, as you race to the end, trying only to survive.  When I tried to explain the game's mechanics to my friends, they were put off by the concepts. In our minds, a paperpusher does not make a great game. Yet everyone whom I've demonstrated to, or let play have expressed their own interest, many of whom bought the game for themselves. So yes, I suggest this game to anyone who wishes to explore humanity at it's finest.

This game hit me like a ton of bricks to the heart. It's one of the most riveting, addictive, and emotionally involving games I've ever played. There are moments with these little animated sprites that will stay with you for a long time, moments you could easily miss because you're busying your manic eyes scouring paperwork for the smallest hint of dereliction and subterfuge, desperate to make enough money to keep your home -- and keep your family alive. The morality play on display here is hard-hitting and unforgettable. One of my favorite games.

I cannot imagine any better emulation of the day-to-day life of an immigration inspector on a recently war torn and still somewhat disputed border of a communist-styled country. There are an ever increasing number of forms, each with their own individual nuances, a few wild characters, and the constant threat of poverty or prison. But then, of course, most of the time is filled with repetitive mundane work. Still, I was surprised how fun this grind could be and I think that is in large part due to its oddly intimate nature. People passes by quickly, but in that short amount of time you learn so much about them. Their height, weight, where they've come from, what they plan on doing for the next few months or so, and possibly even how they react when things turn sour on them. That's an awful lot to learn about a person so suddenly. A character begins to form and you start to feel as if you know them quite well. The same could be said about the setting itself. Without much information or discussion about it, this area, vaguely resembling a former Soviet state, seems not only fully realized but legitimate as well. Though, lots of official looking documents do tend to have that effect.

Wow, this game is so realistic that it made me feel I was really an immigration inspector, risking my life to make some money for my poor family. This game includes sacrifice, as I had to decline the most innocent people to get my money's worth; which was very hard to do irl. Also, I had to make the biggest decision of making my son happy by buying him THE MOST EXPENSIVE CRAYON KIT I HAVE EVAR SEEN FOR 25 DOLLA, or buying cheaper medicine for my dying relatives. Its either get a beetiful drawn picture, or have my relatives live. I guess that's probably an easy choice.  I also think its the best FPS game I evar played and the most realistic one. Better than CoD, Battlefield, Counter-Strike, Gears of War, Halo, etc., combined. Two weapons, best first person view for instant killing!  GG and GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA  ~ 9/10  IGN

Papers Please is a game in which you take the role of a new Border inspector for the 'glorious' country of Arstotzka. The first thing I noticed about this game was the music. Masterfully composed, it conveyed the perfect feelings through out the game. Your first objective is to make enough money for food and heat for your family, though other things will come up quickly, emptying your pockets. Quickly you come into contact with the mysterious organization: The Order Of the EZIC star. I quickly fell in love with the organization attempting to save a failing dystopian civilization and decided to help them. You can choose not to as well. I recomend this ghame to anyone who find the premice and the gameplay interesting. My final score for this game is: 8.75/10
Team up with Jorji to become a drug smuggler and systematically ruin everyone's life with your stamp of justice.  10/10 caused me to fall into deep depression afterward. Glory to Arstotzka.

Papers, Please is grueling, grim, tedious, and a bad choice if you are looking for lighthearted entertainment. You play a customs agent, trying desperately to make ends meet while filing border corssing papers for a corrupt dictatorship. This game is easily the _opposite_ of what people would normally consider fun.  And yet despite all that, or perhaps because of it, this game is amazing!!!  This is an incredibly well-made game! The attention to detail is amazing! There are countless little human touches everywhere whch constantly break up the inhuman levels of paperwork. And even though all you can do is stamp documents, your choices have a real effect on the world around you. People's lives are changed by your stamp, even yours! There are literally dozens of endings that you can get depending on your stamping decisions. The social commentary is also fatnastic, and the moral dilemmas that the game puts you in -with just your stamp- are gut-wrenching! You will never agonize over a piece of paper like you will in Paper's Please, and you will never look at a DHS or customs agent the same way again!  And that is the game's most amazing accomplishment. Without any traiditonal fun game mechanics Papers, Please manages to be engaging, agonizing, cathrtic, insighful, and a blast to play! You'll just have to pick up your stamp to find out what you've been missing!

(1) *A man walks up to counter* ME: 'Papers, please.' Man: 'Hello, I am moving in to live with my HUSBAND.'  (2) *An old man walks up and standing there with nothing to hand in. But from his words, he really wanted to cross the border and get in to the country. Due to the regulation, I denied him. He showed up second time with a passport drawn by hands.LMAO !!!! DENIED!!!!*   10/10

What is there to say about Papers, Please that already hasn't been seen. After a long hiatus due to computer issues and interest waning because I got discouraged due to how poor I did at it the first time. But coming back to the game since February I have to say that I would recommend this game to anyone I know. With the pixelart style visuals it allows for genuine character interactment and moments that challenge you to be a good person or to take care of your family where most games that have moral choices fall flat Papers, Please is a shining example of a game that makes moral choices actually work.   This game has my 100 percent recommendation.
