It's kind of surprising how fun this game is, considering the overwhelming feel of misery and oppression the game has. Papers, Please is a game where you play as a border inspector, checking over paperwork, looking for inconsistencies, and making choices that impact many lives, including those of your family.  The gameplay can get intense at times as you hurry to process as many people correctly as possible. Papers, Please had me hooked very quickly, and never let go. I'm planning to continue playing even though I've beaten the story twice, just to get all the endings and maybe try out endless mode. There's not much music, but what's there is great and fits the game incredbily well. The graphics are beautiful. Arstotska is mostly devoid of color, and this game looks as it should. The game controls almost entirely with the mouse, allowing keyboard shortcuts if you have the money to buy them and increase your efficiency.  I picked up Papers, Please at full price, and it was absolutely worth it. This is one of the best indie games I've played, and I think it's absolutely worth $10. I'd recommend it to just about anyone.  Note: the game has a little non-sexual nudity that can be disabled in the options.
This Game is absolutely amazing.
awesomely addictive game. Very happy for the level of entertainment for the price. fully recommended.

Excellent. Gives great insight into life under tyranny, from an unexpected point of view. Even more important are the parallels to the modern day nanny-surveillance states of the West. Being subjugated to intrusive and humiliating airport security theatre, illegal NSA wiretapping, CCTV monitoring, and constant nanny-state intrusion into our daily lives is the antithesis of being free citizens of a free and democratic state.  Papers, Please should be part of the school curriculum, along with lessons about the nature of tyranny.

I recently wrote a review on this game for Defunct Games, however I really enjoyed papers, please. It's really fun and the gameplay mechanics are unique, although it was one frustrating at times and occasionally it made me rethink my own life which made me retract from the game at had, and I lost my concentration, and the game because of it.

There's something immensely gratifying about a game that rewards you not for cutting corners, cheating the system or getting one over on someone but for being accurate and efficient. Papers please is a game about spotting errors and mistakes, essentially an elaborate 'spot the difference' set in a humourous dystopian communist soviet state. Just like its solid unwavering theme tune, this game is a masterpiece of simplicity and good game design that really builds a sense of tension waiting for the inevitable citation slip every time you give someone the go-ahead to enter. Every time I start it up and the relentless plodding theme tune begins all I hear is yet another nail being hammered into the coffin of big game studios. Glory to Arstotzka.
you would't think it would be this fun but it is 8/10

If you read a review that doesn't recommend this game, the reviewer was probably just upset that Papers Please wasn't CoD. Do not listen to these people.    This is a game for people who appreciate art. Glory to Arstotzka.

Before I played this game I never thought that doing paperwork in a shed could be so engaging. But now, having played even for just short time, I can definitely say that Papers, Please holds a special place in my mind. It's a game that gets under your skin, in a good way. It makes you think about the affect that one person can have on so many others. You are an integral part of hundreds of different stories, some big, some small. Papers, Please is a true example of games as art and games as a medium for presenting us with things we might not want to face.

Hello, sir, welcome to your new job as border control! Here, you check for flaws in peoples' passports! If they don't meet the requirements in the rule book, they need to keep out, if they do, they need to go in! Every person you tell to go somewhere, is five bucks, every person who goes to the wrong place, however, is a five dollar fine! You also have to bay for rent, food, heat and meds! If you can't pay the rent, you die. If your family dies, you die. If you let a terrorist in, we all die! Isn't this job going to be fun?!  Glory to Arstotzka, the worst contry ever!

Absolutely great game. You play as a state officer who checks the passports to enter your country, and you feel the pressure of the government from minute one. Yet you have a lot of freedom in the way to act. You have the chance of deciding when to feel mercy or when to abuse your power; if you want to help the rebels or stick with the government; whether to let the press through even if they are rude, or let a drug dealer pass just because he's really funny. The graphics are simple and the actions, repetitive, but the game gets more and more complex as it goes on, and it's so effective that soon you'll find yourself tense, trying not to make any mistakes so that you can keep your family alive, and hooked to the stories of the characters that pass through your office.  100% recommended.

First of all, 'Papers, Please' is awesome. Here's why:      it's a true indie game that achieves to be indie rather than trying to be triple-A    its art style fits perfectly to the game's setting    it's a great execution in user experience design as it purposedly limits the player's information and activity options    it's a consistent product in every way - setting, UI, story, art style fit together and are consistently presented   Oh, and of course the setting. Making a fun AND informative game about dictatorship and oppression is an achievement in and of itself!

this game is as soulless as its name automatically denotes. Papers please is quite obviously, a game made for the german populace: it is a simulator that sets itself to be as boring as possible. Visa Inspection simulator, to be precise. and although the screenshots and srt style look blocky and grey, the way the game is played will definitely make you think. It is not as adrenaline-inducing as Ground Zeroes or as hyper realistic as Arma, but it still provides a story and offers the player enough immersion into the game where it actually may affect the gameplay individually. simple terms, the game changes the more (or less) involved you are in it. you spend an 8 hour day inspecting and stamping visas and sending people into the country or back out the door. the rest of it it pretty much covered in the tutorial. it sounds boring, and for many, it is. but for those that like a game that requires a bit of wit and willingness to have fun in it, this is definitely a winner.

Game play that is easy to learn, but will have you scrutinizing every last detail to maintain perfection. A simple, but compelling story, full of conspiracies and politics, where a simple drop of your stamp can affect a single individual, or an entire country. A well-executed game and highly recommend so why are you still reading this review instead of buying and playing Papers Please.

With its simplistic pixel art and its straightforward objective, Papers, Please manages to engage players in a way that only it can provide. As the immigration inspector of the great nation Arstotzka, you hold the power to approve or deny people passing through your country's checkpoint. While that may sound simple enough, the job gets more and more complicated as the days pass by, with you having to deal with forged documents, suspected criminals, desperate fugitives, a secret society, and Jorji Costava.   It becomes heavier by the day, and you can feel the risk grow higher when your family is in need of food, shelter and healthcare. Do you compromise a job to save some pour soul, or do you deny them to continue providing for your family? Exactly. There's no other game quite like Papers, Please, and it is well worth your time and investment.

This game is not fun. It is a grueling, despair-inducing process. Day after day doing the same thing, interspersed with prayer that everything turns out alright. That being said, it is amazing. You just have to play it.

I incredbily enjoyed this game, probably one of the best 2d games I have ever gotten the privilage to play. The theme was original, the pixel art put into it was beautifully done, and best of all: the storyline. The storyline itself was in fact a branch game (A game based on your actions) so you as the player had partially gotten to sculpt the majority of the game. The game took place in a foreign country boarder checkpoint and you as the man who was chosen from a random draw to check passport information. After you would complete said storyline you would unlock 'endless mode' which would enable you to play for as long as you desired. The game itself was challenging and required quite a bit of patience, however still was easy enough to be able finish. I strongly encourage playing it no matter what type of gamer you are.

It's 5 dollars, I can buy a mountain dew, and a Watchamacallit, with that money. I would trade those in a heartbeat for this game.  A story where your choices matter, a game where you own skill affects the outcome, and gameplay that increases in difficulty, but never becomes frustrating, a replayable game with over 40 endings.  10/10 Would play again

This game should be purchased by everyone if it's ever on sale. I'd argue for full price, paying full price is well worth it, but a lot of people might take a quick look and give it a pass. Those people, even people uninterested, should purchase this game simply to support indie devs who are trying something different and being successful. This is one of those games.  Never have I thought that a rather simple looking passport checking game could turn out to have such a complex mood and story told simply through the world and minor interactions with npcs. AAA games tell less of a story with so much more, and no game I have played recently has managed to create such emotions with so little.  For this reason alone this game should be purchased and played. The decisions you make will shape your game and the life of your family in the game. Will you give yourself to the glory that is Arstotzka?
This game is a reason to give indie games a chance. I normally stay away from low budget games but this one changed my mind on what potential they have.

Want to review alot of documents? No? That's what I thought as well, until I got Papers, Please.   This game is incredibly unique, It's hard to find anything like this. This game is not for everyone, if you prefer action packed games, Papers, Please is definetly a game that you will not be intersted in. Every little detail in this game matters, and missing something, or taking too long to make sure you don't miss anything, could kill a family member. Another thing about this game is choice. Many people will give you the wrong papers, But will try and bribe you with Money, or a sad story. You can let this people in and risk your job, or just follow the rules and deny them. There is no right answer, and you can never be a good person. It's deppressing, and while they have 20 different endings, none of them are really a 'Good' ending. I've played through this game 6 times, and I still have fun with this game, but I doubt many people will play this game more than twice. I would recommended this to many people, but don't be expected a standard sort of game.   8/10.   Glory to Arstotzka.

This is a pretty novel concept for a game.   You basically do paperwork for a 5 minute day in day out work shift, trying to accurately process as many immigrants as you can. You have to balance your speed and accurately precisely enough to make sure you remain stable in your job.   If you're too slow in processing paperwork, your paycheck will suffer, and hurt your family. The country you live in only rewards labor to citizens with a family to feed, so if you fail them you lose your job. If you're too fast and sloppy with your paperwork, you'll end up either wrongfully denying immigrants, or letting in people with false information, sometimes criminals, and terrorists. If you keep failing in your responsibility to properly check their information, you'll end up getting citations that can deduct from your paycheck and make you lose your job.   As you keep going forward into the game, the immigration process becomes more and more complex, making the game even harder.   It ends up being a pretty good game in time management, and an overall political commentary on the immigration process, and the harsh reality of the work place.

The idea for this game is so simplistic and may look boring first, but IT'S SO GOOD! Papers, Please is addicting and has great gameplay value and replayability. It's also unpredictable and challenging - you never know what's gonna happen after you've made your choice. And there are many choices to make, believe me!  The simplicity of the game has one other benefit: it runs smoothly and doesn't crash at all. I really recommend it to EVERYONE!

Overall a very solid game. Excellent for those who are borderline OCD. Obviously not for those looking for something with action in it, this game is a slow burn. Slow, but good. 8/10

Like most poeple, I thought how can an 1980s Soviet-style immigration border control simulation be at all interesting? But it is amazing! It is the first game I've played where I have felt that I am presented with genuine moral dilemmas with significant in-game consequences. I dont know how many endings there are, but I've played it a few times and each time the ending is different. Some are more favourable than othesr but none are perfect. A few rounds in and the game becomes a bit of a challenge as you have to adapt to the constantly changing rules, increasing layers of beurocracy and an ever-changing political climate, while at the same time trying to protect youself and your family from destitution. Very interesting game and worth a go!

Puzzle game, basc a nerve-wracking version of the classic 'Spot the Difference' game. Going day-to-day was a bit tedious but I was so engulfed trying to get enough money for my family and not messing up at my job that I didn't find it boring; the emotional investment kept it from being so. For a desk job, you bump into a lot of trouble. I never expected to face so many moral decisions in this game so this feeds all my fave evil beauracracy feels.  Also the music!! The pixel art!! What a great mood-setter.

Probably one of the weirdest concepts for a game I've seen, but easily one of the more addictive out there. You are basically a fact checker, but every decision affects how much you and your family has to live, their food and heat needs, and their living situation. Screw up and you lose money, and they may die.
This little game is so much more than a silly little game. I promise. You will love it!! So much more depth than ever expected.

Simple yet complex puzzle game with some deep social undertones.   Like a lot of the other reviews mention, it's more of a look into the life of the struggles faced by people who live under an oppresive regime. It has a lot of choice and consequence gameplay. Take the bribe and feed your family or refuse it and keep them hungry another day. Get penalized for allowing someone with improper papers into the country or separate them from their spouse and send them back to their country where they will no doubt be killed. Seems simple in thought but once you're playing the game it's not as easy.

When looking at the concept for Papers, Please, it sounds very dull. However, the game provides the player with choices that challenges one's morals. Papers, Please is a game that I could spend hours playing without stopping for food or social interaction. The characters in game have emotions, personalities, and become more than just NPCs the longer you play. I recommend Papers, Please for this reason; It is the one game I have played that has made the job of Immigration Officer seem like a plausible career choice. 10/10 Would Recommend.

Papers, Please is one of the best indie games out there. While the premise of running a border checkpoint may seem boring, the game makes the experience engaging, interesting, and even strangely relaxing. Even while your character really only remains in one spot for the entire game, there is still a very entertaining plot that's progression revolves around your decisions, and each choice has an effect that is well merited; truly it feels unnerving to bend the rules as you know you are being watched, yet it also feels immoral to follow the rules strictly.   My only real hangup with the game is that there is a minor gameplay element involving a screening process in which a person's identification may list them as Male or Female, but after scanning them, their sexual organs are revealed which may (according to the game) be grounds for contradicting their listed gender. As a transgender person myself I found this to be cringeworthy since sex and gender are not one in the same, however as there is no blatant transphobic language and there is no extreme consequence for ignoring this gameplay element, I can assume that the Dev is perhaps just unaware that they are being offensive.....it's tolerable, obviously, as I still very much enjoy this game.  Overall, it's a wonderful and unique experience that I will continue to come back to.

This is a unique concept and it's done very well. You play a border guard of the country Arstotzka, tasked with scanning the documents of various entrants to the country and finding forgeries, criminals and more. It's very enjoyable, and has a unique dystopian style that I quite enjoy. It also has an endless mode, so it's replayable even after the story. I'd recommend this game, especially for the low price. Glory to Arsotzka.

Papers please starts with a very simple gameplay : Control the immigrant papers following the rules of your ministry. Check thoroughly that all indications match the rules and accept or deny entry. But the story around your booth gets really interesting. People try to pass through get shot, you may help people with specific stories by letting them enter or killing murderers or spies. You can help your country or let the resistant settle in your autocracy. Meanwhile, you have to pay your rent, medicines and heat for your family. A small game but with really interesting atmosphere where you get hooked to find the discrepancies to earn your wage. Do buy !

Thisi s a really great game. On the surface it looks pretty straight forward, but it gets more and more complicated - but not so complicated that it stops being fun. You are basically a border worker who checks documents on people immigrating over. Your job is to make sure they don't have false information, fake documents, bombs, etc... all while saving money to keep your family alive and comfortable. I learn something new with each passing day (each day is a 'level') and if you mess up you can go back to a previous day and start over. For example, I accepted a bribe on day 11 for $1000. A few days later I moved into a nicer apartment. My neighbors reported my 'new wealth' to the athorities and they took my bribe money and are investigating the situation. I haven't found out what is going to happen yet, but if i lose my job i'm going to revert back to the day before I took the bribe money and be sure not to take it again :) Anyway, great game and definitely something to take about with other people who have played.

“Papers, Please” allows the player to indulge in the fantasy of a border control inspector (quite similar to TSA). The game tackles a lot of interesting and controversial aspects of border security such as body scans and fingerprinting. The game has an inspection view mode which you use to compare sample data such as passport dates or names to existing rules or other data to find and resolve discrepancies.  There is also a very, and I mean very, big focus on memorizing information. You will need to remember just about every little detail about every little rule and you will need to continue to adapt this memory of yours to the ever increasing number of arbitrary rules that must be followed. Failure to follow procedure will result in warnings, fines, and a game over if you push your luck. Sometimes though, you will want to deliberately fail in order to help people out or achieve some other goal.  This game can get downright stressful during the post-review phase where you watch people entering/exiting the country with baited breath, hoping not to hear that telltale sound of a MOA citation being issued. Later on, you have to really be on your toes with all the various paperwork being juggled around and it almost seems like a relief when you find a stupid mistake.  This game is often heralded as an example of when indie games “nail it” on a concept, and I would agree. Papers, Please transforms a boring, repetitive task into something fun and challenging, while still retaining some semblance of story to keep the player pressing on just to see what will happen next.
Glory to Chernobyl! Thats what they say right?

Papers, Please is a unique (as far as I know), highly enjoyable border control simulation, a claim which will probably only make sense once you've started playing.  The mission thrust upon you is to man a fictional border and, using the evidence in front of you and the instructions given to you each morning when you turn up, to decide who to let through into glorious Arstotzka. Getting it right means you earn a living, getting it wrong gets you reprimanded and eventually penalised, which makes the various attempts to corrupt you even more appealing as you struggle to progress from the bottom-grade residence they've assigned you and your family, whilst you try and keep them fed, watered and medicated.   Part memory game, part puzzle, this point and click misadventure balances the need to do a job thrust upon you, whose demands change daily, with the need to look after your loved ones and, perish the thought, yourself. Sounds easy, right? Do your job well and climb the ladder, if only the requirements of your job were not quite so demanding and the clock didn't tick around just that little bit too fast every day as the pressure slowly (and then not so slowly) mounts.  If you only like your games slick and shooty this might not be the one for you, but I believe everyone should try this at least once if only for the music and fantastic deadpan humour, with the very basic graphics ensuring this will run on a wide range of machines (it ran on my old laptop, and that barely coped with streaming video day-to-day). If you're on a notebook, I'd probably try playing with a mouse, as when it gets frantic playing on a touchpad can be quite frustrating.  Completely recommended.
This game is really amazing. I play it with multiple people around so that we each have a job to check something.

I'm not sure how someone made a paper work simulator nail-bitingly, heart-poundingly fun, but they managed to do it. Papers, Please is one of the few times that I can say everyone should play it. Even if it doesn't look all that interesting to you, because of the graphics, the gameplay, whatever, you still need to play it. It does something that alot of other games fail to do. It makes you care. You care about doing well at your job because all the money you make goes to keeping your family alive, and if you don't do well you get penalized for it. And yet, at the same time, it makes you care about the people you work with, which begin to present moral choices that make you question whether or not you should help them or just look after you and yours. Papers, Please succeeds all the way around, and, as I have said before, you need to play it if you have not yet.

This is an excellent game that lives up to the hype. I'd seen a bunch of praise for it on gaming sites I respect, and finally decided to take the plunge for myself. I absolutely do not regret paying full price for such a great game in many respects. First of all, although not marketed as such, this is a fantastic detective simulator that will reward you for careful attention to detail. The sparse story is written well enough to evoke true emotion from you, leading to gut-wrenching decisions that force you to balance your humanity with your survival instinct. While the gameplay is fairly repetitive, the story is rewarding enough and the scenarios are varied enough that it's not really a problem (but if you're wary of the repetitive gameplay, you should still buy it, just wait for a sale.) While this game is not for everyone, if you're into puzzles, looking for clues, paying attention to detail and slower games that make you think, go ahead and give it a download.

'Glory to Arstotzka' Papers, Please is a true gem of an Indie title. With It's minimalist graphics and dreary color pallete, the feeling of an iron curtain border checkpoint is conveyed without equal. The game mechanics start out simple, with you only needing to examine one or two pieces of information, but by the end, you will need to be on the tips of your toes, scanning many documents for discrepencies in a matter of seconds. The game has 20 different endings, but only 3 or so of them are actually different. You have the option of doing your job without question, supporting the insurgent group trying to bring down the government, or fleeing the country. All of these different endings have fun twists to them, and are all worth trying to get. If you are looking for a fantastic game, this is it.

I have very much enjoyed this game, and while playing it, it is not just a simple game as you think it might be.  This game is an examination of conscience  You decide whether to let people in to Artotzka or not, making exceptions and bending the harsh and cruel rules for bribes and other reasons. You begin to question whether or not to let everyone in, detain them, or deny them.  As the game progresses, you get better at cross-examination, while the rules get increasingly tougher, and the terrorist threats seem to be an everyday occurance at the Grestin checkpoint. This puts the pressure on you, making sure you get through enough people to provide heat and food for your family, or to get that next apartment, or the better upgrades for your inspection booth.  Overall, I would highly recommend this game. This game has so much more meaning in it than the game itself. You find out who you will bend the rules for, and who you won't, who you trust, and who you deny on spot for conspiracy.   Yes, buy it, even if it is not on sale. This game is surely worth it. Sure it doesn't last very long, but it is well worth it.

An experience unlike any other you'll find out there, Papers Please turns the monotony of bureaucratic tasks into a game that will keep you busy for hours. Fun? I wouldn't call it that - what it is is imerssive. You'll become a cog in the authoritarian machine in no time, gleefully pointing out the discrepancy in birth dates on some poor soul's passport and work permit, or submitting someone to an unwarranted full body search just to prove their gender. You'll take pride in your work for the man, and like it too.

I don't think you can truely 'win' this game:  You try to do your job to take care of your family - So you deny all the poor oppressed people and you become a horrible human being. You try to help the needy people - You get citations and don't have enough money to feed your family, so you become a horrible father. You try to help EZIC overthrow the tyrannical, communist overlords ruling Arstozka - You get arrested and executed, and become a horribly dead person.  A very dark but absorbing game that faces you with constant moral choices, and in general makes you feel worthless. If that sounds like your kind of thing - and keep in mind, this is a game that makes bureaucracy interesting - then why haven't you played this already?
Awesome concept, keep it up ;) Looking forward to more games from this dev ;)

How does a game with low-res graphics, a single song on the soundtrack, and excellent simulation of bureaucratic tedium create a compelling, immersive moral universe? Play 'Papers, Please' and find out.  Don't let the relatively rough graphics fool you. This game makes you feel every choice you make, and has enough endings and sub-plots to make replays worthwhile. Every day on the job at the border makes you wonder what will come next, and whether you'll know how to handle it.  I can only think of two downsides:     On the first playthrough, the early days may seem tedious... but that is  intentional . Learning the basics, and setting up the routine, is essential for the later parts of the game. Push through the first few levels, and the story will start to unfold.    On replays of the game, the early levels can feel too simple. Once you're used to handling a dozen complicated rules, going back to 2-3 simple rules feels like busywork. This can be mitigated by using saves to replay later parts only, and I generally find it worth pushing through to get to the game behind. But YMMV.

its pretty fun

Papers, please breaks any and all expectations. Never before would I have believed that a game based around on 'spotting the difference' and following strict rules could've achieved so much enjoyment. You play a border agent in a dystopian city of Arztozka. Throught the game, you will learn bits about the universe around you by brief discussions and pleas of those who come across you, begging for safe passage. WIth an extensive amount of possible endings and variations of dialogues on decisions, this game also allows for amazing replay value and enjoyment.

This game is beautiful. At first glance, it seems simple, almost what you expect out of an old school flash puzzle game. Quickly you realize it much more then that. The story mode makes this game a game, otherwise, its rather emulative of real life. Match numbers and documents is mundane, and sometimes a bit too much like real work for some. But the story carries this task far beyond. I played a good stent of this game over the weekend and didn't realize that in the end, I was doing almost real work. What captures you as a player is the decisions you have to make, moral, legal, ethic, financial.  It's overall an amazing experience but I would have to warn you, if you don't find the decisions making and experience factors enjoyable in general, this game may simply be boring to you.

Papers, Please   is a very unique game. 3909 Studios knows how to make a game about simply manning a checkpoint into questioning the ethics of Arstotska while simultaneously questioning my own morals. Through the game things don't get easier. In fact, its quite the contrary. You'll find yourself getting beat over the head with family needs of food, medicine, and heat. All requiring money to obtain, money you don't have. In the beginning of the game I was just a worker keeping criminals and other evildoers out of my country. Then the rent wages went up, my family was getting sick. I noticed that as time went on I started to get more and more desperate for money, accepting bribes whenever I could. I was slowly becoming the person I was originally supposed to keep out. It may be too repetitive for some, but as for me though, they spiced things up enough for the game to not grow stale. The musty pixel art sets the tone in this beautiful game. 3909 Studios did an amazing job, and I look forward to see what else they come out with in the future. 10/10
Who knew that stamping passports was such a good stress releaver!

I watched some streamers play this and I absolutely fell in love with it. So, I bought it, and I can not stop playing! Even though, you are sitting there accepting or declining citizens/foreigners, this is something that is very relaxing, yet intriguing to what is going to come next.

I first found out about this game from a YouTube review about a year ago. I immediately bought it afterwards. If I were to try and explain Papers, Please to you it would see extremely boring. Because it's so much more than what it appears to be.  It's a timed puzzle game. You have to make moraly based decisions, where there usually are no 'good' choices. It's also packed full of social commentary. It's got simple but oh so catchy music. It's deceptively difficult.   Just play it.   Come to Arstotzka, best country in world!

Congratulations.  The October labor lottery is complete. Your name was pulled. Welcome. At first glance I thought Papers, Please was going to be a boring, endless border controll simulator game. Well it was... NOT! It has (Believe it or not) an actual story line and interesting characters. There are several different endings to the game to enjoy. It was (in my opinion) a piece of art. Quite the contrary to being boring actualy. It was funny how much it reminds me of either Nazi Germany or Soviet Russia. Satire maybe? All in all, I enjoyed it a lot. GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA! Ehre sei Arstotzka!
always remember to turn off nudity kids.

The communist state of Arstotzka has just ended a 6-year war with neighboring Kolechia and reclaimed its rightful half of the border town, Grestin. Your job as immigration inspector is to control the flow of people entering the Arstotzkan side of Grestin from Kolechia. Among the throngs of immigrants and visitors looking for work are hidden smugglers, spies, and terrorists. Using only the documents provided by travelers and the Ministry of Admission's primitive inspect, search, and fingerprint systems you must decide who can enter Arstotzka and who will be turned away or arrested.

Border Partol! Checking documents is oddly satisfying and rewards the sharp eye. The learning curve isn't too steep. The story is something I enjoyed more than I expected for this type of game. You have to manage your abysmal finances to feed your family and heat your home every (or every other) day. Pick it up when it's on sale.

Accepted multiple bribes, denied them entry, then had them arrested when they tried to get their money back. I get a bonus when I detain more people. My son is sick and needs medicine.  Glory to Arstotzka

Boarder patrol with humor and serious choices on how family and others live. The rules slowly expand and the work space becomes limiting but encourages close review of each new document. An eye for detail and a good memory will be helpful. Multiple minor errors are offset by the amount received for processing more people.

I really liked this game. It's a simple concept, but executed pretty well. Seems a bit repetitive at first, but it gets (slightly) more complicated as the game progresses. You've really got to pay attention to detail for every entry document that comes through.  Glory to Arstotzka.

Playing as a border control officer has never been this cool! The gameplay is relatively simple - verify the documents of incoming immigrants by comparing them against a list of rules you're given. As you play through, the game throws several interesting moral dilemmas your way, and you may have to make decisions that go against your heart for the sake of providing for your family.  It's quick - I've put around 15 hours into it and gotten every single achievement, but I enjoyed every minute. It's also pretty cheap, and well worth it (considering that it was less than half the price of a movie ticket).  Easily in my top ten of Steam games that I own.

A gem among indie games, Papers Please is definitely worth the deal. It has such a great depth, the gameplay and the story itself constantly make you question yourself. As you play, you are constantly forced to make moral decisions. There are no right or wrong choices — only valid or invalid passports and documents. There are multiple consequences and endings to this game, so the replayability makes it even more worth the purchase.  All in all, it's a wonderful demonstration of the indie game genre moving to another level, beyond what conventional games would do. Definitely get this if you seek something new, or just curious about how it feels like to work at a border checkpoint.
All Hail to Arstotzka - -/

Omg. Amazing 112/10 score  First off i would like to say, any one reading this who missed the whole 'point and click' tag up above please go away. This is not the game for you.   Day one, you won the lottery! Not the money kind of lottery, you won a job! You get to run the new crossing point into your country! They country has been closed for 6 years from others.(How come we dont have that? Lottery for awesome jobs?)  Anyways. So right away, you feel some really good country pride. Either saying to people 'HEY! WELCOME TO THE COUNTRY MAN! SO HAPPY FOR YOU TO SEE YOUR FAMILY AGAIN AFTER 6 YEARS' or you're yelling at people 'GET THE HELL AWAY FROM MY COUNTRY'   Right when you feel like you're doing a great job, someone got by you and there is a terrorist attack with guns and bombs and you can't help but to feel like it's your fault. I mean, you let them in didnt you? Then there are more terrorist attacks. Then people start trying to get you to join a revolution, and you think hey! Thats something to do if i get bored. You start feeling split between your country and the other people.  Then people start giving you stripper cards. Then Drug money.  Serial Killers. People looking for lost loved ones. Then bribing you to let them through.  And you dont know what to do any more. You have to pick your own side. What should you do?   20 different endings to the game are possible, without having to restart it.  This game had me mad, happy, teary eyed and confused. Everyone should buy this game.

What can I say? This tiny gem of a game truly surprised me. I walked into Papers, Please with low expectations. After all, the game is about running a border checkpoint, how hard can that be! Boy was I wrong! Needless to say, I was completely blown away. Sure, there is an innate challenge towards operating a border checkpoint, however the real depth of the game is its ability to convey deep moral dilemmas through its characters. You'll find yourself torn between moral choices day in and day out, all while just trying to feed your family and pay your rent. And as you make these decisions, everything comes together to build a complex story that can end in one of 20 ways. In my opinion, it is worth its entire cost and then some. If you have your doubts, buy it on sale. The experience is well worth every penny.

Fascinating, unique and effective story mechanics, great characters and generally a joy to play. My only real frustration is the very limited workspace you're given, which by the end with so many rules makes going through everything feel annoying at times.

Original and fun, I did get this perverse sense of delight at doing my job properly, catching people with forged papers ('A-Ha!'). Stamping passports is strangely satisfying. The overall design of this game - the mood, the tone, the puzzles, the stories - I'm just so impressed!
This game is strangely addicting, and it makes me feel uncomfortable.

If you don't own this game already, you are really missing out on a unique, challenging, and emotionally draining experience. Every stamp you give will leave you with anxiety. Every sob story you deny with haunt you. Do you play as a government-pleasing worker, an undercover terrorist, or do you only worry about your own family.  One of the best games I have ever played. Very pleasing to look at. Slick controls. Must have!

This game confuses me. It's good. Flawless, not a thing wrong with the game type of good. It always somehow makes me come back to it, and yet, the game is overwhelmingly repetitive. Then, I packed up, moved and forgot about this game. Now, for the stuffs:   The Good:   -Has a fairly long storyline.  -Endless mode with a few customizable options once you complete campaign. -If you mess up in the campaign (like when    you accept the $1000 check those revolutionaries give you    ) you can restart on any previous day. -Random events occur.    Terrorist attacks, people so mad at how long they wait in line they threaten to murder your family and then you have to deny them because 9/10 times their passport is expired, checkpoint inspectors who hate pictures your kid draws for you, and other things    -The same main events occur, but you have choices on what to do. Like Jorji. He's an immigrant who tries to get past the checkpoint several times because he has incorrect entry permits, and when he finally gets his stuff in order and you approve his entry, he tells you his passport is fake. -Each day something new is introduced. (No foreigners, Arstotzkans require entry permits, workers need building permits, there has been an increase of disease from Republia so they need a medical report, etc.) -There are multiple endings. (Find them out for yourself! No spoilers from me here!) -The game makes you decide if you should do your job and be a complete a**hole, or be a soft and weak commie border guard. Arstotzka frowns upon you!    The Bad:     WARNING! OPINION ZONE   -In my opinion, endless mode is boring. It is like campaign, but watered down. From what I've played, there are no random events or main events. Nothing fun happens. -    If you side with the revolutionaries, you better know exactly what to do, otherwise when it becomes end game, and you don't do every single task, you are arrested for crimes against the government.    -You better be whisking people through faster than the speed of sound and correctly, otherwise your kid is going to die of some stupid disease. -The revolutionaries keep demanding you to help them, if you don't, they get pretty rude. -LET ME KEEP MY DRAWING ON THE WALL!  If you read this far, thanks? I didn't say everything good and bad, as I don't want to spoil the whole game for you. Get this game if you can, it really makes you question, would you strictly follow the law, or would you slack off just a bit, and let a whole family through, even if the wife doesn't have proper paperwork? Rating: 9.5/10  -Arrow GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA!

The game may look dead simple, but its not. There are side quests, bribes, funny characters and 20 different endings based on the actions you took in game.   Congratulations Lucas Pope for being able to put this all together, on a game that's fun and casual.  Overal: 7.5/10

A brilliant game that uses unconventional gameplay mechanics to create an amazing, compelling story. I picked this up from a humble bundle sale and didn't expect to like it much. After all, looking through passports isn't fun, right? Wrong. All the while, you find yourself in the middle of a fascinating story that is told in a refreshingly unique way.  It's hard to capture why this game is so good in a short steam review, but that's just a testament to how deep and rich this game is despite its appearance.

Honestly, all this 'indie' garb is new to me. Games that speak a message and look like they could run on a Sega CD are fine by me, though. Back when I was growing up, indie meant the budget aisle at Circuit City, and NO ONE had any insight or comments on the stuff they put back there. Today, there's specialized awards for games that, six years ago, wouldn't be considered games!  Papers, Please is one of those games. Which means this isn't a game. This is a 'life hard-ship simulator'.  Have you ever wished you could live in a Soviet country during the Cold War? No?! I didn't think so. Have you ever wanted to do mundane tasks, much like the day job you fill to pay for video games? No. Me either. Have you ever listened to someone's opinion, only to realize you don't share it, and you've wasted your valuable resources to compare? This is exactly it.  Papers, Please is supposed to tell a tale. But... I finished the game. I was thrown into prison. The end. I was done.  Why should I have to play the game 19 other different ways? Linear storytelling, in this case, would have been better. When your game is based around pushing documents around, it tends to get gruellingly boring. I don't care about plot when I've been doing paperwork for four hours.  10/10 plz dnt buy

Papers, Please is an ambitious game that takes the concept of a dystopian society and the strict controls that are placed on the borders and tries to make it an interactive experience. It's times like this I wish there was the option for a neutral rating on Steam because whilst there are a few positives to the game there are a lot of negatives that I personally disliked about the game.  Starting with positives the nitty, gritty pixelled style of the game is a throwback to the 1980s where this game takes place and adds to the charm of it. It's really great but the downfall of this is that sometimes it can be hard to see if there really is a discrepency that you're expected to pick up on. The music in the game is fantastic (when it plays) and adds to the atmosphere of a society controlled by a strict regime. I literally cannot fault the music; it's perfect for this kind of game to be honest. The save system works on a timeline basis meaning you can go back and replay days and basically create a split timeline which is something that I appreciated as it meant I didn't have to go back and play through parts of the story I'd already seen. It's innovative and something I would urge other game devs to follow this format for other story intensive games with multiple endings. There's very little humour to the game but one of the characters, Jorji, is a light in an otherwise bleak world and it made me smile whenever he popped up into the booth. Cobrastan is best country.  Unfortunately what does let the game down is that after the 2 hour mark it begins to feel more like a job than an actual game and the fun factor completely dies off. Perhaps this was the intention of the game but if you're like me it ends up killing whatever motivation I had for the game. If reflecting the boring job of border control was the game's intention it did a great job at that. The moral choices that you're expected to make sometimes feel cheap and I felt no sympathy for the people I turned away (in fact I took great delight in detaining anyone I could much to the horror of my boyfriend who claims I'd ruin many people's days if I this was my real life job). I'm a sucker for stories that pull at my heart strings and leave me feeling depressed but Papers, Please failed to illicit any of those emotions from me. There are two main stories that you can follow and one is dull and boring whilst the other has a little more action orientated. The former just drags an already dull game downwards. Even whilst playing through both storylines there's very little difference between the two other than choosing to take someone's passport or not, etc. Some variation and more consequences would have been fantastic.  If I look at this game as a game I genuinely cannot recommend this unless you delight in sorting through mounds of paperwork. As a statement this game reflects life in a country being torn apart by conflict and the strict regimes of an oppressive society great (although it's still not fun to play). I'd recommend buying this on sale because you're either going to love it or turn around and absolutely dislike it to the point where playing feels like a chore.

CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX NOTHING BUT GAMING CULTURE AND KATS!   Never thought I'd say this but there's just something weirdly satisfying about a game where your sole job is to do paperwork. Seriously, that's all you do!  In Papers, Please, you play the part of a lucky proletariat picked from a lottery to work at a newly established checkpoint between Soviet Union era-like satellite states. Your job is simple; prevent anyone with false or out of date paperwork passage in or out of the ficticious country of Arstotzka while letting the right ones in.   It's just a wacky good time, processing the flow of depressingly monotonal proletarians to the oppressive thrum of Soviet era propaganda music. The revolving door of characters you encounter are very human in their motives for crossing the border and includes concerned parents, arms dealers, and a beguiling hobo.  Your perspective is as limited as communication with the world outside the grey colored Berlin style city while juxtaposed color palettes off set the drabness of your surroundings. The sound is simple yet precise and at times, the compulsion to lick your thumb before flipping through another page of procedural nonsense is simply overwhelming.  The process is intuitive and not too precise in the sense that where you stamp or place paperwork is not a set thing, allowing for a kind of freedom that is severely lacking in more cerebral titles such as Papers, Please. As a result, you'll find that your in-game desk quickly becomes a reflection of your very own in terms of organization and tidiness. Expect the random pipe bomb thrown from the grey clad masses to disperse the crowd which will thus bring about more stringent and meticulous scrutiny from your bosses.   Check out Papers, Please if you're looking for a more cerebral challenge and have the desire to feel like another cog in an Eastern Block ghetto.    CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX: NOTHING BUT GAMING CULTURE AND KATS!

Another deceptively simple game. The gameplay is simple. The graphics are simple. The sound is simple.   And yet.  The gameplay is simple, check for discrepencies, approve or deny. But there is a whole depth to it. Your method for chacking. How quickly do you check. Accuracy or speed ? Justice or efficiency? You can loose either way. Your choice also changes your future, with 20 different endings. There's even an endless mode with global leatherboards, unfortunatly, there are obvious hackers.  The graphics are simple, but they have been chose for a reason. Firstly, 3D High-res graphics are not needed. In fact, the retro factor is spot on to when the game is set, late November 1981- early January 1982. Set at the eastmost country of the map, with a totalitarian regime, one can assume is ment to be the USSR.  The sound is simple, but it fits in perfectly with the graphic art style, with its 8-bit sound. The melody of the main theme evokes the regime wonderfully and it matches the title screen.  The save system is ingenious. In conclusion, a good solid and original game, from one guy.

A very niche game that can offer a lot of gameplay for someone who enjoys it. Extremely easy to get an idea for whether you like it within 2 hours, so don't be worried about going over the refund limit!

An excellent videogame. Papers, Please is a very deep and sometimes moving game. You play as a border inspector, accepting and denying people into 'The Great Sovereign Nation of Arstotzka'. There's stamps, entry permits, ID supplements, contraband, guns, terrorism, drugs, smugglers, nudity, passports, bribes, fingerprints, and behind it all, the M.O.A (Ministry of Admission). My only complaint is I've played 6.4 hours, and recieved no card drops. But that's besides the point. Your name was pulled in the October labor lottery. You are obliged to buy this game. 10/10  P.S. Always let in Jorji, he ends up smuggling drugs and then bribing you to let him in.

An oddly captivating game. Starting with the bad. Papers Please has only the roughest, most pixilated graphics, which is generally a big turn off for me, but somehow works for this game most of the time. It only sometimes becomes annoying when things can get hard to read or when you are supposed to recognixe details about a person, but it's hard to tell from a 12 pixel face. It also only has two scenes (outside or inside the shack), but dispite that, it managest to tell a captivating story and be an engaging and challenging game. Perpare yourself for moral delemas and hard decisions that need to be made quickly.   Something that may be a turn off to some casual gamers is that this game is timed (by nature of the plot), so every second counts. This is not a sit back and chill sort of game. It's more of an intense attention and memory test that will get your heart rate up as the timer is counting down for the day and your family is cold and hungry and counting on you. Do you guess or take the time to know for sure? Do you help a stranger or ensure your family is safe? These are the sorts of pickles Papers Please will put you in. The multitude of options allows for a lot of replayability, and it gets a little easier with experience, so don't get frustrated if you don't make it far at first.   8/10 great plot and game design, could use a graphics update.
A suprisingly difficult game with tough moral choices and a great aesthetic!
Most games are a distraction. This game is an experience. Go have yours. Very well played. 9/10

Initially I thought this game seemed plain especially with graphics and the concept of being a border control officer didn't seem exciting enough but as I got into the game I was suddenly drawn into it and I noticed that there couldn be different outcomes depending on the decisions you make.

I once saw a Let's Play of this game and immediatly fell in love with it. 'Papers, Please' is like nothing you have ever seen before, you play as an Immigration Inspector deciding the faith of the people in the communistic country of Arstotzka.  You have to carefully check passports, work permits, vaccination papers and so much more and carefully decide who you will accept and who you will decline and do not take your decisions lightly either! everything you do will impact your game.   Besides immigrants you have have to help your family survive the cold winter in lonely Arstotzka and deal with tons of unforseen events such as terrorist attacks, rebellions and serial killers, make sure you make the right decision because it could be your last!  What might turn you on? - Multiple possible endings, strive for the best one! - Incredible atmosphere, the music and colours of the game truly set the right mood. - Wonderful characters, you just WANT to help some of these people, you will care for them, you will betray them.   What might turn you off? - Heavily text based game, it involves a LOT of reading. - Hard, even though the premise might be simple,   this game is really hard and most of your family won't live through your first play through.  In the end, would I recommend this game? Well if you prefer heavy action based games, super intense RPG games or multiplayer madness shooters then no. Do you love the indie type game, those games that are just so weird you love them for being unique and giving you that playstyle no other game could ever give you? Then hell yeah!

I'd heard of this little indie game a long time before I finally played it, and I was glad I did. The game isn't particularly complicated, it isn't a drawn out adventure to defeat evil. It's simple in it's premise: you get a job in the fictional country of Arzstoska as a border customs checker. You need to check the passports of people passing through, allowing entry to the people with the right identification and denying/detaining those without. But the game soon becomes lot more complicated and complex, and soon you have to decide whether to let people through to be with their husbands, despire the fact they don't have all the right papers, or to help stop a wanted criminal, or detain people who haven't done wrong, just so you can get a little extra money so you can get food, warmth and medicine for your family. It's a great game, with loads of replayability. It's fast-paced, complex, and has you questioning your moral choices. Brilliant.

This is definitely one of those games you're bound to be skeptical about, when you see the premise of the game. But rest assured, if you enjoy games that make you think against the clock, while balancing the facts with your moral compass, you'll enjoy this game.  You're a border guard for a small, fictional Eastern European country, and you're the family breadwinner. You're paid per applicant processed, but fined for your mistakes. So what do you do when faced with a question of compassion against the need to feed your family?  This game doesn't do it in a preachy way at all, but it's bound to make you walk away thinking differently about immigration as being about real peoples' lives rather than just statistics.

This game was a unique experience for me as it made me understand or at least get a taste of what kind of pressure Inspectors in the Airport feel. Also your morals are tested as you can risk getting a penalty to accept a bribe or let a woman see her husband depite the fact that her passport contains some errors. Multiple endings make this game full of replayability, but it can sometimes get repetitive depending on the direction you are going making it sort of a chore sometimes. This game can sharpen your skills in being observant and efficient as you have a limited time to earn as much money as you can in order to purchase your basic needs. I recommend this game not because it's really fun, but because of the unique experience. It won't even take up considerable space in your machine.

Choices and consequences. Loyalty or rebellion. Paragon or renegade. These are the elements that you'll encounter in this simple yet addictive puzzle simulator about your role as a immigration checkpoint officer for an authoritarian dictatorship, coated in a Cold War flavour dressing. In Arstotzka, video game plays you. One of my favourite indie titles of all time. Buy it. Now.

The concept of the game is that you work at a border crossing and make shure the immagrants have the right paperwork to get into the country. It does not sound very interesting but trust me, it is. Many things keep it exciting like trying to keep your family alive by making enough money, having the choice to work with a group to overthrough the government, or the fact that there are 20 diffrent endings.
Somehow managing to be fun and boring, this is an amazing, story based game.

Recommended, as a peculiar shade of Zen gaming.  I am really impressed by the depth and involvement that such minimal game can punch. Mind, though: in Arstotzska, the game plays you. You may start off cool and grand, but by the end of the day you will have been whacked hard enough, and at the threshold of the (in-game) month you will be all shivers and totalitarian paranoia.  Whenever you try and invest in humanitarianism or just plain friendliness, nastiness and practical losses will hit you harsh, eventually, steadily contriving to scoop your soul away. All you will strive for is to reach the end of the shift with the least damage to your frayed dignity and salary. Whatever it takes to get there.  Slowly, but eventually, you stop sympathizing with those pesky freedom fighters and thinkers and you will be most annoyed with those popping up with problems and stories to unroll. Like, 'FFS, don't come and waste my working time, you incompetent sub-citizen!'  Whoever is not part of the System becomes Persona non Grata, to you personally, and mighty so. The System feeds you, you are its dog. Love the System. Swerve from your cold detachment and there you go, down down the ditch, Persona non Grata yourself.  This game made me understand better my real, East European country: I never realized how easy it is to betray the lofty values of civilization when bread is your only aim, and the aim itself stretches not farther than tomorrow.  Great, might say infinite, replay value: you against the Evils and the dull Average Joe. The game ticks hypnotic and crunches the hours. In fact you only can get better trough total immersion in the geography and psychopathy of the fictional world of Astotzska: spot the anomaly is, then, your profession and your bread. Great satisfaction to crack a tricky counterfeit in a fraction of second and a burning humiliation when you fail to spot the elephantine one)  Highly enjoyed this game and it pays well to have some knowledge of the former Soviet society: it gives that priceless extra twist of stomach ache.

Subject:Papers Please Genre:Puzzle Developer:3909  Report Card: Stability(Crashes,Bugs): A+ Graphics: A Soundtrack: A Fun Factor: B Characters: A Originality: A+  Overall Rating: 92% A- : Very Good  Other Notes: Theme is very good. Very nice setting and idea. GLORY TO ARSTOSKA.

Man comes in to checkpoint.  -Papers, please.  He hands in the required documents, but he's 3 kg over the information on file.   - You've been selected for a random search  = What?  - Please turn to face the scanner  I find contraband on man, Arstotzka will be in danger if I let him in.  I look into his pixaleted eyes, he wants in. Maybe he wants to see his lover?  NO, FOR THE GLORY OF ARSTOTZKA. I signal the guards to detain him.  Guards come to the door;  > OUT!!  = WHAT IS GOING ON?  > COME OUT!!  = YOU CAN'T TOUCH ME!  Guard comes in, smashes his face in with the butt of his rifle, carries the man away for processing  (Three weeks later)  Man shows up again at my checkpoint, has all the documentation he needs,  I consider approving his entry.  He sees the penant;  = What happened to the penant? What did you do to it! Coach is going to kill me!!  I give back filthy penant, and reject his entry.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA.

Something about this game was really enjoyable. It's not action packed but it has an intriguing story.  It's a bit of a point-and-click your way through your job, but that seems like it would be fairly realistic. The player is forced to monotonously dig through dates and seals of approvals to spot fake paperwork, just like the real border guards. The rules for required documentation was also changing from day to day which makes life harder for both border guards and immigrants.   One component of the game is feeding your family. If you can't work fast enough your family will go broke and you will go to jail for unpaid bills. I was playing on a trackpad and had a hard time with this. Fortunately the game comes with an easier difficulty setting that gives you some help with reaching your quota. Even with this setting on the game can still present interesting dilemmas and moral decisions.   It has a few different endings depending on the choices you made. It was fun but for me it did not warrant a second playthrough to experience an alternative ending.

'Arstotzka so great, passport not required.' If only, Jorji, if only.  The demo for this game was so good it made me get a steam account just so I could play the full version. I get twinkly-eyed when talking about this game, and I talk about it to anyone who will listen. Such an aware and astute political comment. The game some how manages in that little cube checkpoint to be all about human relationships, and how compassion and revolution relate, and a million other themes. Even if you don't play compassionately, I think it's still true that it's about compassion. So there's a lot of heavy material, a lot that I still think about after months. But also it's funny and light? I think it goes back to the charm of relationships and interactions. There are so many potential stories in this game, you see so many people come by the checkout, and you are also confronted with whole states, but somehow the story stays small and personal too, in a way that replicates real politics. I could go on. Just play the game, you'll think a lot about states and morals and rebellion and empathy and power in the process.   That music too! wow!

This is one incredible little game and it all (well mostly) takes place in a tiny little border control booth. It's up to you to let people in to the country and of course they have to have the right papers, a good reason, ID, a visit visa or sometimes even unique documents. The rules of the games change for every work shift that passes you by and you have to make sure that you take a real good look at EVERYTHING to see if the documents are real. If they are you send them on their way in to the country, and if they're not, you send them packing (or call the security on them).   When I started playing I really enjoyed making sure that all the papers are correct and it feelt simple enough to keep a good flow. But... the further I came in to the story everything started to get harder and harder. Checking the papers became a timed puzzle that you have to solve as fast as possible, you have a family that you have to feed and get medecine for, you have events and secret organisations that you have to make sure to keep track of. And once in awhile... you have to reach for a gun... and shoot intruders.   Everything is creating a horrible and very... realistic story which really ends up touching you. I was surprised by how much you could feel for this game. Definatly worth a try if you enjoy story and puzzle gaming.  Recommended!    / Nurgleprobe

It's a hard and depressing game. But you more or less learn to empthaize with real life people who have similar realities. Will you help someone fleeing a much worse situation than yours at the expense of paying for food or heat? Will you accept bribes to ease the financial stress? Do you rush through it making mistakes that cost you money? Will you take it slow at the expense of your paycheck? It's a fun and challanging but don't expect it to cheer you up after a long day.

This is a pretty simple puzzle game that touches all the right notes to be a masterpiece (at least within the Indie scene). You are tasked with handling the people that's trying to get into your country, which presents you choices with actual consequences in the story (None of which, I might add, are ham-fisted in cutscenes or other stuff like that).  Would you allow a criminal into your country if that meant you'll be able to put food on the table of your family that day? Would you allow families that have been separated by war to get together again? Would you take bribes?  Whatever your final choices are, the game do not judge you for them. After all you're just trying to get by, right?

'Papers, Please' is self described as 'A dystopian document thriller.' I couldn't give it a better description than that. Time is money, and you need to process as many passports as possible before the day ends. The more passports you process, the more money you can make, which keeps your family from suffering. The whole process of examing passports for correct data starts out easy at first, but gets tougher every day with more complex bureaucracy. If it wasn't tough enough to suffer through a hard day's work, you also may find your day ending short with a possible terrorist attack. Although this all sounds masochistic, that is where the true beauty of the game shines. The two problems I have with this game is the short amount of time they give you for each day (frantic indeed), and the fact that it retails at $10. I usually don't have a problem with the price of a game, but even at $10, it is a very simple game that could just as easily have been released as a Flash game on Newgrounds. If you love high stress puzzle games, or ever had the dream of working at your local DMV, you definitely need to check this out.

If you have ever heard of don't judge a book by its cover well this one is great and the contents are even better. If you have even thought of buying this game, have no second thoughts, BUY IT. Papers, Please is a game that sounds incredibly boring in a nutshell.  You're a border patrol passpor inspector. It's stylistically low-key (though quite pleasing), simple, and the rules are available to you on-screen at all times.  But somehow the game makes me feel anxious and alert the entire time you're playing it.  Did you check it all? Did you get it right? Every approval or denial leaves you with gritted teeth for the 5 seconds it takes the entree to walk away. As soon as you hear the mechanical whirr of the fax machine printing your mistakes, you kick yourself for missing a detail and keep going.  Really engrossing. Fun to get all the endings, and the way the game saves files makes it incredibly easy to correct previous mistakes allowing you to skip over the need to completely start a new file. A very underrated feature.  Much enjoyed.

This is one game that most probably overlook. I first learned about this game from watching the 'WTF is...' video for the beta of this game by TotalBiscuit. I gave the beta a try and at first I was like 'well this is tedious' but then when I finished the beta for the first time, I looked at the clock and was surprised by how much time had passed since I started playing it. This was back in 2013 mind you! Now I have it for my PC and my iPad. I skipped the story when I learned that the code to unlock Endless mode was the same across all copies of the game and just looked up the code. It's a great time killer and before you realize it, you'll have all of the Issuing Cities memorized.  I started deriving sadistic pleasure from detaining or denying people coming in with work passes. Why? Because glorious Arstotzka has no need for foreigners. Arstotzka has ablebodied workforce of its own. Arstotzka has labor lottery to solve labor shortages. Visit, pass through, immigrate, or seek asylum with Arstotzka. No need for filthy foreigners, especially from Kolechia. But Ministry of Labor says we need foreign labor. Why they impliment work pass system. Will still deny at every possibility.  I will say this though. Between the original PC version and the version on tablets, the tablet version is easier to play. Story is exactly the same and the endless mode code is the same as the PC version too. Don't get me wrong, this is a great game and severely underrated.  So if you're new to Paper's Please,   'Cause no trouble.'  Or if you're a veteran inspector like me...  'Glory to Arstotzka!'

Intense and unforgiving  You work in immigration and have to decide if people are allowed into a fictional country within an alternate universe Europe. That's about it.  Oh and there's daily rules to follo, such as ID card checks, potential terrorists for real, spies and generally nice folk who are desperate (who you have to turn away in order to live... Or do you?).   Every day you have to reach a quota otherwise your family starve, become ill and die. It's very easy to do the latter. It will happen, come to peace with it and then try harder.  Want a challenge? Enjoy creating workflows and formulas to complete your work? Then this is for you.  It's harsh and it's unforgiving but it's really unique.  To critique it slightly: it can drag and become monotonous. But that's part of the role-playing experience in my opinion!

Something that struck me about 'Papers, Please' is that it isn't a fun game. It's a paperwork simulator that feels unrewarding and almost painful, but for a good reason. Everything about this game adds to the story from the dreary atmosphere to the sympathetic characters, and it's this context that turns the dull mechanics into something truly tense and deep.  Possibly the most appealing aspect are the choices you make. The ones you make are both big and small, but you only ever have a few seconds to decide on something that could change the lives of the people you meet. The game genuinely gives the chance to confront these situations, and is more worthy of a game than most because of it.

I didn't know what I was getting myself into when I bought this game. On the surface it's just a simple 'check things and press the right button' game, but there is so much more to it than that......The actual 'game' part turns you into this monster....Do you allow border crossing to a wife who wants to be with her husband, or do you want to feed your kids at the end of the day? Do you suck up to your boss and be a stickler for the rules, or you do you try to enjoy your work and bring some humanity to it? It's a game that makes you consider your actions like no game before or since. It will make you feel like a genius....and it will make you feel uncomfortable. And then MORE uncomfortable. DO NOT think this is a game about getting a high-score by getting all of the border decisions correct. That is such a small part of it. If you want a game that makes you think, and makes you feel, I highly recommend it.

Welcome to Old Soviet Russia simulator, comrades! Papers Please is a game that puts you on a inmigrant inspector's shoes, being your task to check the documments the people willing to enter on your country present to you. The beginning is simple enough: just the passport. Check if the issuing city is right, the expiration date, if the person in the photo looks like the one in front of you... you know, the basics. After that, slam either the 'approved' or 'denied' stampt, and call the next one. You are paid according to how many people you process a day, and if you mess up, a penalty is applied over your salary.  Now, as days pass and world wide events take place, more and more documments are required to enter the country. Entry Permits, Work Permits, Diplomatic Authorizations, IDs... to mention a few. You reach a point in which your table is covered by paperwork, each sheet of paper with lots of data to check. You will encounter wanted crimminals, smugglers, counterfeiters, terrorists and poor people who just want to get through. Your paycheck, which was already misserable, gets smaller and smaller as you process less people (since each takes more time now), screw up more times (don't blame yourself, it's hard not to do that) and the cost of your life goes up (you have to maintain a family of four, plus rent, plus unexpected expenses). You will have to resort to accept bribes, get innocent people arrested to collect bonuses, and be ruthless in general to get those extra coins you need. Important decissions will have to be made, and those will have an impact in the rest of the game.  It's a game that invites you to think. Will you throw your morals out of the window or try to bite the bullet and help the poor chaps in need? It's the law of the jungle out there. Let's see where this get us to.  + Heavily replayable, with multiple endings. + The difficulty curve is steep, but fair. But that doesn't mean that the game will go easy on you... + The story is depressing and surprisingly realistic. ♥♥♥♥ like this happened back in the day. + Extremely easy to learn, and also to fail at. Your doom can come out of anywhere, and there is no way to avoid it. - Feels less like a game and more like an actual job, which I guess is what the devs were aiming at (tip of the hat in that case), but playing Papers Please sure takes a toll on me. - I said that the game is fair, but when you mess up too many times it comes crashing down on you like you wouldn't believe. Penalties in the late game are brutal, but you only have yourself to blame, for not paying enough attention.  This game gets a 8 out of 10. Glory to Arstotzka!

How boring can you get. A bureaucracy 'simulator' where you just sit and stamp papers... Boy was I wrong. Captivated me for quite a few hours and even enjoyed playing what I thought was going to be a very boring game. Aside from things getting more and more bureaucratic and challenging to get through each day, the creator also manages to weave in interesting storylines and moral dilemmas. Do you let in the human trafficker or a child molester. Will you let people get killed by turning them back to their hostile homeland. Do you help an underground organization doing their missions. Mess with politics? Will you be able to pay the bill in the end of the day. Can your son go without his medicine, or shall we not eat for a few days. Just to name some questions that arise. Definately recommended.

To any and all who have ever worked a boring desk job especially in retail or customer care, I highly recommend:  'Papers, Please' A document thriller. You are a father, a husband, a son-in-law, and a brother. You are a provider for 4 mouths. Your budget consists of 2 checkboxes: Does your family eat? Does your family have Heating in Russian November?  Also the rent went up.  For a game that is essentially a desk job work-a-holic simulator where you only work 16 hour shifts because your son needs medicine, it is compelling. It is powerful, and at times, rewarding.  A woman is entering Arstotzka (in-game Russia) from Impor (another in-game country) to visit her son who she hasn't seen in 5 years. She ignores your request for her entry visa until asked because she is so enamored with her trip. Upon receiving the visa, you discover that it is expired. You have 3 mistakes on your belt already, and you've taken a $5 cut to your $55 salary.  Another mistake will be an additional $10. Your son is sick. Your family hasn't had food in 2 days. The rent is $30 and food is $20.  You deny her passport and send her on her way.

This game really shouldn't be fun, but it is. All you're doing is working as an immigration officer on the border of a fictional Soviet-esque country. You check people's identification, search for discrepancies, and judge whether they can come in to the country or not. It sounds completely boring, but it's very addictive, and this is one of those games where time can whizz past whilst you're playing it.  There's also something very charming about the simple retro graphics.  7/10

papers please could have been an incredibly boaring game, if it wasnt done so right. i like to put my self into this guys place and hear the stories and know you could be there angel. while at the same time trying to fend for your wife and kids..... it just makes for great game mecanics. Papers please proves the you dont need to dump 4.5 trillion in graphics as long as you have intresting and good game play mechanics. that get the player into it while keeping them on there toes with ever changing rules. great game love it

Great game with simple but compelling mechanics, more depth of story as you start to get into the game, and troubling moral choices that should be less fun to make.  Example: man and his wife were political refugees of some kind, fleeing their home country. I got tasked with examining their papers. The man's papers were in order, and as he was leaving he told me his wife was behind him in line, and to be nice to her. His wife shows up, but doesn't have the proper documentation. I denied her entry because if I let her in, I'd get a citation and not get paid (my own family was starving). 'Why?' she pleaded. 'You've doomed me.'  10/10 would doom her again.

This is a suprisingly addictive game. At first glance, you may see linear gameplay. But it is far from linear. Every day, this game provides you with a challenge and keeps you on your toes with the storyline. It will keep you actively playing due to needing money for your family. Every night, it could get worse. Or every night it could get better, it depends on how fast and well you work. I also want to talk about this game's many hidden gems. It reminds you that although you have a strict job, you are still human. Sacrificing for others just because you felt bad for them. Or maybe, you just wanted the token. Ending this off on a good note, I'd like to mention one more thing. Jorji. Jorji was easily my favorite character in the game. He'd brighten up the day every time he came and gave me a good laugh. Overall, this game may seem simple on the outside. But when you get to playing it, it's a very dynamic and enjoyable game. I highly recommend Papers, Please.
