“Papers, Please” allows the player to indulge in the fantasy of a border control inspector (quite similar to TSA). The game tackles a lot of interesting and controversial aspects of border security such as body scans and fingerprinting. The game has an inspection view mode which you use to compare sample data such as passport dates or names to existing rules or other data to find and resolve discrepancies.  There is also a very, and I mean very, big focus on memorizing information. You will need to remember just about every little detail about every little rule and you will need to continue to adapt this memory of yours to the ever increasing number of arbitrary rules that must be followed. Failure to follow procedure will result in warnings, fines, and a game over if you push your luck. Sometimes though, you will want to deliberately fail in order to help people out or achieve some other goal.  This game can get downright stressful during the post-review phase where you watch people entering/exiting the country with baited breath, hoping not to hear that telltale sound of a MOA citation being issued. Later on, you have to really be on your toes with all the various paperwork being juggled around and it almost seems like a relief when you find a stupid mistake.  This game is often heralded as an example of when indie games “nail it” on a concept, and I would agree. Papers, Please transforms a boring, repetitive task into something fun and challenging, while still retaining some semblance of story to keep the player pressing on just to see what will happen next.

Papers, Please is a unique (as far as I know), highly enjoyable border control simulation, a claim which will probably only make sense once you've started playing.  The mission thrust upon you is to man a fictional border and, using the evidence in front of you and the instructions given to you each morning when you turn up, to decide who to let through into glorious Arstotzka. Getting it right means you earn a living, getting it wrong gets you reprimanded and eventually penalised, which makes the various attempts to corrupt you even more appealing as you struggle to progress from the bottom-grade residence they've assigned you and your family, whilst you try and keep them fed, watered and medicated.   Part memory game, part puzzle, this point and click misadventure balances the need to do a job thrust upon you, whose demands change daily, with the need to look after your loved ones and, perish the thought, yourself. Sounds easy, right? Do your job well and climb the ladder, if only the requirements of your job were not quite so demanding and the clock didn't tick around just that little bit too fast every day as the pressure slowly (and then not so slowly) mounts.  If you only like your games slick and shooty this might not be the one for you, but I believe everyone should try this at least once if only for the music and fantastic deadpan humour, with the very basic graphics ensuring this will run on a wide range of machines (it ran on my old laptop, and that barely coped with streaming video day-to-day). If you're on a notebook, I'd probably try playing with a mouse, as when it gets frantic playing on a touchpad can be quite frustrating.  Completely recommended.

who knew the repetitive tedium of being an arstotzkan border guard could be so compelling?  i laughed out loud when a new day would bring (yet) another new type of document to inspect wondering how my postage stamp-sized desk could possibly display more.  i shook my head and marveled when i realized this game was actually making me feel overwhelmed and frustrated by the neverending line of visitors and the ridiculous amount of paperwork to organize/verify.  ... then i laughed out loud again as a new component was added to my desk adding yet another layer of complexity to the routine visitor checks.  the drab colors. the dour expressions. the meaningful decisions you have to make with morally ambigious outcomes. the music. like a masochistic glutton for red tape, i couldn't stop playing.  this is a worthwhile videogame experience - it delights and infuriates with clever monotony. probably my 'most memorable' of 2013.  glory to arstotzka.

- Let [name]'s girlfriend into the country even when papers weren't in order on first run; didn't save [name] in time next day. Continues game with a heavy heart of remorse.  - Does the same thing on second run, but managed to save [name]; finds out he'll no longer be stationed at the checkpoint and it's the last I'll see him. Cries for the rest of the game.   It's easy for me to get sucked into the gameplay, as you're trying to process as many people and as perfectly possible so you can earn enough to support your family. You'll find your morals being questioned many times throughout the game - a couple wants to escape the horror of their home country together but one of them doesn't have the proper documents?   What do you do?  Deny her and be a dutiful officer of Arstozka in exchange for pathetic wages, but at the expense of a human life and the couple's happiness?  Let her in at your expense of getting a citation, which could possibly lead to your having debts to your country and causing the downhill slide of your family?  Highly recommended. After all, nothing feels better than yelling 'DETAAAAAAINED!' when papers aren't in order.

One of the best games that came out that year, Papers Please is a simple yet challenging game that has all the bonuses and perks of tough decision making in a story that grips your morals and forces you to question your next move.

I enjoy the game, but I have to be in a very particular mindset to want to play it. The game is frustrating and monotonous at times, and you have to realize that this is a part of the immersion into the setting. It is intentional. However, a frustrating and monotonous game is not one I personally am going to pick up on a regular basis. This is a game that feels very much like work. If that's not something that you're interested in, look elsewhere.  If, however, you like to be immersed into a setting in an interesting, creative way, go for it.

Sometimes you hit rough days where terrorists just wreck everything, but the great nation of Arstotzka will push past these dark days. As a border patrol, it is your job to protect our great nation while also allowing great citizens and foreigners to enter. Will you step up to the challange and defend the motherland?  In all seriousness, I initially bought this game during a summer sale for 5 dollars because of it's great reputation, but I always thought playing it would give me stress. However, I started playing it last night and I deeply regret not playing for a year and a half after I bought it. It isn't just about checking passports, the game has a type of a story line that is fun to follow.   Highly recommended.

A dark, oppressive and tense game about terrorism, security, doing your job and keeping some shred of humanity all while you process immigration paperwork.

A mechanically simple game that contains enormous depth. Sorting and stamping papers can get hectic and stressful, but it's the moral choices that are the real challenge. You can overlook a discrepancy to allow a wife return to her husband, but if you can't afford medicine for your family then you have to realistically consider having her jailed and use the commission to pay for treatment.  Papers, Please puts you in many of these scenarios and stretches your ability to act in a moral way. You will eventually realise that some situations cannot be resolved without something horrible happening to someone - and you are the pivotal deciding factor. A lot of time is spent afterwards justifying the decision to yourself.  A very unique game that provides insight on how people can act in terrible ways, and how anyone, under the appropriate circumstances would act the same, including you.  A longer more detailed review of this depressing, but fantastic game here:  http://theboilingpot.net/papers-please/

It might not sound interesting at first to be an inspector of the border control but this seemingly simple game can keep you occupied for hours because it is really addicting. You want to know each of the possible 20 endings after all and find out every little secret the game has.  The atmosphere is also really well done, since you have to make enough money to feed your family, while you only earn money if you don't make any mistakes. At the same time, though, you are on a schedule so you can't take too much time.  All this is reinforced by the simple graphics which suit the game perfectly. And if you completed the story, there still is an endless mode with different features and difficulties, so in my eyes worth the money.  I give a 5/5, 10/10 or 100/100, whatever you prefer. Glory to Arstotzka!

Let me get this straight, you want me to tell you a review about this game? Whoever you are, you might as well go to the curators, because if you've come for a review on this game, you've come to the wrong place. However, if you have come for an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Ingredients 1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter 3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar 3/4 cup sugar 2 large eggs 1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks 2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour 3/4 teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon fine salt  Directions 1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)  2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.  3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.  4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.  5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.  For a Rocky Road Bar: 1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

This game is truly incredible. Despite essentially being a paper stamping simulator, I agonized over my decisions more in this game than in most ganes with 'moral choice'. It's amazing how engaging looking for discrepancies in paperwork can be when there's a timer ticking away and your ability to feed your family depends on how many people you process. I came to dread the sound of a citation being printed, meaning that I'd made a mistake. In doing this, the game does a great job of destroying your empathy for the potential immigrants, then brings it back for just long enough for you to feel like a terrible person. In other words, I loved it.  My only problem is that the gane doesn't really make you care that much about your family, so I didn't feel as bad as I should've for only feeding them every other day.

Paper, Please is unique. It somehow looks dated and dull at first glance with the retro-like graphics. Yet, suprisingly, it manages to transform a mundane inspection job into a simplistic game with addictive gameplay and high replayability value for the moral choices and endings.  Never have I felt so satisfied admitting immigrants only to find out some of them carry bad influences into Arstotzka, your country.   In some days, you will be shocked to see some fake documents and crazy people that will force you to upgrade your inspection tools.  The difficulty is about right. It eventually ramps out a little bit faster than you think, but it is still not too difficult.  There are some memorable moments when you realize you've made some mistakes and then *boom* someone dies because of your error.  It features two modes; story mode and endless mode.  The flaw that I can find is the music is not too impressive and repetitive.  Well, at the end of the day, this game is worth buying.   Score: 8.5/10 'Cool Job. Glory to Arstotzka.'

Papers Please is a paper stamping, document checking thriller that is set in a dystopian society modelled on the USSR during the Cold War.   The story? Well you were chosen by the October Labour Lottery to serve your great country of Arstotzka by working at the East Grestin border checkpoint. You have to basically check through papers and make sure people are cleared for entry. After a couple of days, you will be contacted by some rebels. Do you help them? That is up to you. A woman trying to enter on an expired document to see her son that she hasn’t seen in 6 years. Do you let her in? All these decisions and more you will have to make during your play through and, depending on what you do and who you let in, depends on which of the 20 different endings you will get.   The gameplay is basically checking through documents and either approving their entry or denying them. You can chose either, you are not forced to deny someone because they have drugs on them, and they might offer some money to let them in. Money you desperately need. As the game progresses, you are given more paperwork to look though and will have to be very vigilant as they might have discrepancies, but they will be very slight as opposed to a completely different name on a passport like you will have at the start of the game. It is a very rewarding game and every time you let someone through and do not receive a citation, you do feel very pleased with yourself.   The visuals are very blocky and will resemble an 8-bit type graphics, but it works perfectly in this game, reflecting the backwardness of Soviet era technology. Every person is different and you have to make sure the person handing you the documents is the same person on the passport photo, so the graphics are a step up from 8-bit. The writing on the documents is not difficult to read at all and is very clear. The colours are very dull, which captures the feeling of Soviet Russia fantastically and builds upon the dead end, doomed society that is modelled on. It is a very good game and can be very funny, and very solemn.  Overall it is a fantastic little puzzle game that is well worth the £2.70 odd that I paid during the sales. I liked it so much, I gifted a copy to one of my friends so they could experience what I had experienced. Well worth getting and a must have to any Steam library.   Enjoy your play though and Glory to Arstotzka!   TribalHARRY

I was doing fine and then I forgot to let a diplomat named Shae through. I was then falsely accused of stealing property owned by the Ministry of Admissions. I was sent to a forced labor camp, and my family back to their village. But I let Jorji through most of the time, and I think that's worth it. <3 u jorji  I restarted from the day Shae was coming through. I let her through. My administrator comes and says I will recieve no more plaques for low citation rates. Jorji comes by again and tells me I can escape to Obristan. I memorize the slip he gives me. The next day an officer tells me I am going to have an information audit the 24th... in 2 days. I steal Obristan passports in order to try to get my family with me in my escape. The next day, after I come home from work, I realize my audit is tomorrow, and I only have enough money to escape by myself. I leave. My wife, son, niece, and mother-in-law are sent back to their village. I make it through the Obristan security transport, even with a horridly-forged passport and access slip (thx Jorji's friend). I am free.  10/10 would abandon family again

This is a passport stamping simulator, and much more. The game starts off simple: You play as a passport inspector in a 1984-esque totalitarian country, deciding who to allow into the country, with a single stamp. As the game progresses, more and more odious regulations are added, making your job harder over time. At one point I had to inspect FIVE different documents just to decide whether that 80-year old bearded grandpa was a smuggler or not (he was). Right, and there's rents to pay and family members to feed at the end of each day. Tough choices are to be made every day - detain a poor sod for that extra 5 dollars in bribes, or let your son starve for a day. Fail to earn enough money over time, and your family starves to death and its game over.   The graphics, though rudimentary at first glance, as well as the simple 8-bit music perfectly complement the dystopic atmosphere of the game.  But the beauty of this game lies in its masterful storytelling. Through the stamping of passports and little dialogues between characters, you begin to learn more about the world of the inspector; the stories of the characters that pass through your passport booth (including the likeable/destestable smuggler Mr Jorji), as well as the truth of the country he lives in. Between the geopolitical tensions between Arsotka and its neighbours, the terrifying inspector from the 'Ministry of Information' and a border guard's long-lost love, the game draws you in with its simple, yet riveting storytelling.  Glory to Arsotska.

Alright, so I don't usually like games with pixelated graphics. I don't usually like games set in a very communist-like setting. And games don't usually make me feel emotions.   But this game, in all it's pixelated glory, is a GEM. It seems close to impossible to tell such a vivid story through a little border patrol inspection booth, but this game does it and it does it amazingly. This little sucker has a ton of endings, good and bad, and every choice you make is going to affect which one you get. Even the choices that look like they really don't matter, they matter - you just don't find that out until five days later and you get one of the bad endings and the game's over. I did that, it frustrated the living daylights out of me, and it just made me want to play the game even more so I could try again and shoot for a new one.   I am really bad at writing reviews and this is really short, but I just can't express in words how much I love this game. It's amazing. Just amazing.

What's the game about?  You work in an American Donut House and customers come in and pay for food. Some you like and you give them extra sugar for their coffee. Some you don't like and you send them away without serving them. Those you really don't like, you send to jail. Also, your boss comes around every now and then to nag you about our poorly you're doing at work.    General feeling after finishing?  WONDERFUL! One of the best games I've played in a while. The story is not complex, but the implications are very nice. I think the art is very in line with the game's theme and I really think the general feeling of working in the conditions presented by the game are close to reality. You memory skills will be tested. And it really provides for a fantastic way to spend you time. Some will surely not call it fun, but again this might just be what makes it a pearl in its right.    Story?  Without it, it wouldn't make much sense, but it's only important in its presentation. You could still get by with a wonderful game if we were talking about assembling computer chips in a factory. Your brain will be tested. Make the right moral decision, but the poor official decision and your boss will not like it.    Gameplay?  Oh, this is the best part of it. Get something right and you get rewarded. Get something wrong and you get penalized (though not at first, though). I'm sure it would work better in a tactile screen but the mouse doesn't distract you that much either.    Graphics?  Pretty simple, but far out. Adds to the complexity of finding out who's a male or female, for example, and that's a very nice touch.    Sound & Music?  You might get a bit tired of it, but it's in line with not only the theme but the imagination of what that country would be. I can't remember anything but the theme, though, so either there was no more music or it wasn't memorable enough.    Replayability?  I did replay it to get to the alternative endings (those I could figure out might make a different), then tried some of the other extra possibilities and then left it at that, the memory of it being all that matters now.

So I'm playing the game and my family is dying. I get to work when...  -Woman arives- Me: 'Papers please' Passport gender: 'Male' Me: 'Are you a man?' Woman: 'As the document says.' -Scans person- -Looks closely- -Sausage- OHHHH GAAAHD NOOOOOOOOOOOO THATS A C*CK  10/10

Right, checking people's papers at a virtual border booth does not sound like a game, it really sounds like a drag indeed, can't deny that. But hey, i don't know if you ever read the line 'your choices matter', but this time around they actually do.  Here's the thing, a 90s-like ex-soviet country is opening its borders and you are the one and only employee at the paper-check booth. People are waiting in a line outside for you to take a look at their papers, and as days go by people will be required to present more and more papers and you'll be equipped by the government with any kind of anti-fraud asset you can dream of. But worry not, at the end of the day you're paid based on how many people checked-in at your booth, and your family is waiting at home for you to provide. Provide food, provide rent money, provide heating money, and eventually pay for medical bills should you not take care of them well enough.  Your family members' lives are on your shoulders because apparently they can't do ♥♥♥♥ to save their lives, literally. And just to add shame to shame you'll be caught in the middle of a ground-breaking crisis and will be required to take sides, be with the government or with the revolution. But hey, you're not going to be disappointed with it, because there is a third faction, and that's the people. They talk to you, they tell their stories sometimes, all they need is just a little help, a little push. And you are king of the booth. Laws have you only let in people with certain documents, and them only, but you can do whatever you want inside your booth. Of course whatever you do against the law will be fined, just make sure the bribe is richer than the fine... but then again what are you gonna do? Will you be another government's puppet, will you side with the conspirators, or will you try to help people? Or just you know, skrew over people for your own good? That's an option too!  Anything you do will have consequencies. Even the way you do those things will. If you really are short on cash you can summon the guards on this dude with a forged passport instead of just denying him in, your friend guard will reward you for that. Or you can just let this guy off with a warning, or accept some cash from him to let him in, or whatever he has to offer, or... you know, just let yourself into his sad story and let him in anyway, who knows! Maybe saving this one guy's day today might save yours and your family's life tomorrow, you never know.  Buy it, i'm serious, you want it.

An absolute masterpiece! I can't believe a game that has the graphics of one of those ancient MS-DOS games can be so addictive and awesome. This is proof that a game doesn't always have to have rich 3D graphics to be successful and entertaining. I picked it up when it was on sale but honestly speaking, I'd gladly pay £15 if I had to. I'd go as far as saying that you can't really put a price on such a game. Games like this are priceless.   As for the length of the game, I heard it can be finished in 3-4 hours but if you are a completionist like me, then expect to invest longer than 10 hours or even more. There's an 'endless' mode you get when you finish the game and that in my opinion increases the replayability manifold. I'm now waiting for a sequel.   Long story short: Papers Please is a must-have!!   Long live Arstotzka!

Honestly, it just wasn't my cup of tea.  Warning that this review's a bit rambly.  The graphics are pretty limited, and things that are pixel-discrepencies often don't count as such to the game; and it's very hard to tell someone's sex, thus making it easy to get warnings/detractions on that front. It was neat getting the perspective of never having anywhere near enough to care for your family, though. At the very least, probably the best way to increase your profitability is to memorize all the surrounding locations, their cities, their insignia, etc. But who has time for that? For your accomodations, you probably should forgo heat the first day, and thence enable it every other day. Maybe do something similar for food.

Papers, Please, is a game full of political intrigue. Papers, Please does a wonderful job of creating interesting characters out of some of the most boring and normal people. The gameplay is well crafted and does a great job of placing the player in a scenario that most would find boring. The characters and evolution of the game's political landscape are done in an interesting way that few others would be capable of acomplishing. Papers, Please earns a solid 4/5, being a game like no other. The power that independant developers is being shown in more and more games, this can be held as an excellent example of this power, the ability to venture into the unknown and create interesting naratives that can pull in as much, or even more support than triple A games, such as Call of Duty.

I have very much enjoyed this game, and while playing it, it is not just a simple game as you think it might be.  This game is an examination of conscience  You decide whether to let people in to Artotzka or not, making exceptions and bending the harsh and cruel rules for bribes and other reasons. You begin to question whether or not to let everyone in, detain them, or deny them.  As the game progresses, you get better at cross-examination, while the rules get increasingly tougher, and the terrorist threats seem to be an everyday occurance at the Grestin checkpoint. This puts the pressure on you, making sure you get through enough people to provide heat and food for your family, or to get that next apartment, or the better upgrades for your inspection booth.  Overall, I would highly recommend this game. This game has so much more meaning in it than the game itself. You find out who you will bend the rules for, and who you won't, who you trust, and who you deny on spot for conspiracy.   Yes, buy it, even if it is not on sale. This game is surely worth it. Sure it doesn't last very long, but it is well worth it.

Papers, Please is a simple, yet complex, rough-looking, yet beautiful game. It does many things right that should not even be right in the first place. It's a special game for sure. The category it would come closest to would probably be fast-paced point-and-click arcade game. If you think it wouldn't be interesting being a communist border-control inspector, you were wrong.
This game takes what sounds like a boring premise and turns it into tense and interesting gameplay. Simply put, this game is exceptional.
My family is dead, but my border is inpenetrable. Is that not all that matters? Glory to Arstotzka

On a 0 - 10 point scale, I would proabably give this a 7.   The game itself, story, setting and that stuff, is surprisingly good and addicting. I have just gotten the perfect ending, which you will not be getting right away when you play for the first time. I usually don't write reviews, but I felt like I had to now. Because the reason this doesn't get a full 10, which it very much deserves, is what happens after you get the perfect ending.  You unlock 'Endless Mode'. I thought that it was a free-roam with customizeable conditions and such. But what it really was was an online challenge mode, with four different game-modes, not customizeable in any way. Heavily leaning towards online-competition.  So for the people that enjoyed the game and would like to keep playing normally after the story finishes, are screwed. There is no way than to redo the story again. Which will get just annoying in the end.  As I said, 7 out of 10.

I love this game so much. It's challenging and keeps you on your toes. Every choice you make, even the smallest of them, has consequences, but it also allows you to go back and change your choices for multiple endings without restarting from the beginning or worrying about saving before every major decision. There are so many different endings, and not just 'good' and 'bad' ones- this game is full of moral gray areas! Overall a great game, and totally worth a few playthroughs.  Plus there's Jorji. Bonus points for Jorji.

Papers, Please is a game in which you play as a border control officer in a communist country called Arstortzka. A big war has just finished and the borders have only just reopened. You have to check people entering the country to see if their papers are in order and decide wether or not you'll let them into the country. For every person that you let into or deny access to the country you earn 5 dollars, which you really need. We'll get to that later. If you let a person into the country when they have forged documetns or if you deny people with fine papers, at first you'll get a warning. You will get a maximum of two warnings before you'll start receiving penalties. The first penalty will cost you five dollars, the second one ten, the third one fifteen. Back to the money aspect again. After every day of checking passports and other documents you'll see how much money you made. You will have to pay rent, food and heat with the money you earn. With this money you'll have to keep alive a family consisting of you, your wife, your uncle, your son, your mother in law and eventually (when you find out your sister is arrested) your niece, but this is optional. If you can't afford food or heat, your family will get hungry and cold respectively. They may also get sick, in which case you'll have to buy them medicine. If you can't afford rent, it's game over. You'll also come across people which will ask you to let people pass. Their family members, for example. Now you can choose to deny that person because they don't have their papers right, or let them through and lose some of your hard earned money. It's got a morality aspect going on. The game meay seem simple or boring, but it's pulls you in and doesn't let go. You set your teeth in it and discover the country of Arstotzka, the conflicts with other countries and the complex, well thought out world of Papers, Please through your little world of passport checking. The game's story focus weaves in perfectly with the gameplay and can say it's well worth the money.
This game is intriguing to say the least. It's kinda fun, but it also has a plot in the background, and a good versus evil type deal. Overall, 11/10 would go to prison again.

Papers, Please is a surreal indie game in which you play as a border inspector working for the communist country, Arstotzka. The game is full of gray areas that force the player to make difficult decisions. The 'puzzles' get increasingly difficult as the game progresses, with more and more rules being put in place for you to follow. This game is not perfect by any means, but the pros heavily outweigh the cons.   The game starts with you finding out you had been chosen in the 'lottery,' and that you are now forced to become Arstotzka's border inspector. They had recently opened the border, so crowds of people who want to get in are large and unruly, with instances such as terrorism becoming a somewhat common occurance. Everybody who comes up to you for entrance to Arstotzka has a reason for going there, whether it be work or family. It is up to you to decide if they are fit to enter by checking their passports and other documents to make sure they are not counterfeit or missing completely. If you let someone in who doesn't have the proper documents, you will be penalized. This is where the concept of choice appears, as it is up to you to decide if you want to let the desperate people in even if they are not qualified. No matter your decision, the game makes you feel terrible for what you have done. If you let them go, you lose money that you need to spend on rent and medicine for your sick family, which results in a fail-state if it happens to often. If you deny them, you will have to see their hopes and dreams crushed as they discover they may not see their family again.    The game plays fine, but the repetitive gameplay gets old rather fast, so you will often have to take a break to avoid getting too sick of the game. The puzzles start off easy, but get harder as the game progresses. It is a gentle slope, so you will never feel overwhelmed by the amount of things you have to do. It is worth noting that you will likely have to do a lot of reading in order to fully understand how to play the game, and a perfect run is pretty much impossible. The more people you get through the more money you make, but if you go too fast you may make more mistakes which result in more penalties.   The art style of this game is interesting to say the least. People look deformed and sad, which fits in with the bleak setting of the game. There is nothing noteworthy about the graphics, but the gray and brown color scale of the game portray a perfect atmoshere.   Overall, this is a great game that really makes you wonder about the choices you make. The gameplay is quite repetitive, but the tone and setting of the game seem to always bring you back for more. This is a must buy for fans of surreal, atmospheric games.

Papers, Please is living proof that a good game doesn't have to rely on HD, 3D graphics, fancy cutscenes etc. Its rather simple appearance enhances the gameplay and story. The story is very intriguing and the choices you're confronted with offer ground for reflection upon one's existence in this world. Your observation skills and reflexes are put to the test as you process the many entrants that show up at your booth. There is a lot to do and a lot to discover, so there is decent replay value!

I was not ready for how intense this was going to be and how perceptive you have to be to advance in this game.  However, from what I could get to, I was faced with heavy moral dilemmas. Should I feed my family, or should I save up to pay rent for a while? Are we going to starve, or get sick and die when I can't afford medication? What's going to happen next that will completly ♥♥♥♥ me over? No spoilers, but from just the small bit of story I experienced, this game really draws you in and overwhelms you. It sucks you in and puts you in this stressful situation; you will actually feel the pressure of what is going on in the story and the panic when you make a terrible choice. This game is excellent, however it was just not for me. I would easily recommend this to someone who is up to more of a perceptive challenge. Be ready for it.  Glory to Arstotzka.

'Papers, Please' is a fun little, simple game where you control a border. The idea is as simple as it gets: you control passports. That's the gameplay. But the backstory to the game, the people you meet, the family you have to take care of, has a deep impact on the game and the future gameplay. The game is absolutely great and fun to play!

For some reason this game is a lot more fun than it seems like it should be. You are in charge of a customs booth either allowing people into the country or denying them based on rules that change as the game goes on. There is also a story that develops as you progress through the days and the choices you make can change your entire future. You can play through this game several times and not get the same ending as long as you make slightly difference choices of course. You don't have to sit there and play the whole day, you can play just a little and come back whenever you want. You could even come back a year later since the mechanics are simple and it's more processing the immigrants than quick reflexes and memorizing controls. Highly recommend it and I think everyone should give this a shot if it seems like something you would be interested in trying.

Had been looking into this game for a while, so I caved in when I saw it for sale. So I was somewhat aquaited with the game when I first started paying it, or so I thought. This game threw so many curveballs my way I felt like a major league baseball player at the plate. I found myself creating a routine to checking informaiton, weighting the pros and cons of letting a single person through, and worrying about my dying son (he died) all in one day. All of this can sound like an overwhelming experience, but it felt perfectly balanced throughout the days in-game by working towards more and more to check everyday. You truly feel like you are deciding the fate of Arstotzka with every person you let through and every decision you make. With there being 20 different endingd you are bound to at least get 3 or so of them through a single play through, and the game offeres you a chance to go back to a certian day to change the outcome.   TL:DR If you would like to have an impact on the fate of a single country in the form of an under paid and over worked border checkpoint inspector, then this is the game for you. Lots of fun.   Glory to Arstotzka! ~In loving memory of my son

I can subscribe the positive reviews. Mostly bought it out of curiousity and because of the very good feedback here and I can say it´s a real great and interesting game. Proves the point, that you can create an excellent game with only 50 MB that beats many high graphic and sound based ones easily, by a great idea. But I agree, it can give you a headache and feeling exhausted after playing it for several hours, you have to concentrate a lot to succeed.. Concentration will just reduce naturally after several hours, its fun, but also stressy fun.  You will get a cynical political satire on the horror of daily mechanisms in totalitarian governments; the thrill of power over stamping, passports and people; the fear and fun of disobeying; the detective sports of hunting potential criminals; the morale ambiguity of following the rules by the book or punishing people; the economical pressure to keep your family and yourselve alive, just for continuing with the game and last but not least - time is money, also in totalitarian countries.  Not enough with that, you will be confronted with terrorist attacks at check points, bribes and daily changing rules in a bureaucratic system. If you always wanted to get an idea about, how a person in a job like this might feel, this might teach you a little lesson. But if you just don´t like refugees, I also highly recommand it.   It made me think about it, after I took my first break. More than most other games are ever able to do. It has changed my point of view on games (size does not matter). It´s totally worth the money, don´t wait for Sale. If you are able to get the idea behind it. It is also like the experience of those game for the C64 in the 80ies, people played like crazy days and nights. You can replay it. Probably a lot. I have played 9 hours with only short break during my first session.  Try easy, if you don´t, you risk a headache and being frustrated with failing too often.  This game is excellent.  Did I make my point clear?

Still a great game overall, and the best out of the games I got in the summer sale that I've played so far. Glory to Arstotzka.

Papers, Please is one of my favorite games of all time and I have finished it atleast 5 times and plan to keep on playing it over and over. I bought the game on GoG first and then bought it on Steam. I think this is a one of a kind game, its smart, yet deceptively simple. The dystopian oppresive regime setting of Arstotzka (clearly influenced from Soviet Russia) is very bleak and life is tough. If you can't afford to pay for heat or food, family members will die. If you can't pay for rent, then well I guess it's game over!  I think this game is very much fun to roleplay, I would suggest doing the first playthrough being 'good' and helping out people in need, and just acknowledging the oppression of Arstotzka. Then it's fun to do another playthrough being 'bad', where you are honorable to Arstotzka. Still, I think this is one of the best indie games I have ever played, and I would really like a sequel if possible! (even though the dev stated that there won't be) Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is a surreal indie game in which you play as a border inspector working for the communist country, Arstotzka. The game is full of gray areas that force the player to make difficult decisions. The 'puzzles' get increasingly difficult as the game progresses, with more and more rules being put in place for you to follow. This game is not perfect by any means, but the pros heavily outweigh the cons.   The game starts with you finding out you had been chosen in the 'lottery,' and that you are now forced to become Arstotzka's border inspector. They had recently opened the border, so crowds of people who want to get in are large and unruly, with instances such as terrorism becoming a somewhat common occurance. Everybody who comes up to you for entrance to Arstotzka has a reason for going there, whether it be work or family. It is up to you to decide if they are fit to enter by checking their passports and other documents to make sure they are not counterfeit or missing completely. If you let someone in who doesn't have the proper documents, you will be penalized. This is where the concept of choice appears, as it is up to you to decide if you want to let the desperate people in even if they are not qualified. No matter your decision, the game makes you feel terrible for what you have done. If you let them go, you lose money that you need to spend on rent and medicine for your sick family, which results in a fail-state if it happens to often. If you deny them, you will have to see their hopes and dreams crushed as they discover they may not see their family again.    The game plays fine, but the repetitive gameplay gets old rather fast, so you will often have to take a break to avoid getting too sick of the game. The puzzles start off easy, but get harder as the game progresses. It is a gentle slope, so you will never feel overwhelmed by the amount of things you have to do. It is worth noting that you will likely have to do a lot of reading in order to fully understand how to play the game, and a perfect run is pretty much impossible. The more people you get through the more money you make, but if you go too fast you may make more mistakes which result in more penalties.   The art style of this game is interesting to say the least. People look deformed and sad, which fits in with the bleak setting of the game. There is nothing noteworthy about the graphics, but the gray and brown color scale of the game portray a perfect atmoshere.   Overall, this is a great game that really makes you wonder about the choices you make. The gameplay is quite repetitive, but the tone and setting of the game seem to always bring you back for more. This is a must buy for fans of surreal, atmospheric games.

Great little game if you don't want to get deeply involved in a game for hours on end, but it is also a great game to play for hours on end. The price of the game along side the small download size make it a great time killer.

Life in Arstotzka has taught me that family is a burden one must shed in order to pay the utility bill. With my pesky kin out the way, I focused mostly on the power trip that comes with ruling the Grestin Border Checkpoint. Papers, Please makes this easy by sending drug-smugglers, terrorists, revolutionaries, shady criminals, and desperate refugees, all coming to prostrate themselves at my stamp. However, the day-to-day trivialities do end up souring the wine that is my dominion/booth. This game would perhaps be better if I conscripted a serf to do the actual work, while I hold all the passports in my iron fist.

I bought Papers, Please quite a while before writing this review, but I just keep coming back to play it some more . . . That's the sign of a great game.  I love the story. The dystopian Arstotzka is a fantastic setting that is effectively depicted through the daily bulletins and the immigrants you see, and you're given so many great morally ambiguous choices to make - you may want to help someone out, but you know it'll cost you a deduction in your pay and you've got a family to keep healthy. Do you help, or do your duty? There's also a lot of story choices involved that definitely impacts how things turn out (in huge ways), and there's a ton of little plotlines to see. Sometimes you'll be excited, sometime's you'll be anxious, sometimes sad, and sometimes heartwarmed. This game's got it all, and there's numerous endings to fit what you've chosen!  The gameplay is also brilliant - it seems like checking increasingly large stacks of immigration papers for discrepencies would get really boring really fast, but it just . . . doesn't. New rules and things to look out for are constantly being given to you to keep things fresh, and while this can get a little overwhelming, the game's difficulty perfectly rides the line between immersing you in the game and being slightly too hard. Papers, Please *is* challenging to play well, there's no doubt, but I don't think it's ever unfair and feeling slightly overwhelmed by the game is entirely appropriate, given its setting and story.  The artwork is great, too. It's a bit unusual, but really fits the tone of the game and looks very good. (Same thing goes for the music!)  Overall, I cannot recommend enough that you at least *try* the game, maybe buy it on sale if you're on the fence about it, but I think it's well worth the asking price!

I started playing Papers Please for the third time and I am still impressed about how well it is put together. The graphics are only on par with NES but they take advantage of the lack of polish to make a very bleak and oppressve world.  On one hand the game feels like working a day job (complete with an unhappy boss if you screw something up), but I like this becuase it forces you to pay more attention to what you are doing. You have to read and understand everything going on in the world or you might slip up, and the more mistakes you have against you the less money you make.  That's another thing - you really get the feeling that you are struggling to make ends meet, and you feel it at the end of every day. It motivates you to want to do better so you can keep food on the table and heat your home. I'm sure it sounds like a cliche to everyone who had working parents, but the game really drives home how important it is and how difficult it can be to live day to day.  The story is very compelling too. The interesting events are notable but at the same time understated compared to most games. Everything just feels like another day even though every one of your actions have definite consequences.  Excellent game, I'm sure I will be playing this for years to come.

Right, so the first time I saw this game, I had absolutely no idea what it was about. Eventually, my friends explained it which got me interested. This game has a very interesting and unique concept. The story goes that you are a relatively skint guy who somehow manages to buy a lottery ticket and win a job. The job is he has to stamp people's passports and decide who gets in and who doesn't. This strategy game stands out from a lot of the others because in most strategy games, there is not much you have to think about. The details of your opponents are just there. In Paper's Please, you need a REALLY good eye for detail. Seriously. You have to check whetehr their country is correct, if they are the right gender e.t.c, e.t.c. I really would recommend this game as it is interesting and puzzling. Also, MULTIPLE ENDINGS (there are 20 of them).  10/10

CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX NOTHING BUT GAMING CULTURE AND KATS!   Never thought I'd say this but there's just something weirdly satisfying about a game where your sole job is to do paperwork. Seriously, that's all you do!  In Papers, Please, you play the part of a lucky proletariat picked from a lottery to work at a newly established checkpoint between Soviet Union era-like satellite states. Your job is simple; prevent anyone with false or out of date paperwork passage in or out of the ficticious country of Arstotzka while letting the right ones in.   It's just a wacky good time, processing the flow of depressingly monotonal proletarians to the oppressive thrum of Soviet era propaganda music. The revolving door of characters you encounter are very human in their motives for crossing the border and includes concerned parents, arms dealers, and a beguiling hobo.  Your perspective is as limited as communication with the world outside the grey colored Berlin style city while juxtaposed color palettes off set the drabness of your surroundings. The sound is simple yet precise and at times, the compulsion to lick your thumb before flipping through another page of procedural nonsense is simply overwhelming.  The process is intuitive and not too precise in the sense that where you stamp or place paperwork is not a set thing, allowing for a kind of freedom that is severely lacking in more cerebral titles such as Papers, Please. As a result, you'll find that your in-game desk quickly becomes a reflection of your very own in terms of organization and tidiness. Expect the random pipe bomb thrown from the grey clad masses to disperse the crowd which will thus bring about more stringent and meticulous scrutiny from your bosses.   Check out Papers, Please if you're looking for a more cerebral challenge and have the desire to feel like another cog in an Eastern Block ghetto.    CHECK OUT THE WHOLE REVIEW AT ETHNOGRAPHIX: NOTHING BUT GAMING CULTURE AND KATS!

Papers, Please is one of my favorite games of all time and I have finished it atleast 5 times and plan to keep on playing it over and over. I bought the game on GoG first and then bought it on Steam. I think this is a one of a kind game, its smart, yet deceptively simple. The dystopian oppresive regime setting of Arstotzka (clearly influenced from Soviet Russia) is very bleak and life is tough. If you can't afford to pay for heat or food, family members will die. If you can't pay for rent, then well I guess it's game over!  I think this game is very much fun to roleplay, I would suggest doing the first playthrough being 'good' and helping out people in need, and just acknowledging the oppression of Arstotzka. Then it's fun to do another playthrough being 'bad', where you are honorable to Arstotzka. Still, I think this is one of the best indie games I have ever played, and I would really like a sequel if possible! (even though the dev stated that there won't be) Glory to Arstotzka!

This game is really different to anything I've seen. In a world where games are mostly violent shooters, or cute and cuddly games, or games with little variation churned out by huge companies, Papers Please is a breath of fresh air. In the beginning you want to obey the game, don't let in that woman, even if it will unlock a secret. Don't follow the order, even if doing it right gets you the best ending. Even trying to not care about your virtual family, who are never seen or named, only known as OK, COLD, SICK, HUNGRY, is not seen as a good thing to do. I must not accept these bribes, they could mess up my track record! My family can go without food tonight. After a while, your heart softens. This guy seems cool, and it's just a silly citation, I'll let him in. My son desperately wants this expensive birthday present. I'll buy it. My niece needs to be adopted. She can some, it's fine. By the end, you should either have a good ending, and the game does offer some replay with the different endings (20 + achievements and collectable tokens). There's only one thing left to say about this game.   GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA

Curator Review:  Will you be a good little servant to the corrupt government or will you serve your own desires first and take penalties while doing your job to help the immigrants? Do you help the poor and the needy seek shelter in your country or do you shut them out because their papers are not in order? Would you help a confused man who you see time and time again gain access to your country or will you turn him away at every chance? Will you risk your job and the life of your family simply for the safety of a person you do not know and will never see again?  Yes, you are 'border patrol' but the reason why this game is so good is that it pits you against yourself. The game questions your morals, it places you in tough situations, it tears at your heart, and it makes your adrenaline rush.  I absolutely love this game.   https://youtu.be/7b8QBNB_gQY

An excellent videogame. Papers, Please is a very deep and sometimes moving game. You play as a border inspector, accepting and denying people into 'The Great Sovereign Nation of Arstotzka'. There's stamps, entry permits, ID supplements, contraband, guns, terrorism, drugs, smugglers, nudity, passports, bribes, fingerprints, and behind it all, the M.O.A (Ministry of Admission). My only complaint is I've played 6.4 hours, and recieved no card drops. But that's besides the point. Your name was pulled in the October labor lottery. You are obliged to buy this game. 10/10  P.S. Always let in Jorji, he ends up smuggling drugs and then bribing you to let him in.

An oddly captivating game. Starting with the bad. Papers Please has only the roughest, most pixilated graphics, which is generally a big turn off for me, but somehow works for this game most of the time. It only sometimes becomes annoying when things can get hard to read or when you are supposed to recognixe details about a person, but it's hard to tell from a 12 pixel face. It also only has two scenes (outside or inside the shack), but dispite that, it managest to tell a captivating story and be an engaging and challenging game. Perpare yourself for moral delemas and hard decisions that need to be made quickly.   Something that may be a turn off to some casual gamers is that this game is timed (by nature of the plot), so every second counts. This is not a sit back and chill sort of game. It's more of an intense attention and memory test that will get your heart rate up as the timer is counting down for the day and your family is cold and hungry and counting on you. Do you guess or take the time to know for sure? Do you help a stranger or ensure your family is safe? These are the sorts of pickles Papers Please will put you in. The multitude of options allows for a lot of replayability, and it gets a little easier with experience, so don't get frustrated if you don't make it far at first.   8/10 great plot and game design, could use a graphics update.

This game is like getting another job. There's constant pressure and new mechanics to try to remember, references to people you haven't met yet testing your memory, and plenty of memorable scenes that mix humor and politics etc.  It's like nothing else I've played, and I'm better for having played through it. I wouldn't want to put this on for hours on end like bejeweled though...  Buy this game to experience something unusual, quirky, and wholly remarkable, not for something to play forever.
10/10 would Papers, Please again. 8/10 would escape Arstotzka again.  4/10 do not completionist.  100/10 Glory to Arstotzka.

It feels like something that should be available all the time, without cost. 2. Some of the more obvious discrepancies should be easier to select. For example, if someone has a gun taped to their back, you have to flip to the rules page, move everything else out of the way, and highlight the gun and the rule for not allowing weapons.   Still a great game overall, and the best out of the games I got in the summer sale that I've played so far. Glory to Arstotzka.

Should I feed my family, or should I save up to pay rent for a while? Are we going to starve, or get sick and die when I can't afford medication? What's going to happen next that will completly ♥♥♥♥ me over? No spoilers, but from just the small bit of story I experienced, this game really draws you in and overwhelms you. It sucks you in and puts you in this stressful situation; you will actually feel the pressure of what is going on in the story and the panic when you make a terrible choice. There is not a huge catalogue of politically themed games, and certainly not many as humorous as this one. Working as an immagartion officer overlooking the paperwork of people wishing to enter into the fictional country of Arstotzka, you are a low level bureaucrat struggeling to make ends meet. Without enough money you are unable to feed your family, pay the electricity bills and get medicine in case someone get sick. The gameplay focuses on making sure incoming documents meet the requirements in shortest amount of time possible, with rules changing from day to day and fines handed out for mistakes. It honestly feels closer to work than play, and the the suspicious atmosphere is bound to put you on edge.   Its an insight into what lives might like for the kind of people it is easy to look down upon and despise.The neat presentation, delightful humour and interesting story elevates it into a rare gem.

Papers, Please is a game that when first looked at, sounds like the worst concept of a game. 'Play as an immigration officer that checks the legal documents of travelers.' The beautiful part of Papers, Please is that that statement is true, and yet it plays as an engaging, nuanced game that has most of what good games should have. However, the games mechanics and narrative are niche, and if you find yourself not liking this game, there are valid reasons.  The game is simple to pick up as you learn the basics of what you need to do, checking to make sure all the information is correct, according to the guidelines the game gives you. The difficulty ramps up as more documents are added and sometimes made obsolete. You must process more and more people through the checkpoint in order to make more money to provide for your family, which while you don't have to keep alive to 'win', you will find yourself working harder to make sure your family is warm, as you have a vested emotional interest.   This pressure to perform at max efficiency will gnaw at you to be faster and faster, which causes you to make mistakes, and the more mistakes you make you will lose money. So Papers, Please is a game about being an obsessive fact checker, making sure every detail is in order, and if you do a good job you can buy upgrades that make you even more efficient, and things to make your family even happier and safer.  The story of Papers, Please is linked to the people going through your booth, and I won't give any spoilers, because you will want to experience these stories first hand. You will listen to the stories these people have of needing to cross the border, but they don't have the right papers. You have to decide, 'WIll I risk my family going without food for a night, to let this man avoid being shot?' And keep in mind, do you even know why he might be shot? This isn't a game of right and wrong, black and white morality so much as it is one of having to choose between two desperately needed options of people trying to survive, but you have to choose how much you can trust and hope when you need to make sure you are safe as well.  Alongside this depressing story is a setting and soundtrack that forces you into an emotionally tired mindset. The theme is engrossing in it's exhausted proudness: its a song you will hear at the start of the game, almost like the national anthem of Arstotzka, the nation you play in. You, as a citizen, must be fiercely loyal each day, despite being worn down by lack of money, hope, and options. The colors are muted and broken by the occasional bright blue or yellow in the form of awards and story options. These drive you to act because you just want to see what a glimmer of salvation is like in this Commmunist Satellite State aesthetic.  And while all of that is amazing, there is a few things you should keep in mind. I'm loathe to use the phrase 'not for everyone', but it certainly applies here. The game is stylized to make something traditionally boring into an engaging experience, but if you are someone who prefers a game that doesn't need to be artsy to be fun, Papers, Please may be too pretentious for you. Note, that does not make you simple or someone who doesn't appreciate theme driven mechanics, but I think we can all agree that some games don't click, just as a popular movie or book may not.  Furthermore, when I have introduced friends to this game, they find it too 'untraditional' in that it isn't your typical game. The theme, objective, and narrative are all against what well known games are notable for. I largely agree with this, and if you find youself as a casual gamer in the sense that you play games for fun, rather than a hobby, only with friends, or to see how it evolves as a form of media, then this game also may not be for you.  This game should run on your computer with no problems due to it's clean but simple pixel graphics. No framerate issues, random crashes, save glitches, corruption problems. Whether you like the game or not, it will run smooth.  In conclusion, this game will be hit or miss for you, and thats ok. You'll find yourself getting into the character, role playing how you have to provide for you family, serve as a loyal citizen of Arstotzka, check papers faster and faster, and deal with a wide variety of story options that change how you think each day. Or, you'll find yourself looking at a game that, while interesting in concept, accomplishes it too well, and is a boring task too similar to work for you to enjoy.  In any case, I highly suggest giving Papers, Please a chance. This purchase could open the door for many other similar games that you'll fall in love with, or will tell you that those games aren't your cup of tea.

It's really both a satisfying challenge and a tasteful throwback.  People who wonder what was awe-inspiring creations in the mid-80's...here you go!  Secretly wrapped in this retro-creation is a layered and complexed detective-sub-game. Challenge yourself to catch the fakes and determine if they are criminals who deserve state-mandated justice or individual-based compassion.

If you ever wanted to know what it's like to have to sit in a booth and experience a gamified version of the banality of being a customs officer (and have it be fun), here's your chance. 'Papers, Please' is a sometimes maddening game of 'What Doesn't Belong' with some additional story elements of intrigue along with the joy of trying to survive as an underpaid, underappreciated border control agent. Once you get things down, the game changes them on you. In addition to some of the story elements, there's also a lightweight management element (personal money, time, family), and penalties (in the form of citations, which can cost you money, or game ends, which can send you to prison and other places).  The game becomes cathartic after you get into the rhythm of it, but you have to have an eye for catching differences and details, otherwise you'll find yourself prone to losing credits. Overall, a really fun game which manages to make something that nobody would think is fun into something fun.  Likes + Matching/Puzzling under pressure + Lightweight storylines + Lightweight personal management  Dislikes + Wish there was an endless mode without constrains ('catharsis mode' -- play endlessly to relax; no time limits, no points penalties, no instant death on failure. Still receive citations and have a score of number correct v. number incorrect) + Wish some story lines could be opted-out of.

A good game can create a unique environment that the player takes part in. Papers Please is one of those games. Although Papers Please barely ever leaves your small inspection desk in the corrupt communist country of Arstotzka (glory!) Lucas Pope is able to create an expansive universe where you feel fully involved. The game itself doesn't have much to it; it is beautifully simple and at some times annoyingly challenging. The overall goal is to make enough money inspecting travel papers to feed your family. You can do this by following every regulation, taking bribes, catching criminals, letting criminals through, or secretly leading a revolution. It doesn't matter, play the way you want to play. What really makes the game great is the setting. From East Grestin to the United Fed, the politics and controversy in the world surrounding your low-paying job is what makes Papers Please feel different from most games. Although it takes place in a large, complicated world with 7 giant countries, you hardly ever see the game outside of your work station. Instead, you get word of what is going on through immigrants and emmigrants coming and going through your inspection booth. Terrorists and secret societies demonstarte conficts outside and inside countries. You may not directly see the universe Lucas Pope creates, but you definitely feel like you're living in it.  TL;DR - Papers Please may be a simple game, but it creates a vast universe that you feel like you're taking part in, even if you don't see it first hand.  Side note: Many people seem to dislike this game because it wasn't what they expected it to be. You have to know that Papers Please is a PUZZLE GAME. It has a good storyline and a unique playstyle, but when it gets down to the basics, it is essentially a 'spot the difference' sort-of thing.

Papers, Please is a subtle game that snuck up on me. I started out playing like I normally would, listening to sob stories and stamping approvals even with missing or incorrect documents, aiding the resistance, and trying to be a caring border guard.  After being jailed multiple times, my entire family dying on me, and other miseries befalling me my playstyle started to shift. Today I found myself barely listening to the conversation of the travelers, picking out their purpose and dates only to see if they matched their documents. A woman approaches, I note she's missing a permit, she starts to talk instead of handing over the document, her pleas that if she is denied she will be killed in her home country barely register as I stamp Denied and flip her back her passport. I let through a pimp a woman begged me to deny earlier as all his documents were correct, and he flips me a card advertising his merchandise. I groan as another Kolechian decides to bomb the border cutting my day and paycheck short.  My transformation is complete, I am a cog in an autocratic machine carrying out my duties to the state. Uncaring, unfeeling, the dystopian state has broken me and molded me to fit their needs.

Would you break the rules at a border check to reunite a family?  Would you approve dangerous people with legitimate passports?  Would you put yourself and your family at risk to help someone else?  Would you help someone if it meant risking outbreak of disease?   Papers, Please isn't a game that forces a particular issue or crams such things down your throat (e.g. Press F to Feel), but it does introduce you to some pretty interesting scenarios (with no definite correct response) during your time at the Arstotska border check. Surrounding these questions, however, is a very entertaining 'paper simulator' that sees you checking documents for inconsistencies and approving or denying entry. Overall, the game provides a suprisingly rich experience and your actions throughout lead to a variety of different endings (I think 20 in all), providing a lot of room for replaying the game (especially after unlocking endless modes).   One of the best indie games around. Definitely recommended.

Glory to Arstotzka    Though a greatly thought provoking and engaging experience, 'Papers, Please' presents itself as about as boring of a game premise that one can imagine. You are a lowly border admissions officer of fictional communist state Arstotzka; checking documentation, denying entry to Kolechian scum, getting threatened by your boss for any mistake, and being paid pennies to do so while under constant threat of ending up in a windowless cell. If you do your job well, you may be able to earn enough money to both heat your home and feed your family. This aspect of the game is at most times tedious and a bit nerve-wracking.  Where 'Papers, Please' truly shines is the story, moved forward through decisions you are faced with. A woman is missing a new piece of documentation and pleads for entry to see her son? Jorji comes in with his crayon-drawn passport yet again? A person pleads for you to deny entry though all their documents are in order? Based on how you act in these situations will unfurl a wonderful series of stories, though you never leave that guard booth. The impacts of each decision is often felt both immediately and through later game events.  Each playthrough is generally brief, lasting only 20-30 minutes, but if you enjoy the game there are a variety of different endings to achieve.   In short, I feel 'Papers, Please' is worth a purchase for the experience at the very least. I've played few games which have been so thought provoking and unique.
10/10 Would work at U.S coustoms.

I think calling this 'game' just a 'game' is an understatement of the highest standard. This game, though it may appear crude in artstyle and graphical design, has been thought out within an inch of its life. Within a very short space of time you are thrown from simply approving and denying people into the glorious Arstotzka, to making complex and at times extremely difficult choices wich will test your moral compass to its limits as you struggle to feed your family in a deprived environment. I don't want to give any spoilers as to what you may encounter in this game, but I will say one thing, #Jorji4President. (You will understand the glory of this man when you play the game.)

Do you have eye for details? Can you follow instructions? Filling to be a part of faceless bureaucracy affecting lives of the people? If yes, you should try this game.

It starts off easy and straightforward: check passports, allow entry or not based on the rules. But with each passing day, the job becomes much more difficult and the pressure to make sure you work quickly and efficiently enough for your family to be fed, warm, and healthy becomes worse. On top of this, a plot slowly emerges and you must decide whether or not to continue to simply follow the rules.

While players may be reluctant to spend time and money on a game that lets you simulate what appears to be a fairly mundane desk job, Papers Please offers an experience both immersive and challanging, with plenty of surprises along the way. You'll find yourself coming back for more, despite feeling exhaustion after completing a day of grueling and often thankless work at the border. Glory to Arstotzka!

Never thought a game where you step into the shoes of a lowly bureaucrat could be this galvanizing. The story is gripping, and wrought with tension. The decisions you take along the way test your moral tenacity. The atmosphere is claustrophobic, everything is set up perfectly to give you a feeling of being chained, both to your chair at the checkpost and to Arstotzka itself. It may take a while to get used to scrutinizing all the required details in the travel documents, especially in the later stages of the game, but it is definitely worth playing.

This game is absolutely brilliant. The gameplay of scrutinising documents for errors is actually really fun and intensely engaging, as you feel under pressure to work quickly since you are on commission and need money to provide for your family. The difficulty ramps up as security in the dystopia tightens, and so you are required to do more work without an increase in pay. Your small desk becomes increasingly cluttered with documents and gives an impression of claustrophobia and an increasingly unreasonable workload. You are also faced with moral decisions between letting people in without proper documentation (thereby being financially penalised for your mistake), or denying them entry but feeling guilty as hell about it. The game has an overarching story that can play out different ways depending on the choices you make; I think there is about 30 different endings. It is one of the most original games I have ever played and I think everyone should own it.

W4C Rating: 9.5/10  This games gives a hauntingly realistic look into the world of Border Checkpoints. Everything from forged passports to terrorist attacks, this game blends the extreme and the mundane into an incredible package that will keep you playing for hours.  The terrible thing is, after about four hours of gameplay, you actually believe that you may have a future in the Ministry of Admissions. I've already added 'Checkpoint Administrator of Admissions' to my CV.  Now to wait for the lottery.  GLORY TO ARSTOTZKA.
Buy, study, and share this game as an example of video games as true art.

This game is the reason why I started preferring indie games over triple A titles. The premise is simple, you are a frontier guard in charge of passport control in what seems to be an eastern European country during the soviet regime. Your job is to check every immigrant's papers and allow or deny their entrance.  I really like this being random although there are certain key events that always play the same way. These tell the story of rebellion against the local government, a terrorist organization, corruption and some other mature themes.  The art does seem dated but the game need no fancy graphics to be entertaining. It keeps getting more and more complicated as new laws are passed to further increase border control and you may choose to play it safe, ally with the rebel or benefit you and your family from helping catching spies. It is a cold war drama that resembles reality quite interestingly.  I really recommend this game for anyone who likes cold war stories, finding the differences kind of games, or just a very well executed idea.

This game is a masterful peice of storytelling, and at the end of the game, whichever ending you got, you can only look back and blame yourself. Every choice is hard to make, between doing what you think is right verses what the government has told you to do. Either way you will be punished. That is why I nominated this game for the 'Villain most in need of a hug' award. There is no written villain in this game. Maybe you could call the government the villain, or the revolutionists, but truthfully, not matter how I play this game, I am the villain at the end of it. And as I sit there thinking about the choices that led me to this horrible ending, I definitely need a hug.

I wish I could write exactly how I feel about this game but it will never do it a fraction of justice. I will try too though, damn I love this game in every way.  You are just some person working a menial job, even at first it seems a little tedious (See below for a more positive note.) but you have a family to support and this is your day job. I work full time so an emulation of tedium isn't so appealing at first, why would I want to enter that World again?  It starts off easy but tedious, each day brings new difficulties and more tedium. What makes this game what it is in it's immersion. The characters you encounter make it what it is, the decisions you make shape the enter game itself. It brings about such minor decisions which can effect certain characters in major ways. Every decision you make will effect the ending and there are many endings. Do you stay loyal or do you rebel? Do you turn a cheek to help your family for own needs or be strict and let your family suffer? That five credit fine for a twenty credit bribe could make a lot of difference.  I know this game has been out for some time, has won a lot of awards and is most likely out of a lot of people's memories. But I'm writing this review for anyone sitting on the fence. Buy it! Even at full price, you won't regret it! The tedium and increased difficulty is overshadowed by an intricate multipathed storyline which will just cloud your judgement at every turn. There's some secrets to discover too.  Even if you try to be the nice guy, there's parts of it where you just want to be a ♥♥♥♥ the next time. This is one game with a lot of options and outcomes for your actions and each playthrough will never be the same.  Note: The main game play is never actually tedious, it's just a fun challenge which increases the difficulty with each day. Once you've got the hang of how it works the first few days are a gold mine. The best experiences are found in exploring the decisions you have made and exploring different options each time afterwards.  I have nothing negative to say about this game. I'm just glad it exist's and will thrust it upon any person who is looking for something to play.  tl;dr Buy and play this game!

Awesome Game!  I read about Papers Please in my favorite gaming mag and bought in on instant. The art style, the feel and everything in this game is fitting.  The game mechanic itself is pretty simple:  Your job is to control immigrants and people who just want to cross the border who want into your grand country of Astorka, you contorl their passports and special documents needed for beeing allowed into the country. That task gets tougher everday, because you have to earn money to pay your rent and provide for your family. And you only get enough money if you are fast and don't make mistakes at your job.   But tahts only half of it. Sometimes there are attacks on the border and opportunities to make a little extra money. On the other hand you are able to help people by letting them in or letting other people not in who are endangerin them. But your employer won't look kindly on that kind off behavior. And then their are the Rebells. Should you support them? what about your family. So many questions. The Game isn't new, but if you like a challange and the pixel look have a try, it's totaly worth it.
