Honestly the foresight of this game to be able to prepare us for what the 2016 American election brought us is outstanding. Border control has never been so fun! 10/10  The music is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing epic too.
Unique game that adequately engages the player into the story by the gameplay set player has to do. A must have if you like a story driven game through it's gameplay.

'Papers, Please' is an exceptionally well-crafted game that manages to entertain and challenge the player through a mixture of tedium and human drama. The game punishes you for lapses in concentration when processing travellers (that's when that rogue incorrect detail will get ya) but it can also reward you for being... well... less than rigid about enforcing the border policies of Arstotzka.   Anyway, I really think that the best way to know if you'll like this game is to play it, because it really is one of those 'marmite' things. If you appreciate playing something a little different every now and then, however, I really do recommend this. It has unique gameplay and graphics, and actually has an Idea behind it - one it manages to explore without making it feel like the gameplay is merely a vehicle for the idea (I think the two intermesh very well, personally).   Also, the sound in this game is excellent. The music, the sound of paper shuffling and stamps clicking....sounds odd but they really are very, very satisfying sounds!
Best 3$ ever spent on a summers sale. Highly recommended
Knew the game from Youtube, finally picked it up myself.  10/10 would deny entry again.  Glory to Arstotzka!

Papers, Please is probably the most captivating game I've played in years: sometimes I just wish I hadn't played it so I could experience it for the first time again. That's not such a big problem though, because it has a good replay value (there are multiple endings and challenges).  The atmosphere is terrific. I really enjoy 'cold war'-like settings, and this is probably the most immersive I've ever witnessed. The effort that's been put even in the minor character is mind blowing - it's amazing how much you can care or emphasize with them, given the peculiar gameplay :D  The gameplay itself is very fast-paced, you'll need to be focused. I enjoyed it a lot. I mean, I enjoyed this game so much, I can't even stress this enough. Highly recommended!

The passport checks are simple but highly addictive. But the real game are the decisions you have tto make. You can help strangers but risk having to pay a penalty which can mean one of your family members won't survive because you don't have the money for heat, food or medicine. Or you can follow the rules to the letter. Well other reviewers have already written about it, so I just want to add that it is a very original subject and the game is simple but has a lot of depth. Shows that you don't need great graphics, animations etc. to make a great game.
Simple game on the surface, but is in fact a deep chasm that tests your moral conscience.

If you ever wanted to know what it's like to have to sit in a booth and experience a gamified version of the banality of being a customs officer (and have it be fun), here's your chance. 'Papers, Please' is a sometimes maddening game of 'What Doesn't Belong' with some additional story elements of intrigue along with the joy of trying to survive as an underpaid, underappreciated border control agent. Once you get things down, the game changes them on you. In addition to some of the story elements, there's also a lightweight management element (personal money, time, family), and penalties (in the form of citations, which can cost you money, or game ends, which can send you to prison and other places).  The game becomes cathartic after you get into the rhythm of it, but you have to have an eye for catching differences and details, otherwise you'll find yourself prone to losing credits. Overall, a really fun game which manages to make something that nobody would think is fun into something fun.  Likes + Matching/Puzzling under pressure + Lightweight storylines + Lightweight personal management  Dislikes + Wish there was an endless mode without constrains ('catharsis mode' -- play endlessly to relax; no time limits, no points penalties, no instant death on failure. Still receive citations and have a score of number correct v. number incorrect) + Wish some story lines could be opted-out of.

If the argument is made that video games cannot be art, one need not look farther than Papers, Please for proof otherwise. This is a fantastic, artistic game. It drips with atmosphere, the music is grippingly threatening, characters are empathetic, and you truly feel overwhelmed with responsibility - do the 'right thing' by not accepting a bribe, or take the bribe in order to feed your family? It's the best kind of karma system, where your decisions have direct consequences, rather than an arbitrary 'good vs. evil' meter. If I had any complaint, it's that I wish there was no time limit during missions, if only so I could take my time; however, the time limit does add to the intensity and it forces you to make hasty decisions, so I cannot rightfully criticize the game for that. I highly recommend Papers, Please.

The part of me that likes playing games and seeing stories wants to replay this game. The part of me that has feelings and empathy doesn't. Papers, Please forces you to make tough choices. Do you let this refugee through the border with out of date documents in order to keep a family together? It might risk you getting fined for the mistake and not having enough money to feed your own child. Or worse, they might be a terrorist that will kill some border guards as soon as you let them through.  This game's success as a game relies on ita good writing. You never feel cheated by unforeseen circumstances because the people and circumstances feel authentic. Well worth a play through if you're willing to play at last once by truly putting yourself into the role.
Brilliant in concept and execution. One of the most novel and engrossing gaming experiences I've ever had. I highly recommend.

If you told me I'd really enjoy playing a game where you check passports to make sure they're valid before letting someone through a border, I'm not sure I'd have believed you. Having played Papers, Please, I can tell you that it's awesome. The game is so much fun and will make you laugh out loud at times, while also offering an enjoyable level of complexity and challenge as the game progresses. The visuals are good, the gameplay straightforward, and the length of the game perfect - not too long, not too short, and definitely worth re-playing to take the story in a different direction.  Highly recommended. Will certainly be gifting this to friends who don't have it.  Glory to Arstotzka.
8/10 solid game for the price

This game has a simple premise, collect papers, check papers for errors or discrepancies stamp the papers, return the papers, over and over again. At first, one might consider this a chore that could never be entertaining, but it is very fun and very enjoyable. The rules are always changing, so you have to remember slightly different rules every day. There are over 25 things that could make someone unable to pass the border, and YOU need to find each and every one of them. There are only several minutes to complete as many clients as possible, so time is of great concern. And since you are paid by the client, and you have a family to keep alive, time is even more pressing. This game will force you to think not only faster, but accurately, since every bad decision you make could kill your family. I would highly recommend this game... just don’t pay ten dollars for it, anything less than six is a fair price.

Never thought a game where you step into the shoes of a lowly bureaucrat could be this galvanizing. The story is gripping, and wrought with tension. The gameplay escalates in complexity but never gets frustrating. As the story progresses, the game keeps you on edge, lest you forget a rule! The decisions you take along the way test your moral tenacity. The atmosphere is claustrophobic, everything is set up perfectly to give you a feeling of being chained, both to your chair at the checkpost and to Arstotzka itself. The music is stately and the animation goes very well with the theme of the game.  It may take a while to get used to scrutinizing all the required details in the travel documents, especially in the later stages of the game, but it is definitely worth playing.

Glory to Arstotzka   With limitation comes innovation, this is how Indi games have boomed this generation, and with 'Papers, please' we see an inventive fresh take placing you in the seat of an immigration border inspector.  Set in the dystopian communist state of Arstotzka, after a six year war with the neighboring state of Kolechia just ending, and the borders just opened, your role is to work as border inspector controlling the flow of people entering Arstotzka.  Fortune has finally smiled on you as you finally will be able to provide for your family after winning the Oct '82 lottery, but this's no common lottery as you live in the communist state of Arstotzka, what the lottery grants you is a job in the government sector giving you a chance to provide for your wife, son, mother in law and uncle.  Every day you start your job with a great amount of pressure making you think 'how much money will I bring home tonight, will my family eat or sleep hungry tonight? Will they sleep in under a working heat system or will they sleep in the cold? As you start your day you will be presented with your rule book and daily policy update that will instruct on how to do your work properly and updating almost on a daily basis with every new permanent policy.  If you ever held a desk job interacting with customers you'll probably be able to relate to the game as they have captured that feeling of holding such a desk job whether it’s from the feeling you get as a new employee to a new job meeting new people and learning step by step how things work and getting familiar with your tools, colleagues and how to do the job.   Being a border inspector your work consist of granting or denying entry into the state of Arstotzka using two stamps, this is the main gameplay idea in nut shell moreover is knowing who should be granted entry and who should be denied. With the help of your rule book and daily update of policies you inspect the documentation of all travelers looking for discrepancies; if found the traveler shall be denied.   Your salary is calculated upon the work done; how many people were processed how many were denied and how many mistakes have you done as you will be penalized after a number of mistakes. By the end of every work day you get paid and have to face an impending dilemma of a short paycheck compared to a larger need. how will you divide your pay, is according to your families need per person; will little jimmy sleep hungry or sick tonight or is it your mother in law that shall bear the hunger. It’s up to you, No easy decisions are made here making it truly impacting your state of mind.  What makes the game mechanic more interesting is the moral dilemma it bombards you with, will you take a bribe to help your family survive another day by granting entry to a drug dealer to furthermore increase your income; or help a loving wife without the proper entry documentation unite with her husband and in the process getting penalized with a decrease in your income.  The aspect of progression in “Papers, please” is well refined and not just in terms of narrative, the game rewards you with items that you can hang on your wall making the booth feel more and more like your own office as you grow attached to it. The work polices also builds up with the game progression as well some recurring characters making you memories some of them if not all, what this aspect does is make you feel even more as part of the border and this dystopian world.  The game does something few other games in the industry does, which is establishing a mechanic, building on that mechanic so well making you feel you're playing a sequel to the game.  As you progress in the thirty day work period the plot widens with many paths to delve in and choices to make with moral impact affecting you, your family members and your country at large. I have found the moral impact at time so effectively applied I found myself thinking of what choice I should take meanwhile effecting the quality of my job as an inspector, this shows how well-crafted this games is and how much thought was put in stringing many aspects making it a great and well imagined product.  Something worth noting also is the saving system which is represented as a time line, giving you the flexibility of returning to any day of the month and picking up from there, this is worth noting since the game has 20 endings depending on your choices and paths taken, making it easy for you to see all endings  If you’re looking for a game with an innovative idea, engaging, involving experience, a well written narrative, fresh and on top of it on a budget price, I cannot urge you enough to at least try this game as its wonderful experience created with great care craftsmanship.   SCORE: 9/10

Oh man... This game...   Stressful and hilarious at the same time, its the dystopian border security simulator you never asked for!  Whats the matter? Dont want to be a border security guard? You won the labor lottery, congratulations! Now make sure you save your meager earnings so you can keep the heat on this winter.  Glory to Arstotzka!
a great little game!

One of the most atmospheric games I've ever played. The gloomy, oppressive mood of Arstotzka permeates through every single moment of the game. You always feel threatened by the government and every single decision you make through the game makes you feel so stressed because every decision may lead you (or your family) to end up in a gulag, or even worse, dead. In other words, this is a perfect 'life in North Korea' simulation. Definitely recommended.

A great game for those who pay a lot of attention to detail.  I've started a couple of games now and it seems like the same people come in every game, which means that to some extent you can learn who you should and shouldn't let through the border control post you are manning. The game also gets easier as you learn what you are looking for in the documents people are presenting you with - but then it also gets harder as you are given more and more documents to examine.  I've only reached one ending, but it appears that there are many different endings to the game depending on some of the decisions you make through the game.  It's definitely a game I would come back to and play again to see what different endings I can achieve.

Few jobs are more soul-sucking than sitting at a cramped desk and shuffling paperwork for hours on end. Now imagine doing that in an Eastern Bloc country during the height of the Cold War, with low pay, bleak conditions and the constant threat of being fired - or worse - if you screw up. Tedious, boring and stressful. Ideal subject matter for a video game, no? And yet Papers, Please is an unforgettable experience. It's been dubbed a 'paperwork simulator' - and that's not entirely inaccurate - but it's truly a game about freedom, power and how fleeting and illusory each can be.  An independent game designed by former Naughty Dog programmer Lucas Pope Papers, Please casts players as a border checkpoint officer in the fictional communist country of Arstotzka. Your job is simple, at least in concept: examine the documents of people who are trying to get into the country, and determine whether they're eligible for entry or should be turned away.  At first it's as easy as checking criteria like passport expiry dates, and rejecting paperwork that's invalid or forged. But before long, Papers, Please becomes a tension-filled juggling act. Every new day adds new rules to follow and new layers of complexity, and every time you let mess up, you lose the money you'd have earned for properly processing that batch of paperwork. To give the game a sense of grim consequence, your wages are tallied up at the end of each day, from which you must pay for rent, food, heat and medicine for your family. Despite the retro-flavoured visuals, the act of shuffling virtual papers is actually surprisingly tactile, and spotting a discrepancy and slamming the 'denied' stamp down on a person's passport imparts an odd thrill of power.  With a deluge of big-budget, high-profile games on the horizon, it might be easy to overlook a quiet, unusual game like Papers, Please. But don't do that, comrade. The consequences would be dire.
